author: LadyWolf
review: Amazing Game! Its Just like the franchise from 3DS but so much better! However, you can tell that it was pulled from a handheld gaming device.CAPCOME & STEAM PLS make the following fixes;Chat and friends are too complicated! Please simplify the system and add regional chat. If you want a good system as an example Warframe has the best in-game chat and friends system I have seenFIX RADIAL MENUS!!!!  I go to Radial Menu and set it the way I want it. Then I save it to the gear loadout. But once I go into a mission the Radial Menue resets its self! Even when I reequip the gear loadout! PLEASE make it so the Radial Menue saves separately from everything else and make sure it never changes unless it is edited by the player!Connection Issues ?! Getting kicked offline makes no sense when you are on a gaming desktop connected by ethernet cable. This is a 3DS problem that for no logical reason has transferred to the pc game. ALSO! Please give a warning if MHW or Steam is about to implement a hotfix or update.          Being in the middle of a hard fight with a team and then everyone disconnecting leaving you to fight the monster alone is the biggest disappointment of the game. Make an in-game customer support messaging system. I know getting messages from players can be overwhelming but some of the best games ever made had a way for players to communicate issues and give valuable input. MHW would greatly benefit from that and it would help players feel that in-game issues are being addressed.

author: sophistry
review: I played this game for endless hours on PS4, so I have a whole lot of experience with the game, in addition to the port. I figure people want to know what the game is like, but also about how it compares. I'll try to do that concisely.The Game:Monster Hunter is a challenging game that rewards teamwork, creative thinking re: item and environment use, caution, timing, and positioning. It has a vast amount of equipment you can make in armor and weapons of varying damage and element types, and a wide range of weapons with (IMO) some pretty cool, unusual mechanics. Most of those require parts from the monsters you'll be hunting, so if you're planning to acquire a range of stuff, you'll be killing a lot of monsters. This is why people will tell you that it's a grind: the crafting.Ideally you're playing the game because you want to hunt monsters, so for me it doesn't feel like much of a grind unless I'm getting screwed by RNG - sometimes the rare-drop gems are frustrating to acquire - but in most cases the game gives you alternate ways to acquire things you need (cultivating plant/insect products, using the Melder to buy gems or other parts with tickets or items you're not using).There are a TON of quality of life improvements in MH:W versus prior MH games. Being able to move (even sprint!) while using consumables, not having to forage for your whetstones or paintballs, being able to access your storage and all of your gear at camp on a mission, no loading screens between zones - sometimes it's the little things that bring the most joy. :)Visuals are somewhat subjective. I think MH:W is a very pretty game, but YMMV.The Port:EDIT: As of this review, the multiplayer connection problems seem to have been solved. Yay!EDIT2: You can now set private online sessions for Friends Only and actually have it work properly, and there's 21:9 support, double hooray! I prefer using the controller even for the port. I have friends who have made the switch to KB+M. This is probably just down to personal preference. AFAIK there's no raw mouse setting, but they did add additional control options for mouse that are supposed to come pretty close to more traditional mouse control for PC. YMMV.Conclusion: This is a competent port if what you want from the game is for the game to play in a manner equivalent to the PS4, with RADICALLY better load times (10, 15 seconds for me, not over a minute, like PS4!) and 60FPS, on a PC, on steam, with your friends.If what you want is for the game to play like most FPS games on PC, with character movement that doesn't feel like it does on console, then you may be disappointed. It's very Souls-esque in that way -- it still has that weighty, Monster Hunter feel, even on PC. It is not going to feel like it's built on the Source engine.

author: HellBlazer75
review: Mᴏɴꜱᴛᴇʀ Hᴜɴᴛᴇʀ: WᴏʀʟᴅMost console player knows how good monster hunter world is. As the pc version just released yesterday I played for like 2.5 hours though spent most of the time creating the character. So here's a short review of the game (PC VER.).ρՐԾՏ:• Pc port performance is quite good.• Incredibly deep and rewarding gameplay.• Beautiful and varied world with so much varieties.• Each monster is different and requires knowledge about the monster to actually beat it in the proper way this gives a feel of a boss fight every time.• Story is moderately good and engaging. • The dense wildlife sounds are so good and many monsters can be identified through their cries, footsteps, and other audio intels.• Combat is great controls might need some tweaking but it's great and weapon types and list is massive and diverse.• Tons of customization also character creation is quite good. • Environmental hazards are something you always have to be careful about as nature can ruin your day beside monsters.• Food cooked by cat chefs what more do you want man :pς๏ภร::• Troublesome design with forced online interactivity.• lip sync is totally crap.• Multiplayer matches can be fiddly to set up.• The new verticality of levels occasionally leads to frustrating AI pathing glitches.• Denuvo DRM I simply can never make myself to like it.• Some notable problems [Motion Blur Depth of Field Bloom/Glow Effects Mouse Acceleration] no way to turn them off needs fixing.• Might face problem with controllers.In the End this game is a must buy for playing coops because coop is the heart of this game. If you love jrpg just buy it. A tip **Try turning off volumetric rendering for a significant fps boost**.  Getting 60fps@Gtx 970 1080p  !!Totally RECOMMENDED!!

author: Gefo
review: Great game. Decent port. Launched with really bad network problems, that are now fixed.Having played many monster hunter games before this one, I have to say this is the most enjoyable one, and a great one to start at for new players. It adds a lot of quality of life improvements, without changing or ruining the core mechanics of the monster hunter franchise.If you buy this just to play the main story, and then never play it again, I have to say it's not worth your 60 bucks.This thrill of the franchise is to learn monster patterns, and improve your play against every monster, while collecting armor and weapon sets. This can't be done without grinding and replaying.

author: Anfifo
review: The bad (and reason for most downvotes):Classic problems at launch (connection mostly) but were mostly addressed or being addressed.Terrible port for now, needs really good machine for solid 60 fps, hopefully this will be addressed soon (for now u can use some mods to address fps drops)Some controls for Keyboard/Mouse feel weird so you're gonna have to costumise that and the mouse movement feels sluggish (there's been a response about having raw mouse input which would probably fix it)(So for now, I highly recommend playing with controller.)-------------The good (obvious personal opinion):- Some parts get really challenging, sometimes gives u that Souls-like boss experience where each "boss" has some different mechanics that you have to learn and counter to beat it.- Allows you to play coop with your friends but still have a great time alone or with randoms- Huge end game grinding- Detailed and varied skills and armours that allow u to make different kinds of builds- A lot of different weapons to choose from with completly different playstyles, making it so that there isnt one best weapons as the best weapon depends on the situation - making almost all weapons viable and useful.- Great community.- Good graphics.- Great overall gameplay

author: Corrective // Ratorma
review: The greatest Co-Op series in the last 14 years, and this one is a great step into modern graphics. Although the gameplay is 10/10, sadly the PC-port got some flaws that doesn't exist in the console version. The game looks great, even though it's always in low resolution textures. There's a few disconnection issues and we haven't gotten the new content that the console version already has (I'd think it's because they have to fix the framerate issues with the particle effects before they release Deviljho, Lunastra, Kulve Taroth and Behemoth). Gameplay is amazing and animations looks so satisfying with amazing monsters and a huge amount of puns! This game would've been 10/10 easily if not for the disconnection issues, framerate drops and slow dripping of content already released on other platforms. It's a must-buy and will continue to be the game of the year despite it's small flaws. 8/10 until they fix the PC-port.

author: NicyNish
review: When i first started this game, i complained how awful the controls are and how confusing this game is (i mean i'm still figuring things out and i know it seems ridiculous). Not to mention you start with the hardest but the strongest weapon there is, which is the great sword. It's super strong but super slow and hard to master, and there for not the best for new players in my opinion. I started to play A LOT better when i switched to switch axe, which is my favorite weapon to use even to this day.There is a lot to learn in this game, what weapon fits you the best and how to master it, how each and every monster moves, what items are good to keep and to use in the future because the game doesn't really tell you that, and then what armor pieces you wear because they all have their own unique "skill" that makes you faster in certain things etc. (GET ARMOR THAT HAS EARPLUGS! Monster roars wont stun you and you get free hits on them while they are at it ;) Literally my favorite thing in the whole game.I love the game, i love the monsters and they are all adorable, but i still complain about the hitboxes sometimes. You get stunned or hit even when it shouldn't.I do recommend this game but... it takes some time to learn ok. Don't get frustrated or give up!

author: Styrka
review: Its a great pick up! Don't believe the mixed review, those are mainly due to the initial period of the launch. The game is pretty solid, it has a good player base and quite friendly to new comers. Its a very grindy game, you Hunt, gather, craft gear, hunt new monsters, craft better gear and weapons to fight the next. Initially I thought repeating a cycle like that would get old pretty quickly, however the 14 weapon types choices allowed me to change things up every now and then. You can play can through this entire game solo should you wish, but I found that for a grindy game like this..playing coop with people was way more enjoyable. It doesn't matter if your don't have anyone to play with, since 90% of the time people are more than happy to lend a hand, especially those who are pass Hunter rank 100. Through playing a lot I saw a lot of familiar faces and ended up becoming friends with them as well, we'd hop on to do stupid things together like learning a completely new weapon mid quest and get wreck.

author: Panda
review: I've only played games of the MH series for a total of 2-3 hours before Monster Hunter: World, and I would say MHW is a great introduction to the series. While I do not have great knowledge of the previous MH games, I believe MHW has streamlined a lot of realtively tedious systems while reserving the main draw and spirit of the series. The loop of hunting>crafting>improving kept me entertained for 300 hours so far. There are 14 different weapons providing a wild variation of combat style for the player to master. The monsters themselves have a lot of character and each fight with them is like a date to get to know them better. You would get a great sense of complishment when you have finally handling a previously tough monster with grace and efficiency. New to the series is the seamless maps where there is no longer loadings between zones, so the exploration feels smoother and more absorbing.The UI and control will need to get into and they are far from perfect. I do suggest checking out some beginner's guide and video to help, but slowly adapting and improving is part of the journey and really not that difficult in the end. The port had problems when it first launched but improvements have been made constantly in the following months. Connection problems have also been vastly improved. And these had been reasons to the majority of the early negative reviews.I've only started playing with other players online after like 250 hours of solo play, and I do agree that multiplayer does add another layer of fun to it. But it is definitely not an "only fun with friends" game.Bottom line, it is a modern iteration of a beloved series packed full of content well worth the price, can be enjoyed by fans of the series or newcomers alike. Norminating it for Steam GOTY 2018.

author: Sting
review: To start this i should say i never played any other MH.So, at first when it released i was REALLY skeptical beacause the game seems like a boring grindfest with cool graphics and a lot of bugs. ALOT.Well i waited like 3 months to see if a promo would come and it did so i get the game and tought to myself, well it was cheap if i can put something like 10hours and enjoy it would be worth it.Ok first impression with actually playing was "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ this combat is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome" (Bow)I got instantly hooked, and discovered the game is way more deeper than i tought, every monster is a differente battle and the story is cool too.The looks of the game are REALLY good, almost every weapon as a unique look and a unique feel to it.Better yet you can play as you want even in the endgame, you dont NEED to follow the meta, you can just enjoy the wep that suits you.Now the grinding, ofc it has the grinding its almost impossible to not have, but it is worth it? I would say yes, cause everytime you capture/slay a monster you DO get better, you DO know more about the monster and the feel of accomplishment grows as you progress your character.Anyway, the grapichs are kinda blocky sometimes and the game still not fully polished (I have a high end spec and sometimes it drops to 40fps)It has some little bugs (nothing game breaking atleast for me)My final review isStory - 7/10Graphics - 8/10 (at everything at MAX)Gameplay - 10/10Sound(Music) - 10/10Fun - 11/10I would say the price is okay, isnt that expensive, but it does get cheaper so if you still dont know wait up and buy on sale.

author: Caitlyssa. ♥
review: To clarify, I have enjoyed every title I played in the Monster Hunter series, and World is no exception, I would like to discuss why more people should experience these series. Also... this is my first ever review, so please don't judge too harshly.Despite acquiring over 1300 hours in the game at the point of me writing this review, I must admit I was a late comer. I did not start playing Monster Hunter: World until Summer of 2019 therefore I cannot speak about anything that happened before then. I have been playing the game on and off for the past year and there are things I would like to see in game going forward which I am eager to share with you here; however in my humble opinion majority of the experience this game has to offer is indeed good.So... Monster Hunter: World. In this game you take the role of a hunter, your main objective is to kill or trap monsters that inhabit the various areas of the world. You can then use the materials to craft equipment and upgrade it. The story revolves around The Research Commission's Fifth Fleet and the challenges they must brave in the New World.So what are some of the things that I like about this game? Right of the bat as you enter the game for the first time, you are greeted with a delightfully detailed yet easy to use character creator. The face, skin tones, make up, all of the menus were easy to navigate through. I was in fact able to create a character that actually bares a striking resemblance to myself in real life despite having less customisation options than we have now. I am sure that most would agree that it is much easier to immerse yourself in a world when you are pleased with how your character turned out. Mentioning the world above brings me onto my next point. Despite being someone who enjoys large, continuous worlds to explore; I still had no issues with area sizes in this game. In fact; I think the areas on the map (though not joined together) have enough variety to keep you engaged all the time. With the addition of Guiding Lands in Iceborne DLC it has only got better. You discover a whole variety of things from monster tracks and endemic life, to conversing with natives of the land such as Grimalkynes and Gajalaka. Aside from quests, you can hunt monsters in expeditions too, each area spawns different monsters which live in that particular habitat. Other things you are able to do in any of those areas include but aren't limited to: Fishing, gathering, collecting rare materials and conducting general studies of flora and fauna via researchers that spawn within the area. You are a part of the Research Commission after all. All materials that you acquire can be used to craft and improve equipment, making you more efficient on hunts. The next point is of course: Equipment! There are fourteen weapon types you can use. Melee weapons such as Sword and Shield, Greatsword, Lance and others, as well as ranged weapons such as Light and Heavy Bowguns and Bows. Weapons of increased rarity that you craft have higher amounts of customisation options that impact their stats and usability. As well as having basic weapons, you also have elemental weapons; all of which now after release of Iceborne DLC have a huge abundance of customisation options to choose from. Prior to the DLC I must admit the choice was rather average for weapons. Armours in this game also have a large variety and are also highly customisable. The addition of layered armours that can be equipped over existing armours without removing your desired skills granted by your current set can not only make your hunter deadly in combat but stylish too, because no matter what you do, you must look good doing it! There are more then plenty customisation options here to make your hunter stand out from the crowd! So go wild! So what about quests? Questing in this game can be done solo or with 1, 2 or 3 other hunters online. Quests are divided into assigned (or story) quests, optional quests, investigations, event quests and special assignments. Investigations are great for gathering materials and going for achievements. Event quests allow you to get your hands on certain unique items that are only available during certain events. Special assignments are used for collaboration quests and assignments with unique rewards. In my opinion questing in this game is extremely fun as well as rewarding! The reward system is based on RNG. Higher reward level quests have increased chances of dropping unique and valuable items. The other types of quests available are siege quests. Such as Kulve Taroth and Iceborne DLC Safi'jiiva. Siege quests are extremely fun and rewarding also; however the one issue I have ran into with the siege quests is it can take a very long time to get the items you desire. Siege quests take a much longer time to complete than normal quests; and with RNG loot system you might need to do a lot of runs before getting what you want causing the whole experience to feel like a bit of a chore. Even though this issue has been more or less resolved in Iceborne with Safi'jiiva... memories still remain with me, and possibly others. Let's talk a little bit about what I would like to see in future patches. Again this is my personal opinion. The one huge issue for me personally: I don't feel enough monsters from previous titles have made a return in the New World sadly. Don't get me wrong, it was amazing for me to see Zinogre, Brachydios and Rajang! However I was really hoping to see all members of The Fated Four in the New World. I am praying for the day we could see Gammoth, Astalos and Mizutsune grace us with their presence. We already have Glavenus from The Fated Four, please let us have the others too. I understand there were issues with some skeletons, and I pray that they will be resolved. Besides that, I feel they should put in more monsters from the Frontier series as majority of people were unable to experience them due to Frontier being Japan exclusive. Personally I would have loved to experience monsters like Orugaron, Shantien, Hyujikiki, Anorupatisu and many others.Overall Monster Hunter: World is a great game that I would recommend to anyone looking for a fun and unique experience be it solo or with friends. Addition of Iceborne DLC has made the game nothing shy of amazing and I hope they continue to surprise and impress. Kind regards, ♥

author: Jack
review: Do you enjoy endless grinding?Do you enjoy fiddlestick mechanics?Do you love broken muiltiplayer?Then by all means, Welcome to Monster Hunter: World.This game has been advertised as a Multiplayer game, and yes it is.But forget playing the main story with friends, that won't happen. The player hosting the hunt has to finish all the cut scenes in that hunt,after that you can join them through a SOS flare. And that's if the steamonline server decides not to kick you offline. Should you manage to join a online session, pray to the networking gods that steam does not decide to kick you. From testing it's not from lack of bandwidth.It also seems like the password protection you can enable for sessions is broken,as I've had players other than my friends (who had the password) join my session.The multiplayer interaction is also very limited, other players are not allowed in your"town session" and multiplayer interaction is strictly limited to the common area orto the hunts. The PC-control scheme is awful, It's pretty much unplayable unless you rebind half the keys.For example, if you want to un-sheathe your weapon you just attack (or press CTRL). IF you want to sheathe the weapon you press SHIFT, which also happens to be the run button. No, you can't run with your weapon out, you can still dodge. If you need to heal, hold Q and then press either the left or right button on you mouse (which are your attack buttons). You can of course scroll as well, as long as you are not using a ranged weapon, then you're stuck with the left or right button. Or you could put stuff on your quick access menu buttons F1-F4 and then use an item with button 1-5. Also pretty much every item you use has a casting time with a animation lock that can not be interrupted (we will cover this later).The menu system is bad even for a console port. If you want to use the menu, you can't do anything else at all while using it. The key binds for menues and the game overall are very questionable. Everything feels very clunky and slow. Being a fast paced game, this is not how it should be.That was most the technical stuff, let's cover the actual gameplay elements. I don't know where to start really.. Let's begin with the weapon choices. MH:W has a lot of weapons to offer, but don't worry.You will probably only be using about 4 or 5 of them. All the weapons have different combosthat will be displayed when visiting the training area, memorize them, because this is the only time they are shown. Many of the weapons are slow and unwieldy and each animation HAS to finished (aka animation lock). If you are mid swing and a monster charges you, you will get hit and possibly oneshotted. After a while, battling horrible animation locks and Son of a monkey mechanics you switch to a faster weapon.The problem being then that the overall weapon balance in this game is non existing. Sure, your shiny new weapon might be faster but it does Poo on a stick damage to the mobs you are fighting. Sure, each weapon can be upgraded via killing monsters and harvesting their parts, once you have found all the bodyparts required you can create either a higher tier weapon or something completely different that uses the previous weapon as a base. But even then, the balance is abysmal.Sure, you can craft a water aspected light bowgun to fight that fire aspected monster. But you will probably have a horrible time killing it compared to using a bow or a sword and shield. Imo light bowgun is one of the weakest weapons in the game unless you can fasttrack it to higher tiers after having farmed bodyparts from monsters using other weapons first. Which brings us into the combat section.Combat in this game is CLUNKY, and not in a good way. It's un-intuitive, riddled with bugs, poor design choices and really really bad animation locks. For example, you run into combat, heave your buster sword off your back and swing at the... oh the monster moved? No problem, I'll just wait for the animation lock and... tail to the face. No problem, I'll just get back up and... the monster is devouring me.The animation locks in this game are ridiculous, when you attack, you commit yourself up to 2 seconds, during which you have no control over your character. If you happen to get hit during this animation you might take "reduced damage". This is the way the game compensates for you not being able to dodge something that should be completely dodgeable. Another problem that arises when you employ this heavy of a animation block is that combo attacks with faster weapons pretty much locks you out of combat at times. You will continue in a straight line no matter where you point the camera. The direction of your character dictates which way you will attack. At times it feels like I'm driving a freight train instead of controlling a supposedly very agile badass monsterhunter. But surely the enemies must have to follow the same rules? Nope, they do what ever they like, when ever they like to. For example, they can stop mid attack and just swing at you. Or they can charge you, run you over and stun you. Turn around and do the same thing over and over until you are dead without you being able to do anything about it. Some enemies have attacks with hitboxes larger than they themselves are, attacks that should not have hit you most of the time to. This results in you getting punted all over for about 2-6 seconds and loosing a lot of HP in the process. Trying to dodge anything in this game is more luck than it is skill, sure, there are some hardcore players out there (mostly former MH players) who will strongly disagree with my review. You are welcome to do so. But I find the combat in this game below all criticism, this should be where the game shines but instead it out right kills the game for me personally. It seems to me they focused more on making this game look pretty and making the food look delicious.There are a lot of questionable design choices in this game, enough to make me not want to play this game any more.It saddens me, but this game could have been epic, as it is now (half a year after first release) it's riddled with bugs, the menu system is equal to a console port back in 2002 and the overall gameplay is cabbage. (if you made it this far, please keep reading)As Qeenie would have said "But Jack, don't you have anything nice to say about this game?"Sure, I do.The game is extremely pretty. The character customization is fantastic, the fact that you get to design your Palico (cat) is wonderful. The animation quality is extremely good. The cut scenes have been crafted with love. But unfortunately these things do not out-weigh the fact that the rest of the game is bad. I tried, I really did. But after having tried and putting up with all the tartar sauce this game throws at you, I decided to uninstall it and leave it in my steam collection to gather virtual dust for now.Please do keep in mind that these are my personal thoughts and opinions about the game and should be viewed as  such. If you feel like picking up the game and trying it out, please do so. You might have a blast, you might have a Jumpin’ Jehoshaphat time. Who knows?

author: Mors
review: This game has surprisingly become a GOTY for me. I have played MH 3 in the past and didn't quite get it, but MHW completely swallowed me and left no chance for other games at the time.Yes, it has some minor bugs related to the connectivity in multiplayer, such as people not connecting to my SOS signals, but I still can join online quests myself and respond to any SOS that has been posted by others. Steam friends can easily join my session or quests aswell. That is why I don't think that is so much of a deal.The hunts seem repetitive at start, but completely change from the mid-game on with the bosses possesing a new set of moves and phases, making almost every fight an interesting challange.With the diversity of crafting recipes and ways to go around many mehcanics it's hard to get bored of exploring and collecting stuff ingame. (That feel, when you go to the scariest location to get soem honey)And last but not least - multiplayer. Coop hunts and investigations with my friends were something that in my list became better than the summons in Dark Souls universe. The thrill of fighting a strong enemy together, awesome teamwork and the excitement after you finally get your reward is beyond all limits. TL:DRI highly recommend this game to anyone familiar with slashers or (cough) dark-souls-style games. I'll be sorry for that, but to people not knowing the MH series I'd call MHW a child of Warframe and DS. Vote MH!

author: Professor
review: It's an excellent game with engaging mechanics ruined by a lazy port that constantly reminds you this was a console game and a questionable company that constantly reminds you this was a console game. CAPCOM has decided the content release schedule for PC will be several months behind consoles and some content will never come to PC. Given the initial release problems with the PC port, this made sense, but continuing this pattern into the Iceborne expansion does not. This was a great time to synchronize the release schedules and CAPCOM chose not to. Thus, I cannot recommend this product, despite it being a great game.

author: 10shi
review: It's hard to praise Monster Hunter: World in a way that doesn't simply praise the Monster Hunter franchise as a whole. The core concept remains untouched and that contributes heavily to Monster Hunter: World's success as a game. Gorgeous art direction combined with fun and flashy combat alone will have you sinking hours into this game. What separates World from its predecessors is how polished it is. The single-map areas, the fluid movement, the streamlined user interface, all of these improvements minimize the previous games' constant reminders that you're playing a game. The immersion factor in this game is second to few (I recommend turning off certain GUI elements such as damage indicators to improve this effect further). However, streamlining inevitably shaves off layers of depth to the game, and this is the most damning criticism of Monster Hunter: World. Longtime fans of the franchise might be turned off from playing the game entirely, but I personally find that it's easy to go back and forth between World and older games without feeling like one experience is a downgrade of the other. Some changes are welcome, such as the improved armor skill system, which makes a lot more sense and allows for greater flexibility with how armor is used. Others feel unnecessary simplifications, such as simplified crafting recipes, as keeping the old recipes would have put an even greater focus on using your environment, which is one of the main points of the game; I feel like that was a missed opportunity more than anything.All in all, I think Monster Hunter: World is well worth putting time into despite how different it might feel from the earlier games. What World proves is that Monster Hunter belongs in a large-scale format. The games deserve a massive scale to highlight what makes them so good.

author: Colapops
review: After a shaky start thanks to server weirdness, the game is finally in its stable and steady state. Some people still have problems with connecting and staying connected to friends for multiplayer (arguably the focus of the series), but I haven't experienced anything of the sort.Monster Hunter as a series has always been a little tedious and this game cuts out a great deal of that. This whole game, while still Monster Hunter at its core, greatly streamlines the experience without losing any of the appeal. It axes a lot of the grind for materials through various ways without removing the fun of tackling monsters to get the equipment you need to fight more monsters.Probably the biggest drawback to the game is the... let's call it the Japanese UI. For whatever reason, user-friendly and workable UIs don't seem to be the strongpoint of most Japanese developers. While I am totally used to this thanks to old Monster Hunter titles, Souls titles, etc. friends new to the series have expressed very valid criticsm of the way the game handles menus, information presentation, and controls. This also affects multiplayer connectivity in an obtuse way since it can be a hassle to get through the menus.Probably the biggest crime the game suffers from is first-title syndrome. Monster Hunter games have fallen into a pattern where the first game in a new generation is essentially a barebones version of what will come next. If the pattern follows, we will get something like Monster Hunter World: Ultimate which will include much more content in the form of monsters, equipment, locales, and maybe even new mechanics (bring back playing as a palico!!!). It isn't even necessarily the case that Monster Hunter World in its current form lacks content, but that people experienced with the series and familiar with the gameplay will be able to blaze through all of the hunts without much issue. Almost nothing has changed with old monster behavior while the new monsters--though cool--are not exactly breaking the mold.This is a wonderful game that will give you a ton of fun despite its relatively minor flaws, but hopefully this title is greatly expanded upon in its current form, rather than re-released with new things packaged in as older titles in the Monster Hunter franchise have been.buy it or you're as dumb as a gargwa

author: nananana BATMAN!!
review: Well if you want the summary, Monster Hunter: World isn't for the people who don't like grinding in video games. While I am being one of those people who does not enjoy grinding, I still enjoyed this game most of the time, just don't expect that this game will change your view about the grinding, that's what I thought as well. While saying all that, this games' grind is not a necessity it is just a tool to feel better. For the people who don't want to do the same thing over and over again, I rate this game 6/10. Now for the ones that know the drill, this game is pretty good. It is still not perfect but it is a good game to spend your time on, at least when you compare it with most of the MMOs out there. It is still far from perfect the hitboxes are a bit off, the story is dull, the monster you're trying to catch is running away every 4 minutes is frustrating and spamming the same attacks is real. The way I complain feels like this game is hard and unbalanced right? Sadly it is but not cuz of those reasons, it is cuz the difficulty doesn't change whatever you do. I have a friend that has double game time compared to mine and if we die we both die whatever he is prepared for this specific fight or not, cuz it is not balanced good enough to respond your preparation. For me personally, this is not the worst thing but the grind in this game is not necessary it is just there. At the start game challenges you and you feel like you should grind to get better gear so you don't die as much but that challenge is only there for the first few quests after that game creates an illusion that you should grind but you don't have to. In my 50+ game hour, I changed my armor only 3 times and when you understand that the game is not challenging you enough to get better gear, it starts to feel a bit dull, you just kill the new monster and move on to the next one without hype or excitement just to reach end game.It is very good for its genre, but it is just good at best for general consumers/10

author: What Could This Be?
review: Edit: Iceborne fixed a lot of gripes I had with the game however sieges still suck, atleast safi is somewhat enjoyable. Clutch claw is honestly the worst mechanic they've added to the franchise, the monsters still run on MHW AI which is honestly a joke. however a lot of the fights are still enjoyable, Alatreon is straight up the best fight in the game (maybe even the franchise) and the game will guarantee you atleast 300-1000 hours of playtime, so I changed my score.First things first, I absolutely love this game. Fun gameplay but I love the franchise so that's a given, nice gameplay, beautiful locales and the monsters look amazing and alive.Now for the reason why I don't recommend this game. it is due to one very small detail they put into how they deal with event quests.They're timegated on real dates. It is just really demotivating to be unable to access parts of the content just because you aren't able to play when capcom wants you to play their game. I don't hate it when you force me to play online. I just really hate it when I feel like I miss stuff just because I either didn't feel like playing or was too busy to play.

author: Gabe
review: There's no way I'm not recommending MHW on PC, with that said, the port is far from perfect. Here's a few reasons why:- Doesn't run great, despite running on a 10 year old engine and not offering a significant enough improvement over the (far less powerful) console versions. - Poor scalability. Other than the volume rendering setting, you're lucky if you're able to squeeze 15fps going from Highest to Low. On the plus side, this means the game will look relatively similar across the board, but seeing as how PC is all about offering as many options as possible, I think the bad outweighs the good in this case. - Low resolution textures and character shadows across the board. The game looks washed out, same as the console versions, you can fix that by disabling the volumetric fog but I'm not sure it's worth the compromise. - No Dualshock 4 support or button prompts. I've seen far more modest games supporting this feature, so it's a mystery to me why Capcom chose to not include it here. - Mouse and Keyboard controls are serviceable, but not great. Same as Yakuza 0, a controller is pretty much required if you want to get the most out of this game. It's better than the console versions, but not by much. Pound for pound, I feel like the console version is able to achieve more with considerably less, so good luck running this at console quality visuals on a 400$ (price of a PS4 Pro) PC. I feel like they could've done a lot more with this port, but I'm still gonna recommend it simply because you can technically push the visuals/performance further if you have the hardware for it. Just don't expect to do so on anything under 800$.Edit: It does support my Dualshock 4, it just doesn't recognize it as a Dualshock 4. It thinks it's an Xbox One controller, so no touch pad support or DS4 button prompts. But it does work.

author: Zaeroso
review: Overall rating: 8.5/10Reasons for all the thumbs down are:1. Ultrawide is NOT supported (I was really annoyed with this)2. People are crashing on loading up the game (I never experienced this with my i7-8700k & GTX 1080ti)3. The Xbox One controller isn't fully supported.4. The performance on this game is a joke (Overclocked GTX 1080ti just hits a stable 60fps on 1440p)5. The aggravating way you CANNOT skip cutscenes.6. In my opinion this game looks way worse than I expected. There are a lot of reasons for this game though such as:1. It's completely unique to anything on the market right now or even in development. 2. The thrill of defeating a large mosnter. You cannot defeat a boss in just 1 minute by glitching it, you have to stick to a 10 minute + fight hitting weakspots.3. Diverse range of weapons for every play style.4. Vast upgrading system for weapons and armour development throughout the game.There are many more reasons, if you have a decent PC and a fat wallet then try this game. There is a certain constant GRIND for pretty much every second in the game but if you don't like it then just refund it :)I highly recommend this game!

author: Rai
review: Monster Hunter, a series that I grew up with, that I've sunk thousands (plural) of hours into, and a series that I'll always love and respect, on PC. A dream come true at last. Add on to that the fact that this is the most welcoming Monster Hunter game of the series, and you've got this whole package.Now, let's get to the bad first, which is probably the main reason you're looking at reviews.As of today, 8/13, this port has a multitude of issues, mostly in Multiplayer. Fortunately, this game has a wonderful community with temporary fixes galore. The first being adding the following into your STEAM launcher options:-nofriendsui -udpYour "Target" should look similar to this:"C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\Steam.exe" -nofriendsui -udpThis has fixed 99.9% of the multiplayer issues for me. However, that's not all the issues:-FPS issues, genrally fixed by turning Volumetric Rendering to OFF.-Heavy dips in certain fights and with lightning weapons, I believe caused by particle effects rendering separately instead of one entity.-Save corruption (as reported by a miniscule amount of people), caused by crashing during a save sequence.-The default keyboard controls are absolutely atrocious. You will NEED to rebind these if you plan on using KBM.-There are some issues with latest nVidia drivers (again, as of this writing), and you'll need to use old drivers.-This game features LESS monsters overall than other titles in the series.However, the game has plenty of pros as well:+This game is the most welcoming and smallest learning curve of ANY Monster Hunter game in the series.+The game is gorgeous. Hands down, the game is beautiful.+The game is a blast with friends!+The game has Poogie!+The weapons are diverse with deep skill ceilings for each of them.+The combat is engaging and fun.+Literally infinite playability!Monster Hunter is a series known to receive a plethorea of free updates over each title's lifetime. That speaks for itself!Overall, I'm thrilled Monster Hunter is finally on PC. If this is your first time treading the waters, expect to face off against some Monsters that will challenge your patience. Some of the fights are fierce and unforgiving. Others are far more easy on you, letting you ease your way up. The community is immaculate, and one of the best communities I've ever experienced in any game series.If you have any interest at all, even a small amount, I strongly recommend picking it up for at least the first major hunt. That'll leave your playtime under 2 hours. If you decide this isn't the right game for you, you can return it at that point.Overall, I'd give the game a solid 8/10. Minus two points for some admittedly severe port issues. Capcom has acknowledged these issues and is already working on a fix.Bottom line, this game is phenomenal. I'll be sinking several hundreds of hours into this game as I have the prior titles. Now if you'll excuse me, I need more jewels!

author: Hlebka
review: One of the most frustrating games I've ever played, even harder than all the soulsborne series I've played when reached master rank, if you are trying to solo. But the reward of learning this game is like nothing else: satisfying, highly coordinated and refreshing combats especially with one or three other friends while having countless play style and build options in end game. It's really fun to learn to recognise the signs the monsters give before attacking. Once you know all attacks before they happen, you can easily dodge and hit the monster between the attacks.Also, LS is the best weapon.

With this new patch, I rarely got network error again when playing co-op. I hope the developer continue to improve this game. Thank you for listening to MWH PC players, CAPCOM!

author: Neo_Bahamut_19
review: People waited MONTHS for this game to release on PC. The network issues occurred on console during its launch. The fact that you didn't plan for this and it's going on during the PC launch months later is abysmal.Update 2020: This is still happening, be ready to experience random disconnects at any time. Not everyone has a mother paying for their rig, so not everyone can afford to replace their CPU because some company decided to put a crap-tier DRM in their game. This isn't affecting my i7-5820k, but it is affecting people with decent enough CPUs they shouldn't be having issues. Browsing the forums will reveal multiple threads of people with mid-tier CPUs (i5s) having issues.Update 2020: Game performance is a lot better on at least my rig, so if you quit out for performance reasons alone, maybe now you can give it a try. The controls for keyboard/mouse are so "consolized" that they ruin the flow if you want to use the native input for PC. Simple things that could have been addressed regarding this were not. I've spent the last hour ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with them only to get them to the point of being "servicable". There are so many double-bound controls in here it's unreal, not allowing people to split off or overlap controls on keyboard/mouse is moronic at best and ignorant to the platform at worst. Why can't I have Sneak on Ctrl and Dodge on Space Bar, why do I have to have both on both to accomplish a facsimile of this?Update 2020: They've tried to address some of the issues, but most of the issues (double-bound controls) still remain. Some common multi-input commands have been changed to allow you to bind a single key for them. In addition to the controls being abysmal, the entire UI was ported over as-is. What this means is tedious processes for inventory management and the like if you're using a keyboard/mouse. Most ported games attempt to at least address this in some manner. You might as well have a controller sitting by on-hand ready to go if you want to sort through your inventory, it'll be faster. Proper PC settings such as FOV sliders were left out for unknown reasons. Lacking a FOV slider has genuinely made me motion-sick. Setting the camera to the "far" distance helps some, but that gained a, what, in-game 2 feet follow distance or something? It's broken. End point. If two people are on the same assigned quest, both have to finish the cutscene separately, and then one has to leave their game to join the other. Given some missions have multiple cutscenes and leave only a fraction of the mission at the end for co-op, it's embarrasing. This is crap that was handled better 10 years ago, literally, other people have cited Borderlands as a perfect example. Not to mention how many loops you have to go through just to play with your friends without having randoms join your session. I can set it to private, but then I HAVE to copy a code and send it to a friend so they can join, and simply inviting friends through Steam doesn't work either if it's set to Private. This is ludacrous, this is stuff that has been resolved in damn near every other PC game since the late 2000's. This is what I'd call a "wiki game". Why? Because only about half of the mechanics, at best, are described in game. The rest you have to find out by either reading a fan-created Wiki page, watching a YouTube video, or reading the forums. The game will not guide you to certain key mechanics or explain fully what certain things do. This goes from weapons, to gadgets, to quest mechanics. Be prepared to constantly be alt-tabbing out of the game to figure stuff out, which is why so much of the playerbase doesn't know what they're doing or quit on the game. This is largely a byproduct of Japanese game design, as many of the studios over there (From Soft, Square Enix, Konami, etc.) are known to leave massive amounts of information out of their game, information about core mechanics.Lastly, stop trolling your fans and people who are new to the franchise and experiencing it for the first time ever on PC. For ♥♥♥♥s sakes, you have a "trololo" sub-forum and have been downright dismissive of legitimate complaints, bug reports, and serious glaring issues that have been brought to your attention.The sad part is that a good few of the issues were prevalent during the console release and were never addressed. Typically when a game waits for months after console release to come to PC, such as FFXV, it'll arrive with a slew of fixes and tweaks that weren't implemented at the launch of the console version as well as additional adjustments to fit the platform, justfying the full launch price. Sadly, not only does this PC port suffer from ALL of the console issues, but it actually (somehow, magically), managed to suffer from even more issues.I will still continue to play the game, but to anyone else who asks if they should buy, I'll say "not now, maybe in the future if Capcom gets their act together."

author: spineduke
review: After a 10 year + hiatus of MH, I'm finally back.It's hard to explain how excited I am for this game - my last encounter was on the PSP and I remember distinctly how we dreamed for a MH game with a bigger scope and budget. Ten years later, and World is Capcom's first serious foray into "HD" territory and with it come new challenges and new promise.For a newcomer, World is both welcoming and intimidating - the variety and depth of systems are relentless, but thankfully, the game is ready and willing to break it all down and teach to those who are willing to learn. The game is centered around hunting beasts and crafting armor and weapons, a never-ending cycle of hunts and accumulating power.The game takes place across several hunting grounds, all richly diverse and beautiful - each locale feels alive and rife with history and experience. Ancient trees reach to the very tops of the forest and you find yourself crossing through tree canopies, streams and twisting caverns. The game's features a believable and logical ecosystem, with predator and prey. Mosquitoes swarm the rivers at night, mushrooms grow in cool humid places, raptors lurk around where omnivores come to feed. The game is wonderfully vertical and you'll eventually realize how many things you missed the first time round because you simply didn't look above you. Grappling hook opportunities are plenty abound and you'll find yourself swinging and launching yourself from vantage point to the next like a ninja. Shortcuts and secret areas will eventually present themselves to you, perhaps through your own discovery. Reward is there to those who seek it.Hunts are executed with planning and on the fly thinking - as you battle your prey across the map, you'll find vantage points to leap upon them, trees they can be lured into, even paralyzing frogs that can be tricked into running into. The fluidity and variety of scenarios that the same hunt can be present is something that MHW can be proud of. The weapon roster is incredible - with over 15 years of refining and experience, Capcom have mastered the variety of playstyles to offer - each weapon comes with its own ebb and flow. Many are easy to learn but have a mastery that only comes from ones own experience - there are no level-up tricks here. A better sword does not make for a better technique. With time, you find yourself maximizing every window of opportunity, dodging every attack and creating a battle flow that shuts down the prey before they can do anything about it. There's a world of difference between the first hunt and the 300th you do with a weapon. The game knows this, and encourages it - arenas exist where speedruns are tested and hunters are expected to use every hunting trick they know.The quality of life changes are very welcome as well - load times are almost non-existent, menu interactions are streamlined, gathering and many small interactions have been sped up, in order to make sure you spend less time prepping and more time hunting. The hub area has a variety of systems that you can level up and research, allowing you access to a garden where you can grow your own supplies, and an expedition hub where you can foster and train palico cats to go on their own hunts.There's so much more to talk about, but MHW is one of general excitement - on the technical side, there are shortcomings (CPU/GPU performance needs optimizing, networking is unstable) but this will most likely change with time. This is Capcoms baby, and they know if they give the PC version the love it deserves, the community will give back ten times over.See you on the hunting grounds!

author: Walrus-Sama
review: Okay, so I would like to first point out that this is the first Monster Hunter game I've played. I did know about the series and had interest but never got around to playing it until now. So if you haven't guessed Monster Hunter revolves around hunting Monsters (well, yeah). The gameplay loop is; track monster > find monster > fight monster > defeat monster (slay or capture) > use parts dropped by monster to create better gear > repeat. That's the core of the game pretty much. May seem repetative on paper but the game has enough depth and variety to feel fresh throughout.   Combat is very 'weighty' and at first may feel a bit clunky, but it's not really once you get used too it. So it kinda like Dark Souls in that regard. There are 14 weapon classes to choose from, depending on what type of playstyle you want, all are viable. So the game is decently balanced as far as gear goes, can use what you want. The game's power/progression is tied to your gear, not your characters stats or whatever, so you can easily switch to a different weapon type/armor if you want (though you will need the resources to make/upgrade them).The Monsters are pretty well designed and every one of them feels like a boss fight. Some monsters may look like others but they all have unique traits so they do feel different enough. They all have their own personalities and quirks. Monsters do have varying tiers of difficulty which is usually represented by the mission rank.The game does have multiplayer and co-op is very fun. Having a team usually helps in dealing with difficult monsters and playing with others just feels overall better than playing alone. Everyone also gets their own rewards (except from mission reward money, which is split between players). The game is also balanced enough that a lvl 100 Veteran joining a lvl 1's game to help doesn't feel too overpowered, it's less about gear and more about experience and game knowledge. More experienced players generally being more helpful but even a lvl 1 dude still plays their part in a fight. So co-op's good.As for the ports performance, it's pretty good. 60 fps everywhere (there is a mild fps dip when manually saving and loading screens but that's to be expected I guess).  Only real negatives I can think of is their are a few very noticable low res textures here and there, though the game does look pretty good overall. There is a free HD texture pack dlc thing but the spec requirements seem awfully high for such a minor improvement, so I don't think the HD dlc is worth it (I could be wrong). Though it's free so whatever. The other negative would be NPC voices, lip syncing is very noticable not synced to the English voices (And I'm guessing most other langauges), and not all lines are actually voiced (speaking to NPC's in the hub world area usually has them just mutter a short generic voiced line while most of the info is just in written text that you scroll through).I can personally overlook these flaws as gameplay is solid, but some people may be bothered by these.Overall, the game is pretty solid, good gameplay, good progression, fun and balanced co-op, Monsters are cool. Game has a few flaws, but nothing is perfect.Very good game, would recommend.

author: Panda
review: Good game, a few port issues. Has full mouse and keyboard support, also works with XB1 and PS4 pads, just activate them in Steam settings. Decent performance, around 120fps at 1440p with a 1080ti and i5 8400, you will need to turn down one of the lighting settings, going from very high to off I went from 80fps to 126, and it looked better. Has uncapped frame rates, 21:9 support added aswell.

author: Maple Tides
review: After humble beginnings on the Playstation 2 and PSP I became heavily invested in the franchise, spending many hours of my teenage years hunting with friends and making great memories. The first time delivering a wyvern egg; running for my life or the first time slaying Fatalis; truly epic. After "Freedom Unite" I didn't follow onto the Nintendo DS, or therefore any of the subsequent games, that was until Monster Hunter World...Literally 10 years since "Unite" released I picked up my sword once again and boy, it felt like I never left, but everything was so beautiful. Capcom have shown such passion for the game and playerbase, and the amount of content really reflects that. As a fan I am so very proud of how far the franchise has come and this game truly showcases all the great features of Monster Hunter and the certain charm that comes along with it. For new and returning players I feel this game is a great entry to the MW catalogue, a must play!

author: Amagad
review: Multiplayer seems to be fixed, so I am changing my review to positive as I promised! This is my first Monster Hunter game but I've become quickly addicted to it.  For a newcomer like me, I'd essentially describe it as a souls game but with more giant dragons and complex weapon move sets.  Also, just like a souls game, there can be some extremely frusterating moments where I felt cheated by mechanic, hitbox, stun, etc., but ultimately I've found that practicing and learning about each monster has made things much easier.  My biggest gripe, since I like to play Fashion Souls, is the lack of customization when combing various sets of armor for a build, but other than a few hideous frankenarmor sets I've made, it hasn't been too bad.  Multiplayer is where I have the most fun by far, especially when finding a team of competent players to hunt with.  This is why I initially gave a negative review because I had such a hard time playing online due to sever issues.  I think the graphics are fine, although I had to do some adjusting to achieve stable FPS.  There are moments when everything seems a bit washed out, but I think it has to do with specific lighting in certain environments, and it isn't a major issue.Finally, as a cat lover, Palicos are pretty much the greatest thing ever!  =^.^=

author: Applicant
review: I'm not sure if this is the correct time in my play through to write a review, but at 93 hours in and having had the end credits roll I think it's about time I put my thoughts to speech bubble.I have no problem recommending this game, particularly when on sale. Why I played:I was interested in an action game that was challenging, revolved around beautiful locations with interesting and varied hunts that required preparation to succeed in. I was ready to do some grinding as long as the rewards were worthwhile and I continued to enjoy the game.What I was pleasantly surprised about:The locations feel very real to life. It's not quite the open world you're used to. The locations are big but they are more maze-like than they are open plains like. And it works for me. The verticality of these locations particularly is something that I love about this game and something not many games do or do well. I found a weapon (insect glaive) that also let me play a vertical play style, with multiple jumps and dashes in the air that required good positional awareness and quick thinking. (I feel like my rocket league skills transferred over a bit into playing that weapon). I was also surprised how good the online portion of the game is. Not only are there a lot of players still playing, it really livens the world knowing that you can invite others, friends or strangers, to join in on the fun. This does often cause fights to be trivial unless you set a specific level limit to who can join. Even with limits, monsters appear to be a lot easier to take down in tandem rather than solo. This is why I chose to fight each new monster solo first before inviting or joining others to fight them. I was also surprised at the difficulty of the game. It was actually a lot easier, at least in terms of the fighting, than I expected. Very few monsters posed a challenge to me in my initial 93 hour playtime. That said, the difficulty does seem to ramp up the further you progress into the game. This is good because of lot of other games get this wrong. They become easier the more you progress. That said, I beat the final boss solo on my own on my first try and it wasn't even that tough. It could be that the insect glaive counters it or not but outside of three monsters, I beat all of them solo on my first try.  And because the game was a bit easy, the preparation didn't feel all that important. I would normally just choose one of two meals each time. I still don't know what mixing items does not do I care to find out. I never sold an item. I would use armor with elemental resistances against certain challenging monsters but that was about it. I only used the basic heal and antidote potions for restoration and only on occasion did I bother with the attack power potion and the full restore food thing. Why I continued/continue to play:The grind is real, and you grind to get gear as most people will have gathered by now. The gear is all mostly unique, with a specific set/s gained from materials harvested from their respective monsters. Each set is lovingly designed and absolutely beautiful. I grinded because I wanted to collect all the sets, even if having each set did not necessarily provide functional value within the game. I just like how they look. And you can also customize them too, at least, you can the advanced armor sets that you get access to later in the game. Once that hits, it's another ball park for me. In a way, I kind of wish I had to work harder to unlock colors or had to find rare materials in each environment that allowed me to paint parts of my armor. Basically once the color function is unlocked, it's unlocked and all  your advanced sets can be customized. I also continue to play because I still haven't defeated all the monsters. There are still many to defeat, both new (partly because I also purchased the expansion in a bundle) and buffed up versions of old ones too. I look forward to the challenge of defeating them and reaping the rewards. Final Verdict:Definitely a fun game, fairly priced in my region compared to what Square Enix does (terrible prices in my region). I've gotten into it and look forward to playing it some more.

author: AzriLuqman
review: Monster Hunter is an action role-playing game for the PlayStation 2. The game was developed and published by Capcom. Monster Hunter was released in North America on September 21, 2004. It was remade and expanded in Monster Hunter G, which was released in Japan and was brought to North America and Europe as Monster Hunter Freedom for the PlayStation Portable.Much of the game can be played offline through single-player. The majority of the content is in the online section of the game. Only some monsters are found in single-player and the player's rewards are smaller (and less valuable) when they are offline. The goal for players online is not to defeat the most monsters but to reach the highest hunter rank, which is the storyline that is carried out online by non-player characters.  ---Source By : Wikipedia''..I've played the First Monster Hunter on Playstation 2 back then in 2004 and probably the best RolePlayingGame maded by CAPCOM...took me around years to complete the entire game solo...since Playstation 2 ONLINE mode needed A Router/Modem to connect through the internet...Control/Movement in the game is much worse rather than the newest installation...since you gotta swing those G.Sword/Sword Shield/Long Sword or even the fancy Hammer with the right analog stick...but yeah...its fun and challenging though...I've been through most of the series except the 4th and it was exclusive for Nintendo 3DS. This game available almost in all form of gaming platform. Monster Hunter : World would be my End-Game for the entire series since I've been waiting for years for HUGE improvement from their development. Multiplayer issues for this game since the launch was almost Un-Playable. 200k Players were playing this game since the launch too. Now its gone to 160k Players state by today's date 8/14/2018. For all Players...Give it a try...Its not a DarkSoul game but the Multiplayer much better than DarkSoul Series since we all need the SoapStone to summon nearby players to make coop game available....Monster Hunter : World allowed Drop-In and Drop-Out. ENJOY!.."

author: MythicT4ng.
review: Big fan of Monster Hunter series!! I have been playing MH way back since the initial release on PSP. I can literally say that Monster Hunter accompanied my entire childhood. I have put almost 500hours into MHW on PS4 already and here comes the Steam version! This is a great step for MH series to actually land on PC platform. HUGE thanks to Capcom for making this decision. I gotta say that I enjoy every second of the game. The juicy parts of MH from its previous versions have been well executed and carried on into this current version. Let the hunt begin!

author: NyxCrab
review: If you want a game where you just run around beating up huge monsters with a weapon larger than you are, this is the game for you. Despite how simple the weapons seem at first, every weapon has a surprising amount of depth to them both in combos and positioning when fighting monsters. It's addicting as all hell too, and can be really challenging even if sometimes that challenge feels cheap, most of the time it's fair and there's ways to avoid some of the more annoying attacks. Soundtrack is amazing too and it helps make hunts versus harder monsters feel that much more badass. The connection problems are pretty much entirely fixed at this time and it's not that hard to find SOS's . That is a bit annoying, but it wasn't annoying enough to really annoy me once I figured that out. I highly recommend this game.

author: Der Ungrund
review: Just posting to counter the review bombing that's going on.  I haven't had a single technical issue with this game.  Runs at 60fps+ on high with the newest NVidia drivers (my specs: i7, 1070).  I've played for 11 hours now.  Multiplayer didn't work the weekend after release, but I haven't had single drop out since.  Get it if you want it as it's a great game.

author: Cypher
review: You hunt monsters with unique weapons with it's own mechanics. You fight these large or small monsters with your own skill and intelligence of your items, environments and monster's info. You can go with a squad of 4-player, or alone. You can even SOS if you can't hunt the monster on your own. The game is best played multiplayer.  The game is great for single-player as well. Graphics is amazing even in low quality. Good gameplay every single time you went out to hunt. On the downside, the game is grindy for the certain materials you need. You will need to depend on the drops on the materials only, not the weapons themselves except for a certain event item which there are only 2. Those are sieges. Everything else is obtainable. No microtransactions ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and no lootboxes. ☐ Bad☒ Below-Average☐ Average☐ Above-Average☐ MasterpieceThere isn't much of a story. Most of the time you follow what the Handler does. In my opinion and experiences, I can say, the story sucks. However, the story isn't the selling point of the game. If you're looking for a story-driven game, this is not it. This is a heavy-gameplay-driven game. Involving real-time reflex and strategy. There isn't much of the story and mostly the story only serves to progress through the next monsters that you will be encountering as well as hunting or slaying. ☐ Journalist☐ Below-Average☐ Gamer☒ Above-Average☐ Dark SoulsEvery hunter will pick one of the weapons. Every weapon is also unique to their own with their own set of moves and special abilities. Mastering a weapon is not as easy, but every weapon will reveal itself, the way of the blades, to you. The map is an immersive layered floor with each map is different. There's no single map like each other. You, as the hunter, will have to adapt and learn the environment and use it to fight. Either in your favor, or against you. You'll have to think things through to fight and take down the beasts. Use the elements to your advantage and victory is within your grasp. Knowledge will help you. Every little hard work that you put in, into hunting a monster, either research or build-testing or item hunting. Does not matter. Victory is not far from your hands.☐ Confusing☐ Below-Average☐ Average☒ Above-Average☐ CinematicSound designs are a bit clunky as they use the same style as their previous installments or series but with some improvements to fit in with PC/PS4. The sounds aren't nothing to write home about. However, they are unique since they are exactly what monsters are represented to sound like. With that said, I think you'll enjoy the experiences the game provides you with as you hear the monsters shook you with rumble and roar.☐ One-Time☐ Below-Average☐ Normal Loop☐ Above-Average☒ Infinite-PossibilitiesEvery hunt will not be the same. You will spend time hunting the monsters again and again. However, every hunt will never be the same as you have different weapons with different playstyles as well as different builds suited for different occasion, playstyle of each of playstyles of the weapons and mechanics as well as the environments. Safe to say, the gameplay's replayability is nothing short but always excitement once you get into the hunt. Prepare yourselves as you fight through the challenges ahead. Happy hunting.☐ DO NOT GET☐ Below-Average☐ Up-to-you.☐ Above-Average☒ MUST HAVEI love Monster Hunter Games. I will be biased. However, I will say, the price for the BASE game itself is quite expensive so it is better to wait for a discount. The Expansion DLC which is Iceborne, is definitely worth the price as the Expansion DLC provides better coverage, bugfixes and gameplay fixes as well as improvements upon the base game. If you plan to buy the base game only, wait for the sale. The Expansion DLC, is definitely worth the price but it is still very expensive. Do I recommend the game? ONLY if you can sink in at least 100 hours. The tutorial alone is 1-3 hours depending on how fast you read or not at all as well as how well you understand the game. So money, will go down the drain if you choose to spend it on this game. It's worth it though. 500 hours of gameplay is average for most players for this game. Be prepared.

author: Occams Raven
review: tl;dr This game leaves me with seriously conflicted feelings.On one hand, you have - beautiful set pieces- engaging, vibrant environments - tons of content and mechanics to master - awesome artwork and character/monster/weapon designs- online multiplayer- an awesome, arching single player experience- fantastic sound design- Pallicos- weighty, complex and demanding combatAnd on paper this all seems like what a AAA title needs to be.  It hits all the right marks in very satisfying (albeit sometimes frustrating) ways.But often times, it's the moments between the action that really kill this game and make it unplayable.  Ignoring the fact that the option to disable mouse acceleration/joystick emulation isn't available (since I don't really mind playing with controller) there are a whole host of bugs and design flaws that break immersion and sometimes, break the game.1.  Online multiplayer network issues where fixed.2. Online multiplayer is great (part 2)...when it doesn't pull you out of the story.  I'm not really clear on why Capcom decided to run with this mechanic, but party members aren't allowed to join each other on main story quests until the monster of the hour shows its face in an elaborate cut-scene.  On the surface, I get it, this stops people from being boosted to higher tier monsters right from the start.  However the complete downside to this is that people who want to quest together have to all slog through the quest, hit the designated cut-scene and then back out of the mission either all together to start it again or have one person stay and chance that the other members can leave their quest and hop into the one that's continued beyond the cut-scene (remember: network issues).  This mechanic kills gameplay immersion like a brick to the face and doesn't even stop people from being boosted since a veteran can join a newbie player's quest with relative ease.3. Bugs, for the most part, have been addressed.4. Targeting.  Monsters jump and frolic across your screen like they're made of feather and tissue paper which makes keeping track of them challenging at times.  What's worse though, is that the targeting system does little to make sure you're hitting in the right direction or even looking at the right monster.  Sometimes I would have the cursor lock on to a monster that was right next to me, only to have my character swinging fruitlessly at an empty space, position unchanged.  Also, with the amount of monsters and wildlife at play in any given area, one bad swipe or even touch to RS and you've found yourself looking at a monster in a tree 200 yards away.  tl;dr our hunters' attacks feel solid and deliberate but the targeting system feels like it's from the perspective of the monsters flailing around on our screen - chaotically unfocused.After some fine tuning I can finally recommend this game, it's just sad that it took so long for an already "polished" port to be brought up to standard for release.

author: Keef
review: This game is pretty dang fun. There's not a very good party system you can lock into with your friends but you can pretty easily join their hunts by other means. This only really gets in the way during the initial story line quests. There is a lot of RNG to the end game because in order to get some of the jewels you need to complete your builds you will need to kill a ton of monsters. In the end though I think killing a ton of monsters is really what it's all about anyway. The joy you can find in this game will be of your own design. None of the fights ever feel easy. There are several different weapon types you can try out and many different types within those weapons to use. The combat is thrilling and the monsters are dangerous. They will surprise you when you underestimate them. All in all I give monster hunter world the thumbs up. Do like I did and wait for a sale as always though!

author: SpartanSam0034
review: *This review is exclusively for coop/multiplayer. if you play solo, this review is semi-irrelevant*If you think this will be a fun game to play with 2+ friends, like me turn back now. First off, every single cut scene and story mission is required, and unskippable. You have to watch them all, you have to do 1-2 hours of tutorials, and most importantly you cannot play 90% of the story missions with friends. they can join you for the 4 mins of each hunt portion of a story mission, but they also have to have done that story mission before. That means to play cooperatively without having already beat the game, you both have to play the missions SEPARATELY AND AT THE SAME TIME. One person has to quit the mission, then join their friend for the hunt, then quit again and each separately play through the next story mission. It's a completely broken "coop" system, that makes playing through 40 hours of story the biggest chore I've ever experienced in a game. After 14 hours, myself and 4 friends all gave up because we were so sick of playing so little of the game together. On top of that, you cannot buy the DLC separately from the main game. 2 of us bought the base game, thinking we could just buy the DLC later. NOPE. So we tried to refund the base game after buying the DLC version, and steam told us we couldn't because it counts hours as played on BOTH GAMES. I've never seen either of these issues in 20 years of gaming. The optional hunts are the only way to play together consistently. But to progress your character, you have to play the story. There's no other way to get everything you need. And optional hunts are just re-playable story mode hunts of the same monsters, so you're just doing the same thing you just did in the story with friends.Please just don't buy this game unless you want to play (a game literally made for playing with 4+ people) solo.
