author: Angelic
review: I absolutely adored Monster Hunter World when it came out for the PS4, and proceeded to sink over 200 hours into the game (rookie numbers, I know, gotta' pump 'em up) but opted to take a break to play other games while I waited for the PC port to come out.  This was mainly so I could play with my friends.  Monster Hunter:  World has absolutely AMAZING gameplay, and is perfect for people who want a good-looking grind-based game.  However, I can't honestly recommend Monster Hunter: World in this state on PC, however, for a number of reasons.I could deal with the lack of options for motion blur or more granular options for video settings.  I could deal with the multiplayer connection issues despite the fact that the primary reason that I bought the game for both myself and a friend was to play together on launch and help people in low rank while we geared up.  I could deal with the weird texture bugs and other visual side-grades that make the game either washed out or the water reflections not working as well as they do in the console variants.I could deal with them if all of these things came together for a game that ran at a consistent 60 FPS above the recommended settings at 1080p.  As it stands, many people are having extreme issues running the game at anything above 45 fps with some settings on, and in a lot of cases, even if people can end up tweaking their games to reach 60 fps and slap on that wonderful vsync (because screen tearing is rampant), there are a metric BOATLOAD of performance issues, not limited to: stuttering, incredible framerate drops and frame-time issues during end-game monster hunts (Teostra, Lunestra, anything with a fair amount of particles), a certain area in the game running around 20-30% worse than other areas, among other things.But on top of that, there is absolutely no implementation of VAC or other anti-cheat software alongside the game... while a significant implementation of Denuvo was put into place.  The time and effort that was expended to do this could have been spent shoring up the game's performance on launch, or at the very least a bit more QA when it comes to it.  It's unfortunate that Capcom decided to launch this game in such a sorry state, because from a gameplay perspective, this has to be the best Monster Hunter yet, especially with the quality-of-life improvements made for new players.I'd say that if you don't already own it on another platform, you have an extremely high-end / beefy rig, still make use of that refund feature, and come back in a couple more months after Capcom decides to fix their game to the point it should have been at at launch of PC.

author: Pzyke
review: This game has amazing gameplay, superb looking armor, lots of grinding and most importantly a bunch of challenging monsters to dominate. In the begining there is alot of new information to take in and new mechainics to learn since the game is originaly a Japanese IP. But that's not a negative, no indeed it is one of the strongest features of this game, the part where you have to think and craft your own path to being a badass hunter.There are so many armor sets and consumables to collect and learn to use effectively that after the first 100 hours you realise something gamebreaking, like for example: what the "Max Potions" do in the game. (they max your hp out at the 150 mark.) And talking about items to learn about, you also have to keep track of what the 30 other consumables do and when to use them. And yet there's more to learn about.Moving on to the armor system where you have to manage skills that comes along with said armor and puting together a nice build for yourself with different skills, defense and attack for the respective monster and element. Also you will have to either look stylish and feel fabolous or look like absolute garbage but kick ass (until you unlock the transmog system that is.)Now you have crafted some nice looking armor with some good skills and a weapon with the appropriate element for whatever elegant beast you aim for, now comes the combat system.The combat system feels fluent and rewarding once you have learned how the animations (they feel like they take hours when just starting a new weapon) and monsters attack patterns work. Most weapons are balanced so whatever weapon you choose is viable and really fun to use. It all depens on what your playstyle is and some skills ofcourse. Some weapons have a higher skill-ceiling making them extremely rewarding to master. But most of the weapons are easy to learn and hard to master.The monsters not only look nice but feels nice to fight against. And their attacks and enviroment makes sense, so you feel like you can apply logic to most hunts which makes learning about a monster and following it studing its habits a real thing which not only makes sense but gives the exact feeling of being a hunter. However there's no need to go that far if you just want to get a nice impresive low kill time. The scoutflies automaticly gives out the monsters position (if you have researched the monster before.)As is already stated applying the correct elemental damage and defense is critical for a successful hunt or capture, but learning the monsters weak points and what limbs are severable (There's no blood) is also very important.The other thing to know about combat is that 97% of the monsters you will face are very soloable (Thank God) that means:  no friends required, you don't even need to interact with other players if that's your playstyle. I myself enjoyed the full game completely solo. Atleast until the endgame content where it just got more effective to have a group of skilled players.But don't worry, you are not alone in fighting the monsters. You always have your Palico (Pet Cat) at your side, and you can give him some cool weapons that benefit you or just build him into a devestation agent and make yourself your sidekicks sidekick. Normaly your felyne friend brings you health in form of vigorwasp spray and stations but he/she can be customised with different gadets depending on your needs and playstyle.Ofcourse the multiplayer is always avalibe. But I recommend trying some monsters solo, It's a completely different game solo.This game offers a fun story and stays fun (But kinda grindy endgame.) I have yet to tire of anything in the game with a current 200 hours on record. I'm positive I can devote another 100-150 hours and still have fun.9.6/ 10 Game. Recommended to play if you like epic fights.

author: mast3r
review: Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). Melt the butter in a saucepan. Stir in flour to form a paste. Add water, white sugar and brown sugar, and bring to a boil. Reduce temperature and let simmer.    Place the bottom crust in your pan. Fill with apples, mounded slightly. Cover with a lattice work crust. Gently pour the sugar and butter liquid over the crust. Pour slowly so that it does not run off.    Bake 15 minutes in the preheated oven. Reduce the temperature to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Continue baking for 35 to 45 minutes, until apples are soft.

author: Mentras
review: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD is getting more and more negative reviews. The overall review rating became "mixed" (12th August 2018), after more and more players joined the hunt. But why does this game get so many bad reviews? Honestly...I don't really now. I saw 300k people playing this game today so the game has to do something right, not wrong.Here are some of the main issues that other players seem to have with this game. A lot of people are complaining about really bad keyboard controls. I don't know why but I don't have any problems at all with the keyboard controls. Maybe I can adapt to new things really fast...I don't know.  Even more people are complaining about really bad performance. I am playing this game in 4k and can't complain about that. I had to lower some setting tho, that's true. If you want to know what hardware I got in my rig, simply check out my profile. Everything is listed there. I can't speak for people with old or cheap hardware, but if someone can't match the recommended specifications, then this person is not in the position to complain about performance.  Alright, I have to do some real talk here. This game doesn't have bad graphics at all. As I said, I am playing this game in 4k and it looks sooooo freaking beautiful. The whole art design is 100% monster hunter. The lighting is beautiful and the landscape is far more than decent. There are some low resolution textures but overall it's really good. The game doesn't have the newest high-end graphics, and it's eating more performance as it should for what is given, but it's still more than I can wish for. I played games like witcher 3, crysis 3 and DOOM in 4k and they all look better. But people have to understand that games don't have to be the best looking games ever made. More and more games are coming with awsome graphics, but these games are losing more and more of their cool gameplay, content and story. Graphics aren't everything as long as the other aspects of the game are working. Well, I am with the 21:9 people here. It's sad that this game doesn't support it (yet). And to those who complain about the 21:9 players being mad. Shame on you, they have every right to be mad. Guys we are living in 2018. Even if only 0,3% of the playerbase got 21:9...they have to be treated equal. Everybody should be treated equal! Well, this topic is very clear for me. No problems at all. I played this game for 21 hours now and I was playing 50% of the time in coop mode. I NEVER had any connection problems etc. . I played the old Monster Hunter games on multiple consoles for hundrets of hours and I can say that this game is everything I was hoping for. It's prettier, deeper and more fun than the old games. It's everything I was hoping for.

author: Silver
review: It's a game that's definitely not for everyone, and as a lot of the negative reviews say, it is indeed very grindy-feeling, and there are hunts that can take upwards of the entirety of your 50-minute allocated limit, a fair portion of the time spent simply chasing the monster. However, the gameplay is very well-done, and each and every weapon type has a lot of nuances and variety to them, with each weapon having a different learning curve, and a lot of room for mastery over the combat style. Even choice of weapon aside, that's only half the battle since the other half consists of also learning the patterns and "tells" of the monsters you fight. All in all, it's a game that requires quite a bit of skill to appropriately master, while having a forgiving enough learning curve early on to allow a new player to adapt to the different style of gameplay.If you're on the fence about getting any Monster Hunter title for the matter, do the appropriate research to see if it's something you would like, since there's a significant amount of negative reviews that do nothing but demonstrate that the person didn't actually bother learning how the game is on a level beyond "Online action RPG". For the style of game it sets out to be, it does an excellent job (though obviously not without faults and a few bugs) and as a person who has played many hunter-style games, World definitely feels best in franchise thus far, and among the top in the genre, period. The bottom line I want everyone to understand about these "Hunting" games is what you're actually getting into.

author: C z a r
review: I have a serious problem of reviewing this great game.For one thing, it is a simple scoped game with a LOT of replayability....I mean A HECK TON of it! On another side of the coin is a grind fest of just being in a grind just to grind more to get to a place that you can grind some more.Kill monsters to get better weapons and armor to kill bigger monsters to get even better wepons and armor to kill bigger and more ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up monsters.It is beautiful. It is polished to a god send shine.It is fun. It is sooo much fun. Imagine being a borderline superhero in dinosaur times with dragons around. This is basically it. Everything is trying to kill you while you hold some weapon that is ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up in size in comparison to you. An axe bigger than life. A sword almost taller than you. A ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ musical instrument that you will slaughter a 10m tall t-rex.It is as ridiculous in theme as it is amazing in it.The downsides are down to UI heavy navigation, and the gameplay itself that can be BRUTAL to you.On a child level: this game is a dream coming true. Kill a T-Rex with a sword??? I'm in decades ago!On an adult level: this game is a dream coming true. Kill a T-Re....You get the point. Watch streams and youtube videos. If you're still caught into it, it is because you'll love it.One of the few 10/10 I ever give. Instant classic!

author: Jonny AN
review: Compared to the PS4 version I played for 170 hours, it has:> 10-30X faster load times> A higher framerate at a higher resolution> The ability to use the keyboard and mouse or controller> Steam friend integration> Free multiplayer> Ease of multitasking (tabbing over to a browser to check reddit etc)By all accounts the PC version is already the superior version.Yes the mouse could have been implemented better.Yes the performance could have been betterYes the servers are having a hissyfit right nowHowever, I feel just fine playing with a controllerAlso with some settings tweaks it isn't hard to beat the console versions on performance.And lets be completely honest here; Not only did MHW have server issues at the launch of the console version, but I doubt that a single person will deny that a load of PC games had server issues at their launch as well.Are there issues to be worked on and fixed? Yes.But is it a complete writeoff of a port that's not worth playing? Not even close.

author: Jahandar
review: Great game! The fights have the intensity of a Dark Souls boss, adding a lot of gameplay depth from the various weapons and other mechanics. The monster hunting and crafting gameplay loop is satisfying and co-op has been a lot of fun.

author: ZeldascoRN
review: Great game as this is my first Monster Hunter Game.A Few things they should fix:1. Graphical settings like Motion Blur toggles, Mouse acceleration, etc.2. Fix the Targeting System!Otherwise, this is a great game.

author: ChaseFace
review: Monster Hunter World is amazing. If you like action games with a lot of depth and you don't mind a good amount of grinding to get rare item drops, you'll enjoy it. The online multiplayer is immaculate (minus waiting on people who haven't seen all cutscenes, etc). The monster design and variety is awesome. The amount of weapon classes is superb and each weapon changes the way you play the game drastically. There are options to play support if you equip the right decorations and weapon (hunting horn is for those of you who like being "the guy we need for every fight"), and the music is amazingly well-composed orchestral music. No loot boxes or any of that modern nonsense. Get it. It's the most fun I've had in years.

author: JamesWarlord
review: [Nov. 2020 Edit]My previous review was painfully long so here it goes an updated one straight to the point of what I see about the current state of the game. > The game is grind as always. If you don't like grinding stay away.> There is no best weapon/class, just how it must be.> The DLC content adds a ton of stuff  if you are new to MHW I highly recommend playing the base game first and take your time doing the story. If you rush it you won't get good.> Everything can be killed solo if you learn the monster patterns, you will still  even in end game by one-shot attacks and the such. Stay away if you can't tolerate frustration. (except for sieges which is faster done in a session with people)> If you think you suck or don't know what to do,  watch video guides in Youtube or read stuff in google. You really will learn how to play in no time.> People still play, but it is recommended to join "hunting" discords so you can actually get things done. (Not that you can't hunt solo anyways)> Hackers still lurk around but you barely see them. I've seen one once in my past 100 hours, although it is fairly common to see people using overlays to maximize on damage.> Even though it will get tedious and tiresome past Master Rank 100, I must say the price is worth it with a discount. I wouldn't pay full price for the DLC although I did for the base game.

author: LordBlade
review: Absolutely amazing.I've been playing the Monster Hunter games since the beginning, and I have to say that World is definitely a shining example of the series. There were fears of the game being "dumbed down" or oversimplified to reach a larger audience, but that's clearly not the case. The core gameplay is the same classic style. Pick a weapon, learn it's moves and timing, study the monsters and learn when to attack and when to evade. This isn't some button mashing game like God of War, this is a skillful, methodical hunting game where the monsters are lethal and you need to fight smart.Of course the game's been out on consoles for some time, and everyone already knows how amazing it is. The real focus here is how good is the PC version. Simply put, it's mindblowing. People again had fears of some bad port, poorly optimized and all that nonsense. Happily, none of that's an issue.Firstly the performance of the game is vastly superior to the consoles. Not only does PC get better graphical quality, but it gets a much better framerate, with the ability to play at 30, 60 or uncapped FPS. My system's a couple of years old now, but I'm easily able to play at max settings with uncapped FPS and generally seems to float around 90 FPS for most of the time. My wife's system is actually quite a bit older, but she is able to play on max settings at a steady 60 FPS. The main thing is that the game is far more CPU dependant than GPU. So having a top of the line graphics card won't help much if your CPU is garbage.One tip is to turn off Volumetric Rendering. It barely does anything graphically, but with it off you'll notice a huge jump in performance it the feature itself is a massive drain on resources for some reason.As far as controls go, mouse and keyboard works wonderfully. Not only are the controls smooth and responsive, but using mouse and keyboard lets use use hotkeys for inventory (instead of an inventory wheel or cycling like with a controller). You can set up 4 batches of hotkeys no less (hitting F1-F4 for a list and the 1-8 for an option). This lets you use what you want, when you want, without having to worry about cycling through your inventory or finding the option on a radial menu. Need a heal? Need antidotes? Need to grab your fishing rod? All super quick and easy. I can't imagine ever going back to console after having this benefit.Monster Hunter World is definitely a perfect example of the series. It's fun, it's challenging and the multiplayer is awesome and easy to do. Definitely a must have for any fan of the series (many people have switched from console to PC, even after owning the console version) and an amazing game for those who love epic boss battles in a Dark Souls style combat system.

author: Gingen
review: Network issues and missing content aside, this game is phenominal. I adore it and just want more content and monsters and G rank to fill the voids in my heart that MH4U so easily filled.Also there's an Ultrawide mod now that works flawlessly, even if the HUD is a bit offset :)

author: Archie
review: Monster Hunter World is an action RPG game where you hunt monsters, craft weapons and armor and hunt even tougher monsters. An absolute fun game which has a lot of content and updates for FREE.You only need to buy Iceborne expansion for newest content and access hardest difficulty to date.This is one of the few games where you can make your own personal kitty cat which you fully customize with your character (Psst, you make your own waifu look sexy)Each weapon has its own unique playstyle which can mastered, some are easier than others but trust me all of the weapons have complex mechanics which any player can learn and master.The graphics is also stunning, its the best looking Monster Hunter game to date!The monsters also have amazing designs which can be easily identified, it shows how good the designs are.FYI: If you're new to the game, refer to the Arekzz basic weapon guides if you want to understand the basic of weapons also don't use defender armor and weapons it will make your experience easy. Try using normal equipment since the defender gear is those who want to rush to Iceborne expansion+14 weapons which all are viable if the player masters (I already mastered it all hehe)+Builds has a lot of variety, go full on damage build or mix damage skills with utility skills which will significantly change your playstyle!+Can customize your own character and your OWN CAT+Has a lot of depth, even after 500+ hours i'm still learning new things like maybe a hidden weapon mechanic or finding new ways to exploit monsters weakness+Amazing armor and weapon designs+FREE UPDATES, optional paid cosmetics and stuff+Crossever events like Witcher 3, FF14 and Assassin's Creed etc+/-Controller is IMO better than mouse and keyboard but if you know how to rebind proper keys then its actually better than controller especially bow and bowguns+/-Can be grindy but still the grind is super fun trust me-Optimization can be random, but i recommend playing with 16gb ram to ensure stable fpsAlso turn off volumetric fog, it eats fps-Some weapons look ugly since they use monster parts slap on a bone base weapon for some reason(Looking at your Glavenus Great sword)Overall, Monster Hunter World is such an amazing that everyone has to play. ALSO BUY ICEBORNE9/10

author: Grizzle
review: Is it the greatest monster hunter game? Well, thats debatable due to the vast difference in content from the other main line series.Is it the best playing monster hunter? Hell yes it is.Monster hunter world may not have the 100 or so monsters the previous main line monster hunter has but people have to understand, they have been reusing the same models since the psp/ps2 time with little improvment on hit boxes/gathering/wep movement.Monster hunter world finally takes a huge step in the right direction (even if you say its more casual) to where movement feels so much more in the players control and making gathering items/harevting not a pain in the ass as previous titles. The  addition on how monsters look and act now with turf wars is also all new to the series. No re used assets speaks to why theres not as many monsters.The only down side to World to me is the unique desigins of weapons has been lost, many looking damn near similar to eachother, Im talking about you hunting horn.The Armour skills in this game can be a little overwhelming also as min/maxing  is alot more common with every piece of armour now having a set skill rather than the full set.All I can say after 300 hours hours is, when the hell is G rank/World 2 coming out? I crave.

author: 𝕍𝕚𝕔𝕖
review: Played on console originally and I have to say it runs far better on PC than console. However if you want to run this game in max with smooth gameplay then make sure you have a decent rig, else you will be most likely running the game in Mid Setting just for smooth gameplay. Also, none of the console events are on the game yet, nor the DLC (Cross-over DLC). For people who are not sure about moving over from Console to PC I would wait till there is a sale. Simple summary: It's fun to play solo or with friends, there is plenty of content to go through even with the console events and DLC not being out yet.That's me done.

author: Asphe
review: The best Monster Hunter game yet. Everything I wanted to see in a MH game. Best solo MH experience so far.Multiplayer? Between the interface UI and the constant disconnects [the game ups the difficulty when more players join... but doesn't lower it back if everyone is disconnected]... get used to playing with yourself and cat. This is a YMMV issue though and with Iceborne, this sort of thing seems to be rare.Before you buy, try to see if anyone in your local area has problems... if they do. Buy it for the solo experience.Iceborne adds just a few combat mechanics and yet another way to grind. The changes both make the game easier to get into and the grind more tolerable and a lot more fun. Finally, a good reason to replay the end-game with your friends.Updated for Iceborne.

author: Viridium
review: Is this core gameplay enjoyable: Yes.Is the port enjoyable: Sadly not.This port is so ridden with serious bugs and massive oversights it kills a lot of the fun of the game. You gotta ask: What did they do the half year it took to port this for the PC? Especially the horrible implementation of multiplayer makes coop more of an annoyance than fun.Bugs:- Game can only be played with some specific settíngs e.g. only runs in borderless windowed othewise it has massive graphic glitche/isn't playable for me.- Good friend can't play at all because of Blue Screens with an even better PC than mine.- Weekly quests reset after each relog, making it nearly impossible to finish them.Horrible design:- Mouse has no DPI or sensitivity settings and uses one of the most annoying accelaration models I have ever seen.- Multiplayer feels as tedious as a game that came out 1995 and not 2018. You need to jump through several hoops just to play with friends. Why can't you join some quests at all? Why some only after playing the first minutes of a mission? Why can't you declare a party and do everything together like in every game since 2003?- Graphic settings are extremely limited. FOV can't be changed, motion blur and several other stable settings for PC can't be changed at all despite beeing used ingame. Some settings annoy me visually and I can't get rid of them, some other cost unreasonable amounts of GPU power and reducing overall performance with no way to turn them of to improve the performance.Especially the horrible multiplayer implementation makes this game feel like you play an old game on an playsation emulator and not a 60 buck title on PC.Can't recommend it with major overhaul of multiplayer, improved graphic settings and bug fixes.

author: Jet Black
review: If I put 100+ hours into a game I think it is definitely review-material (93 hours at this point but I know I'll hit 100 soon). This is my first Monster Hunter game and truly I have had a blast throughout. The game format may be repetative for some, but not any more repetative than any other game. You are always climbing a ladder to a new challenge, crafting new equipment and weapons. The general craft, eat, explore, quest, craft loop is mostly never-ending, but you will get different opportunities, as the challenges increase, to practice your rock-paper-scissors setups versus different monsters. Change up your gear for an elemental resist or craft up a weapon that will give more blast damage to break parts. Is fighting up-close on one monster not working? Switch to a more mobile or even a ranged weapon. Getting smacked around? Maybe a shield is your friend. Consider the weapon types as character classes: With 14 different weapon types there is always something new to try and each plays dramatically different from each other. Don't come here for the story (unless maybe you are a Monster Hunter veteran, but then you wouldn't be reading this review). It's a neat world that is created for sure, but it's more fun exploring and bumping into monsters than reading what the NPCs have to say. The only real negative for me is that the world, while dynamic, shows its cards on occasion as monsters do follow the occasional script. It's not too bad as they do bump into each other at odd times and things can get quite exciting, but overall it would have been cooler if the monsters weren't quite as scheduled and had more freedom. Performance-wise I have had zero issues on an older PC. At the time of review, I'm sporting an i7 4770k and a 980 Ti and getting 60FPS in most areas at 1080p. Played all my hours with a Steam Controller, which works quite well. If any of this sounds good to you, give this game a try. If the fear of doing the same thing over and over has you down, maybe try something else, or pick this up on a sale where you think you can get enough play to make it wortwhile.Edit: Took a long break from this but picked it up again at HR 47. Still so much more game I haven't experienced and Capcom keeps updating and adding new quests and monsters.

author: dronti_ti
review: Fun, engaging, fast-paced action. MHW is a game that gives veteran players a new challenge with nicer QOL changes to weapons, menuing, and other actions that were considered a chore. There's a weapon for every playstyle, and this Monster Hunter game is a great place to start if new to the series. Multiplayer is fun and more accessible than the other games, and I always have a blast hunting with my friends. Fun solo play and multiplayer aspects. The graphics are better than every previous monster hunter game and with the new patches I've had little internet/server issues with this game. Definitely worth its money for the amount of time and enjoyment I get out of this game.

author: Flare
review: The Witcher crossover is REALLY GOOD for this game, and weirdly enough feels pretty natural in MHW's format. I wish there were more narrative beats to the real MHW campaign, but this is a hub and spoke world at its core and I don't mind grinding quests with friends anyways.Great multiplayer experience and entry-game for newcomers such as myself. Highly recommend playing with a controller if you aren't familiar with these kinds of games.Also, as a heads up to new players:- Your friends can't help you until you see all of the cutscenes in the quest. THEN you can fire your SOS flare and survive until they arrive.- Learn to dodge roll and use those invincibility frames for the flop! Incredibly important for late game monsters.- Learn where your weapon is best applicable. Focus on parts you want and form a plan with your team for capturing or killing.- Have fun!

author: THE[KAMI]
review: Good for solo players for now, beautiful graphics when you have an awesome rig. So far no hiccups when it comes to in-game graphics or animation for me.Doesn't have good UI for keyboard users, the thing with the mouse wheel for multiple items is such a pain, when trying to switch to keyboard interface, it doesn't even show the shortcuts on screen which is crucial for mmorpg games when it comes to getting used to the keys than to try and remember another 10+ more custom shortcuts. DID NOT PAY FOR THIS GAME FOR SERVER ISSUES upon multiplayer matchups. Constant 50382-MW1 and 83-mw1 errors, once disconnected can't join back into the matchup as you have "left the quest". Once game gone "offlline" (nothing to do with my internet since my discord is still ongoing), you need to restart the game just to get "online", going back to title just doesn't work sometimes. Keep having to RESTART GAME + remake quest when you just wanna have fun with your friends is such a KILLJOY and it can keep going on for like the whole day just to do a single hunt!! Followed the online "fixes" and CAPCOM's recommendation fixes nothing works, still disconnects. ♥♥♥♥ you shouldn't even push the fixing part to the users. CAPCOM PLEASE FIX THIS IF YOU WANT TO KEEP THE PLAYERS, OMFG!!! DISAPPOINTMENT.

author: Super Starman
review: The game is fun as hell. The connection issues are real, but they're way over-blown. Comments like "might as well not be a multiplayer" are mindless hyperbole, or only representative of edge cases. In my experience, I get the occasional disconnect, but mostly lots of very successful, fun multiplayer. I have 120+ hours on it already, and the vast majority of that time has been hunts completed with friendsUpdate: the connection issues have been fixed for a long time. I have over 600 hours in the game now, and still love it.

author: 【﻿WHIRLIGIG】
review: With only two days after release, I already have 18.2 hours in this game. The combat is fluid, the controls on K&B are easy to pick up and attune to (but you can always change them) The main core gameplay of the game is also the grind. MH has mastered this technique of gameplay over the years and it never gets boring. Level design is decent, and each area is unique in itself, as well as each encounter being unique. Sometimes you will face a monster that only runs, other times the same type but cheeses one damn move and KO's you in two hits, other times another creature will show up and have a "Turf War" Everyone else who has downvoted this game is only due to hardware issues, I have had no problems running this game at 1080p with nothing but 50-60fps(Specs for people who care)EVGA 1060 FTW 3GBAMD 6350 6-Core Overclocked to 4.5ghz (Stock CPU Cooler)16GB RAMMSI 970 motherboard EVGA Bronze 700 power supplyI cannot compare with complaints about servers as well, My friend and I who I have played with has had no problems except the few DC's on launch day, the only other time we have ran into issues is during the attempt of trying to make a public session insteado of a private, and running into 50382-MW1, which was easily solved by my friend providing an invite code to his public lobby.Overall the complaints towards this game seem to only be for low end computers (this is a 2017-18 game afterall) Expect it to run into problems with outdated drivers and CPU's. As Far as it being "CPU intensive" is a stretch, Ive have it run only to reach a max of 50% (this was with Youtube, and Discord running) If you are looking for a fun game to sink time into with friends, with a grind that doesnt get boring, fights that are different and fun with each encounter (for the first 100 hours) and a decent soundtrack to compliment those encounters, MH:W is for you.

author: Myamoto
review: Monster Hunter: WorldThe first Monster Hunter game to come to PC, I played Tri on wii and Freedom Unite in psp but this one feels really different from the previous ones.Pors:- Easily to learn the ropesThe weapon crafting tree shows what you can craft, other games kinda just threw what you could craft at the time.- Tutorials are easy to acess and learn the basicsIt doesn't hold your hand but that's a good thing, it challenges your ability to learn what weapons you would like to spend time with.- GraphicsHonestly all the previous games had this polygon graphic, I don't mind it but World came to refresh things up.- InteractionsTurf wars, environmental traps, collectable wildlife. No more "I'm good now" animation when chugging potions (You can actually run while drinking them)- SlingerI got to love to have a ranged option that doesn't render you imobile, then again everything in this game is made to feel dynamic.- WeaponsNew moves and the graphics also helps to flesh them out.- MantlesThese are new lifesavers in the game, other than the palicoes sometimes.And now we go to the...Cons:- Feels "Incomplete"While yes there are new monsters in this game there's only so much you can hunt, Monster Hunter: World bring us 31 large monsters to hunt while Freedom Unite had 58, doesn't seem like a large difference, but hunting the same monster over and over again gets boring really fast.- It's not as rewardingIn Freedom Unite I remember fighting Kirin for the first time, the damn thing kept jumping around while I ran after it with a greatsword only to be struck by lighting and get sent back to the camp, here in world it's most like the same, but some aspects of the game like fast travel and higher mobility makes the game easier in a way. Therefore when you finally slay that annoying elder dragon, it doesn't feel as rewarding as the other ones.- PalicoesI honestly preferred the old ones, when you build their trust and companionship towards you, they even sacrifice themselves to save you, in World, sure it happens sometimes but unless you ping like a madman, they often forget that you exist and instead start to chug a potion while you're stunned.- No Akantor nor Nargacuga (yet)It's more of a personal con but still a con nonetheless, Akantor is my favorite elder dragon (his armor is awesome) and Nargacuga (the upcoming DLC Iceborne will bring him back) being a great and enjoyable fight.Honestly I'm quite biased since I love Monster Hunter, being a fan since wii release with Tri, I'm not quite fit to say how good is the game by itself, but-Compared to other games World lacks in replayability and content (I'm looking at you transmog) but as a starting point is a really good game to go with, it's rather easier than other games and also got a ton of new stuff to try out.To me, it can be enjoyable to hangout with friends or challenge yourself to a solo match against its monsters.Personal Grade: 9/10Unbiased Grade: 7/10Thank you Capcom for making this awesome game.

author: Romp
review: Took me 200 hours before i had to actually start min/maxing builds that valued stats and effects over aesthetics. Those first 200 hours were absolutely incredible though. Would recommend for anyone that wants a fun boss battle game with lots of small things to take up your time, like capturing animals, fishing, and wearing silly hats.Once you reach the post game monsters for the base game and iceborne respectively, monsters do tend to lose their nuanced difficulty and turn into "they one-shot you with no tact", so there's that problem too i guess.

author: Mhblis
review: TL/DR 19/8/18 50Hrs playedWhole heartedly rate this a solid 8 out of 10. Well worth the full purchase price.Needs more monsters which are already on their way for free.Needs a bit more variety in the armor and weapon looks. Talk of this already in the works and part of more monsters.What can I say. I love Monster Hunter and World has done nothing but reinforce that. At minimum spec my machine will happily do 60fps at Mostly medium settings. Some tweaking was required but which game doesn't on PC these days. Also you don't need 60 FPS but I will admit this time I doesn't hurt.The game play is great and everything I love about Monster Hunter. You have to learn your Monsters tells. Deliberate inputs on you attacks. Its not just button mash and hope for the best. Attacks feel deliberate and meaty. Its absolutly satisfying getting the big hits off or to get thumped by some of the Monsters.And the quality of life additions are absolutly fantastic. No more mindless grinding and menu navigation to craft simple staple items. It does it on the fly as you have items in your inventory to do it.Multiplayer has been great fun with a planned group.ConsYes there are connection issues but I've had the same issues with other games through steam previously and they did eventually got fixed. Sadly the new UI update was badly times to conincide with the release so that hasn't helped. But its only been a week and already parts of it has been resolved. The rest will come.Playing with randoms on the fly is a great idea but can at times be really tedious when people can fail missions or mess up captures due to the next issue.The communication system is actually pretty poor and this is where it being a console port really shows. It just doesn't have the vesititlity of what you expect a Multiplayer PC game to have. ITs not terrible and does the job but it could be better.Tobi-Kadashi is just too much Zinogre to not be Zinogre.--Overall I highly recommend this for anyone interested or veterans of  Monster Hunter.

review: Latest Update broke the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game and now it does not launch. Capcom can not confirm if they are trying to fix or will fix it. Players are left in the dark not knowing if they need to try more stupid work around to get the game to run or wait for a patch.

Could get even worse with Iceborne release.

author: javulas
review: I'm pointing out what's wrong with this game, and even then, it's not that big of an obstacle.The game has unskippable cutscenes. Trash.It's also a Japanese game. I hate anime. Unfortunately for me, they happen to go hand in hand.But the story and the (youtube link) , only happen during the cutscenes and are basically irrelevant to the meat and potatoes of the game. "Handler, did you say something? I just murdered this giant raging flame-spewing T-Rex. I must continue to feed on the powerful. Speaking of which, here's a giant death-breathing pickle..."Now that's my kind of story. Shut up and go slaughter that giant monster. That's WHY you're playing in the first place.

author: ๖ۣۜGαЪყнн*~
review: I've been a fan of this franchise since the beginning and I have to say...  I did not like MHW at first because of how easy it is  compared to the other titles. BUT...the changes in graphics, maps and some other mechanics were incredible. The game grew on me, and now there are the challenges I really longed for. The arch-tempered monsters are really strong and the turf wars between them makes you think "HOLY CRAP!" every time.  Also, they release events, new monsters and items really often, which makes you appreciate all the effort that it's put into this game. Most of the content is free, and they bring tons of gameplay hours and fun with it. :3

author: Combustible
review: In short: If you thought about buying MHW: don't get discouraged by alot of the bad reviews and try out this masterpiece of a game.First of all... I can not believe how many people seem to base their reviews purely on some mostly minor PC-Port related issues. It often comes to the point were not the game itself gets reviewed, but it gets compared only to the PS4 Version.Sure... especially in the two weeks after its release PC players encountered alot of connection problems (of cause me too). I can understand how that can lead to frustration in the playerbase.BUT... even with those and other problems taken into consideration that occured, I never thought of giving WORLD a bad review, because the game is a masterpiece. Being someone who has played alot of Monster Hunter Games before WORLD, I can say without hesitation, that this is in my opinion the best game in the franchise so far. It is DEFINITLY the Monster Hunter with the most fluent and satisfying gameplay ever and I am so glad that this game can get more people into the franchise. I really hope that noone who is thinking about buying this game (especially as a MH newcomer) gets discouraged by alot of these outrageous reviews. The connection issues as well as other problems coming from the early time of the PC release are long gone and Capcom is releasing DLC quite fast now.So... i really hope that this review contributed at least a little to you buying the best game in the MH franchise.And if so: Good Hunt!

author: Taiga
review: I have never played a Monster Hunter game before, so World was my first experience with the series. I wasn't even planning on buying it until a few days before release, and it turned out to be one of the most enjoyable games that I've played in a long time.The environments in the game are Large, Rich, and Visually interesting; Every one of them being highly different from the last.Each landscape hosts a plethora of creatures, ranging from the many different kinds of fish that inhabit the new worlds lakes and rivers, to the large monsters that the game mainly revolves around.Co-op is a major part of Monster Hunter, and it works exceptionally well. Every weapon-type can be built in different ways, so you and your squad can compliment each other by optimizing your build to control the monster, heal your teammates, or just do as much damage as possible.A minor complaint is the inability to progress through the main storyline together without jumping through the hoops of individually entering the quest to watch the cutscene, before leaving and joining your friends quest so you can play together. It befuddles me a bit, considering that later on in the game certain quests use shared cutscenes where you can even see all the player characters simultaneously.The main story/questline however is, atleast to me, a rather small part of the game as a whole as once you finish it you unlock the levelling system, which allows you to unlock new quests, items and armor pieces.If I could say one negative thing about the game it would be that a few of the monsters are very similar to eachother, not just in terms of gameplay, but also physical likeness, which is a shame, but the game makes up for it with the fourteen highly different weapon-types that all have unique attacks and combos which keeps the game interesting for me even after clocking nearly 400 hours into it.Monster Hunter World is the best game I've had the privilege of playing this year, and I would like to thank the devs and community for giving me such a good experience!

author: patmarsons
review: Over 500 hours and I still only have 2 attack decos.Games good thoedit: 590 hours in and i finally have 4 attack boost decosedit: 1000 hour check-in. HR 835 and pretty much every deco i could ever want. Just waiting on Iceborne now.oh yeah game's still good

author: ```skunk3```
review: I would rate this game as neutral if I could. This is my first Monster Hunter game. At first I wasn't too impressed. There was a lot of connectivity issues and overall I do still think that the online multiplayer is needlessly tedious and annoying at times due to cutscenes that are required to be seen before you can join someone else's quest or someone else joins yours. (This is only for new quests not done yet, story mode stuff.) I just wish that it was a lot easier to party up with people and be together all of the time instead of having to party up, disband, party up again, disband, over and over and over again. Also, randoms can be very good or very stupid. It's definitely best to play in a party of four with your friends rather than relying on randoms. Pros:- the graphics are awesome- the sound is very good as well- pretty 'epic' fights- large variety of weapons to use for lots of different play styles- game runs quite smooth if you have the hardware to run it properly- Palicos are super cute- it's cool to see two or more monsters fighting each other- the game seems pretty well optimized for PC, but then again I use a controller- no mandatory day one DLC crap necessary to enjoy the gameCons:- the game is very grindy, so if grinding out materials isn't your thing, this game isn't for you because you WILL spend a lot of time doing the same things over and over and over again- many things in the game are not explained very well- while the combat isn't terrible, it's not good either... you basically just do the same things over and over while rolling / dodging - huge leap in difficulty after you hit high rank- playing solo feels really boring, at least for me... although it seems far easier than playing multiplayer -monster AI sometimes doesn't make any sense-normal "aggro" systems in most games is totally different in this game-having to sharpen weapons in battle (even hammers!) is annoying and stupid-the amount of time it takes to use items in battle - like potions, etc - is ridiculous and often leads to deaths-some game mechanics feel way more random than they should be, like mounting monsters-unless you grind a lot, you're never going to have enough money or materials to craft what you need- the storyline is stupid, but who really cares?- while "friendly fire" isn't on in the sense that you can damage each other, friendly hits do often cancel your own attacks and bring you out of a charged attack, which is super annoying, especially with 4 players- damage seems inconsistent. sometimes you take very little damage and other times you can get hit with something that kills you in one shot if you're not at max HP. - many weapons feel very slow and it is quite easy to miss a LOT of attacks- getting stunned/dazed lasts a long time and can easily result in you getting killed- always running out of stamina gets really annoying- enemy monsters are damage sponges that have what seems to be a billion HP - without resorting to the internet for information, it can be very hard to find certain items or to unlock certain quests because you get little to no info in the game- lots of "Leeroy Jenkins" type people in multiplayer- monsters always running away in battle and having to chase after them several times gets annoying AF- you can't cancel certain attacks in the middle of attacking and instead of have to watch and wait as your character swings their weapon around like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and the animation is finished- not being able to do certain things multiplayer, like go on Grimalkyne quests and whatnot (the stuff only shows up for the party leader)- can't quickly and easily join hosted quests/optionals/events with a friend... you basically HAVE TO chat and both join the same thing at the same time, hopefully before the player list fills up- always being low on money (crafting higher rank gear and weapons costs a ton of money)- the Melder makes no sense at allOverall I'd say that there's a bunch of annoying aspects of the game (IMHO) but overall the game isn't bad, but the bad/annoying aspects of it outweigh the good. If you're into grindy cooperative stuff and have 3 friends to play with and don't mind using the internet for info so you can powerlevel your way through the game and grind out all your materials, it's not so bad.

author: Ava Sans Frontières
review: It is with a heavy heart that I rate this game negatively. For I absolutely love it.I purchased it back on PS, and have been a fan since.Why a negative rating then?Well, for one clear reason. The game crashes randomly, a lot. I get the crash known as ERR12, which tells me that my graphics drivers have crashed. This is the same crash that reviewers got prior to launch, and the same crash that Capcom said they had fixed.However, it has not been fixed. I have done absolutely everything on my part to make sure that I wasn't the cause, but I am not. Everything is pristinely updated, every rumored fix and analysis has been made. And the graphics driver itself doesn't even crash - add that my rig is more than capable of handling the game (and it does run beautifully when it does).No; this is simply the game shutting down. And I can turn it right back up. Which, of course wouldn't be a problem except for the progress lost. Now I have completed the game, albeit an uphill battle against the ERR12 - but I have grown so jaded by it that I have to say; it is borderline unplayable. Every single hunt is done in fear of losing all progress. The game is not fun, when all you think about is "Ah I just got this rare material, I hope I don't crash". And all joy is absolutely sucked out of you when it then does crash, just as you're about to kill a monster or have collected particularly good materials.And when you're playing with friends, neither is it particularly a happy occassion to have to say "all right guys, I crashed, we have to restart" over and over.I also happen to know I am not the only one getting this recurring, random crash.So developers, please. I beg of you, fix this problem with your game. I have heard absolutely nothing from you. Be transparent. I love this game, and I want to play so many thousand hours if possible. But not in this state.And this is why, I have to rate the game negatively. I love it, but it is borderline unplayable.

author: Snootles
review: Pro: Monster Hunter on PC, finally. No more peering at a small DS screen. This is the biggest reason for the thumbs up.Con: Why they changed this is beyond me. If you're getting this game so you can co-op with someone be aware. You cannot co-op the main storyline together. It will tell you that you haven't progressed far enough in the storyline as to be able to play together. It is based off which cutscenes you have watched. This was a huge let down for me and my player 2.Personal con: It's nothing like MH portable 3rd HD which is my personal favourite. It for sure has the stronger online/co-op experience.Edit: there is a semi work around for co-op through the storyline. You both have to watch all the cutscenes leading up to the fight with a monster. When you can shoot an SOS flare, one player has to back out and join the other. May not always work.

author: ttv/The_Jedi
review: I've put around 140 hrs into the game, and I'm still discovering new things. So off rip the game gets a recommend from me. There is some issues with disconnects from time to time, but 95% of the time I dont have any major issues at all. Monsters are challenging, and continue to be so even in the late stages of the game. There's a few things that could really use some PC optimizations like the menus, you cant click back from the menus you have to manually hit the back button every time. The item process is a little choppy as well because of this. All in all these are minor issues and once you get used to them dont hinder play at all. The dev team seems to be very responsive as well, so if there are any major issues with the game I'm sure they will be patched. If you like quality 3rd person co-op monster hunting games, this is the one for you. GJ Capcom.

author: Moose Poops
review: Addictive gameplay, beautiful graphics, and epic monster battles. And hardly any complaints. I have no idea what people are on about in this game. The servers are fine, people!Only cons- Can't pause even when playing solo.- You'll have to play this game for a while to get used to the complicated control system.

author: 𝓂𝒶𝒾𝒹
review: This review is written as of when I have well over 300+ hours in Monster Hunter World. Coming from the perspective of a veteran player that used to clock well over 500+ hours in Monster Hunter Freedom Unite and reached 2G/G2, I feel like there's a lot of things this game does right and better than the predecessors, but it still has some minor flaws. I am not going to be covering what the game is about and such, you are better off reading other reviews. I will be covering the differences between World and its predecessors. Could it use some improvements? Yes!!! The game will definitely bore some players like myself after a while because while updates are happening, the small pool of monsters will bore a lot of people, leaving them to move onto MHGU until World either updates itself and add a major expansion or players will casually hop on to check on new updates. I currently play both MHGU and World right now, and I love both equally, but there are some things World does that simply frustrates me with it’s lazy weapon designs and horribly implemented concepts such as Slingers, which you all know I hate by this point. I would rate World as a 8/10, while not a perfect game, it does a lot of things right that the series needed to advance itself and cater to newer audiences. I hope you find my review helpful.

author: JW
review: This is my first foray into the Monster Hunter series like I'm sure is the case with many players of this game, and I have to say... I'm hooked.The quality of gameplay is top-notch, rivaling any action-rpg past or present to my knowledge. The story is pretty threadbare, but it's neat that it is actually about the monsters, and does what it ought to. It runs brilliantly if you have the hardware to support it, though my own hardware's showing signs of aging, with my CPU being a 4790k. I do have a RTX 2070 though, and it runs very smoothly for me.I just can not recommend this game enough. Learn the quirks of combat, take in your surroundings, learn the monsters abilities, and find those one or two weapon types that speak to you... I don't think you'll regret it.If Capcom can continue to keep up the steady stream of new and engaging content, with a community tilt that keeps players active and participating, I think they have something truly special on their hands that will serve as a big breakthrough for the series.... garnering new and committed fans to this long-going, and well-beloved franchise.5/5

author: Eurykins
review: ***Take the NEGATIVE comments with a grain of salt. The DC issues have been widely noted/affected by the STEAM CLIENT CHAT, as opposed to the game server's itself. I highly doubt that people have bothered updating/attempting to fix the issues after posting up their negative comments, and the vast majority of the "complaints" were based around DC'ing and such. Fix (of sorts) for the Multiplayer DC: Secondary notion/option: > Personally, the -tcp one is the one that worked for me. Kicked off the new Steam chat client in lieu of the older version, and I've had a DC once in a blue moon since then. Works far better than not doing so.My thoughts on the game:This was my first Monster Hunter game I've ever played. I was super excited to try it out on the PC port, and, despite my pc being extremely behind on specs (CanIRunIt actually noted my computer as being unable to play the game at all), I have found this game to be amazing.Yes, I have to run it on lower graphics/specs, but it makes the combat basically 100% smooth (or as smooth as you could hope from an underspec'd computer), which will honestly make or break the game entirely. I should know- the frustration of the intial fighting fps drops almost actually caused me to put the game down and walk away from it. So I fine-tuned down the settings until I had a smooth combat/frames while playing, and that made ALL of the difference between having a frustrating time while playing the game and having a blast. I also run the game on mouse/keyboard, and once you change a few keybinds, it doesn't feel nearly as clunky as the default settings and actually makes for decent gameplay experience. Solo is fun. Multiplayer even moreso, assuming people are working as a TEAM and not purposefully hindering each other (IE. constantly smacking another teammate out of their combos, as teammates's attacks CAN hit (though doesn't really do much damage as far as I can tell) and can cause interrupts), but I've not really had much issue since I rarely do any pugging/public partying personally. Monster hunts are dynamic, and the amount of craziness that can ensue when multiple large monsters come into conflict during a hunt can instantly turn an "easy hunt" into a fiesta. Status effects, elements, weaponry, and even the sheer terrain can also play huge factors during the fights, which pulls you into the fight and beckons you to be constantly aware of your surroundings and how you approach each situation. Storyline is not necessarily the shining point of this game, but I wouldn't expect it to be so in this sort of game. You're here for the HUNTS, the CAPTURING/KILLING, and TRACKING of monsters. Storyline is something that can be expected to be on the backburners when the combat system, item gathering/looting, and crafting systems/trees are to be held in higher regards and importance in a game like this. TL;DR: Its combat system and the entire hunting of monsters is executed very well. Story isn't great, but not really the reason in picking up this game to begin with IMO. Multiplayer is great, and the fix has worked fantastically well. If you want to play the game to play it because you want to hunt monsters, then get the game. It is amazing.9/10 (Good storyline would have bumped it up to a 10 for me.)

author: HOLYONE
review: This is my first exposure to the series, and I must say I'm highly impressed. The world feels like a living eco system, and has beautfiul areas at max settings. The combat is varied, as not only do the 14 different weapon types have seperate animations, they have their own set of combos as well. This makes each type of weapon play in unqiue ways, which makes the system always feel fresh. The premise is simple, but their are many intricacies in the gameplay that give it depth.

author: Jinxykins
review: Do you like obnoxiously-designed menu systems?Do you get excited over unintuitive user interfaces and controls?Do you crave frequent disconnects and connection issues?Don't you just wish you could buy a game in hopes of playing with friends, only to find out that your friend can't join you in story-based quests because of cutscenes or being on the same quest somehow makes you ineligible to join for the same damn quest?Well, ho boy, do I have the game for you!We got your frequent disconnects.We got your obnoxious UI design.We even got arbitrary reasons why you can't progress the quests at the same time with friends.Hell, we'll even toss in some crappy DRM for the low, low price of a AAA title./sarcasmIn all honesty, this game would be a lot better if it didn't seem like the UI and Co-op design was made by a first-year college game design student with a C- GPA.If you purchase it now, be aware of the problems you are inhereting with it.Edit: I will be re-evaluating this review once Capcom fixes the online issues and PC controls.

author: El Papà
review: (I've played all handheld MH games since MHF on PSP. 600+ hours)It's definitely a huge "level up" from the previous games. Fighting is a lot smoother, especially with ranged weapons, map design is awesome and graphics are of course top notch, with 70 fps on a gtx 1060 (high). Unfortunately a few things have been dumbed down(easier, less time consuming/grindy), like gathering and quest preparation. But that's not a big deal, since it has the same charm as the previous installations.A big minus point is the multiplayer system. They should've stuck wholly with the old system of SP and MP separated or to make a new system from scratch and not mix things up like they did.4 player per quest in a session of up to 16 people who can only see themselves in the "Gathering hall".. Where nobody goes. It's still like singleplayer, but with invisible coop friends in the lobby who can't join you on every quest.Quite a few quests have cutscenes, which disables coop for until the cutscene has been completed.Denuvo is also a bummer... But what can you do? (yeah yeah boycott.. But I made an exception on this game) Probably some people of the higher management have decided on this.There are also some minor bugs with server connectivity/stability. But otherwise, very solid game.Definitely recommended for fans of the previous games.Quite a few friends of mine who are new to the series love it! But it's not for everyone of course.

author: Pherros
review: As a long time Monster Hunter fan/player since Monster Hunter Tri; I wholeheartedly reccommend MH:W! It still keeps the fun and engaging battle mechanics of the old games, while also adding a plethora of new features & quality of life changes. Anybody who is a long time MH player will immediately notice how everything is more convenient. Whetstone's, Pickaxes, and Bug nets are all now an infinite use items that are always within your inventory, so no need to buy or collect them.  No more having to paintball monsters to track them; now, they have added a new "scoutfly" system which helps with material/monster tracking through interacting with footprints/markings. Cool drinks are only needed in specific situations, and no longer needed for the entire zone. (It appears that Hot drinks may have been removed from the game). Every weapon has a new ability or functionality introduced. This is also the most beginner friendly/forgiving of all the other games in the series; But that's not neccessarily a bad thing. But, I do hope they would bring back the Leviathan hunts, G-Rank missions, Armor transmogs, and underwater battles with the next game.All in all 10/10 Capcom. This one of the few IP's you haven't tarnished yet. And THANK YOU for not adding loot boxes & "cancerous" microtransactions.

author: ₰Lin₰
review: Don't get me wrong. I'm going to naturally vote yes for this game because I love both Monster Hunter World: Iceborne and the series of Monster Hunter as a whole but let's mention the elephant in the room first before I go into the review.The Iceborne update caused a lot of problems for PC users. Frequent crashes, lowered performance, increased GPU power being taken, many players rendered unable to even be able to run the game. I actually didn't experience this issue until the second update into Iceborne where they changed their anti-cheat, where I started seeing very noticeable performance plummeting. With that said, I could almost not recommend this game.But, these are things you can get past or fix if you're interested in Monster Hunter. As a series veteran (Playing since Monster Hunter Tri on the Wii) this game goes above and beyond what is expected of a future title of a franchise whilst adding new improvements to the game and numerous quality of life changes to make the game more accessible to new fans while keeping it fresh and interesting for fans of old.If you don't know the gameplay of Monster Hunter, why are you here? Of all the places to learn about what a game is, a buried Steam Review probably isn't the best place. But I'll run through it anyway. Monster Hunter is a game series where you hunt monsters and slay them (or capture them) and use materials you've acquired from their body to craft new armor and weapons for you to use. Gradually you grow stronger and stronger and tackle more difficult monsters as you rise to the top, perfecting your skills as a hunter and making your ideal armor set. The gameplay loop can be difficult and slow for new players, as hunting time varies depending on how familiar you are with the game.Hunts can range anywhere from 10-30 minutes or even a full 50 minutes if you're really struggling. The true appeal of the game for me personally is gradually learning a monsters behaviors and patterns and punishing each attack you're familiar with using one of your own devastating attacks from a large repertoire of moves each of the 13 weapons has. The thrill of the hunt comes from mastering your opponent and being duly rewarded for your effort, or challenging yourself in the Arena to try and slay a monster in record times.The levels in Monster Hunter World: Iceborne are huge, vast and expansive ecosystems full of thriving life. Your first time in any of the gigantic areas of the game may leave you lost for long periods of time until you adjust yourself to your surroundings. But once you do, even when you grow accustomed to what each level has to offer, you appreciate how beautifully developed they all are.With all that said, it's all within stark contrast of MonHun's older games, where each level had quadrant-like areas that had to be loaded separately and weren't all that appealing to the eyes. I can still go back to such hunting grounds and love them for what they are, but if you were to ask me which I prefer: the Ancient Steppe in Monster Hunter Generations Ultimate or the Ancient Forest in Monster Hunter World: Iceborne,  I'm going to say the Ancient Forest.There's honestly so much more I could say about the game but I have a feeling anyone whose reading this has already moved along so I'll finish up here. If you have an interest in difficult fights, expansive worlds building your own character and crafting your own armor and weapons, look up a video and make the decision. I personally think it's well worth your money and time if you're into this kind of game.

author: a.m Kunkka-chan
review: As a long time veteran of the series, this one is hands down the most new player friendly. That does not mean that it is easy, it has a lot of the quality of life changes that really help the game. I whole heartedly that anyone who has considered playing a Monster Hunter game that this is the best one to start with.Its not without its flaws, there are some truely amazing weapon designs the embody each monster and uniqueness. on the other hand there are some lack luster bland samey weapons that populate more than the fair share than they should. The armor on the other hand, you feel the theme of each monster. Some designs are strange but every set tells you exactly what monster it came from. Fashion hunting is not that hard as well while striving for maximising Armor skills to the maximum.In conclusion, both veterans and new players alike will thoroughly enjoy this game. It has a lot to offer and a huge dev support to make it great.

author: babycakes
review: After 300 hours in Monster Hunter World, my family and friends voiced their growing concerns that I may have a problem. I beg to differ. There is a macrocosm of a time sink in MHW. So many things are going on simultaneously; new players may be overwhelmed or turned off by the fact that you could spend hours researching/reading/understanding the various mechanics of the game in order to actually play it. The basic tutorial tips and tricks do not explain it all. There are extensive amounts of: objectives (bounties); item and ingredient collection; armor upgrading (for you AND your Palico sidekick); literal farming (cultivating bugs, plants, and mushrooms); item crafting (potions, powders, ammunition, traps, etc.); capturing pets; decorating your room; changing appearance; customizing food buff recipes; main story quests; optional story quests; unwritten optional quests.1) GameplayIf you love murdering animals over and over again so that you can wear their skin and organs, then this game is for you. The addictive essence of this game involves making gear to improve your build(s), theorycrafting, revising your gear, hunting for drops to craft your revisions, and then hunting some more to ensure that you are satisfied with your build. 1a) Multiplayer Contrary to what the game title suggests, MHW is not open world. There are huge maps, but hunts are instance based, and multiplayer is sort of like that too. There is a max of 16 players allowed in an Online Session. I’ve spent countless hours both soloing and in groups. (The online connection has greatly improved since the game’s release.) While multiplayer usually enhances the hunting experience, I feel that MHW is best played with actual friends. Firing SOS flares is a mixed bag: I’ll either get a pro, or I’ll end up babysitting the troll picking flowers on the other side of the map during a 15-minute timed instance. Occasionally, I’ll get someone who’s actually just… normal. Guild cards are an interesting concept. You get to design your own hunter-approved business card detailing your equipment and other gameplay statistics. You can trade these with other players, and I frequently customize mine after changing my gear or after unlocking a new background. However, Guild cards do not act as the in-game friends list. This is a big missed opportunity! Guild cards should allow you to see if that player is on and allow you to join their Online Session. Currently, guild cards allow you to inspect the player’s gameplay statistics and their Steam profile page. I would much prefer joining that person’s Online Session within the game, so I can keep my Steam friends list uncluttered. 1b) Weapons Weapon variety is quite amazing in this game. So far, I’ve learned 5 different weapons. Each time rejuvenated my interest. I’d watch at least 20 minutes of YouTube videos each and take detailed notes for each weapon LOL. Certain weapons deal specific categories of damage, which in turn affect monsters in different ways. With each weapon being drastically different from each other, it was almost like hitting the restart button and learning the game all over again. The weapons have unique sets of moves, yet they remain balanced. For instance, larger weapons which do more damage per hit often sacrifice mobility and/or ease of use. Weapons with top tier damage output are often the most technically demanding. And then there are weapons which are easy to use, but difficult to master.1c) Limited time raidsThe current (and first for PC) limited event is the Kulve Taroth raid. In MHW fashion, it took me 10 hours of experience and 2 different explanation videos to figure out how to maximize the hunt and earn the best drops. Still, I find it very enjoyable and well done.2) Character CreationDesigning a character is one of my favorite things to do ever. If you go through my screen shot history, you will see that my hunter has undergone routine change of hair color and clothing dyes. My only critique would be that I expected a higher level of customization for a PC MMO, i.e. change body type, height, facial structure - similar to Saint’s Row 3 or something. I enjoyed the preset noses and mouths, but I wasn’t 100% satisfied with the the eyes, jawlines, and brows. I was also underwhelmed by the selection of hairstyles. Having male and female hunters share the same hair styles is rather lazy. Like is anyone really going to put the Admiral hairstyle, sideburns and all, on their female avatar?3) GraphicsGood, but I expected better. Like others, I was disappointed that the detailed graphics in the character creation aren’t consistent with the in-game graphics. On the first day, I took screen shots and saw how blurry it was on the character model in the sunlight. Nevertheless, there is a lot of detail in the environment and background. Animations are also superb, from your hunter’s moves to monster’s attacks. 4) ControlsCapcom spent a decent amount of time optimizing MHW for PC, but it feels like they neglected the controls. For starters, you CANNOT REBIND GAMEPAD BUTTONS. That personally grinds my gears because I consider that the hallmark of a lazy port (I’m looking at you, Bayonetta). I can’t execute certain attacks properly if I don’t like what the Y button (Xbox One controller) is bound to, so gamepad’s out the window for me. While I am used to playing MHW with keyboard and mouse, that’s not perfect either. There should be a permanent hotkey bar when using keyboard and mouse. It wouldn’t need to look or behave differently than it already does except prevent it from fading away. Players who do not want it to be permanent should be able to uncheck that setting in Options. Having to hit an F1 - F4 key and then a number key is not a big deal when you need to tap whetstone or HP potion. But it can be absolutely dreadful when you're laying down traps and tranquilizer bombs. Sometimes in the heat of battle, it can be stressful hitting the correct item. To this day, I will STILL accidentally waste items because of this. Further annoyances include keyboard and mouse getting the short end of the stick because they didn't program really small but significant details from the gamepad to keyboard. For example, you can fire your sheathed Light Bowgun without reloading on the gamepad: simply press RT (Shoot/Fire). However, pressing Right Click (Shoot/Fire) does nothing. You want to expertly dodge and shoot the monster in the face? Too bad; you get to reload and then get knocked over by its next attack! 5) Misc Complaints- The Handler (your storyline partner) is so obnoxiously cheerful that it’s unsettling.- For some reason, I find that the male character model looks extremely old, even at the youngest age setting.- Why are 95% of the armors so HIDEOUS that you wouldn’t want to wear them? I get this isn’t frou frou anime wonderland, but it is extremely difficult to find combinations of gear that have optimal skills *and* look good. - Related to that, the inability to fully customize armor pigments drive me insane. WHY MUST ONLY THIS MINISCULE BELT BUCKLE DETAIL CHANGE COLOR? This further decreases your chances of making useful AND good looking equipment!- Why don’t you see other players in your Online Session on every floor of town? They only appear on the 4th floor, but I’m never up there unless there is an event and you have to talk to a specific NPC up there. - Why is there no fall damage, but there is friendly fire? You should definitely die when you jump 3 stories off the map. - New gear from collaborations comes more slowly than anticipated. Maybe there are regional sync/licensing issues.
