review: 養生獵人，想肝就肝( ￣▽￣)σ不得不說環境生物是一個亮點，偶爾釣釣魚什麼的也挺不錯。連機體驗可以說很不錯了，從剛發售那時候極其蛋疼的高峰期掉線到最近幾乎不掉線，甚至並不需要加速器（我一直用電腦連手機熱點玩的一點壓力都沒有2333）玩，還是值得好評的。畫面就不說了，各人有各人的看法吧，經歷了PSP畫質的我對於世界的畫質還是很欣慰的（雖然我的顯卡是真的辣雞）。期待後面出的新怪以及新活動(๑•̀ㅁ•́ฅ)

author: TacoGumPrime
review: Reminds me of Club Penguin.

author: LAXY
review: Updated for IceborneYeah, you know what, the main game and Iceborne launched a pile of trash. Weird errors, certain processors not supported, and just an overall increase in CPU usage for no reason. I nearly stopped playing just because the stuttering on Iceborne content was so terrible.Now these issues are (at least mostly) fixed, and they are consistently working on fixes and putting in the crossover events from PS4, it's clear they want this to be a good port. Title updates have FINALLY been matched with consoles as well, so PC players don't have to wait a month or 2 for monsters to come out.The multiplayer can still be hard for people to understand, there's a dumb stipulation where you can't join a story quest until the host as well as anyone wanting to join the quest has watched the cutscene on their own time.ALL THIS BEING SAID, ♥♥♥♥ is this game fun. I mean really fun. Iceborne REALLY kicked up the difficulty later on AND added a lot more monsters. Essentially double the roster.There's no better feeling than just getting together with friends, goofing around, hunting some big-ass monsters, stealing your Insect Glaive main friends mounts with a hammer, customizing your shoutouts to be goofy, the list goes on. The flow in this game is great, and the animations, the scale of the monsters, they all add to the experience.Some of the late-game weapon designs have actually been improved in Iceborne as well, there are some beautiful weapon designs in this game, but I still think there should have been more.So yeah, it's a bit buggy, and a CPU hog, but those can be fixed. The gameplay, which is something that should have been solid from the start, is damn solid. Iceborne added a lot of much needed content to the game as well, so if you're enjoying the base game, feel free to pick up Iceborne for the other half of the game.10/10, would introduce friends to my favourite series again. Now remove denuvo.

author: 1L1NC4
review: Long time MHW fan. Online issues are a bit of a drag, but haven't stopped me from pumping more hours into this game than I've worked in the last two weeks. A couple of tips to help your enjoyment.Don't bother with matchmade lobbies until they're fixed. They're mostly pointless anyway. Create a lobby and search for SOS flares when you want to play with randoms. If you're playing with friends, create a lobby, don't bother making it private unless you want to restrict a friend from joining. If you search for a lobby and there's none to be seen, someone will need to make a new lobby to join. If someone is having difficulty joining a quest, just drop the quest and re-take it. This can result in some resources being lost, like a use of an investigation or a voucher, but by the time that's a factor, you'll need to take that into account.Vouchers double the money you get from a quest, do them in single player early on, later on they aren't as important as  you can use the bandit mantle to generate more money faster with the right weapons.Lastly, if you're going to play with KB+M, expect some weirdness, you're likely going to need to rebind controls, especially if you play shooters or anything else. I highly recomment steam controller or another controller if you have it. If you like Monster Hunter and don't have it on another platform, this game is a mustbuy. If you haven't played Monster Hunter but are interested in the series, this game is a fanstastic jump on point. If you plan to play this game multiplayer, keep in mind that certain aspects of the story quest lock other players out. Like players not able to join prior to seeing a cutscene, players not able to join until they have completed said quest. It's a lot of frustration if you go into it blind. Just keep in mind you're going to have to play alone(or with randoms or a friend that's ahead). Once you hit high rank, the quests require you see the cutscene, but you can then abandon and join your friends and progress together, it's a bit of a work around, but it's acceptable for an otherwise solid game.I have difficulty not recommending a game that I've put 86 hours into and expect to be in my top 5 most played games in a year.

If you are a solo player, this gives you no problem at all, else, wait until they finish fixing the connection.Story: 6/10Gameplay: 8.5/10Audio: 8/10Replayability: 10/10

author: Nova
review: It may have a few connection errors here and there and also some frame drops in particular battles, but it's still a whole lot of fun to play.So as it comes to my opinion I'd recommend this game especially for Monster Hunter fans but also for franchise newbies like myself.

author: Yono
review: I really do not understand the negative reviews at all.First of all, let me preface this by saying this is one of the best games I've ever played. It's absolutely the best Monster Hunter game in the series, it strips away TONS of the tedious, frustrating things about the old games. It feels way smoother to play, all the weapons are more interesting, hitboxes are better, monsters feel more fair and telegraph their attacks better, item management is way smoother, gathering is less tedious, the environment is far more immersive, grinding is less RNG based and more skill based since you now have options to do hard challenge quests for easier grind, armor sets are simplified... It's truly an astounding game and I would recommend it to anyone.As for the negative reviews this game is getting, to address the complaints.--It is not optimized badly at all. There is one graphic setting, Volume Rendering Quality, that needs to be turned off, however. This setting covers the game in a blue haze that makes it look way worse, and also causes tons of performance issues. Leaving this setting on by default was a mistake, however, after turning this off, I run the game at max settings without ever dropping frames on my GTX 1080. This isn't an easy game to max, that doesn't mean its badly optimized when the game looks so amazing. --The online in its current state, yes, has some problems. However, they are greatly exaggerated. I think the biggest reason for the sheer volume of negative reviews is the fact that at the current moment, the auto-matchmaking button isn't functional at all, and always returns an error message (at least for me). HOWEVER, playing with friends works ok, SOS flares work perfectly, the lobby search function works ok, joining lobbies via code is 100% failproof. There are some disconnection issues, but not enough currently to hamper the experience for me. I can understand people's frustration towards this, however, to bombard the game with negative reviews for it just makes absolutely no sense to me considering I have seen games with FAR worse connection issues have review scores above 90%.This game is 100% worth your time and money for me, and that's why I'm leaving a positive review.

author: Little Light
review: **October 2018 updateThe game is getting better with patches to fix the bugs and events to catch up to the console versions. You'll still find a lot of negative whiny reviews that make up BS until proven wrong or those who will simply make a negative review because maybe they didnt get one thing they felt entitled to. I suggest avoiding those for more realistic expectations.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------You'll find plenty of reviews telling you what the game lacks and has issues with, so I'll try not to write a book on those. The game just released on PC so I'm realistic to believe there will be some issues with it, and the disconnection ones can get annoying at times, but I'm hopeful it will be resolved in time.+PhasingOne thing that does impress me is how the game phases to a single player experience should you do get disconnected. Instead of the game crashing like most other games, the other people disappear to you and your cat takes over. Not to praise it over the errors it has, but how seamless it keeps the game from ever just crashing because of them in my experience. Now if it only scaled down the creature when you end up fighting it alone. :3+GameplayShould you be lucky enough to not experience any real issues you'll find a game that will take over your social life, but the best part is you can take your friends with you. It's a mix of fast pace action, and casually collecting things you need, so a little patience helps in order to get all you need to be most effective. There ends up being a lot of things you can do back at the hub.+CombatI regret this is my first Monster Hunter experience, but I love fighting giant creatures I have no place picking a fight with and coming out successful. The controls took a little time to get used to since I use a controller and couldnt remap them, but wasn't a problem after a while. Each an every weapon has it's own unique playstyle so I'd recommend looking up any of the great guides on youtube to get the most out of them.+Other StuffThe game has a lot of little nuances to show you a lot went into it, like even just sitting in your room interacting with the pets you can collect. There's just a lot of little things to go into the most random stuff. I just feel too many people give reviews for the wrong reasons and not what reviews are actually about. If I couldnt get the game to play, I wouldn't review it till I actually could. That would be a more accurate impression imo. I think the worst kind of reviews are those that blame a game for the users own mistake, which I don't see too much here. But the ones blaming a game for not being a perfect port at launch are not realistic. There has never been a perfect launch or a perfect port right out the door. Expectations for that are too high. I'm amazed the game runs as well as it does.+Final ThoughtsThe game does have DC problems you will encounter, but if you can deal with them you'll find the game super fun. Just be patient and have realistic expectations to when stuff will be resolved. I mean for example, there's still people out there that are surprised when a Bethesda game has bugs. Most of us that have been around a while expect them and they've been making PC games forever. So who honestly expects a perfect port of the first PC Monster Hunter game without any issues? Now I'm not defending them for the stuff that doesnt work. If they don't fix them, by all means bust out your torches and pitchforks, but reasonable launch expectations are reasonable.

author: Choko
review: If you're a fan of the Monster Hunter series, this game is the golden egg we've all been waiting for. If there is a quality of life enhancement you wanted, now we have it. Many new mechanics and many new monsters to be had, it's not just the same old Rathian and Rathalos here!Currently, this "port" is struggling with server issues, which are largely a result of the staggering number of players on at once. There are some performance issues as well, but those should be ironed out soon. Take heed to the minimum/recommended specs! They're currently rather accurate as to what it takes to get a good experience.

author: [SWE]Dr Brobotnik
review: Okay, this game is what everybody who likes Monster Hunter wants, it has all the things that made the previous installments great, varied and meaingful combat, cool monsters, cool gear, and a slew of weapons, some new and some returning ones that have been given new tricks to shine with. With that out of the way, this is a port of the original PS4 version and the port, while working well enough for most players, have been suffering some issues with a large enough number of players to range in four digit number. I'm not talking about minor problems that doesn't stop you from having a good time, but rather CTD's, incomplete optimizations, FPS loss and not being able to start the game. An unofficial patch is out by now and it can be found in the Steam news.For more info on what the problems are, check the forums. Capcom have not patched it themselves yet but the game launched one day before the weekend so it's not that strange.The online funconality is also not working constantly server side, but this will most likely be fixed. I'm gonna recommend this game on the basis that is will probably work and is a terrific game, but the port has problems and if this turns you off then you may want to hold off for now and let them fix things.

author: Ferengi
review: As someone who is semi-new to the Monster Hunter universe but a veteran to PC ports and gaming alike, I'll say I am quite shocked on how many people dislike the port. The game runs perfectly for me at max settings with only a few FPS dips during "turf wars", and I assume I am just a weird person but I found the default bindings workable/good (Though I am only using the bow so prob. easier for me). I think there is a few settings I'd like to see added but nothing I can't manually disable via the files. (I think even motion blur is in there). I think the friend system is a bit wonky and I dislike not being able to share a hub with others but it's all minor things to a fun and exciting game.My PC:AMD 8300 FX OC to 4.1ghzGTX 1060 6gb (Boosted to 14gb)16GB of DDR38TB HDD/1TB SSDGame runs at about 200 FPS on average with slight dips to 60/45 FPS when too many bigger monsters are on the screen (I.E turf wars)

author: PastaPillows
review: Quick reminder to everyone complaining about the server issues: the servers on the PS4 version are also pretty awful. Give it some time; this is the most accessible Monster Hunter title out there, and their servers are overloaded right now, as expected.As far as performance, you need a good rig to handle this game, no questions asked. That said, it of course still has its issues (lightning-based elemental particles seem to really cut into the framerate) but overall, I'm enjoying this port over the PS4 version.More on performance, I'm using a good rig (Nvidia GTX 1080, Intel i7 6700k processor, 16 GB of RAM) and this game runs at a consistent 60 frames a second almost all of the time. As I said above, lightning particles seem to dip the framerate and cause it to stutter upon contact. Aside from that, the load times are significantly improved over the PS4 version, so much so that I almost find it jarring at how fast it loads. I put this game on my SSD, and because of that, the load times are cut down to about 2 to 5 seconds, compared to the PS4's 30 to 60 second load times.As far as content itself, this Monster Hunter title has overall less monsters than previous entries to Monster Hunter, but that's also because they're likely having to remake assets and animations for this game, since it looks completely different than the other titles. Because of this, expect it to be somewhat shallow in comparison. Make no mistake, there are still plenty of monsters to fight however. Additionally, this port does not have the content that the Playstation 4 has *yet*. We're likely to get free DLC such as Deviljho and etc later on, but some crossover content present in the PS4 version might be missing (aka content such as the Horizon Zero Dawn content might make it over, it might not, we'll just have to wait and see).tl;dr: The game itself is very very good, although it's missing a notable amount of monsters from the previous titles. Performance is actually very good, *if* you have the hardware to handle it. There are still some strange things about the performance though, such as lightning particle effects causing the game to stutter.

author: Wolfgand
review: Monster Hunter World is the next step in the Monster Hunter (MH) franchise and one of the best installments in the series. Although it takes some notes from the classic MH experience, it provides significant improvements in terms of making the game more accessible with maintaining the notorious difficulty. If you are new to Monster Hunter games and you are planning to buy Monster Hunter World, keep in mind that this game is mainly grinding boss battle after boss battle and retrieving their dropped materials, then repeating the battles until you obtain enough materials to craft better equipment so you can fight the next, stronger boss. If this gameplay loop does not seem like something you enjoy, I’d strongly advise against picking up this game. The fun of Monster Hunter is reflected best in its fighting, which brings to the forefront the incredibly tight combat mechanics, along with the monsters themselves. The monsters may initially seem like massive damage sponges, but once you start engaging their attack patterns, moves and behavior it becomes very clear that these bosses hit hard and hit fast, making fights thrilling and lots of fun. While World has one of the smallest monster rosters in the series, it still contains enough variety to keep players satisfied. World brings many quality of life changes to the series, cutting down a lot of the convoluted systems and making them more easy to access and manage, with the most notable examples being the skill system. Smaller changes that are still worth mentioning are eating meals, managing equipment during hunts, item management, being able to consume items during movement, and etc. For the people curious about end game, this may be the most polarizing part of the game. The end game will mostly revolve around you farming jewels to create that perfectly mixed armor set in order for you to fight new upcoming Arc Tempered Monsters. These hunts will then reward you with an even more extreme version of the original monster’s armor set. While I and many others are fine with and love the end game, it’s also understandable the disappointment of others in terms of expecting more. However, even now Capcom is working hard to improve that with interesting and fun events and collaborations, Kulve Taroth and Behemoth being more recent examples. Although I love this series and specifically this installment, it’s important to mention this game’s shortcomings. While Monster Hunter World is the biggest graphical evolution the games have ever had, it’s sad to see how uninspired and boring most of the weapons and armor sets when looking back at the old games. Although this also seems like something Capcom is slowly fixing with updates, releasing interesting and fun new armor sets as well as layered armors is something that could greatly add to the game. Another problem I have with world is the decision of making the end game grind about collecting jewels. Previous games would allow you to obtain jewels by fighting specific monsters which led to the player having much more interaction with most if not all of the Monster Roster, however in world you just keep farming tempered elder dragons over and over hoping to god you’ll get an attack jewel. Instead of this boring grind, you could have to fight specific monsters for them, such as Paoiumu, Jyuratodus, Uragaan, Radobaan or any other monsters you have very little reason to fight in late game. In summary, this is a strong staple in the series, a FANTASTIC entry point to newcomers and a clear step in the right direction for the future of the franchise. The game could also improve a bit on one of these flaws are deal breakers but rather small inconveniences. I'd recommend interested newcomers and vets pick this one up. Happy Hunting

author: Proffy
review: This game is great for single player.But for those who seek co-op sessions with their friends like me, I won't recommend this game until they fix Multiplayer.Edit: They already fixed Communication Errors. Not totally fixed but at least it happens less frequent than before. Just to be clear, I bought it for its multiplayer feature. That's why I gave it a Negative Feedback.

author: Bellona
review: So I have now beaten the main story of MHW and I believe it is now appropriate to give it a review. Before I start off, full disclosure. I have played Monster Hunter games in the past. I’ve played 70hrs of Monster Hunter 3 Ultimate on the Wii U and I’ve played 30hrs of Freedom Unite on the PPSSPP Emulator. Since enjoying those games years ago I have been eagerly anticipating a more streamlined Monster Hunter experience for a better and more powerful gaming system, namely the PC.This review will be broken up into 4 sections. The Good, The Bad, PC Performance, and a ConclusionIf you have never played a Monster Hunter game one of the best things it has going for it is its sense of progression. Over time the player feels a sense of how they have changed and adapted over the course of the game. This ranges from better and cooler looking gear to being more competent at the gameplay. While the player progresses and acquires new gear they will encounter roadblocks along the way, these are called Anjanath in LR and Nergigante and Vaal Hazak in HR (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Val Hazzak is crazy). There are two ways to move on when one reaches this point, either grind for better gear by beating up the same monster a couple of times or improve tactically. Though at a certain point new gear is a must, but there is that option if you are good enough. This rinse and repeat is essentially the game play loop. You have to like this to enjoy the game, especially the very weighty and deliberate combat similar to the Souls Series (this came out first btw).For those who have not played a Monster hunter it is not an MMO (think similar to Warframe if you have played that). At the core it is a 4 player group up hunting game. It is the best game series on the market in my opinion for this type of game play. Co-op is a must to truly enjoy this game to the fullest.The game has a lot of content in it, however I’ll come back to this point later in the review.Streamlining of game’s systems has helped out this title immensely. The game has way less tedium than the older games in the series and more emphasis on the hunting with less time spend trying to find a damned flashbug.If you like the gameplay of the Monster Hunter Series this is everything that is good about it made better. However, those people have already bought this game. I’m hoping to speak to those more on the fence, especially if you are wondering if this game is for you. I will talk about this in the conclusion.There is still tedium for things like ore mining and collecting materials this is made worse by the fact that the farming (like a garden) aspect of the game has been nerfed for some unknown bizarre reason.Finding the gems for monsters if RNGesus doesn’t look favorably on you can become terrible I know this from past Monster Hunter games, it is the same in this game, but I’ve yet to experience it.The story and its voice acting in both English and Japanese is absolutely terrible unredeemable trash. I have no idea why Capcom thought Monster Hunter needed a story. It’s terrible and it interferes with game play as you have to back out of the mission and restart just to do a story missions with friends.THE CUTSCENES ARE UNSKIPPABLE. WHY DO I HAVE TO WATCH UNCANNY VALLEY TALK TO UNCANNY VALLEY x12. I JUST WANT TO FIGHT MONSTERS!There is a lot of content in this game compared to other AAA games on the market, but compared to other Monster Hunter games it is shorter, While I understand why as they can’t just add all the old monsters as they need an HD revamp. Currently I feel a bit lonely without some classics like Tigrex, Brachydios, and Lagiacrus (I need water combat as an expansion plz). Without G-Rank the game is shorter than other Monster Hunter games so make of that what you will.So I will start with if you have anything less than a GTX 9-- series card or an Intel i7 6---k CPU you are SOL. These are pretty much needed to get 1080p 60fps. I have a GTX 1080 and an i7 8700k and I still get frame drops in the Teostra fight. This game needs a performance patch badly, some particle effects just wreck the game. Additionally, the new Nvidia drivers for the game are completely busted (398.82) roll back to the June drivers (398.36) you’ll gain 30fps. The game also has motion blur that is terrible, disabling the ingame anti aliasing makes it much better but the effect is still there. This needs to be patched. Finally the game is currently plagued with disconnects and its terrible I don’t get them often but some of my friends do. It’s really a mixed bag. I’ve heard mixed things about KB+M, but I don’t know as I use a controller and it works really well. The game is designed for it from the ground up. So overall the performance is just passable. (this is all as of 8/15/18)Luckily with the freedom of the PC in the future there may be more we can do with configuration and graphics stuff through modding ect. But that remains to be seen, except for a performance mod by the same guy that made FAR mod for Nier: Automata.If you love Monster Hunter and want to play it in glorious HD at 60fps you already bought the game. Personally if you are on the fence, go watch some gameplay and see if the core gameplay loop interests you. I wouldn’t recommend this game to everyone, but I would recommend everyone at least check it out as you may find it to be to your liking. Also the game will be receiving 4 new monster like the PS4 and XBONE version in the near future so Capcom seems committed to wanting the players to stick around likely because they will make an expansion with G-Rank, so keep that in mind as well.I hope this was helpful. If you have any questions feel free to ask in the comments. I will update this review in the future if the state of the game changes drastically with regards to performance and content.

author: CocoBunHun
review: Oh boy;OkayPlaying alone is challenging once your hero rating goes up, not impossible but challenging. Preparation is key. Farm your bounties; investigations, mats etc, until you have your armor nice enough for the fight. If you just blaze through the main quest it will make it impossible. Same goes for weapons. I have been having fun.Downside was the connection issues at first. I alt tab a lot and that caused my game to disconnect from multiplayer. After disabling the steam (friends) overlay and setting my display to windowed fullscreen, the issues stopped for the most part.Another thing I have noticed is a lag when you have four people and two monsters going at it. They start to skip around the map. I have no problem with the graphics except the can randomly be low res on some structures. Overall, great game. The story is progressing nicely but it's kind of short (thank you google). Combat is kinda clunky with ranged weapons (so I went with hammer) and it's nice when you play with other ppl. You can almost always find what quest you're on in the SOS section to play with randoms. Plenty of armor and armor designs; currently dressed up as a unicorn.

author: JesterChaotic
review: Server issues are being worked on and most problems are gone. 3 out of 4 comments agree. Happy to be able to play with friends now....now I just need friends.

author: John
review: I've been playing Monster Hunter  since first gen and I must say, this game is really enjoyable. Although I do wish they optimize the game for older systems since the CPU usage is always at 100% for me and I really hope they would add underwater combat back even though at this point, it would be a pipe dream...

author: Grumpette
review: TLDR: Great fun if you have friends that also play, but get it on sale, it's way overpriced at USD$60.  Overall this was a let-down, a stick with no carrot.I wish there was a neutral rather than a yes or no vote as I'm really mixed on this one.  Giving it a thumbs up rather than down simply due to the fact that playing it through once  solo definitely was a tonne of fun but I just felt thoroughly disappointed when I got to the "end".I was gifted this by a friend, we were meant to play it together but mostly weren't able to due to the port issues at launch.  These initial issues, constantly being disconnected were a real game breaker.  The amount of time it took to get that fixed was sad; especially considering that the PC release was postponed significantly to iron out such issues, and this was a HUGE one.  It was eventually (mostly) rectified but it came way too late since the population by then had already left in frustration at not being able to play an MMO as an actual MMO.edit: Tried coming back to the game for Icebourne but feel completely lost.In the end I found it's easier to get things done solo than in a party with others anyway, again killing the MMO aspect of the game.  Generally playing with open squad someone joined, got insta-carted and spoiled the rewards and or killed the mission completely despite the fact that I almost had the monster dead before they arrived, awesome bro thanks for nothing!  On the other hand, your trusty Palico when armed with the right tools for the fight is actually more reliable than a teammate 130% of the time.The length of the main questline, left me feeling I'd missed something, I wanted more, way more!  The monster animations and artwork in the game are REALLY incredible, the creation of the world is SUPER immersive and it definitely has that going for it.  However once the main questline is done and you hit HR100 there really doesn't seem any point in continuing any further.  Yes you can grind for more parts to make more gear but for what?  New content coming in another 6 months?   The combat just isn't that replayable, especially when it's better played solo, that totally killed it for me.  I found the rare house pets, I got all the food bits, I did 92% of the achievements but I just can't keep going, I wanted an MMO, this failed to deliver.edit: Tried coming back to this for Iceborne but so many new gear sets I have no idea what's going on anymore.  Like new gear but no new content...not sure where to begin.

author: Smingleigh
review: I'm really enjoying this game. I picked up the trail of the Pukei-Pukei I was hunting, but found an Anjanath (think T-Rex) footprint right in the middleof the trail. I advanced cautiously, and found my prey already locked in battle with the Anjanath that towered over it. I crept forward, wanting to see how the fight was progressing before deciding whether or not to join the fray or find another target, when a furious Great Jagras steamed right into the back of me, getting the attention of the battling monsters. A rolling, tumbling, chaotic four-way fight ensued. During this a pack of regular Jagras weighed in, but most of them were stamped to paste by the Anjanath in short order. I think at one point I rode the top of the Great Jagras, stabbing it in the head. I know I cut off the Pukei-Pukei's tail. The last thing I saw was the Great Jagras eating the last of its kin to bulk up, mid-fight, but the Anjanath, finally tiring of the fragile Hunter, chomped me to unconsciousness. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to get back into the field to see if the Pukei-Pukei survived. If it did, I plan to correct that situation, promptly.

author: cheshire.panther
review: OK, was seriously busy playing the game, but it's time to offset this surge of negative reviews from whiny ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.This is nerly perfect PC port, hands down the best series in the universe and one of the best if not the best game in the series. I had somewhere around 1000+ play hours of 2G/3G combined and I dont regret every one of them. It's impossible to explain what makes MH so good - the thrill, the insane difficulty curve, the fact that you have to actually learn how your weapons and enemies work rather than grind levels - but at some point it just clicks and you can never go back.

author: nukiies
review: Newest Review and Last Update:After, at this point, nearly 200 hours of gameplay, I think I can finally validate a well written review for this game.I have been playing Monster Hunter since Tri, about 8 years ago. I have played Tri, 3U, 4U and Generations. This review, if mentioning the older games, will be in referance to those.Monster Hunter World is a great game to start at if you are new to the series. It revamped some things, which makes the game slightly less complicated than previous games. That being said, there is still alot to learn as a beginner. The game is somewhat cluttered. Theres a ton of little things to learn and remember, which veterans take for granted in just knowing from experience. I feel, though, that any beginner can easily pick these things up with time and practice.As far as this game being "too easy", I think it's relative. I felt this game to be easier than previous games, but it could also be because I am used to the delayed movements, constant need to roll and dodge, repeated movesets of certain monsters that was used in previous games, and the million little things to remember when it came to items, armor, weapons, the canteen, etc. I think its an awesome game, and I think its a fun challenge that will be fulfilling and rewarding for new and old players.Despite all this, Monster Hunter was always a game I hesitated to confidently recommend to others. It isn't because it's a bad game; it's a wonderful game. It is because it *can* be a grindfest, and I know that is a deal breaker for some people. I personally don't mind that about it at all, but after thinking about it for a bit, came to a conclusion of who I think would like that aspect:If you are the kind of person that does not mind repetative actions, sometimes tediously, as long as its to reach a goal (game advancement, new armor or new weapons), then you will probably love this game.If you are the kind of person that does not like repeating things of any kind, irregardless of what it brings you, then I think this game would annoy the crap out of you. Lol!Monster Hunter has always been known as a game that was a grind in order to get materials for weapons and armor, and for the people that played the game, *thats why they played it*. Part of the joy of Monster Hunter was the work and effort it took in order to FINALLY get that piece of armor and that weapon you've been wanting for ages. If that is you... buy this game. Haha. (Although, I will admit, advancing in the weapon tree is much easier than previous titles IMO, but it still provides a nice challenge!)As for other things in this game, the graphics are beautiful (to me), but keep in mind this game is a port. The movements are delayed, as if using a controller, even if you are using a mouse and keyboard. Using multiplayer can be finnicky; people will drop from sessions or quests from time to time, and seeing other peoples quests to join sometimes can be a challenge. But, after playing many many multiplayer missions, I found the problems to be few. This game can also be demanding of your computer, but my computer isn't new and runs just fine, despite a little lag.All in all, I love this game. I love the grind, I love the corniness, I love the outrageous armor that makes me look like a meatball half the time.... I just love it.But that could be nostolgia speaking. ;) ---------Previously Updated Review:Thankfully, the issue was fixed for me and the game now works. I've been playing Monster Hunter for close to a decade, so this being on PC makes me excited. From what I can tell so far, it looks like a wonderful game. Camera angles can be a little wonky, but its nothing bad at all! I hope it continues to work for others so that we can all enjoy this game.---------Previous Review Upon Game Release: Crashes in the same spot during the intro every time. Been waiting forever for this to come to PC, Disappointed.

author: Sheikan
review: By far one of the greatest games to play with friends. I have been a huge fan of monster hunter since monster hunter 3 Ultimate for Nintendo 3DS and Wii U. author: Ao
review: the game is ok, but compared to the other games in the series it is definitely lacking in the monster aspect. however, there are a lot of quality of life stuff that just improves the game, but at the same time just streamlines certain experiences such as mantles, or scoutflies and the stupid story. once you get past the flaws, it's definitely fun, It's just barebones in its number of monsters. Give it a try.

author: Soya
review: After playing this game for @12+ hours, it is in my opinion a dreadful game in its current state. There are simply numerous problems (very poorly optimized for PC, hit boxes & hit detection is a complete joke, clipping scenery during fights ranges from poor to very poor, camera fixture and targeting will make you sick after a while as it switches and spins the camera so much during a fight it defies believe, choppy frame rates during fights even on a top end pc, very poor textures in many places especially when close up, spend more time on the ground/knocked down/stuck in scenery/waiting for some animation to finish before I can control my chr again mostly from 'shaky' cam as I cannot predict what the monster will do next and in which direction, often network issues drops you in the middle of doing things with a group, etc etc). The game has real potential, I like the open world, the way the game organizes you into monster quests & fetch quests, survival & gathering resources is done pretty good (apart from the TERRIBLE inventory system, not intuitive at all pretty much the opposite, spend way to much time to having to sort your inventory due to it being designed for controller ONLY and even then its still really poorly done) and overall story is not bad.I should have known better, a title coming directly from console is never, or very very rarely, going to work well on the PC at its release. Alas I bought it cheaper from somewhere else which means I cannot refund this pile of monster poo. But that point is mute anyways cause the tutorial in the game takes 2+ hours so even if I bought it on steam, I would have run past the deadline once I gotten to the real game.Overall, after the initial tutorial part and figuring out part, the game became a frustrated affair more and more so to the point where I no longer felt it was worth my time and effort. It needs some patching, as in its current state I would not recommend you touch this with a barge-pole. That opinion does not even take into account that I play with black bars on either side of my screen as it ONLY supports 16:9 resolutions, not 21:9 nor 16:10 nor proper 4k (from what I have read on forums anyways). A real shame that developers/publishers still think they can get away with porting over decent console titles to the PC without putting any real effort into the port itself leaving it in a terrible state with numerous problems and issues which can easily be resolved should they actually be bothered (but its all about the money!).My 2cs.

review: --[Graphics]-- ☐ Real Life☑ Beautiful☐ Good☐ Decent☐ Bad☐ 240p☐ paint.exe--[Gameplay]-- ☑ Addictive ☐ Very good☐ Good☐ Nothing special☐ Meh☐ Starring at walls is better☐ NOPE--[Audio]--☐ Eargasm☐ Very good☑ Good☐ Not too bad☐ Bad☐ Earrape--[Audience]--☐ Minecraft players☑ Teens☑ Adults☐ Average Solitaire Players--[PC Requirements]-- ☐ Check if you can run minesweeper☐ Potato☐ Decent☑ Fast☐ 4k Gaming PC ☐ Ask NASA if they have a spare computer--[Difficulty]-- ☐ Two braincells needed☐ Easy☐ Significant brain usage☐ Easy to learn / Hard to master☑ Difficult☐ Gosu Korean Starcraft player☐ Dark Souls--[Story]-- ☑ If you want story, then go read a book.☐ Text or Audio floating around☐ Good☐ Fantastic☐ It‘ll replace your life --[Game Length]-- ☐ Long enough for a cup of tea☐ Short☐ Average☑ Long☐ Infinite---- ☐ Just click on buy☐ Worth the price☑ If u have some spare money left☐ Get it on Steam Summer Sale☐ You could also just burn your money --[Bugs]-- ☐ None☑ Minor bugs☐ Can get annoying☐ Assassin‘s Creed: Unity☐ Get a bug spray or more.... alot more. or maybe a flamethrower.

author: Drai
review: It is a game that you play with your friends and you make a session on your host or your friends host which is nice because it have self host connection and the game itself has feature of either doing side quests helps you getting materials for your gear + you can help your friends on their hunt awhile you are doing side quests with them on the same boss, but the game loses the feature that real co-op on adventuring on same quest hunt/capture for example a boss called baranoth you need to finish the quest alone or using SOS flare which 3 more random players helps you on the quest or a friend that did the quest already and you can't proceed together as start fresh until some of you step ahead or step behind I rate the game 8.5/10 because I like hunting monsters and also capturing :D but if they allow co-op on the same quest would be awesome, but still the game is really nice never expected would come out like this

author: Big Bird
review: Games in the Monster Hunter series have proven time and time again to be extremely fun, not that I can personally comment on all of them since I've only played Tri, 3P, GU, and recently Rise. That being said, what blew me away in World was the sheer ecological scale and the expeditionary atmosphere that I think no other game has come close to accomplishing in recent times. The soundtracks are wondrous (case in point, Stars At Our Backs), the gameplay is challenging, and visually it is absoloutely stunning, all of which contributes to a pretty stellar and memorable experience. If you've never picked up a Monster Hunter game before, and/or you're someone who wants to experience the sublimity of a New World (heh), then Monster Hunter:World is perfect.

author: PROVIDENCE
review: Very happy with this port. Performance is actually very good (It was my primary worry for this game) and other than the finnicky item select the keyboard controls are actually pretty nice, good enough for me to switch off of my xbox controller at least. My only gripes so far is how some cutscenes don't match the video with the audio (This might be fixed through a patch) and how the game doesn't render in ultrawide when playing at 2560 x 1080 (It doesn't stretch the screen at least, it just displays black bars on the side)Overall, a lot of these problems can (and hopefully will be) fixed. I hope I won't run into more issues, however so far the port is pretty good!EDIT: You can actually switch to keyboard item select mode, not sure how to use it yet but it appears to be a simple 1-8 hotkey bar, so it seems that problem is mainly caused by the game not automatically switching between keyboard/gamepad quick switch layouts (If it did, it would probably cause some compatibility issues, so I'm not going to call this a negative point by any means)

author: Axi
review: Hammer go bonk

author: Decimos
review: If you like Dark souls and Lost Planet 2. You'll like this game. Majority of the negative reviews are either about performance or Denuvo. This game is very CPU intensive. Don't know what that means? Let me explain, so if you have GTX1080 for a GPU but have an i5 gen CPU. Don't expect a constant 60 frames. However, there are plenty of guides on how to optimize your graphics settings. Fun game to play solo or with randoms. It's x10 better with friends though (Obviously).

author: FatCat
review: So, I was hesitant to buy the game at first, there is quite a bit of negative press for it (or was at the time). A lot of issues with connectivity and fps. And other assorted issues people were having. After hedging around for a bit I decided to just buy it.I am SO GLAD that I did. First off, let's address the issues people are having with the game. It's most likely either drivers related, or hardware too low specced to run the settings they are trying to run. The game is fairly demanding, especially on the CPU. Make sure you have a decent CPU and a decent CPU cooler. Also you want a fairly new graphics card, older cards are going to really struggle.Secondly the connectivity issues are largely fixed, there are still some issues (like all online games I have ever played to be honest) but they are not common and they are very fast to fix. That said I think they still have a few more little bugs to hammer out, but it is easily playable the few times I've had issues it did not affect my gameplay for more than a few seconds, and it happens rarely.Third: Guys, I have not bought a major title in a very long time, and the ones I have bought were very disappointing. I have more lately been likely to play simple pixel indie games. But I LOVE this game, Capcom banged this one out of the park, and they have left themselves tons of room to expand. This is new ground for them so yes, there were some rough spots. The real tell-tell sign that this game is great, is that even the people saying not to buy it have hundreds of hours of gameplay invested, if you get 100 hours of gameplay out of your game I think you really got your moneys worth. I won't get in depth or anything, because anything else I could say has been said many times over. If you're on the fence because of negative reviews I highly suggest you try it, because most of the negative reviews are either out dated or very impatient people (mad that they have to wait for content released already on other systems). -Byron

author: Saigofu (Old Acc)
review: Hey boys and girls. The game does work with controller, you just need to set it up on steam big picture. Open steam on big picture mode, go to settings and controller options and set your controller. Then it should work. Works fine for me.

author: Stim The One
review: This certainly wasn't a game for me, yet it has charmed me nonetheless. Some might think it has an RPG feel, but the feel ends at the surface and underneath that your character is unchanging and in no way growing, with only your ability and equipment improving, often the first being the most important. At times it is downright unfair as monsters can downright destroy anyone except a particular build made for them... an example is with the Nightshade that will either torture you, disable you or be able to do nothing if you are immune to its gimmick.But, despite all this, the game is accessible, action-packed, the story is not terrible and apparently it has several improvements of method compared to past games, the cats are adorable, Catma makes the best food cutscene, and yes, I am including Iceborne in this review because honestly, playing without it feels like a cut of content. The sense of pride on beating a monster, especially a harder one... especially if you have turned a flawless strategy to downright humiliate it... it is strong. There are several points in the story where you need to take your skill a step up, the first few being the Anja and the Rathalos. And after that you will continuously hunt them like it is nothing.Not for everyone, though it has something for everyone.

author: mardmental
review: fantastic game that is suffering from bad reviews due to some minor complaints.constant 50/60 FPS at max 1920x1080 and no other issues so its a thumbs up from me :)

author: knee ✧
review: i like the chicken

author: Average New Yorker
review: I've gone through withdrawal without the game for a solid month.My Desktop was in storage, and my gaming laptop is being repaired. But I had a strong desire to play the game, especially with all the events going on right now. I listen to Monster Hunter World News, and watch speed run and strategies in my free time. It was so bad that I literally dug out my old Nintendo DS after two weeks without this game just so I can play the previous titles.This game is great, the cross overs are amazing (Please add a Nier:Automata crossover next.) and I can't wait for the PC content to be caught up with the consoles. I buy the gestures to support the devs so they can keep up the good work.10/10 can't wait to start hunting again!

author: BalliStiX
review: Monster Hunter: World is a great game with some awesome mechanics. It's visually stunning - Playing at 3840 x 2160 with settings set to High. I did notice that some levels I would get a frame drop to 40fps but most of the time I would get a solid 60 - 70fps.The game is designed to be Co-Op, If you nobody on your friends list also plays you can always use the in-game Group finder or just fire off an SOS signal at the beginning of the mission. There were a few bumps at the beginning of the game with this but these have now been fixed and I always had a full group a few minutes after the SOS signal went up.I found the Mouse and Keyboard controls really weird and ended up playing with my Xbox Controller. I did find a few people online who did use Mouse & Keys so it's personal preference really. I tried to rebind keys but I just couldn't get used to it.The biggest let down for myself was the story. I'm not really sure what to say here, It was just... bad.Rinse and Repeat.Also the cutscenes being really poorly synced up with the english voice acting didn't help.In all honesty, MH:W isn't about the story, it's about grinding gear and making yourself look badass. Although the gameplay is fun there isn't much to it. Once you've worked out the pattern you can beat any monster while eating dinner at the same time. It's not very challenging at all, it's also quite fustrating when you're trying to craft a peice of gear and are only missing one part but due to RNG you have to kill the same monster 3 - 4 times before you get the right bit. I would recommend the game - I certainly enjoyed myself and got my moneys worth but if you haven't already bought the game yet then I would either go to CD Keys or wait for a sale.

author: Java Bean
review: As someone who's played all the westernized games in this series, it's baffling to me how many people have reviewed this game negatively. Even if I take off the rose-colored glasses of nostalgia, and look at this game objectively, I simply cannot give it a negative review. ______________________MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD features beautiful graphics, dynamic cutscenes, and one hell of a grind for gear. For some, that last one may be a negative, but I can assure you, this mechanic has  been at the heart of the series, and truly makes MH what it is and has been all these years for me. If that isn't your cup of tea, stop right here, and find another game. The roster of MHW monsters includes a perfect blend of new and old (in my humble opinion), and lots of brand new NPC hunters to get to know along the way. You can play this game solo or multiplayer, and with 14 different weapon types to slay your feathered, fuzzy, or scaley foes, you're in for a long haul. Even after you've completed the main story line, you're not done! Rest assured that the Fifth Fleet will still need you, and Capcom is sure to add better, bigger monsters with even more grandiose fighting mechanics. Now, let's talk ...I'm willing to admit that on PC release, there were definitely a few things that didn't quite hit the mark. Mainly, the multiplayer error issues. For a month or so, it was  difficult to play this game in any sort of mulitplayer fashion, as almost everyone was getting disconnected constantly. As someone who prefers to play this game with friends, I can understand the countless "would not recommend" reviews here based solely on the fact that it was basically impossible to play with friends in that state. Capcom stepped up to the plate and communicated those issues, and worked with the community to fix them. At one point, there was a call for players to send developers their error codes, etc. Since the updates, I have not experienced a singular disconnection issue due to servers while playing with friends or strangers. In closing, I would 110% recommend this game, especially with a few of your best mates in tow. There's a tremendous amount of fun to be had here, and it is definitely worth a play.

author: Fadeyy =)
review: Game is amazing when it comes to visuals such as graphics of both characters and monsters/elder dragons. Customization features are at a godlike level when it comes to armor, decorations, layered armors etc...Magnificent storyline both for the base game (Base world) and DLC (Iceborne). The amount of time spent on the game is still a recurring thing. Even after 300+ hours even if the base and dlc main stories have been completed, there is still a lot of room for improvements in terms of skills both with DPS and weapon mastery.The game seems a never-ending cycle of hunt and its also amazing that there is different ranks of monsters as well as the ranking system for hunters such as Hunter Rank (HR for Base world) and Master Rank (MR for Iceborne) Lastly, it is quite funny to see a DLC being more expensive than its actual base game! But it is totally worth it in my opinion as the number of features added in Iceborne is simply over the top compared to the standard Base World.I strongly recommend this game if you are a person who likes challenges, rerun after failure to become stronger and also meet a wonderful community with only 0.333% of toxicity. Well off! Buy it and Set Sail! Then get Iceborne and improve day after day!Enjoy!

author: Baba Farid
review: It's been a long time coming. The return of yours truly! Monster Hunter World is the first Monster Hunter I've put time into. I tried playing 4 Ultimate on the 3DS but I couldn't get too far. I got MHW on a whim because it was on sale and say ♥♥♥♥ it let's try this one. I was very surprised how accessible this game was compared to the previous titles. There are still mechanics and skills that the game doesn't tell you which is infuriating at times especially if it's your first Monster Hunter game. The premise behind the game might be simple, but it tells a somewhat complex story. You're part of the Fifth Fleet in pursuit of a colossal Elder Dragon known as Zorah Magdaros. Once every decade, Elder Dragons trek across the sea to travel to a region known as the New World. This migration event is referred to as the Elder Crossing and has baffled the Guild for years. The Guild is the main governing body in the Monster Hunter universe, and they work alongside the Elder Dragon Observation to monitor and research particular species. To get to the bottom of this mysterious pattern, the Guild forms the Research Commission, dispatching them in large groups to the New World. The game begins as you're shipwrecked upon arrival to the New World after an attack by Zorah Magdaros. The main objective in Monster Hunter: World is simply to battle gigantic monsters in epic locations. As a hunter, you take on numerous quests to kill increasingly difficult beasts in their unique habitats. Depending on the region, like the Coral Highlands or Rotten Vale, you encounter different monsters which utilize their environment to their advantage. While the story revolves around acquiring contracts to hunt down monsters, the enemy variety the game presents is truly astounding. Just like previous entries in the franchise, Monster Hunter: World maintains the sense that the creatures are the stars of the show. Even if you come across a Kulu-Ya-Ku or Pukei-Pukei in the wild, you realize that they have distinct personalities. Unlike other games, you never feel like you're battling mindless creatures. A large part of the journey is discovering what playstyle suits your skill level. Whether you choose to equip a massive sword or a projectile weapon, mastering it takes time. For example, you may not like how an oversized hammer feels in comparison to the quick attacks of a bone sword. There are dozens of options, so determining what works for you is imperative to success. You can also craft, upgrade and purchase new items at any time. Monster Hunter: World features in-depth customization options which allow you to tailor your character and feline companion. It's great to generate a hunter that looks somewhat like you. This process allows for deeper immersion because you feel like a part of the game. This is just for the base game. The expansion Iceborne adds more monsters, quests, etc. It is a paid add-on but it is definitely worth the cost. The game does go on sale during the Steam events so keep an eye on that. Iceborne also includes a 2 new areas and an endgame. We recently got the final update for the game so the game is fully completed. On this date of this review I have not fought Fatalis but I heard good things about the fight. I'm glad they ended layered armors and weapons. The game is hella grindy so if you don't like that then the game isn't for you. I recommend the game

author: DriftOff
review: Monster Hunter has been a long loved franchise of mine, and Monster Hunter World is a unique experience. For veteran MH players, this game poses both fun activities and challenging hunts. The variety of weapons and armour skills allow players to find their preferred play style, enhancing both solo play and group play as well. For newer players to the series however, this game will for sure be a challenge at times. The hunts are long and extensive, and unless geared correctly, players will face difficulties slaying stronger monsters. You have the option of calling for help as the game allows auto matchmaking after turning it on during the hunt through the SoS flare.The game ultimately comes down to repeatability, as one would need a few hunts of the same monster for rarer materials to upgrade or craft deadlier weapons and stronger armour. However, this is simply a way for the game to allow players to familiarize themselves with each monster, and players will often find each hunt being easier and easier until facing off against a new monster, which the cycle then resets. There are a few event quests that have lenient hunter rank (basically your player level) minimums, such as Fatalis and Alatreon. If you are looking for a challenge however, they are both very fun and rewarding if successful.In terms of game space, the game is simply just beautiful. The environment is immersive with incredible details and many interactible features to assist hunters on their hunts. The music is heavenly, and offers a significant mood enhancement during the matching activities. Some maps even have secrets for hunters to discover, as well as indigenous species for hunters to interact and communicate with. The monster design are diverse and realistic. While many monsters are returning icons of previous titles, they were brought in with new moves and new armour and weapon designs. The Iceborne DLC is a MUST GET. It doubles the base game content and allows players to traverse newer areas to face against unique monsters to the series. It also adds an additional raid on top of the base game.Overall, this is a true PvE game. It is both solo and group playing friendly, and with friends, it can be very fun. 9.8/10

author: GoblinoidPreem
review: TLDR: Awesome game, but some changes have to be made in the next gameMonster hunter Iceborne is in my opinion one of the best games / expansions out there I have ever played. It improved on the base game substantially and made the endgame a lot more fun. When compared to the older games (I only have a bit of experience with MHGU / MHXX) the QoL changes make the game so much more enjoyable, so much so that it was rather hard for me to get started with MHXX (I’m currently emulating it, with a retexture it looks pretty good for a 3ds game). That said there are a few things in my opinion capcom and the monster hunter team have to improve in the next game.Coop Story progressionI understand that the devs want to incentivise players to fight the monster alone, so they learn how it behaves. But in my opinion limiting coop in assigned missions isnt the correct approach. It was extremely annoying having to wait for a friend to watch the cutscene, just for me to be able to join. This in my opinion is one of the things that they have to drastically change in the next release.Bloated damage valuesFrom my understanding this was done so players have a better understanding of how much damage they would actually do with a given weapon. This though hurts more than it actually helps, since it confuses new players especially with skills like attack boost, that only show you how much true raw you get from them, thus making them look less valuable. In the next game we should have at least an option to display true raw instead of bloated raw. When it comes to elemental damage, this should also be changed. Currently bloated elemental damage is just true elemental damage * 10.Displaying elemental damage separatelyOne of the reasons why I think players might consider elemental damage less valuable at first glance, is because we have no visual feedback. Having an option to display elemental damage separately from raw (elements could have a designated color) when attacking could clear up this issue.Increasing viability of elemental damage on certain weaponsSome weapons like the GS and Hammer don’t benefit much from elemental damage, thanks to the huge motion values and slow attack rate they possess. Since elemental damage isnt affected by motion values, this means that the damage increase they provide is a lot less valuable than raw. In order to fix this, capcom should increase the elemental damage on those weapons, till they can at least make up the difference that the huge motion values provide. This could be very useful for crit draw GS, where most of the time the player isnt taking advantage of those huge motion values and elemental damage might actually have a chance to catch up.On another note, GL could get elemental shells (similarly to PEPCBs), which would change the way GL is played. Instead of being able to ignore all HZV, now GL would have to precisely attack those juicy elemental HZVs.Finally the lance, currently in MHW it has an elemental modifier of 0.8. In the next game they should buff it to at least 1  or higher.Clutch ClawPersonally I hate this mechanic, for the soul reason that it forces you to tenderize to deal damage. In addition the claw often grapples me to the part I wasn't aiming to, which is also infuriating. If they ever use this mechanic in future games, I would like it if they refin it to be less clunky.

author: Grandpappy Smith
review: Honestly, in terms of just general feel and depth of content, MHW and the Iceborne expansion are head and shoulders above most other games out there. There are definitely some reasonable criticisms to level against the game, especially with regards to clutch claw implementation, optimization, and some other odds and ends, but it took me hundreds of hours to even start to feel the drag of such things. Beyond that, none of those concerns actually outweigh how much plain fun I have hunting monsters and building gear. While I mostly play solo, group play is another thing entirely and there's just so much engaging content to be explored here. If you're looking a game to get absolutely lost in the world of, and to always have considerably different play styles available by a simple weapon switch, look no further. There's some overlap between weapons, but honestly if things start to feel stale you can always start messing around with something else and it's like a whole new game, and all the weapons have layers upon layers of mastery to discover. The learning curve can be steep, but it is very worth it and very rewarding. Highly recommended.

author: WanaxDigammes
review: A fantastic step forward for the franchise, and a great game in general. For new players, it's a game in which you fight big bosses to craft new and powerful gear so you can fight bigger and harder bosses that give even better gear, etc. Although the base game lacks a bit in content (for a Monster Hunter game) with only 36 or so monsters to fight, the combination of the Iceborne expansion and the extensive changes and quality of life improvements to the classic Monster Hunter formula justify this. Monster Hunter is a franchise that will eat up days of your life and you'll only be halfway through when you realize it. The monster fights have some the best music, atmosphere, and flavor of any video game experience ever. Can't recommend enough.

author: slayer1984
review: For anyone who loves an immersive game experience or wants to have a fun multiplayer experience this game is for you. It has very deep and satisfying game play mechanics with amazingly designed monsters which make every hunt a thrilling one. The multiplayer is amazing with lot of strategic and support mechanics and team play demanding scenarios. The developers have put so much content in this game that one can play it for 200+ hrs and not feel bored. Definitely a 10/10 and game of the generation material right here.

author: r-rex
review: currently my favorite game to play with friends, extremely fun, worth every cent. yes, it does require a pretty decent pc, but my god is this game fun. the grinding mechanics are great, the feeling of finishing off a monster with your new gear and making combinations of skill effects, attacks, and armor fashion is amazing. the servers aren't the best, but this game  can be fun even by yourself. it's incredible looks and outstanding way of showing us those monsters we grew up with and a bonus of other great new monsters is just perfect. to sum this up, if you have the right conditions to play, should you buy it? absolutely. you will not regret it.

author: HalfQilin
review: I cannot recommend this game enough! This is my favorite iteration in the Monster Hunter series, and that's saying something considering how good the other games are. I love games with skill based combat, and MHW is exactly that. It's a wonderful semi-open world and the gameplay is limitless. I spent numerous hour just hunting pets for fun. The combat is difficult but rewarding, and the learning curve isn't terrible. You won't realize that you're grinding for gear because you'll be enjoying the fights so much. The multiplayer is great and every part of the game is a work of art. It's beautifully animated, got a wonderful soundtrack and the amount of time that Capcom put into even the smallest of details is obvious. My favorite game and I'm quite excited to continue mastering it. 10/10

author: Wilson
review: One of my favorite games, and an introduction to a series I've come to really like despite the fact if I'd started with the older monster hunter games I probably would have quit them for being clunky and awkward.This is the perfect introduction to the series in my opinion as it shows the series off at its best, with all the weapon types being extremely satisfying, and most importantly viable to use once learned. Veterans complain about it being too easy or lacking in content compared to older games, but the easy counterpoint to that for me is that the experience here is so much more fun and refined that I've gotten much more time out of this game than something like Generations Ultimate which has much more content. Also, the only things that are "easier" are quality of life improvements that simply make the game better.In short, if you like third person melee/ranged combat and boss fights in general, I highly recommend this game, especially if you can get some friends to hunt with you.

author: Morrismaster
review: Monster Hunter World is lots of fun for new and veteran hunters alike. It brings several ease of life conveniences to the Monster Hunter series that will help new players transition into what can be a difficult game. Like past Monster Hunter games, the player must spend a fair amount of time collecting resources to improve armor and weapons. This is at times a grind, but that is part of the Monster Hunter experience and fun. There is great satisfaction in defeating difficult monsters both alone and online with others. Definitely recommend the game. And prepare yourselves...  Iceborne is coming.

author: Chaemirix
review: Monster Hunter: World marks the best entry point for players who are interested in this series. If you're a fan of big boss battles and action gameplay, you owe it to yourself to give World a go.That's not to say the game is not without flaws. It does a poor job of onboarding new players, and the co-op experience as you progress through the story can be frustrating, but compared to the older titles of the series, Monster Hunter: World is an incredible jump in many ways.Veterans of the genre may find it lacks the same amount of content of previous iterations, as well as the challenge that High Rank and G-Rank used to posses, but the number of improvements made in quality of life, visual fidelity, and smoothness of combat are well worth it.It's a great series, give it a go. I can only hope it'll continue to get better with each expansion.

author: Mashiro
review: Ok i am gonna give my honest opinion about this game. So At first i was reluctant to buy this game because of its bad review which is bad network connection when playing with friends , at first i did not believe so i ask my friends and they told me that theres really bad network connection which will make u disconnect when playing with friends. Despite the negative comment i decided to put my faith on this game and i bought the game, and i started playing mhw and surprisingly this game is not that bad just that theres a small network issue and the rest of the game is fine. I would suggest this game as its super fun but grindy which is my type of games!!

author: Demii
review: 150 hours on Playstation, and at the time of writing 63 hours on PC. This game is a masterpiece of gameplay, level design and RPG Mechanics. I've always been interested in the Monster Hunter genre but it was only until Monster Hunter World that I really fell in love with it. The gameplay is really smooth, the Monster fights are appropriately challenging. Most of the normal monsters are no problem, but if you don't prepare for harder fights you'll struggle. The progression into increasingly challenging monsters and utilising gear crafted from previous kills to aid in future fights is really rewarding and satisfying, you feel as if you are improving as a hunter as you progress through the game.The campaign is great and is not as grindy as some of the game's predecessors.The only thing I'd say is that after 200 hours, I'm naturally less motivated to play. The End Game is about optimising your gear for the most effective DPS, so a little bit of a grind for not much reward, but there's a good 60-70 hours of the game's main story and Monster progression arch before you get into that, so it's honestly not a bad thing at all it just gives the hardcore playerbase more goals to achieve.

author: TheBlackCake
review: First of all i want to say that i love monster hunter series, so i'll just talk about things that i've disliked in MHW since i'm already fan of the game, it have my upvote aways.Cons:Connection Problem: everyone know about this one, its pretty sad when you are playing with a friend or a random and someone get disconnected, the biggest problem is that the monster scale for multiplayer keeps active, so when someone join your session and someone gets disconnected you need to quit the mission and try again, or fight agains't a monster buffed for 2-4 players and have the double of the needed work, the system should add some kind of reconnect or down scale the monster stats when someone leave the session.. and this take me to the second point.Multiplayer Scale: When someone join you the monster gets buffed, but its not always a pro player right? sometimes is just someone learning how to play, there is no problem on it, but i think the game double the enemy HP on online session so, if you have a teammate that are not doing so good, you will have a lot of extra work, since MH series its has a lot of focus on multiplayer it should have a better party system, at this point its better to clear a quest alone than play with friends, trust me, you will clear it much easier doing all on your on. i think they should change the hp scale or damage, to incentive the multiplayer, not incentive the solo play. and this take me to the next point.Revives limited to 3: When you are playing on your on, 3 deaths is fair, but when you are playing on mutiplayer it should make the 3 death individual, or else you have 4 players with a 3 death limit, that its the other thing that make the multiplayer less viable than solo play, everyone do mistakes, that is normal, but when you have 4 players and 3 deaths, if everyone do 1 mistake, you've failed already, and since the hp is hella buffed, it much better have 3 lifes and play alone than play with other ppl that you don't know if they are on a good day or not. i think the 3 death only should be only for quests like Kuelve Taroth or Behemoth since those are suppose to be hard and everyone know what they are doing, but for normal missions the death counter should be individual and if someone die 3 they need to keep on the ground and watch his teammates play, or get quitted from the quest and not recive the reward. for those two above, either scaling less the monster hp for multiplayer or making the death counter individual would improve a lot the party system and make much more viable to play in party than solo, at this point, i would only recommend to play in party if you have a pre-made team with pre-made builds, else, don't try to play with random's, do it on your own.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Grinding: Monster Hunter is a grind fest since ever, who plays it usually likes it, but  MHW look's way more casual, its super easy to craft the weapons and sets, i haven't seen any difficulty in craft system, the only thing that make it a little more hard its the gem's, but you can drop one with less than 10 runs, and can also purchase it with week tickets, i've made my Drachen Set so easy at HR 60 or less... and its the end game set actually... the only two things that make's you keep playing at certain point its the events with new layered armor and the Decorations, i also want to say that the decoration system 100% based on luck its pretty bad, its somehow impossible to drop the Deco you need without and event like Great Jagras, it should have a craft system for Deco, but first you need a better craft system for set's, or else player's will not have anything to do...---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------That is all i can remember right now, my Cons are more likely things that need some kind of improvment, none of them make the game inviable, the game still pretty cool, for a casual player you should be able to play for like 300-600 hoursfor someone that already know the series, probably 100-300 hours if you don't want to grind the luck system of Decorations...the game still epic, i'll not talk about Pros  since there is a lot of stuff, and everyone talk about them already =P, the game is cool, if you like it, buy it, its worth.Sorry for my bad english and Thanks for reading it until here

author: Glitchbyte
review: BUY IT!  This game is the ANSWER - Go YouTube a video of the gameplay!  ITS AMAZING! Its Shadow of Collosus meets Assassin's Creed meets Final Fantasy meets Tomb Raider.  This game has the RIGHT AMOUNT of grinding, upgrading, story, exploring, questing, CO-OP PLAY etc.  Its a GREAT game with a HUGE variety of weapons (fight/play style) choices - all of which can be upgraded further.  You can use a 600 pound hammer that plays like its actually HEAVY, you can use a heavy GUN with all kinds of custom crafted ammo, you can use twin daggers that have VICIOUS crit chance... and there's over 10 other weapon types!  Everything has a skill tree!  It's creative and well thought - there is tons to hunt and grind and explore.  The maps are HUGE with 3 layers of height/depth.  So basically each area map is made of 18ish smaller maps, and each of those maps can have a higher ground/lower ground map.  Its EASY to utilize though, and you can set waypoints for yourself on anything or any creature you want!   You get an ADORABLE little buddy to fight alongside you who can help you out by dropping heals or setting traps - he also routes out items for you and even levels up himself!  You can equip and upgrade his sh!t too!  The attention to detail in this game is AMAZING - ex: your little friend hops on a tiny raft when you go in water too deep for him.AND THE CO-OP!  YOU CAN PLAY CO-OP and I'M NOT TALKING THAT CRAPPY SPLIT SCREEN CO-OP IM TALKING REAL MUTLIPLAYER!  AND ITS SO DAMN FUN!  You can d!ck around in the same area for HOURS and not get bored!  You can capture monsters, track monsters, kill monsters, carve monsters, break monsters, jump onto the backs of monsters, run and hide from monsters....  ITS SO GOOD.  You actually do have to hide if you run into something you're not yet ready to take on - which makes it FUN - its not stupid-easy like so many other games out there!The environment is endlessly open - you can harvest, farm, dig, mine, grab, capture almost everything!  The freedom of movement in the game is FANTASTIC.  You can slide, rappel, climb, dodge et all. The negative reviews from its first release on PC are due to the controls - the game started on console (PS4, XBOX) - where it did amazing, by the way.  When CAPCOM ported it over to PC there were some control issues, but most - if not all - of that has been resolved now.  It doesn't take long to tackle the menus and inventory and all the information you need is there.  Meeting up with your friends is a little non-intuitive, but really its not difficult and once you do an Expedition with a friend, you will be immersed for HOURS.  Basically, you have to do the first 1 or 2 quests alone.  Then, you have two options.  You start a Quest/Expedition and send up an SOS which your friend will search for and then join you.  OR, better yet, just start a Quest/Expedition while you and your friend are in the same online session, and he/she can search for it and join.Haven't had this much fun with a game in AGES.  After getting duped into trying ATLAS (IT IS HORRIBLE) this has TOTALLY lifted my spirits!!!!!!
