review: first 100+ hours single player experience work very well for newcomer   to adapt and still have interest point to explore for MH fans. repetitive mechanics maybe make feel tired but honestly i still have some thing new to learn in every hunt, even hunting squisy G.Jagras and Slay Hard as Steel Daorah that is never get old.

author: Zovereign
review: I feel compelled to leave this review seeing this is still 'mixed' - this game has an immense amount of content (save currently @ ~350hr, some afk) and is all included in the $40 price tag, a significant amount still not released for months to come. It can feel a bit grindy mid game, but the 'gameplay loop' is very refined and there are tons of players responding to SOS flares.The game has significant amounts of mods including QoL and transmog (works online), has a lot of advanced graphics settings now, and again the upcoming free content (witcher 3 crossover) looks excellent.The only downside I can think of is the relatively high system requirements and some odd learning curves figuring out different mechanics and systems within the game. These really help develop a nice feeling of progression and flexibility with builds long term however, and are worth learning.Also the soundtrack is great.

author: Meloncat
review: Pretty solid game. I got about 80 hours of it before I ran out of content at release. Playing with friends greatly improves the experience but is not mandatory given the party functions (doubly so since they fixed the pretty rough connections on release). I remember when I played I had a weird issue of my graphics being downgraded despite settings on high, so I am not sure what the deal was there. It should be plenty noticable if you have the same as it was low res textures in spots despite the big picture looking pretty.I hate scoring on 1-10 but on a Buy it at full price, buy it with a small % off, buy it with a big % off, or do not buy it, I'd say it's a buy full price or on sale for low % off. Fun game

review: Monster Hunter was the very first game i got on my PS2 and i played that game religiously when i was a kid. I got everything singleplayer could get me as i did not have acsess to online at that time. Then i got myself a PC and i kept seeing all these Monster Hunter games on all these diffrent consoles and i could not afford to get myself a console just to play one game. Finally after all these years i finally get to play one of my all time favorite games on the platform of my choosing and its all i remember it was and more. The nostalgia from my childhood came rushing back to me as i started this game and i loved every second of it. Even though this game had a rought start with online connections and still suffer right now to get some of the promised new content out i will still highly recommend this game for anyone who loves the thrill of hunting huge monsters with fellow friends/players.

author: Quietus
review: What's this?! A Monster Huntering game. On PC. Yes. Yes it is.This is basically my first Monster Hunter game and I've had nothing but fun with it, okay and some angering moments... lol I have MH4U on 3DS, never got invested much into it. :\ Moving on! You get some tiny blades, giant ass blades and some bows and some other thing that you throw a bug at the monster and get buffs. That's pretty neat. THERE'S AN AXE. THAT TRANSFORMS into a GIANT ASS SWORD too. My favorite is the Charge Blade, sword and shield (fuuuu-SHUN HA) NOW IT'S GIANT ASS AXE. Slay those monsters with'em for endless hours of *fun* and even rage enducing failures. Like... You died... To a Great Jagras, . Or you just straight up missed a roll and got one shotted, it's okay it happens to the best. Even worse. A poison dart from a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Gajalaka... . Disclaimer: Results may vary amongst players for the fun part. There's grind, but stop complaining. It's worth it. It's rewarding grind. Super! Rewarding! You get stronger, bruh. There's farming, hunt and gather! Gather and hunt! Unless you're jewel farming, you'll never get the one you so desperately need. :( You can slay a monster or capture a monster. Capturing kinda works like the Pokemonz; weaken it for 100% success. lol There's even little creatures and critters you can trap and have as pets in your room!There's collab events too. For example: We had Mega Man and Devil May Cry events. Get some themed gear for you or your palico. What's a palico? Your very own cat buddy! They meow and throw bombs and heal you. They're great, they're so great. Sometimes really annoying and dumb. For multiplayer, there's open sessions you can join. Or just have a private session for you and your friends, or community. Uses a session ID that you can just copy/paste. It'll change every time you play too, to be noted. You can also play solo, you'll eventually have to get some help. But a lot of the game is doable solo, that's how I played.The soundtrack is beautiful. Bazelgeuse and Nergigante's themes are my absolute favorite. The sound design is sooooo damn fantastic. Environment sounds, ambient and just all of it. The monster roars are SO GOOD. The fact that they put irl animal sounds in with a lot of the monster sounds is amazing. You'll notice chickens and whales, for example. I love this game's sound design so much. OH! Deviljho's sounds are so gross, I love it. You'll see, er hear.The game runs great. Little high on CPU usage. But. It's not that bad. There's peeps with higher end processors getting high readings too. Everybody struggles a little together. ;) Lil rough for streamers on a single PC setup, but it's doable. Pro tip: In OBS, under video. You might have to drop it to 30fps, if you're getting to much frame drops. It'll lower OBS' process and give you a little more wiggle room. It's what I do and some others do aswell.If wondering (Note: at the time of posting this):FX-835016GB GTX 970 SSCAverages 60fps after some tweakings. I really recommend this, full price or on sale. Fun solo, funner with a buddy and even moar funner with a full party. It's also not for everyone, do some searching, watch vids and streams.

review: Having played all the previous Monster Hunter games, going back as far as the original Playstation game, this is the only game of the series I would recommend to a new player to the franchise - the quality of life changes make previous titles feel nigh unplayable frankly.

author: Ham
review: More than what meets the eye. This is one of those games where you cannot just look at videos, trailers, gameplays and expect to know and understand what the game is. To truly understand this game, you need to have friends who play the game and love a chill grind session without anything to worry about.The game's story ends at 30 hours but the game just starts getting better from there. Starting from the various limited quests to the other collabs like the recent Devil May Cry Collab. Content as an RPG may be on the lacking side but the game is pretty easy to get into compared to similar titles with steep learning curves.All in all I'd ask anyone with friends who own this game to atleast borrow their accounts and check out the game and then decide if its worth the price.

review: I don't understand why so many people are complaining that it's grindy at end game etc when they've played the storyline quest and have put 100 hrs+ into it. Well, to me..it is definitely worth the money for the enjoyment and excitement of something new.It's my first time playing MH series but it's definitely a good game to play especially with friends. You'll explore on how to beat different monsters, use different weapons and strategize different tactics.10/10 game for me!

author: PiranhaPig
review: As a long time Monster Hunter fan, I can confidently say that this is the best game in the series, technically speaking. Many of the things that have kept players away from the series have been remedied, and i'd say it's a much better experience throughout.  World certainly lacks in this department. Nobody really uses voice chat, and it's much harder to make new friends than it used to be in games like mh3u, mostly due to the bigger lobbies.That said, playing with friends is flawless from my experience, haven't had any issues there whatsoever. Instead of having the online be restricted to gathering hall quests,  quests can now be played co-op, even the story quests. (Every player needs to enter the quest individually first if it's the first time fighting a monster to watch said monster's cutscene which is rather annoying, but minor.)As for solo, it's the best solo campaign in the series, without a doubt, though I dislike not being able to skip cutscenes (EDIT: after a second playthrough this issue is a  bigger than I initially thought! Playing the game again feels like a drag after seeing all the cutscenes once already. This only really applies on repeat playthroughs, though.) If you're a Monster Hunter veteran, the first half will probably be no challenge at all, but the later game stuff, especially the so-called  bring some appreciated difficulty. A lot of features have been streamlined, such as the loading zones in between areas, your inventory size, and some other less notable ones. These changes took some time to get used to, but made the game a more enjoyable experience overall.It seems relatively well optimized, nothing amazing here, but I was able to run it at 50-60fps throughout at low-medium settings on my mid-tier computer, which surprisingly still looks pretty good. There's a  of new monsters, though the returning monster-scene is rather dissapointing in comparison. That being said, the new monsters are very cool. This game really promotes using the environment to your advantage, and i feel as though the new monsters use this to the fullest. All of the returning monsters have been given some new moves and visuals as well, though, again, there's not many of them.All of the weapons have also been given a  of new moves and combo's. Even weapons like the dual blades are slightly more complex this time around, bringing in some much needed variety, and weapons like the Insect Glaive and the ranged weapons have been simplified, bringing in some much needed usability. (EDIT: The Iceborne expansion improves the difficulty and lack of content a lot, though it still doesn't come close to 4u or generations in terms of total monsters or weapon design. It also includes a lot of fanservice for veterans of the series with returning monsters, music and classic armor sets and weapons.)  Monster Hunter fans will feel right at home, even if a lot was changed or straight up removed. The online isn't great, but the amazing environments and new additions make up for it. If you're on the fence about this game, i definitely recommend picking it up.

author: Raddish

author: AzuRe
review: Edited Review.Monster Hunter: World (the 5th Generation in the franchise).This game went through a lot on the PC platform, since August of 2018 and the Dev. Team is fixing almost every game breaking issue. (This explains the mixed reviews).In previous games, you start the game, create a character, gather items, fish and hunt, and repeat, every rank has its own load of Monsters, they're very challenging and enjoyable to fight. There was basically no story back then, if a problem happens...kill a monster.. if you like a monster....kill it, if someone is stealing your honey....kill it....and so on. At some point it will become grindy and repetitive....RNG was a pain. Lots of that changed in here.In Monster Hunter: World they for once added an actual story with NPCs revolving around it.You start, create your character and start, you gather & hunt. Every encounter will have its own purpose with exception to few. As you progress you'll find yourself achieving higher ranks, and so fight new monster or even previous monster but harder and much rewarding.You craft gear, combine items and use the farm to make sure you never lack the essentials.To each armor there are different skills, and so making and armor based on look (fashion hunting) or mixed set (skill based) is very possible. There are 14 weapons, each is unique, but all of them fall below two type: Melee or Ranged.Each will have its own playstyle, and each can be played however you want as long as you have the correct skills set. Some can output very high damage, others can be very defensive and some can be used as support (keep in mind ANY weapon can be used as one of those).You also have a companion that helps you very well...they're talking cats....Palicos .====Pros:====- The Graphics are amazing (comparing it to any previous generation) It is too good to be real.- The music is special, some fights have their own unique music and some give you anxiety when you hear them.- Multiplier is a thing, previous games you could have 4 people in a room, now you could have up to 16, but a quest can have up to 4 hunters with scaling difficulty. You can join other during their hunts or even fire and SOS flare to let others join you if you find yourself in trouble.- Controls are very flexible, supporting all types of controllers (as long as it is supported by Steam) and Mouse & Keyboard (which can be optimized even further with Macros).- 14 weapons --> plenty of possible play styles.- Solo gameplay....yes you're NOT forced to be online to play.- Grinding is NOT as heavy as previous games, there are specific quests that give much higher chance than regular quests to give rare items. (We're talking about up to 16% drop rate).- Free Updates, the game has been getting free update since it release, last update was released already, the next one is a payed Expansion almost as big as the base game.- Mods, Capcom stated its not with nor against modding., there are plenty of mods out there, but if you ever consider cheating please do it offline.======Cons:======- PC Optimization is a bit  lacking. It took 6 Months for them to enable actual HD Textures (30 GB aside from the base game). The game CPU usage is still not optimized....I highly recommend using Special K mode to resolve that issue.- Content Delay, PC was released 8-ish months after consoles, however now we have almost everything the consoles have (with exception to exclusives).- Hackers sometimes ruin the hunts, but you can easily kick them out if you're the Quest leader or the Session leader.- Previous games had PLENTY of content....this one is lacking them since the monsters and everything else was designed from scratch. But this issue will be solved with Iceborn release.=====I have been a fan of the Franchise since 2004-2005, This game is innovation. it is very addictive, and kinda repetitive but as you make friends and hunt with others or even alone you will always find something new or different to do. Can't wait for Iceborn and G/Master Rank, returning monster and NEW monsters and MUCH MORE.

author: Cekata&Celoline
review: So here are my thoughts about MHW. Keep in mind that i have never played other Monster Hunter games and this is purely from a person who wanted to try this game because of the hype.The hype was real and i actually was not disappointed, the game looked amazing, it was smooth and very comfortable to get into even as someone who isn't actually very adept in rpg games like this.You can connect with friends for epic 4 player fights and its not as bad as people make it out to be for the following reasons:1. From what i have learned the monsters get 2.6hp multiplier no matter how many people are in, so don't worry about it being more difficult with more players.2. Most players are very helpful and try not to let you cart and while trolls exist yes, during my almost 100 hours i have not met one player who didn't work their hardest to make the hunt work.Good things about multiplayer and MHW in general:1. Can play with friends hunting monsters, go on expeditions and explore the vast worlds or just hang around in the gathering hub.2. The variety of weapons, there are so many types of weapons and the weapon trees are huge and really in-depth, same with armors. You can't stick with only one set of armor and expect it to carry you to the end-game.3. The game is beautiful and really breath-taking. Showed my non-gaming some of the screenshots and they fell in love with it.Negatives about multiplayer:Cheaters(damage multipliers, infinite items and so on) - i personally don't mind these people if they don't actively ruin the experience like one-shot the monster you've had the pleasure of fighting the first time.Connection issues - this has now been fixed and it is very good to hear that people are listened to and problems are being dealt with.The variety in design - after a bit most monsters look the same and the weapons have the same problem, luckily the armor sets do not share that problem which for me is a huge part of some games. Fashion is necessary at one point haha.In conclusion: An amazing game with little flaws that aren't noticeable almost. Expect hours upon hours of fun, a lot of grind and many monsters that you will learn to fight. It feels great and i would suggest you to look past the negative reviews and try it out for yourself. After all, its an experience and everyone differs. So go for it and become the greatest hunter in the fifth fleet to date.

author: ODEIO JOGADOR DE FENNEC
review: Awsome

author: ✨Mao Meo
review: A game overflowing with love and insanely worth its price for hours and hours of content, could have been worth even a subscription fee to stretch it. Challenging and incredibly immersive with the coming on PC being a huge step for the franchise. Incredible additions to quality of life compared to the previous franchise and a massive amount of detail in its work.MH community is famous to be whiny with hardcore vegans players. The developer team is not experienced at all in PC as Japan is all about consoles; ***the game need to be entirely reprogrammed for it to have a PC port, thus the delaays***. The port is great and works smoothly with issues being read and fixed as they go.We keep having more events and DLCs, all of them which comes with their A+ content. All the whine just disencourage how CAPCOM *finally* decided to take a step towards PC to give a hand to their western audience.

author: TargaryanSME
review: Monster Hunter: World is a very good game that deserves the praise. It's quite possibly one of the coolest non-combat hubs I've seen in a game. I also really love how dino/monster fights can have unexpected twists. A monster might get tangled up in vines or you might find a new monster suddenly attacking the one you were just fighting. I also enjoy climbing on top of a monster and riding it while attacking, or enlisting other monsters in the hunt. This game is not just for everybody, and it's important to realize that before jumping in based on review scores and word of mouth alone. If you enjoy the game, fine. If it's not for you, that's fine too... this game is worth 10/10 for me. :)

author: LordFryingPan
review: Is Monster Hunter: World worth the price? - Definitely, this is a great game whether you like to finish everything alone or bringing your army of friends to help you with your quests. (I pre-ordered the game and saved at least 25 USD but I still think its worth the price.)Is Monster Hunter: World fun?- Sure, it had its issues when it was first launched in PC, but this is definitely a fun game with lots of content and hundreds of hours of fun activities which will keep you logged in always. There are tons of players and even if you're new to the series, experienced players usually just enters your room and help you slay the monster. Is Monster Hunter: World perfect for its genre? - Definitely not. While a great game, I first started playing the franchise when it was on PSP and it's a bit repetitive if you're a fan of the series for that long. Should this stop me from buying future Monster Hunter release? No. It will not. While huge new contents are almost rare to none, this is still a great game and is improving over time. Overall thoughts on the game: - Just buy it, it's fun.

author: Sikk #Oligarch
review: 've been playing the Monster Hunter series for a long time. I enjoyed every single one.Let me jump straight into the negative point(s).-only 32 boss monsters -lacking some graphical optionsThat's it.BUT! They will add free(!) content with new monsters in the futureThey've fixed the connectivity issue and the game works fine.The connectivity issue wasn't even a problem for solo players to begin with.To all players crying about coop because they can not handle some monsters... git good.Every single one is solo-able.It has beautiful graphics and the loading screen time isn't worth mentioning since it's almost non existent.It's a beautiful game for both veterans and beginners since it does have a decent story and some sort of guidance throughout the game.I am highly recommending this game. 10/10

author: Wowenz
review: A very good game, especially if you're into grinding. You'll feel the weight of every weapon. I have already played the console version, and bought another one on the PC for playing with PC friends and to experience the 60+ fps smoothness. Very enjoyable, you'll be surprised you have already spent a ton of hours in the game.I would ignore the negative reviews, since most of them are about Denuvo, their PC not being able to handle it,  visual options that aren't in the game, connection issues(which is now fixed btw). They are mostly isolated and personal issues. I have friends playing this with a 750Ti and they are all having fun with it.

author: Zalanore
review: Having played many of the previous games I'd consider this more aking to Monster Hunter lite, but still a crazy enjoyable game. For those just entering the series it's the perfect game. I fully admit there were some excessively detailed and often bothersome mechanics in the previous games. I think this one over-simplifies many aspects to the point of being boring (like putting cool drink mushrooms at the entrance of every lava zone), but most of the ease of life changes are much appreciated (like not having to go to the wiki to look up monster weaknesses). Overall I'd give it an 8/10. Very enjoyable, but slightly too easy.

author: Qinglan-chan
review: Even the connection issue is terrible, the game itself is still the best one in this year.

author: Rukinaa
review: arrived on PC in August of 2018, continuing the  franchise and bringing a plethora of quality of life changes and a huge graphical update to create a  game unlike anything that has come before it.      It is no secret to long-standing fans of the series that the plot of  games is usually quite weak and unfortunately,  doesn't break from this pattern. With an unremarkable scenario and characters who you probably won't care about or for, the game does very little to create a story that compels you to make any progress, relying instead on its gameplay. For newcomers to the franchise, you may be disappointed by the storyline, though veteran players will not be suprised at all.     The quality of life changes brought to the table in  make it one of the most engaging hunting experiences yet. All the weapons you expect are present and have been updated to improve their gameplay experience and alongside the much more interactive environments really lend themselves to creating more dynamic and variable hunts than ever before, all layered with a plethora of new monsters to fight and some old fan favourites making a welcome return.      is without a doubt the best looking  game and some of the environments look fantastic. The introductory Ancient Forest map in particular stands as the poster boy with a brilliant aesthetic which really brings the forest ecosystem to life. Despite this however, some ofthe environments are much more bland with dreary colours that sort of blend together and lacking any features that make them stand out or make them memorable. On the other hand, all the monsters look fantastic, whether it's the new monsters who you are meeting for the first time, or old favourites who have had a facelift, you'll certainly be impressed.      has a good soundtrack overall with a few standout tracks, however the music mostly falls into the ambience of the hunt and you usually don't pay it much attention over the roars and slashes of the fight. That being said, if you find time to listen to the soundtrack, you will find the kind of melodies that have become inexorably tied to the franchise - quality music, but I don't see myself listening to it in my spare time.      , like any  game has fantastic replayabilty with a number of quests to undertake and gear to craft once the credits have rolled. It's not uncommon to hear  players stating that the main scenario is just the tutorial for what is to come, and with a load of incoming DLC content on the horizon, I'm inclined to agree. As you set your own goals, you will find hours slipping away from you as you spend time in the New World, looking for those elusive monster parts or the perfect decoration for your armour. Of course, due to the nature of the game, the endgame is grindy but, at least in my opinion, the gameplay is fun enough to keep it from becoming a chore.      Overall, I think that  is a solid entry in the series and that the changes made here make it forward into future games. With it being the most acessible to new players yet, there has never been a better entry than  to try out this series of games.

author: Skurkanas
review: Alright so seeing this getting torn to shreds because it doesn't support 2012x3086 resolutions or whatever, I thought I'd add my 50 cents and talk about wether the actual GAME is fun.Disclaimer: I haven't touched a console since the N-64 and haven't played any of the previous Monster Hunter games. I also generally avoid japanese/korean grindfests like the plague, so I was pretty sceptical going into this.~ 140 hours later ~What I like:1. For a game about killing monsters, there is a surprising amount of depth to it. With low rank, high rank and the unofficial "endgame", there are distinct chapters to the game that each offer a new level of challenge. And unlike the "New Game +" found in many other asian titles, it isn't just a cheap way to extend playtime by copy-pasting everything with twice health and damage, but you actually unlock new layers of complexity (New Monsters, New Armor Sets, new Skills, Gem-Slots, Augmentations...), that would be overwhelming if introduced right at the start.2. Customisation. There's a ton of ways to build your equipment to fit your playstyle. And 16 really distinct weapon types, that completely change your approach to a fight, offering a fresh angle if you get bored of your "main" weapon.3. The Fights. They did a good job adding weight to the animations, both of your weapons and the monsters. There's plenty of "oh ♥♥♥♥" moments when you see a house-sized mass of fangs and horns charging at you, and plenty of gratification (and feedback) when you land that Hammer Smash right in its face. Or manage to dodge at the last second. Or manage to blow the pesky thing out of the sky. They did all this while still making the fights feel - mostly - fair. While arbitrary hit-boxes do exist, there is not a whole lot of them. If you die, you (usually) know what went wrong.4. Quality of Life improvements. Talking to a mate who played the older games, Capcom apparently went out of their way to make this game "streamlined". Aka, they removed a TON of pointless tedium so common in asian games (and thankfully absent from western games since the late 80ies). There are still plenty of gripes and nuisances (and I will get to that in a bit), but for someone like me who usually avoids asian games, it's at least tolerable.What I dislike:1. The "Consoleness". They didn't really manage to get that out of the game. The menus, the interaction with NPCs, the crafting, the item management. Everything takes about 4-5 times as many clicks as it has to. Pretty clunky when you are used to Mouse&Keyboard, but probably can't be done better for controllers.2. The Grind. It's much less than I feared it would be (for much of low and high rank, you will get enough materials from killing monsters once or twice to craft their gear), so progression feels smooth all the way into endgame, but once you reach endgame and start farming for gems and augmentations, the Grind is definitely there.3. The Multiplayer-System. I don't mean the multiplayer itself. IF you get it to work, it's a ton of fun to murder a monster as a group (especially since this also brings in combos and support-"classes" you won't really see in solo). The problem is in getting it to work.Used to MMO's full of people you could readily interact with? Used to hotjoining friends at the press of a button? Think again. MHW-multiplayer is trying hard to bring back those LAN-party days of needlessly complicated peer-to-peer. Much like the menus, joining a multiplayer session takes about 3-4 times more steps than necessary. And despite servers for 16 players, you will not actually see any of them outside of a very specific hub node.On the upside, they took quick action to fix some very annoying connectivity issues and as i mentioned, once you DO get on the same server and into the same quest, it's a blast.So in conclusion, while the game really shows its console roots, it did away with enough of them to be enjoyable, even if you are new to the series or this kind of game in general.

author: bsandro
review: Game is really good despite being somewhat different from previous Monster Hunter installations; even though some mechanics were simplified or removed the core of the game is still the same - pure skill-based combat.I encountered infamous connection errors just twice in ~60 hours, and while rare fps dips are present they are not as horrible as promised (Ryzen 2700, GTX1060).Played about 300-400 hours of MHWorld on PS4 and thought I'd skip PC version but it turned out to be really nice. Strongly recommending to anyone who like good action PvE games with good lore and cool mechanics.

author: ToxicKnief
review: Amazing game. Full of content and hours of good hunting.If you like boss battles like the ones in Dark Souls, you will like these as well.The graphics could be a bit more improved, but overall it looks very good.Controls lean more towards controllers, but the mouse and keyboard can be played. It does take some time to get used to.Overall: Good game, if you like the type of game.

author: Mr.Enge
review: Overall this is a great game and really fun, but at end game you don't know what to do anymore, you just hunting for decoration and that's it no more content, and you need to improve the security and network engineer, because i see a lot of HR999 people joining my SOS and just carry the game,but that's not fun at all.

author: Bandersaur
review: It's been a tough week for Monster Hunter. Until today I could not call this a multiplayer title - the game has been plagued with disconnection issues on PC since launch. Today though - that all changed. An update dropped - and with it all the networking problems dissapeared. This game is a blast to play with friends now, and I highly reccomend it. That said, there are still a host of issues. The optimisation is pretty bad. You can't play it with mouse and keyboard unless you hate yourself. The chat system and menu implementation is atrocious. But all in all - It's now a game I can play with friends and enjoy. But seriously capcom. Get rid of the need for everyone to have watched the cutscene in singleplayer before they can play the mission with friends. That was a straight up dumb idea.

author: Laken
review: It's definitely worth your time. Everything about the game was beautiful. The difficulty, character models, progression, storyline, small cinematics/cutscenes, community, and everything in between was top notch.This is my first rpg in a long time. I've played nothing but Mobas and Battle Royale for so long, hopping to a game like this was a great first time experience.This is a game you can definitely progress at your own time. There's no need to rush to the end game. Perhaps it may even be better to take your time. By taking your time, I mean; grind for your gears, head onto Exploration find all gatherings, max out your trackings, help out newcomers, etc.So about my ratings, Here are the things I enjoyed about the game.-- Combat --The combat is clunky. That's how it is. I'm used to the fluid dynamics of animation cancelling, barage of abilities, and no haptic feedback. With this game, every move you make staggers a little bit. It shows the weight of your attacks and weak points for pulling of abilities. It's a slow paced game. You need to attack, dodge/counterattack every move the monster makes. Trying to bust out a over 9000 dps ain't going to help you out in this game. Every assignment (assuming you are using a weapon relative to the boss being fought) should and would take roughly 5~30min completion.-- Storyline --The story was beautiful. I don't want to say too much and spoil it. But when I got to the end, finished the final boss I felt a sense of achievement. Watching the credits roll down and the music playing It felt amazing. I felt my character progress from zero to hero at that point. All my hardwork, achievements, dedication to the Guild and all Hunters made my heart sway-- Plenty to do --There's plenty to do. Did you finish the game? Try doing it again with another weapon zero to hero. Do this 14 times as there are so many weapons to choose from. Plenty of armors to collect, builds to discover and invent. I completed the game using a bow, now I want to try complete the game with a different weapon.-- Community --There will always be people who are there willing to help. There were plenty of times I got stuck on so many monsters, I had to queue up in sessions just to get it done. There are people who are most likely doing the same quests as you. Even if you start the game late, people are taking their time. they also want x specific materials but they don't want to grind it alone so they go back hop onto Join quest and look at some SOS for free quick zen cashes or mats to grab.-- Difficulty --There difficulty is well set. At the high rank level the bosses require a lot more game sense and structural approach. the were plenty of cases such as the first time Anjanath i had difficulties because you don't know the monster's abilties at first. It's all about trial and error and adapting to the situation. Get into the habit of taking your time against the boss; Hit and anticipate. Every monster in the game won't let you just bash their life out without retaliating at all. Always look for that window.-- It's not going to die anytime soon --The game isn't going to die. Thinking about investing time, but realizing in a few months/years time it's going to die doesn't apply to this game. Games like these are fun both single player and multiplayer. Technically it's meant to be played as singleplayer. games where the community is heavily important isn't that important for this game. Though it is fun and better to be accompanied by people.Honestly, It's really worth playing the game. If you're feeling empty; searching for that game that will interest you, keep you up at night thinking about strategies approaching you will do after you get up in the morning, or come after school/work. I think this game would be it. give it a go

author: RuM

author: Zefiant
review: (UPDATED REVIEW AS OF MAY 2019 AT BOTTOM)Great game but poorly executed. Play it on console if you can afford to. (GOOD ON PC NOW)The PC version:-several months behind in content -server issues -poorly optimized, even with high end GPU, FPS dips constantly in certain situations -very CPU heavy, requires an insane rig ("25% of all CPU time is spent switching active threads because the game has over 100 threads.")  -awful keyboard and mouse controls with no meaningful adjustments available in settings -uses Denuvo, if that sort of thing bothers you It's shame, because if the FPS and server issues could be fixed, then I would highly recommend it. It took them 6 months to port this game over to PC and it feels like I'm playing a bootleg emulated version of the console game. I'm hopeful for fixes in the near future, but knowing Capcom and their track record, we won't see noticeable improvements for months or ever. If servers are no longer an issue when someone reads this review, then it's likely because so many people have finished the game and aren't playing, reducing the load on the servers.As a long time MH player since the PS2, this game was a massive letdown. For returning fans, play Generations Ultimate for the switch instead.MAY 2019 UPDATE TO REVIEW:Most graphical and performance issues have been resolved. Keyboard and mouse issues have been resolved.Game is still several months behind in updates, but at least it's now playable on PC.Gameplay still panders to MMO audiences rather than MH fans, but it's a good game on it's own merits. If you don't like min-maxing your gear in MMOs, then there's not much endgame content to enjoy. Timed events limit your ability to do as you please, but it adds a longer life span to the game; for better or worse.Final verdict: Monster Hunter: World is a good game, it's just not a very good Monster Hunter. If you're a hardcore MH fan, consider MHGen Ultimate on Switch instead. If you don't mind a simplified experience, then MH:W is fine.

author: Zazz
review: I was going  to give this game a negative review just so they would pay more attention to the connection issues the game is going through, but it seems that won't be necessary, so far that's the only negative point of the game I can agree with (this coming from someone who strongly agree with most of the negative reviews around with the exception of those that don't provide any useful information at all).Now despite the disconnection issues (which I think steam has something to do with) I've been having a great time with my friends and yes the progression on the quests may make you play alone for a bit  you can still hunt the monsters with your friends once they finished watching the cinematics (you can leave the mission at any given time to continue it later) Here in some negative comments they make it seem like you have to complete the whole game to play with your friends, so fear not, if it doesn't work they can always join you through SOS signals, I think there is information out there on how the multiplayer works.Now adressing the graphical issues, so far I am running it at constant 60FPS on high settings with a GTX1060 (3GB) with the other specs are above the recommended, only FPS's drops I get are when it's either raining or when in a party 4 with a lot of effects going around, without dropping below 30fps, the blur everyone is talking about is named volumetric fog and there is a pinned post on the discussion thread of the game that tells you that disabling it will increase your perfomance (although it doesn't specify that it will get rid of the blurry effect as well) so you should be good as long as your specs are on or above the recommended ones, forgot to mention that you can set the frames to 30fps,60fps or no limit, I would recommend disabling v-sync unless you are streaming. The complains about the combat system: It is a bit clunky I'm not gonna lie and the target system is awful so don't use it, aside from that that's the way Monster Hunter's combat is and has been for a long while, you have 13 other weapons to try if you don't like your current one's moveset, you'll see this won't bother you at all once you get better with them.So without any bias; The combat system is quite fine and won't drag the fun out of the game (except for the dumb target lock-in don't use that crap with mouse and keyboard, it's awful).Now adressing the "♥♥♥♥ port" ones, these ones... Clearly have no idea what a bad port looks like, the things you need to configure are there in the options panel, and for those that aren't go to the game folder and modify the config.ini file text into whatever you wish and unlike other ports the game shows you the keyboard/mouse keys you need to press instead of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Xbox controller ones. Obviously it's not a PC game, but if you are gonna bash the game for being a port then do it properly.And finally my personal opinion about the game.It's great, but keep in mind it's not a game for everyone since you'll need to grind materials in order to get better gear (Not to an excessive MMO grinding style unless you are looking to use all the weapons and armors in the game) so far I didn't find it as repetitive and dense as in other games since everything I do feels like progress, you can have more than one character so you can also play alone while your friends aren't around if you wish to progress together, it's really enjoyable when it comes to multiplayer, except for the disconnection issue that's going on right now which can be painfully annoying, the big monsters feel quite unique along with their weaknesses, each map also feels quite unique and quite pretty, love the conceptual art of the game and the work behind it. I would keep going but I think there are better well structured reviews here that'd do a better job than me at it.tl;dr : Game is nice just make sure you know what the game goes about and what you do in it, if multiplayer connection issues will make you hate the game then wait until they patch it although they aren't as severe as the negative comments make it seem, you can go online through the in-game board and rejoin the session if that helps.

author: Icephyre
review: *update: Party disconnection issues have been fixedSolid port other than the party disconnection issues. Intel i7 4770K, GPU 1070, 16GB RAM, 144Hz g-sync display. I average around  92 fps even with my 'ancient processor'. Turn volume rendering off. If you dislike the motion blur when swinging the camera around, disable AA.

author: Tibby Cat
review: I've played the game for about thirteen hours now and I love it! It's a heck of a fun game and the gameplay loop is addicting and the monsters have a really cool design about them. Getting toknow the creature and it's animations and getting better everytime you fight it is satisfyting  and adding a friend in makes it all the more fun. The story is meh and feels a little more pushed into my face , especiallly with the unskippable cutscenes. (welcome to 2004) I know I have a lot of hours left in the game, so i'm really looking forward to that. If you asked me to recommend this game, I would say rather confidently: No, not right now. -M/kb support in my opinion is pretty awful. The mouse feels way smoother than it should and doesn't feel natural at all. -Connection issues galore. Besides it having an issue with keeping the steam community from going wild when playing to the point that I just have to go offline on steam to stop pop ups of friends coming up. It took me 30 minutes to connect to a server- and then 30 more minutes to find a party I can connect to. Once I connect, the chances of me being DC'd in the middle of the hunt are rather high. -Even when playing with friends, we would get these connection issues and it is pretty frustrating. The game lets you continue on the hunt alone if you get DC'd, but I was hoping not to face THIS many issues at launch. -no 21:9 support. My favorite moniter has been rendered useless. It'll say that the game is running at my native resolution but i'm playing with black bars on the side. Luckily, I have a 2nd monitor that i'm able to force the game onto and play 16:9. An indie game I got for free the other day has 21:9 support. -The co-op system isn't ideal and is feels very dated. This isn't a technical problem, but bad game design. Still, not in my favor buuut my friends and I just deal with it. Not a big problem, but could turn some people off from playing the game with someone. -Aesthetically it's a pretty game, but not pretty enough to be demanding so much from your CPU. I'm not a super technical wizard, but the game pushes my 6700 into 75-90% CPU usage. I don't suffer any framerate lag, but I can definitely hear and see my computer using all it's got. I've played most of the demanding games out there with minimal to no issues at my native resolution, but this game makes my computer do its best Torbjorn impersonation. I'm sure there's a lot more issues going on with a lot of other people out there, but this is all I could think of off the top of my head. If you really want this game RIGHT NOW, be aware you might not have the smoothest of gaming given to you for your hard earned money. If you can wait it out a bit and hope for a patch, then do so. You might be rewarded. I don't regret my purchase, but I'm definitely not completely satisfied with it. Anyway, I'mma go hunt some monsters. Tibby out.UPDATE 1.22.19 It's been a long time coming, but CAPCOM has updated the game into a state in which I could whole heartedly reccomend it. There has been a steady stream of updates and fixed a lot of the issues which were ailing the experience for me. The best part of all these updates...THEY FINALLY ADDED OFFICIAL ULTRAWIDE SUPPORT. Thanks, CAPCOM. Please don't break it.

author: Puppet of Fate
review: [] Beginner[] Casual[] Normal[] Expert[] There is none[] Bad[] Alright[] Good[] Frustrating[] Boring[] Fun[] Challenging[] Just press a bunch of buttons[] Average[] Hard[] Unfair[] Paint.exe[] Alright[] Good[] Beautiful[] Earrape[] Alright[] Good[] Beautiful[] Game itself is one big BUG[] Can get annoying[] Few Bugs[] Nothing encountered[] Really short (0 - 3 hours)[] Short (4 - 7 hours)[] Few hours (8 - 20 hours)[] Long (21-50 hours)[] Very Long (51-100 hours)[] Extremely Long (101+ hours)[] Endless...[] Full price[] Wait for Sale[] Wait for Deep Sale[] Nope[] Xbox Controller[] PS Controller  9/10The only thing currently stopping me from rating it higher is that the connection issues, the glaring mouse issue and the missing 21:9 resolution is really annoying. author: friend
review: dogsht servers fix ur game thanks

author: Cervantes
review: I had never played a Monster Hunter game before, and I don't own a controller so I had the mixed pleasure of getting the full PC port experience. The controls will feel awkward, there's no way around it, nothing was tailored with KB+mouse in mind and the only effort the devs did was to let us rebind most combat controls with relative freedom, which I appreciate.From what I've heard this game is a good Monster Hunter game, but if you were not into that to begin with it won't change your mind. I can understand that, because the core gameplay is very... special. It basically revolves around switching between weapon sheathed and drawn to perform two very distinct sets of contextual actions, a lot of those you would expect to be able to do in any situation like for example "moving at a decent pace" or "grabbing something on the ground". Nope, gotta spend 5 whole seconds to fold your ridiculously huge weapon fourways on your back before you can do ANYTHING else than attacking with the aforementionned weapon.This makes every fight feel like an uncomfortable mess of animation locks, awkward movements and sheer frustration, since most monsters in the game move quite fast and hit quite hard (as in one or two shot you). The gameplay is all about timing your actions properly rather than quick and/or complex executions. And since every decently big monster in this game has a ridiculous (and invisible) HP pool, most hunts will take longer than a damn Timewalking dungeon in WoW. However, it does feel really satisfying when you manage to go ham on a monster, be it from teamwork, mounting it or just landing a really big (and long-winded) attack.Also the game involves a LOT of grinding, especially when you start to get into item sets. You'll need to kill that same monster you struggled on for 40 whole minutes about 120 times before you finally get the one 2% component you need to craft the final piece of armor you need from him.The multiplayer aspect of the game is very important, and that's where most of the fun you'll had will come from. Unfortunately it's full of oversights and problems. First off, the server keep sh*tting the bed. It seriously disconnects you from sessions way too often to be dismissed as a "release issue", fix it already. Then there is no "matchmaking" to speak of AND no global lobby or even global chat to use to find people to play with. The only time you'll see other players is during the mission itself, during which communication is usually extremely limited since the chat is awkward to use and every mission is timed. So you'll find yourself joining randoms from the "respond to SOS" menu, then leaving and never seeing them again usually without exchanging a word once the hunt is over. Playing with friends through the "story" was also a bit annoying since most missions require you to play solo until you get all the cutscenes, then quit in front of the monster, redo the mission and THEN you can invite your friend assuming he's done the exact same thing.To conclude I'd say the game is a good timekiller. The story is easily forgettable and just here to introduce the various monsters and areas in the game. Visuals are great and I thought it was a good discovery experience, albeit riddled with frustrating controls and server errors which prevented me from reliably play with my friends. It is quite addictive, and there are a lot of weapons to try out and a lot of big monsters to kill or capture. I probably won't spend the hundreds of hours required to fully gear myself out and take on the biggest challenges, but I can see the appeal.[edit]Guess I did anyway. It sure is an addictive game !

author: Ryver Cryx
review: Clocked at 85 hours, i think its time to redo my reviewThe bad:-INTERWEBZ CONNECTION PLZ FIX MAKE POST ABOUT IT IN STEAM FORUM > yes it has issues, but not as bad as people say, it works 75% of the time.-Lack of information on items and skills. a *demon pill* buff lasts 20 seconds, and a *demondrug* buff lasts untill u get KO'd, and a *demondust* buff lasts 3 minutes, but nowhere is this info on the item discription nor does it say on how much buffing it does, this is just an example on how bad the some of the info is.-80% of gear is junk, Yes you heard it, in this *farming for items to get stronger* most of the stuff u get has useless skills on it, you can do certain builds for certain monsters, but why would i sacrifice my attack for the ability to eat muschrooms?-Cliche acting, Serieusly, the acting comes to a point where you just cringe at the characters, andi dont mind bad acting, but when it becomes cringeworthy it becomes a problem.The good:-has some of the most epic fights i have ever seen in video games. It's true, i don't know allot of games that offer me these kind of *edge of my seat moments*, These is just something about fighting a huge mosnter and the camera goes everywhere, its just so ♥♥♥♥ cool.-Difficulty scales nicely. the game is in 3 parts, the *Blue stars* storyline is where you get the introduction and ez mode for casuals, the *Red stars* dtoryline is where the difficulty ramps up, mainly with bigger HP pools on the monsters but also allot of new ones with new moves. And then there is the endgame or the *Tempered* monsters who have even more additions to their moves.-Cat companions, need i say more?This game is for everyone, from Casual to hardcore, you most likely WILL enjoy this, and since the succes it had, one can only imagine the cool next monster hunter game that's coming for us.A memorable game that should be in your library.

author: Coey
review: I love the Monster Hunter franchise and I will be comparing this to other entries in the series for how it holds up as a Monster Hunter game. I'll just cut to the chase.>Pros:-A few things are streamlined in a pretty good way. You have infinite whetstones, picks, and bug nets, and you always have a BBQ spit and fishing rod with you. None of this takes up any inventory space. I guess I enjoyed the flow of having to buy picks, bug nets, and whetstones, but I always took those items with me anyways. You were honestly screwed if you didn't bring whetstones. You'd never run out since you'd have a full stack or so, and you were kind of forced to bring them anyways.-Gathering goes by a lot quicker. The animations are faster to the point where you can gather while running by items, and the nodes tend to give you a little bit more herbs and such this time around too. This streamlines the process in a pretty alright way.-Every weapon seems to have at least one new thing it can do, and they're all pretty neat.-Combat is actually pretty fun, if not a bit too easy.-Paintballs have been removed and replaced by the scoutfly feature, which is fair enough. I don't mind actually tracking the monster down.-They're adding in new monsters via updates, which is nice.>Cons:-There are only around 30 monsters in the game at the time of writing, and I doubt we're going to see a lot more in the game with the updates.-The game is WAY too easy. I was only genuinely challenged a few times throughout the game so far, whereas other MH titles have brutalized me before.-There are tempered monsters which are buffed versions of the monsters in the game. It just gives the monster a damage multiplier. It's lazy and not nearly as unique as the hyper, frenzy, and deviant monsters we've seen before.-There's so much healing everywhere it's ridiculous. There's not nearly as much pressure from running out of supplies as there was in the previous games because there's free healing everywhere more or less. -Armor system is a mess. You can just take whatever pieces of armor you want and slap them together and get full benefits, as a single piece of armor will give you a full skill. There's really not much of a reason to get an entire set anymore.-Weapons all look incredibly bland. In previous titles weapons would all be unique looking, but in Monster Hunter World, they're all more or less the two "bone" and "iron" versions of that weapon with a few edits.-Armors actually look relatively bland, too. This is most likely to make it so sets that are all mixed together don't clash as much.-Network issues are fairly common. Expect to be disconnected and be unable to connect.-A lot of random FPS drops out of nowhere.-Denuvo doesn't exactly effect the gameplay, but this game has it. I suppose it's up to you whether you're okay with that or not.-You only get about 80 hours or so of content compared to the hundreds you'd get in other Monster Hunters. I'm hoping the G-rank update fixes this.This game can be fun at times but they really messed up on several parts, and the slog of getting through hunts that don't really offer much of a challenge kind of makes that fun a little harder to get to. I normally don't write a lot of reviews but I wanted to say something. Just play one of the previous titles if you're looking at getting into the franchise.

author: Scrub McGrub
review: *This review is written after reaching credits and 72 hours of playtime*The game of Monster Hunter: World is very well documented and reviewed thanks to the console version at this time. I could have played that version of the game at launch, but decided to hold out on PC for a smoother experience and improved visuals....... well that was a mistake. Even on a GTX 1080, 32 gigs of RAM, and a i7-8700... the game has bad issues. Serious frame drops down into the teens on some of the late game content. Texture bug that will have you seeing muddy low res textures through the whole game, even when set to the highest texture setting. What should have been the best way to play the game is actually a couple steps behind PS4 pro and Xbox One X. The game itself is fine, very enjoyable... limited mod support ATM. You'll need it if you want the proper controller prompts on Dual Shock. Obvious this port was rushed and sloppy. Upcoming DLC is free anyway- so not like Capcom will give an apology gift.Bottom line.... if you waited this long like me. Give it a couple months of updates and you'll likely hit a holliday sale on the game anyway. Or if you're the type of person that likes a sub-console experience on your PC (maybe that's all your rig can do).... then have at it.

author: SithDuelist
review: The game is unplayable for me since the most recent update on Jan 9. I did not purchase/install the expansion (Iceborne). Previously I used med/low settings at 1080p30. The menu now runs at seconds per frame rather than frames per second, and dropping every graphical setting in the game to the lowest value (or off if possible) still leaves the main hub running like a slide show. Perusing the forums shows I'm far from the only one with this issue. I cannot recommend this game in its current state to anyone.EDIT: As of 1/21, after a game update and updating my PC from Win7 to Win10, the game is now working again. However, it now crashes upon any loss of focus; this includes selecting any options within the steam overlay, like controller settings. While the base gameplay is great, the ongoing technical issues leave me hesitating to recommend the game.EDIT: As of April, the technical issues appear to be resolved. I am getting good FPS and the game no longer crashes upon loss of focus. The gameplay remains extremely solid. Since the tech issues are resolved, I can now strongly recommend this game.

author: Dax
review: I've been a huge Monster Hunter fan since Tri, and had put in a large amount of hours in Monster Hunter: World on Ps4.There have been a number of issues with the PC port however the only one that qualifies for making the game unplayable (connection issues) has since been fixed.I personally play with my DS4 however I have a number of friends playing with keyboard and mouse who both prefer it over the controller, so there's a element of subjectivity to which controls feel best.Despite these issues, I can't see myself thinking this game isn't worth it just on sheer amount of content and genuine old school fun you can achieve with this game. It's a testiment to the franchise and takes it in an exciting new direction.

author: Flik
review: Great port of a fantastic game that's fun to play through all over again. Serves as a good jumping in point for anyone not familiar with Monster Hunter games too. Had no tech issues or online issues as of 10 hrs played all multiplayer. Using a controller so can't comment on keyboard and mouse if that has any issues but some friends are using that and haven't complained.

author: Lavender
review: It has a lot of problems, but damn I'm extremely glad I decided to try this game on a whim 'cause it got me into monhun SO hard. Charge blade quickly became my favourite weapon in any game ever (and took me weeks to learn everything it has to offer).The main thing World has that stands out from other monhun games is the environmental design. It feels SO carefully put together to feel like actual places rather than the collection of rooms connected by corridors the other games don't really try to hide. Monster behaviours feel distinct from each other and even something as simple as variation in how aggressive different monsters are when they see you really feels good (even if it's odd that they're all aggressive when you first meet them in a story quest). Having monsters WAY stronger than you're intended to be fighting roaming the areas is scary (at least to a monhun first-timer) and it feels great!World really stands out as an experience above all the other games, though I would say Rise is more fun to play. The slinger & clutch claw stuff is annoying & when you're using it fully it just makes the game easier in a way that isn't fun at all. Elder dragons are mostly just frustrating to fight in World and I was surprised when I actually had fun fighting them in Rise.

author: Meconium
review: With any game that comes from a console, I am highly hesitant to purchase. This hits home though! Are there bugs? Well, what game releases and doesn't have them? Zero. So, there you go. Ignore a lot of the negative reviews. A majority are people upset at the anti-piracy software they use (which is causing zero performance issues), multiplayer issues (look up port forwarding?), or just general people trying to make the game run on a min-spec machine. My only complaint? Allow me to join missions with people that are higher than me in the story. Just don't give ME the credit till I've completed the story up to that part. I cannot believe some of these reviews. You own a PC, do you know how to even run it? If you want something to work without effort, get a console system and don't complain you are locked at 30fps. If you want run games at 60+fps with all the settings high...upgrade more than once every 10 years, learn how a PC works, and learn how to tweak your system. Seriously. I'm almost 50yrs old, and run circles around people in their 20s with PC knowledge. Game is good. Play with your friends. Enjoy. Look at the specs. Upgrade if you're below. Learn your PC. Win.

author: NotASpy
review: Monster Hunter: World is a real special game, that is everything one could ask for in a Monster Hunter game. There are tons of weapons with various play styles, tons of unique monsters to fight that all have their own abilities and tendencies. There is a load of challenges to complete, cosmetics to collect, and so much more this game will really keep you busy with content. They have tons of events by holidays, or games like RE2, Witcher 3, FFXIV, and more that add even more stuff to do. This is really just a gem of a game, and it is sooo much more fun with friends. I started the game solo couldnt get into it, but once I teamed up even with randoms the game became so much more enjoyable. Overall, hit big gooses with big swords wearing a Geralt armor set while my pet is in a wedding dress throwing big bugs in my face, what more could one want?

author: Calum Gettum
review: Let me start of by saying, i would recommend this game to anyone and everyone who has even the slightest interesst in great combat, interessting enemy designes or even just cool armor and weapon designs. and not just the game itself, if you are really interessted in the game or trying to get into the series it would be a crime not to also get the iceborne extension which just about doubles the playtime and content and brings even more great challange and exciting monsters to hunt down. World brings high levels of Custommisation and build veriaty with 14 diffirent weapon types and hundrets of armor sets with interchangable parts and unique abilitys to fit whatever playstyle you prefer. every weapon type feels unique and brings a diffirent style of play, light- and heavy-bowgun might look similar at first but feel worlds apart in actuall play. sword and shield and dual blades might seem like similar short ranged fast weapons, but while dual blades are a test in stamina manigement, positioning and timing, sword and shield is a utility beast, being able to do cutting and blunt damage and using item with the weapon drawn. the lance makes you feel like an impenetrable fortress but the gunlance offers unimaginable offensive abilitys. no two weapons feel alike even if they have similaritys at first. the monsters that you will be facing through out the game also have no equil, every monster has their own personallity and every hunt is a learning experiance to perfect playing around them as efficiantly as possible. but this game isnt just you with a sword in a blank room, fighting an overzised lizard, part of what makes a great hunter is the ability to use the enviroment to your advantage. wether that be by picking up slinger ammo to chuck at the monster to cause all sorts of effects, or knocking over rocks to crush it for massive damage, tipping over plants to make them spill poison that the monster can step in. the world feels full of usfull things and looks wonderfull at the same time. now, my recommendation comes with a bit of an asterisk. if you are truly going to get into this game i would suggust doing it along side someone who already knows it somewhat well, and this has a few reasons.firstly, the game can be VERY overwhelming at first and even tho it tries its best to explain everything to the player it can be easy to just skip over some of the text boxes and miss important information. learing through text boxes can be quite boring and might turn some players away entirely (i've certainly met people who ranted endlessly about how bad the game is just because they didnt understand/know about a mechanic that they had skipped over in the tutorial). having someone at your side to explain more important mechanics along with basic things can be extremely helpful at first, a lot of youtubers also make great tutorials on weapons, armor skills and the such to help anyone wondering about how to optimize or even just improve their play, tho none of this is really required. all in all its a game best enjoyed with an open mind and a good friend.

author: TyresTyco
review: Review update due to iceborne 07.02.2020.As expected Capcom continues to screw up the PC version. I'm no tech guru but what they have done with the Anti Temper Code is ridicilous. Please look for the Tech section as mentioned in the initial Review to learn exact infos about the whole situation.Iceborne is the peak of mhw's lifecycle. The game itself is amazing. Just the code behind it is even for japanese standards.. pretty anti consumer and 10 years backwards.I can't change this Review to Positive even If I love this Game. The way they handle the PC Version is a disgrace. Monster Hunter deserved better and I hope they use their new RE Engine for mhw2 without blowing a lot of cpus off.Go ahead and try this excellent game. If you have issues, steams refund option sure comes in handy.--------It is a shame what capcom is doing with this Version of the game. This is Monster Hunter, a game where people hunt and slay monsters. It is fluid and fun. Its repititive and grindy but the overall gameplay variety due to the awesome weapons makes it up for the for a MH game small monster roster.I'm a huge fan of the series. Especially now with "next gen" graphics and QoL improvements.So why a negative review? It's simple.Capcom screwed it up. They aknowledged that they dont have a real clue about PC game developing months ago. Which is ok. Everyone has to learn. But the way they patch the game is by far the worst Ive ever seen.They don't really fix things. They make the game with every new patch totally unplayable for a lot of people.I don't have any crash problems but the stutters and framepacing after the kulve taroth update seriously makes me nuts. (Still playable but annoying imho)There are countless threads in the mhw steamhub tech section for more info in that regard.I just want to voice my opinion with this review that capcom should get their butts together and aknowledge the problems half the playerbase have. They are silent..  one look at steamdb shows that a lot of people just quit during the kulve update because they simply can't play at all. Capcoms response? None at all. That shows me that they don't really deserve a positive review at all.. regardless how fun the game is. They screwed it up big time with the inability to handle PC version development.I will change this review once capcom decide to finally fix their game instead of giving candy via useless limited event content which half of the community can't play due to stutters and crashs.People on the fence buying this should hold it and watch the patch progress. Or buy it and try it out for yourself and refund it if you have problems.------------...

I recommend anyone with a Nvidia card who is having major framerate issues to consider rolling back their drivers to find one that works, as that worked for me.

author: DuBeUsTTV
review: It's hard to describe the thrill of switching gears, going from games with guns and fast-paced bullet-dodging, hiding behind cover antics, to suddenly facing off against fearsome beasts of considerable size that'll do so much as eat you alive in a single flash of fangs.  Being the first PC Monster Hunter experience, Monster Hunter: World has definitely captivated some new fans (myself included) into the genre...albeit with the current meta of games holding true to the "RNG" scene of things.With a variety of weapons to choose from (fourteen to be specific), there's a different playstyle and different strategy with each weapon, and each monster; add one, two, or three extra buddies into the equation, and either you can wind up with a hellish torment of salt and rage, or a barrel of laughs so large that no comedy out there will ever outdo it.The story is short, able to be finished within a relatively short amount of time (I'd estimate...ten or so hours, at most?, non-stop?), provided you aren't the type of player who gets into a desire to hunt/capture a specific Monster for their parts to make the newest, greatest, best of gear you can have at that current time!  Plenty of extra quests on the side, though most still involve hunting, or gathering-that's a good, easy description for Monster Hunter:  Hunter/Gatherer.  But the developers at Capcom have a way of tying in continuous events and other universes in their repertoir to entice and interest players for days/weeks to come.If you want action,  MHW has got it.  If you want thrills, MHW has got it.  If you want salt, hell, MHW has got it (trust me, sometimes, mechanics will leave you questioning the meaning of life).

author: Sizz-Lorr
review: Decided to update my review, as the game has had a great many updates and changes as well. As indicated by the comparison of recent reviews to overall reviews, Capcom has proved themselves on PC as more than willing to resolve issues, listen to player feedback, and implement great updates and changes. At the time of this writing (Nov. 29 2019), that's an 89% postive of 11,810 reviews on recent  (just the past 30 days alone) to a 63% overall of 52,370 reviews total. This game never deserved mixed reviews, however if you are on the fence at all I implore to check out gameplay and guides. The quality of this game is undeniable, and almost all the negative issues present at launch are gone, or reduced to outliers! (connections issues were the main culprit, some very niche concerns of PC port options, refer to previous update notes if you're interested)The Monster Hunter Series has never held your hand, but MH World is by the far the most entry friendly entry in the series. It's a game that may require patience to learn your enemy, learn your weapon, and keep standing back up after getting beatdown. It is NOT a hack and slash game. Also the entirety of the game can be played solo if thats your cup of tea. Capcom has not only been updating with great fixes and QoL updates, but also tons of FREE content. Adding entire new monsters, rotating event quests, seasonal celebration events, collaborations with series like Megaman, DMC and more.  All in all, Monster Hunter Worlds is truly an amazing game becoming one of my favorites of all time, and it honestly would be a shame if you didn't at least try it. Monster Hunter is a game series that essentially boils down to big boss fights. In Worlds, that is big boss fights in beautiful seamless maps with no loading between zones and many many quality of life upgrades from the old handheld bound titles. Yes there are little small fries too, its not just one big boss in an arena. One of the themes of Worlds, is well...being a world. The maps look amazing but the focus on detail of being simulating an actual ecosystem is immersing. Many large monsters can roam the through the forests as your tracking and hunting one specific target, there are many species of small monsters native to the different maps, and tons of endemic life throughout. You can even catch said endemic life with a net and allow them to roam back in your house! I highly recommend watching Making of Monster Hunter video series to catch a glimpse of the passion, reasoning, and crafting care put into this game. The core of gameplay revolves around two parts, monsters and weapons, I'd argue this the summary of what you need to master. There are 14 weapon types, and these might be more akin to classes you'd see in other games. The movesets, attacks, playstyle, it will all be quite different from one another. As playstyle can vary quite drastically, it should only be a matter of patience finding what suits you. Check out the "All weapon types gameplay trailer" to get a teasing idea of the main weapons and how they might play. It's a game that may require patience to learn your enemy, learn your weapon, and keep standing back up after getting beatdown. Check out Arekkz & Gaijin Hunter for guides to learn the core of each weapon, and they also have other great informative videos to gleam info from. A good Hunter always takes notes, so they may better hunt their prey. The other, more obvious, key of gameplay is the monsters themselves. Much like learning your weapon, learning your enemy is key to victory. Each monster a range of attacks and patterns, and if you want to avoid being lunch it's best you pick up on them. Monster behaviours can vary from hunt to hunt, even if it's the same exact monster. In the game there are Low Rank and High Rank versions, and some variants later on. Low Rank are a basic version that is teaching you both the monster and the game. Remember, an informed hunter is the best kind. Don't be afraid to do your research on the monster, whether in-game looking at weaknesses etc, or out of game guides and such.To elaborate more on this, the headlining and most frustrating is the "Connection lost" message during a hunt, though pretty much resolved and now occasional stuff you might expect in just about any onine game. If dc/d you remain in the same hunt, but now youre by yourself.However, as hunts in multiplayer are scaled up, unless the monster is almost dead is it best to just leave if you are stuck solo. There are two options to leaving a quest, "Abandon Quest" and "Return from Quest". Abandoning allows you to return the hub in the state you were before the hunt started, allowing you to keep all items you may have used up, but losing anything you picked up during the quest. The other option simply returns you as you are, keeping any new things you gained, but on the same note any items used will remain expended. *Side Note* Cutscenes cannot be skipped, nor can they be watched together. So the easiest way to play these quests together is to post the quest and go in solo (you can still be in the MP lobby) get to the cutscene, then your friends can join in as long as they have watched the cutscene themselves. You can also fire SOS flares at that point, allowing any random player to join in, or you can return/abandon quest and repost in the hub if you so desire.  I have played a lot of ports, including many Bandai Namco games, and I have to say MHW is a great port on PC. Easily better than any of the Dark Souls ports, 3 included. Capcom has also included many updates addressing qualms or issues PC players have brought up. The game has a good many options, good customisable keybindings (including side mouse butons etc). Frame limits can be 30, 60, or Unlimited. You can use a controller, but mouse and keyboard are great, and with almost everything being remappable you can find what works best for you. There is NOW an option to turn off motion blur but I don't really notice the blur being intense like many other games, but I also always keep it on in my games I tend to like it or at least not care. Some resolutions or widescreen may not be supported, so if thats something serious to you definitely look into what is supported for your setup. (I have not bothered to check if this is part is any different when updating this review so I'll leave as is) I play on the higest graphics settings, with my FPS ranging from mid 40s to mid 65s. I haven't bothered turning down settings and seeing what FPS I get because this game runs super smooth and plays nicely. I have a launch edition gtx 1080 or whatever, but Capcom really put the focus in development to the gameplay running smoothly. My fps stays around the range, the low end is when I'm in a lava area with enviromental effects and lava spewing up with two monsters running around with explosive scales going off and all 4 of us trying to murder their faces. I think the game runs smooth and crisp, and pretty much offers almost anything one could want. As long as you can run and play the game, it's about the overall experience and it definitely delivers. Sadly if you can't get it to run no matter what, there's always steam refund. Left for reference MHW has become the most successful Japanese game on steam, surpassing even the Dark Soul series.. That's not to say it's good because a lot of people are playing it, that you should ignore all the negative reviews and just buy it, or whatever comes to mind. Look around, look past the initial red thumbs down reviews saying bad pc port and severe connection issues. As I have gone over, those issues do exist but not at all the extent you might think by just browsing the negative reviews. At this very moment there are 305k people in game, 8500 thumbs down is .

author: cogwork
review: A refreshing game in today's era of microtransactions and lootboxes. No ability to pay for power (pay to look kinda nice instead) is the garnish on this fantastic masterpiece of a game. As someone who's never played any Monster Hunter game before World, this game enthralled me and sucked me in completely. I played it shortly after my finals ended to give me something to do over the break. I thought I would play this for a bit and then go back to NieR: Automata again. I did not. In the time since I've started playing, I have logged over 190 hours in less than a month. That makes up for a little over 30% of all time I've had since I booted up the game for the first time, and accounts for eight days straight of gameplay.A fantastic combat system, beautiful music, gorgeous graphics, amazing depth, and the promise of even more to come. 9/10, one of the best action games I've played in a long time, please Capcom get the PC version caught up to console ASAP, I need me that simultaneous Iceborn release.

author: GuilelessMonk
review: This is furstrating for me to say because I do really like this game, I just wish it would let me play it with my friends. Nearly everytime I tried to play with my friends it would kick one of us out of the instance and force us to continue the fight alone. This wasn't always what happened, sometimes things were fine and we just got to enjoy the game, but getting though a fight without the servers decideding to split us was a rare treat. Even then it was tainted by the continuous threat of disconnecting us.I looked up and tried all the fixes I could find, turns out this is a fairly common problem, and none of them worked. A couple seemed like they were working only for us to be split up again and again the next day. I wasn't losing internet, I was on discord with them the whole time, and I've play other online games with them.For a game that is so focused on playing online with your friends to screw up the online portion of the game so bad is a real shame. Because there is a good game in here and I like it, I just wish the servers were usable
