author: IroncladLion
review: At just over 900 hours, I have now just 100% Monster Hunter World. As a 0.4% player to have completed all achievements MHW has to offer, here is my review.This is a superb game, I didn't even think I'd like this game when looking at it in the steam store. It looked a bit like an MMO, which it isn't at all. People said it was grindy, which it isn't, until well after you've finished the main storyline. And while the story is basic, it does an excellent job introducing you to the world, and hits the immersion factor just right.Here's the deal with this game, it's about big hunts, and big accomplishments. What I mean, is that unlike other games, you don't plow through 100+ enemies in one mission / raid. You generally hunt ONE monster per hunt (can have multiple targets per hunt on occasion). But that one monster could take anywhere from 5-50 minutes to track down, weaken, and either slay, or capture. Every hunt you take on is a challenge which will test you. Whether you come out of that hunt alive or not is based on how well you prepared, your knowledge of the monster, using the environment to your advantage, and the expertise with your weapon of choice. Every monster you take down is a memorable experience, which makes it that much more rewarding when you can high five other hunters / huntresses who have also beaten that same monster. It's a different style of gameplay, but I find hunting one monster in this game far more rewarding than blasting 100 generic enemies in another game.Another excellent aspect to this game is that it is equally enjoyable solo as it is in mutliplayer. Every hunt is scaled to be able to accomplish solo, or provide a challenge to a dedicated hunting team of 4. I played through most of the early game entirely solo, and only ventured into multiplayer once things got really tough, which let me tell you, the monsters get tough. This isn't a game where the brave hero clobbers everything in sight, and the game gets easier as you unlock more abilities. This is the kind of game where every new challenge you face will make you think it's impossible, until you take the time to improve yourself and best the monster standing in your way. Which by the way, . There is no easy mode, if you want to make it to the end, you better become one hell of a hunter / huntress.As for actual content, I don't think I've ever played a game at this level. It's not just about the numbers of monsters in the game, which there are many. It's about the quality of everything that goes into MHW. The monsters, the animations, the worldbuilding, the maps, the endemic wildlife, the weapons, it's ALL SO DAMN WELL DONE. Speaking of weapons, there are 14 different weapons types. Every single one feels like it could be the main weapon in it's own game. I've taken the time to go on 100+ hunts with each weapon, and they all have something unique and useful to offer. Want an excellent beginner weapon? The Sword and shield is a great start. Want to try a heavy weapon? The Greatsword hits like truck. Want to feel like you are going through a pre-flight checklist before unleashing the big nut? Charge blade is ready for launch. Want to feel like you are in an anime battle? The Longsword is for you. Want to try a ranged weapon? Score a bullseye with the Bow & Arrow. Think all the other weapons are nerdy and want to play a shooter? 360 noscope with the Light Bowgun. This list goes on, but I'll stop there.Can't forget the negatives of course. The biggest issue I've found while playing is that depending on how steam feels, you can have a great day of multiplayer hunts, or you will be constantly disconnected from multiplayer matches. This isn't an issue when playing solo of course, but if you are trying to play with others, it CAN be an issue. Bugs? I think I can count the number of times I found a bug on one hand, and that's after 900 hours. Early on, the user interface (UI) is extremely confusing. This IS a console port after all, and was designed with consoles in mind. With time, it all becomes very quick to navigate, but new players will often struggle figuring it out (I had to sit down and push buttons for about an hour to finally understand how all the menus worked). Last thing to address is the grind, which many people will complain about. Given the scale of the game, I honestly feel that the pace of progression is perfect. Some players try to craft  as the progress. DON'T DO THIS, you will go CRAZY. That'd be like walking into a grocery store, buying one of every single food item, and trying to eat them all to figure out what you wanted to make for dinner that night. The game has so much content that you can spend a lot of time crafting every piece of armor or weapon, but unless you try to 100% the game like I have, all that can wait. You can complete the game with any one weapon type, and a handful of armor sets. I crafted 3 armor sets which got me through the main storyline. The game really isn't grindly until post storyline, but by that point you will be 50+ hours in.The biggest deciding factor on if YOU will like this game, is if you enjoy hunting big monsters, crafting new gear, and hunting even bigger, tougher monsters. If you like that idea, this is hands down the best game you will ever find. There's a lot of little details in the game that make it that much more enjoyable, but I'll let you find those out for yourself. Now excuse me, I need to get back to hunting.

author: bedsheet
review: I decided to wait until I'd sunk a few hours into this game before reviewing it, mainly because there's so much content to explore it wouldn't seem fair to write a review before I've experienced the majority of it. I'll preface this by saying that this was my first actual Monster Hunter game, so I can't really compare it to previous titles.I'll start with the obvious, you're going to need a powerful PC to run this game. This game looks just as stunning as the screenshots and trailers show, with the downside to that being it'll make your GPU run like a jet engine if you're not careful. If getting the most framerates possible never bothered you, this game is a pleasure to the eyes graphically. If you're like me on the other hand, the beauty of the game is hampered by the less than ideal performance on powerful hardware, especially in dense regions such as as the Ancient Forest when it's raining. This can obviously be countered by turning down either the resolution or the settings, which I'd personally recommend due to the nature of the game being very active and reaction times and input lag being big factors on how you perform.Onto the actual game, it's very fun. You're hunting huge monsters for what seems like forever, usually about 20 - 30 minutes (!) with the constant threat of death lurking at every corner. You'll need a lot of patience for this game, but god does it pay off when you finally kill the bastard you've been hunting for ages. Every monster you fight is a boss battle, even the easier early game monsters feel like a final boss. Craft armour and weapons with the materials of the monster you just killed, only to realise you need to kill it a few more times to get the thing you wanted. It's not very forgiving and very grindy, but if you're looking for a game you can sink hundreds of hours into without even noticing, its perfect. You've got a lot of weapon choices, all of which have their own unique characteristics with pros and cons, i'd recommend experimenting with as many as possible during the story so you can optimise how you approach the end game a lot easier.About the story, it's not very good to be completely honest. Then again that's not really what the game is about, the story is just kinda there to give you a reason to hunt these big monsters, and it accomplishes that goal perfectly. So no real complaints from me. The game picks up after the story though in my opinion, you're given free reign over the map with loads of side quests and investigations to do. It's also when you start becoming good at the game, killing monsters that used to take over half an hour in under 10 minutes. It really feels like you've become the chad hunter all the npc's always called you. You get access to the hardest monsters in the game, which reward you appropriately with some of the best gear in the game. This game can be boiled down to grinding till you're at the top, and then grinding some more, that's why I love it so much. There's a few QOL issues, but there's a lot of mods available to fix anything that you might find a little bit annoying. Overall though, the game feels polished, the multiplayer is a lot more reliable than it was back at launch and I don't think I encountered any game breaking bugs or glitches throughout my entire playthrough. Other than the less than ideal performance I mentioned earlier, I don't have any real complaints about the game. I used to complain about difficulty but if you play smart and get better at the game in general, you'll realise how it's a bit stupid to complain about it. I would 100% recommend this game at full price, and considering how often it feels like it's on sale, there's not much reason not to bite the bullet when it comes to a game with this much content.

author: Amatus
review: A slightly slower-paced hack n slash action game than other titles in the genre, though there are plenty of good systems to complement it. Inventory management and a level of strategy are required in this title, making for a fulfilling experience that sets itself apart from other action games. Character customization is quite good, with a surprising amount of options to set. Fashion is not too amazing in the base game due to linear gear progression and the limited amount of Layered Armors (cosmetic-only clothes) available at the moment. The expansion Iceborne will fix this by adding craftable Layered Armors for most, if not all of armor sets already available.Make sure to back up your saves manually, because you will put a lot of hours into this game and cloud saves are very unreliable on Steam.The PC version is sadly far behind the console version. Very annoying, but still a good game.

author: Starkkoder
review: Monster Hunter World is an incredible game, although is really different from the other games, it manages to add a lot of variety to the game, a new world that really feels alive and you have that feel of hunting a monster and not only having a boss battle.The multiplayer experience is awesome, the way it makes it quick and adjust the difficult makes it really fun to play with friends and try a lot of different builds.

author: Shirroy
review: A masterpiece IMHOThe game truly puts you in the role of a fresh "Monster Hunter" you start off slowly, scrounging around, getting some end monster parts and crafting or upgrading your first weapon of choice. Then after some time you get to the real good stuff and that is the HUNTS. you get into challenging fun battles alone or with a buddy or three.The battles can be hard but the rewards will more than make up for it.Resource gathering can be a pain at first but that all gets easier with time and as you progress through the story and unlock various stuff that can help with it.The environments/maps are all Beautiful and lots of interact-able stuff are added from environmental hazards that work for both the hunters and the monsters to endemic life creatures that you can capture and place in your personal room.The sound effects/BGM are beautiful too from the ambiance it provides while traversing the maps to the thrill it gives when facing the Monsters. The sound effects given to each Monster fits them so well that you can clearly know, after some experience, which monster is where and what they're doing.As for the story, don't expect too much for it, Monster Hunter franchise never really did focus on the story aspect of their games but it's there. Compared to previous Monster Hunter titles the story for world and iceborne is way better though.The Grind is the main factor and the end-game when considering this game, fights are hard but rewarding, the harder the monster the better the reward kind of thing, but it won't always give you what you want after the hunt and may require you to rerun specific monster for upgrades then hunter the higher tier monsters after, rinse and repeat. TLDR; Game is very much Worth it, A must-buy on sale and definitely worth playing with friendsThe Devs have really poured out their love for the game with continuous free Title updates, excluding the iceborne DLC expansion itself, they have released lots of long-time fan favorite monsters all for FREE. The only paid "microtransactions" are cosmetics and totally optional.

author: HEX 13
review: For new potential players (pre iceborne):monster hunter world is at its core and by name a game where you go around and hunt monsters i know shocking the game play is fluid with each of the 16 weapons offering unique play style to suit what you like for example you could have a giant sword with slow charged up strikes or on the opposite end two swift daggers that stack up damage rather than blow it all in one go. For player who like to optimize you can look in depth at all the armour sets and skills and see what works for you, this does not however alienate player who just want to look cool since for most monster you shouldn't need to follow the meta like a religion.the game isn't without its flaws for example the start of the game can drag out a bit and certain other sections of the game can be a bit of a drag but overall the pacing is relatively good.  TLDR the game does a good job at providing diverse play style to all kinds of different players if you can get past the somewhat slow start to the game.Post Iceborne:Alright here i am again so iceborne is worthwhile for all players because for new players you get loads of new monsters that can give you quite a challenge and for old player it adds loads of monsters that were sorely missing from the base game even monsters no one could have seen coming. it also adds onto the already great weapons by adding new moves and loads of new weapons to craft as you would expect from an entire new rank. in shot iceborne takes everything good about base mhw and adds to it significantly making the game even more worth while.

author: Cirrus
review: We're now at end-of-life for Monster Hunter World + Iceborne, and there's no better time to get into the game if you like (or think you'd like) it.The seasonal festivals will rotate every 2 weeks, giving access to almost all the event quests, which means you'll be able to just binge everything. The 2 siege monsters will rotate every two weeks, and the one released in Iceborne will even get solo/duo HP scaling (the one released in HR already has a scaling MR version.)There are plenty of mods at the Nexus and even a rework mod in the works (ICE) when you "finish" Iceborne and want to play through the game in a different way, if you can't wait till Rise or won't grab a Switch just for it.MHW and Iceborne has it's fair share of problems, but the bulk of the game is just pure git-gud-fun.

There are only a few things that are really hard to get and consistaintly feel just out of reach, but from my experience it does not impede on how much fun the game is. There are many different weapons for many different types of people. It’s a great game in my opinion.

author: ri_tard
review: There are a lot of pros and cons.This Game requires skill / timing / experience and a lot of grind !cons:- unskippable cutscenes, you are "forced" to watch all cutscenes and even 15 min. of credits in the End- The "Handler" is an annoying childish and overexcited Character, gotta cringe hard on her.- some Quests are only available for a limited time, so if you miss an Event then you wont get the Armor or Weapon and you have to wait a few weeks till you can play that Event again.- In the Story they always say "WE" but in the end its only "YOU" who fights against the Monsters.- Some Attacks are simply not avoidable, for example when you are lying on the Ground after a hit and the Monster starts using a Beam attack over your body you instantly die while getting up. The devs should make an option where you can roll to the side.- A lot of "Search for ??? Tracks" Missions- decoration farming is RNG and a real pain in the A**, not even fun tbh- the real game starts after the storypros:- Very fun when you have friends to play with. A lot of stupid sh1t can happen together.- a lot of diffrent Boss fights- a lot of diffrent playstyles (DD/Support/Tank or a mix of all 3 together) melee or ranged, a lot of combos and weapons to choose from- You can be creative with your builds/sets play however you like- You have to adapt, every Monster has its own strengths and weaknesses, that means your favourite set might work on one monster but not on othersAll in one this Game is pretty fun

author: Reif001
review: One of the best game of the year, great story , great desing and great mechanics.Its a good game for newbies and pro players.A few disconnection problem in the begining but now it runs like a charm on my low-spec PC.You can choose to craft from a ton of armors and weapons, also new updates are introduced every month (new monsters , festival events , armor , weapons , gadgets and more) keeps the game alive.I recommend this game to everyone who want's to have some good old fun with or without friends.

author: U.D.
review: Monster Hunter: World is a good game for a bunch of reasons.The visuals are amazing, every area is unique and the world really feels alive, as there are many different species interacting with you, the environment and each other.The gameplay is pretty fun, even though it just mostly consists of you hunting one large monster after another for their loot to make better gear to hunt monsters better, but it does not get all that repetitive. With a large variety of monsters to hunt and 14 different weapon types to use, and a large pool of passive effects from your gear, you can put a lot of playtime into this game.However, to those who have played some of the previous Monster Hunter titles, this game might not have enough endgame content to satisfy you. After completing the main story, all you basically do is hunt stronger versions of the same monsters you already fought dozens of times or wait for a new event to show up for any bit of new content.Until then though, there is still plenty of satisfying gameplay, so generally I still would recommend this game.

author: Dawnmetty
review: The Monster Hunter franchise is pretty big and pretty awesome, but it is not for everyone. Some people will claim it's hard, some people claim it's boring or lame for lots and different reasons. Fear not, for i will try my best to pull you into this world (wink wink) of awesomeness.In this game, there are 14 types of weapons for you to use, 3 are ranged and 11 are melee, varying from fast and light to heavy and brutal weapons, so i'm pretty sure you will find at least 3 weapons that you will play the most. Now to the real reason people play this franchise: Everyone likes boss battles, right? Now imagine that EVERY SINGLE hunt is a boss battle, with huge monsters and flashy details. That's Monster Hunter, my friend.There are lots and lots of monsters in this and other MH games, so you will have quite a lot to do, and yes, you will need to farm in this game, but the thing is, you will fight the same monster over and over again, right? But every hunt will be completely different from the previous one. How? Well, in one hunt you might cart twice and have a hard time, on the next, you might absolutely rek the monster and in the next, hell, who knows?One thing worth mentioning is, sometimes you gotta research or do some trial and error all by yourself, without someone telling you to, for things to properly work. You know, google some answers, monster elemental weaknesses, where to find what, what weapon is best for you against what monster, or even go with the classic social relationship, where someone you know, knows something you might not know and pass the knowledge further, which is pretty great.Overall, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ awesome game. Also, please don't compare this game to previous ones because it is completely different. I mean, the core of the game is the same, kill stuff, make weapons and armor of said stuff, use newly acquired stuff to kill even stronger stuff and so on and on. But what i'm refering to is with the slinger, living ecosystem, using the environment to your advantage, it's all first appearing on this game, so previous games are pretty different, but don't feel discouraged to try the previous ones, too! They are what built this awesome game, so do yourself a favor, and try them aswell.EDIT: After 850 hours of game, i gotta say, this game gets boring as ♥♥♥♥. I only managed to get more out of this because i kept making specific weapon-only runs, other than that, i rather play any of the old MH's, but that's my opinion.

author: Garroz

author: Kitro
review: Some of the most fun I've had all year.  If, like me, you havent played a Monster Hunter before, the gameplay is mostly boss fights and crafting. There isnt much story / drama, but more Sandboxy elements than expected.Aside from just fighting giant monsters in the wild, you'll end up:- Tracking and researching monsters- Picking flowers / mining- Fishing - Exploring for camp sites- Arm wrestling - Staged arena battles against different combinations of monsters. I can see how maybe the MH mechanics inspired DarkSouls.

author: MyPingIsHuge
review: Launch day problems:Connection issues: EDIT: Fixed after 2 patches, at least for me.Texture quality: for some reason, a lot of the textures are insanly ugly and low-res. Especially obvious during the main menu, of all things.Xeno Save "issue": for some people, one of the final bosses will autosave before a cutscene that will crash your game until you install a windows package.Little annoyances like not being able to skip cutscenes and not being able to join a friend until they've already seen them.Performance is also garbage, with top cards struggling to hold 60fps, but for some reason very old cards, below minimum requirements, can run it at 10~15fps. The inability to turn off things like motion blur, bloom, change depth of field, and other post-processing options might have something to do with the bad performance.Requires a mod that you can find in the steam forums (tech support section) to fix alt-tabbing on fullscreen, the insane CPU usage that freezes your pc if you try to do anything else, and the slightly lower resolution than what it should have.These are the main issues of the game right now. Even after all of this, it's still superior to the console version is almost every way, and plays very well on keyboard after you customize it and change some settings. The game itself has incredible gameplay with tons of replayability, but the plot is awful and the characters are as bland as possible.Lots of gameplay hours here. Feels like Dragon's Dogma 2, even carrying some of the same problems regarding the awful writing but great gameplay.Worth 130 reais? Probably not. 60 dollars? Maybe. It's a very fun game, and i've already played it for almost 100 hours as of the writing of this review. I like it, but it's hard to overlook the port issues. Beware.

author: Mir
review: Only downside is the lack of content compared to other games in the series, but the game makes use of RNG droprates for decorations in late-game to incentivise running the same monsters over and over again. While not necessarily bad, it leaves much to be desired. However, I cannot fault Capcom for finally going through with their accelerated release schedule, as the content that is now coming out is helping a lot in the end game.If you're a die-hard fan like me, just buy it.If you aren't, still buy it - you'll turn into one.Edit Post-Iceborne: Lack of content sated, this game is amazing.

author: HayleighWolfu
review: I've had few disconnects, I've been able to deal with connecting to lobbies/sessions relatively fine, with only one friend having semi-frequent disconnects.The game makes many QoL changes over previous iterations, and I've thoroughly enjoyed the game.Either I've been extremely lucky or others have been spouting doom and gloom over rare things (Unless it's hardware related in which case it's understandable), because the issues I keep seeing posted I've not experienced, and neither have my friends, bar one specific monster draining FPS.My only 2 issues with the port are that the mouse controls feel a little wonky, but I've tweaked the settings to reduce that significantly, and the prior mentioned monster being a drain on FPS.

author: Raito
review: All the bad reviews come from people having technical issues so I'm gonna leave a review based on my personal experience. I haven't experienced any issues. The game itself is amazing. I love these type of grindy games where I get to slay really cool looking monsters in a beautiful world. If you don't like grinding, or long, difficult boss battles then this game isn't for you. If you're into Dark Souls or Bloodborne you'll love this. This game reminds me of Dragon's Dogma A LOT and I loved that game so this is a must-have for me. The feeling of finally killing a monster that's been a pain in the ass is great and it truly feels rewarding. Every weapon is unique and really feels different from the others. The same can be said for the monsters, which have such cool, well thought-out designs. Of course, the most important thing, the gameplay, is fun and challenging. So yeah, I love this game and I think it's a genuinely good game. I'm sorry for the people who are having issues with the game and can't experience it how it should be, but I'm sure Capcom will fix these issues soon.One thing I would say is the price on Steam is a bit too much right now. Wait for a sale or price drop.

[No Pun intended]In a nutshell, this game really made me enjoy life again when I'm feeling depressed.

review: I love it. This is my first monster hunter experience and its pretty great. I see alot of people talking about the port and I would have to disagree. author: Shara
review: This game is great.  Monster Hunter World has some great visuals and very tight controls.  It is not the most user inuitive experience for new-comers but I feel if you stick with it and give it some time to aclimatize to the experience that it will be rewarding.  This game can be brutal and quite difficult to learn, so as someone who loves a challenge this is certainly a game that I love to play.  It has wonderful visuals and tons of RPG elements and a fun grind to it gathering materials.  The game has had a rocky launch with lots of disconnecting which causes quests to fail or groups to disband when playing multiplayer(quite annoying).  I really hope they are able to patch all the server issues we've been having over the last couple of days.  Otherwise I would say this game is just great aside from those particular problems with the multiplayer.  I would recommend this game to anyone that enjoys a challenging repeatable game.

author: MissVol†z [ᴘɪᴘɪꜱ]
review: Edit: I am redacting my negative review on the note that the connection errors I had been expiriencing are all but gone. Luckly, within a few days of release and getting better by the day. I am now able to carry a hunt with my newby friends. Controls are still bad on keyboard and unfriendly to left handed players. Please capcom fix this issue, it would be make the game a lot better. It's like a fly buzzing around you while  you're trying to eat a high quality well prepared steak. It's annoying and ruins part of a other wise amazing game.If you're going to purchase this game go buy a cheap 20$ controller or a wireless orUSB cable adapter if you already have a console controller. Right now it makes a huge difference in playing enjoyment.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Firstly, I come from the console version of this game. It's amazing and addictive, having put almost 600 hours into it since Release. I put off doing the current Behemoth expansion crossover because didn't want to not burn myself out.But, what was a smooth and fun experiance on console has become rather frustrating and rage inducing for some of my friends. I bought this game for not only myslef but for 3 other people seeing I had such a blast on PS4. Since those three people have never played a monster hunter game it's really frustrating that I cannot help them. I'm a hunting horn main without a team to buff, it's disheartening. We can't even connect to eachother with out the error time out smaking us apart! Also, the cutscene restiction is very multiplayer unfriendly, it plauges the console version now the pc. Can we at least play the story missions together from the start?Graphics are amazing, and that 60fps on a mid teir cpu like mine on highest detail settings! I've been so pleased.The mouse and keyboard controls are really bad with no left handed support and it's very confusing. Two of my friends are left handed and it's hell for them to remap their keys and half the time the keys don't work. Can't use the num pad well either. Even the keysboard is right handed oriented it's still bad. We had to switch to controller which we didn't want in the first place.Please capcom get on that connection problem, if you're not going to fix anything else can you please let me play soundly with my friends without being afraid to DC half way through a hunt. The monster hunter team has been amazing for addressing console issues, please show the pc version just as much love and attention.As much as I don't want to. Until the connection problems are fixed this will be negative review.I bought the pc version FOR co-op with my PC friends, I do not want to solo this game again,

author: diasandro
review: Monster Hunter: World (MHW) is a hunting game focusing on fighting the big monsters. It is the first series that is finally coming to PC after its previous predessecors which were only released on PC. With its release on both PC and consoles MHW brings many veterans hunters and new hunters alike, to the new world which fulls of beauty and danger lurking in every corner of the world. It is your job as a hunter, to balance this ecosystem and make sure the danger does not destroy the world.MHW is an open world game, with 5 different maps. Unlike previous titles which are clustered into different region, MHW have seamless map, making sure you have no loading screen during your hunt. With its open world, hunters can use the environment to their advantage, such as using the vines to trap a monster, ledge to have an over head jump attack, wedge beetles to swing around, etc. As you are travelling around the map, you will find some big monsters to hunt and some small ones as well doing their activities. Sometimes you might find some monsters are interacting to each other also.Combat in MH is always unique in a way. If you are a new hunter, be aware that it is not a hack and slash game. Combat is rather a stiff and rigid one, which is doing an animation after an animation. Unlike typical JRPG hack and slash which can be done by blindly spamming attack, MH is more like timing your attack to hit your target. MH is always like a 'live version' of turn based game, in which you need to attack when the monster is in passive state (not attacking) and choose whether to dodge, evade, or counter when the monster is attacking on you. Further there is no life/hp bar to show your monster's health, rather you need to watch your monsters behavior as it will weakened after certain attack.The point of this game is for you to fight a monster, gather their material, craft the weapon and armor from it, wear it, then hunt a stronger mosnter than before. This cycle makes the game itself called a 'boss-fighting simulator'. There are good amount of monsters you can hunt to give yourself a plenty hours of fun until you are burned to nothing left. There also tons of weapon types and sets you can try. Just experiment and enjoy yourself playing the game.While the multplayer was bad at the beginning of the game, Capcom has fixed this issue. You can join lobby or throw SOS in order to get into multiplayer. However it is advised that for new hunters to play SOLO along the first part of story lines in order to learn about the game. Some monsters tend to be hard to beat first time. While SOS is one way to skip the hard part, you might find it hard later on. However, if you are someone unable to beat a mosnter, some hunters might wanna help you still, just throw the flare and wait for help to come. There are some hunters out there willing to lend a hand to you.Unfortunately, I have to say that the game might not be able to run properly on a toaster. Even though the min requirement is a bit low, still you need to have a higher specs than that to have it running well. Hopefully few patches more from Capcom will fix some of the leak in the game that might slow the game a bit. Is the game worth the price? Full price of the game is already worth it. I finish the story line in about 45 hours, spend some times to do the tempered, which finally reaches HR 100 (to get the final optional / side quest) after 180 hours. You will find a lot of fun during the time. However, I do not advise to get the paid DLC, as the DLC is basically some cosmetics that does not do anything to the game, only change visuals aspect, yet it is worthless.In conclusion, I personally have fun with the game. Only some minor leakage from the game spoil the gameplay. As I already reaches 180 hours during editing this latest review, I could say I have the game worth more than the price I have to pay.Edit: 27 January 2019After one year release of first release, there is a big event happening almost around a month. For people willing to buy the game, now it is a best time to get it. A lot of events that were there in the previous additions are presented here and you might have a full lot of content to play for the whole month. There is also an announcement of Iceborne expansion (paid) coming later this year, which features new map, story, and Master rank (one rank higher than Arch Tempered).PC is finally about to catch up to console updates, with only a few monsters left before we finally catch up to them. Game is more complete now and some QoL updates are being released also on fix on the bugs. It is totally playable now.

review: All I needed was to see how this game ran on PC to give it a review, Im rocking a 4790k and a GTX 980 and this game is running very fluent!Monster Hunter is a beautiful vast open world game with tons of content that can keep you grinding and playing for hours on end. Im happy to say that the PC version of this is phenomenal and runs great dont be afraid to double down like me.This game is very demanding but its well optimized aswell it runs above 60 at almost all times and hardly goes down.If you haven't already jumped on this you should its very good and very fun especially with friends, I will say that one thing I didn't like about the PC version of this is how they handled Groups/Squads, on console you make a Squad and it creates a session for you and your friends, on the PC version you don't get that option you just get the option for a "friends session" I was real dissappointed with that.Overall, Monster Hunter has tons of content and this is the BEST VERSION of this game right now if you have a capable PC get this today you will not regret it and dont be afraid to add me if you want to hunt!

review: As a return player from console (ps4 non pro)I can tell that this port is goodIt load extremely fast than console (even without SSD)It runs at my totally potato laptop (i5 4210U, geforce gt 830m) with the I even tested on public pc (i3 8100, geforce gtx 1050ti) and it still runs well with if you have performace issue at Rotten valley just downgrade your graphic card driver. (before downgrade, fps around 10, after downgrade, went back to solid 30fps)This game is design for pattern learning,time invest, gear grinding.so if people that keep die and keep complain about the game have bad enemy design. so far the problem is on multiplayer, which not bother me much as i solo player.give them some time to fix the problem.If you want a good singleplayer game, go get it, is not bad.

author: Caramel Macchiato
review: Pre-ordered, and I have no regrets. So far it's one of the best open world grind rpg's I've ever played. And yes, it's a port, it'll be clunky. Like most games made on console first, it's always highly recommended to play with a controller. Not sure why people are giving this game so much ♥♥♥♥ when they laud Dark Souls despite having the same control problems. Speaking of, the combat is A LOT like Dark Souls. Positioning, timing, dodging, weapons have an attack speed and durability, prepare before hand. Yes, you'll get hit. Yes, you'll flail around for awhile. But when you hit? Oh man, do you HIT! It feels amazing!I haven't gotten far, only to the very first expedition quest, and already I'm having a great time. And I am aware of the multiplayer connection issues, but this game works totally well even without multiplayer. So chill out, jeez! Enjoy the damn game and be happy that it's here!UPDATE: Did multiplayer, played a quest with it. It's very hard to figure out when and how you can connect, so the challenge is mostly in getting together. Once you're in though, it's really fun and works very well!

author: ZEBpai
review: This is the first Monster Hunter game that I've played and the first released PC version of the Monster Hunter franchise. You play as a hunter of the Fifth Fleet and tasked to discover and solve the mysteries of the New World.I usually wait for sales before but this is the first game that I've bought a game exactly when it was released. Although this is my first Monster Hunter game I allotted some of my time to take a look of the previous games. Aside from the improved graphics/visuals from the previous games the gameplay really improved a lot as well. There are different kinds of weapons that you could choose from each with different play styles. You can fully customize your gears as well, mix & matching them with the skills and deco slots that you need. You could also change your sidekick Palico gears as well. So far, I have tried most of the weapons and change loadouts depending on the hunt I am doing. You are free to choose if you only want to use one specific weapon or try all of them.The story is ok but It falls of short to me since that's what I'm looking for in games. But I think MH is the endless hunting of monsters praying to the RNG Gods to give you the decos that you need. I think we couldn't get bored with the games as long there some continuous updates with new monsters and also season events. Right now, only the console have the season events but eventually it will be on the PC version as well.But for me the real end game is...Hahaha! You also have a room that you could put pets. You can move into bigger rooms as you move on with the game. The bg music and the ambience of the room is so relaxing that you could just sit on the bed or the garden all day.My overall rating:

author: Linker
review: Cant believe I havent reviewed this game yet. Ok lets go.As you can see from my hours, Ive definitely had my fair share of enjoyable experience from the game. I have played from the Steam release day 1 first hours and played almost 4 months nonstop this game. Its easily one of the best games Ive played so far and Im planning to replay it again with friends (definitely burnout a bit). Id love to keep the review short, but I love writing about this game, since I loved this game for months and months and still do. Witnessed 83-MW1 spams at the launch, Teostra almost crashing PCs with supernova, and other huge struggles the launch gave me and everyone else. Even when the road was bumpy and full of blockages, I still kept going forward, enjoying every hour of the game I managed to play solo and with friends. Playing with friends can be a mess in the start to understand because of being unable to join quests and such. Good tip to play with friends is to have everyone initiate the quest like normal going in solo, you find the area where the monster quest cutscene starts, you watch it throughout (♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ unskippable cutscenes absolute ass). After this, you return from the quest (DONT ABANDON). Now you are able to join anyone who has watched the cutscene as well.  You repeat this with every quest sadly, but this is how Ive done it with 3 different friends Ive played the game throughout with.For the older fans, its a completely new Monster Hunter, that has taken a huge turn in terms of gameplay change and such. While they added a lot of QoL features, they also gave some very questionable game mechanics, such as massively increased superman dive iframes, mantles and palico special items. Ive only played most of the newer titles such as 4U and GU, tried Port3rd and FU only a bit to tell World is very  different to the older titles. Not necessarily in a bad way, but in a completely new experience-kind of way.For newer players, its a third person ARPG that has some MMO-ish elements such as grinding for materials to upgrade weapons and such (arguable for RPG titles in general but MMOs really get the rep for this). Monster Hunter World is basically hunting monsters to progress story and finding out whats going on in the New World.Some pros and cons based on my own tastes and experiences:+ Replayability value is huge if you're into grinding    - Though if you dont have a taste for grinding, the game might as well last around 40-50 hours which is still really solid.+ Monsters and armor look amazing compared to the older titles. Armors have a nice mix of practicality and high fantasy    - Weapons lack creativity and its often a big complaint towards Capcom.+ Maps feel very alive. The endemic life and gathering makes it really enjoyable to just run around gathering materials and possible endemic life to decorate your home with the new pets you found    - Maps like ancient forest can feel extremely choky and small at times when fighting big monsters. Map amount is also quite        limited.+ Mod support    - Some of them are very questionable and defy the standards of the game such as solomoth and DPS meter.I could be writing on for days, but I want to keep the review at reasonable lengths.Big tips for new players to either avoid or get the game definitelyAvoid:- Dont like grinding- Dont like big monsters- Has to have massive open areas to explore- Played older MHs and wants a more traditional experience.Definitely go for it:- You loved old MHs but felt like they needed a major change- Love grinding- Set yourself personal improvement goals such as speedrunning certain monsters, no hit-challenges and dodge rolling roars.- Have friends to play withTL;DR If you're a MH veteran and want something similar, play GU and avoid this game completely. For newer players, if you hate grinding, I recommend avoiding this game. Its a fun experience but it has a lot of tedious parts scattered here and there.

author: Kaiser
review: Game runs on my potato on medium. Can run it at high textures but 30 frames if I don't want my PC to explode. Always disable volume rendering quality.CPU: AMD Phenom II X6GPU: Asus R9 270x 2GB8 GB RAMPros: It's MH on PC without going to China MMO or playing on emulators.Cons: Denuvo & no Ultra wide support. Capcom fix that.Edit: They fixed the connection issues we shall see the actual results this weekend since it always happens at those points the most.The reviews pointing out there is a boss that corrupts your save under a crash for a final cutscene are not an issue of the game but the PC's not having the required codecs to run this.Edit 2: They added multiple improvements got rid of the electric weapon fps bug, motion blur options, more mouse options, updates have been worked on almost every week you can check that on SteamDB.We got all the quality of life updates that console had inside the PC release, Jho release was faster, Autumn Festival with Ignition GS and Layered Armor, they communicated that Kulve will possibly appear around November. Things are looking good.Edit 3: Getting improved changes to keyboard and extended keybindings. They also don't seem to mind mods for now so you can get some pretty cool stuff and QoL changes, updates seem fine with Kulve Taroth arriving, then Lunastra soon and Arch Tempered content at the same time, we can expect to catch up to consoles pretty soon.

author: faux semblants
review: Game is plagued by network issues. If you have international friends playing the game or if you or someone else has mediocre internet then you will have to deal with constant disconnects from the hunt or even the session altogether. It wouldn't be so bad because in theory you should be able to rejoin a quest in progress, but no, slots in the quest are filled even if you are no longer in it. Using a VPN to have everyone connected on the same continental servers seems to mitigate the problem quite significantly, however, this is merely a band-aid solution.

author: Wolfie<3
review: Many Monsters.Such Combat.Very Difficult.8/10 Monster Hunter World is an absolute breathtaking game with so much to do, so much to explore and so many monsters to hunt. The base game is extremely challenging to newcomers as it throws you directly in the deep water with little to no assistance; leaving you all on your own. However, after about 20hrs in you will start to gain the basics and of the game and the core mechanics. If you are struggling with getting the hang of things then have a look at youtube where there are tutorials which will guide you into the NEW WORLD and BEYOND!!!I recommend Arekkz Gaming - The game has a huge assortment of weapons and armour sets to craft. Each weapon has its own individual play style and skill ceiling for you to master. As you progress through the game you will find the the various trees with elements in order to upgrade your weapons to make the stronger and specific to certain monsters.The monsters are very difficult in this game, each with their own abilities and attack patterns. But once you learn them they will be easy to overcome and net you a quest completion :) The game should always be played with other people in order for you to learn and be successful.I will recommend the game to any monster hunter fan who wants to be put to the test at their skills.Now coming to ICEBORNE, the DLC expansion shipped in a broken mess with many bugs and glitches and not to mention the game's anti-cheat taking up 95% CPU usage. But that has all been patched since and it look stable from now. The DLC expands with a new region and many new monsters, weapons and armour sets to be hunted and crafted. There will be many updates in the coming months to match it up with the console road map. If you have completed the base Monster Hunter game and are looking to expand your world then ICEBORNE is surely the DLC for you.

author: Windsfavor
review: One of the best grind game on steam.It is my first Monster Hunter game yet im pretty sure it is not gonna be my last.What i really like about this game is each time you dive into the combat against the monster, it is a new challenge. Because even though you have the end game gear and the tactics etc., you can still make that unforgiving mistake that ends up you being on the ground.(Fricking diablo,behemoth man.)Capcom wasn't expecting this game to exceed the number of players they were expecting to be on PC. Nowadays they are working faster for PC, updates are coming one after another.If you like souls-like combat and grind and also kicking monster ♥♥♥, this game is for you.

author: Ricia

author: Mimic
review: Gifted by a friend who waited for me to get it and yet himself is RARELY ON IT + Plenty to do+ Events & still gets updates+ Plenty of online players- Lip sync is laughable in any language- Handler is stupid and ruin the story IMO- Cannot skip cut-scenesThis is my first MH game, I heard and looked at some stuff from past games but thought nothing of the series but it looked some what fun from what I saw. I actually really enjoy this game, there is something to do for everyone let it be the grinders, the explorers, the supports or plain hell-rain loose on all players.I really enjoy just spending ages exploring the map collecting stuff or just enjoying what there is to offer. I like finding secrets and heck found something I was not even looking for because I got lost by mistake. Beating the crap out of monsters over and over is satisfying specially if you get the hang of mounting them for massive damage.Plenty of weapons to choose from so you don't feel you need to be tied down to a certain gameplay and I do like that type of freedom for gameplay. Events are very rewarding specially for your level even if the items they give are not a weapon or armour you use it is still nice to collect and have.I do however, REALLLYYYYYY hate how you cannot skip cut-scenes even on a 2nd character slot. I am sorry I understand story is important in a game, at least to some but if we have already seen it on another character or already in your cutscene gallery, let us SKIP IT.Some of them go on for WAY too long and even cringy to watch due to how stupid the characters are and the lip-sync and mouth movements are just weird.I hate the Handler, sorry but she is useless. You can take her out of the game and nothing will really change. She is a forced plot device to get stuff moving which can be done without her. She loves to get in trouble and wander ALONE into new lands multiple times and is still shocked when a monster appears to try and eat her. If anything the story is focused way too much on her and makes you feel like the side-kick.I don't find her funny or charming or anything they were trying to go for unless it was annoying and I am not alone in this. She can really take you out of the story they are trying to tell and how much she talks in the hub world about the main mission even though there is a text box telling you what you need to do to carry on the story.That is just my nitpick, I adore the game and can spend hours on it even if I am ignoring the story to do what I want such as grind stuff for my next armor/weapon.

author: Death's Index Finger
review: Monster Hunter World is a game about hunting HUGE monsters and netting little monsters as pets.The game features 14 different weapon class/types. Each weapon has different play style. You could be a samurai with a long sword, a rambo with a bow gun, a real man with a Great sword or be THE  trumpet dude.It has max of 4 players coop in a mission but It can be also played in solo.With each different class you can build a composition depending on the monster you hunt.Nowww it the questionsWith these being my first MH game, I'd say its a little difficult. The difficult part for me is learning the weapon, I suggest watching youtube soo you understand and know what weapon you will use. The monsters are interesting, their attack feels more of RNG than a pattern which makes it really fun to fight the chaos. If some games a 5 minute boss fights may feel an hour, THIS GAME IS LITERALLY CONSIST OF 20-40 MINUTE BOSS FIGHTS and you cant pause the game. so no pee break. Cutscenes cannot be skipped and the story is not the best but its not bad. But you don't buy this game for the story, you came here to make your character as your waifu and check each armor and see which one looks the sexiest right... RIGHT!Yes. To get your equipment you need to hunt different monsters and get different parts. the material you get is RNG so it may take a few more hunts to craft what you want. I'd say about 4-6 hunts to get a full set of armor if you are lucky. Late game grindiness: Why not add with another RNG. The another one is the decorations, they are added stats to your armor, its also RNG when you defeat a hard monster( tempered).Kinda. like i said, learning the playstyle of a weapon is boring because its mostly wall of text given to you and trial and error soo i'd suggests again watching youtube for guides. The order of each monsters in story makes it possible for you to learn your moveset. unless you constantly change. Yeah,really worth. It took me 50+ hours to finish the story and it doesn't stop there... there are tons of sidequest, and more variants and harder monsters to hunt. This game got me hooked that I got 80 hours within 5 days.You can play this game with a 4 player co-op optionally, having another player makes the game much MORE CHAOTIC, its harder because you don't know who the monster will target, its harder but its more FUN. Some hunts is made for multiplayer - Ancient Leshen, Extreme Behemoth, Kulve Tarot- These monsters are made for Multiplayer, dont be a fool like me wasting an hour on Ancient leshen and 4 hours soloing KT. ITS ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ BANGERS. REALLY . GREAT . OST. Each makes the fight more intense specially proof of a hero. my issues:Hit boxes is kinda clunky so its quite frustrating.IM ALWAYS LOST IN ANCIENT FOREST!and rip decoration farming its hell.NO PAUSEIts a really fun game that I look forward playing every morning. Each weapon has a unique experience EXCEPT I ONLY PLAYED GREAT SWORD LIKE A MAN; and each different monster has different experience that makes you adapt more. Hitbobxes may be frustrating but its just skill issue. jk. So overall a 8/10 games. Really addicting, really fun and has tons of content. Worth the bucks that will give you about 200 hours of hunting frustrations so happy hunting. EGG MISSIONS are made by SATAN himself.

author: FluffyButtSheep
review: Best game for people starting with the Monster Hunter franchise.Most fluent combat in the series, everything feels smooth when using it.Very immersive, beautiful to look at and lovely looking environments. Provides a decent enough challenge for new comers to enjoy. All 14 weapons feel different in how they play and have their own style. No pay 2 win mechanics at all and you get the whole game with one purchase.  Unnecessary story, it's a game where you hunt monsters and progression and you have a credit stealing side-kick just to insult it further.End game is a grind, an extremely RNG based grind which can get frustrating quickly with particular events only lasting so long.Awful excuses for content which are limited in availability as well. (Arch Tempered System)Artificial difficulty content which adds almost nothing new fight wise for most of the end-game content in the game. Game does not explain in-depth mechanics which are key to understanding how the game works. Connection issues which make me want to strangle a Dodogama. Monster Hunter: World is the 5th game in the main series of Monster Hunter, if you ever wanted to get into the franchise this is the best game in my opinion to try. But I do recommend you have a friend to play with or just someone who knows how Monster Hunter works. This game does not hold your hand and gives you the information in your "Hunter Notes". This was my first entry into Monster Hunter and I'm glad I picked it up, Capcom did a good job in making it easy for new players to come along but a decent enough challenge for experienced players. There is so much to do but it isn't intimidating or a chore to do for the most part. For the most part you can just view the story as a "it's there" sorta deal. I tried to enjoy what it gave but it didn't give me much to enjoy, except the cutscenes with the monsters involved, they really set you up for what you have to deal with, they're beautifully done and most monsters are enjoyable and don't feel like bull crap when you face them.All the weapons in this game feel different, no two weapon feels similar at all, leading into different ways to approach the task at hand. Do you go in with a massive slow heavy hitting sword or shoot it to death with arrows? It's all up to you to decided how you want to do, just have fun it is a game after all. Endgame wise this is where I have my nitpicks with, it becomes nothing more than a grind. Sure you can bring friends to have fun and take your mind off it but for me it got annoying, decoration farming can be done very quickly and there are some events that make it easier to get more. However there is a siege monster which is strongly recommended you face in a group working together is the worst case. The fight itself is fun, for the first few times but it get stale and when you grind it 50-100+ times and still don't get what you want is frustrating. There is no pay 2 win bypass which is a blessing, but there is no other way to trade in parts of the monster to get the weapon you desire so badly. The worst part about endgame in this game for me personally is the Arch Tempered system. It is meant to be very difficult to do and is reserved for the strongest monsters the game. For a majority of them they do nothing different for the most part, only a select few change it up if not at all. They add more health, more damage and change mostly nothing at all. There are good boys and good girls in the AT system but more bad boys than good. Go play the game, it's fun with friends and makes for some great giggles and just a great experience, just wish Capcom would stop the awful excuses for content.

author: Ottomic
review: Monster Hunter is, perhaps, the greatest series about level-less(ish) fights where player skill and knowledge is king over everything else that factors in. Choose your weapon among the over dozen types available, know its moveset, know your enemy and beat incredible odds by slaying or capturing incredibly powerful monsters. Craft equipment out of their spoils to complement your hunting, and move onto even more dangerous, powerful and difficult creatures, alone or in company.This installment brings a whole heap of changes to the franchise, making the world and hunts feel way more chaotic, wild and unpredictable than before. The player will be able to take further advantage of its surroundings be it hiding, ambushing or using the environment against their foes but also bringing new dangers and ever-changing conditions into the fights. The movesets have been more balanced and diversified, and the game feels the same it's always been, albeit more evolved and dynamic than before.Compared to the old games, it's true that MHW loses part of its 1v1 charm, and that doesn't mean everyone will agree with all the changes that have been brought to this installment, but I don't think any of them can be considered a net negative, and as the first ever in the series to reach PC, I'm very happy with how the game turned out. If Generations was brought to the PC I would probably play that as much if not more than World, but both the old and the new formula stand out as excellent products, each in their own unique way. The only thing I really feel brings the game down a bit is the new story focus as it railroads the player into boring and frankly kind of stupid "story missions" that don't really help the game flow, and maybe the lack of a "new game plus" mode (which to be frank has never been in any game in the franchise).8/10. This is a great game I would recommend any fan of games such as Platinum Games brawlers or Action RPGs in general and in particular the more punishing, skill oriented ones such as Dark Souls. It can get frustrating at times, and some weapons are a bit restrictive when it comes to playing them "right", but it is a great product overall.

author: Vimane
review: With Monster Hunter: Rise on its way, it would be nice to finally write a review about one of my favourite games ever.Monster Hunter. A title that's rather ironic, since it honestly sounds like a generic mobile game, while actually being the complete opposite. It's incredible how unique this game actually is. In my 15 years of gaming there's really no other game that I could compare it to, well, at least not to something even being remotely this good. Anyway, I'm gonna elaborate on my positive statement a bit more and dive deeper into some of the game's minor problems as well.First of all, it's important to know that games like these are supposed to be played slowly. You need to take your time with it to reach the full enjoyment potential. Sure, it's possible to speedrun the game and just go for the main quests for whatever reason, but you would just probably ruin the game for yourself, since it relies heavily on something entirely different to have remaining content. MHW essentially revolves around monsters the most, there's no real story that goes along with it, and that's totally fine. The main things are the variety of monsters and planning/crafting your gear. It may sound dull, but it's actually incredibly fun. There weren't many cases of me being bored while hunting the same monsters all over again for gear, and it's really hard to achieve something like this if you think about it. In summary, there's a gameplay loop you always do while playing it - Prepare, Eat, Hunt, Craft, Repeat. In other words, you prepare for the upcoming hunt, take best possible weapons, items etc. Then, you (should) eat before every quest to boost your stats and hunt a certain monster. After returning from a quest, you will gain monster materials, which can be used in many ways to craft something. That's that.Now, for a game like this without any actual story or lore, it's obviously extremely important for the gameplay to be very good. It is in fact, very good. There's something to be taken into a consideration though, character behaviour is rather unique compared to the other games, which may result in a clunky and slow feeling, but the harsh reality is, that you are just still bad at the game. There are dozens of negative takes on any Monster Hunter games in general that judge the gameplay by being ''overly sluggish'', and honestly I don't blame them. I had the same mindset when I first started playing the game, even considered refunding it. Obviously after getting into it more I started to understand that this game is simply different, and I have to adapt to fully enjoy it. Different is often seen as something unacceptable, and in this case, it gets ♥♥♥♥ on by most of the newer players that didn't even hit the 2h mark yet. Anyway, my point is that MHW is a game that simply requires some time for the player to understand it's true beauty.There are 14 weapons in the game, but it's honestly disrespectful to call them ''weapons''. Those weapons change the gameplay so drastically that they should be called ''classes'' instead. Everyone will probably find their best pick, since they vary from stuff like long sword, hammer, lance, as well as ranged weapons like bow or even bowgun. All of them have a completely different moveset, so learning them all at once would be a hard challenge, thus pretty much everyone mains a certain weapon for tough monsters. It's an amazing feeling that is, getting burned out cause of a certain weapon - slaying monsters all over again without breaking a sweat, so you decide to try out a new weapon and the game becomes fresh again. It's one of the biggest pros of this franchise in general, the pure difference of gameplay everyone experiences with their certain weapon is amazing.Sadly though, there's a rather annoying cosmetic problem this game has with those weapons. For some reason, World decided to just slap some of the monster parts on the majority of weapons, and only a few get unique design. It's sad, because fashion-hunting is important for a lot of players here, including myself. Seeing a weapon with great stats while looking ♥♥♥♥ makes me not even want it, that's how serious it might be. Well, at least all armors look amazing and different. From what I've heard, Rise will bring back the unique weapons again, so it shouldn't be a problem anymore, thankfully.I realize that it's already a very long read, so in my second to last paragraph, I'm going to talk about the influence of soundtracks. I’m a serious soundtrack enthusiast so I appreciate the variety as well as quality of them in every entertainment media. Many people tend to underappreciate the influence of soundtracks and see them only as a background noise. What they don’t realize is that those “background noises” actually make you feel emotions while engaging yourself in a fiction, that’s why they are there in the first place. And without a doubt, the soundtrack in MHW absolutely delivers. It can vary from a happy fantasy-like themes to dark Latin chanting making your bones chill. Quality is there, quantity is there, and its overall uniqueness is there. What more would you want? Now for the last topic: The story, or rather the lack of it. I mentioned before that’s it’s not a big deal that MHW focuses solely on the gameplay, but who wouldn’t like to see a decent story to go along with it? Unfortunately, MHW is the first Monster Hunter game that really tried it, and sadly utterly failed. I’m not gonna talk about it in big details since it’s still spoilers, that’s why I also avoided talking about monsters as well. Anyway, it’s just not good, it constantly tried to make you feel like being in a middle of some mystery, but honestly I just couldn’t care less, so I can’t even fully explain its problems even if I tried to. Don’t get me wrong though, I still felt really engaged in it because of the amazing monsters that I had to fight against, but at the end of the day you can’t deny the fact that it’s just straight up flat.I could keep writing on and on about a lot of other positive aspects this game has, but it’s probably more considerate to write about the most impactful pros and cons. So yeah, MHW could improve in a lot of way, just like every other game out there, but I’m ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ certain it’s a near perfection for sure if there ever was one. The amount of memories and joy it brought me is outstanding, the feeling is so strong that I even decided to buy a Switch to experience the classic Monster Hunter, as well as to await the newest entry in the series that is MHR. Thanks you Capcom for releasing the first ever Monster Hunter on PC, since it allowed me to finally discover this amazing franchise and let me feel a variety of priceless emotions while playing it.

author: • Ryo •
review: one of the best Co-op games I've played ever!and Iceborne was even better than the basegame itself!everything is amazingly fun in this game except for a few things- the fact that you can't join a friend unless they've watched a cutscene you've already watched is kinda lame and it's stopping players from progressing together- the handler is annoying as hell and I hope there was a way to use her as bait for monsters- the fact that players can't rejoin a quest after they DC is pretty annoying - game is getting filled with hackers and reporting them doesn't seem to do anythinganything else was perfectly made and I thank Capcom for creating such a lovely game

author: Rastamonsta
review: Extreamly great and streamlined introduction to the series for new players. The game runs perfectly beyond a few FPS issues on High with my GTX 1060 and I7 core. Some reoccuring issues for many people is the connections (which is nothing new, the PS4 inital launch was the exact same, espcially since its the 1.0 patch), and forceing cutscenes on people. That last point is pretty annoying in multiplayer but it is ONLY for the main assignments aka the story missions. after you finished low rank, cutscenes are sparse and very far between. Its almost comical how much I honestly forgot about cutscenes until I go back and help friends still in low rank.Beyond that, the combat is great, the mechanics and difficulty are incredibly rewarding, and Capcom have outdone themselves. I've played this for 160+ hours on PS4 and am enjoying the process all over again.

author: Marwissa
review: Updated March 06 2019 Storyline is good, but between HR 16-30-50 it's a time for you to pick and choose on your own so doing event quests help! But it's boring between since you just have to raise your HR level. With Iceborne coming it might help if you've passed HR 16+ but depends. They're adding G-Rank (or Master Rank as they call it) so it's good to see they're adding games like the old ones!Bow is much better now than 4U! It feels like an authentic bow experience, but LBG is still a bit weird compared to the old games but it might be setting/binding issues. Multiplayer issue is now fixed but you might get a drop once in a while (Haven't had one in a long time, and usually its my team disconnecting as opposed to me due to their internet). But alt-tabbing can cause multiplayer to disconnect so playing in borderless solves that. Radical menu wasn't an issue but to prevent it from being auto-resetted you have to save the loadout which saves the radical menu. Also, for HR 50+: Finding Tempered Elder Investigations is annoying but it also feels like an authentic experience similar to farming (Spent like 1 hour 30 following Kirin to get tracks lol) -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Originally August 22 2018 Recommend: MaybePlayed MH4U, MHGen and MHXX (IG/LBG)Comparing to the old games: so far it's been pretty good. Storyline is as good as 4U, much better than Gen/XX! There's been some changes like Mega Dash Juice not present and armour, skills, palico and effect system but overall the changes aren't so bad. I think it's actually easier now to make better armour sets and skills. New monsters are interesting to fight and it's nice they kept some old ones. The new pet and room upgrade is cool too, feels more like a 'world'.  Hoping they bring back some 4U and Gen like Glavenus and the Magalas. They took out the Hunter Arts from Gen/XX but it's not so bad, since attack combos seem a bit more buffed (i.e Aerial art is now included in the Insect Glaive, I think). The new LBG is weird to play, so not sure how I feel about that. Glaive options has been slightly nerfed, doesn't seem like there are as many choices for some ailments. The apperance of the IG doesn't seem to deviate much, so appearance wise it's a bit lacking compared to some of the beautiful glaives in 4U :( Also, if you've played 4U/Gen/XX, sometimes it's easy to figure out an attack pattern because of how some similar they are to previous monsters. There are some new attack patterns present, so it's not a huge issue. However, they really simplified the game. There's no paint-ball, there's no waving to the ship, no micromanaging Palicoes. No mini-games now for sending Palicoes to gather things.  Auto-crafting is nice but I've never used it since it wastes materials. The Argosy is a cool new feature but I feel like I'm using it to just make more cash.  It feels like it's spoon-feeding you some aspects of the game. To me, it feels like this game has been easier so far than 4U and Gen. In some ways, that's good for sanity but also feels like a half-authentic experience. Hopefully, in future DLCs, G-Rank will be implemented. Using controller and so far it feels like a 3DS/Switch experience. Sometimes the right trigger (on a Dualshock) doesn't work, so alt-tabbing or pressing Steam home button and going to controller will fix it, but it's definitely going to be annoying for weapons that need the trigger/pods. There are some issues: 1. Multiplayer: Keeps disconnecting even with some 'fixes' like making your own session before joining a friends. It's really annoying when you're trying to hunt together. Sometimes it's you, sometimes it's your friend, and this is really big when you're helping with story or trying to hunt for parts together since the monster's multiplier is still there even after disconnection. Friend invites kind of work, kind of don't. Definitely need to fix this, because it's infuriating. There's a disconnection every hour, and sometimes every time we start a quest. 2.  The new Radical Menu: It's a good implement from the new system, but for some reason it won't save even after changing items, and keeps defaulting to a really old 'saved' version. 3. Alt-tabbing crashes the game sometimes. Game can also alt-tab on it's own for no reason, and then alt-tab back in. If you're hunting with friends, the Discord overlay is a life-saver, if you don't disconnect first...  Overall: Multiplayer is super infuriating and upsetting, but the story and play is good. Solo play is excellent.8.5 out of 10 for issues above, would be a solid 10/10 if they fixed the issues. (On a side note...this game has made me and my friends appreciate Siege servers)

author: ☣️Karnage
review: The stupidity of the human race never ceases to amaze me. Yes, MHW as a PC port has its problems, but you'll find that most negative reviews have been given in regards to network stability. Which is something that Capcom has no control over as the online portion of the game is handled through Steam. In other words, complete and utter morons that have taken no time to research the issue have decided to put the blame on an innocent party instead of trying to find a solution. And yes, there is a solution to the problem.You see, MHW, doesn't utilize dedicated servers. All networking is peer to server to peer with Steam being the middle man that handles the connections. Until recently, Steam utilized traditional networking protocols (TCP/UDP) with their services. MHW on PC was developed with this in mind. When Steam released their last major update, introducing such things as a new UI and Discord-esque communication services, they also changed over to the WebSocket protocol.Because of this, MHW and any other peer to server to peer titles on Steam have found that the new protocol provides horrible service for the usage of peer to server to peer connections for online gaming. That's not to say that peer to server to peer with traditional protocols doesn't have its problems, but certainly not as bad as this. Steam is completely to blame for this problem and one can simply add "-nofriendsui -udp" or "-nofriendsui -tcp" to their Steam shortcut launch options to revert the changes and improve their network stability for the time being. With that said, due to MHW primarily being a singleplayer title, saves are local and thus dropping a connection does not hurt your progress in any way. Again, there are other problems with this PC port of MHW and this is certainly not a game for everyone due to how difficult the game can be.But in regards to the vast majority of negative reviews, they simply shouldn't exist and these people are an embarrassment to our species. As a fan of the franchise, MHW is a great title and even tho it was quite annoying having to change many settings and keybindings to get a proper KB+M experience, I highly recommend this title to my fellow Monster Hunters. Happy hunting, fivers!

author: ObviousIssues
review: I really cannot stress enough how good it feels to play a mainline Monster Hunter game on PC. If you're a longtime fan of the series, well, you're probably playing it by now. If you're new to these games, or have only played one or two of them in the past, probably on handheld devices, don't worry. This is quite different. Systems have been streamlined, for approachability or to cut down on mechanics, yes, but the depth of gameplay is still there, if not improved upon. If you want to know if you'd like this game, watch some videos about how a hunt goes and how the different weapons work. If you could see yourself trying new things and fighting monsters over and over to perfect your skills and build just the right equipment, you'll love Monster Hunter World. If that sounds boring and repetitive to you, then it probably will be and you should give it a pass. The gameplay model isn't for everyone. Just remember, this is a Capcom action game. There's gonna be janky hitboxes, and there's gonna be goofy animations, and a lot of the stuff you're capable of is going to be ridiculous and over the top. But there's a reason this is their highest selling game ever.
