author: poorboy
review: A terrific game. I have finished both story arcs at the time of this writing (80 hours of play in). I may update this review if/when I reach HR100 for the final cutscene.First of all, why I recommend this game for new prospective buyers:-Fast, intense combat mechanics-Careful gameplay is rewarded; mindless spamming of the attack key will get you killed-Comparisons may be drawn to Souls-like games, Souls fans will appreciate MH-MHW is the most acessible MH in the series (with the exception of MH Generations, which is reasonably accessible but is only availble on 3DS and Switch at the moment)-The graphics are the best of any MH game, and are beautiful in their own rightHowever, there are people who refuse to think strategically, who want scripted setpieces, and linear corridors. If this is you, this game is not for you.Now, here's my analysis of MHW as a MH veteran:-Amount of content is lower than other MH games. This is a big deal. It took me 80 hours to complete both story arcs; it took me ~120 hours to get to this point in MH4U on the 3DS.-Easier matchmaking than any of the past MH games. I have to stress that MHW's multiplayer worked absolutely fine for the first two days; I firmly believed that Steam updated its multiplayer API and that is what caused all the connections issues-Certain mechanics have been massively simplified and are objectively easier than previous gamesAn explanation of the last point:-Most item crafting has been made mind-bogglingly easy. All crafting has 100% chance of success. Potions and Cold Drinks only require one ingredient. Tranq bombs are now made with only two ingredients. -Mining and gathering points respawn over time, meaning you'll never actually run out of resources mid-hunt.-Palico Abilities are incredibly useful, and can be requested on demand.-Palicoes basically never die. When they faint, it's for a matter of mere seconds.-Free traps exist throughout the map.-Potions can be consumed on the move, which makes the game unbelievably easy for many monsters. (For people who say that you move too slowly while drinking potions for it to make a difference, you obviously haven't tried sprinting while drinking a potion.)-Scoutflies have replaced Psychoserum and Paintball-Many items that had to be manually thrown (without any form of aim assist) are now fired by a slingshot that has autoaim, such as stones, dung bombs, flash bombs, sound bombs.-You can fast travel all over the place-You can equip an item that literally makes you invulnerable (or another item that makes you invisible)-You can withdraw items from your item box mid-hunt if you need to restock your items.-Unlimited Whetstones.-Monster carves, mining/bone materials, and account items go straight to your item box, negating the need for inventory managementWhat does this mean for us? Gone are the days where we would meticulously plan our items in a perfect balance of utility and leaving free space for gathering. Gone are the days where if we ran out of potions, we had to scavenge raw materials from herbs and mushrooms and honey from certain gathering points to make more. We can literally just leave combat, fast travel back to camp, pull potions out of your item box, and go back to the fight. There's no more danger. There's no more careful map knowledge needed. There's no fear that once you have picked the land clean of the mushrooms and herbs, that you would no longer have any more materials, since they respawn anyway. There's no getting around it: MHW is easier than any other Monster Hunter before it.One could argue that they are simply quality-of-life changes. I'm ambivalent. I don't think they're good/bad since they have both their drawbacks and their benefits. I'm glad that Capcom wants to innovate rather than keep everything the same (like some certain titles and series). It's one of the few ways to make a game fresh, especially since there have been almost a dozen MH games already. If you are looking for "classic" Monster Hunter, your best title is going to be Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate. MH Generations won't be for you either.TL;DR MHW is the most accessible Monster Hunter and is suitable for newbies who like smart and tactical gameplay. MH Veterans will also find something to love here, as Capcom has changed certain mechanics to make gameplay feel fresh. MHW's graphics may also cause MH Veterans to shed a tear, MH has never looked this beautiful.Note: I recognize that, at the time of this writing, MHW has lots of connection issues. I attribute this to Steam rather than Capcom; the connection issues only started when Steam rolled out an update. Plus, the game just launched. Launch issues are to be expected for any triple A title. I finished the entirety of the campaign solo.

author: Yet Another Otaku
review: As a veteran of the monster hunter series with hundreds of hours clocked in since Freedom 2, my best way to describe Monster Hunter is "Different, but not in a bad way". Most of the changes compared to previous games were done with either realism or user friendlyness in mind. For example theres much more interaction with the environment by both the player and the monster, or supplies are easier to craft with an auto-combination function upon collecting the ingredients which are far easier to find and collect than in previous games. Just casually picking up some highlighted herbs and some honey without even having to stop, just slowing down a little, while following the monster into the next area, which are automatically converted into megapotion sure is handy, but compared to previous games can feel almost too easy. Multiplayer has been improved a lot, its integrated with the story, not forcing you to decide between doing one or the other, however what i would like is an option to limit the max hr for the quest participants, since higher level players can join low level monster hunts and make the fight too easy, taking some of the fun out of the game.The number of monsters may seem a little small, but i guess i've just been pampered by the 4th gen games on that regard. However that number mostly originates from there being little monsters from previous games, with most being originals, and the ammount of new original monsters is up to pair with other games. For comparisons sake, Monster Hunter Tri had even less monsters. Its a little dissapointing to not see some of our most favorite faces like Zinogre or Nargacuga in the new world tho, but at least Deviljho and Uragaan made it there, *sigh* yeah thats greatI can't say i personally had many performance issues, but i also have a gaming rig. Sure its not exactly a game for a budget pc, but i cant say i havent been warned enough of that before buying it. What i heard about it i cant say its reason enough for me to give it a bad review, mostly cause I've seen a lot of games with even worse launches or pc ports. Remember the pc port of Dark Souls before the remaster? Overall, i do enjoy Monster Hunter World and will enjoy it for a while, even if it makes me feel like an old person reminiscing about the good old days where we had to collect blue mushrooms alongside herbs to craft potions, but hey, at least i got MHGU coming to the west soon for all those nostalgia feelings.

author: Alexis
review: I've been playing monster hunter since playing 3u on the 3ds. I even bought a extra analog stick for that when I didn't have an XL 3ds and bought one for 4u and monster hunter generations. I have to say, for various reasons this is my favorite monster hunter experience.PS: I had about 300 hours clocked in on, 4u and generations. The only reason I currently have 10 on this is because I just bought the game 2 days ago. I can easily see myself clocking 300+ in on this. It made 10 hours fly by so fast I didn't even realize until now. 11/10But if you are looking for a much more hardcore experience. 4u followed by generations , or if you have a switch generations ultimate may be more for you. I personally am sticking with world because it made my world go round :D

author: Krioth - The Eternal Dragon
review: Its a wonderful looking game, stunning and beautiful, runs on high/ultra on a 3 to 4 year old pc. Keybinding settings. are nice and varied, personal preferance i use a controller, takes me back to the psp days of Monster hunter. and all that nostalgia.Multiplayer servers. can be. a little bit troublesome to connect. but have been able to do missions with friends. wish you could do the whole game coop. (the main quests) would add to the fun.in the classic monster hunter style, grind items, make gear, grind better items and harder monsters, while progressing through a story. a new nice and varied set of monsters and ecosystems, colorful and vivid forests, to dark damp caves. well worth the money, for the game plenty of content to keep you going. the DLC's are mostly emotes, and hair styles, not worth complaining over. a hairstyle is mostly covered by armor, i will shed no tears, because i cant do a tiny emote, that no one particularly looks at anyway. and the sound Track for this game is nice. if you really wish to own it. in summary, definately worth the money. a long story, some wonderful monsters to battle, nice customisation on characters. a little polish needed on the servers. but thats easily fixed. 8.5/10

author: DarkAssassin011
review: Updating my review. They seemed to have fixed the networking issues within this game now. Game is still great, with improvements to the PC controls and the better networking, I would 100% recommend this game.  Old review is bellow for reference.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------I would like to preface this review by saying I love to play this game. It is a lot of fun to learn how to hunt each monster and farm and craft the materials from each hunt. Playing this game with friends is where it really shines, and unfortunately this is also where this review goes south.At the time of writing this game's multiplayer is mostly an error code simulator. I have successfully hunted in a group, it is possible but nothing is more disappointing then getting disconnected in the middle of a quest. You lose all of your party members and although you stay in the quest the difficulty stays at the multiplayer level, the monsters get a slight health boost ect. so to finish the hunt requires extra effort. This often leads to a l lot of wasted time.Aside from the multiplayer issues this game is fantastic. The controls take some getting used to unless you opt for the controller. I mapped a lot of buttons to my mouse so it feels pretty good for me. I cant in good sense recommend this game until the connection issues get fixed. If you plan to play solo 100% this game is ready for you today and you will love it. If you are like me and want to play with friends, you will be disappointed.

review: First Monster Hunter for me and I am really impressed. I never thought this game would get so much of my attention even though I started with Charge Blade as my first weapon on which I later learned that this is probably the worst weapon for beginners.However this did not stop me from getting addicted to hunting. With tons of weapon guides online I managed to master this first weapon and stayed with it pretty much the whole base game.Once I found myself a bit bored I just switched to another weapon, Insect Glaive in my case and it's like playing a new game. author: GokoAFMTTV
review: One of the best Monster Hunter games to date and also the best one to start off with for anyone new to the series. The game has had a very large number of free content through updates and the one expansion they have essentially doubles as a new game in of itself, the total amount of large monsters in the game rivals that of the older games despite a lot of older monsters being left out of this game. The online multiplayer is a lot of fun and quite balanced and the overall community of Monster Hunter is helpful, nice, and welcoming so most people are always down to help in any way that they can. This game can either be played casually or hardcore with the level of grind that's in the game, min maxing is totally optional and because of that the game can easily have hundreds if not thousands of hours of replay value and enjoyment. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who is either a fan of Monster Hunter or wanting to get into Monster Hunter, 100% worth the price of both the base game and dlc, especially moreso if both end up on sale!

author: Koopy Sandwich
review: I'm glad MH is finally available on PC. Double-dipped after playing it ~400 hours on PS4 to be able to play with PC friends, no regrets. The game is fantastic, albeit more 'casual' than previous MH titles it feels fresh and modern, with some of the core clunk replaced by QoL features I wouldn't want to lose out on nowadays. Very fun mix of old monsters and new, beautiful additions. The port runs without issues on my machine, but with a few graphic quirks and occasional connectivity issues - though seeing how much long term support and content additions previous titles and the PS4 version of MHW have gotten in the past, I'm almost certain those will be ironed out before long. Can't wait for the demon pickle to ruin my hunts again. Just don't ever add Plesioth to the game. PLEASE.

review: Monster Hunter: World is beautiful, satisfying to play and will scratch that grinding itch. With new challenges in the form of new monsters and different quests being added to the game all the time, Monster Hunter: World is utterly amazing and absolutely worth your time and money. 9/10.

author: \varnothing (They/Them)
review: This game is getting review bombed for no good reason, you should effectively ignore the average "ALL REVIEWS" metric. The game is fantastic, possibly the best in the series up to this point and you're doing yourself a disservice by ignoring the game because of a few launch hiccups.

author: Lucidity
review: First of all, I think the gameplay is done pretty well and the game is enjoyable so far.However, the port to PC is done terribly. - No option to disable motion blur, sorry for the large number of people who get motion sickness.- The mouse input has reverse acceleration and is basically emulating a joystick, so everything feels really clunky and awful to navigate. I cannot stress how much this takes away from the combat gameplay.- Optimization is greatly lacking. I got an average of ~35 frames on an RX 580 / Ryzen 2700X and ~50 after disabling volumetric rendering.- The menus are clearly designed for a console and very unintuitive with no changes to the layout or even adding in a scrollable field. If there are 25 items within a menu, instead of being able to smoothly scroll through all 25, they are locked to pages.- Going off of the last point, the escape button doesn't work to exit out of any of the menus. What modern day game or application doesn't make use of the escape button in 2018? It's such an intuitive action for me to take and after 5 hours I still find myself trying to hit escape to exit out of menus instead of the right mouse button.- They also didn't bother to change a good number of tooltips off of their respective Xbox buttons rather than the actual keybind. This may be nitpicking, but it really does feel like a game made for console through and through.tl;dr: Game is great, PC port is done awfully.

author: 小peekachu
review: I can see how this game can become one's part of life.I'm still very earlier in game but I'm already amazed by Capcom for putting together such a game: a very in depth pve game. It's possible THE best pure pve game I have played.Personally, I think it's very hard to pull off a pve multiplayer game that is balanced. But Capcom did it. This game... It's so smoothly balanced, in term of weapon types, combat style, damage points, armors and items farming, environmental, buffs, and the FREEDOM, there is just so much.You have to experience yourself. MHW made me feels entertained, surprised, interested, satisfied, and ACCOMPLISHED. Capcom must have studied game and human psychology good. Cuz by combining these two they created an utopia that it's hard to resist, it resonates the "heroness" within ourselves, and the vision where hard work can be visually and measurably pays off. Try it yourself, or you could be missing out big time.Now let's hold the high horse for a sec. Yes, I'm very new to this game series, mhw pc version it's actually my first encounter to the series. (Never heard of this game before, and no one I knew well enough were a mhw gamer, btw I'm very introvert and don't social much so..)Therefore I can very much understand how this game can appear "too complicate" and tmi at first for the new comers and how that can be somewhat off putting. But for me, it was worth it, putting all these hours to explore, to study, to try to understand and master it. (Yes I'm only at level 11 lol) However, this game does require some patient or it won't be as enjoyable. This review is getting long, ill come back and add more thoughts as I go. So far the only few suggestions I could make is:1. I wish there were an option for posting an expedition which could let your friends join in, right now it's just weird and hard to do. 2. the inconvenience of sending back guild card. Edit: apparently Capcom kinda fix the issue, you could go into setting and set it up as automatically accept and send back guide card. Edit: 3. Multiplayer can sometimes be too easy. Could need some re-balance work. p.s.

author: Woargh
review: This is my first time playing a game like this and I'm surprised at how easy it was to learn. There are a few helpful tips which the game doesn't tell you, but the MHW community is both helpful, nice and very active in-game.Overall this is a wonderful game with beautiful monsters unlike anything I've ever seen before. There are a lot of aspects to the game, not just hunting monsters. Controls are on point and I love the balance between story, dialog and gameplay.I currently only have a little over 300 hours in-game and I'm nowhere near done plus there is always a new update and/or event to play.I would highly recommened this game to everyone, especially if you've never tried this type of game before. It opens up a whole new world within gaming.Game was played on an Xbox One controller and it was flawless.

author: kymai
review: This game has changed my friends' life, it improved our relationship and our confidence in each other.I've spent more than 300 hours visiting every corner of Monster Hunter World, it made me happy and hungry.Happy because this Monster Hunter game is in effect the highest point of an exceptional series, which is able to effectively rework its formula with this new "World", perfectly combining tradition and innovation.Hungry because (apart the delicious meals in the Canteen), the game has left me with an irresistible desire to continue to venture among the lands of an enveloping and highly inspired world full of monsters, a living world with an obsessive attention to every detail.You can't give up the sensations of pure enjoyment offered by the refined gameplay: complex, multi-faceted and never so accessible.It's also a pleasure to play in coop, to master all the weapons, to refine mathematically every build.The porting and streamlining work of Capcom have produced a grinding videogame that doesn't renounce any of the key elements of its hardcore legacy.A product that still manage to open up its own niche to the general public, providing that the players are able to put the right dedication.There are some rough edges, like bad  performance, unpleasant PC optimization and network problems, but nothing that really affects the immense value of one of the first "must buy"  monster hunting games.

author: Derpy Herp
review: Having started with the Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate on the 3DS and loving every moment of it, I was beyond excited to see that the series would finally make its way to more mainline consoles. When the game first launched there were numerous issues with the multiplayer systems, which explains the overall mixed reviews, but thankfully Capcom fixed them all the following months, and since then I personally haven't experienced any major issues since then.After playing the game for over 400 hours I can safely say that this is one of my all time favourite games, and with the Iceborne DLC dropping sometime this year (hopefully), I can see myself easily managing to put another 400 hours into this. I would highly recommend getting this game, playing the MH4U on the 3DS created some amazing memories and MHW let me re-live them.

author: Al'ghale
review: At this point you should ignore the Mixed review rating of this game. All connection issues have long since been resolved and a lot of the people who gave it a Negative review never bothered to update their reviews.""Or so I thought when I first saw the trailer for MH World. I don't consider myself an MH veteran, but I've been playing MH since Tri first came out on the original Wii. To me it seemed World was trying to set itself apart from the older titles to the point where it couldn't be considered a true MH title. I reserved further opinions until I played World first-hand and suffice to say, I couldn't be more wrong than that.World takes what's offered in the recent games (mostly 4U) and repackage it in an HD offering. Depending on the game you last played, the mounting system and verticality emphasis in 4U might be new for you. It takes some time to get used to, but it feels right at home when you learn how to use it. Also for better or for worse, some mechanics and QoL improvements in Generations, most notably Hunter Arts and Styles are missing.""Apart from the QoL improvements, there are three main things that I notice really. There are new environmental hazards for you to play around with. For example toads that can paralyze, boulders that can fall at enemies, and flashbomb-like insects. Slingers, mini-bow which shoots select objects which you can find randomly on the wild. Finally, there is also a grappling hook which propels you across distance. Much to the traditional MH tradition, the three are poorly explained especially the environmental hazards. However they make great additions to the core gameplay. I admit I miss the point of using slingers, but these make dungs and flash bombs not as tedious to use.World is first and foremost, catered to newcomers. As a newcomer, it can get daunting to get so much mechanics thrown at you at once. But I think the game did a good job explaining some of the mechanics via the in-game tutorial, something I would really appreciate back when I first started in Tri. The game is considerably easier and also much more "lived-in". All in all if you would like to check what Monster Hunter is about, World is a good entry point to start with.Right the issues. From a gameplay standpoint, I think the inventory and crafting system is too dumbed down, but that's something I can live with. Port-wise is something I have issues though. I do have FPS problems, but I'd choose it over the server issues any day. It can be abysmal at times and connection errors will periodically occur even when idling. Right now, I won't hope much for the multiplayer component of the game.Overall, I think World is a great game with a somewhat troubled port job. While I would recommend waiting for a while if you only want to play multiplayer, the game is still fun when soloed on its own right.

author: AitoKurittaja
review: While Monster Hunter world itself is a good game, it is not really what Monster Hunter has been back in day.It is so much more easier with its mechanics to play that you wouldn't even understand it as a newcomer what Monster hunter has been before this.You can get triple or quadruple the armor skills you had before. You have insane amounts of weapon combos to boost, overpowered to top it off.You can slam monsters against walls with your nut slinger, because why not. You do not need to search for monsters, your automatic bug tracking system does it for you.You do not have to think what you pack in your hunts, you can always fast travel to your camp and always get what you want from your box.You do not have to think room in your backpack. No need to carry book of combos, bug nets, pick axes nothing, you always have those with you.You can spend half of your hunt with overpowered magical capes, what itself is something that would make veterans turn in their graves.You do not even have to walk as your animal taxi service does it for you.You never have to worry about negative skills here.You get so much more materials compared to old games and you get them faster and easier.... tickets.....And gunners in World, My God, it completely breaks the game with massive amounts of easymode dmg they can do.... and  in world they have same armor and defence as well.... in classic Monster Hunters, gunner armor was different and had half the defence.List goes on.Is monster hunter world good game? yes it is, but it is nothing what old Monster Hunters were and humiliates the monsters.Poor Alatreon is coming soon and will get eaten alive in 2 minutes, due of the easymode mechanics this game has.I have spent over 2000 hours with Monster Hunter 2 and Freedom Unite.600 Hours with Portable 3rd.800 hours with World / Iceborne.300 hours with Generations Ultimate, which I prefer to world now.I really hope that they never add  here as rumored, because it does not deserve to come here when the game mechanics are like this.I understand why world was made like this, to please larger community and it did work. But it is saddening as it gives wrong image from the whole genre. Because this is what people think when you bring up monster hunter to them.'' Oh Monster Hunter world ? '' sobbing quietly in my apartment.Still I like this game, and it looks nice ( weapon design is bit lazy though compared to old games )If you did read this, then thank you. And good hunting.If you have nintendo switch, give Generations Ultimate a try, it is what Monster Hunter was.

author: Professortbag
review: It's the closest thing we will get to a proper monster hunter game on PC and it's pretty good. Pros:Combat is fantastic, weapons work very well with controller and feel satisfying to use.The new monsters are interesting designsIt is a challenging gameBest looking monster hunter game released yet, probably one of the best looking games this yearCons:Unskippable cutscenes and very heavily story focussed for a MH game in my opinion. Back in the day it was just "There's a big dragon coming to town, take it out". At least let me skip the damn cutscenes! (hopefully this will be modded out soon enough)A strange multiplayer system. Before in MH you had a gathering hall and a village quest system. Essentially it was a single player and an offline series of quests. Here it somewhere in between. Good luck trying to quest with a friend at the same time, due to the story and cutscenes you can't do most quests right off the bat. I believe both have to see the cutscenes to be able to que together. It's annoying.I have probably played at least 1000+ hrs in all the previous games and while I think this game is certainly the simpliest of the franchise it is still worth it. They simplified a few systems and improved older ones. I see why the changes have been made but it just feels different. The palico system is again changed, They perfected it in MHP3rd and have been messing about ever since but for a new buyer it shouldn't really matter

author: Seth Knows
review: This is my first Monster Hunter game, and I can now say that it won't be my last.I play most games with one of my good friends, we play some PvP occasionally, but like to delve into games with incredibly deep and challenging mechanics on the PvE side. Notice that I do not have hundreds or even thousands of hours into this game yet, but I will. This is more of a novice review, as we've only completed the campaign and Iceborne, and there is so much more. MHW is as deep as the Mariana Trench, and as wide as the Pacific Ocean, let me explain...What makes this game so challenging, yet so masterful, is each weapon. I've used the Insect Glaive (favorite) for most of my play time. It's very fun to use, as there are many ways to attack and evade enemies. It took me a good 60+ hours to even figure out and effectively use every move with this weapon, chances are, I'm not even that great with it. I have used the Switch Axe and Hammer as well, both equally as interesting and fun to use as the Glaive. The hammer is becoming my main weapon, as it's move set and ability to knock out the monster is amazing. I'm simply impressed with how each weapon feels vastly different from one another, yet still viable (though some more than others.)You have to also tweak your build(s) to fight each different type of beast or to match your play style. Each weapon and armor set have numerous different paths that allow you to efficiently tackle each challenge. This, in combination with the monsters' weaknesses, weapon variety, and other buffs make this game extremely deep and complex. I have yet to master any of it personally.The monster and world design is excellent, I still get lost in the Ancient Forest sometimes. And seeing another monster swoop in and start fighting with the monster you were tasked with killing in the first place, is awesome to witness. Each monster you fight feels like the end-game boss battle, you have to learn it's attack patterns and adapt. There are many different locations to explore, though some are more fleshed out than others.There are cons, however, and I know I will get flamed by all the diehard Monster Hunter fanboys, as I've already seen it on many other reviews. The first negative about this game is very important to me, because I put this game down for 2 years and never touched it til now because of it. Cooperative play is not as good as I'd like. If you want to play this with your friend or friends from beginning to end, that won't happen. There are many hunts in the campaign that you HAVE to solo, which is frustrating. I understand that I need to learn the mechanics of the game, that's fine, but I bought this game to play with friends, and many people just disregard or cover their ears when someone mentions any issues about this game. It should all be co-op (cutscenes included), or none of the campaign should be. Quit splitting up groups of people for a cutscene. The co-op opens up massively in Iceborne and the endgame, which is what we stuck around for.As a whole, I'm a huge fan on the franchise now, but this game isn't for everyone. If you want to turn your brain off, this game isn't for you; if you want to hack n' slash, this game isn't for you; if you want to enjoy a seamless co-op experience from start to finish, this game isn't for you, if you want a game to hold your hand and tell you every little thing you need to do, this game is not for you.If you want the ultimate challenge, this game is DEFINITELY for you.

author: Statyk
review: I've played MH3U, MH4U, MHO, MHGen, MHXX, and MHW for the PS4 (A collective 2000+ hours between them all). It's amazing seeing the leap in graphical fidelity and gameplay designs that this game has gone through in MHW. Gameplay is much more fluid and the world feels much more alive than before. Going from MH4U Gunlance to MHW Gunlance is almost an entirely different game. When I first got heavily into MH3U, I always wished monster hunter could turn out to be the game MHW is with its open environments, monster tracking system (and not just paintballs), and gathering/crafting system and I can't get enough.- Graphics are top notch and each area of the game is screenshot worthy. Rotten Vale with its Dalamadur skeleton-based upper half and the Coral Highlands' surreal ocean-like appearance are so unique and I love them.- Monsters interact and have meaningful turfwars. I remember bringing Anjanath to Rathalos on purpose so me and my boss could finish the fight in time.- Gathering is much faster and the new auto-crafting option is really handy.- Radial Menu is a game-changer. Going from smashing through the item bar to this has saved me time and time again.- Gunlance no longer sends people flying on normal shells. This might not seem like much but I've been kicked from lobbies in previous games simply for playing my favorite weapon because people were afraid of getting disrupted.- Weapons in general are more fluid. Attacks can flow into other attacks more freely while previous games had more of preset "combo" inputs. This is more apparent in weapons like SnS, GL, Lance, and Greatsword.- Voice acting and cinematic scenes are amazing! People might not like Handler and the crew but hearing the NPCs around me talking and being a part of the environment is a huge deal.- Camps in the mission area alleviate last-minute prep mistakes and allows me to swap weapons and armor sets that I might like against one monster over the other.- Playing with friends is a blast now that I can actually play with them on a system most of them play on. 2000 hours of playing mostly solo or with randoms is mostly gone and it feels great.- NETWORK ISSUES ALL FIXED, DON'T HAVE ANY ISSUES ANYMORE- Performance can take a significant hit on Nvidia's latest (398.82) drivers even though they state it's optimized for MHW. I don't know why they did this but I would typically sit around 45-60 FPS during missions. During Zorah Magdoros I dropped to around 22FPS with resolution scaling dropping as well. Once I downgraded my Nvidia driver to 398.36, I've not yet dropped below 50FPS. Zorah is now a consistent 60FPS. Please keep that in mind. This is with everything in the game on highest and volume rendering at mid.- STUTTERING ON THUNDER AND BLAST EFFECTS FIXED- No PS4 input icons by default. I love my PS4 controller and unfortunately had to install a simple handy mod to replace the xbox controller buttons. It would be nice if there was an option to swap input icons in the settings.- Gathering Hub seems kinda useless. I wish they chose to forgo the multiplayer hub and redesigned Astera for multiplayer gameplay. The area is much bigger and has everything in it. On the PS4, loading times meant going to the gathering hub was a total waste of time, but thankfully it's pretty quick on PC and SSDs (about 2-3 seconds) so I'm more okay with going up there to see friends. It's still a fairly useless area of the hub though...- For some reason the PC version has lower texture resolutions than the consoles. This seems like either a mistake or a really odd choice to make. Thankfully someone found out how to fix it by editing mipmap levels and I look forward to that mod but this REALLY should get fixed officially.This review is probably pretty choppy and I probably left out a lot of things I love or dislike about the game but instead of figuring it out I'm going to go back and dump another 500+ hours into it like I did on the PS4 lol______________- Intel i7-4790k @ 4.0GHz- Nvidia GTX1080 8GB- 16GB RAM- 500GB Sandisk SSD

author: Private piss baby
review: good

author: Red Wolf
review: I played Monster Hunter Generations on the 3DS and this one is much more streamlined. Despite this game being more user friendly, it's still incredibly cryptic and you won't get far without doing some research on your own. The game doesn't do the best job of explaining itself to say the least. Also, the multiplayer menus take a minute to get used to. The process of figuring out how to get multiplayer to function the way I wanted it to was pretty annoying.Now that my gripes are out of the way, this is one of the best games I've ever played. The graphics are beautiful. Sound effects and soundtrack are fantastic. And most importantly, the gameplay is superb. A perfect balance of grind and reward. It doesn't take long before you're wearing some awesome looking armor and feel somewhat powerful with your weapon of choice.That being said, this game isn't easy. Not only is every weapon super unique and have different purposes, but you need to be very good with at least two or three of them to get by. Learning the combos and proper technique takes a bit of research, unless you go with the dual blades or sword and shield builds. The boss fights are incredibly difficult, rivaling Dark Souls and similar style games in difficulty. But it just makes the grind that much more rewarding.10/10

author: Flick
review: Overall a very solid game, plays well, runs well and is a great PC port of a console game.Yes there are some server issues for multiplayer, no they're not stopping me from playing with friends, it's a mild inconvenience.Yes it could have more graphics settings, however this is the most customisation and steam integration I have seen for a console port in recent years, well done I say, wish more ports were this good.Yes it uses 80-90% of the my CPU / GPU, and I want it to! why would I want a game to sip at my resources!? Use them all and give me an amazing looking game!Ultimately the gameplay is what matters and this game has it in spades, nothing else feels as good as chasing down a big hulking moster and bashing it's face in with an axe.Do any of the issues posted stop me from doing that? Nope, not in the slightest, not even a little bit, well done Capcom.

review: You fight really big monstersPretty frustrating when you think you dodge through something, but the timing is weird, or a monster runs at a wall and has big damage hitboxes as a stationary boyPretty rewarding when you blow a monster's face up with your axe that morphs into a swordYou gotta grind a lot, but the fights never go exactly the same. author: You Das
review: I hardly ever review games on steam, but this one getting "mixed" reviews seems wrong. Absolutely one of the best "AAA" games to come out all year (or last year, or the year before that...). A lot of the negative reviews seem to be focused on the network problems during the first two-three weeks after launch, which are mostly fixed by now. To me it seemed like a minor issue anyway, since I always got my connectivity issues resolved within around 10 minutes (though maybe I'm an outlier) by just trying to reconnect a few times, never mind the fact that this game is thoroughly enjoyable as a single player experience as well, if you're into single player games (which I am).I'll leave this review short, and just urge you to try if you're into RPGs, ARPGs, CRPGs, JRPGs, fighting games or any other good games. A quality product, through and through. 92/100, if you like points.

author: Hiunaut
review: Pros:-Fairly good combat, but definitely the best one in the whole franchise yet-Grind maybe tedious, but it's fair and fun to do-Satsifying movement control-You fight giant hairy T-rex with your pet cat dressed as mascot of a dead chameleon dragon (or wyvern in this game)Cons:-Terrible connection issues at this moment, while it is possible to play with other people online, you will find yourself disconnecting often regardless of your end of the internet. Capcom needs to fix this issue as soon as possible-If you look for a good storyline, I suggest you turn away, Monster Hunter has never been story-focused game, it's not a bad story, it's pretty meh-Low to Mid PC should be aware that this is game is huge CPU tax-I want to dress my cat as a hot dog, where is the damn hot dog costume Capcom?!

author: ImAGodDmnDragn
review: This is a great game and I'm going to recommend it as the gameplay alone justifies the purchase.  That said, this is a really lazy port and the studio behind it should be embarrassed at the low quality of the product they're selling.  I play to write a more detailed review later, but for now I'll just say the multiplayer code is buggy and the options don't even try to conform to the standard PC users are used to.  Still, if you are willing to look past that, the game offers the highest-quality gameplay experience which is even better with friends. (When it works.)*Edit: So it seems like they cleaned up the multiplayer code a bunch as I don't have nearly the amount of problems I used to.  That said, I hope the next game does a better job at matchmaking options as finding the hunt you want can be tedious.  The game itself is solid, but I do have a few complaints just in case a developer ends up reading this.1.  Have control setup options that work for mouse/keyboard users.  I shouldn't have to press an f-key to bring up my quick menu, I should be able to map buttons to my mouse or keyboard that just let me quick-select certain items (of my choice).  It's super clunky as is and takes away from the fun factor.2.  Give us damage meter options.  The awards at the end of the hunts are laughable, I don't need to know who grilled the most steak.  Let me know damage, blocking, stunning, sleeping, and other relevant combat stats so I have an easier time improving my performance.3.  Either make things more intuitive or give your players better tutorials.4.  Your pterodactyl crashing randomly adds absolutely nothing to the game, please do away with that crap.Those are my four main complaints 300 or so hours in.  Let me say again how great this game is, happy hunting all!

author: Avalanject
review: TL/DR: An incredible game that everyone needs to try, and with Iceborne out now it couldn't be more worth it. So many things to do and discover, and if you're not just in it for the Monster Hunting there's hundreds of other little activities to partake in. Play it with friends though, its a 100 times more fun.This is easily my favourite game that I've played in a long time and since I'm enjoying it so much I figure that I might as well spend the time to type up a legitimate review to pay homage to this incredible game. This is my first entry in the Monster Hunter series, although I did play a trial for Generations on my 3DS a while back, but I couldn't get into it. It didn't seem like my game.I was hesitant to spend the big $80 toll on this game, but I eventually gave in, and I was launched into a brand new world unlike anything I'd ever expected. The game can start off extremely confusing and overwhelming, but once you've played around 20 hours, you should get the hang of everything and how this world works.The game-play consists of tracking and hunting monsters, fighting them, killing or trapping them, looting the corpses for profit, then turning their skin into new weapons and armour to help you take on stronger monsters. It is a bit of a grind at times, but the game itself has never felt too grindy to me. In fact, I don't enjoy grindy games such as Destiny or Warframe, but there's something about this game that hits different, and it is so much more enjoyable. It has around 14 weapons or something, and each one feels very fun in its own right and can make the game a whole new experience. Throughout the base game I stuck with a trusty Hammer, and it is quite satisfying crushing the skulls of giant monsters and flipping through the air like sonic, but it does get quite old after 200 hours. For Iceborne I decided to take a different route and started using the Switch Axe, which is a little bit more complicated and allows me to dig my axe into the sides of monsters heads and drill their skulls out until they explode (♥♥♥♥ is crazy).  Using a different weapon feels like I'm playing an entirely new game and that's another thing that I love so much about this game. Every weapons play-style is extremely unique and its always fun trying out new play-styles. So mix it up every now and again for a better experience (although I wouldn't juggle more than like 5 weapons, because you're going to run out of materials pretty fast if you hope to craft a very strong weapon/armour set for each category)The world itself is very beautiful, interactive, and overall very immersive. Nothing from the plants, bugs, monsters, or wildlife feels out of place in this big world. The monsters range from giant lizards, giant pulsating pickles with legs, flying fire lions, to lightning powered unicorns, and not a single one seems as though it shouldn't be here. Each monster fits its appropriate environment accordingly and the way that each monster interacts with these environments, from having nests and feeding grounds, only adds to the immersion of this game, and shows just how dedicated the team behind this game is. The different layers to some of the maps, the spots where monsters get stuck, and the boulders around the maps that you can drop on monsters for massive damage are incredible and really make the player feel apart of the world.The story overall isn't anything too exciting and as said in a popular review; is realistically just more of a glorified tutorial. This doesn't necessarily mean that it's nothing interesting though. I'm not exactly knowledgeable on Monster Hunter lore, but the story was still quite engaging to me, and every new monster introduced made me thrilled to fight it and see what its armour and weapons might look like. Its definitely worth the money on it's own, and i finished it at about 100 hours or so (including having done a few optional missions and what not).So if you like to show off achievements you'll love this game, and Iceborne even more. There's tonnes of little side objectives such as optional missions, trying to catch rare endemic life, collecting treasure, taking photos for research, exploring to discover and befriend secret cat tribes, fishing, collecting mini and large crowns for your monsters, and so much more. This can all be shown off on your spectacular Guild Card, and this can be customised however you wish with titles such as "Spread for Papa" or mine, "Commander of Cute" which is pretty stupid but I'm not really that creative. You also have your own personal room where you can choose to display your rare fish and other creatures, but now with Iceborne you can catch and display a much larger range of rare creatures, edit your entire house and even have 16 whole people inside your room, around a table drinking and passing out. I once spent around 10 minutes just floating around with 3 strangers in the Hot Springs and doing nothing, before we all left and went on a mission together. If these other aspects of the game aren't enough, just get it for the community because I've never played with anyone toxic in my entire 400 hours, nor have I ever seen a negative community post. The community for this game is amazing.The crossovers for this game are also lots of fun, such as the mission for Geralt, and being able to use Igni whilst dressed up as Geralt or Ciri, it's all really fun and something that not a lot of other games let you experience alongside the base game like nothing is wrong. There are a few console exclusive crossovers which is quite unfortunate, but lots of games have console exclusive content so we just have to learn to deal with it. A lot of people would also argue that the developers of this game do not care as much about their PC audience due to late releases etc, but I'm considerably patient and don't tend to hold grudges so it doesn't necessarily bother me. Also, seeing as the Iceborne updates are going to be caught up with consoles in about March, then every update after that will be in sync across the board, I give extra credit to Capcom and I think that this disproves a lot of these claims. How can you hate them when they let you dress up your cat as an 8-bit Mega Man?Overall I love the ♥♥♥♥ out of this game and that's why I've taken the time out of my day to write this. It's been a long time coming. The world, the characters, the monsters, the weapons, the armour. Everything in this game is absolutely beautiful to me and I want to thank Capcom for not only bringing me this incredible game, but for introducing me to the world of Monster Hunter. A world that I would now consider myself a part of, and a world that I'm more than happy to be a part of. :)My original review: (At about 35 hours)you hit barroth and he goes back to poo lair, he love poo he loves poo i collect his poo for research poo

author: Tasi
review: Wanted to throw my review in the pile because I don't believe the 'mixed' rating the game currentaly has is entirely fair.I firmly believe most of the negative reviews stem from the launch of the game, which I agree hasn't been the smoothest with several issues that severly hindered my enjoyment of the game.But in it's current state, Monster Hunter World functions pretty well and is highly enjoyable too! Admittedly, I have never had the opportunity to play any other Monster Hunter title since I only play on PC, but as a newcomer to the series I am definitely excited about the franchise now, I've never played something quite like it.If I had describe the game to someone who has no idea what Monster Hunter is, I'd say it's a bosh rush with very unique weapons that take time to master, and fill very nice niches a lot of other hack and slash games haven't really covered, at least to me.As someone who always looks to the user-rating of a game, I'd say it's worth to look past the mixed one on this game, as most issues are adressed, and there's a tremendous amount of fun to be had!

author: Gunfire
review: One of the best grindy games I've played ever.So much to do, so many weapons to master. Each weapon works completely differently from the others, which makes the game a totally new experience every time.The bad reviews are mostly (I would say 90%) about technical issues. Most of them were already fixed and I rarely ever get a disconnect from the game nowadays. And I' always play this game in co-op.They even added more customization options allowing you to change most keybinds, which is a well worth addition for this PC version.This was/is my first Monster Hunter experience, and I'm very glad for it to be so.10/10 recommended!

author: Mikkiss
review: Most of the negative comments are from people who want to coop this game but the online experience is poopy right now. The game itself is alot of fun i recommend it. If you want to coop just singular quest, there shouldn't be any problem. But playing the game fully coop is annoying since the game sometimes finds you a new session after missions for some reason. Also it takes often multiple tries to find a server in general. If you play the whole game solo, then there souldnt be any problems with the online stuff.Highly recommend using a controller. With a controller its alot easier, but keyboard and mice is playable too.The game: 8.5/10The online coop experience: Its ♥♥♥♥ at the moment we will see if it gets better when there is less people playing (currently they have 200 000 players everyday 24.8.2018)

author: R!SK
review: It's a great game and even better with friends/people to play with! Various open areas in the main game plus a beautiful ice open area in the Iceborne Expansion, adding more monsters than the already good roster of monsters to hunt and craft weapons and armor from. Great visuals and great soundtrack. PS: It's demanding from you PC.Score: 9/10

author: Mitsuho
review: A gorgeous world to explore, whether you do quests or simple explorations. Slightly buggy multiplayer gameplay with the occassional server problems. Cute and ugly monsters to fight with their own signature attacks to follow (Pukei Pukei poison farts). An interactive environment during gameplay and battles, whether it is hanging rocks or paratoads, which assist one in bringing down monsters can be found scattered all across the maps. A wide variety of weapons to choose from and master, whether selecting to weild a single weapon and mastering it or being adept at handling several weapons, this gives the opportunity for players to customize the gameplay to their playstyle. Further customizations can come from the multitude of equippable gears that the player can create and utilize the various stat effects each provide. Not to mention our fierce and loyal Palicos that flick around their feline tails, bonk monsters thrice their size on the heads and help you during your battles with a variety of their own set of equippable gears and traps.  And ofcourse being served a dish by a chef cat before heading in to the unknown. With perhaps more better optimization and added game content the game could be an even better joy, albeit the grindfest can be an annoyance after awhile for most players and can make the game more tedious unless one enjoys it.

author: White Glint
review: Aight. I'mma keep it real with you guys. The game is wonderful. I've dumped 500 hours into the console version and I expect to dump at least 200 into the PC version with my friends. As a game, I can 100% reccommend this game. But as a port, I cannot back this game 100%. The PC port has quite a few issues, the biggest being that you can kill the final boss and your save DIES. That is unacceptable. There are a lot of things I'm willing to let fly, but that is not one of them.I'll play devil's advocate; you CAN just back up your save right before that fight. Which is what I advise everyone to do. But not everyone is going to be made known to that knowledge, which means some of the less fortunate won't have done that, resulting in hours of work down the drain that no one is going to want to do again.I'm torn because I want to say "BUY THIS JAWN CAUSE THE GAME HOT" and honestly I'mma still say that. But don't go in without taking precautions. For everyone who has the game and knows about this, take it upon yourselves and spread the issues like wildfire so people don't go in blind and then have their saves die after some odd 40+ hours of work. For these reasons above, I'll be downvoting. People are more likely to read downvotes anyway. Take the steps necessary to prevent your save from going down the drain. And when you do buy this game, go get the Special K fix.EDIT: It's been forever ago and I'm certain the fabled save issue is long gone, so I'll go ahead and give the thumbs up back. Please don't pay people to clear Fatalis for you, thanks.

author: Maulman
review: I really cannot stress enough how flawed the review balance for this game is right now. It's sickening to see that people are hating so heavily off of what was told by capcom to be a port, sold as a port, for the first time for the series on a PC platform. The game functions as advertised. It's very entertaining, minimal FPS drops, and engaging gameplay with characters. Sure, the cutscenes and NPCs are off because the animations are still for the Japanese language. But you can get over it very quickly with how little impact it is towards the game as a whole.What I will address seperately is: The multiplayer problem:I live in Japan. This is a very hard place to be from, when all of your friends are foreign.I am friends with a lot of foreigners. I am playing Japan to Austrailia or Japan to Germany, literally all the time.I can connect with such little issue to them that it is often the Austrailian's internet that prevents them from playing with me. I have never been so badly disconnected that in the middle of a fight with one of the bigger monsters in the game (i.e. Rathalos, Diablos) I have been left alone. It's probably not the servers. It's you.Now onto the rest of my review.21:9 Support? use a 3rd party program to force the ratio.This game was not meant to be played on keyboard and mouse. Treat it like souls and buy yourself a wired controller. You can use it for other games as well. I'm sorry if you can't.The UI is meant to be simplified for consoles but is honestly still crap. Bad for organization and those with intense OCD qualities like yours truly.TL:DR: Game's good at heart, polished to near perfection, but a little clunky around the edges.If you can't treat it like it wants to be treated, like a woman, it will scorn you.

author: Grapedrink
review: Monster hunter world is a fun satisfying single player game. However, it is not at this time a multiplayer game. Playing with a group of friends has been a trial, most quests require everyone to go forward, see a cutscene, then abandon the quest and remake for everyone to play together. Some days we will be disconnected every quest, and not only does it disconnect you, but it puts you back in your own offline session. You can continue to fight, but the monsters stay up at scaling for 4 players, instead of scaling back down when there is only one player. The disconnects wouldn't be as much of an issue if they fixed the monster scaling, or the monster scaling wouldn't be such an issue if they fixed the disconnects. The fact that the PC version had 6 months additional development time, and this issue wasn't resolved (and so far hasn't been fixed or even lessened in the first two weeks of release) indicates that this is not a priority for the monster hunter team. I would not recommend this game for multiplayer content.

review: Monster Hunter but with more depth and quality and heavily simplified gathering.Downsides, because of the new generation and hike in quality, that means less monsters and they can't just import them, plus there's a larger element of RNG with how decorations are now, but on the bright side, mods!Mods fix everything bad here except the lack of content. author: Light Tim
review: TL;DR: Monster Hunter: World is a game that I 100% suggest to all people, with a few warnings for the few players that might not like the genre.Monster Hunter: World (or MHW as I will put it for now on,) Is a action RPG that is about playing a up and coming hunter going on a boat to the new world to a science post to learn about why the giant 'elder' monsters come to the new world every so often. You hunt, you grow, you hunt bigger things, and you find the focus of the game: hunting. The game focuses on the hunting experience, and everything is built around it. You craft better armor and better weapons to get hit by giant monsters, and hit them better. You collect food and meds to support your hitting, and being hit, of giant monsters better. And that is were I suggest were people really think if they would enjoy the game. Do you like hunting? If yes, ask if you would like hunting very big things? If yes again, would you hunt things that would make your caveman ancestor proud inbetween his screams of terror? If yes, then you would likely like this game.Now here is the part were I post things that you should watch out for so you know about it ahead of time. There will be grind, but if you like hunting, then all grind is reduced to just collecting meds to keep hitting the monsters you like hitting.You will have a wealth of choices, and some time will be wasted on "Will I hunt X thing now? Or Y thing? Oh hey Z thing popped up?! Do I pick that?"And lastly, you will curse your luck on rewards. You will love and hate gems before you even find out what they are. You will hate how you get one item in midgame you will love, and be told you have a chance of picking up more, only to never get one 200 more hours in, and your friends will say "Oh my five Xes? I just got lucky." while they envy you for the Y rare thing you picked up they need but you don't.Also if you main a weapon that isn't ranged, you will fear the mating call of air raid sirens that have become locked onto your butt. This is not final destination, you can use other weapon types.

author: Vakarian
review: I waited a long time for this. I even played Monster Hunter Frontier in korean because i wanted a PC Monster Hunter game so badly. The game improved in many ways and even got a bit less complex, without making it too easy for casual players. They added a lot of new monsters to hunt and the new maps are also great in terms of atmosphere. Performancewise it runs solid on my GTX 970 (60 FPS) with SSAO and Volumetric Fog disabled. Server disconnects happen here and there, but for me, it doesnt destroy the gameplay experience at all. So yeah.. i love the Monster Hunter universe and im glad i can finally play it on the PC. Thanks Capcom!

author: Cosmos
review: 50 hour update:  This game has made me feel feelings I haven't felt from a video game in years. It's up there, for me, with Dark Souls 1, Shadow of the Colossus, Ocarina of Time, Breathe of the Wild, and many other all-time favorites. This game, despite the current connection issues, is as close to perfect as a video game can be. NO SPOILER REVIEW:I avoided all trailers and videos while I waited for it to come out on PC, because I love MH and the excitement of exploring yourself and finding all of the giant monsters. So, without spoiling any of what I've found in my ~10 hours so far, I will simply say that everything has exceeded my expectations. As a fan of Monster Hunter, I was certainly already hyped, but after diving in I can say I never expected a game of this caliber. The world the player finds themselves in is nothing short of spectacular. The environment is infinitely more lush than any MHW predecessor, the colors are and tone of the world are beautiful, and the player and beast modeling is excellent. Tracking and fighting one of the gorgeous beasts is absolutely epic, and the length of the battles and sturdiness of the monsters makes them truly feel like a worthy adversary. Combat-wise, the mechanics are just like previous MH games. If you haven't played one, think Dark Souls meets Zelda, with more of an edge toward DS. Each weapon has a very individualized moveset and playstyle, all catering to different types of players. Evading (see: rolling in DS) is your primary damage avoidance---certain weapons may come with shields, as well, or unlock alternative Evade abilities. I, personally, have enjoyed the Insect Glaive, which allows you to zip around through the air attacking super-fast, while simultaneously buffing yourself and your party with your Kinesect offhand (this isn't a spoiler, this is one of the first weapon options you are provided with).As for the multiplayer, you can now hang around town with up to 16 in your online session, and then do your quests or expeditions with a party of 4. Smacking monsters and exporing with friends is a blast, but so far does not seem to change the game much, other than making it actually possilbe to nail some of the bigger monsters, which would be quite difficult to solo. All-in-all, I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone looking for a true adventure to get themselves lost in.

author: Dominus
review: MHW is an incredible RPG where you can explore colorful landscapes and hunt a plethora of beautiful and dangerous monsters. There's a ton of variety in terms of how you can play the game. With 14 different weapon classes, each weapon provides a unique way to experience the game. From chopping off tails with a sword bigger than your body, to unloading a machine gun into a dragon's face, to bonking an unicorn on the head with a giant guitar, MHW provides you with many different ways to get an adrenaline rush. Each monster is unique in their own way and provides different levels of challenge. Some of the more difficult monsters in the game have given me some of the most intense gaming experiences I've ever had. The game itself requires a good amount of time investment to get into the good stuff. There's a lot of grinding required as you learn how different monsters behave and as you farm up monster parts to build the next best weapon or piece of armor. On its own, the base game can provide around 100 hours of gameplay (although Iceborne's Defender gear has substantially lowered the amount of grinding needed) with tons of customization and monsters to battle. Iceborne is the cherry on top and builds on top of the already impressive base game. At a price of $30, the base game is well worth the money and I highly recommend getting MHW if you're looking for a challenging RPG where you get to bully monsters all day long. May the Sapphire Star guide your way!

author: Freep
review: Everything about this game seems like an improvement from earlier monster hunter games, but it is missing the things that made me play monster hunter four for so many hours.  The community is silent due to the numerous things holding back social interaction from the huge hub area that is a pain to traverse to the chat box that hides in the corner of the screen and gets drowned out by system messages.Despite the community not being so great, the game itself is beyond great.  Amazing gameplay and fantastic improvements to older features.  It just doesn't have as much playability.

author: MoNSTeR
review: In light of the network settings, performance issues, and  *** SEE UPDATE ***, it pains me to say that there are some SERIOUS problems with the Monster Hunter World PC release.HOWEVER, the game is still incredible. I am a mostly-solo hunter with a lot of experience in the franchise, but MHW is the first game I've been able to recruit a full hunting team, and it's been a blast. Yes, the network errors (that as of the time of writing Capcom is actively working on a fix for) can be a bit frustrating, but most can be resolved by simply restarting the game or recreating a session.The game looks beautiful, it runs well (after a few tweaks) and the variable resolution scaling helps a lot to smooth out those hitches. It's just plain fun to progress and fight bigger and badder Monsters in this big beautiful world. I am anxiously awaiting additional content that I'm sure will be added... and also those fixes mentioned above.I rate the launch of the game at 4/10I rate the game itself 9.5/10*** Update: The 'Save Corruption on Defeating the Final Boss' is not real -- it is a Codec issue only with playing the cutscenes. Please see  for more information.

author: Ren
review: Closing on about 1500+ hours on all monster hunter games (MHW on PS4 included), I can say it has got me hooked every since my first game. With 14 weapons available, you'll never run out of weapon and armor sets to make according to your playstyle.The things that bothers me with MHW, is the lack of G-Rank in the game, and the lack of monsters to hunt. Get this is you want to spend hours of your life grinding for that one decoration you need in all of your sets.

author: Sluglip
review: After playing the older games (3u/4u/freedom) It's a breath of fresh air to the series. It takes the foundation of the older games and builds up on it. The maps are no longer broken up into separate sections that need their own load screen to enter. And all the weapons have been given brand new mechanics to them making them feel more diverse and deep. However with the changes to the game over previous titles it also lacks some of the longevity that titles like 4u and the new generations u have. By that I mean the amount of monster added to the game and the addition of G-rank. In world there is only 24 (about only 21 on pc currently) in the game, and more to come. While on the 3ds title there was 70. In the end world is a step in the right direction. However it's like your grandpa who went to walk up the stairs to go the bathroom but instead only make it 3/4 the way there and ♥♥♥♥ his pants instead. I would reccomend this game if you have never played a monster hunter game before and want to know what it's all about.

author: OverCooked
review: I have a GTX 1060 and an i7 8700. Game runs like butter, even with a full party using elemental weapons.TL;DRThe game is very well made with beautiful design in most categories (Combat, World, Character, Armor, Weapon), more than 100 hours of content and tons of replayability. But the online needs some work, because there are server issues. I would get the game if you aren't using wifi. I think I had a total of 5 disconnects when playing with friends and I have a ton of hours on this game. Controls can also be improved. Definitely worth $60.I'm not going to seperate the pros and cons, since they are kinda intertwined.The soundtrack, game design, and combat are fantastic. There is hidden content, the game doesn't really tell you about. IE Cat villages that give you different tools for your Palico (humanoid cat), bounties and investigations that give you extra bonuses from hunting monsters. Most of the different items you can use aren't well explained, so newbies to the series might not use them at all. Using the training area is HIGHLY recommended. Each weapon has different mechanics. Even something like a bow has combos and different skills. The game world feels alive, with monsters interacting with each other and the evironment around them. There are even turf wars between some monsters. You can use the environment to your advantage when fighting monsters. Making them run into trees, dropping boulders on them, kicking frogs (you'll understand if you play), etc. You can even break different parts of the monster (break their horns, cut off their tail, crack their nails, shred up their wings, etc.).Once you get High End, the difficulty increases by a lot, more monsters are introduced, and more game mechanics are introduced as well. Low End is more for an introduction to the game and world. Getting to High End takes about 20-30 hours.I don't really know too much about the voice sync problems, since I always listen to games in the language they were made in and the japanese sync is passable.Compared to other MH titles, the game is a lot more streamlined. Geared towards making grinding less tedious, and trying to expand it's fan base. You can take this as a con or a pro depending on how big a fan you are of MH.   This is a game where you are meant to grind monsters and take your time exploring. It isn't something you are supposed to sprint through at a break neck pace. If you try, you will end up wasting tens of hours backtracking, because you'll soon find enemies can one shot you and your weapons aren't doing a lot of damage. If you aren't into that, don't get the game.However, there's something satisfying about getting stomped by a monster, grinding for 2 hours, then obliterating them for revenge. Then, putting them in an arena, only to wreck them again with a dragonator.You're also meant to explore the different weapon types. If you try to focus on one weapon type, a monster will come along to render it useless. NEVER play with randoms, NEVER use SOS. That's probably the reason why there aren't a lot of public servers open. Most are cancer. They join, then leave, causing you to solo a monster meant for 3-4 people.There are connection issues, but they will be fixed. When it comes to making an online game, you can run all the tests you want, but having servers support hundreds of thousands at once for the first time without bugs, is near impossible.I played the game through with a few friends, and yes, let me tell you. The game is fun alone, but it is a blast with friends. Enemies are more difficult, and you can use different strategies to take down different monsters.As for the controls. I use mouse and keyboard, but it can be difficult, if you don't have very good hand-eye coordination. The UI for item usage is the best out of any MH game, but I can see why people are complaining about it. It requires you to press multiple buttons to switch items (Hold "Q" while mouse scrolling, or left and right clicking). I have a gaming mouse, so I can just map the stuff. Not really an issue for me.Comboing with the different weapons requires you to use Left CTRL and Left and Right Mouse buttons. TheI don't use the lock on at all. It takes away a lot of the camera freedom and can switch to different body parts if you move the camera the wrong way. Free handing it is far better more me and I don't have the same problems with acceleration like the other people. Maybe I'm used to it, or the problem is insignificant.I play the game a lot, so if you think I have bias, feel free to try and call me out on it. I'll try and respond to everyone that disagrees.Finally, and most important. Use an ethernet cable, and download the new GEFORCE Driver for MH and your game issues will decrease significantly.
