author: Proft
review: Kept telling my friend I'd check this game out but I never bought it. After a while my friend just bought the game for me. Basically: Super fun.The game is kind of slow to start. The first hour or so is pretty cutscene heavy and feels very hand holdy, but it picks up. I'll be honest, the actual story is pretty meh, but all the story is anyways is a fat tutorial so... yeah. Gameplay is this games strength though. I think the easiest way to explain it is that every fight is a boss fight (minus killing the pesky smaller mobs of course). Some monsters are really easy to fight, especially if you're padded with the right armor. Later on you might as well be wearing paper, you'll get punished for not knowing fights/not knowing when to hit and when to dodge/block. The community is pretty friendly for the most part, there's some people who get salty at higher ranked things but that's kind of unavoidable. Playing with other players is really fun, but do your best to know as much as you can about the weapon you're using and the monster you're fighting and what you should bring. You don't wanna be the guy who uses the last of the groups carts (respawns). For learning a monster I'd recommend just soloing it and playing evasive while you learn all of its abilities/tells. For learning your weapon, I'd probably just look up a youtube video. I recommend Arekkz, he has fairly quick tutorials for every weapon and it'll really help speed up the learning process for your weapon. Oh and as far as I know the textures for pc are still bugged, so even on high settings you'll only get the lowest textures. Just look around on Nexus for the high res work around.Oh and you should send your guild card to people you group with and take guild cards from everyone that sends them to you. It's not a friend request or anything, you get to see their hunter stats n poses n stuff, but the real benefit to this is that you're letting hunters use your palico and getting more palicos to use for yourself in tailraider safaris. Those'll open up towards the end of the story.TL;DRGreat fun, nice community, do your part/be as learned as you can and you'll be fine. Textures are buggy, just check the nexus for a fix. Accept/Receive all the guild cards you can.

author: Artie
review: Here is my updated review as of sept. 9 2018:Presently Monster Hunter World has covered a big ass chunk of its problems including its day one/week(s) 1-2 server issues or rather the lack there of of proper servers. The game is still fun as all heck and they only keep on adding more and more content into the game. Did i mention that this content is free? because it is. Denuvo is still a thing but eh what can you do about it. Controls are cool i like the M&K controlls so i have no idea on the status of controller stuff, graphics, likewise i have no idea if they did any form of changes to it bc my pc is beefy af. I really like how a lot of the stuff is streamlines, the mantles and bounties are really nice the investigations are also cool too and really helpful later on. And ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ i love the unique monsters in this game geez. so that about covers it this game got better and i reccomend it bc it's great, dont know what else to say :shrug:.review from launch:Monster Hunter World was my most anticipated game this year and so far I am kinda let down. For this review I’m going to go through several things that I do not like about this game and only give slight attention to things to that people have already said in copious numbers of reviews i.e. denuvo, connection problems, and video settings. However I will still address them and give my thoughts over them. So, first I want to preface this by saying that I have played over 1500 hours collectively in the monster hunter game series and have been a part of its fan base for about 4~5 years, with that in mind I will relate how I feel this game could have been better given prior game interactions and where this game improves upon the typical monster hunter formula. Bugs:I can’t just ignore these problems so I am going to get to them in the beginning, this game is pretty solid gameplay wise I have not run into any form of bugs aside from bad graphical quality, but one of my friends game's does freak out whenever he tabs out of the game and then he has to restart it (we both play in borderless windowed and I don’t have this problem). The main bugs that plague this game are in its multiplayer section. So, in prior monster hunter games online play was super easy since the single and multiplayer sections of the games were sectioned off, all you did was make the lobby and bam you were good, just give friends the passcode and they were in no server issues everything worked really well and there weren’t many connectivity issues if any. This games current lobby system is a gigantic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mess, with crappy servers and net code that die almost always when someone is in your lobby and not to mention that the only way to remake your lobby if you have been given an error code is to restart the game instead of just being able to restart it from a menu or from the title screen. This is why I brought up the whole prior games separate systems because it prevented this annoyance which I guess I took for granted. The only other bugs I can think of would be denuvo and I only think of it as a bug since it is a pest :/ I don’t understand why they had to put it into the game denuvo doesn’t work all it does is just punish the people that buy the game pirates will break it like they always do. All together I wasn’t too worried about it since I WAS going to treat this as a predominantly multiplayer game but well can’t think of it as that with these ♥♥♥♥ servers, so oh well. Gameplay: So the gameplay itself is pretty good when you are able to play it, the graphics are pretty good and I love all of the cool animations with the weapons. In prior monster hunter games the story sat at its own back burner being able to be done whenever the player felt like it and in this one it's kinda forced on the player which isn’t really a bad thing but just again another annoyance. This is without mentioning your annoying ass partner that I wish I could just turn off. There is also the problem of not being able to skip cut scenes which I always hate. I love monster hunter's gameplay it is fun as frick and all of this forced story and nonskippable cut scenes just distract from that. What I wanted was a fun experienced fast paced monster slaying experience but instead all I’m feeling right now is just this slow ass early-game. I’m hopeful that late game is much better so when I get to it I’ll edit this part. Graphics: My pc's specs are:Ryzen 7 1800x cpu 4.0 ghzNVidia gtx 1080ti16 GB ddr4 ramAnd at the moment I have most of the settings on high except for that one volume thing that every review said to turn off. I can’t really complain about the graphical quality the game looks great and I’m able to run it well given my high end specs. It is another annoyance that I don’t have more options for settings, the main reason I play on pc is so that I can have those options, I get that it is practically beating a dead horse at this point but given that this is 2018 and that this is a title that sold millions of copies and that Capcom had been working on this for like 8 months this shouldn’t really be acceptable. Improvements on the series:Okay so here is what I think the game got right and brings to the table. I think that the mantle and the slinger systems are really cool and love all of the interactive environments. At first I was reprehensive to the map design since I felt like I was getting lost but I love how you are able to track down monsters through footprints and their weird secretions. I do kinda miss the style oriented fighting that was introduced in generations but I also like the new moves and mounting finishers that were introduced in this game as well. How it could have been better:First separate multiplayer and single player content most people I know were only looking forward to playing multiplayer and were used to that given prior title experiences. Second, more options for pc or even console like turning off tutorial hints or the expedition lady or just anyone trying to talk during a quest, it is distracting and pulls you out of the fight. Third, skip cut scenes I just want to have the choice I like having the choice to do things. Fourth, an improvement to the lobby systems, I’m talking about removing this weird ass 16 player lobbies but the max cap is 4 people a quest just make the lobbies 4 people to help server side. This ties in slightly with the prior point, there is a literal gathering hub that the devs could have used for multiplayer only content separating the two, I wish they had it would have improved this game by a lot in my eyes. TLDR; this game could have been great if it hadn’t been brought down by a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ port, I guess what I was really wanting though was a typical monster hunter experience and got something that strays far from the typical formula and succeeds to a degree but otherwise flops. For now, I’m not going to recommend this game, but if these problems get fixed then I’ll make sure to change it and this review accordingly

review: While other "PC master race" always rants for issues, I'm just happy to play and miraculously run this on my rig (i3 4160 gtx 650 1gb) albeit on lowest settings possible in 1028x768 in 20-30+ fps and using kb and mouse, been waiting for ages since PSP MH games and was really happy with it. author: MNC mascot
review: Probably said a million times, but not being able to start story missions with friends and having them join mid-quest is so stupid.Also unskippable cutscenes and you can't join your friends if they're further in the story than you.

author: emara
review: I was initially hesitant to purchase this game as it was relatively new (2018 I believe), as my laptop typically struggles with the extreme graphics many AAA games have, and I was unsure I would have time to actually play the game since it was finals season. A friend convinced me to get it since it was on sale and despite my hesitance to actually start playing, I was immediately hooked. I've put around 40 hours into this game in the past two weeks since purchasing it. That is 40 hours I probably should have used to study instead. -The graphics were not so intensive that my computer struggled to run it -Multiplayer system is fun and enjoyable. I've had more fun running around on expeditions just hunting monsters and gathering resources than progressing through the main story line.-Resources necessary for upgrading weapons and armor require some grinding, but it has not been to a point were I was getting bored with farming the same monster for upgrade parts.Overall, I would give this game a solid 8/10. Playing with a group of friends and engaging in the co-op makes the game several times more enjoyable.

author: Necrokattuz
review: Don't get me wrong, the game is a lot of fun, and I can see myself playing this for many many hours - but there are glaring issues that keep me from recommending it at a $60 price tag.Control options are telling of a "lazy port", you're basically just assigning keyboard keys to gamepad button functions from the consoles, and there is incredibly little in the ways of customization. This means if on console "Triangle" controlled four to five different things based on situation, mapping that function to E will control four to five different things based on situation, with no way to split the functions. You're going to be gathering items with the secondary attack button when your weapon is sheathed and there's no way to change it. The mouse look feels more like it's emulating a control stick.The online system is wonky and unintuitive, as I gather this is how the game is set up on console too, so this is a design choice, and a poor one. You can't join people doing the story until they've seen every cutscene in a particular hunt, even if you're at the same point in the story, which makes progressing together, something that you take for granted in other games, a massive pain in the backside. This is reminiscent of some early 2000s crap that leaves you scratching your head that a big budget title could go this direction for something that has "World" in the title.There are connectivity issues that seem to be more of a client issue than a server issue. People who have problems consistently have problems with disconnects and such, and people who do not have problems seem to never have problems (thankfully I'm one of the ones who do not have problems, about half of my buddies in discord get disconnected all of the time though).There is also some pretty sketch performance issues with graphics cards that don't appear to be an issue with "potato PCs" as some may call it, rather very fincky driver version needs - and some Nvidia driver versions (notably the most current one) causing two of my friends to crash during cutscenes (which are unskippable, by the way).Overall this game is rich in quality content, but you may have to break through a thick shell of frustration to get to it. There are guides out there if you go digging in Reddit and such to help you out, but you should not have to go digging for guides to get basic features that we normally take for granted to work for a full priced 60 dollar title.

author: Baxie
review: I started the amazing journey with this franchise with Monster Hunter 3 Ultimate and I played through all the western releases since. I was truly excited when they finally announced that the next game will be on PC.As a veteran I must say this is a really great game. Especially with Iceborne which added so needed variety in monsters (even tho they are still mostly wyverns and elder dragons).Compared to old games, this game has many quality of life improvements and whole experience is simply less frustrating. Prior to this game I used to tell my friends that MH is amazing franchise which they should definitely try, but that there are some frustrating mechanics they have to get used to. They'll either love it or hate it. But I don't have to say that anymore.Surely, the game keeps some frustrating aspects (or brings a new ones - hey jewel grinding, I'm looking at you), but overall this is one of the best entries in the series so far. It's definitely the best game if you never played MH before. And it's the great game to continue your MH journey if you're a veteran.Some people say that difficulty decreased compared to old games. I used to think so too, but then I realised it's not really a difficulty which decreased. It's just a lot of frustration is gone. And that's a good thing. One great example why this game isn't easier is the final fight against Fatalis. This is easily one of the hardest fights In the whole series and you'll love it :) And if you never played MH game before and you have no idea what it's about, it's basically a boss fight after a boss fight (note: a few tutorial/early quests might be just gathering/exploring and not actual hunting, but compared to older games there is way less quests like that). So there is a constant action and a lot of challenging fights. Each boss (monster) fight rewards materials specific for that particular monster. Those can be used to craft various weapons and armor. If I have to compare it to other games, I like to say it's Dark Souls meets Diablo. But much much better and still unique ;) One advice for newcomers - there is defender armor. Try to avoid that. It's meant to help you get to the Iceborne content faster. It does its job well simply because it gives you insane advantage. But as a result, early progress can feel too easy and not enough challenging. Boring even. So if you want the full Monster Hunter experience you'll surely enjoy, progress using other armor you craft and upgrade or replace with a new one from monsters you hunt along the way. Also try to play at least through the story solo or with a friend(s) who started a new character with you. Basically for the very same reason. Having experienced hunter with the end game gear in your quest will feel too easy and boring.If you avoid these, you'll surely have a great time. Even tho the game is no longer getting new content, it's still worth picking up and I'll definitely keep playing for a while so I'll see you in a gathering hub maybe.

author: Xedhadeaus
review: Monster Hunter... The perfect grind game. Historically known for having delightful amounts of content shoved into such a small space that you can somehow justify having a console specifically for one of their games. Hopefully I can be as brief as possible with this but it is absolutely atrocious that a game that is about hunting can have more mechanics and equipment tailored to specific ways to accomplish practically anything related to survival, AND have more equipment diversity and item purpose than any survival game that could ever hope to exist... While not being a survival game. Back to the point. Monster Hunter is like a vast painting that has you searching for Waldo, except that there is more than one. And while the typical person will find Waldo and move on. The people who appreciate the art and stick around to find that there are a whole lot of Waldos just strolling around just shy of plain sight. Everything about the game can be made into fun with a little know how.Unfortunately, this review isn't about monster hunter, it's about Monster Hunter World.-Monster Hunter World is a Fantastic game set to appeal to the masses, delivering much more fluid combat, Crystalline attention to detail, admirable amounts of content, easy to start co op, An array of weapons to choose from and adapt to, and skills to support every set up and idea. Please stick around for the rest if you read this, because I am going to start with the bad. Monster Hunter World made a big mistake (In my opinion). The things you would normally go out and kill monsters for has been trivialized beyond recognition. The shortest way I can describe this to you is, Imagine if a good game had several seasons of content, and the content costs nothing now so they make the entire game laughably easy to catch you up so you can get to the content they can gouge you for. But instead of there being content at the end, it's RNG, and instead of the game being old and full of content, it's brand new, and has very little at the end. -Do not mistake me, I LOVE this game, But growing up, half of the mettle was getting a crew of able willed hunters together to slay, and in most cases, dismantle a monster to craft its armor. Where half the battle is people using traps so none of us have to constantly flank the monster, or breaking several wings to make a piece of equipment... Monster Hunter World made practically every item but gems and plates, and choice irritants like Vaal Hazak's fang or Nergigante's tail, EXTREMELY easy to obtain without severing or breaking. The whole point of Monster Hunter is enjoying the methodical turn of the thickest solution of delicious thoughtful and well excecuted content... And Monster Hunter World literally pours water in it to make it easier to mix up. But it doesn't taste the same.-In a month or so, Everyone on PC will be farming Kulve Taroth to get some of, if not mostly the best weapons available in the game in another slog of RNG delivered progression. Weapons that mostly outclass or replace what weapons you wasted your time earning. And because it is a limited time quest, once it is gone, you will be left with inferior weapons to chase, or more RNG supported decoration farming... The general content climate of this series departure makes absolutely no sense to me. Moving on...GOOD STUFF! Monster Hunter World Is a graphical marvel and overall sight to see, the game and many of its assets are top notch, animations are mostly fluid, and performance is almost perfect now that teostra's fire has been fixed, There are a few lighting hiccups here and there, but that's on my end.-The quests are more involved, and only require brute force and VERY little know how to complete, you won't be catching fish or killing copious amounts of raptors because you're hoping you don't need to kill big bad Tigrex to boost your hunter rank. (It isn't always a good thing.)-SOS flares! No more looking outside of the ad hoc party seeing a few minute men wave at the screen and then make and destroy half a dozen houses so you can open your room and help them out. -General quality of life changes, infinite tent and item box access, being able to eat mid mission, the entire slinger mechanic...-Free DLC Updates, New monsters, gear. They said they were going to make it accessible for everyone, and they sure did. Monster Hunter World is an undeniable addition to the roster of games. There is a lot to do, and fun to be had. You will fully enjoy this game without issue until you hit the endgame, at that point I recommend you make some friends or answer some SOS flares. unless you are patient enough to wait for more content.-To be fair, other games exist, and there are other things to do. But I hope the developers know that our tastebuds have demanded a king's ransom after experiencing the reimagining of a game we used to pour our lives into decades ago, so as much as I want to cry and complain that my game changed a little, and I miss the old days. It's finally on PC,

author: ApolloMan
review: I have been playing monster hunter since monster Freedom Unite on PSP and I have pretty much played every game in the series since then. This game seems like the next logical step in the monster hunter series. One does not need to have a wiki in  order to really get into the nit and gritty of the game. The combat seems much more fast pacedI really enjoy this game...when it works. It seems that my mates and I experience connection issues everytime we play. We often get so disgusted with connection issues that we just have to stop playing. The game looks decent enough for being developed on an older engine. Graphical performance has also been underwhelming due to the fact that my gtx 1060 will go from a solid 45-50 fps to 10-15 fps at certain points, and especially while using dual blades. I have noticed other people experiencing similar performance issues. Until these issues are fixed, I cannot recommend this game.

author: Lt. Tits McGee
review: one of the best multiplayer games in 2018+ Great visuals+ Solid gameplay and controls + The game is filled with content ( not only hunting monster you can do other side stuff )+ Free constant updates + Diverse weapons ( Classes ) styles- Content are coming out slow ( it seems they learnt and started pushing out content on a fast pace )- The game suffers from FPS problems- The game lack official mod support ( you can still mod your game without ruining people experience )- Some function and options should have been free but they sell it ( like editing you game or changing your gender you have to buy "Edit ticket" )- Overall the game is addictive and fun and it encourage you to go online and hunt with people. The community is nice and I have not faced any hacker or troll player yet. Right now the contents are coming out on fast pace and the game is not repetitive.

author: LAGRIE
review: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD----------------------------------------Playing Monster Hunter since MH freedom.And this one has grown on me.It improves on allot of aspects, even tho its a little more player friendly, i do think its what this franchise needed.Hunting Monster is now even more fun, since they actually attack each other now, like actual wildlife.The area's are now open instead of sub areas.Whet stones are no longer an extra micromanage, its now always in your box.The Game looks great and runs pretty good on my rig.Its crazy to see MH come to pc, and it sure delivers.The port itself is good, but it could use a few fixes.The Connection issues is what bugs me the most at times, but it will get sorted out.Im one of the lucky ones, and the game does not disconnect that often on me.Its an amazing game, with strong design choises, great music, and memorable monsters.Even there are less Monsters then in preivious Mh's, its understandable since its an entire new engine, and the update AI and Graphics also come to mind. 'even updates are planned with new monsters and returning older ones).Its a Strong experience for new comers, and one of the more beginner friendly Mh's out there.So Hunters, join me in the next hunt !!! MEOW !!!!Sry for the bad english and enjoy MH !!!

author: Wushnedge
review: First of all, this game is great. Played on PS4 and playing through again on PC, loving my time with it.It's Monster Hunter. That's all you should need.I personally haven't had any problems with in game performance or connectivity, only a few blips that were very early after release which are understandable considering the amount of people trying to access multiplayer at once. As of writing I've played all of today (2 days after release) with no multiplayer issues whatsoever.Currently running on an i5-4690k, 970 and 8GB of RAM on high with little to no frame drops or performance issues, so just make sure your PC is reasonable and you should be fine. Denuvo also hasn't been a problem. As long as you don't have a potato PC and can connect to the internet (which you should be able to considering you're downloading a game on steam and you're getting a game with a large amount of multiplayer) then you shouldn't have any problems. I don't support Denuvo in the slightest, but I don't see why people decide to cry about it and stop themselves from enjoying a great game.Tl;dr game good

author: Atratzu
review: Whew... where do I start?Monster Hunter is a huge RPG developed by Capcom and released in 2018. Monster Hunter has lots of small detailed armor and crafting work to compliment the very large level maps, and countless hours of content. My brothers are consistently surprised that I insist on paying attention to stories in games, but they were especially surprised that I could kind of follow the Monster Hunter story.I don't blame them though, the story is hard to follow. And there are huge gaps in the main story as you get derailed hunting/farming/fishing/gathering/crafting/researching/leveling.You are part of the Fifth Fleet which has been summoned to help "Research" Monsters in the New World.I think the plot can be summed up best (and spoiler free) a conversation my brother and I had after we finished the main game:Me: "We did it... now we can go home"Tim: "You never go home" I'm not someone who gets overwhelmed by open world games easily. I've played a lot of open world games, and seen a lot of mechanics. I've also played many MMORPG's which are often most guilty of presenting far too many activities/options to the player too fast.Monster Hunter: World left me baffled within hours. Not only did the combat seem complex, but the crafting, grinding, and questing system seemed foreign and strange to me....It doesn't help matters that I wasn't actually playing in my own style for the first 15-or-so-hours. My brothers were trying to speed me through the story because Monster Hunter has no idea that friends want to help friends progress through the game!! But one sub topic at a time.I suggest getting a feel for the game on your own for a few hours, go explore, try to fight smaller monsters, poke around. Let yourself make mistakes at the start of the game. Once you're later in the game you REALLY don't wanna mess up on what gear you're crafting and waste materials you spent hours to get.Next, the "early co op complaint". Friends can't join your game until you're seen cutscenes. On one hand, I get it... the cutscene stops combat and you need to watch Tyrannosaurus Rex do his animation and see his name and exclaim "oh god! run away!!!"But on the other hand... I want to run around the world with my friends, or HELP my friends FIND the Tyrannosaurus in the first place.Now once you get into the same game... NOW the fun can really start.You're more than capable of playing through the whole game on your own, and if you had a bumbling sidekick like me, you'd be all the better without it. But having another person can really help take down monsters faster. That's part of the reason why my brothers wanted me to get Monster Hunter: World. The end game is tough and it's easier with a friend or three! Safety in Numbers.I'd love to go into greater detail on the different weapons (I stuck with the Bow when in a group, and the Insect Glaive or Charge Blade on my own) but believe it or not, steam reviews have a character limit... I uhhh... I've hit it before. Suffice to say, Monster Hunter: World has MORE than enough for anyone remotely interested in giving it a go!At the time of this review I've only played 36 hours and haven't barely gotten started.

author: HunterRayder93
review: [ING] Version:And since I first discovered the Monster Hunter series through the "Monster Hunter 3tri" version of the Wii that I have fallen in love with the brand, with its interesting and unique style, the idea of ​​hunting monsters and making them out of them. materials to create more and more powerful armor and weapons fascinated me a lot, the 3tri I never managed to finish I was very trapped with the online at the time, but only years later when the 3ds-WiiU version of the 3tri / Ultimed lo came out I finished 100% reaching the highest levels of the guild missions, I tried once to play the first titles for Psp the first Monster hunter and the Freedom 2 and Freedom ultimed, the first I stopped at the beginning in the first 3-4 star missions while the Freedoom 2-Ultimed I didn't even start it, since then I stopped playing but as in many things I always followed the updates on the game from outside, I knew of the existence of Monster hunter: world on PC for some time but the idea of buy me the expansion to be able to playing at the highest levels bothered me, after many ups and downs I decided to buy World and Ice Bronr at the end and I can say that I am really 100% satisfied.Basically the game play and as I remembered it I had no problems in understanding the mechanics the only problem I had was in the controls that if played with mouse and keyboard this game is really complicated, in fact I immediately started playing with the controller and in fact I feel much better, and says one who basically on PC mainly play mouse and keyboard.Wolrd basic comunqe in many things greatly facilitates the gameplay such as the search for monsters that thanks to the "Guiding insects" makes it less difficult to search for monsters to hunt without having to use the phantom "color bombs" as in the previous MH, even the areas hunting are much more beautiful, more explorable and "less distant" making your experience much more exciting and freer, even the collection of materials is easier now just approach a collection point to be able to collect the materials that can be combined to create items or to use at the forge for new weapons and armor, in essence World has greatly improved the quality of life by making many missions less frustrating and easier for everyone both for veterans of the series and for new players playing for the first time to an MH.But there are pros and cons:[PRO]- Stunning graphics-Variety of monsters of truly wide- Infinite amount of missions- More extensive character creation and customization than in previous episodes-Ability to create cosmetic armor!- Interested history filled with well-curated footage in animations-With Iceborn they give you a piece of equipment so you can go straight to the end of the game and play with your friends at the highest levels-Open world hunting areas without loading from one area to another[CON]-Apart from the first hunting areas, the coral area is too large and dispersed... after 3 days I still struggle to understand where to go to find the monsters and follow them, while the "cemetery" and the lava area are too small as if the developers haven't focused enough on those last 2 areas that are still nice to see and explore.- Finding a server is difficult sometimes you go into sessions full of players but all of high grade Master and you little one are not targeted... sometimes I wait a few minutes because someone comes to my rescue (maybe because the game has reached the end of its development cycle now?)-Playing with mouse and keyboard is not easy, this game was born on consoles and like a console game it must be played with the controller there are no other ways.-Even if the grappling hook is an interesting mechanic added with Iceborn... I sometimes find its use ... somewhat complicated at times I still get confused switching from the sling to the grapple.[ITA] Version:E da quando ho scoperto per la prima volta la serie di Monster Hunter tramite la versione della Wii "Monster Hunter 3tri" che mi sono innamorato perso del brand, con quel suo stile interessante e unico, l'idea di cacciare mostri e ricavarne da essi materiali per creare armature e armi sempre più potenti mi affascinò tantissimo, il 3tri non lo riuscii mai a finire mi ero intrappato molto con l'online all'epoca, ma solo anni dopo quando uscì la versione per 3ds-WiiU del 3tri/Ultimed lo finii al 100% arrivando ai massimi livelli delle missioni di gilda, provai una volta a giocarmi i primi titoli per Psp il primo Monster hunter e il Freedom 2 e Freedom ultimed, il primo mi fermai all'inizio nelle prime missioni a 3-4 stelle mentre il Freedoom 2-Ultimed non lo iniziai neanche, da allora ho smesso di giocare ma come in molte cose seguii sempre da fuori gli aggiornamenti sul gioco, sapevo dell'esistenza di Monster hunter: world su PC già da tempo ma l'idea di comprarmi l'espansione per poter giocare ai livelli massimi mi scocciava, dopo tante peripezie mi sono deciso di comprarmi alla fine World e Ice Bronr e posso dire di esserne d'avvero soddisfatto al 100%.Di base il game play e come me lo ricordavo non ho avuto problemi nel capire le meccaniche l'unico problema che ho avuto e stato nei controlli che se giocato con mouse e tastiera questo gioco risulto d'avvero complicato, infatti fin da subito sono partito col giocare con il controller e in fatti mi sto molto meglio, e lo dice uno che di base su PC gioco prevalentemente mouse e tastiera.Wolrd comunqe di base in molte cose facilita molto il gameplay come la ricerca dei mostri che grazie agli "Insetti guida" rende meno ostico la ricerca dei mostri da cacciare senza dover più usare le fantomatiche "bombe colore" come nei precedenti MH, anche le zone di caccia sono molto più belle più esplorabili e "meno sistanziate" rendendo la propria esperienza molto più entusiasmante e più libera, anche la raccolta dei materiali e più semplice ora basta avvicinarsi ad un punto di raccolta per poter raccoglier i materiali da poter combinare per creare oggetti o da usare alla forgia per nuove armi e armature, in sostanza World ha migliorato di molto la qualità della vita rendendo molte missioni meno frustranti e più facili per tutti sia per i veterani della serie che per i nuovi giocatori  che giocano per la prima volta ad un MH.Pero ci sono dei pro e dei contro:[PRO]-Grafica sbalorditiva-Varietà dei mostri d'avvero ampia-Quantità di missioni infinite-Creazione e personalizazione del personaggio più ampia rispetto ai precedenti episodi-Possibilità di creare armature cosmetiche!-Storia interessate piene di filmati ben curati nelle animazioni-Con Iceborn ti regalano un equipaggiamento per poter arrivare direttamente alla fine del gioco e giocare con i tuoi amici ai massimi livelli-Zone di caccia Open world senza caricamenti da un area all'altra[CON]-A parte le prime zone di caccia , la zona corallina e troppo grande e dispersiva...dopo 3 giorni faccio ancora fatica a capire dove andare per scovare i mostri e seguirli, mentre la zona del "cimitero" e quella lavica sono troppo piccole come se gli sviluppatori non si sono concentrati abbastanza su quelle 2 ultime zone che percarità sono comunque belle da vedere ed esplorare.-Trovare un server e difficile alle volte vai in sessioni piene di giocatori ma tutti di grado alto Maestro e te piccolino non vieni preso di mira...alle volte apsetto un pò di minuti perchè viene qualcuno a venire in mio soccorso (forse perchè il gioco ormai e arrivato alla fine del suo ciclo di sviluppo?)-Giocare con Mouse e tastiera non e semplice, questo gioco e nato su console e come un gioco per console deve essere giocato per forza col controller non ci sono altri modi.-Anche se il rampino e una meccanica interessante aggiunta con Iceborn... trovo alel volte il suo utilizzo...alquanto complicato alle volte faccio ancora confusione a passare dalla fionda al rampino.

author: Al
review: Monster Hunter World isn't called Monster Hunter 5, but it's totally Monster Hunter 5. It's also kind of a reboot for the series. MHW feels like a game that takes into account the things most people ask themselves when they first play MH, such as “Why is the map an item taking space in my bag?” and “Why is the quest rewards window on a timer?”. MHW gets rid of a lot of the stupid stuff that has carried over from game to game for no good reason besides it being how it has always been done. A lot of things have changed, but at its core, this is still very much the same style of game.For the uninitiated, Monster Hunter is a game about hunting monsters, of course. But seriously, Monster Hunter is a game about boss fights and loot. It’s about learning bosses’ attack patterns, preparing for fights, and reaping the rewards when you beat the bosses. Bosses don’t drop weapons and pieces of armor, like in Diablo or WoW, though. You get monster parts from carving their corpses, and then you craft your gear from those parts. This might sound gruesome, but there is very little gore in the game. The game has a light-hearted comedic style to it, and is no more violent than something like Zelda. There is a story tying everything together, but it is not much more than an excuse to lead you into new areas and introduce new monsters to kill.Compared to Monster Hunter Generations, Monster Hunter World controls much more fluidly, but if you’re looking for a Monster Hunter game that controls as smoothly as Devil May Cry, you’ll be sorely disappointed. This is still that kind of clunky, complex, animation priority heavy Monster Hunter. There have been a few key improvements that make the game feel much better to play, though. The biggest ones being the weapon sheathing and item using systems. You automatically sheathe your weapon when you start running now, so you can get away from a monster more quickly. You also don’t have to stop running to use an item anymore, so you don’t have to stand there and go through a long drinking animation and risk getting hit again. These might sound like small things, but they’re huge improvements and make the game play much better.The biggest change to the game is in the hunting itself, though. In previous games, you had to carry paintballs around, run around an area to find the monsters, and throw the paintballs at the monsters to track them. Every zone was also separated by a loading screen, which could slow the game down a lot, depending on the system you were playing on. These were things some people defended as if the game wouldn’t be Monster Hunter if they changed them, but they’ve changed them, and the game is better for it. There are no paintballs in MHW. You don’t have to carry anything, craft anything, or throw anything at the monsters to track them. In MHW, you find monster footprints, hair, and scales, and track monsters by scent, like a dog. Their scents are visually represented by the scoutflies. The scoutflies are swarms of firefly looking bugs that lead you in the right direction, and even highlight gatherable items, like mushrooms, herbs, and more monster tracks. You gain experience tracking each monster as you collect more of their tracks, and eventually, you’ll automatically start tracking a monster without having to find their tracks. You can also put a pin on anything on the map, and have the scoutlies guide you to it. It doesn’t even have to be a monster. You can have them guide you to a mining node if you want.Zone loading screens are completely gone in MHW. Monsters still run away into other zones, each zone is still numbered on the map, and monsters are still kind of tethered to one zone at a time, there just aren’t loading screens. Each level feels like a big open world, but it's really not much different from how it was in the old games, it's just bigger and faster. The core monster tracking and chasing game is still the same.Monster Hunter World is also really good at slowly introducing you to the game's mechanics and explaining things through tutorials and tooltips. The amount of info thrown at you in the beginning of the game is pretty overwhelming, even for a MH veteran, but you can always go back and read all of these tutorials again, because the game saves them all for you. The game also keeps a detailed notebook full of monster weaknesses, weak points, and even loot tables. You can pull all of this stuff up any time you want, too. Tooltips on rare monster parts even tell you what you have to do to get them. There's a small Wiki's worth of information built right into the game.Monster Hunter World introduces a ton of other improvements as well. You can now go to any area and freely explore, hunt, or farm herbs and mushrooms without taking some useless voucher turn-in quest. Crafting has been greatly simplified. You don't need recipe books, required materials have been reduced, and the game even gives you the option to automatically craft any item when you get the required materials. You only get one Palico and they don't have talent trees anymore. All you need to worry about is their gear. You have access to food and your bank at the starting camp in every map, so you can rebuff if you die, change your armor and weapon, and even store and restock items in the middle of a quest. You don't need to carry honey to make more Mega Potions anymore, just fast travel back to camp and restock. Did I mention you can fast travel? You can open up your map and travel to any campsite you've discovered. Items like the whetstone, bug net, BBQ spit, and fishing pole get their own dedicated inventory slots, and the whetstone has infinite uses. There are no mining picks, and you never put anything you carve from a monster in your bags, so you have a lot more free bag space now. It also makes it so you never have to discard an item to loot a monster part again. There's too many things for me to list here, but they all add up and make the game much more intuitive.Multiplayer on PC has been pretty iffy so far. A patch that fixes some of the network issues has been released now, but online was a mess during the first week and a half after launch. It wasn’t just when playing multiplayer either. Since you have to make online sessions when you start a game, I would get huge lag spikes and disconnect messages, even when playing alone. It got to the point where I would just start the game in Steam’s offline mode to avoid these issues. There are still some problems, especially during peak hours, but the online is working much better now.Monster Hunter World has some beautiful graphics, but it's the art direction that really makes them shine. Environments in MHW look natural and tell a story of their own. The way each zone blends into the next is seamless and makes sense. For example, the desert area has a river going through the Western part of the map. The river starts at a waterfall in the North, and ends in a muddy lake in the Southernmost section of the map, where the mudskipper monster, Yuratodus, hangs out. There's tall grass around the river, and cacti deep in the desert. The trails going from the river to the desert look like they were eroded by streams flowing down to the river, like maybe this area floods sometime during the year, or maybe the swamp covered more of the desert at one point.The game looks great, but technically, it’s kind of a mess. Some issues have been alleviated with a recent patch, but others remain. The most noticeable issue is the low resolution textures. For whatever reason, the game doesn't load the high res textures, even though they are installed on your computer. Modders have gotten them to load with mods, so we know they’re there. There are also major issues with one of the Elder Dragons, Teostra, and the last map, Elder’s Recess. This map has a bunch of lava, smoke, heat wave effects, and a ton of sh

author: Mago
review: No inicio que lançou eu critiquei muito o jogo por não ver contexto em matar monstros grandes vulgo "bosses", eu considerava pateta quem perdia tempo jogando isso (vide minha primeira experiencia no dauntless), porem depois muito tempo eu comprei e decidi jogar, e acabei me apegando muito ao jogo, excelente em todos os tipos de sistema, recomendounico ponto negativo é a velocidade desbalanceada de alguns monstros X seu tamanho, as vezes voce fica questionando sua existencia.English Version At the beginning it launched I criticized the game a lot for not seeing context in killing big monsters aka "bosses", I considered goofy who lost time playing this (see my first experience on dauntless), but after a long time I bought and decided to play, and I ended up getting very attached to the game, excellent in all types of systems, I recommendonly negative point is the unbalanced speed of some monsters X their size, sometimes you are questioning their existence.

author: Sin
review: This game, even though i agree with some of the statements the negative reviews make, is not as bad as people put out to be. Yes the multiplayer could be worked on however after figuring out how things work it was very easy to join friends even if they were mid fight. I also understand that (at the time of making this) only have 11.8 hours, but for never playing monster hunter before this one it is extremely enjoyable and fun whether you are fighting a monster or just roaming around gathering materials for better armor, more potions, making items, etc. Lastly, the campaign could be better because it is somewhat straight forward and doesnt leave any room to feel attached however it is a great way to hone your skills and gain experience fighting bigger and stronger monsters as you progress. 8/10 i would say?

author: IamsDog
review: While the launch of MHW PC wasn't the cleanest the gameplay itself is pretty dang good. Ignoring the disconnection issue, since it is already November and the issue is not relevant anymore, it's a fun game that will entertain you for at least 100 hours. The price you pay compared to the sheer amount of content is well worth it especially if it's on sale. Now, do understand that this is an action grinding game. So, if you don't like fact pace action games that require quicker reaction times and tons of grinding then this game is not for you. Now for some of the cons: if you're looking for a good story you're not going to get it, you have this creepy partner that will annoy you at nearly every given moment, and the learning curve at the beginning will frustrate new players to the Monster Hunter series. Overall, if you like the game genre and you were already thinking about getting this game definitely get it. It's currently on sale for 34% off and it's more than worth that price. Have fun and take care!

author: MRGIGAS
review: QUALITY OF LIFE IMPROVEMENTS AND A PC MASTERPIECEI am a veteran of the MH series, having played since MH1. MHW has many quality of life improvements over previous titles, making the game more accessible to those who have less time to play. Still, the game retains its depth. It is very noticeable that the MH team has wanted to release a PC title for a very long time.||||||||||||||||||||||| PERFORMANCE|||||||||||||||||R7 2700x, 1080ti,  3200 14-14-14-34 RAMI am able to maintain a solid 60 fps while recording at 1440p. You will need at least a modern quad core processor and a 1070 to play this game at 1440p, and at least an old i5 and 1060 to play this game at 1080p. Yes, you will need to turn the fog off, but maintaining 60fps+ is very easy otherwise while maintaining great visuals.||||||||||||||||||||||| GAMEPLAY|||||||||||||||||I have never felt such a high level of immersion in a MH title. This game truly makes you feel like you are part of the Monster Hunter ::world::, and ditches the gimmick mechanics from the spinoffs (MHX, XX, etc) in favor of amazing combo play.The game starts off extremely easy and then ramps up back to normal difficulty just before high rank. The monsters behave more reasonably and are less abusable. Every weapon class feels unique and useful. Utility items and status effects are more part of the game than they were before.||||||||||||||||||||||| DESIGN|||||||||||||||||Most of the armor sets and weapons look great, though many of the ones in low rank are very boring. The new armor system is simplified, but encourages varied gameplay. Meta sets are much less dominant, which is great for those of us that like to roleplay. The new gathering system and merchant NPCs make the game feel less repetative and allow you to focus on hunting monsters. The scoutflies are an amazing addition.The improved audio, visuals, and animations come together perfectly to deliver a long-overdue upgrade to the series. This game looks and plays much better than previous titles, yet maintains its distinct MH feel. This is how you make a game - great graphics do not mean a loss of stylization. Previous monsters breath new life, and new monsters have their distinct personalities.I feel like I am re-discovering Monster Hunter. This is what the game should have been from the start.

author: Just Toshi
review: This game is at the top of my favourites right now!The only thing I've personally had is disconnects to servers, For example: Me and 2 other friends were all hunting together killing a monster and all of a sudden, I or one of them get disconnected, Now this can be a major pain in the butt, But it's only just been released.I don't expect it to be perfect on release!Now for the good stuff;: Oh my god, This stuff gets intense when you run out of heals and youre on your last life, god does it get your blood pumping! My personal experience, The mongrel Diablos, God I spent hours hunting him to get a kill/capture on him!Many times I wanted to just stop, But I just couldn't, You get sucked in pretty bad (Or atleast I do). : These can be really funny, Watching your friend get constant CC chained then proceeds to die can be hilarious, Grouping up can have its pros and cons:; You can all smash a monster together, You can gather materials together aswell it's a good experience all round in my opinion!; If you group up with a bunch of randoms, Sometimes they dont pull their weight, Either it being them doing no damage or them dying constantly causing the mission to fail and you lose all progress. It can be frustrating wasting 25 mins on a hunt for it to go down the drain... Thats the main con other than the one I listed at the beggining (Disconnecting)But, Overall I've got something like 35 hours on my character and I'm just hitting the harder content, Ive enjoyed every single bit of it. I highly reccoment this game! Its a fun game to jump on with a bunch of friends and even making friends!Hope you enjoyed this review and it wasn't toooooooo long!Happy hunting!Toshi~EDIT: Just lost all 190 hours of work due to a bug they haven't fixed yet, Theres absolutely nothing I can do about it unless I backed up the save files prior to now, I wasn't informed it was an issue so I did not backup anything. BE CAREFUL EVERYONE, BACKUP NOW!

author: Chan
review: I remember playing Monster Hunter Freedom Unite under my blanket because it was past bedtime. I remember falling asleep to the Pokke Village theme every weekend night.I remember discovering my childhood nightmare, the abomination Khezu.I remember wondering why was there a giant sword at the back of the village.and fast forward about a decade or so, just after slaying the final boss of MHW: Iceborn, Fatalis, with the very same greatsword I spent countless hours as a kid, day dreaming about what myths, legend or story that this mysterious black sword holds, I've felt like I've just uncovered one of the greatest mystery of my life. It's a weird feeling.I never did finish Freedom Unite, nor do I know why. Pokke Village was where everything began for me, and now it ended with Iceborn.I'm sure each of everyone's experience with MH here is completely unique.Some may began from the very first Monster Hunter released, and some from World or any titles in between, it doesn't matter. It's more than just a game.It's an adventure. Trust me.TLDR: Uncovered a childhood mystery after finishing Iceborn. Experiencing mental breakdown. 10/10 would do it again. Good luck out there fellow hunters!May the light of the sapphire star guide your way. o7

author: Starri♡
review: It's an ok game..Pros: -Lots of weapons to choose from -Fun combat-Story is interesting-Can play solo or multiplayer -Options to choose preferred dub (monster language?!) Cons: -Major muliplayer issues 1. Can't join another's hunt while they have a cutscene, only fix around that is to join after they started the hunt) 2. When idling too long in the lobby, it'll put you to offline mode so you have to return to main screen 3. Sometimes disconnects during hunt -The graphics aren't crisp clear like they were on the console -Not really suited for keyboard/mouse controls, feels wonky -Certain particles will cause lag Overall if you're a solo player, get this game, but if you enjoy playing with friends, prepare to be frustrated with the amount of multiplayer problems they have currently until the developers decide to fix it!

author: Scott
review: Have been obsessed with this game as soon as I bought it. Gorgeous graphics, fun combat, and perfect for those who like grindy games where you go out in the world and gather resources for upgrades. Can be played either co-op or by yourself, and the story missions where you have to watch the first cutscene before playing with a group are less intrusive than I thought they'd be. No problem here playing with friends. Edit 1/22/20: ICEBORNE is sweet!Edit: 9/2/20: 350+ hours, still sweet!Edit: 1/29/22: 425+ hours, still sweet! Rise is sweet too!

author: CombatWombat
review: Excellent game! I played Tri before this on the Wii and it feels like I am right back in the thick of it! Because this game was originally built for console, some controls may be confusing to use but there are easy workarounds if you find them. I would also say that the communication controls are a bit lackluster for a game that relies so much on coordination with other people. Many people have complained that some weapon types are confusing to use and can deter new players, which I agree. New players should definitely take some time to use the training area to test out different weapons and watch guides when needed. There are certainly easy and effective to use weapons as well as more difficult to learn but fun weapons that cater to a variety of playstyles. It also really helps to have friends to play with. It really enhances your experience when you find yourself working as a coordinated team with 3 other friends or strangers to take down big monsters. Happy Hunting!

author: Onza
review: Just BRILLIANT !A fantastic game and one i believe everyone should experience .- beautiful landscapes - awesome creatures/monsters - massive amount of replayability - fluid combat - large weapon variety - stunning armour variations - free new dlc content and events - great multiplayer experience - networking was horrible the first week but has since been fixed - port performance not the best and could've been done better - no ps4 buttons - i hear the amount of creatures in this title is far less than that of other titles in the series , not too big a deal seeing as all these creatures had to be remade for this game - some textures not working on the pc versionA brilliant game thats worth well over the asking price 9/10 recommend

author: Kiel
review: As a veteran of the previous Monster Hunter games, this new installment does a lot of things right, but also is lacking in certain important aspects. Pros: - A MH game that looks good- tweaks to classes that make them more enjoyable than previous games- being able to walk and shoot my LBG / HBG- no more zone segregation- no more tedious farming runs- much faster paced and fluid combat- multiplayer is much easier to setup- easier to organize gear and gear setsCons:- story is forgettable garbage- gear set customization is horrible- lack of monster variety- not very many maps- massive lack of endgame content (ie, monsters, gear sets, challenges, missions, expeditions, etc)- horrible RNG on gem creation (which also affects endgame and gear-set customization)All in all, this is a good game for newcomers to get into. The biggest issue is whether or not you played the previous MH games. If you have, the more prevalent these cons will probably apply to you. My biggest personal issue was that I could not find enough enjoyment to sink hundreds of hours into this game like I did in 3U and 4U due to lack of monster variety, missions, and no meaningful purpose behind expeditions.I've gotten to 200 hours on PS4's release. I couldn't get past 30 starting over again on PC. Take that as you will.

author: Dodowingster
review: Monster Hunter World is a game, a brilliant and fun game.Everybody knows that Monster Hunter games have always been bad at their graphics. The game looks awesome and crappy at times BUT this is a  game after all, in fact this is the first Monster Hunter game that looks absolutely amazing compared to the older titles, where as looked more PS2 ish. The cutscenes might look a bit off as the camera tends to blur a face partially at times, but most of the time it's the handler.Let's be real here, MHW's visual and audio designs especially hitting monsters are  compared to the older titles, which includes blood slicing here and there. The soundtracks are pretty amusing to hear especially the elder dragon's except for Kushala....overall the OSTs are great but it still can't beat Monster Hunter Tri's OST....... Monster Hunter never had a story to begin with, but MHW fills the gap and it is not that bad. It's pretty nice got something here and there. The only problem with the story is....the handler, not because she's annoying (which she is) but the game fails to portray us players what a handler actually do....maybe not.....just patch her out and it's fixedUse Monster Hunter Language to avoid her annoyance....you are welcomeEvery weapon in this game is viable, and that's the fun part. I was once a SnS(Sword and Shield) main and never wanted to try other weapons, then I went to Charge Blade which can also block and works quite familiar with SnS. Then I change to LS(longsword) which turn out to be fun until.........................migod the weapon that I sh*t on the most turned to be my most favourite of all. The game also have dynamic environmental that you could interact with to gain the upper hand against the snorting Trex or other monsters. The simplest joy to wedge beetle and be the next spiderman that is PS4 exclusive at coral highlands is really fun....until Kirin hit you and you fell down.........There's not too less or too many monsters in the game but you will meet, a velocidodo, a puki puki, static squirrel, snorting Trex, married wyverns, married underground bull, flying lion, lightning horse, a cameraman, fluffy bat and a retarded jagras and many more. Wait I forgot to mentio- Boeing 52.......................... f*ckMost of the time it is the connection issues but they are fixed now. Still when you fight a Kushala or a Teostra, then beware for some FPS drops..... The keyboard and mouse controls are okay ish but the key bindings are a little messed up. Why does the shortcut are binded to F1, F2, F3 and so on? It's odd but can get used to but I rather 1~8 to be the shortcut.Overall I give this game a 7/10  if they add in G Rank with Lagiacrus my baby into this game then it deserves more than that. Most likely a DLC but its okay for me

author: Sunny Bear 써니
review: This game is visually stunning. Yes, it has a downside, online play. However, you are still able to play this game offline and enjoy the story mode. So, I don't understand why many people are upset about connection issues as the game offers both single and multiplayer gameplay. Personally, I haven't had any of my games disconnect and I played with a friend in Korea and I'm currently living in England. If you're looking to play this game with a group of friends then I suggest you wait until they stabilise the servers. Because other reviews have said that their is a online server issue. But if you can enjoy this game on your own, just play single player in the meantime. Trust me, it is worth it. I was only gifted this game yesterday and I am addicted. It's definitely a thumbs up for me, disconnecting servers isn't enough for me to leave a negative review on this game. I have an AMD R9280X and I'm still able to enjoy the beautiful graphics!UPDATE: Be warned once you hit HR this game likes to troll you. However, it is still fun until you get randomly dropped off right next to Odogaron or in a swarm of Girros'. GRRRRR! Still love this game though.PROS: - Runs better than PS4 MHW (DUH)- Visually stunning (Considering I have poor GPU)- Large monsters are ACTUALLY challenging (Definitely a pro, as easy quest games are boring)- Endless amount of gameplay and content- Fun times with friends- Cute customisations - Easy controller use (I use a PS3 controller)CONS:- The Handler - Not being able to connect online (very rarely happens)- Random location drops (Only happened at the start of High Rank)- Not being able to skip cut scenes. Well, maybe that bit is okay but not being able to queue in Quests w/ friends until you've all watched the cutscene seperately. (Really disturbs the MHW grind)PC SPEC: - CPU: i7-4790 (3.60GHZ)- GPU: AMD R9 280x- 16GB RAM

author: Probably Bradley
review: Feels very casual consumer when compared to the handheld titles however it still keeps all the charm and content from the handheld titles (content is just coming in at a slower rate for obvious reasons)If you're standoff'ish because you played handheld and this doesn't seem like the same game you're robbing yourself of an incredible Monster Hunter game, you should just jump right in. The Iceborne DLC may seem pricey but it's worth your zenny don't worry.Super excited to see how for Monster Hunter can go in this format.11/10 game 100% Biased review.

author: FAT CONTROLLER
review: Monster Hunter: World has very quickly joined the very small list of games that could be considered to be the greatest games of the generation - and even the decade. With Iceborne already having proved to be a smash hit on consoles earlier this year, this game will be talked about for many, many years to come.10/10

author: Dr.Yeet

author: Velesianus
review: No thanks. The worst optimized port I've ever seen in decades of gaming. My gpu justs sits there idle while my cpu starts break dancing as soon as it has to load a splash screen. I love capcom and MH but man this feels like they downloaded an emulator from github and bolted the game to it.UPDATE: well they fixed most of the major issues and it really is a fantastic game so I guess it's time to flip the thumb around. I'll still be holding off on IB for a month or two after it launches given my experience with the launch of the core game.

author: Crim
review: Review Update 11/4The majority of the issues I had with the game have been fixed. No more connection issues, no from fps drops against certain monsters, raw mouse input has been added to the game, keyboard customization has been expandeed upon. Some of my other previous complaints can be addressed with modding. The only remaining thing that bugs me is not having DoF options and off course the UI still remains control centric. However, this is now a great game worth playing.-------------------------------------------------------------Review Update 8/26:A patch addressing the network connection issues was rolled out. This has greatly improved network stability, I have not disconnected except once since the patch was rolled out in the 30+ hours I've played since. However, I have noticed that I now fail to create online sessions (lobbies) every now and then. Not a big deal as usually trying to create a session one or two more time gets it through. I am not changing my review to reccomended, yet. There are other significant performance issues with the game and after 140+ hours and testing across two machines, the game needs an optimization patch. Certain areas of the rotten vale causes significant fps drop anywhere from 20 to 40 at its worst. Two late stage monsters have attacks that can cause significant drops as well and these two happen to be monsters you will be farming quite a bit of in the end game. Once in a while the game will also hang almost as if it froze for 1-2 seconds and in the middle of a fight this can be disasterous. From my experience, this is not common and has only been happening to me the last 3 days. There have been no changes made to my machines, drivers and so on. What needs to fixed:-FPS drops on certain maps-FPS drops against two specific monsters (that I've noticed so far) -Random stuttering -Need raw mouse input -Options to disable/enable motion blur and DoFWanted improvements but not deal breaking: -Better menus for keyboard and mouse -Ability to skip cutscenes -Being able to save your SoS/matchmaking filter preferences PC specs this was tested on (tested on both nvidia drivers 398.36 and 398.82):AMD:Ryzen 2600X @ 4.2GhzTeam Group 16GB 3000Mhz RAMGigabyte GTX 1080 MSI X470 GPLUSCorsair SF 600Intel:i5-6600K @ 4.4Ghz TridentZ 16GB 3000Mhz RAMGigabyte GTX 1080ASUS Z-170A Corsair HX 750 ----------------------------------------------Let me start by saying I absolutely adore this game. I put in 200 hours on the PS4 since it launched on that and stopped playing it in anticipation of the PC port. Unfortunately, while the game is fantastic, these rampant technical problems are a deal breaker. I'm still playing through bregrudingly in hopes that it will be fixed sooner than later. The frequent disconnects is absolutely maddening and there is no real excuse because no smart attempt was made to make sure this doesn't happen AGAIN. This happened on console but not nearly to the extent it is happening on PC. Why was there no public beta of the game like on console? This problem would have been discovered immediately and the launch reception wouldn't be "mixed". From another technical perspective, while I appreciate the ability to rebind everything, the amateur hour shows when it comes to the development team's familiarty with PC. The menus have not been changed for ease of navigation with a mouse and keyboard, there is no tool tips when you hover over something with your cursor. Inventory management with a mouse is not intuitive. Emulating a joystick with a mouse instead of giving us raw input is a mind boggling decision that anyone that has used a mouse before would not make. Not being able to turn off motion blur is another huge turn off. The game tries to overload the processor with 32 threads and most people are running 4 core and 4 threads, even those of us with 6 or 8 core processors and 12/16 threads don't cope with it well. I get a stable 60fps 95% of the time but that's only because I'm brute forcing my way through the performance issue with overkill hardware. Would I reccomend the game? If you already like monster hunter, absolutely, it might be worth coping with the issues as they are until it is resolved. If you are unsure about the game or you are unfamiliar with the series, for goodness sake do yourself a favor and skip it until it's fixed.

author: Calvin9360
review: if you  are like me and have all of your apps and games on 1 percent because your heaset will earrape you if you don't, please consider the following:Prior to startup, please put your headset on the table and wait untill game is loaded, then open your volume mixer and put your game (in this case monster hunter world) to the volume you wish it to be. Then put on the headset again and check of the volume is better.Now for the REAL ADVICEOfcourse this game is playable with a keyboard, but i strongly suggest you get a controller for this game. The radial menu has a circle with 8 options, without a controller you will be able to reach 4 of those. But don't worry for the most usefull items are within reach by holding Q and switching with your left and right mousebutton.

author: 👽🐬 Old Black Nerd🐬👽
review: Works like a charm. Devs on top of issues. Going to play more now that my cousin's babies are gone (babies come before monster hunting!)Edit: Had more time to play, and as I predicted in a thread before the game came out, incels are whining that they only get 59 fps on their ULTRA MEGA GTX10091686869 GRAPHICS CARD OF DOOM or other ""PC gamer" ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.My specs are PC Windows 8.1 64bitIntel Core i7-4870HQ CPU @ 2.50 GhZ24gb ramNVIDIA GeForce GTX 980M1920x1080And this laptop is maybe almost 4 years old now and I run the game on high with smooth FPS. I don't have a FPS counter or whatever, but it doesn't stutter or hitch at all. It's smooth.SO, if you want a review from someone who is normal and isn't "PC MASTER RACE" type of person, then this is a fun buy and you will enjoy it.Also I had streaming on in the background and it still ran smooth so.... yeah. I don't know what else to say about the negative reviews except they're alarmist, from the most finicky of incel PC obsessionists in the toxic PC gaming community.

author: Paradox
review: Lets go ahead and get this out of the way now. Are the connection drops Annoying? Yes Yes they are.Does it break the game? No. No it does not.Yes the game is very fun to play multiplayer, and it has advantages and a little disadvantage , but the most fun comes from a well diversed group . The problem , with any luck, will be fixed in time I am sure. That being said, the game looks and feels amazing. Playing it on the PS4 as long as I have, the Load times on the PC are MUCH better.  In the PS4 variation you could get up while your group was waiting for the pre level loading, and go make yourself a hot cup of tea and sit down just as the game finally finished loading and spit you all out on the map.  Here on the PC? Oh yeah, sooo much better!The game has a few challenging points... but trust me, once you start getting into the groove of things, the game still keeps that challenge but its fun , and when you start getting further into the game it gets incredibly satisfying when you win a mission.Edit: The Monkey Is Coming. Fear. And. Respect.The. Monkey.

author: JimmieRamone
review: I've played about 20x as long on PS4. Switching to PC for better frame rate and to play with more friends. Anyway, I can't say enough good things about this game. Easy to pick up; difficult to master (I don't consider myself one yet) and ridiculously fun once you find the weapon(s) that fits you. Low Rank hunts are pretty barren on Steam, I've come to realize, but that's negated somewhat by the new Defender gear designed to bring newcomers up to speed for Iceborne. Just understand and prepare yourself for the real MonHun experience, which requires you to hunt the same monster multiple times to craft weapons and armor.

author: yami_san
review: Performance issues on win 7, but amazing game nonetheless. I'll update the review after finishing the campaign or after patches.-Windows 10 removed perfomance issues ingame. Stable 40-60 fps. Not sure about intro sequence or cutscenes. Pretty sure it's because of 388 nvidia driver, try it! Later patches improved performance.- You CAN play all the story missions in co-op with friends. Sure, they have to watch the intro cutscenes for them first, but they can abandon the quest itself afterwards and join you. But you gotta have friends, that's a big issue for me.- Low Rank quests are really easy for me. I got carted like 2 or 3 times total. And I'm using a new unfamiliar weapon class every day. But difficulty picks up a bit in High Rank and tempered post game monsters pose a reall challenge. That's cool!- Networks has been stable after patches.-People don't seem to communicate a lot.  Voice chat volume EXTREMELY low for some people.

author: Smoky Levante
review: this i a great game performance wise it runs smoothly and looks great (atleast on my rig)its not very beginner friendly requiring alot of trial and error to figure things out the first few times you go on a hunt this is also an amazing timesink with friends as hunts can go up to 1 hour but generally never takes longer than 30 mins monsters difficulty scales if there are more people such as more agressive behaviour and a larger health pool best thing is how capcom handled the delivery having high res textures as an optional pretty mutch almost halves the size of the game a godsend for people with capped internet or little harddrive space without music the hunts feel dead so before you turn it off in favour of your own give it a listen and the pallicos are just the damn  cutest thing ive ever seen a must have mod is bazel goes ree (thank me later)

author: Amos
review: All I've expected and more. So much more.You will struggle. You will die. You will try again and again. You will succeed. And most importantly you will enjoy the thrill of the hunt.Monster hunting has never been better. Okay there are less monsters than in Generations, but semi-open world will embrace, swallow and spit you out. And you will beg to go back.There will be close calls, almost wins and many, many deaths. Both yours and your enemies'. They get killed, captured and put in circus. Perhaps not the last one. To add insult to injury, you will carve your enemies up, make weapons and armor from their body parts, beat their family with it and feel good about it.That's he loop. Have fun and git good.Cheers

author: Space Rat
review: I remember being a young kid and grabbing monster hunter for ps2 from EB Games. I was so bad at it but something about it made me love it. I have played every monster hunter since then and I must say this game is amazing. I understand that there are some things some veteran players may dislike but as for me I think it's the most accessible and fun Monster Hunter to date. I hope they continue this "open world" theme in future titles.

author: Rubyko
review: Unskippable cutscenes and the way the SOS system works in main quests make the co-op experience a bit obtuse at times but asides from that this game panders to me in every way. Extremely fun combat, cool setting, great monsters, beating said monsters feels really rewarding and the game looks super pretty to boot. A lot of the sections and animations in this game are packed to the brim with personality and you can tell this game was made with a lot of passion behind it. Worth every cent.

author: RemyBucks
review: Having never played another monster hunter game I was originally skeptical if I would like the game or not, I watched certain streamers play it like maximilliandood and thought it looked pretty cool. After playing it for almost 100 hours I can say it earns its place as one of my top played games, it has so many iceberg like levels of depth and enjoyment to be had for casual or hardcore players, the replay-ability is insane and attributes to the time sink people have credited it as. it goes on sale pretty regularly so if you like rpgs or action games chances are you'll like this. its got something for everyone.

author: GoldFox
review: Very good game. No bugs so far, the only real problem is disconnection from online mode from time to time, wich is can be easily fixed.

author: NordmaN
review: Untill Capcom fixes the handshaking between Steam and there own servers i can NOT recommend this game if you want to enjoy a smooth co-op experience with friends.However, if you are a lonewolf kinda human it wont bother you one bit, the game can be played and everything can be done solo. The mouse acceleration or smoothening is a bit of a let down on PC when "raw" is the best way to go. Using a gamepad is a much more enjoyable experience IMO. You need a beast PC if you want to crank up the settings, don't even try to run many background tasks that utilize the CPU because of Denuvo DRM. Textures in cutscenes look like something from a few years ago even on best setting. During gameplay the world and graphics do look good, but it feel it could be better considering the kinda small zones you get to play in, it is 2018 afterall. I run this game on a 1080Ti paired with a very overclocked 5930k and 32gb of RAM.The game is hard to recommend because of all its obvious flaws, but when it works it is a very fun experience. Kinda wish steam had a option for "maybe" and not only "yes and no". at the moment i have to go with a no.

author: F-Holes
review: -Extremely deep weapon gameplay - each weapons plays like an entirely new experience.-Very well designed Monsters, each one feels unique with it's own personality.-Runs very smoothly after a few graphic tweaks.-Fun online hunting component.-Epic open landscapes to explore, each very unique and well designed.-So much depth in crafting/forging/cultivating/cooking, seems a little overwhelming at first.-Lots of hidden features, secrets & nuances in all aspects of the game.-Very satisfying gameplay loop of killing Monsters, which can take anywhere up to an hour, then using the materials to better yourself and hunt bigger Monsters.Very highly recommended.

author: Max
review: From personal bias I would tell everyone looking for game recommendations to play the Monster Hunter series, but to be fully honest previous entries weren't for everyone. They've had a historically high learning curve and a couple of clunky mechanics to get used to. This game is the exception.Monster Hunter: World is a refreshing, new take on Monster Hunter that stays true to the many things that make the it rewarding and fun, all the while making it more accessible to new players. It's a truly immersive game world, and while I will always go back to the handheld titles for their unique qualities, this game will remain a great entry point for any new player. The coming "Iceborne" expansion will be more significant than any expansion to a game that you are used to, and the equivalent for previous titles has constituted a whole re-release of the game. This game as it is feels as complete as any G game in the Monster Hunter series, and will be immense once the expansion comes out.  Be excited, buy now, and be ready for fall, when the real game begins.

The real thing you're gonna have to deal with is trying to connect with someone else but to be honest I haven't been troubled by the servers (guess I'm just lucky lol). Game never seems to get old and always puts a smile on my face when discovering something new.
