author: Saph
review: Held off on writing a review until I finished the story.First and foremost, there is something you should be aware of before purchasing:-The cutscene after the final story monster can allegedly corrupt your save. Simply back up your save beforehand to avoid losing progress. It's under C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\userdata[YOUR STEAM ID HERE]\582010\remoteNow then, onto the port. The game has run beautifully from start to finish on my little old 960 with a mix of medium to high settings. A solid 60fps ensured that every hunt felt incredible, from flow to mechanics to just enjoying the stunning environments as I bashed Azure Rathalos' stupid noggin in.Make sure to check your specs on the store page. If you aren't up to snuff then it's not a great idea to buy the game.As for the game itself, well.Monster Huter World is the most recent addition to the franchise, it boasts much higher graphical fidelity, greater quality of life features and most importantly, no zone transitions between areas.I went in blind on day 1 and immediately got hooked, taking out low rank relatively quickly and having a blast while doing so. From Jagras to Magdaros, every fight felt unique and challenging in their own ways. The monsters themselves feel much more responsive than previous games and some are pretty challenging if you haven't done your homework on them.As for gear, the team did a fantastic job of re-imagining the move sets for weapons. Adding in new combos and mechanics that make them all feel organic to the combat as a whole. I started with the trusty Insect Glaive which boasts a new aerial dodge, new attack animations for the ground and air combos as well as a new elemental/status/healing bug swarm for the Kinsect to summon. Once hit, the cloud of bugs will apply whatever damage, element or effect your Kinsect is alligned to and they can make for some great combo extenders and openers.About halfway into High Rank I switched back to my MH3U main, the Greatsword. Oh boy, the new greatsword... They added a shoulder tackle that you can use to cancel out of your charged swing or out of a roll as a quicker way to reach the new finisher that does some pretty big boy damage and feels incredible to land. The addition of aerial combat as introduced by 4 has been expanded upon too, when you jump off a ledge there's a brief window where you can hop in any direction when you begin the aerial swing which can be used to combo even the hardiest monsters into submission. Plus you can now charge your aerial swing which allows for greater damage and a higher chance of mounting the monster.There are a number of new mobility mechanics that make the game flow so much smoother than older iterations, my favourite being the slide. When you sprint or roll on a slope your character will slide down at incredible speeds. You can even use new slide attacks out of it and some can even be charged or have a follow-up move.There's also a grappling hook that makes climbing feel much faster as well as its utility in the newest addition to your hunter arsenal, the Slinger. This little wrist mounted crossbow type weapon can be used with any weapon type and has a ton of ammo types and the ability to grapple onto special grapple points in order to swing around some areas for quicker movement and a nice evasive/offensive option in fights.The slinger boasts a ton of ammo types, including things like throwing knives and various pods used in previous games. There are a number of other types that can be found in the environments including ones like: -Brightmoss, which glows and sticks to whatever it hits, useful for pointing out monster weak points to inexperienced members or just for lighting up dark areas.-Stone, becuse who doesn't love flinging rocks at monsters? Useful for drawing agro and knocking down certain flora which includes some other ammo types.-Scatternut, does a lot of stagger damage and can be useful for extending your friends' combos as they go to town.-Slinger Thorn, sticks to the target and can be hit to deal additional damage. Useful for monster parts that bounce some weapon types and for breaking parts in general.-Watermoss, deals a small amount of water damage and can be used to wash certain dirty monsters for easier damage. There are many more types all with unique effects and utility, making the Slinger an incredibly useful tool for hunting and exploring. Some more fantastical than others, but they all have their uses.Now for quality of life.The first thing I checked was item sets, these are useful for hunters that like to save time at the item box between hunts. Although for another point, camps also have item boxes now. You can enter your tent to change gear and access the item box mid hunt. To make them even more useful you can now eat at camp, meaning if you forget to get your pre-hunt grub on you don't have to worry about being at a disadvantage any more. Oh, and you can fast travel to your camps from anywhere on the map.Moving on, there's the item wheel. This handy little guy lets you quickly use specific items on the fly without cycling through your entire inventory. I would be remiss if I didn't mention that this feature is a massive help to the Sword and Shield as it is the only weapon that lets you use items without sheathing it first. It also let's you use the slinger while it's drawn which is great for setting up combos.I also want to talk about how decorations and charms work now. Instead of the traditional points system, abilities now use levels. Say you have a Fire Res decoration, it'll just give you a level in the Fire Res skill when slotted instead of just 2/5 points needed for the first tier of the skill in previous games. Decorations also come in three sizes and as such, so do decoration slots themselves. Meaning the bigger the decoration, the more levels it will provide in the skill it gives.Charms are more or less the same deal, they give specific abilities just like decorations but now they can be upgraded depending on the type. These additions really streamline the skill system and make for a much easier time going for a build you want to use. Armour also functions in the same way, but now there are set bonuses on some sets. Unlike other games though, most don't require you to wear a full set, but rather just 2-5 pieces of the set. This allows for much more freedom without making it feel like a chore to go for specific setups.The verdict, All in all, I'm really enjoying my time with MHW. Connection issues aside it's a fantastic port of a fantastic game with a lot of heart. Couple that with Capcom releasing existing console events and DLC quests for free at a faster rate and you've got a pretty good deal in my book.I will say though that I do have a couple of minor peeves with the game. The first is that the faces look pretty bad up close and the second is the lack of unique weapon designs. Both very minor things, but they do detract a bit from my personal experience.I can't recommend the game enough to anyone looking for a fun hunting sim/ARPG hybrid. There's plenty to do in the game which makes it a great time sink too. Just make sure you can run it before purchase and all should be well.We even just got a patch to address the connectivity issues that were present at launch within the month of release, that's what I'd call consumer friendly.TL;DROnline can be pretty bad at times currently with disconnections from Steam, but the game itself is incredible and completely playable solo. It's well worth a buy in my book and I'm dying for more content already.If you like to hunt, or play good ARPGs, get it.

author: Frenchyz
review: Highly recommend this game.  It has a high ceiling for skills and it is blast to play with friends.

author: Taeysa
review: 866 hours in, probably many more to come. I've been with this game since its PC release, and never left. This isn't going to be up for debate when it comes to MHW, or Rise. I don't care what you prefer, it's your preference for a reason.That being said, let's get into it.(For the sakes of story progression, I am practically only giving the opening cutscene's worth of knowledge, as to save spoilers, because nobody likes those!)Monster Hunter: World drops you into the boots of your Hunter, an obvious, monster hunter. Aeyy get it?Your job, once arriving in the newest uncharted part of the world, is to seek out, slay monsters, and document the various types of endemic life in the area, all the while attempting to stop an encroaching geological catastrophe. This game is hard, and this game is unforgiving, but some people like myself appreciate, and enjoy a challenge.If you find that you are someone who really enjoys a specific sort of game where you grind for your progression, this game is a game that will captivate your attention for a long time coming. The graphics are beautiful, the soundtrack is incredible, and I've made many good friends over the years out of a shared interest in this hobby. The playerbase has slightly declined over the years, as it came out in 2018, but it is still actively thriving. You can always open up a server browser and look for active sessions, so finding people to play with isn't difficult. It DOES however, follow the Dark Souls law of the land, where if you are doing a main story mission, you can not have other players join you via the lobby system, or the SOS flare system, until you have finished watching all cutscenes pertaining to that specific fight, event, or assignment. (But this isn't a problem, and you will quickly come to learn how every single fight goes.)Thanks for reading! If you have any questions, leave'em below! If not, have a good one!

author: Misanthr0py
review: + No loading screens during hunts.+ Specialized tools.+ Ecosystem feels alive. Monsters interact with each other.+ Weapons have new moves. I used to hate Lance. Not anymore.- Connection issues. A lot of disconnects. This is especially frustrating during a hunt since the multiplayer buffed monster does not revert back to it's weaker singleplayer one, making killing it so much slower alone.- Optimization could have been done better. With i7-8700k, 1060 6gb and 16gb of RAM, I had to lower my graphical settings to mid-low to alleviate the micro freezes/stutters. These freezes caused desync in multiplayer and made the monster teleport soon after to catch up. In singleplayer I got audio desyncs during cutscenes.I've enjoyed previous MH installments and I do not regret spending 60€ on this one but I feel like if you haven't played MH before, you probably should wait for a sale, or a fix to some of the problems we are having right now.

author: GrimoireWeiss
review: First Monster Hunter game I played. Maps are cool and their size is decent but you will have to revisit them often if you want to dive deeper into the game. That means they can get boring after few hundreds of hours or less even if they look nice and have a lot of detail. This game clearly has some grind because you will be hunting same monsters multiple times but there is large amount of them and you have different species. If you upgrade your gear and improve you strategy then you become a more efficient hunter.Then you have big amount of cool weapons to use. Large amount of cool armor sets that give you different stats. I am a cat lover who owns a cat so having a cat companion in the game was hype for me. There are fun crossover missions like Resident Evil, Devil May Cry, Final Fantasy or The Witcher. The Witcher has 1-2 hours long story mission fully voiced by original Gerald VA. Other missions are more like special scenarios that unlock special skins. Try to google Monster Hunter DMC Charge Sword. It looks awesome.Today it's not a expensive game and it will provide you with a long and fun adventure. You will spend good amount of time playing it but once you finish the main story then it's time for your love to the game to shine. If you continue doing stuff you will unlock new monsters but that requires time and dedication. After you complete the story there are still many monsters to battle and stuff to upgrade. That means you have to ask if you like this kind of stuff and want to continue. Even me after 300 hours I still have few monsters I haven't batlled yet and I heard they are not easy. Good game and worth your time if you like this stuff. For such small price you will get a lot of content.

(God bless america) Patch or two later, the server problem is not AS bad. Admittedly it's still there from time to time.But more often than not, it works just fine.Another patch in and I can turn off the god awful blur without the use of a mod.Which FYI Anti-Aliasing is also a pain to the eye so shut that off if you want it to look a little better.Now it's an optimal game.But let's get into pros and cons.

author: T.K.
review: Monster Hunter: World is, without any hyperbole, my Favorite MH game to date. Bearing in mind, I had only every briefly played a small snippted of 4U (the demo) and I have put over 200 Hours into Generations, and I have also put 300 hours into World already on Xbox One, and if a game is strong enough for me to buy it twice then I feel like that is saying something.The gameplay is fantastic, weapons all feel strong and unique and I definitely struggle when picking one to main, all of the combo improvements and flow changes give weapons many might have considered "clunky" or "slow" a lot of new life and make everything feel amazing and fun. The monsters, even familiar and returning ones, feature interesting attack patterns and are genuinely fun to fight against (once you start getting past monsters like Kulu Ya-Ku and start fighting things like Anjanath and Rathian, thats when the game really starts feeling good.) Level design is also great, with the maps flowing really nicely with shortcuts and hidden pathways, and navigating them and searching them is super rewarding because more often than not you'll find a hidden campsite, or an upgrade for your Cat Companion, or good places to gather materials and supplies! With all of these positives, I do want to get some of my personal gripes out of the way, and the overall negatives attached to this game, so I'll list them off in bullet points: - A lack of weapon design variety. While I like the idea that we start with base weapons and upgrade them into unique ones, more often than not a weapon tree will only have 5 or 6 unique weapons models while most are just the base Ore/Bone weapons with animal skins lazily stapled on.  - A lack of Monster Variety.  There are only TWO lightning monsters. TWO ice monsters. And worst of all -- ONE SINGLE WATER MONSTER. A surprise when you consider the game features nearly FIVE MONSTERS THAT ARE WEAK TO WATER. It seems very imbalanced and it also just makes the lack of weapon variety more apparent when there's only a handful of variants. - The Story. Most MH games don't even feature a story outside of text-boxes, and honestly I feel like it should have stayed that way. The story is incredibly weak, full of hokey and pointless dialogue about "aether currents" and "energy" and all of this other nonsense. It's a very weak narritive to string together the excuse that you're killing creatures on a new continent.  - A lack of maps. This could potentially be solved with the addition of new creatures but there isn't a Tundra specific region, nor is there a dedicated water area, you fight the single solitary water monster in the desert. - PC Specific issues. Textures are just bad, and its easy to miss that on PS4/Xbox but oh my god are they terrible on PC. Pixelated, smudgy, even at max some textures just look rough and unpolished. Fixed with potential patches or fan mods, but we'll have to wait and see. Servers are also very flakey, though they tended to be on consoles as well, the problem is even worse here. Dropping out mid quest happens frequently, quests can severely lag mid hunt, and there's constant connection issues and errors, as well as a weird bug where if you disconnect from a lobby you can't reconnect? forcing friends to essentially rotate hosting lobbies. - PC control issues. Weirdly there's a mouse smoothing thing I noticed when attempting to play with mouse and keyboard. The controls themselves are fine, especially since its rebindable, but there's an acceleration put on the mouse to make it move in-game to that of a thumbstick which i found really weird feeling, and I wasn't able to find a way to disable it, so for the most part just stick to controller if you can. -----------------------------Conclusion-----------------------------This game is incredible, and despite it's minor issues I can still completely recommend it to anyone who's thinking about purchasing it. It is 100% worth it, and it is even better to play through with friends!

author: Attaris
review: [Mandatory English not the first language disclaimer]edit: single mod was used - SpacialKRight of the bat - I enjoyed the game. Problem is that after 170 hours of play time game decided that it had enough of me and corrupted my save files. No warning signs, no nothing. Tried multiple suggested fixes but of course nothing worked. So, naturally, I contacted capcom support. After initial back and forth waited over a month for the reply for my last email (I guess some folks are slower than others). After even more back and forth I'm happy to report that so far I've got 6 template responses that's translates more or less to "woops, sh*t outta luck,son". The lovely lady at capcom support even remarked that doesn't matter how many times I write their official stance is to throw arms up in the air and leave the customers to fend for themselves. I guess, capcom values compliance more than persistence.So here we are - 30 euros (thank God, I didn't buy it on launch) and 170 hours down the drain. As for game itself, it was fun while it lasted. PC port is mediocre at best but than again most of these japanese ports are. Definitely recommend getting SpecialK mod because more likely than not the game will run horribly without it.Oh, and for the love of God, back up your saves manually after each play session. Steam cloud will not help because they don't keep previous versions of your save files and as soon as you close your game corrupted data will be uploaded. So make your due diligence because capcom didn't make theirs.With the Iceborne dropping in January (console release already launched, mind you) this might be even more relevant because I'm sure the base game will be discounted at some point before Iceborne PC launch.Lastly, I want to say I've never ran into this issue in my 20+ years of PC gaming. Maybe it was luck. Than again, I never have played capcom games up to now...Oh, and capcom name not being in capitals is on purpose too. I don't feel that company that is completely fine with shipping a product with such inherent flaws AND refusing any kind of support deserves to be in capitals, do you?

author: IhazHedont
review: I think this game has been the first in a while that made me played it so much.I have seen many posts and reviews about performances issues; I do not have the most recent rig (i7 4790K and a 2070 SUPER), on a 1440P screens, and have no issues whatsoever. Man this game is for you.

author: ⎛⎛Lord Sithaniel⎞⎞
review: I had an awful starting experience and played it during launch. I held back with writing a review because i tought they gonna patch these issues. But well they sure took their time! And they patched many of them just to introduce new bugs or reintroduce old ones.Monster Hunter got a solid gameplay foundation that exceeds as a multiplayer coop game. Its fun to slowly get better gear by killing weaker and then stronger monsters.Combat is incredible challenging and rewarding in the long run. There are lots of things to do and most of them are really fun because the game is definetly unique in its own way. Weapon variety is really good...until you play a couple of them. Some have barely any combos while others got a couple, but being it a game that has only a handful of maps and not many enemies to beat the amount of combos you can make is really really low. There are many different armors and weapon upgrades on the other hand but i rather would have prefered less weapons and a better focus on the balancing and combos as some upgrades are often more op in every situation. Also i dont seem any reason that some upgrades require very special parts which make you farm the same monster over and over again and you still dont get that part. Its less in this game, luckily you dont need rathalos plates for every crappy equipment anymore, but its still there to some extent. I dont mind if its a bit grindy, but atleast only if you know what you are grinding for. The game should tell you from the beginning which item has a % drop rate or even better by completely removing low drop rate items and instead give more items the bigger the monster was.The games difficulty spikes very hard. At one point you are breezing trough the game but keep failing at 1 specific monster until again you win easily. The last bossfight as an example is one of the more easier monster for some reason. Too many of the enemies have stunlocks or 1 shot attacks which punish mistakes harshly.This might be fine at a game where you can quickly try again but in monster hunter it takes a longer process to quit and start another quest. Everything is unnecessarily slow in this game. There is also no aggro system or in any way its predicable who the monster will attack. Im currently healing in some far away corner while my friend with a two handed sword is completely depleting its life bar. So suddenly the monster decides to turn a 180 and jump dozens of meters at me. This is problematic because some monsters have undodgeable/blockable abillties that are can only be known/dodged if you know its complete moveset by heart.At last there is something i personally found an issue with that is rarely mentioned. For a game that features collecting things and building it into armors or weapons the whole inventory system and ui isnt made out to sort the items successfully. This isnt a problem if you just rush trough the main story and keep using the same weapon but rather in lategame when you need to switch between fire to ice armor and so on. Making the player do their own costumized inventory tabs would have solved this issue or introducing a better sorting system. Even the best part is pretty much riddled with tons of issues. First it starts off being a coop game. Then the devs had the great idea to lock the coop in the main missions until everyone met the monster. Which makes no sense whatsover since you can just quit, restart the level after seeing the monster and then everyone can play together. So as a coop game it fails but when it works, it is indeed really fun. There is also a common connectivity issue that just kicks out all or or one player. People cant rejoin you after that and if you are fighting a monster with your friends for 30 minutes and one gets kicked out is an experience i dont want others to have. There is only a handful of maps. Those arent really as big as you might think they would but finally they fixed the levels by not making them into sub levels connected with entry/exit points but rather a proper level that connects smaller fighting arenas in a setting with liniar pathlines. Im not really a huge fan of these pathlines as they serve usually no porpuse than wasting your time with walking. I wished the arena system would have been scrapped . Otherwise the maps itself look really greatly designed and each arena is completely different and easily recognizeable.While the whole environment looks fantastic human characters as an example look really silly and cartoonish because of their bad facial gestures. On a technical level the framerate is complete garbage and even newest hardware has problems. The monsters really look great on the other hand. Their animations are well done for the most part but thats about it. Often the camera is blocked by the environment because some spots are too narrow fighting big monsters. Also lots of monsters are just bigger reskins of older ones. Thats okay for introducing a stronger variant of the older ones but the amount of monsters and maps for a full price game is just lacking.Soundtrack is very ambient but i rather prefered something funky or rock/metalesque while fighting monsters. I mostly use my own music and muted the ingame music very soon. The soundeffects of the monsters feel good as they have a good impact and especially if you use your weapons as they make lots of good special soundeffects that feel fullfilling.Completely crap. They shouldnt have invested so much money into the animations of some boring talking cinematics and instead did more to fix the issues with this game and add more content because it severly lacks. And if you say that the game has hundreds of hours of playtime to get everything. Yeah it does. But if would cut out all the walking sequences, cutscenes and reduce the life of the bosses you probably wont even have a 10 hour game.Back to the main story its a complete boring mess. I skipped all of the textboxes and only watched cutscenes and i still understood as much as my buddy did who read everything.Monster hunter world suffers from a lot of different issues, be it technical or gameplay wise. Having some weapon balance issues can be overlooked but getting kicked out of the session because of some connection errors on capcoms site can make the game really tun sour quickly. It doesnt help how they designed the coop nature in the main story campaign and how the story itself is rather boring. But monster hunter exceeds in challenging and a rewarding combat system, while not completely perfect, it is really fun. But i solely dont recommend the game because of the many technical issues the game has.6/10 Above average

author: Otreksheyesya
review: Rant:Time of writing I have spent 329.4 hours on this game.I came here because I saw that some idiots are bombing the hell out of this game over a movie that no one is going to take seriously and  most likely will not watch. But instead of ignoring the movie on release date, they instead chose to damage a good games reputation simply because its 2020 and every one has to find something to ♥♥♥♥♥ and complain about.Actual game review:Great game, 14 weapons each with INSANE amount of variety for each one (Different monsters apply different effects towards each weapon in terms of stats, bonus effects and looks.)Crazy amount of Armour that can be used to mix and match in order to find a good game style for your weapon/overall style.Monster count is MASSIVE. The only way to get bored if you spam one monster over and over again because they refuse to drop that one item you need to finish your specific item in order to move on with your game and not spend hours and hours on grinding because the monster is a stingy piece of existing moving fecal matter.The grind can get boring a little if you just spam the same monster. But the game is 100% worth a try because it can turn to a 1v1 with you and a monster. to a 4v3 with randoms/friends against 3 monsters who hate each other and hate type of fuster cluck. At first it can be a little bit hard in terms of figuring out what weapons but the end result is satisfying once the weapon is found.Weapon Tips:Great sword: Massive Damage, Low mobility when in hands, can use block and kick.Sword and shield: Low damage (when compared to the other weapons) great attack speed, great mobility, Can block.Dual blades: Low damage, Great movement, high critical hits, 2 forms of attack.Long Sword: Decent movement and attack speed, Can punish monster hits when timed correctly, great range (can hit other hunters)Hammer: Slow and heavy damage like the Great sword, Can be charged up to attack harder, Can be used to stun or break monster parts.Hunting horn: Lower damage then the hammer, Can buff allies and self.Lance: Great range, decent damage, 3 attack in each combo. Can charge towards a monster to increase damage output, can block.Gunlance: Decent damage, can block, can use ammo in a limited range in order to provide point blank shots.Switch axe: Decent damage, decent speed, amazing elemental damage, can latch on to a monster and blow the weapon up in them, changes modes from axe to sword and back.Charge blade: Sword and shield with greater damage, slower attacks, can self buff both sword and shield components and combine to get an axe, sacrifising mobility for even greater damage.Insect glaive: Fast, great range, Self and party buff (I think), areal combos, insect companion to shoot monster with.Bow: Fast damage, great range, Can be used to debuff monster.Light bowgun: Fast movement, fast damage, can be modified in order to add bonus unique twists, Can plant mines on the ground or plant mines into monster.heavy bowgun: Slow movement, Massive damage, can be modified in order to add bonus unique twists, Can either go full minigun or a powerful sniper shot.I hope this helps someone and if I messed up with some weapon information I am sorry. Feel free to correct me in the comments (If you so wish) Otherwise Please do not let the negative reviews hurt this game because some people want to complain about a movie that was never meant to be taken seriously.

author: Rajangles
review: Monster Hunter: World is honestly one of the best games, on release it had its problems (majority of them are fixed) and you still get the pesky errors (less frequent now) but those aside it's a great game to sink time into by yourself and with friends. There's a range of weapons to choose from both melee and ranged, heavy and light weapons, Bloodborne style weapons that can morph into other weapons, some support weapons and even a weeb weapon (looking at you long sword). Each weapon has it's playstyle, Hammers bonk the head to Knock Out the monster, Hunting Horn plays songs to buff your hunting squads, Dual Blade attack at a fast pace, Bowguns attack from range using different ammo types... there's a weapon for every person who wants to play this game.Further into the game you unlock better and better gear which in turn allows you to easily create builds to either meta slave (Builds that make fights 10x easier) or augment how your weapon/playstyle works already. Attacking in the air a lot more? Deal an extra 30% damage from Airborne Attacks :D. The Base Game alone is honestly worth it but recently we got an expansion. Iceborne. Wow just wow. The xpac brought along a new game mechanic: The Clutch Claw. This has been a massive, massive boon to certain weapons (Hammer and Lance/Gunlance). The Clutch Claw makes fights extremely fun and faster pace than the base game. Along with the Clutch Claw, Iceborne brought along Master Rank (harder monsters to fight), more monsters to fight, subspecies of monsters and new zones, it improved on the base game tenfold and continues to do so with every update. :)If you can pick this game up for full price to support the devs, they deserve it.If you pick this game up on a sale, it's hella worth!If you have any questions, feel free to comment :DEnjoy the hunts, fellow HuntersSome Basement Dweller :D

author: Verkhinow
review: Was disappointed with the very few and short content at first, the end game credits felt longer than the whole Xeno'Jiiva fight. Now with the release and promise of new content such sa Behemoth, Kulve Taroth (both very enjoyable hunts) and future G-ranked monsters; there's just alot of stuff to do and look forward to.-Game offers alot of weapons to master, all of which i found to be enjoyable.-The progression of making and farming sets is enjoyable and all the more when completed and field-tested.-A must-have for fans of the series.-The hunts at first felt lacking (used to MHFU and Dark Souls), but new end-game contents are quite the step-up. Nonetheless, the fights were fun.-It's pretty and scenic.A must have for fans of the series.

author: minicooper237
review: Great addition to the Monster Hunter series and the first to come to PC. Fans of the series will likely enjoy this one as it keeps to the same formula of hunting monsters to craft better gear to hunt monsters, etc. Newcomers may also enjoy this installment as it has the most quality of life improvements out of all of the games, streamlining gameplay and making it smoother. The downsides to this game are that it's combat can and will feel clunky to those new to the series and the number of monsters to hunt in this one is quite a bit smaller than in previous games.  All in all, I would recomend this game and I hope for the series to continue on PC in the future.

author: Frostilyte
review: Monster Hunter: World is a game I very much enjoyed playing. The depth to the weapons, monsters, and environment create a combat system that is satisfying to master, while tweaking gear load-outs kept me invested well beyond when I would have stopped playing The lack of monster variety in its latter half and terrible story are only minor inconveniences, and I can even look past the silly online implementation because of how well crafted the rest of the game is. However, the issues with the online and performance are absolutely shameful, so I can't recommend Monster Hunter: World to anyone in its current state. With future patches this will be an easy recommendation, but for right now consumers should steer clear.Full review here if you like reading: Note: Intend to update the review to positive once game patches address all issues present in gameUpdate: Updated to positive as the game is now in a state where it isn't a complete disaster performance wise.

author: Şmirgol Şaşlık
review: I waited for this game's PC release impatiently. What was delivered wasn't what I've expected.The main game was extremely short for 60€. After the main game you can start grinding and levelling your Hunter Rank to further upgrade your equipment and fight against the same monsters but with more damage. But the game quickly starts feeling extremely boring afer completing the story. It's not like the story was any good but you got to unlock new areas, monsters and equipment as you progressed which felt very rewarding.Sometimes like randomly when you try to slay an enemy one or sometimes even two large boss enemies will coincidentally pop out and meet up on the same spot. The announcement trailer showed how Anjanath and Rathian fought against each other. My experience is 80% of the time at least one of the two or three enemies will focus on you instead fighing each other even though during that they hit each other with their heavy attacks. Like:"". So to me it is rather a nuisance than a feature. You can use an item that makes one enemy bail out but still an annoying and unnecessary game mechanic since you don't always expect this to happen. I am not sure about this but I also got the feeling that they aren't even damaging each other. Never occured to me that the monster I was hunting died or starting limping after receiving couple of hits from other large monsters.Tried playing Co-Op with friends. Can't really recommend. I don't know how exactly the game scales the difficulty with a party but the monsters became way more tankier and I was better off doing the quests alone. Esspecially because the whole team is allowed to faint at maximum up to three times. Some quests even allow less faints! Also as a closed ranged hunter 50% of the time you need to chase the monster since the AI very often changes its target and runs between them.Speaking of Co-Op. I was trying to help a friend since his savegame got corrupted and he had to start a new game. I wanted to carry him through the beginning quests quickly to where he used to be but technically I couldn't. I always got disconnected due to communication errors.The gameplay is really difficult at the beginning. Most weapons felt clunky to me. I decided to go with the longsword. The game didn't teach much. Looked up tutorial videos on the weapons. After getting used to it a little it was really fun esspecially the counter mechanic and mounting enemies. But there were still things that bothered me:I wished one could have more control over his character. I despise clunky gameplay and stuns and think it is really bad game design. I like to have control over my character and not being locked into slow animations. The only weapon with high speed are the dual swords but they are really situational due to their short range which I didn't like. The game could have been made more difficult in other aspects like more limitations concerning healing resources for example. Having less healing means in exchange for more swiftness and control. That would have been nice.I would recommend this game if at least:Everything else is still bearable.

author: SquareWheel
review: I've had both high and low opinions of MHW over the years.  I've written pages about the steps and missteps of the game in the past, but I'll skip all that here.  What I want to say is that with this final major content update, Capcom have given the game a great sendoff.Fatalis is an excellent boss battle.  It feels like the perfect difficulty, without gimmicks or tricks.  It can be fought solo or in a group.  The custom arena makes for an interesting setting, and the tools are provided to the player to make the quest manageable.  Capcom hit it out of the park with this one.With this update, the much-maligned tenderize mechanic has had its effect duration doubled.  While I think this should have been done sooner in Iceborne's life, they got it right eventually.  The new Shaver jewel also makes tenderizing faster for light weapons, again letting you focus on the combat itself.They rebalanced decoration drop rates, reducing the unrelenting grind.  Essential jewels are now meldable, making certain classes like bow more viable without early luck.Finally, mod support has been re-enabled without requiring workarounds.  This survived a bugfix patch so I'm assuming this was a decision made and not an error.  The game is better with mods so this is a welcome change.My wishlist of game changes is still long, but Capcom have been taking more steps forward than back.  With Iceborne's story complete, I'm now happy to recommend this game.

author: Nixu
review: An online co-op game with the worst online features I have seen. Constant communications errors and joining friends' quests is next to impossible.Update: Now that the communications errors that were present at launch have been fixed, the game can be quite enjoyable in co-op. Some design choices haven't been fixed yet and most like never will be. To play a story quest in co-op each player must first enter the quest alone, watch a cut scene, exit the quest (or wait for other players to get to your location), and finally re-enter with the party. In the long run this might be a minor inconvenience, but still something to be noted.UPDATE 2020:With Iceborn released the game has become unplayable for some people as the newest patch comes with a new anti-cheat system. PCs with slower CPUs might start to experience problems. In addition to the new anti-cheat system, some limited bounties now cannot be completed without purchasing the Iceborne expansion. I would avoid buying __JUST__ MHW as it has been kind of crippled with the release of the Iceborne expansion. People with slower CPUs might want to avoid buying the game or the expansion until the high CPU usage problem due to anti-cheat/DRM has been fixed.UPDATE 2020/12:CPU usage problems have been solved for some time and the game is still fun to play with my friends.  I would recommend this game for players that like the genre. My only major worry as a player is the end-of-service for the servers. The game still has a good number of players playing it daily, so I am hopeful that the online features will be working a year or two more.

author: Potentially Funky
review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for his Birthday from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Warau :)
review: In my opinion, truly, a MASTERPIECE.TL;DR in the end.> Graphics: 8/10> Story: 8/10 > Gameplay: 10/10> Voice Acting: 7/10> HUD/Menu/Interface: 10/10> Weapons/Armor: 10/10--My experience with it (Pros)--  I had so much fun playing MH:W! I have been waiting since the console release for the PC release, and damn I was not disappointed. I didn't check any streams/reviews/spoilers and jumped straight to it at DAY 1. The servers were working only 2/3 of the time, but I played mostly solo in the beginning so I didn't really mind. The first two quests were pretty silly, I didn't pay much attention since they were irrelevant. But then the game starts to progress fast! Around the  mission, my friends hopped in, and damn doing this thing with three semi-geared people is pretty tough! I was so fascinated with all the kinds of armour and weapons the game has to offer! Every time I slayed a new monster, I returned back to the blacksmith to see what kind of new EPIC gear I can make out of it.  That was mostly the hype I already had for it, but even after 50-60 hours, the game was still so attractive.   Everything has a progression which is really interesting! Damn even the stupidest thing, like the Canteen that you eat from can be upgraded! Side quests are interesting and fun to do... most of them! Some are just to gather stuff around the map, others to slay some specific monster, just what sidequests are supposed to be!  Now... I won't lie. If you want to play Monster Hunter, be prepeared. You need to farm the ♥♥♥♥ out of it. You have to kill monsters multiple times in order to create weapons and armors from them, which is pretty reasonable in my opinion. If I had to kill every monster once or twice and be done with it, it'd be pretty damn stupid.   The main story took me around 80-90 hours without trying to rush it.   Would I love for it to have more or even endless monsters to kill? Sure! Looking forward to the DLCs if there are any!--Cons--   I SWEAR TO GOD, THAT ONE B***H THAT IS YOUR "PARTNER" IS THE WORST NPC IN ANY GAME THERE IS. SHE'S DUMB, ANNOYING, USELESS AND UTTERLY IRRITATING. I WAS STUCK IN ONE QUEST AND EVERY TIME I LOST AND RETURNED TO BASE, I HEARD HER ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ VOICE. I HAD TO MUTE THE "VOICE" FROM THE ENTIRE GAME JUST SO I COULD BE SET FREE FROM HER. SHE'S THE DEVIL AND CURSE WHOEVER CREATED HER. F*** THE HANDLER. F*** THAT. IF SOMEONE CLAIMS THAT SHE IS THAT BAD, THE THE WHOLE GAME IS BAD BECAUSE OF HER, I WILL SUPPORT HIM.Since we're done with that, let's move to other, less important cons. Many people are complaining about certain things and I plan on adressing most of them:1. Graphics:  The graphics are not the best, but they sure are solid. This game has GAMEPLAY > GRAPHICS, which in my case didn't bother me at all. Please stop being obsessed with the realistic pristine graphics standard, it some times does not matter.2. The delayed release:  Guys, you knew it was delayed, Capcom said that they did not intend to release the game on PC and didn't want to release a rushed version but also not delay it too much since they are doing it anyway. Leaving a negative review and saying "the game was delayed for 6 months" is absolutely moronic.3. Keyboard/Mounse Issues:  The game is meant to be played with a gamepad (aka xBox controller, ps4 controller etc), just like Dark Souls or Rocket League or so many other pc games... the controls are not simplified just so mouse/keyboard users can have it easy. So if you don't like that, don't buy the game to begin with. You KNEW that a gamepad is recommended, if you ignore that don't come back whining.~TL;DR~The game is amazing if you know what you're about to play. Most bad critics imo are from players who didn't know what they're buying. The game is excellent for what it is. 100% recommended for either solo or co-op.

author: Elle Yeah
review: most immersive and grounded monster hunter world design thus far, but a lot of it falls short as far as what a monster hunter game is. don't get me wrong, the game is genuinely fantastic and some of the best responsive gameplay with a minimum of prior classic monhun clunkiness, but the story is probably one of the worst i've ever experienced in any AAA title ever. especially when juxtaposed against the subtextual story of early monster hunters framing you as the hunter and ultimately defender of a small village that has to gather and sustain themselves. now you are a soldier of a fleet full of top-tier warriors sent to the new world by the guild (i believe they sent the fleets i forgor) to, not do what the guild is allegedly supposed to do, which is prevent invasive species from taking over as well as local populations from becoming overgrown or dangerous in their expanses of territory getting too close to the villages, but instead the guild creates a hit list for legitimately every monster you encounter, none of them invasive until you are tasked to literally kill the monster that prevents the other powerful dragons from overgrowing or invading territory and draining the life of the area. twice. maybe three times? it at least shows you what it does in its environment while also saving you 3 times and for some reason the guild does not realize this is how nature takes care of this issue that the guild believes it needs to take care of, but they decide you need to destroy it just so that... you can do it instead i guess? you genuinely do this for both the original species and its variant that is stronger, for taking down stronger dragons that are a threat. why it was written this way i haven't a clue in hell but i want whatever the ♥♥♥♥ monster hunter's a-team is smoking. this isn't even subtext, this is all stated at the very end of the game at the ending cutscene of iceborne very enthusiastically by everyone's favorite character, your handler, in a scene that you would think would be said with concern about what you've done, and an added, "a-are we the baddies?" quip to tie it all together.basically, the story is either complete ignorance to both real-life history as well as the monster hunter message, or the biggest meta game they've ever made. but i guess that doesn't matter to most because at least the gameplay is good.ending note though, if it wasn't obvious from my prior text wall and as someone that genuinely loves stories in games, i 100% recommend downloaded the "skip cutscenes" mod that allows you to skip all cutscenes save for the ones that would literally crash/break the game if skipped since for some reason the way they built this game, cutscenes are their own strange world map and cannot have anyone but you in them. this online game is not built for that and if you are ever helping a newbie in this game, you have to wait for them to watch the cutscene to be able to aid them and explain how that works. if there are two or more of you starting out fresh, you will all need to watch the cutscenes separately and then everyone but one of you leave the mission and then join the person that didn't leave theirs in order to proceed together.i know this sounds extremely negative, and it definitely is in some regards, but i do honestly recommend this game. like i said, the gameplay is phenomenal, but if you are looking for a good immersive story, you won't find it in here. and as someone that loves the way the older games had lore/story told through avoidable subtext, personal character growth of your own and not the in game character through levels but your skill in knowing how the monster acts and visual storytelling (the most modern and popular comparison here i would say being fromsoft titles), never believe that these games have "never been about the story".

author: Vask
review: I love this game! the only major downfall to this game is that it is lagging behind its console counterparts...Well....There are a few other things like its steep learning curve (very steep). You will probably die a lot and you will probably spend a lot of time tinkering with equipment too  unfortunately this game does not clarify how these things work so for some who are looking for that hand holding, you will probably be unhappy to know that it doesn't do much of that for you. ..... and its lackluster approach to multiplayer matchmaking wont win any points either, especially with story missions where you cant join games unless you your friends and the host have seen all of the cutscenes for that particular mission can make helping others along with the story a very tedious experience for newcomers.getting past that though it has a huge community, and with time invested in learning your weapon of choice and understanding how to properly prepare yourself and learning how to dance around the monsters and breaking through the games steep learning curve there is a ton of fun to be had with this game. It heavily outweighs the cons in my personal opinion.It offers enough variety in customization with its range of weapons and armor customization along with decorations(a sort of materia-like gem slot system) which help you customize your hunter with a range of modifers to handle pretty much any situation the game has to throw at you.  It offers a solid challenge to players too, though the game makes you fight mostly the same 20+ish monsters which may sound repetative, but they iterate them and make changes to their strength and behavior depending on their size rank and temperament, their difficulty will also scale depending if your playing with other people online (which makes them pretty hard if you have 4 people) or if your set in a mission/investigation where you will have to hunt multiple monsters in the same run. for me, no two runs ever feel the same and its what keeps me coming back to the game. there is also something very satisfying about having the ability to topple a bloodthirsty monster that is more than 3 times your size.

author: 𝕊𝕔𝕒𝕣𝕝𝕖𝕥
review: As a veteran of the series, this one took some getting used to, but overall the experience was a positive one. The visuals are top-notch for a MH title, and never before have I felt so immersed in the world itself. The removal of zone-by-zone loading helps make areas feel vast and seamless, and the addition of endemic life and monster turf-wars was astonishing. Really makes you feel like you're a small part of something grand-scale.Unfortunately some of the biggest parts of Monster Hunter, namely the creature variation and weapon appearances are noticeably lacking in this installment. Compared to past titles in terms of overall content, this one is rather dry... so a long-term investment may leave some feeling underwhelmed by the end of the day.However, I feel that the level of immersion (and actual storytelling in a MH game?!) is something that shouldn't be overlooked--I was pleasantly surprised. Whether a fan or new to the series, I'd say it's worth giving it a shot.

author: S0rch3r
review: Full disclaimer, I love monster hunter as a series and have been playing back since the PS2 days. Nevertheless, this is a brilliant game for anyone looking for a good online solo/coop hack'n'slash game where you just want a basic grind system. The QOL improvemnts inthis game compared to some of the older ones make this a really easy game to drop in and play regardless of your experience with the series and setting the game in an entirely new place (the 'New World') really helps make the game more accesible for new players. For returning players some of the old favourite monsters are back and bigger than ever, the weapons have a good balance and plenty of new moves to keep gameplay fresh if coming off from another MH game, but again the controls are simple enough that anyone can pick up and play. The progresion curve is also a hell of a lot more forgiving than older games, personally I'd say tis is a bit of a negative as i liked the sudden 'walls' that come out of nowhere but this if this helps the MH seris expand to a larger player base then I can't compain.Pros:Its freaking monster hunter on PC!!! Finally! (Not including MHO or MHF as they're region locked as rather awkward to play outside of host countries)Poogie is backBeautiful environments3 monsters to a map at a timeDrop in/out playGreat ecosystems & day/night/weather cyclesGood event quest (weekly/fornightly challenges) cycleCons:Suprisingly small monster poolCame out late for PC, so most people have played it heavily on console prior to PC release (myself included)Late game doesn't 'pop' as much as older games - the limited monster pool and lack of G rank may attribute to thisNo alpacasMight have been better suited if this was the equivalent of MHG/MHX/MHGU/MHXX (the 10year anniversay of MH)Rather repetitive weapon design

author: Ryuji
review: As a long time fan of the series, Monster Hunter World was a breath of fresh air. Despite not having most of the old monsters it introduces a whole new set of beasts to hunt as well as some long time iconic monster, like the Rathalos. Monster Hunter World takes the battle mechanic that previous games had and improves it for the better, including some QoL changes as well, such as walking while taking a pot, infinite Whetsones, improved and added weapon combos, etc. Although it has great changes, as the time of this review it lacks G Rank, some old monsters and a Thundra map, but that is something that might come with a future update.

author: Rachel Riley
review: EDIT:Alright, after taking a break from MHW hoping that they would fix the game's issues, finally I can say that Monter Hunter World is a playable game now. The network connectivity issues have definitely been fixed, they also included the support for raw mouse input in the options which is a much needed and welcomed addition to the game. Furthermore, it feels like the game has been optimised slightly despite still having some issues with frame drops for some monsters (very rarely, tbh, but when it happens, it's quite bad). But I can still live with that. I can finally recommend this game!

It rewards dedication with high skill ceiling combat, but you can still be effective and have fun even if you're completely new.Fun solo or with others; better with friends, but easy to find others to play with through in-game systems.

author: -=DVF=-De-Guvnor
review: 170 hours in, had to write a review before my 200th hunt! (updated at 1000 hunts!)Monster hunter is a hard to explain title to someone who's new to the series. Its mainly a co-operative "thinking persons" beat em up (although single player is possible). It combines that with a crafting system, progression via XP (Hunter Rank) and a LOT of customisation options for your character. It's not the kind of game where you make 1 build, limited to the class you chose at the beginning though, it remains completely open and you can change class/weapon/abilities on the fly between battles.The key premise is that your character NEVER levels up and gains abilities, you craft new armours, weapons and decorations which grant extra abilities instead. So you always have a kind of "level 1 character" but beefed up by his high level armour etc.If you are new to monster hunter this is the perfect entry point, it's a lot easier to play without making the game boring or too easy.  There's a challenge there for newbies and veterans alike, but vets have to wait some time after the main story for that challenge!Mixed reviews are not the best result for this game, which admittedly did have online connection problems for the first two weeks following launch.  Finally, do make sure you have slightly better than the minimum recommended spec as this game will destroy even the most capable PC on the highest settings (I have a VR rig and it pushes it on Max!)

author: Yukeh
review: TL;DR -HUGE open ended levels with extreme amounts of detail and quirks that change based on time of day.-Great soundtrack-Huge variety in customization-"Go-at-your-own-pace" gameplay-A living, breathing nature with life cycles-Optional material grinding-Optional but extremely detailed and rewarding exploration-Lots of lore you can unlock in-game by exploring-Drop in drop out coop, with optional passwords and integrated steam invite-The cutest companion in gaming history, that you customize along with yourself-If it moves, you can hunt it or catch itThis game is really therapeutic by yourself.If i were to compare this game to other games, i would draw parallels between the mission system of Metal Gear Solid V, the worlds of Horizon: Zero dawn and Zelda: Breath of the wild and the combat and world building of Dragon's dogma.The level of detail is absurd, unfortunately it will only be noticed by the people that care to look. Basically - if you can see it move, you can capture and study it. This applies to everything from giant dragons to birds to even ants and tiny fish swimming in schools. There are even creatures and critters that only appear at certain times of the day!While in-game movement can at times feel clunky, i haven't encountered anything that severely detracts from the experience or is in any way game breaking. Setup with a controller (which is absolutely recommended to play) can be a little confusing at first, so here's how to disable Steam Big Picture mode so you can use the regular steam overlay while you play.Go to Steam in the top left corner of the steam client > Settings > In-game > Untick "Use the big picture overlay when using a steam input enabled controller".I also suggest disabling motion blur and V-sync in advanced graphics settings if you are playing on a high definition monitor. Now tech advice aside, once you start the game you are given language options. Scroll through the list of SPOKEN LANGUAGES and change it either to "Monster Hunter Language" or "Japanese" for the best experience, both with dialogue and cutscenes. It DOES have a dub (that most certainly doesnt seem low quality at all) but the lip sync seems to be aligned to either Japanese or Monster Hunter Language, and like any originally japan-exclusive franchise the game has exaggerated animesque body language and expressions.Is my review missing something? Suggest in the comments.

author: Zancoth (FLIM)
review: Kill weird dragons!I have 1500 hours in this game and completed the main game 100% on PS4. I have the platinum trophy.This game takes a while to get used to, but once you do it's really satisfying, and has a lot of content and replayability value. I've played through the game 3 times. Changing to a different weapon completely changes the way you have to play, so if you're starting to get tired of the gameplay loop, just changing your weapon will give you quite a big change. Certain weapons feel like you're playing a completely different game.It takes a bit of time and fiddling to get used to some features that will help you out in the long run - like the Radial Wheel menu. Using it will let you place bombs, traps, and use healing items nearly instantly, rather than having to scroll through a left/right menu for a few seconds. It'll really help your survivability and your effectiveness.Overall this game is a lot better than its predecessors on handheld consoles. The gameplay is a lot more accessible in this iteration.That's not to say the game is too easy now, it definitely has the same core gameplay, but it just feels better - because of the improved framerate and visuals. The amount of combos and different attacks available is much higher as well, from what I've played of the older ones. It just works better.Overall, this game is great.

review: this games getting pretty heavily review bombed, its hardly perfect but does it derserved a mixed or negitave score? hell nogood:-huge amount of weapons, each changes the gameplay style massivly-weapon trees crafter from farming monsters-lots of different monsters, all are unique -grinding in this game feels rewarding mostly because you cant just sleep through it, its actually mentally stimulating-satisfying killsbad-some of the hitboxes (only some monsters really show some terrible hitboxes, most are ok)-MP bugs, theyre plentiful and can be frustrating, but with most bugs in most games, expect this to be fixed very soon-mouse+other controls, when quickly swiping on the mouse it feels very delayed, ive heard its because its emulated or something, 99% of the time it feels fine however-story is ...there.... but honestly its ok enough to make me motivated to carry through. its sort of like racing games in a way. if you have every track or car unlocked from the start i dont think i would play too much, but add a mediocre story and add progression and ill sit there for hoursthis game has bugs, no doubt about it but that doesnt mean it deserves to be bombed. bugs can (and will) be fixed, the core gameplay is extremly enjoyable, thats whats important. if you are a solo player chances are you wont even notice a lot of the issues that people are complaining about, i didnt until i started answering other peoples SOS flares

author: pantsu
review: GameplayHave you ever wanted to skip all the grind on low level monsters and go straight to the final boss? This game is what It feels like; every hunt is thrilling and will keep you on the edge, no matter if you hunt solo or with groups.  It seems very difficult at first; however, if you're careful and understand the moveset of each monster you'll be able to deal staggering blows that feel extremely rewarding. Hunting a monster without taking any damage and getting in the flow of the hunt is pure catharsis.There is a great variety of weapons, and they all seem to come straight out of an anime, so don't expect much realism if that's your thing; melee weapons like greatswords that take seconds to deal a single hit from dual blades that devour your stamina to ranged weapons like bows that shoot arrows the size of your character and bowguns that can shoot like a minigun, there is always a weapon to fit your style, and they're all equally viable from early to late game so it's all down to a matter of preference, though some are more complex than others.The game is split in two parts: Low Rank (LR) and High Rank (HR). LR is where you spend most of the main story missions; monsters deal less damage and have less hp but your equipment is also weaker. HR is where true Monster Hunter begins; monsters have more hp and damage but this is where you start crafting your endgame gear.GraphicsPretty good, but it's heavy on the hardware and requires a better gaming PC to run it properly.SoundNo music while exploring the maps, it starts when the monster is attacking you; also becomes a cue to when the monster is about to sleep when it stops playing. Some monsters have unique tracks. Weapon sound effects are very satisfying, and it really feels powerful when you deal a critical blow.PlotBarely enough to justify your hunts, don't get into this game if you expect to feel something other than satisfaction while slaying monsters.ConclusionGame is fantastic, one of the best I have ever played. No microtransactions or lootbox BS except for a few cosmetic items (and even then, there are plenty you can get by just playing). Port is ok, had a few problems on release but they all seem fixed now.MH:W is the first game of the series that I have ever played, since every release so far was on a console that I didn't own. I always felt that I'd enjoy the series and I'm totally hooked; hunting giant creatures for "research" never felt so fun.

author: ブラジル人TRUNKS
review: Stop hating on the game because of the movie. Capcom had nothing to do with the comments made in the movie. Monster Hunter World is one of the best Action RPG out there. After investing thousands of hours in the PS4 version I bought the PC version just to replay through it again in upgraded specs.I wouldn't normally take my time to defend any company like this but after following the Monster Hunter team closely on their update videos which a lot of it was free content added to the game, These guys don't deserve this treatment at all.

author: PlagueofMidgets
review: - No option to disable DOF- No option to disable or adjust Bloom- No option to disable Mouse Acceleration- No option to adjust FOV- No option to rebind buttons for Controllers- Very limited Antialising- Limited granulatiy in other graphics settings- No 21:9 Screen Ratio support- Bugged Full Screen support- Bug of High Resolution Textures not loading at max settings- Bug of Screen Space Reflections not displaying but still consuming system resources- Bugged DOF Distance Detection causing erratic blur on objects that should be in focus- No SLI support- Terrible optimization

author: Metacortex
review: CORRUPT SAVED DATA ISSUEWhile playing the game it suddenly crashed to desktop. When relaunching the game there was an error message:Failed to load save data.Revert save data to default?[Yes] [No]Clicking No over and over again just repeated the same error message. However after clicking Yes in order to continue I was mad to discover that all my progress so far has gone down the drain and now I have to restart from scratch including re-doing the painstaking character creation and re-watching the unskippable cut scenes - Groundhog Day style. It makes me cringe thinking that if I ever want to continue playing this game then I will have to restart from the beginning - I get that I have only played 17 hours which is small fry compared to other players who have lost their character progress after 50 hours or so, but still, 17 hours is a lot considering all the other AAA games out there that I could have completed in less than half the time.What kind of game in this day and age can't even get the fundamentals right? I have played many games from many genres over the years, and something as common as a crash to desktop has never required me to start from scratch due to corrupt saved data...until now. If this game is so vulnerable to saved data corruption, then the developers need to allow multiple save slots per character so that if your most recent save file gets corrupted then at least you can load an older save file and recover most of your progress. But this game is intent on putting all your eggs in one basket which is never a good idea for a game designed to take most players between 40 and 50 hours just to finish the story mode.This game is already a grindfest to begin with, but the allure of fighting new unique monsters and the journey of building up my character's weapons and armor in preparation for the final boss kept me going. However, until the developers fix this issue, I'm not willing to spend another hour on this monster of a game (pun intended) with the horrible idea lurking in the back of my mind that another crash might mean bye-bye to my character.**EDIT**I appreciate all the helpful comments here especially the one with a link on how to quickly back up the saved data using a script. If I have time I might start playing this game again and run that script each time I complete a mission (and have 10 different timestamped backups at any one time). This doesn't mean I find it acceptable that gamers have to resort to doing this just because the developers can't implement a reliable save feature. If this was a cheap indie game made by some unknown developer then I would have been more forgiving, but this is an expensive AAA title made by Capcom and I am shocked at why this sort of issue should even exist from such a major game developer.

author: Rog - Obbu
review: One of my favourite games of the past decade.MH:W is basically all boss fights, and reasonably lengthy ones at that.You go into areas, track monsters down and then spend 5-15 minutes fighting them at length, and sometimes chasing them down if they flee.Deep combat and great crafting - with a whole slew of different weapon types and playstyles, 18 different weapon types, each playing very differently from one another, from tanky lance to aggressive dual blades to heavy ranged bowguns or light agile bows - the formula is simple, hunt down a ravening monster, fight it solo or in co-op groups of up to 4 players, chop it up and use the materials to make new weapons/armour to take on harder foes.With foes ranging from water-spout shooting lizards to gigantic rolly-polly rock monsters, to aerial bombing opportunists, to unicorns, to gargantuan volcano monsters, or big old dragons - there's a massive array of opponents to be hunted, learned, defeated and farmed for materials.It's completely combat-centric, with very little story holding it together, but they are focusing on their strength: the combat is top notch. The graphics are beautiful and the environments are diverse, from jungles to deserts to volcanic crystalline regions.The expansion is also genuinely excellent, adding in a bunch of new creatures, new weapons and gear, and a new snow area.If you enjoy challenging boss fights, deep combat and unique creature designs, this one is a must play.

author: Berry
review: It's been about 8 or so months since I've placed this review and been playing. This review will be updated slightly to reflect that. I definitely now consider myself a fan of this series.This being a completely new experience to me going in, I had just one expectation going in - sounding like this was an MMO-like title, I wanted to see if I could play with my friends. With all the current time I've spent in it going through all of the main story and a bit of the endgame, I must say that this game left me conflicted a bit. It goes from something so extremely fresh to me that these past few days I quite literally couldn't put this down, to just being beyond frustrated to various things that only a very few other titles managed to do. Yet exhilarating would be the main word I would use to summerize... for the most part. The premise is simple, alongside the story, which is simply you going out into set maps and tasked to hunt down monsters of all kinds using the tools and weapons available to you. It's progression based with rpg elements into it - but instead of improving your own character you rather improve the tools you use in the game in order to take down stronger threats later on such as your armor and weapons. Doing so generally requires you to constantly hunt monsters or gather gear until it's strong enough to get to the next part of the game. In regards to hunting monsters, you have two options to take them out which is either simply killing it, or using tools to capture it - however capturing monsters is not available to any monsters classified as an "Elder Dragon" which is more or less a boss fight in simple terms.While you may not get a lot of depth in the story department or maybe even some of the visual elements present in the game it is a complete beast to go into the gameplay mechanics, yet not hard at all to understand. When going into the field to do the main part of the game you're given a large open map for you to roam around in to hunt monster or to gather up materials for use. This game does feature an item crafting system, so theres a lot of field collectables to get in order to stock on supplies - it also has a feature turned on some items by default to automatically craft ingredients out in the field into items such as herbs into potions, really neat. To find your monster target, you generally need to search around the map to find it though you have a lot of tools to help you do so. The field all around you can potentially have tracks left by the monsters like footprints, gashes, or even various markings specific to that monsters left lying around that your scoutflies (essentially this game's version of a tracking system, which also highlights items you can pick up) will notify you of. You can interact with this in order to give a lead for your scoutflies as well as get some research experience on it, plus these are left around real time so you can actually use it to detect the general location of where a monster is located at. It's very immersive with just a really simple mechanic, a trend this game does in spades.You have a selection of 14 different weapon types (11 Melee based, 3 Ranged based) all playing very uniquely from each other to combat monsters with as well as your other gadgets like your Slinger (Essentially a slingshot with makeshift ammo), Tools (like mantles), and various combat items like bomb barrels. Monsters animate, react, and fight in a quite realistic matter and almost always can have various body parts of them chipped off them which can actually affect how they fight move, and so on. If you're in a party of 1 or 2 human players, you also have your NPC partner aid you in fighting which is a cat creature called a Palico. The other basic stuff you can expect from this kind of game is here and it's all up to you to use the generous amount of tools at your disposal to deal with your target as you see fit.This game has quite a lot of mechanics to it but actually playing it in action is very fluid, simple, and crazy addictive to use, learn about, and even strive to get really good at it as you thread through progression. There is some form of tutorials within the game to help you get started but this game is more on the side of letting the player figure things out and for the most part it works out really well.There really is quite a lot of great things to this game, but even the latest entry in the series that tries it's best to introduce new players into it still shows a bit of it's jank.For my problems with the game itself, some monsters come into mind in the subject of their attack range not being totally accurate to their animations being done (The monsters known as Nergigante and Diablos in specific) esepcially when a lot of the other monsters not having this kind of issue it can get really jarring going into those. Then theres a lot on info in the game that is very briefly mentioned or not explained at all like some weapon skills, various quests type, certain skills in how to proc them, the various buffs in the game either via items or skills to name a few that I ended up having to seek outside assistance for. Some of the smaller things include some missing oraganization UI elements - managing your investigations properly is one big thing for me, and the fact that loot drops is all RNG based so especially in regard to weapon/armor upgrade, sometimes all you can do is just keeping farming monsters until you get the part you need (Breaking specific parts to get specific items is also, up to RNG, again specifically with Diablos for an example with horns) - However to add a little tidbit even though bad rng is a thing this game does keep grind to a minimum from beginning and even a little to the end generally. Pretty much all the online issues and many of the PC port issues many people and I've had in the past has been fixed so that's great! There is some weird things still present like if you disconnect from everyone in the middle of the hunt, the monster you're fighting if there is one will still have multiplayer multipliers on them even though you're now solo against it although that's very likely intentional (still kinda sucks when the d/c was not intentional)It's unknown whether or not we'll get updated to consoles or if cross-play can even become a reality for this title. I'm also fairly sure we are missing a few, if just small cosmetic things, event items due to the fact we didn't get certain events played on the PC version when the console versions was the only thing there. Speaking of events, the special quests recycle every week which is something I've never liked at all. While it seems seasonal festival enables a lot of the special event quests to be active I never liked the idea of having to play a game on a specific time frame to access content I can miss - specially when a lot of the event quests in this game could be vital to character progression.It is most definitely worth getting the PC version now, if you don't mind having a slight delay on game content. Otherwise I'd still recommend the console version if that's something you're worried about.08/20/2018 - first posted review.04/13/2019 - updated, and still playing the game to this date.

author: Midir
review: Monster Hunter arrives in full force on PC! While it offers a few twists on the familiar MonHun formula, MHW is very much the classic experience but beefed up for current generation consoles and the PC market.For those looking to expand on their existing Monster Hunting experience, this game might feel a bit barren, especially compared to the most recent Ultimate and Generations titles released on handheld and console, however for new entrants to the franchise, this is very much the perfect place to start, offering a good variety of monsters and weapons to hone your hunting skills.All in all, MHW provides a stable and amazingly nice to look at platform for both it's current and future content and most fans of third-person action will have little to complain about with the depth and breadth of activities on offer here.Average Game Length? Milage may very hugely here especially given the random nature of certain drops, a staple of the series. A singular hunt can take anywhere from a few minutes to nearly an hour whereas completing the story of the game will likely take most players around the 30 or more hour mark if you aren't speedrunning.A Bit Like? Monster Hunter! More seriously this game really birthed it's own genre, but for similar titles try God Eater and Dauntless.Is It Fun? Absolutely. Battling huge monsters is a blast with or without friends, exploring the amazing environments, the satisfaction of finding that one loot drop and time-limited challenge expeditions all add together to give a hell of a lot of entertainment.Worth The Price? MHW does carry a full fat price tag of around £50 when not on sale and while it would be hard not to reccomend for the amount of time you can get out of it, it's worth bearing in mind that other similar titles can be cheaper if you're unsure of the genre, but rest assured this is a complete expereince with more content being added at a steady clip with no additional costs for new monsters or hunts.
