author: Kodyd194
review: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD is a great game, hands down. As someone new to the monster hunter series, prior to World I had only played the first entry. I have had a really enjoyable experience and am really glad this game came to PC. Hours of Monster Hunting fun, multiplayer, customization, and just a ton to do. Many announced free updates coming down the line to add even more content to the game just sweetens the deal. I don't really know how this compares to previous Monster Hunter titles, but I would really recommend it if you are interested at all, its been a great experience so far. The only negative I have had with the game is the bad Capcom servers, but I expected that going in. They are working on the connection issues now, but my gut tells me even after there fix connections will be spotty.  Overall even with that one issue, I have had tons of fun multiplayer with friends, and I would recommend the game to  veteran Monster Hunter fans or newcomers alike.

author: SoapyTarantula
review: Let me preface this by stating the obvious, the game suffers from a pretty textbook case of "console port" syndrome. Performance isn't good and can hardly be justified. It has technical problems and for a lot of people it'll make your CPU run at basically all out for no good reason (my 8700k spikes to 50%). While I got used to it, if you want to use keyboard and mouse controls you may find it very awkward, especially the mouse. There is no direct input control from the mouse, its all emulating controller inputs; this means *very* noticeable pseudo mouse-acceleration, there are ways to combat it a bit but it will always remain to some extent.But I still enjoy the game.This is my first entry into Monster Hunter and apart from inital hiccups, I've been having fun. I  playing weapon or character barbie in any game (I picked up Escape From Tarkov almost entirely for the gun barbie) and this game has plenty. Once I found a weapon or two that I don't hate (I will never like the Greatsword) I've been having loads of fun just roaming outside the town and hunting whatever I may find. The game really makes you feel like you can take down any beast you can see, no matter the size.The game does not really make it clear what the information it gives you is supposed to mean. Sure, this weapon adds 10 Affinity, but what even is Affinity? How is elemental damage applied? Is it per hit? Is it a chance on hit? The game doesn't explain a lot of things to you, and most of these things are things I'd expect any other game to tell me more about. What is attack buff (M)? Is it better than attack buff (S)? Be prepared to Google a lot of things, or have them explained to you by someone that already has.I had a lot of my own self-hype ripped apart by my introduction to the game, but I still believe its a game I'll be putting many hours into, and with any luck CAPCOM will try to solve the port issues soon.

author: Whompp
review: Great segway of a franchise from the japanese market. They really captivated the nostalgia of the original Monster Hunter that debuted on the PS2. Having played most every other game in the franchise Monster Hunter World is really welcoming for both the veteran hunter and rookie alike. My MAIN gripe with this game upon release was the connection issues and having what I beleive unnecessary gatekeeping (having to watch the cutscenes in a quest to play multiplayer), but now since most of my friends have completed the story and connection issues seem to be all but gone. 10/10 for the current state of the game and enjoyment I've derived seeing my buddies get haymakered by Nerg.

author: Renato
review: Downvote for no support to 21:9 aspect ratio, but the game seems to be good.Update: The game crashes a lot the connection with online session, not a problem with mi connection but something in the game it loses itself in the online communication.I even had an stupid experience where i sent an S.O.S guy entered to help me and the online session crashed again but at least the game alows you to continue as an offline session so i kep t trying to kill the ratian solo, but was one of the worst experience since it took almost the 50min of the time limit to complete because i only realised at the end that the game removed the other player since the online session crash but the monster kept the HP gap for being in a party.I'm very down to play the game since those bad experiences

review: As a MH Veteran from the PS2 onward, this game brings several quality of life improvements that make it the most approachable game in the series. I am eagerly awaiting the expansion.

review: Fantastic game. There's always something to do, something new to see, and something new to kill. An excellent game to play with friends or by yourself if you just want to relax.

OF. CATS. <3 14/10 would play with their virtual cat again <3

author: Armageddon596
review: It's different from the traditional titles for Wii U, 3DS and PSP wherein  it's much more immersive and the graphics always astound me. Currently at HR 83 and will continue to grind for decor and equipment until Iceborne comes out! Wud definitely recommend, especially when you're playing with good friends! Let's get the hunt on!

author: noorr
review: After one night of playing, the port seems to be working fine. No capped FPS either if you're worried about that. After playing the PS4 version on non-pro console, I can appreciate not playing a slideshow. Gameplay wise, despite all the new mechanics and quality of life changes, it's still the good old Monster Hunter we've come to know and love. Kinda clunky, grindy and very difficult, yet rewarding and enjoyable experience.Edit: Took me around 32 hours to beat the final boss. Still really enjoying myself. Network play is an issue to an extend I guess, but after getting connected to friends' lobbies, it seemed to mostly work fine for me. I'm mainly a solo player though with only couple hours in online so take my opinion on this one with a grain of salt.Onwards to the end-game content!

author: Corrodias
review: This is the first MH game I've played, so I can't compare it to the others. I've recently discovered a love of action challenge games, including the Dark Souls series, and at this point I've played this game nearly 3 times as much as any DS game. It's always satisfying, even when it seems frustrating, because you always know you *can* get better and you *can* make chumps of the enemies that were besting you before. The incredible variety of playstyles in the different weapons keeps it fresh for quite a while.

author: CloudyMao
review: The only things that annoy me about this game is that if you want to help out ppl that haven't done the full story yet, then they have to view the cutscenes before you can help; the optimisation isn't the greatest, it's slowly getting fixed, lag issues and particle effects causing lag for no decent reason are fixed now, and i'm pretty sure that they're going to continue improving the optimization so i'm not too caught up on it.Other than that there really isn't anything to complain about at all, everything is being released slowly enough to keep the whole game exciting while not overwhelming, it's well staged, the farming/grinding that has to be done isn't boring and there isn't a whole ton of it. The story element is actually not so bad, and pretty wholesome. Pickle is still a SOB, Bagel has the best music in-game, Palicos are actually useful now. The game is BEAUTIFUL, expeditions are a treat because of it. the co-op is pretty damn good, I kindof wish there was a way to know which optional quests you haven't unlocked in-game, but I love that the game doesn't hand-hold you through anything. Using a gamepad and keyboard at the same time for convinience is amazing, because the transition between them is completely seemless. Armour sets are still super ugly P L E A S E  G I V E  U S  T R A N S M O G.Wiggler head OP Ghillie OPLearn your weapons, Don't trip up your team, communicate - and you'll have a really great time.10/10, play until my bum is numb and then keep playingWell worth the money, the time too. There's a hell of a lot of game here already and they're just going to keep releasing content. Don't worry too much about making tons of sets and weapons until you get to high rank, then you can really focus on the play style you enjoy and sorting your sets out to suit that.Highly recommend.

review: played 100 hours on ps4 and im still fighting new stuff, i love the older monster hunters, and i love this one aswell, i have my issues with some of the controls for keyboard but most of them can be fixed by using a controller though

author: Avak
review: Good Game, But Worst Server ever.... Multiplayer always DC.

author: ovler
review: I dont have to play league anymore!

author: Sigishi
review: Already got 400 hours in on the PS4 version and still got the PC. Starting over in Monster Hunter is always a tough call but there is still new content on the horizon. My 5 year old PC chugs a bit here and there but I'm playing just fine and the load times are a lot faster than on the console.The only cons I can think off is that it lacks proper PS4 controller support and the modular visual approach on the weapons is a bit stale and boring sometimes.

author: maathyas
review: even after months of launch, PC networking and setting up of co-op with friends is so complex and difficult.player textures look terrible compared to NPCs. (rewatch the cut-scenes again).no 21:9 support.sadly it was ok at the start, but on 2nd day, networking was terrible and no way friends could play consistently together in same sessions. and sadly it was beyond the 2hr refund mark otherwise would request for refund.And the official Steam FAQ and even the Crapcom Support page is hopeless in addressing our issues. This is what we get for paying full-price to an experienced triple-A publisher?

author: jfasdfkjdsafjksdafsjaklfj
review: Honestly there's not a game like this out there. The whole Monster Hunter series is amazing through and through and the fact even after two years of release they've added an expansion for it called Iceborne as well as several FREE title updates that includes festivals and even more monsters is simply amazing. You can easily find yourself putting over a 1,000 hours into the game. I played it on PS4, and just recently bought it again for PC and still absolutely love this game. To put this game in the simplest of terms you go around killing monsters and using those monster parts to make armor and weapons from which you'll use to go hunt and kill stronger monsters which you again will use their materials to craft even stronger armor and weapons than you had before and repeat. The only really grindy aspect of the game that may put people off is when you get towards the very end of the game, BUT by that point you'll already be well invested into the game. If you've never played the series at all I would HIGHLY recommend giving it a shot. If you're ever struggling at any point you can shoot up an SOS flare that will allow other players/hunters to come and help you with a quest. The whole Monster Hunter franchise is easily one of my top 3 favorite franchises, so I very much so recommend this game.

author: Reset
review: The best experience I had in a while with the following things:Boss killing, learning weapon mechanics, doing builds and grindings materials for them, doing difficult missions and failing miserably. The coop experience is not exactly great at first since each player must see their cutscenes separately, but when there is no cutscene involved (after seeing them all or doing minor quests), it is great.I would personally recommend watching the weapon showcase series  and then watching a gameplay with those you liked -- if possible one where the player actually is good (just type "MHW + the name of the weapon + TA rules" on youtube).

author: Pyramid Head's Meat Socket
review: Honestly this might be one of my favourite games to play in general, even much better when you have friends around to play with you. I also feel comfortable in knowing that after purchasing the game it can be played offline as well even though it might be difficult to kill endgame monsters alone. This was my first entry into the Monster Hunter franchise and now a comfort game for me. Easy to get addicted to since how this works is that you fight strong monsters to get stronger weapons that help you with stronger monsters. The game at least has a bestiary and information on drops so if you don't have access to a stable connection you don't need it to find information on monsters. The game is cute, charming but difficult and at times unforgiving with how the monster AI functions and yeah having to tenderise a monster for critical spots can be tiring but it's a minor inconvenience. Please please PLEASE try the game out if you ever wanted to get a taste of what Monster Hunter is all about, the price is really worth the experience and the DLC is practically a whole new game. Most of the DLC after that are cosmetic which a good chunk (but not all) can be earned in-game anyway as well.

author: Mr.Elektro
review: What a game!Monster Hunter throws player into the world of huge monsters and even bigger weapons. As a power house of man you smack monsters in the face with a giant hammer, you hop around like annoying fly using insect glaive, shoot them with a gun bigger than GAU-8 Avenger, or you just became an indestructible mountain and make a kebab using your lance and shield.And all this feels so satisfying, because every successful hunt is well deserved. You want to slap monsters like Jerry slaps Tom, then you have to work for it. Every new monster is a challenge, tough, but fair. But after few tries, you'll became stronger. You'll study monsters moves and use them to your advantage. You'll utilize a new move of your weapon understanding it little bit more. And after hundreds of hours of fun, you'll be that power house who just wipes floor with most of the monsters.Behind that, there is another game. Game of tactics, careful preparation, studying weakness of each monster. Building gear with skills that suit your play style to max out your potential against that feared elder dragon looking at you across the mountain.Monster Hunter has been my favorite game series for many years and Monster Hunter: World only reassured me in that view. I can only recommend this game, and I always will. It can be overwhelming in the beginning, but it's worth it! Poogie for life!

author: Montblanc
review: Deleted my buddy's save just because he hadn't played in a while. Absolutely unacceptable considering they already had the code to check for and update old saves of that format and for some reason decided to just not do it. If every game is going to be constantly supported for a good 2-3 years, then not making sure that user saves are protected is something that ruins everything your entire development team worked for.Was having the game step through each version's save file format and convert it just that hard of a concept for you? Was pressing Ctrl+C and Ctrl+V to move the already existing code you had just too arduous of a task?I'm not even going to go into the fact that you get locked into an endless loop of the game asking if you want to overwrite your "corrupted" save, leaving the only way for your user to prevent the complete destruction of a save that's at least 50 hours long is to open task manager because your big brained programmers disabled Alt+F4.Capcom, fire your entire development team that worked on this port. You'd be better off.

author: Vera Caelestis
review: This is one of my favourite games of all time, I've invested plenty of hours and after my headset charges gonna go play some more! it's genuinely unique and great in it's own right, it's even better with friends and i've met some truly wonderful people while playing, on my original character I have about 400 hours in and have yet to master the weapons. It's as simple as the name sounds you hunt giant monsters!!! some are adorable like Dodogama and some are grotesque (won't name it that's for you to find out!!)  it's got a good gameplay loop too and something for everyone if you like the game of course!!! there's Katana's, Giant hammers, bow's, bow's that are guns, a pole vault with blades, your classic sword and shield, a giant sword and many more that I can't name off the top of my head, If you want to play with friends you got it!!! there's so much to strive for and play, it's truly a labour of love, for those without a switch hearing about monster hunter rise wanting to enter the franchise, well this is a perfect gateway.

author: 🐠•-F I S H-•🐟
review: Totally worth it!

author: Revaltz
review: 1st MH game on PCPro:smooth gameplaylots of new mechanicsgood Weapons varietygood for newbie or even exp MH playerupdates catching up to ps4Cons:Compare to other mh games, fewer monster varietyJust buy it

author: Riftsu
review: Well since the game runs pretty good on my part I just want to say im pretty satisfied, before the patch with the Netcode problems I would have gave a Negative Review but now its pretty good and I would recommend it. ( But have atleast a good PC :P )

author: Slyder
review: To be honest, you can't call MHW a multiplayer game. Even though it HAS a multiplayer, the servers are utter garbage and random disconnects aren't anything special anymore. Added to that comes the fact, that if you're playing with a party of 2 or 4 people you're at a huge disadvantage in MP, since there's no real scaling for the monsters. It's either single player, or MP "difficulty". So no matter if you're 2 or 4 people, the monster will be exactly the same.And difficulty regarding the scaling is basicalls:- HP increase /which doesnt really matter)- the fact that breaking parts takes usually 10 years longer than in SP, so most of the times you kill the monster before the parts break even though only hitting  one specific part. (Looking at you Val Hazak)- Insane damage increases for the monsters, up to where you can get oneshot by any attack no matterhow much elemental def or normal def you have.There's probably a lot morethat I forgot, but it is just frustrating.I really like the game, and I really want to have fun in MP, but this game just isnt fun in MP, and sadly not very hard in SP. In the end it's still a decent Monster Hunter, but I just can't recommend it.EDIT:WELL, I guess it's time to edit this review. While it wasn't a pleasing experience at the start with lots of internet issues, it surely turned out to be a masterpiece once those problems were fixed.Lots of cool monsters that got added with the updates, fun events and even sieges with other players. Monster Hunter World truly was a great game, here's hoping Rise will be a worthy successor on PC.

author: Stoic Oak
review: When people ask me why I enjoy Monster Hunter after multiple entries in the franchise, and thousands of hours spent playing the games, I respond by telling them about the core gameplay loop. Fight monster, Get materials to make better and stronger gear, to then fight bigger and badder monsters. Nothing can describe the feeling of conquering a wall that stands in your way by stepping back, re-evaluating your tools, and then coming at it with either a new weapon, sharper tools, or even a greater understanding of the base mechanics.

author: gaspipe
review: johnny depp running simulator

author: RamblinRichard
review: To people who haven't played a Monster Hunter game before; It's strength is its core gameplay, just watch a video of anyone playing the game and you will get the idea, but its a bit better than that, as a large part of beating some of these monsters is learning how to beat them. Learning the moves the monsters make and also there being a lot of depth with each of the 12 weapon styles that are in the game (each of which have a lot of variants, cosmetically and gameplay wise). Monster designs are very unique, fantastic effort to make them feel realistic and are excellently animated. The story is ok, I wasn't really there for the story and the game was brilliant either way. But I think the real selling point to the game I don't really know how you would not like the sound of using a gigantic Axe that can transform into a sword that is powered by explosives to fight a T-Rex that breathes fire. I played that one mission 14 times not just because I wanted to grind that monster but because it was a fantastic experience each time, and I got better and better at it.To those who have played a monster hunter game before; This game doesn't have nearly as much endgame as MH4U, and for that I am very sad. I think I only had two more monsters to hunt at this play time and I was taking it slowly.

author: G8R
review: good game, play monster hunter, no shut up play monster hunter.

author: Greendetective
review: This game is AMAZING but the story is torture...

author: RemineTheCat
review: 16/8/2018: Not Recommended.- This game runs ~60FPS on a 1060 6GB, 16GB RAM, i7-7700HQ, with all low...this sucks- Network is bad. For me, I constantly have to check my network in every online  game, so I know that this could (potentially) be smooth while playing MH:W. Instead, the game rarely connects me to any open session, dumps me into offline while I want to have some fun helping strangers to beat Anjanath, or in the middle of the fight with Rathian... Not that I mind, but the entire network system could have been better.

author: 12wrld
review: Monster Hunter World is a insane step up graphic wise compared to all previous MH games. Story is alright but nothing too fancy just like the other games. I play on a prebuilt crap ACER desktop with a 1060 and get very good game play. Anyway here are my thoughts:[Pro]- Good Graphics and animation- Balanced in a way so even if you don't have friends MOST quests are solo-able.- Lots of even quest to gather good weapons, armour, and items. As a Great Sword user, with the proper augmentation and gems, the Wyvern Ignition Impact which is obtainable thorugh a event quest is very very good.- No pay to win- Fulfilling when you beat a elder dragon for the first time- Very interactive field. - No cancerous online players who chat crap or talk crap about you[Cons]- Some quests are definately harder to solo. (Eg, Kulve Taroth, Behemoth, etc)- Shop seems kinda lacking so I use a mod that allows me to buy great potions and flash pods which are otherwise a pain in the ass to make if you want to do a lot of quests in a quick succession- Great Sword designs are mostly all the same - Some weapons types are better than others imo- Not beginner friendly at all. I played MH before so I knew basic stuff but if you're a beginner, you might have a difficult time figuring things out. One thing that is very annoying is weapon combos, The practice range doesn't show you all the combos so you're better off watching a YT video.- Once you beat everything, it's kinda like, what now? (Guess this can go with all games) I help my friends out tho.- Have to watch all cutscene before someone or you friend can join or reply to your SOS call during quest,- Sometimes Glitchy. When I play with my friend, whenever one of us dies, our screen freezes for a short time.- Some times, monsters are a bit glitchy but it rarely is a problem.- Hate pink rathian's running around move where she constantly knocks you down repeatedlyOtherthan that, its an all right game overall. Will 10/10 buy Icebourne when it comes out even thought I can kinda guess what monsters will come out XD.

review: FAILED TO JOIN SESSION...FAILED TO JOIN SESSION........................................................Multiplayer is not from 2018. You have to create sessions, then join posted quests if you want to play coop with your friends. Capcom needs to streamline this system...

review: Quando adquiri esse jogo jamais imaginei que ficaria tão viciada quanto estou agora. O começo pode ser lento, mas a progressão das armas, das batalhas e dos monstros faz com que você se sinta um crackudo em abstinência louco pra conseguir droga. Fora que tem multiplayer e você pode matar bichões com seus amigos/pessoas aleatórias, o que torna a experiência mil vezes mais divertida. 10/10

review: Hard to learn, hard to get used to.Be patient and you'll learn to love it once you've figured out what's going on.

author: Borkuto
review: When you want a pet cat but your parents don't allow.

author: Joayy
review: I've played MH4U and MH Generations on the 3DS, and played the hell out of both of them (prob over 300 hours on MH4U). I've been anticipating the PC release of this game for quite some time, and it did not disappoint. The game is not without its flaws: network problems still exist, although drastically reduced after the most recent patch; monster pool is significantly smaller than former games; every once in a while, certain monsters' attack will case a frame drop (Teostra's supernova), although that could just be my PC; mouse and keyboard controls are apparently not good, although I just use controller. But as a whole, this is a great game. Monster design is still rock-solid: new monsters are fresh and don't just feel like reskins of older monsters, and classic monsters look awesome. New features like the SOS mechanic is a very welcome addition. Autocrafting is extremely useful. Controls, with controller, are set up well. Weapon/Armor reworks made certain aspects of the game more simplistic, but not overly so. Compared to other Monster Hunter games, this is one of, if not, the best.I'm not trying to sound like some crusader on Capcom's behalf, there are clearly some isssues with this game, but this game is worth the price.

author: Jokerr ≋
review: Score: 7/10Pros:+ Each fight is a lot of fun; Really feels like a boss+ Combat system is fluid + Each hit really feels like a solid connection, not like hitting a sponge+ Dynamic open world; monsters interact with eachother+ Each fight can be different+ 14 weapons, each with a different playstyleCons:- Optimization isn't great- No options for motion blur/depth of field/bloom- Finding a party/team/lobby is convoluted... lobbies could have a higher max person cap- Denuvo anti-tamperNeutral:* Haven't used it but I've heard mouse and keyboard can be really bad, definitely recommend using a controller for this game.* Having friends is better for this game, but public play can be good as well, though hard at times to find a group to help you.Overall, the game content itself is pretty solid. I'd recommend the game based off the gameplay itself. If you are able to run it, I'd definitely pick it up or maybe wait for them to (hopefully) update the game with some more graphical setting options or make it run smoother.

author: gent
review: Overall enjoying it so far! It was pretty frustrating at first, but you get over it once you figure out all the hidden controls. Quite fun. 8/10 so far. Bought it for sale, unsure if its worth $60 still but definitely worth 30/20!

author: Donny Donowitz
review: Monster Hunter World. Put a monster to sleep, drop two big ass barrel bombs on its head. Rinse, repeat. But seriously, aside from the story, its a great game. Easiest to hardest to use weapons in order (This is just my opinion however my mates agree for the most part) : Light Bowgun, Heavy Bowgun, Dual Blades, Bow, Sword and Shield, Hammer, Lance, Hunting Horn, Long Sword, Switch Axe, Great Sword, Insect Glaive, Gun Lance, Charge Blade.

author: Jeb
review: I recommend this game mostly to those who are newer to the Monster Hunter franchise. Veterans will be disappointed. Anyone seeing that the reviews are "Mixed" and 50% of them are negative, it's entirely because of the "broken" multiplayer. I have not had a single issue with the multiplayer so far and I've played well over 12 hours with friends. Not recommending a game because of a miniscule part of it that is a non-issue is honestly baffling to me because you could, instead, not recommend the game because it doesn't live up to the expectations of the other games but puts out in many other areas.Arbitrary ratings that I will explain:Combat: 7/10Story: 3/10Content: 6/10Port: 5/10Monster Hunter is simple in both the name and combat. The title of the game is "Monster Hunter" and your objective in the game is to literally hunt monsters. If you've came for combat that's refined in almost every aspect, this is the game for you. At the start of the game, past the intro, you have access to all weapons. There are a total of 14 of them: Sword & Shield, Dual Swords, Greatsword, Longsword, Hammer, Hunting Horn, Gunlance, Lance, Bow, Bowgun, Heavy Bowgun, Switch Axe, Charge Blade, and Insect Glaive. With other games, a large catalog of different items usually equates to many much similar playstyles, however in Monster Hunter over the past 14 years, they've refined and perfected each weapon to feel and play extremely differently, including even the bowguns. Because of this, you can enter the game, play through all of the content, and play through it again with a different weapon, forcing you to evaluate when & how you need to attack and when to play it safe. The only drawback with the newest installment, Monster Hunter World, is that for some weapons they have become extremely powerful as the tools in their kit have been increased while others have only had minor tweaks, falling much farther behind other weapons. However, you can still as easily play through the entire game with even with the objectively worst weapon in the game and only be slightly behind the pack. What doesn't make this a 10 is the monster cast. Playing as both Bows, Switch Axes, and Longsword, I never felt any challenge against any of the monsters or it, instead, felt artificial. Normally, the most annoying monster to fight in the franchise has always been the Diablos as he charges and charges and charges while his shoulder checks are the size of the Pacific. Though, in this installment, he didn't seem to have that same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ characteristic I always gave him. His mischievous behavior felt tame in comparison to the older games, including even MH4U. It's almost as if they turned the dial down from "Normal" to "Slow" for World. Even outside of this, the only times I've ever felt threatened was when I get chained by a monster's combo, but even though it was my own mistake and I should have carted, I didn't. The story has never been the strong suit of the game. It's CapCom. In some of the older games, the lack of story didn't feel like a downside to the game at all as your goal as the player is to rise up in the ranks of the revered monster hunters and defeat the beasts that plague the lands. With all of the cutscenes, dialogues with NPCs, and overarching story, it feels arbitrary. Had it been the small tidbits of information we got through quest info or talking with the NPCs only briefly, I wouldn't feel the need to even grade this because it's obvious that's not one of the areas they were focusing on. I will say one thing that does help its grade: the voice acting. Some of it is bland, but all of the main characters have conviction, sound fluent, and even some of the dialogue was (not much for the better) changed to be a bit more western. It's a good shift that I think is underappreciated by many. Back to talking about the story: it's trying to shove it in your face all of the time. There's always the Handler saying the same line over and over after each mission you complete, if you're farming for a weapon or armor piece and there's the massive objective pins. It's easy to get lost with the real game when you start entirely because the story NPCs keep shoving it in your face that "YOU HAVE TO DO THIS QUEST NOW!!!" I don't want to spoil the story, but it's honestly not that much to talk about anyways.I hate to give this anything under a 10. In the earlier inclusions of the franchise, I refer mostly to Monster Hunter Freedom Unite as that is the game I played most, there was always G-Rank. There are three "difficulties" in the game that are categorized as Ranks. You have: Low-rank, Hi-rank, and G-rank. Low-rank is entirely to get you used to the game and find what weapon you want to use. Some weapons aren't that great in this section but in the newer sequels to the game, they've polished this up. Hi-rank is to ease you into G-rank. It begins to show you the diverse cast of monsters that are difficult both with damage, attack patterns, and mechanics. Closing towards the end of Hi-rank, you begin to fight Elder Dragons, which are effectively the bosses of the Monster Hunter franchise. This includes the: Teostra, Lunastra, Kushala Daora, Kirin, Fatalis, Alatreon, Jhen Mohran, Dire Miralis, and Dalamadur to name a few. Each monster feels different and some even have sub-classes like the Oroshi Kirin or Rusted Kushala Daora which change some of the core mechanics of the Elder Dragon to make for a new twist on the beast. However, without G-Rank, you are left without the ultimate difficulty and, personally, the way the game is meant to be played. You can first see this in Monster Hunter Tri where they decided to ditch G-Rank and stop at Hi-rank, leaving the "ultimate challenge" to be the Alatreon, which was an interesting fight for sure, but not a proper way to leave the difficulty scale. As the games forged onwards, G-rank seemingly kept being "delayed until a further date" because they couldn't finish it in time. For a game like Monster Hunter World, this makes perfect sense as they could actually have good graphics as opposed to the seemingly 144p of the handheld consoles. However, after 9 months of the base game being released, along with an article saying that the PC port will "launch with G-rank", there is no G-rank. For those who don't play past halfway through Hi-rank, this doesn't affect them in the slightest, which is supposedly most of the community. Even without G-rank, the game still stands with a decent amount of content as the monsters feel diverse, even though they don't feel threatening. Each monster feels unique, each with their own gimmick and they play around that gimmick. A lot of other people talk a lot of ♥♥♥♥ about this port, which is well received, but in opposition to them, I've NEVER had an issue so far with multiplayer. No dropped connection, lag, anything. The controls feel wonky, the mouse has an emulated console camera acceleration that makes it feel awkward.

author: Animus Furandi
review: Monster Hunter: World is, in no uncertain terms, one of the defining games of this generation and one of the greatest multiplayer or even single-player experiences of all time. It's visually stunning, difficulty and rewards are balanced perfectly, it affords the community little opportunity to be a bad one, the amount of content is staggering, and the number of ways to play and complete your goals make it a pure joy to play. If you aren't playing this game now while there's a community to enjoy it with, you're missing out on one of the most incredible experiences in gaming in many years.

author: Friend
review: I want to preface this review by stating that Monster Hunter is my all-time favorite series of games like... ever. I think across the board I have something ludacris like 14k hours total, yes, even the lil spin-off titles and whatnot. I won't waste a lot of your time, and I will try to make my review look pretty so it's not just a wall of text. The list will mostly be for people who are new to the series. Those that are grizzled MonHun vets can look to the section below the bullet points.I hope this review helps! :DThere is plenty I might have neglected to really speak about above, but for the moment, those are the biggest positives and negatives about the game, coming from the standpoint of someone who has played the previous titles and basically slaves away on these games. Hands down, this game is BORING. I found myself 100 hours in, really pushing myself to find something to do. I literally had no direction at all! The game drops you off at the end of the story, very low hunter rank, and just basically tells you to sniff dirty footprints and lick mucus until you find the tempered monsters.From that point on you will be rinse and repeating the same monsters you've fought throughout the entire game, except they just hit harder. It's actually really disappointing. Monsters like Xeno don't even come close to real end-game monsters from previous games like the Fatalis or Rajang. It's slow, telegraphs everything like it's in slow motion, and sucks gigantic balls. In previous games, you got into G-rank. That was where you put hair on your gooch and fought the monsters that really were absolute hell to take on 1-1. Suddenly you are facing new monsters you have never seen before and boy do they either move fast and slam you hard or they have really nifty attack patterns you have to learn to avoid taking a beam of some elemet to the face, vaporizing you instantly. World just... LACKS all that high-class stuff that separated good hunters from REALLY good hunters.If I can make one big comparison, it would be Glavenus compared to Anjanath. In Generations, this was a t-rex with a really sick twist. This bigass freak had a bladed tail it could run across its jaw to heat it up before spin dashing at you. It had flair, personality, style, and was a really cool monster to fight all around. Anjanath on the other hand is like Glavenus' stupid little brother that has allergies. Not only does his "fire breath" come out as a lame sneeze, his design is much less WOW than Glavenus. It's simplistic and uninspired, which I guess kinda fits World's narrative for being "more realistic", but then again they throw in ♥♥♥♥ like Teostra and Kushala just to get old fans of the series rock hard, so that all goes out the window.I think the thing that was most infuriating to me personally was the weapon/armor designs. I found my friends on Discord asking me "What weapon/armor is that?" because the designs are so flat. In all the previous titles, the armor and weapons you created from monster parts really expressed the personality and design of the monsters they came from.I ran out of characters! D:

author: NekoMashiron
review: Been playing since MHFU days..Much Smoother Gameplay, though easier...Hope they return old Monsters from previous Generations. Missed killing 2 Saiyan's that looked at the full moon when you hunt them. Still recommended for New Players who want to try Hunting for Rare Items but not getting any of it. (DESIRE SENSOR is REAL). for veterans we've been there done that so... its so normal.

author: lupus
review: Good game, good entertainment, action, music. Levels are fun to explore and it is exciting to find monsters and the new world in the beginning.Weapons are interesting and differ enough to make the player to want to try them out. The fights are, at times, too slow for my taste and the tedious sheath mechanic to use heals, sling ammo, utility etc. is just annoying and tedious.Monsters mostly have super obvious attacks and they don't really differ that much. Flying in attack, spinning tail, swipe, charge attack. Repeat, reskin. The difficulty in this game comes from the absolute necessity to be skilled enough to set up your attacks & combos in addition to predict the next move so you can hit the monster with a big bang.It's an ok and unique game

author: Juju
review: I've never recommended anything this strongly.This game is just always fun and never stops. There's so much to do and so much to learn, so this game singlehandedly occupied me through the 2020 quarantine. And even after finishing pretty much everything, I still keep coming back just because the hunts are so fun. The monsters you meet are always challenging, but never unfair.  The weapons handle unlike any other game, and feel extremely satisfying.To get the most out of the game, I suggest:- Try out a lot of different weapons, there are 14 for a reason.- Take your time progressing through the story. After hunting a monster for the first time, check if you like the armor and weapons you can make from its parts.- Either have someone who can explain mechanics (ask me if you like), or be prepared to research them. There's lots you want to learn, in and out of combat.- And most importantly, DO NOT use 'Defender' weapons or 'Guardian' armor! They only exist to make you skip the base game and buy the expansion quickly, by being much stronger than all base game items you're able to get.Oh, and Iceborne is just as great as the base game. It starts after MHW's endgame content, and comes with a complete story, followed by its own endgame. Don't bother buying it until after you finished all base game content and want more.

author: Poseidon
review: Wow! This is a game that kept me quite busy. If you like sitting on the edge of your seat and praying that you can win, then this is for you! Never have I ever struggled and sometimes hated a game as much as this. Planning out your gear for every fight and improving it along the way is what made this game for me. Every new monster is a new completely different fight and with it comes all new skills. I would recommend you first play it before buying the ICE BORN DLC.Also much better then Monster Hunter Rise.

author: Kharne
review: The current review bombing on this game is completely unjustified and just plain stupid. I write really rarely reviews for games but I had to stand up against this massive influx of BS.To counteract I will just deliver some background information why this review bombing is happening:In the new released Monster Hunter movie someone stated a bad joke which (why ever) insulted a lot chinese people, which in return see it as their sworn task to damage this IP somehow. Ultimatively resulting in angry folks redirecting their anger in the most pathetic way towards this game...Now, let me explain why this game is actually great:The game itself is a very smooth transition of a series from handheld and nintendo consoles to a truly beautiful experience on pc. It sure takes some time to get adjusted to it`s somewhat initially felt clunky combat system. but after a while you start to adapt and to learn how to manuver correctly and to use the environment fluently. Leading into a wonderful symphony of fighting massive monsters in astounding environments. Sure the areas are limited but very diverse in appearance. This together with loads of content and a very diverse weapon pool you can sink hundrets of hours into this game before you actually get bored of it.The core mechanics of this game consists of the monsters itself and the loot they provide. Loot which in return is used to craft better and better gear, like armor and weapons. Despite its simpel core mechanics, it feels heavily rewarding.The story is nothing to focus on to much and represents the weakest part of this game. Monster hunter games where never known for good story writing anyway. BUT if you are looking for a captivating game to spent hundreds of hours solo or even with your buddies (4 players give the best expierience btw.) and don`t mind a little grind here and there and that the story is somewhat flat. Then you are here spot on!~ Oh, and a very important tip of mine, use a gamepad. It makes this game so much more accessable.

author: MettCool
review: ProsVisually beautiful game. Controls are surprisingly good, coming from the handheld series to mouse and keyboard.Online also works surprisingly well, with making and joining groups a breeze after you get the hang of it.ConsNot as hard as older titles. Much less content (32 large monsters compared to 70+ in handheld games).Handler can be pretty annoying (I eventually muted all voice acting by about mid-game).The decision to make viewing the cutscenes mandatory before a friend can join your hunt in story quests is a bit of a pain. All in all, I'd recommend it for the experience alone. It's an impressive title that builds up its environments exceptionally well. The quality of life changes make it easy for people to get into it, even if they are unfamiliar with the series. Iceborne will remedy my gripes about the low monster count a little, but paying the price of a whole extra AAA game for DLC isn't worth it, for me.

author: Raito
review: What a ride of a game. I played Monster Hunter before, with 3 Ultimate on the DS and got similarly addicted this time. But I had an even greater time with this game. The fights are intense, and getting stronger feels incredibly rewarding. Being able to play with friends or randoms so easily makes it even better. There's really not a lot to be said about the game, but it's basically just boss fight after boss fight, to gather materials and become stronger. The becoming stronger and more skilled part is the most satisfying, though. Being able to shred through a boss within minutes that was able to easily kill you just 10 hours ago feels so good. I'm really happy they brought this to PC!9/10

author: Shep
review: Veteran hunter, I've been around since MH3U, and have played all of the titles released since then, including the MHFU port to iOS. I say this because there are some comparisons between this game and previous gens that are necessary to properly critique this entry into the series.I was super duper hype for Monster Hunter World, to the point that I play it both on PS4 and PC. I prefer it on PC since I get to have a little more control over it than I do on the PS4. Spoiler alert, I don't recommend it on PS4, but if you have more friends playing it on PS4, get it for PS4, it's still really good, and the stuff I say below still applies. The real meat and potatoes of MonHun. Quality of life changes have been made out the wazoo; it's never been a better time to be introduced to the series. Gathering was streamlined, inventory space has been made far more spacious, and the armor skill system was simplified so that it's not a complicated mess. Combat is nuanced, to the point that you'll want to go and watch an Arrekz(?) Gaming or GaijinHunter video to properly understand your choice of weapon. The learning curve is high, but it's incredibly rewarding once you pick up on how things work. More in-game tutorials would be appreciated, but frankly it's still a huge step forward from what it previously was. 9/10You don't play Monster Hunter for the story- you hunt monsters. The Handler looks star-y eyed at pretty locales, won't let you skip cutscenes, and generally slows down the main gameplay loop. There's some INSANE lore if you go back and look into the official art books, and look at the landscapes of MH4U, but MHW doesn't really offer much. It takes place on a "New World", which is to say a big ol' island nobody's colonized or documented sufficiently. Don't expect to be captivated by anything new or unique. 1/10 There are some bumpin themes from across the series. These ones are good too. If you don't like the music, you can turn it off and just play something on Youtube in the background. 7/10 The graphics of the previous games have all been compared to PS2-era graphics. This is an apt comparison. The graphics of MHW are a monumental step forward, with lots of attention and detail put into individual nooks and crannies of the world. The monsters are high-def, the views are spectacular, and the faces of all humanoid characters dip into the uncanny valley at a rate that makes me wish I could always hide my eyes. 8/10The total playtime I've got for this series as a whole is somewhere in the 2500-3000 hour range. I've dunked maybe ~150 hours in total on MHW, with 100 of those on the PS4 version. I blame this disparity in time sinkage partly to the fact that previous titles were on 3DS or Switch, which are far more portable than my heavy-ass desktop computer. I also attribute the lack of hours this gen to the . The Monster Hunter dev team gets huge kudos for putting out such quality content that has me always coming back for more, but I'm more than willing to wait another year or few if more monsters get developed, tested, and churned out. Monster Hunter World is a good game. I've enjoyed it, and I'm playing it some more to fully appreciate the last of the weapon types that I haven't solo'd my way to High Rank and beyond with. It's far from perfect, and there are some aspects of this entry that I feel lack the luster I've come to enjoy from previous titles. But it's something I always try to recommend others try, if only so I can do some hunting with them too. I heartily recommend this game, and hope that the Iceborne expansion brings us some fresh-ass content.

author: Snoob
review: Ever since I picked up a copy of Monster Hunter 3 Ultimate for the Wii U in a desperate attempt to get a game for the system that didn't suck, I've been hooked on the series. This is a franchise that, historically, will take you on an adventure, obfuscate a ton of things that are probably vital information, and, most importantly, ask you to take down giant monsters with comically-oversized weapons so you can make armor and more weapons from their corpses. It turns out that the name is a bit on the nose, you could say. And then comes World, the black sheep of the family and the most polarizing member of the whole shebang. But I'm getting a little ahead of myself.In Monster Hunter, the player's job is to... hunt monsters. Big surprise there. Choosing from an arsenal of 14 different weapons, each with their own crafting trees to explore, the job has a few core tenants. First, scouting the area is important, both to find your quarry and see what parts of the environment you can use to your advantage later. On top of that, natural resources are important for your continued progression, and should be harvested when possible. Next comes the actual  part, as you go toe to toe with a motley assortment of beasts ranging from "somewhat oversized iguana" to "a veritable mountain that threatens to eradicate all life in the world". Yeah. Power creep's pretty high, but the game starts you out small and makes you scale up slowly (sometimes a bit too slowly, honestly). Rarely will you feel out of your depth, even if you might have to look for some guidance every now and then.The biggest selling point of World, in my opinion, is the improved combat system. Monster Hunter has always felt a bit... clunky. And while that was its signature style, going to World just feels like such a breath of fresh air. There's a freedom of movement that feels so liberating, like you're an actual person and not an entity locked into place while performing a variety of actions. The addition of the Slinger and grappling capability have made delivering payloads like incapacitating Flash Bombs more streamlined, but now the monsters are a bit smarter about things and eventually learn to close their eyes (or something) at higher tiers. Damage numbers are a nice quality of life feature, even if I turned them off once I got more comfortable with the weapons' rebalancing, and so many tactics that you used to just have to know ("Hit Rathian in the face") feel less like hidden stratagems and more like things you can learn through natural experimentation. Most importantly, though, with a mouse and keyboard, using a ranged weapon no longer feels like hot garbage (although it's still a little clunky).Capcom's MonHun team have also been hard at work adding more value to this game ever since it launched. Much like on the console versions, it feels like every single month adds something new, whether it's a monster, new sets of armor, a limited-time festival, or all of the above. This all comes completely free of cost to all owners, allowing everybody to stay on the same playing field, and makes it sting a little less when it was announced that the "G rank" equivalent (effectively a ton more content, and traditionally a seperate game entirely for this series) would be a paid DLC this time around not too far back. This has given it a lot of additional mileage in my book, and I keep coming back to World to check out the new content despite being technically "done" with it in record time for a game in the series.No game is without flaw, however, and World has one or two, especially if you're a returning fan. It's incredibly obvious that the series moving to an entirely new engine meant that all work had to be thrown out and done from scratch, and so a lot of fan-favorite monsters didn't make it back, at least not yet (but despite this, we have enough room for 4 variants on the same skeleton in the form of Rathian, Rathalos, and their variants...). Each of World's existing monsters stands out on their own decently, but without classics like Nargacuga, Tigrex, or Zinogre, the game feels like it's missing some important icons that would look amazing in "true" HD. Furthermore, there are several points where the game is clearly just throwing busy work at you to pad it out, whether it be needing to grind Hunter Rank to get the "real" end-game quests unlocked (more egregiously than the series usually resorts to, at least), a multitude of quests which seem to exist just to show off a monster you'll have to fight on the next one, or (and this one is the most egregious) a point where you have to goof around doing other quests for a while while marking tracks for unknown monsters in order to unlock the last few you'll need to complete the game by fighting the ultimate big bad.If this giant wall of text has scared you, here's my summary: Monster Hunter World is the perfect way to get into Monster Hunter as a series, especially if you've been turned off in the past by how esoteric it is. While it makes me somewhat anxious that Capcom may simplify the formula down more further down the line, World effectively acts like a much-needed booster shot of modernization, a teaspoon of bitter medicine that many fans may just need to swallow. It's become one of my go-to "Do you have this yet?" games to suggest for co-op, and the only reason I don't have more hours is because the back half of the year had so many excellent releases I needed to play as well.Plus, you know, there's still Generations Ultimate on the Switch if you like the old formula more.

author: RiderRonin
review: Alright so I wanted to throw my hat in the ring after reading a good chunk of reviews and comments for this game. I may not have the highest hour count on THIS particular game but have been playing Monster Hunter since the dawn of it's first day so it's my most played game series hands down. I have a huge love for this series but haven't really had a chance to voice it until now. I am going to voice this from the point of a new buyer who has never played the series before and at the end voice my old hunter geezer opinion.This game is one hell of a ride if you have the right taste for it, it is diffenitly one of those games that apeals to a certain group of folks. So I can't blame anyone who just doesn't vibe with it because it's one of those games that you bash your head against a brick wall till it breaks. Yes this game is a bit softened up for the newcomer which is great, many people I tried to introduce to this series before either stuck with it or ran away. The more new blood the better and I had even singed up to take on a new hunter and teach them the game (this group was the Adopt a Hunter program if you wanna check it out). Once again I understand that this isn't for everyone but I hope this helps.Pros:Beautiful game with great graphics, lighting, sound and music can't go wrong there.A healthy variety of monsters, locations, quests and side bits to do.Great pool of weapon choices that can fit a play style for everyone and revamp it's game time by switching things up.Armors have unique builds of a matching set or even throwing random pieces together for flexability.Open area exploration (not a true open world) with large map spaces with secrets and resources unique for each place.Group hunting that allows you and three more buddies to gear up and quest out even in the "story" side of things.Constantly being updated with more fun stuff including monsters and soon to be areas.Cons:Can feel like you are bashing your head against a brick wall, steep learning curve that can be overwhelming.Weapons can look identical when upgrading until hitting the higher end of it.Side options can feel rather weak and uninteresting like fishing or small animal captures.The grind can be a pit when it comes to gathering monster resources overall a big time sink if you don't like the grind.Rather short in a Monster Hunter game senseBig boi review:Alright lets tear into this and start by diving into that learning curve a bit more since my Cons are pretty short and heres why. The curve is the hardest part about this game, as is with all games this hits you with a combat and knowledge curve. Figuring out how to use your weapon of choice against any and all monsters can be tough since each monster is different. This causes you to figure out paterns for the monsters attacks to see where you can fit in a slash or two yourself, and can be frustrating because it may seem your weapon just isn't fast enough to hit and keep up with your target. So you already have a tall glass to handle when it comes to learning the monsters attacks and your own but just to bust your knee caps some more lets add to it. The other shopping list you need to know is things like item combos, food selections, elemental strengths and weaknesses, weapon sharpness, armor skills, map knowledge, resources and their locations, ect. Added on top to this is the fact that this game is a grind, not in a level up sense but more in a "Get the right things to build the thing" way. If RNG isn't atleast sneezing your way than have fun running that monster fight a few more times, to infinity and beyond! This is the hardest part about the game but this is where I am going to turn it on it's head, ready? That's the whole point. Much like many sandbox survival games where in you are thrown into a world with little to no knowledge and you just start to throw yourself at things to see what happens. This is the same way except you can't build a tiny starting house into a castle of awesome, YOU ARE THE TINY STARTING HOUSE. It's going to start you small and kick you until you figure out what works with what THIS IS THAT TYPE OF GAME. I am putting heavy emphasis on this because I want to make sure you understand what you are in for! I like this kind of game it makes you feel like an underdog, a small speck on the world but you transform into Big Boi McGee king of all that is ass kickerie. This game isn't very story powerful either, though this is the best attempt they have had through the whole series. So in all honesty there is little to hold onto to keep going unless you are the type of player who likes the power grind. Even after all this is said the game tries it's best to tell you how pretty much everything works. Each time you run into a new feature it gives you everyones favorite thing, reading material. But it does it's job it shows you what that new feature is, how to use it on a basic sense and then just leaves you. This includes weapons, there is a whole training area with cliffs and dummy barrels and even a full combo list to help you get a feel for the weapon in every base environmental way. You will also notice that if you really start chewing into this meal that there really isn't allot of fat. Sure you can go a city block times a country mile of play time with this game but it is rather lacking. The monsters are only really a okay scoop instead of a double scoop of raisin bran or even a triple from the past games. As cruddy as this is it's nice to know that they are making new content including new areas and monsters for us to handle.Grumpy old hunter time:From a long time player spot this game is still fun but lacks so much content wise. The quality of life improvements are a grand thing but makes it 4 ply soft for an already skilled player coming back into this. I also have to recommend the PC version of this overall, yeah it had a rough start but I played this on xbox too and that had the same issues at the start as well. PC is also only a sliver behind in terms of content updates from the consoles that soon it's going to be word for word with it anyways. I mean if you have more friends playing it on a console compared to PC than by all means play with them but if you don't have friends who play this or just don't care either way than just swing for PC. The fact that there still isn't a G rank miffs me, for those who don't know G rank is the big daddy level of difficulty that normally comes with a good wallop of monsters and fun times.The verdict:I think anyone who really gives it a good ol try will enjoy this game, even if they aren't super into the grindy game type it might just have them turn coat about it. I highly recommend you get this game, but if anything in this review or others you may have read or watched still has you on the fence just wait till a sale if ya don't like it not a big loss. I give this game an easy 8 outa 10 even with my grumpy old hunter self not feeling a HUGE challenge anymore doesn't mean I don't get a kick outa this game still.

author: Just Hitting My Stride

author: ⎛⎝ JR ⎠⎞
review: Monster Hunter World is exactly the same great, gloriously addictive game on PC as it’s always been.Since the console launch there’s been a whole slew of updates and content additions, and PC players stand to benefit from these changes. Lots of the content is still yet to roll out on PC, but it's looking likely the PC version will catch up with the consoles eventually. It’s also the best place to be for higher frame rates and resolutions, particularly when the PS4 can dip below 30 frames per second on occasion. Visually though, there’s really not much to distinguish playing Monster Hunter World on a PS4 Pro compared to a top-end PC, aside from the frame rate. Ultimately in an action game like this though, frame rate is incredibly important, particularly when trying out last-second dodge rolls or attempting to time your counter-attacks. Performance isn't anything to write home about it but it's decent enough, although the taxing CPU demands could occasionally cause a few dips.Most importantly though, Monster Hunter has never truly had a home on PC before. It’s a series that has blossomed from underground sensation to monstrously huge hit, and yet only now has Capcom decided it’s worthy of coming to PC. Fortunately, the wait has been truly worth it. MHW is the single biggest shift in the series’ history, modernising the experience, adding plenty of quality-of-life changes, and finally breaking free from the shackles of handhelds.It's a fantastic game and a decent port, although the mouse and keyboard support currently leaves a lot to be desired. It feels as if mouse movement has been mapped to analogue stick movement and it's just awful to control. Make plugging in a console controller or remapping some of the default controls your first priority for a smoother experience.Arriving eight months late on PC, everything that can be said about Monster Hunter World already has been. Rest assured though, the wait was indeed worth it. Anyone looking for a deep action game they can potentially invest hundreds of hours into need look no further. This is Monster Hunter, back and better than it's ever been before.

author: Gaelabreaha
review: Not going to lie lost track of the days while playing this game and racked 80 hours in 4 days, I see a lot of people giving it neg reviews over the smallest reasons look here's a list of some pills you gotta swallow. 1 - Gonna get this fat pill outa the way so listen Monster Hunter was never designed to be played with KB+M from the ground up it just isn't MH has always been that way years before the conception of PC MH was even a thing, HOWEVER that does not mean you cannot adapt to the controls scheme they already have. Instead of trying to change everything to fit you adapt to the games controls it'll happen eventually. A lot of people want to change them but they never try to just adapt to them like any games control scheme I can understand wanting to have some things be much easier to do but your fingers will learn and it won't be such a stiffiling experience then especially when you develop muscle memory.2 - On release the port was meh it did it's job and has it's functionality boom done (wording it for past tense because they're going to fix the PC port I don't see why they wouldn't but will change if they don't but even then it's really noothing to get bent out of shape for). Furthermore no PC port is ever perfect and this game isn't any different. The game IS NOT A BAD GAME by any means it's a a fantastic game with a meh port but can steam read that? No so you get thousands of neg reviews that pretty much are boggled down to  - Lack of some visual options - Connection issuesPersonally not affected by Denuvo don't care about it, Visuals are pretty solid some textures don't look great but when 90% of what you do is fighting monsters you never really have time to notice or see the texture flaws especially since the camera itself isn't on top of your character and is decently far back for you not to notice but i'm assuming they'll be fixed if not like I said earlier you don't really notice or atleast I don't. Connection issues I've DC'd twice out of my 80 hours so far 1 DC per 40 hours pretty much, I played mostly solo and grouped with friends on occasion and popped some SOS flares every now and again.Personally as someone that's played previous MH titles this one sets itself a part is is a ton of fun to have, the game will be fixed it's only been 4 days since release at the time of making this review. In my opinion most of the neg reviews are people getting bent out of shape over multiplayer like they're not going to fix it.........well ofc they are going to fix it why wouldn't they. Would I reccommend this game? Well my play time speaks for itself. If you wouldn't enjoy jumping onto a dragons back stabing it's eyes in and then taking your massive Great Sword and slamming it and ripping it out of it's face causing it to fall out of the sky to your fellow hunters or maybe you enjoy a much more lucrative approach setting traps poisoning the monsters favourite meat with various types of ailments. What ever kind of playstyle you want to go for in this game, it has you covered.

author: Ɱᴀʟ​​​ɪᴋᴇɴ ♞

author: Helmic
review: It's an absolutely brilliant game, the most fun I've had in a game in years, with even its most complex and fiddly bits seeming to have real purpose in either driving long term satisfiaction in progression or pacing the game to space out the adrenaline-pumping highs with quiet or relaxed moments where you just need to sharpen your weapon, heal up, and then track down that boss monster again to continue the fight.It's also a game that gets some very critical things wrong in terms of usability, with multiplayer in particular showing the game's online heritage as a Nintendo exclusive.  To have a friend join you in a storyline mission that has cutscenes in it, you must first start the mission, progress far enough in that mission until you have seen all the cutscenes (which can take as long as 20 minutes to accomplish as you'll often be told to find something with limited direction before the relevant cutscene plays), and then you ahve to  and then recreate the mission again so that your friends can join.  Oh, and all your friends have to have seen the cutscene as well themselves, so they all have to be doing the same thing, no exceptions.  This means that playing with friends in anything other than postgame content almost prohibitively time consuming, and since the main campaign where all these shenanigans occur can easily last you 40-60 hours (I'm 90 hours in at the time of writing this review and I still haven't beaten the main campaign yet) a lot of people simply will never reach a point in the game where they can just play the damn game with friends.And that's assuming your connection keeps up.  For what seems to be a peer-to-peer game, everyone I play with suffers from constant disconnections despite clearly still being connected on Steam and on Discord.  Players who are disconnected are then forced to face a boss that's had its HP boosted quite a bit all by themselves. And if you fail the mission because of that disconnect, any resources you spent trying to boost your rewards like vouchers (you get only one a day and can only hold up to five) or investigations are destroyed.Oh, just to make things worse, those scarce vouchers and uses for your investigations are also used the moment you post a mission, whether or not you start it.  You often have to remake a mission because other players can't join it until its remade, so get used to having to choose between your friendships and your willingness to part with your last voucher.  It's needlessly vindictive and punishing for a game that's overly fond of crashing on many people's systems, there's no good reason that those vouchers couldn't just be spent the moment you get your rewards.But I still recommend the game.  It's not in as bad a state as the original Dark Souls at launch, and it's an utterly brilliant game.  It's hard to know what to gush about first: the sheer variety in playstyles afforded by the fourteen different weapon types that all almost play like unqiue genres of games, the exquistiely paced boss fights that alternate between quiet tracking and gathering and loud and bombastic combat, the loving detail put into everything that makes the forests sway in the wind and interact with your hunts or how a Tobi-Kadachi will leave those marks on the trees you find by using them to scratch itself in a lovingly rendered animation, or the massive variety in weapon and armor assets that all have their own niche uses that give you an excuse to collect them all and theorycraft new hyperspecialized builds meant to play a specific role against a single boss, or how item-only progression fixes a lot of problems with level-based progression in RPG's by removing problems like overlevelling or shoehorning you into a specific playstyle forever...It's so hard not to gush about the brilliance of the game, and that makes it so much more painful that the port doesnt' quite do it justice.  It's not even that bad a port, my game has only crashed once in 90 hours of play as I'm using a CPU with FMA3 support - an AMD FX 8350, a CPU that generally doesn't do very good in games but holds a steady 60 FPS at 1080p with a GTX 1070, I can only assume the game's been multithreaded competently.  There's rebinding options and graphic options and little touches that make it clear real effort was put into the PC release.But the parts where it does fail hurts the most, because Monster Hunter is very much a cooperative game at heart and a game with such brilliant interplay between a team and a monster that could easily combo anyone to death that makes one wrong move just doesn't deserve the disconnects, the crashes, the performance issues on different PC's, the horrible UX problems for playing together, the mean-spirited wasting of vouchers and investigations when it's the game that messed up.I still recommend the game.  I still want people to try it, even if it's only for that two hour refund window, because Capcom has promised to support this game and I think people can still love this game despite its serious flaws.  There's just been so much love put into this game that you can feel, the real appreciation for having all these systems interact to create what can only be called fantasy nature porn.  There's what seems to be dozens of lengthy animations of cats cooking you food in the most flamboyant way possible for what amounts to just a buff, thousands and thousands must have been spent just animating that alone.  There's too much effort here to just dismiss it entirely.If the game works on your machine, if you have friends patient enough to deal with the need to use what are effectively even more annoying Friend Codes in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Steam game, if you like Dark Souls-like combat systems, if this game seems interesting to you, this is probably a game you'll want to pay full price for.  But if you're unsure, wait a few weeks and see if these issues have been addressed.

author: seriGawsty
review: First time i tried this game, i found it VERY slow and tiring to play, i tried like a few quests then stopped playing it..a few months later ,curious of what iceborne has brought to the game, i reinstall it and plan to play for a bitso i decided to switch my weapon to something different (was using great sword,which is THE slowest weapon in the game), for me it was the long sword ,and  THAT is where the game clicked for me., i absolutely loved the gameplay of that weapon and was intrigued to try of all its combos and this led to me being more and more interested in the game and its lore and the rest is history... :Dso my point is , if you ever go tired of this game in the beginning, it might be just because of the weapon you chose! ,there are 14 different weapons with each of them having unique movements and combos, i invite you to try all of them in the training area ( go to your room, then talk to the tailraider "cat") TLDR : be patient with the game, choose which weapon suits you best  ,and enjoy the hunt!

author: Katsura9000
review: EDIT 1: I don't get it why people complain about crashes, 40 hours in and I had 0 crashes during any point of the game, or any problem with the save file after the final boss,perhaps it would be a good idea to check your PC or related drivers.Or people not getting to 60FPS on high end systems, i7 6700hq and gtx 1070 and mostly 60FPS ( ultra settings with volumetric fog at low ) or few dips to low 50s when 3 monsters engage in a treesome ( rare thing tho ) .-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------As someone who never played MH before I fell in love with this game from the first hour in.I don't get why people are saying it is a bad PC port:- Sure there's the multiplayer network problems but hopefully we will get that fixed soon.- Runs well on my laptop i7 6700hq/gtx1070, constant 60FPS with a few dips into low 50s, Ultra settings and volumetric fog at low /w Xbox1 controller.- My CPU usage is in the 50-75% range and GPU is about 80-90% usage, to mention that I  capped my frames at 60 for that gsync treat.- But yeah in 15 or so hours of playing I didn't encounter any crashes or bugs.- As for people that complain about mouse control, you are all abosolute madmen, do   yourself a favor and go grab a controller, it's like cheaper than the game.- Tip for Nvidia users, don't get the new driver for MHW ( aka Version 398.82 ) , it will make your game run bad,wait for them to fix it and meanwhile use any previous driver. ( I use 398.11 )

author: DC
review: Monster Hunter is a game about facing large beasts that are stronger, faster, and tougher than you are. However, you have one advantage that stand above them all: You're much SMARTER than them.To find victory and complete your hunt, you'll have to be patient, diligent, but above all else: You'll need to be VERY observant. Skill is optional if you can cleverly utilize your environment, such as knocking down large boulders or luring your prey into bigger, much nastier baddies.If these qualities are not your cup of tea, you will not like this game very much. Otherwise, you'll be addicted and won't stop playing it.The gameplay aside, the story has an innocent and carefree charm, where you play as an agent of a research team that simply wants to know how these monsters tick-- Even if they have to ask you to open up a few of them to find out exactly how. Then, on top of that, the charismatic personality that each monster has is another thing that will draw you into this game; from self-indulging, long-tongued birds and mud-loving puppy-dragons to literal fire-cats and a later ravenous dragon that can't stop itching itself.Even then, you can always just kick back and enjoy the enormous meals the inhabitants eat every day, or maybe catch a few water geckos to put into your personal home.If you're willing to allow yourself to get sucked into another world, you'll greatly enjoy this very aptly named game: Monster Hunter "World".

review: While the gameplay itself is engaging and amazing, Capcom has managed to ruin the launch of a flagship game once more.Servers are abused rodents that cannot handle more than 5minutes of multiplayer and the performance is completely disgusting for what the game offers. The graphics are subpar and actually below console due to bugs and the CPU usage makes you wish you used this game and not Prime95.This is excluding the fact that your whole save can be lost after the final boss if the game crashes during the credits.For now, avoid the game and wait until -if- Capcom fixes the issues, specially if you're a KB/M user, not having the beefiest of rigs or want to play multiplayer.Shamefur dispray, Capcom.

author: Helel
review: MHW is probably the best entry in the series so far. The quality of life improvements and updates to combat make the gameplay so much better than previous games. I love that I don't need to waste inventory space with whetstones, pickaxes, & bug nets. The new monsters are unique and fun to hunt and the equipment looks great. I'm very glad that they added armor transmog. I adore the hunt locales, they're all breathtaking. Compared to previous games, it's much easier to learn how to do everything, and I was able to learn how to use weapons I struggled with much faster and easier than before. It's definitely a great starting point for anyone new to monster hunter to get a taste for the series. That all being said, this is probably my least favorite Monster Hunter game I've played so far. While combat is lot faster and more fun, the non elder dragon hunts all felt very samey and boring pretty quickly. Besides a few amazing songs I overall found the soundtrack to be kinda meh. Hunting monsters for decorations was far more tedious than the talisman farming of past games. The addition of the clutch claw made most of the fights a lot easier and more formulaic.I'm totally stoked for MH Rise, and I hope they bring back the Mizutsune and/or the Lagiacrus.
