author: Squabbey
review: Pros:- Fantastic Gameplay- Weapons feel unique with great feedback- Monster design is interesting and each type feels unique, even variants of the same monster have different bahviours (more aggressive, quicker, different movesets).- Monster animation and design convey behaviour very well.- Sound design is excellent.Cons:- Network issues concerning multiplayer- Due to the nature of the game it is best played on a gamepad (controller). Similar to how RTS should be played on mouse and keyboard.Summary:- Easily game of the year 2018- Small but frustrating (at times) disconnecting issues but these will likely be ironed out soon enough.- Better played with gamepad (controller).

author: Edward Garbagehands
review: With or without the Iceborne expansion this game is still a great deal of fun. Every monster has been lovingly crafted to deliver plenty of challenge while still providing a fulfilling, cinematic experience and with the many different weapon types and skill combinations at your disposal, you are bound to find a playstyle that works for you.Special mention to the community, which is one of the best I have ever had the pleasure of being a part of out of all of the games I have tried in the past. Not once did I ever feel I was paired with someone toxic, and I have never met a dedicated griefer (although the game already makes it hard to do that anyways).

author: Clearly
review: Am not experiencing connectivity issues since the Aug. 23 patch, a very solid multiplayer experience. My internet speed is 14MB/s down, 5.5MB/s up. As of this review, I have 25 hours on the game, and have done an upwards of 100 multiplayer lobbies. So far, I have DC'd in the middle of just 1 of them. Only 1 of them and this is from a pool of 100 multiplayer lobbies. I would say they have fixed the connectivity issues, but I am just one opinion of many. Others may feel like this game is just as broken as it were when it first launched, but I say this is a very enjoyable game with friends and strangers alike. Aside from the connectivity being fixed, this game is jam packed with a variety of activities to do in the many zones avaliable (I'm just 25 hours in and I feel like I'm not close to beating the main questline yet). Missions range from killing small creatures, to zone bosses, to arena with bosses, to time attack, to open world exploration, to a lot more. As you play the game you unlock more missions that not only let you discover new materials for new armor/weapons, but some of these materials can be used to upgrade the quality of life things at the main town.Gameplay is fun and extremely engaging with both the environment and players (the game heavily rewards those who explore the world rather than those who rush through the game). Utilizing the environment to gain the upper hand, when defeating bosses will make the fight a lot easier. Using the SOS flare to get people into your quest/expeditions not only enhances your experience, but challenges you as well. Movement is fluid and feels very much like dark souls, where you would do 1 2 strikes and roll out of the way and do more 1 2 strikes again and then roll out of the way. If you're feeling confidient, you can do your hard hitting attacks that would leave you vulnerable to incoming attacks. There is such a thing as "animation trap", where if you do an attack or action, you would be stuck in that attack or action animation until the animation is done. This is very important because it forces the player to be smart with their actions, so its not just a mindless button mashing hack and slash game. The community is helpful and will try to cooperate with you. From my 100 multiplayer lobbies, I have not ran into a single troll. Those who join you to aid you will actually aid you.Lastly, controllers arent required, but would make your combos a lot easier to do. I've found little to no issues with keyboard and mouse, however keyboard and mouse do require you to be more precise with your inputs to achieve what you want to do.

author: Astral Medic
review: Never played a Monster Hunter game before in my life but this game is absolutely amazing and extremely addictive. The combat is fun and satisfying and the game has a serious plot but is quirky and very enjoyable. The game has had some network issues recently but it hasn't affected me too much at all. I can still join others online and request others to my game successfully. Only the occassional error for me. But I hear it's an issue with steam and they are on the way with fixes so that's goo news. Otherwise, amazing gameplay, epic large scale battles, fun as hell to play with others, and makes you feel like a badass! Even with the small network issues, I can still recommend this game.I'm not one to care too much about a PC port as others so yes there are also PC port issues, but they don't bother me so I can't take those into consideration. The game is fun and it has me hooked and that's all I ask for. Plus you have a walking cat as a companion (called a Palico) and a canteen of cat chefs that cook for you in an amazing cutscene. It's the little things in the game you have to love.

author: Hollow_Knight
review: Finally, Monster Hunter on PC!-The GoodAn excellent (and much awaited) update to the Monster Hunter formula that keeps all the good bits and cuts down on a lot of the busy-work of previous games, making it much more accessible to newcomers to the franchise, and keeping it enjoyable for the veterans.If you've never played Monster Hunter, this is the one to start with.Capcom have already released a load of free new content on the console versions, which is scheduled to make its way to the PC in the near future.-The (potentially) Bad.The PC version really is a great port but does require a powerful all-round machine to play on high settings, not just a good GPU.  At time of writing I have had absolutley no issues with crashes or frame dips.  Capcom have acknowledged the connection issues and are supposedly addressing them.  For my part, I found multiplayer generally works really well, but may require you to open your router ports.Do keep in mind that playing the game entirely solo is both totally possible and immensely rewarding in it's own way.

author: Hatouli
review: Pretty fun. i've pretty much done everything I can do. But I still play. That's how much fun the game is. If you enjoy using big weapons to hit even bigger monsters then you will like this game.The story is meh but it's a monhun game so story never was a focus in the series because the story is just a tool to show you the monsters one by one and teach you the basics of the game.The real game starts after the story. You will most likely beat the story in 100 hours or less and then your next 200+ hours will be events, grinding and learning new weapons. if that's not your schtik don't bother.DON'T GO FOR CROWNS UNLESS YOU DESPISE BEING SANE

author: Bean
review: I've had my concerns about an old game like monster hunter, but once i started playing the game I instantly liked it. The fighting system in this game is very nice with a variety of different play styles.  The game is also very rewarding if effort is put in. I recommend this game to anyone who's loves a game that has a good story related adventure and a just a fun calming but exciting open world experience.Also best to get the game when its on sale, cause I did and I very little mooonneeeyy.

author: Kess
review: Game is very good, the combat is fun and fluidThe content provided allows for numerous hundreds of hours of gameplay, the end game grind is surprisingly "not boring" either. This includes hunting monsters, mastering and adapting to the 14 weapon types that the game throws at you and then creating a variety of builds for said weapons, or to purely just have funGranted, the story isn't really the best, but it exists just for progression purposes (lets be honest, no one plays Monster Hunter for the story anyway)Don't let the mixed reviews fool you, it's just due to the recent review bombing of people getting offended over an insensitive joke from the Monster Hunter movie that is merely a nationality pun, even then they should've done it on websites that relates DIRECTLY to the movie, the game devs have nothing to do with it.Get the game if you're into whacking monsters in the head with a big stick, that or you're yearning for some "souls-like"combat fun

author: Sailor Darkness
review: Original review reflected state the game initially launched in. I no longer get nearly as many disconnects to the point I believe it may be fixed. I'll be changing my review to a thumbs up.The game is absolutely beautiful and even though you go through the same island hundreds of times it never gets old. There's always a sense of wonder/adventure and if you look hard enough you will find something new! The story of the game is kind of meh (maybe due to translation, maybe just trying to keep a lower ESRB rating) but the gameplay itself can help with that. You might go through one canyon one time and get obliterated by some monsters, so the next time you decide "well maybe I'll try this cave opening and see where it goes, maybe I can go around". I find myself talking to my Feyline companion a lot of the times when in uncharted areas or when theres a very powerful monster around. You sort of get the sense even though you're out on "quests/investigations/expeditions" you are the master as well as player of the story unfolding in the current zone. The Zones, animals, and even armor/weapons are for the most part beautiful. Some of the monsters seem to follow a theme which I suppose makes sense, but personally I wouldn't mind some more outlandish looking ones. The elder dragons in the late game make up for it though. The map of each zone feels very natural but at the same time is structured in a way that makes you think decide mid sprint which path is the best to take to get to where you need to go. It can be missed in the heat of a chase, but the scenery is so well done you truly feel like you're in a desert, forest, highland range, etc... The weapons and armor range from bland to so beautiful you want to stop everything and just farm for that partcular thing. They truly shine towards the late game where you have everything unlocked, so don't be disappointed if every weapon you are using looks like a plain metal/bone weapon with some locks of monster hair glued on there at first. :P That will change! Speaking of grinding, the last thing I want to mention is that this is the only game I've played that understands what kind of game it is - it understands its a grind and embraces it. In games notorious for grinding, which are still decent-great games, you feel the grind. You dread it. In this one, you crave it. You want to get back out on a hunt. Even if its for a monster you've killed 100+ times you want to go back and bash it's face in with a powerful weapon you just made as payback for the dozens of times he killed you when the two of you first met. Don't let that idea spoil the your expectations for the first kill of every monster though. It will be the toughest part of the game, and you never lose that sense of accomplishment all the way through. Even while you're leveled up and bullying the once terrifying monster, you think in the back of your mind that not too long ago the situation was reversed. The ways to go about encountering that monster are very versatile and you can set up your own quest and prepare (or jump right in) and gather party members to help, or even go solo... However, I prefer dropping into a player's quest who has shot an SOS flare. I like feeling like I'm helping out, and, truth be told, I'm a bit of a showoff so I like lower level players to look at my armor/ weapons and be amazed at how well and how cool I look lol. I'm not a fan of the X/10 ratings system or anything like that, but I will say if you like adventure, if you like character creation and customization, and you dont mind having to use your imagination for a story you can get lost in then this game will provide you with hours upon hours of enjoyment. (Friends to play with make the game interesting and play a totally different way, but it's in no way a requirement. You can have fun just playing solo if that's your thing.)Original review follows:--------Wait until they fix the multiplayer connection issues to buy. The best part is playing with your friends or shooting an SOS flare to have people come help you when the battle gets too intense. You cant do that if you get an error message that can't be fixed until you restart the game, and then your friends have to create a new lobby because it's bugged from your error code. I'm betting it's Denuvo because nearly all multiplayer and cpu usage bugs can be traced back to that POS program. I'm no game dev though so whatevs, could just be capcom dropped the ball. Other than all that bug BS it's a fantastic game. When this gets fixed it's worth a buy. In its current state, it's not.

author: PrimusAvatar
review: After 250+ hours on PS4 and reaching my 100 hour mark on MH:W on PC, as well as having played previous entries in the series on different platforms - I think I'm finally qualified to voice an oppinion.What newcommers to the series might be expecting:You saw the trailers and thought that this is just a sunny version of Dark Souls or something. Even though they emphasized some common elements in the marketing materials this couldn't be more further from the truth. Both the setting and the gameplay are very different. MH:W is a game you can play solo or with firends, working together, not against each other, towards a common goal. Enemies come in all shapes, sizes, evolutions and with all kinds of fun abilities but there's more to this game than just whaking a lizard on its head.A cute and powerful Cat companion (the species is called "Palicoes") levels up beside you and ensures you're never facing those dangers alone even when you're not playing with other players. You can customize it, and up to 2 players can play together with their cats.Why is the cat impotrant in my review? I played with several firends and I've noticed that they weren't sold on the game until they relized that it's not that bleak of a setting and most of them were cat lovers, so there you have it :)Gameplay stuff:As you progress through the game, more and more gameplay features become available. 50 hours in on both PC and PS4 i was still unlocking new stuff. To me this is a big plus because it keeps the game fresh seemingly all the time. I won't spoil the engdame but I'll just say it's very fun.Is it grindy? Yes, but not as much as you'd expect. Some MMO's, ARPG's and F2P games are grindy in a very unfun way. This isn't. The difference is what you're woking towards and how ofthen you're rewarded in a meaningful way. This game always showers you with gameplay-changing rewards and still manages to stay interesting well into the deep endgame. They achieved this by having 14 weapon tech trees, dozens of armor sets and dozens of ways to make of of those aforementioned things work in very different ways. This means that even if you didnt get a drop of that thing you wanted you'll commonly get other fun stuff you havent experienced yet.Those 14 weapons are easy to use but hard to master, each of them changes the way you play in vastly different ways.Visually:As a game engine developer I can tell that the engine itself doesn't feature almost any of the modern featues you'd expect from AAA projects, but so did Breath of the Wild, and both team's artists managed to visualise those games in such ways that they seem a heck of a lot better than the engineers probably expected. :) The level design is georgeous, extremly well constructed and visual deficiencies are very well hidden.Animation:While cinematic animations on humans are subpar, the monster animations and combat movements are among the best that anyone could offer at this point. Only by playing the game yourself will you actually feel the vast difference.Sound:Apart from some weird choices (horse sounds on purple wolf/panther monsters) the combat sounds are very well balanced and interesting. The soundtrack is amazing and I listen to it very often.

author: Chiro-Ice-San
review: TLDR: Game is repetitive, but that's the point, grinding the same monster over and over to gain better equip. If u r not a fan of that, don't buy this game. The story is plain and simple and feels like it was made onlz for sake of having in game. I didn't like the characters at all, all are forced. There are some bugs now and then, but my biggest issue was terrible hitbox on many weapons/mosnters. But still one playthrough of it was enjoyable, so if u don't mind grind, give it a try in some sale.Pros: -Customization of character is pretty solid and complex-Variety of monsters, armors and weapons with ton of movesets.-Coop, players in base making it slightly more alive.-Interesting biomes/maps with more to do then just killing big monsters-small tasks like gardening, research, etc.-Great for lovers of grindy games.Cons:-There are some minor bugs or texture glitches (at least I experienced them)-HITBOXES ARE BROKEN. Not only those of monsters but yours as well. Many time you will be glad you managed to hit monster even tho it shouldn't but it will also happen vice versa. Monsters many times were not even near touching me but I got hit. It was infuriating. This is not a bug, this is just lazy. It took a lot of fun from many fights for me.- PC is getting major events in great delay compared to consolesEven tho there's ton of armors, also in ng+ I dislike a lot of them so I didn't find grinding after finishing story for the first time appealing. (this is rather my opinion only, ur might differ)In the end I would give this game 7/10. It's not bad but it's not that amazing as I hoped it to be. Like I said minor bugs and broken hitboxes were too annoying and the grind felt unrewarding in ng+. It's worth getting in some sale. I got it in 50% for 30 €.

author: Nipz
review: This is another entry in the Monster Hunter series but very polished and with new mechanics. Its very fun for beginners to the Monster Hunter series and veterans alike. As a long time fan of the Monster Hunter series, I feel beginning of this game is very easy and that's good. I'm used to the rough starts that the old games used to give us. This would traditionally throw off any new players however this one gently puts you into the groove of a hunter and I think that's fantastic.Whether you are a new player or a veteran hunter, you will enjoy this game. Who doesn't like to go on a hunt for a big monster with their trusty helper cat companion?I recommend this game because of all the helpful tutorials to get started and staying faithful to what a Monster Hunter game should be. It is very fun and I expect to lose a lot of time on it.

author: Johnny Cool
review: If you like games with great build variety and complexity this is the game for you. The world is a living breathing Ecosystem and everything from the smallest of bug to the largest of Wyverns can be captured.  If you are a fan of RPGs with a lot of gear grinding, as well as worlds to fully immerse yourself in MH:W is currently the best game on the market.For reference - this is my first MH game and I come from a backround of playing many RPGs, MMORPGs, and ARPGs.

author: Pawpatine
review: It's sad to say, that most of the negative reviews are not wrong. The launch of this is highly disappointing after waiting so long for it. We were promised a good port for the wait, we were delivered crap. The gameplay itself is amazing, I LOVE monster hunter games. Played nearly every one thats been out. Keyboard controls : I honestly don't understand the issue people have with keyboard controls, it took a little to get used to, but they're fine imho. I'd argue better than any of the keyboard controls for the souls series.Optimization : This game is hit or miss, you either got lucky and have a cpu/gpu the game likes, or you don't. I'm running an i7-6700k and a 1080TI and barely pull over 100 FPS with a few options disabled. Considering my setup, I honestly find this disappointing, there's no reason I shouldn't get 144 FPS on my 1080p monitor, but i can get passed that as really I stay over 60 and thats all that matters.The networking... my god.. the networking. "Disconnected" is all you'll see your steam do, for some reason it's steam thats getting caused to dc over and over until finally you're dropped out of online sessions. Have yet to find a fix for this, tried changing the region in steam itself, did nothing. I've maybe had one session of staying online for more than one quest with people. Pretty rediculous.I love the game, but I can fully understand people not being happy with this port. Even more so if you're not a fan of MH, because if you're not a fan of MH in general you aren't pushing the unhappiness back with "FINALLY A PC VERSION."For the love of god capcom, fix it. This could be HUGE for MH if you fix it in a timely fashion, starting with the disconnects!!!

author: Swoop
review: I decided to wait a week or so before writing this review - it is easy to get triggered over port/launch growing pains, especially over a title as huge as Monster Hunter.Quick and Dirty - huge thumbs up. It's an extremely fun game for folks new to the series that eases you in to the life before trying to murder you.Details: The game staggered out the door with pretty debilitating connectivity issues that prevented people from playing together.  Most of the reviews were made during this time, so I feel, at a glance, they don't represent the game well.  Capcom has patched since, and tho there are still a few connectivity issues, I haven't had any now in almost 20 hours of gameplay since the fix went live.If you've never played Monster Hunter before (like me), the idea is very simple.  You hunt monsters and use their loot to  make better armor and weapons so that you can go out  and hunter meaner monsters for better loot and armor.  It's a simple template, but ohhhhh so satisfying.There is a plethora of armor, weapons, augments, and skill gems, which are very diverse - huge 2 handed swords, daggers, sword n board, huge slow firing guns, agile guns, the bow of course, and the unique weapons like the insect glaive.  My point is that this game can cater to almost any playstyle.The fights themselves are intense. You can spend 10-30 minutes just on one hunt and not breathe for at least half of that time.  Each new monster seems challenging, tho going back to them once you've been at it a while  just makes you shake your head at the thought that these cute little things were ever scary.Single Player is definitely a thing.  The monsters aren't quite as aggressive and are dialed back a bit. You can bring your trusty Palico with you  - a cat pretty much, that can buff/help you in a few ways.  It's a nice way to play if you have to be offline or if you just enjoy the solo challenge.  It's definitely more forgiving than previous Monster Hunters when it comes to solo play.Multi-Player is where it's at for me.  You can have up to 4 players on a hunt.  If you have just 2 players, your Palico's can join you.  There is just something really great about throwing down against these huge monsters with 3 other people that is so satisfying.The game still has some performance quirks to work out, especially for folks wanting to get the most out of their PCs.  I am not one to crucify a game because it isn't a virtual reality masterpiece.  It is a beautiful game on my 970 and runs at 60fps.. and that is enough for me.That's pretty much it.  If you read this far, thank you, and I really hope you enjoy Monster Hunter: World if you decide to give it a shot - I know I did!

author: Revalopod
review: Monster Hunter: World is an incredible action RPG with a breathtaking world to explore, featuring compelling combat against massive magnificent monsters. It consists of a simple core loop: kill monsters to get gear and then kill more monsters to get better gear. Exploring the world is a huge joy in and of itself, with its highly detailed environment and roaming inhabitants. The combat is fast and frenetic, and killing monsters is rewarding and fun. The audio is very good, with satisfying damage sounds, and the music is epic. Unfortunately the story and characters feel quite underwhelming compared to the rest of the game. - Monster Hunter: World has some incredibly impressive looking visuals. The environments are fantastically lush and vibrant which makes them a pleasure to explore. Everywhere you go there’s impressive scenery to behold, but there’s also a plethora of small details such as little insects that really help make this world feel alive. The big monsters are a huge enjoyment to fight thanks in part to their fluid animations and highly detailed textures. The monsters are also visually coherent with the environment, which helps immerse you into the fantastical world. - The music is epic and well orchestrated, and sounds quite good. But the best part of the audio is the sounds: the sound effects offer great feedback during combat and the ambience and creature sounds are great. - After quite an extensive tutorial, you will get the opportunity to explore the massive world at leisure. What I really like about the world is how dense and detailed it is; it does a great job at making you feel tiny and insignificant. Scattered throughout this world are numerous native creatures, including some large monsters that require you to track them down by finding clues. The fauna isn’t the only thing you can hunt; there’s also plenty of plants and ores scattered about that are essential to crafting or upgrading gear. The collection of items is swift and satisfying and rarely slows you down, so it’s desirable to harvest everything in sight.A great feature about Monster Hunter: World is that the monsters aren’t just a living loot container waiting to be harvested. They actually interact with the environment and can even duel other monsters. Observing one large monster viciously scrabble against an even larger monster is always exciting. Killing the monsters yourself feels rewarding, as combat takes quite a bit of skill to master. The combat doesn’t always feel fluid, with some moves feeling sluggish to respond, but it is always fast and frenetic and highly enjoyable. Every corpse can be harvested for parts, and you can then use these parts to craft or upgrade gear. The main hub area, Astera, is fairly large and is where you’ll be spending time initiating quests, crafting gear and other preparations. Here you can also cook food, release pets into your room, and find squads. The character customisations is quite good, and you can also customise your own little Palico companion. You can choose from a huge assortment of unique weapons, which include dual wielded blades, sword and shield, or a bowgun to name a few. Each weapon has quite a large upgrade tree, which is fun to progress through. From monster parts you can craft new armour, and these usually posses stats consistent with the monster its made from. While exploring the world, you have access to numerous useful tools, and can craft and consume potions on the fly. Your melee weapon loses sharpness during combat, so you need to frequently sharpen it. Sometimes it felt this gear management detracted from the gameplay experience, but only slightly. Overall, the gameplay is hugely enjoyable. - You are a hunter who is part of the Fifth Fleet, and your job is to support the Research Commission in unraveling the mysterious surrounding  New World. Your main focus is discovering why the Elder Dragons migrate to New World every decade. You are accompanied by a Palico, which is a little catlike creature, and you also receive help and guidance from several other NPCs. The story is interesting but not particularly great, and the characters are quite basic.  - Monster Hunter: World is a very demanding game that is taxing on even the strongest PCs. Even a GTX 1070 struggles to maintain 60FPS on the highest settings. - The campaign will last quite a long time, but there’s so much more replayability besides that. I could easily see myself exceeding a hundred hours in this game Yes, Monster Hunter: World is a great looking and incredibly fun game, with plenty of content.Monster Hunter: World is a fantastic action RPG with an incredible world to explore and immerse yourself in.I give this game a 9/10

author: golw
review: The boss fights can be really cinematic, and are tremendous fun the first time or two, but become fairly repetitive after that. The story, setting, characters and anything outside of raw mechanics is easily forgotten, and uncomfortably juvenile. The fluff of this game is the kind that reminds me of a childhood playing video games but not in a friendly nostalgic way, more of a "I can't believe I ever thought this wasn't stupid" kind of way.Playing this game, I see an absolute mountain of potential. The core gameplay of hunting a monster is great. Finding the clues, identifying creatures, following tracks, locating nests, surveying the environment, locating hazards, laying traps, and generally figuring out the best way to kill this creature before engaging in exciting and very long, arduous battles; its all amazing. Where the game falls short is that it isn't a low budget indie game directed by a single team with a single vision, because this game is a huge mess of the most embarassing and anime cliches that do nothing to benefit the game and everything to detract from it. If you've got $60 to spare, and really enjoy MMO style grind, I would reccomend the game as a fun play once you get through the absurdly lengthy tutorial portion. However, if you plan to play this with friends, I wouldn't suggest it unless you and your friends are all very patient. The non-gameplay parts of the game are so mind numbingly stupid I can't comprehend how a company as big as CAPCOM allowed it to happen. It's so bad that I feel they need to issue a public apology to anyone who bought the game, and anyone who has been a fan of their products. That this is a console port is not an acceptable excuse for how pisspoor the interface is. Even when you finally figure out how to play with your friends, the execution is so clunky, that it still fails to work about half the time.If you're anything like me, you'll play the game for a week and enjoy parts of it, and generally kind of have fun playing it. You'll get a lot of hours out of it during that one week; and after that, you'll feel that there's really nothing worth replaying it for, because even though you may have new armors and new weapons to grind, they don't actually do anything new, or change the game at all.

author: Recoson
review: Review - Using Xbox360 controller Pros-+Controller worked fine no issues (others have had issues, mainly ps4 controllers)+Ultra-wide seemed fine 21:9 at 3440x1440 on fullscreen (again, other ppl had problems with ultra-wide not sure)+Game is complicated, high reward in learning high difficulty weapons.+Awesome environments+Crafting system is expansive+So many viable builds, all better adapted to different situations+Coop is fun once you get it working+Monsters are unique and fun to fightCons-+Optimisation is a problem for those with low-end PC's, make sure to turn off volumetric rendering for huge FPS boost, couldn't run on max settings at 60 fps with 2 gtx 1080 SLI and AMD Ryzen 7 1800x Eight-core Processor (am running res at 3440x1440 though), but once volumetric rendering was off perfectly fine solid 60fps. +Coop online UI is a little ♥♥♥♥♥, not a major issue.+Game pretty much needs TAA turned on, so it will be a bit blurry but the jagged edges in this are way worse than most other games, also appears to have no motion-blur on/off option which is annoying, but you can get used to it.NEW PROBLEM: Game has massive connection problems right now, i'm leaving a positive review because the game is still fun overall even solo, but coop right now is almost unplayable. just constant error codes.Overall, 8.5/10 really filled a hole for me in terms of games that I was lacking. Just need to optimise certain settings and overall more video options so people can get their desired look from the game.

author: Daemonicus
review: Personal Rating: Must Play : 9/10Value for money: Priced a bit expensive, a must buy on discountPlay-time:- Campaign: 20 - 35+ hours depending on skill/gear balance / Multiplayer: Endless until you've farmed everythingPros:- Very accessible for new comers to genre, lots of quality of life change to series- 14 different weapons, quite a number which plays very differently- Gorgeous graphics and huge maps- NPC feel very different, though play little purpose in game/story - except your buddy palico- Decent keyboard and mouse controls for a game with strong history on controller focus - Controllers support for those who dislike playing with kb+m- Slower, harder but more rewarding combat (Versus Dauntless more arcadey/action oriented playstyle)- Has just the right amount of depth without being too complex- Great support for builds and tips available, min-maxs players will enjot their time - Grindy fun, if you enjoy it- Fun events, even has a Witcher 3 & DMC collaboration events- Great for playing solo or multi-player- A fair number of multiplayer games available to join anytime- Monster are different enough in patterns to always keep you on your toes- Very atmospheric, and fun to watch monsters battle each other (turf wars)- Sound design is great: monster roars, sound effects and music does not disappoint- Game rewards twitch reaction and skill- Mods are available for the PC, though no official supportCons:- Requires a decent computer to play- A lot fewer monsters compared to previous games- Re-occuring events are time based, somewhat annoying, especially if you're after that one specific event- Wonky match making / multiplayer / connectivity still- RNG plays a great part in loot rewards - decorations, monster drops, Kulve Taroth- Short play through, if your goal is to beat the story only- Story used as an excuse to hunt everything, this is no Titanafall 2- Weapon designs aren't as cool or interesting in this iteration- Weird story design - friends are not able to join mission until criteria is met (unfriendly co-op aspect)- Multiplayer difficulty scaling - If you're disconnected in a multiplayer game, get to solo the extra difficulty- PC version receives updates slower than console counterpart- Vegans and monster lovers should avoid this gameI am quite biased to Monster Hunter, which I had picked up when it first appeared on the Nintendo 3DS.This game is not without its flaws, but I feel the pros far outweight it. The game feels a lot more streamlined than previous iterations and is a large step forward. I played about 75% of the time solo, and had equally as much fun on multiplayer. The upcoming expansion pack will be a must buy for me, and we'll have a good few months to review it on the consoles first to truly evaluate it.There were previously demos to give you a taste of the game, which I think they should've added to this as well. The game will need a bit of time for one to understand the nuances; and once you have that part down, you'll truly enjoy the game. Mastering the fight against any particular monster gives you the rush of satisfaction and this feeling stays all the way till end-game. If you can get over the technical aspect of the cons, this game will not disappoint.

author: Malachite Orange
review: MHW is a fun game with lots of contant and many hours of gameplay, I would recommend it to friends if only the issues regarding constant disconnections is fixed. For a game advertised as an online multiplayer game I shouldn't constantly have to restart a new multiplayer session every 20 minutes because of disconnects.

author: Gio.UNG
review: Love this game! Over 600 hours now and it's been an awesome experience.  The game offers lots of great challenges. It has a long learning curve since most of the weapons are very different from each other. Once you master your  weapons the fighrs get very satisfying. Aside from challenges it can be relaxing and enjoyable experience especially when helping lower level sos calls or just chilling in guiding lands (Iceborne endgame content)Playing in a full party of 4 is the best way to experience the game for me but solo hunts are fun too.I highly recommend this to anyone who loves challenging games that requires precision, timing and patience. Battles with each monster is different so plan the quest, research the monster you're hunting, take the right gear/equipment, and skills. Happy hunting!

author: The Footlong Fart™©
review: Honest review the game is solid,  there has been a lot of hate for the anti piracy use of deunovo and i don't agree with the use but it hasn't affected the gameplay at all. It runs solidly no crashes and no stuttering or frame rate drops. There are some issues with the connectivity of multiplayer which is really annoying because this game shines with multiplayer. As usual there is a lot of people who just jump on the bandwagon of the new shiny hype game.  This game is hard it's frustrating and fun at the same time, but you need to understand it is also grindy. The controls are not janky it's skill you need to time your hits to counter hard hitting fast monsters.  People lack this understanding and complain if you can push yourself over that learning hurdle you'll find a fantastic community with heaps of content and as you get better more difficult monsters to fight. Also PALICO FASHION is a thing, if you get stuck look up a guide don't complain. 8/10 solid port some connectivity issues otherwise it's stable and fun.

author: The Not-So-Silent Mage
review: Monster Hunter World is, all things considered, a fantastic video game with few flaws.It is the answer to the rather specific question "What if you took the boss fights from your adventure games and just made them the entire game?" Turns out, it makes a very fun game.The game is visually spectacular, and its soundtrack is lively and colourful, but don't let all that dazzle distract you - this game entirely revolves around its gameplay - the moment-to-moment, giant monster fighting. It has a combat system that's easy to learn but hard to master, allowing newbies to just jump in and play the game with friends but rewarding veterans who take their time to study and prepare.The game is hard, but fair. You'll end up failing once in a while, and even that's the best case scenario. However, the game leaves around many clues on how you can always improve, or get better, which makes it a fun game.One of this game's coolest features is its extensive lineup of monsters, as they are called. In reality, they are just fantasy dinosaurs. They act very realistically, with fight-or-flight tactics, preferred territories and prey, etc. A vast part of the gameplay is tracking them, studying their habits, weaknesses and abilities, movement, and understanding how to overpower them.The world is also vast and beautiful, with many secrets to uncover and things to find.The game's story is simple and weak, but not a lot of gametime is dedicated to it so it's no biggie. The biggest problem with the game is the difficulty curve. There isn't a very good tutorial, and the game is very complex and deep. Without proper research, players may end up making things harder for themselves or not even know about some features the game has to offer.I'd recommend this game to anybody who likes difficult action-adventure games, or for someone looking for a game with real meat to sink their teeth into. If you're looking for an epic, intruiging story, or can't stand a difficult experience, steer clear.

author: DarkFenix
review: The pros:Well, it's Monster Hunter. It's  come to PC, where it should stay.The cons:Well, it's Capcom. That means an otherwise excellent game marred by sloppy QA, lazy porting, and slow patching.Overall:In spite of the game's technical flaws (for me it crashes a lot when minimising, and is always disconnecting) it's still awesome fun, still worth buying (though not at Steam's exorbitant price, seriously, go to other licensed sellers), and definitely still worth playing.

author: Wolfguarde
review: The game's excellent, the port currently is not. Severe networking issues that remain unfixed, some crippling performance issues for players at the low end of the hardware range for the game, and a general lack of developer communication are really hurting the launch.That said, disregarding the state of the port, the game's improved on (or simply fixed) many of the small quality of life issues that made previous titles less enjoyable. Items can be set to autocraft upon picking up their materials during missions, hitboxes on almost every monster are now realistic instead of large boxes around limbs, heads, and feet that hit you from metres away. The dodge iframe window for the player seems to be smaller, but this is somewhat less of an issue than it would be if the aforementioned hitbox issues hadn't been fixed. Tranqs now throw at the player's feet rather than through the air, and affect the area around their point of impact, making captures significantly easier. Plates and gems are possible to meld with Wyverian prints.The lack of G rank content is something of a downer, though we may see it in the future. I was also expecting a much wider range of monsters (many of the older monsters appear to be missing from the game, though I've yet to clear the hunter rank grind to confirm this). There's much to be said for or against the game, and ultimately the only reason this is getting a thumbs up is because there's no middle option.If you're running a good rig, give the game a go. If you're running something on the lower end of the hardware range, consider waiting a few weeks for the developers to either iron out the problems or show they're not going to.

Hope the devs keep updating this title.Currently there's a fair amount of bugs which are affecting a variety of people, with the biggest / major problem being connectivity. People who purchased the game are rightly frustrated that they're unable to play with their friends.Port forwarding the monster hunter ports seems to have helped with connectivity issues for me personally and haven't suffered connection drops while playing with friends.If you're planning on playing the game solo the majority of the time, your probably fine purchasing the game in its current state. Otherwise, I'd keep an eye out for patches and purchase the game once the connectivity issues have been resolved.

author: Deos
review: I have never reviewed a game on steam before. Between laziness, and not really wanting to use the social side of steam for anything other than personal friends, it just wasn't something I saw worth doing.However, I love monster hunter. World got me into the game, and introduced me to a wonderful series. I am now playing through MHGU to experience the old world hunting style, and anxiously await Rise for when it comes out. World is not a perfect game. I have screamed at, called bull on it (looking at you MR Kulve timer) and struggled through every fight available, from LR Great Jagras to Fatalis. I dislike the clutch claw, I dislike the cut scenes being forced single player, but that doesn't matter. All in all I love Monster hunter. When I heard that people were hating on this game because of a movie made by another group, a movie I haven't seen even if I am planning too, then I felt I had to do my part to maintain the positive image that this beautiful game deserves.Over 500 hours in, and I have to say that it was worth every minute of struggle, rage, and tears that led to a glorious triumph. Extreme Behemoth, Ancient Leshen, Raging Brachydios, Alatreaon, Fatalis, the Arch-tempered and so many more.Monster Hunter is a 10/10 game that will forever live on in my heart as a true treasure.

author: AKU
review: I've never played a Monster Hunter title before. I randomly stumbled upon MH:W on the store page and thought to myself : "Hey, why not give it a shot, maybe you will play it for day or two".Looks like I was wrong.... Why is it so fun to hit big monsters with big sticks?Its honestly one of the best games I've played in the last couple of years. Once you get over the relatively small learning curve and start to get good at the game it just feels so incredibly satisfying. The sound design of breaking parts of a monster, the moment when you topple it and it flails around helplessly or just succeeding on a grapple attack with the Iceborne grapple makes you feel like such a badass.The design of the monsters themselves is just gorgeous. From an overgrown fat gecko, to a giant T-Rex that looks like a giant pickle, to an evil traditional dragon, some of them more deadly than others. The pseudo realistic way they are portrayed makes them stand out from "normal" fantasy creations and makes it so much more satisfying to actually learn their weak spots. No monsters feels the same (Rathalos, Azure Rathalos, and so on  somewhat do, but manage to feel different in their own unique fighting styles) making every hunt unique in itself. Once you jump into multiplayer with friends or strangers, it starts to just feel like animal cruelty against the monsters. If you have a group that actually knows what they are doing it, the difficulty gets kind of easy but it never stops being satisfying, even if its just 4 dudes whacking on a permanently toppled monster.This game made me forever want more monsters to hunt and makes me hope that we will get another Monster Hunter title for the PC in the future.Also.. ♥♥♥♥ the Handler...

author: Flipperi80
review: Ender-lohikäärme eli Ender Dragon on Minecraft 1.0.0 -päivityksen mukana peliin lisätty end-ulottuvuudessa elävä Minecraftin päävastus. Se on toinen Minecraftin päävastuksista: toinen niistä on Wither. Sen tekstuuri muistuttaa Endermania mustalta väriltään ja violeteilta silmiltään.SisällysluetteloTietoaPudotuksetTaisteluBugitTriviaaKatso myösTietoaKun Ender-lohikäärme on lähellä, peliruudun yläosaan ilmestyy violetti "Boss Health" -palkki, joka kuvaa Ender-lohikäärmeen HP:n määrää. "Boss Health" -palkin yläpuolelle tulee teksti  ender-lohikäärme tai ender-dragon. endissä on aina vain yksi Ender-lohikäärme, joka saa lisää elinvoimaa obsidiaanipilarien päällä olevista ender-kristalleista.Ender-lohikäärmeen kuollessa se tiputtaa kokemuspalloja. Lisäksi silloin voi mennä pois endistä, koska paluuportaali on vapaana. Portaaliin mennessä Minecraftin lopputekstit ilmestyvät näkyviin (lopputekstit voi ohittaa "Esc" -näppäimellä tai Playstation 3 tai 4 versiossa ympyrällä ja pelaaja spawnaa takaisin ylämaailmaan sänkynsä viereen (mutta vain jos pelaaja on nukkunut siinä) tai paikkaan, johon pelaaja syntyi. Tämän jälkeen endiin voi mennä vapaasti takaisin, mutta sinne ei enää spawnaa Ender-lohikäärmettä paitsi, jos on asentanut modin, joka mahdollistaa ender-lohikäärmeen spawnaamisen lohikäärmeen munasta, käyttämällä huijausta "summon Ender_Dragon" tai spawnaamalla se uudestaan neljällä itsecraftatulla end-kristallilla.

author: Vincent Vanille
review: This is a tough game for me to make a review on, I've dropped this game twice out of frustration or apathy, and I've picked it up three times in a row over the span of two years, constantly fighting with this game. As all of my mutuals enjoyed it, I didn't seem to, and they talked about how fun it was, yet I didn't. I just struggled with it, as someone who never played a MH game, and more importantly someone who was never too fond of farming all that much it seemed like a gem of a game I just wouldn't be able to enjoy.But I can now definitively say after almost 175 hours logged that Monster Hunter World is an amazing game.My review won't be glossing over technical issues too much because I have a low/mid-end rig, and so any complaints I could be making would be a toss-up between poor optimization, or just hardware limitations, and you could find complaints about netcode and other issues on thousands of other reviews, and I think they're valid because me and my friends struggled at ends for hours just to do a full hunt together in multiplayer.This review is coming from the standpoint of solo hunts from Jagras to Nergigante, and the bits of multiplayer I've logged in with friends.The most crucial thing to mention when it comes to MHW is weapon choice is vital to your enjoyment of the game. To get into it, you need to find the thing that fits you even down to combos or movement. Going into the training area in Astera gives you access to all of this. In my attempts where I dropped the game, I had been playing longsword, and then sword and shield. Both were sort of fun, but didn't give me what I so desperately wanted in the game, it made my movements feel so rigid and rough, and only served to make the gameplay feel sluggish to me. On my third attempt at trying the game though I sat down, and ended up finding Insect Glaive, this weapon gave me what I wanted, and turned a sluggish, boring, and nearly agonizing experience playing chase with a monster that'd fly to the other end of the map once damaged into a fun, engaging, and exciting experience. Everyone has their weapon preference, and it's up to you to find what fits you most.The graphics are something that I haven't been able to fully enjoy because of rig issues, but from gameplay videos it's stayed quite consistent that while facial animations aren't the greatest. All of the little stylish things in Monster Hunter such as the palicoes and their food, or the monster designs managed to be stellar all throughout the base game and Iceborne.Ecosystems in this game look beautiful as there's logical application to how the monsters would function within them, watching them fight for their lands, and seeing how monsters function in these landmasses is what makes the experience so immersive and captivating which has led me to enjoy this game on my run through for hours on end.In the later game a big appeal is going through and farming out these things called gems which can be used to augment armors and builds so you can have the perks you want, this allows it so no matter what you do in MHW, you'll always manage to find a way to make your build work out with whatever you like. Meaning MHW Fashion isn't impossible in the least, and even with transmog armor options, it means you can have your set customized down to colors.The one gripe I could possibly have with this game other than what was glossed over above, and it's something that comes down to people's personal preferences which is why I address this, is MHW losing the aesthetic of prior Monster Hunter games. Looking at the old games you can get a sense of this sort of high fantasy larger than life sort of look, which rigid and bold colors for landscapes and armors, and behemoths to fight that looked more fantasy than ever, but MHW grayscaled it a bit, and made their monsters more applicable to what you'd see as what people would hypothesize dinosaurs and dragons to have looked like, and while that's not bad. It's just not everyone's taste, and I'd at least like to acknowledge that.Overall, this game is a blast, and as someone who had a really hard time getting into it. I'd just like to say it was worth it, and I'm glad I stuck it out for this game.

author: SteChizzle
review: This game really touches on the human instinct to conquer and be the most dominant species. You enter a very beautiful world that is pleasing to the eye, You go out and discover all the little secret pathways and the cats native to the land whom you can befriend. Sandy beaches, great forests and lakes. As you make your journey through this beautiful world you find all the creatures that inhabit it. You watch as they go about their own business, just trying to survive and what is your first instinct? That's it. Murder. You spring to action as the defenceless creature tries to run away, but fear not as you have that horrible little sprite from The Legend of Zelda's cousins by your side, these creatures are the real monsters. They will stop at nothing until they have forced you to wipe out every bit of life on the planet. As your target limps off and you sharpen your weapon, these green little demons chase after the poor creature, leading you to it's home so you can sever each of it's limbs. all so you can skin it and use it's body parts to adorn yourself and your clothing with the best money can buy. And now you have conquered this beast... what now? You follow the green demon flies into battle once more to slay more and more creatures, again and again, and when you stand on top of your mountain of animal carcasses and body parts you quickly realise that in your search to hunt the monsters, you have become one. YOU are the monster, murdering creatures in the wild to wear them. But it's okay because the green demon flies say it's okay, and off you go to continue your killing spree.11/10 would lose my humanity again

author: Squidvasion
review: I haven't really fallen in love with a game quite like I have for MHW. I've always known about the MH series, but never really gave it a shot, and I didn't even pick up MHW when it was initially launched. Foolish me. One day almost on a whim I figured "Hm, I suppose I will try this game" and now I'm pretty much hooked on the entire franchise across the board, with zealot level of fanboyism.Where do I even begin really? I suppose I will start with how the game works. The games premise is simple. You're a hunter heading to the New World on the 5th fleet and your task is to hunt the monsters there all in the name of science and exploration and all that fun stuff. The story is a little on the shallow side but it gets you through the motions and unlocks new monsters appropriately for you to fight, tied in with some honestly gorgeous cutscenes (sadly unskippable.)The meat and bones of the game, and the entire series really, are the monsters and the ensuing battles you have with them. I have a hard time putting together the words for exactly how to describe how perfectly Capcom has put the whole system together. Every single monster I fight feels so alive and filled with personality, that no other game I've played is really even on par with. The movements, the sounds, the fluidity is just sublime. Pair all of that up with a fantastic soundtrack and you will find yourself completely consumed by each encounter.Combat is not as easy as just mashing buttons and winning, so I found that initially I had a tricky time figuring out how to fight effectively, but once I got the hang of it I couldn't stop. Combat itself is a bit heavier (think dark souls) and surgical. Actions taken or not taken will have heavy consequences, and each monster has unique movements and attack patterns for you to learn and recognize. Expect to fail often at first, but when you do succeed and you hear that victory theme, it is very rewarding and fulfilling.Lets talk about the graphics. This game is absolutely gorgeous, with each map loaded to the brim with beautiful foliage and fauna for you to gawk at as you run through looking for your mark. Map sizes are big and exploring them is enjoyable, but not so big as to needlessly draw hunts out. As stated earlier, when it comes to monster design, the people at Capcom have set the bar into an entirely new realm. Every single monster in the game is beautifully crafted and watching them move around or interact with the world is an absolute joy to behold, no game I can think of has pulled off design quite like this in my opinion. The hunter you create and play as is also expertly detailed and animated, with a pretty powerful character creation tool backing it up, most players will be able to make a character to fit their specifications quite nicely.Sound and music design is a powerful ally to MHW's graphics as well. I've fought an Anjanath hundreds of times and still get chills when I hear it enrage. Every monster has a wide assortment of loud roars, aggressive snarls and snaps, and defeated whimpers, which add so much life to each and every one of them. Each map, and many of the monsters (although not all of them) have their own unique theme for when you fight them, and each of those themes is very good. They went with a more orchestral vibe in MHW though which is a little different from their previous titles. Personally I love it, but the classic themes are hard not to enjoy as well so it's a toss up here, but either way the music is very good.If you're looking for a fair amount of endgame to grind on as well, then MHW has you covered, although the gem droprate is pretty abysmal for a few of them (attack gem). However, a lot of the endgame issues have been addressed in the Iceborne expansion so I wouldn't worry about it too much (PC release is right around the corner)At the end of the day, I really can't give this game enough praise, it has completely changed how I look at action combat and monster/boss designs, and will likely remain at the top of my list for a very long time. Looking forward to many more years of hunting monsters, and can't wait for the, hopefully, entire monster roster to join us in the New World.

author: whY002
review: I have been playing MH series for a long time. Though I am not as hardcore as those thoudsand-hour players, I still would like to talk a little about this game.Lemme talk about the biggest problem for this game first: not enough content. This game is designed to be grinding and I must say there are just too few monsters and maps. My personal favorite is MHGU(3ds/switch) content-wise.The graphics is AWESOME....... for a monster hunter game. It is mediocre if you put it in a larger scale with all those new fancy looking 3A titles, but it's the BEST for a monster hunter game. And that pretty much wraps up 80% of why this game is good. A monster hunter game with good graphics..... just WOW.1.Combat    The combat system is always the core element for monster hunter, just like its prequels this one deliveries top-notch combat system. It is simple, easy to get a hang on, but very hard to master. For beginner there are easier weapons to choose from and later you will find those "easy" weapon also has depth that requires a lot of practice to master. Take my personally fav weapon for example, lance is not played by a lot because of its relatively simpler movement set: poke, charge and counter. These three movement covers 99% of lance combat however it takes timeless effort to master when to poke, how many times should you poke, when to counter, etc. 10/10(though i miss the hunter arts and style)2.Story    you are sapphire star and now you have to collect some mushroom for our chef. 0/10Yep, that's it, this game is all about hunting monsters and nothing else. One more thing I would like to address is the monster design. Other than the older ones(shown in prequels) the new ones honestly seem to be a little dull. I dont blame the dev because they intended to deliver a more "realistic" feeling in this game, unlike previous ones it feels more like a magic world. This is still a very decent MH game(now that the connection problem is solved) and if you can find some friends to play with I think you will have a great time and since this one is the easiest of all MH games it's a good starting point if youve never played MH. 8.8/10

author: Alia-chan
review: I never wanted to be a monster hunter. I didn't know the first thing about the beady eyed rock-wielding Kululaku or the raging Anjanath. But then one day I come stumbling into a sprawling hunter's camp, surrounded by strutting hunters who were wearing the spoils of their hunts, a spiked Nergigante helmet or the glistening blue scales of a Legiana breastplate. And suddenly, the spark to hunt was ignited. The hunter's outpost isn't without its downsides, however. There is an annoying lady, the 'Handler', yapping at me and waving her hands in an excited fashion. I try to ignore her, but she is following me, telling me about footprints that have been tracked to the west of the Wildspire Waste, perhaps I should head out there to collect samples and sniff them some? Oh! And the hunkering Zorah Magdaros is on the move! This landmass of an elder dragon, I wonder what we could do to slow its--I am nodding in agreement, anything to get her away from me. But the next thing I know, she has slammed a book in my face and I am being smothered by its musty pages. This is where you need to go! Lawd woman, I don't need glasses! Get that book out of my face! Yes, I'll see to it that the Great Jagras is turned into a green leather jacket on my next hunt! The Vaal Hazak is stalking the Rotten Vale being all emo and dark? What, you say his cloak makes a super cool looking armour!? He's on the list!And so, twin blades in hand, wearing the generic free weapon-smith donated armour, I head out into the world. I am off to hunt me some monsters!

author: Morbex
review: It's true that this monster hunter is a bit more user friendly and newcomer friendly, regarding the scoutflies, infinite whetstones etc. But i really recommend this monster hunter to anybody, old and new players, the graphics are amazing, the gameplay feels smooth as ever, i love the map and new monster designs.It's a great experience, 👍

author: NekoMimiSakuya
review: I completely love this game. I've played other MH titles and although this version isn't the exact same formula as the others, it still has it's own charm and flavor.  There are plenty of updates and events although some of them are after they're released for the console version. Overall it's a great title so long as you're familiar with the genre and don't mind repeatedly hunting monsters. Happy Hunting!

author: Lamii Inkfeather
review: Personally, I was reluctant to buy Monster Hunter World when it first came out on PC, the stories of lacking content, bad controls, and ridiculous CPU usage.All of those things are no more. The game has improved immensely since then and I am incredibly happy to have gotten the game.The world itself is visually gorgeous and immersive. You feel like you're out exploring a living world.The combat is fluid and smooth, it's rewarding when you learn a monsters patterns and behaviour. You can feel yourself improving as a hunter over time.There's so many weapons, so many skills and so many types of builds to play around with. For a theorycrafter like me, the game never gets old.The average new player will get 100-150 hours out of the main story. That alone is worth the cost of the game.From there, once you reach the endgame, the game turns into grinding for the sake of grinding. You need to be the type of person who enjoys hunting and enjoys the challenge of the endgame monsters, and enjoy hunting them over and over.However even if you do not enjoy that aspect, as said, the game's storyline for itself is worth the cost, anything after that feels like free entertainment.Pros:Visually stunningImmersiveMany weapon types, one for any type of personSmooth controls (I play with a controller)Fluid and lifelike combatSeveral hundreds of hours of entertainmentModdableChallenging but not unfairGreat multiplayer experience with friendsCons:High CPU usageLow variety in visual weapon designGets grindy after the storySlow content releases (This has been improving though)Jewel RNG is bullsh*tRare connection issuesPersonal score: A solid 8/10The game is great and a ton of fun, but can get grindy and repetitive outside of events.Luckily capcom has been stepping up their game and that has been improving lately.The game is more fun with friends, but completely viable to play solo. Most hunts are even faster solo, if you're a good hunter.For any fans of Dark Souls, who enjoys the type of evasive combat where you punish openings, I will 100% recommend this game.For any other our there, pick up on sale, maybe you'll find a new gem.

author: MissBashfulFace
review: I only played Monster Hunter 3 Ultimate on 3ds and while that experience wasn't the best, it got me hooked on the franchise. When MHW was first announced I waited patiently for the pc release and I was not disappointed. This. Game. Is. Awesome! MHW is a great starting game for newbies and something for veterans to sink their teeth into. It makes great quality of life changes that makes hunting less of a hassle, there is a large amount of fantastic challenging monsters to hunt with more being added with free DLC, graphics are the best in the series, and the multiplayer makes the experience 10x more enjoyable!There might be some hiccups in the game occasionally but the developers are constantly fixing stuff for the community. If you're looking for a fun multiplayer experience or even a solo grinding adventure, this game is for you!

author: Gustaw
review: First of all I want to mention I played monster hunter before World back in the PSP era of Freedom Unite so I may be biased towards certain aspects of the game.TL:DR A Great game in most aspects exept the story however, it is plagued with annoying bugs which stay in game for too long timeStory:As a rather new thing in Monster Hunter World or MHW for short a more proper story has been added. Unfortunately the story is really bland and for the most part feels like a chore rather than anything interesting. I heard some people saying it gives a nice direction of what needs to be done next and serves as a very extended tutorial but it seems rather far-fetched.Gameplay:This is where the game shines, player has many different weapons to choose from and each of them feels unique in it's own right from simple sword and shield up to a strange supporting weapon that is hunting horn allowing anyone to find something to suit their taste. The armor and later decorations provide different skills that boost the player abilities or protect them from enemy actions which makes it possible to costumize builds to their liking. The combat may sometimes feel a little bit clunky so to speak with attacks not hitting how they should and the monsters sometimes seem to cheat on hitboxes but it's not that big of an issue overall.The most important thing however are the monsters. Each of them requires a different approach how to fight them, personally I like to think about each monster as a boss battle, and while some of them are easier and some are harder it still seems that unless you are heavily overgeared they can best you if you don't take them seriously. The only downside I find in MHW compared to other monster hunter games is that comparably there are much less monsters to fight (for example in MHW there are 31 monsters while in Freedom Unite there were 62).The other great part are large maps with many interactable objects, hidden paths and areas you sometimes find even after countless hours of gameplay, it's possible to use enviroment to your advantage when fighting the monster but just as well it may become a disadvatage, good example is poison flowers which create a pool of poison that can apply the status to both player and the monster.The thing that is rather poorly made is the equipement management. It wasn't changed much compared to previous titles, and it feels clunky. so taking too many items can sometimes make it rather confusing when you try to select that antidote. Tt is remedied somehow by the quickwheel that allows for easy access to most important items if you set it correctly beforehand. Compared to previous title monster tracking is also much easier thanks to the scoutflies showing the way and not needing to rely on using paintball to mark monster every so often.Multiplayer:The game features a multiplayer aspect and I highly recommend to make use of it. Hunting monsters feel like an adventure with a group of friends and for the most part if you're struggling by yourself with a certain monster, it may prove to be a better idea to try fighting it with a group. The main problem of multiplayer comes from the story due to the fact that each player needs to watch the unskippable cutscenes individually, before they can access the same mission together. It is annoying and if you want to progress at the same time with others prepare for some waiting till someone finishes that cutscene, or finds that spot where the cutscene is triggered etc. Once story is completed the problem is solved so in worst case scenario it's possible to put up with a story and rush it before playing with friends.Graphics:While it isn't the prettiest game ever made in history it does have it's own style and overall looks great. It is easiest to see it while observing the maps and how much detail was put into making them. That seems to be especially true for a certain map that is unlocked throughout the story that is really unique as though it really care from a different world.Audio:The soundtrack isn't exactly the most memorable type but it seems good and fits the game well. Monsters have different tracks attached to them so the track does not seem repetitive and the transitions between them sound natural without any annoying stuttering or whatnot. Other than that the sound effects are all on point and the voiceover for character is okayish (exept for handler because she's annoying af regardless of which language is used).Technical:Lastly the main problem that is PC port and how Capcom handles it. Well to no surprise the requirements are rather high but that's rather understandable, the problem is the number of bugs that plagues this game to this day. For example early on there was a problem with game randomly disconnecting from the server which for some players made it nearly impossible to play with their friends. Currently the game may randomly freeze even stopping other programs from functioning correctly it happens mostly when viewing the workshop but it's nonetheless annoying. The bugs are slowly being fixed but those things shouldn't happen in the first place.Overall:If you can look past the bugs or some clunky gameplay elements the game provides a great way to spend time regardless if you want to just make one or two missions a day or spend next week playing it all the time as even after completing the story there are lots of things to do and new free for all players content constantly being added to the game.

The end-game is a bit boring though. E: With Iceborne added and expanded during the past year or so, I'd say the game became even more enthralling. The endgame isn't nearly as boring as it used to be, too! 8/10

author: TrippinTurtle
review: Honestly one of my favorite games ever.Visuals and sounds / music are phenomenal, It's challenging and with both friends or solo it's tons of fun. Updates and Events are regular and the devs plan on catching up with the console updates, so tons of stuff is / gets added.I have yet to lose interest after running around stunning enviorments for 150+ hours now, and I don't plan on stopping anytime soon. It's a shame the game gets so many downvotes because it doesn't fit everyone's playstyle. It has an unique combat system and most people that complain say that "It's slow and clunky". But with a little bit of practice and patience you can see it's fast and fun gameplay. One could say, "Git Gud".I've played previous MH games and I'd say this is a good sequal with alot of things improved from the older games. 10/10, without a doubt.

author: Nystal
review: I had a good time with Monster Hunter, the Main plot kept me going for a good 75 hours,  I personally had some goals of my own I did in the post-main plot content which kept me going for a further 25 hours, for some - this is where the game really begins but for me it just didn't carry me beyond that point.I certainly recommend Monster Hunter: World and think its worth the price.

author: Myon~
review: Great game for those who are fans of the Monster Hunter franchise. It has a lot of things to offer and a lot more things to discover. It starts you off with a story, after that you are free to create your own adventure, whether it will be researching monsters, hunting largest and smallest of the creatures, creating the strongest armor set, or just having fun with your friends.

author: James
review: This is my first proper try at a monster hunter game (I had played MHFU and MH3U in the past but never stuck with them) and I'm absolutely loving it! It's totally accessible for new players to the series and really fun! There were some server issues at the launch which is why a lot of negative reviews exist but they have been fixed since then. It does lack content compared to previous games in the series but the quality of life improvements and the combat is absolutely fun as hell and makes for a wonderful experience. Thanks to World I have also bought MHGU for the switch and I'm really loving it aswell and really makes me appreciate the older MH games. I switch a lot between both games currently.If you're on the fence about the series and interested in trying it out or worried about the mixed reviews then don't be, jump right in! You'll absolutely have a blast playing.
