author: Baklavah
review: After much waiting, backhanded comments from Console players, unfounded claims that Capcom would not deliver a proper port and the whining masses review bombing the game because they have potatoes and/or experienced connection issues (which were more on Steam's side than Capcom's) which are now FIXED, I am going to review this game.IT IS AMAZING! Period.The game offers a wonderfully engaging gameplay loop with many different monsters to hunt, providing a variety of experiences that a Monster Hunter title should have.Sporting a roster of 14 weapon types, there's something for everyone. From the speedy dual swords to the powerhouse greatsword, you can do anything if you're willing to take the time to learn your weapon's intricacies and master positioning. It takes time, of course, but with MHW, time is not an issue. The only limited thing in the game are the time-sensitive events, that are around for a short while before being switched up for a new set of event quests.Like exploring? Welcome to the EXTREMELY open zones of Monster Hunter: World. When on an expedition for research, or hunting a specific monster, there are no loading screens out in the selected zones. The sprawling landscapes are home to several ecosystems and a staggering number of creatures. Without giving too much away, all I can really say is that the zones are massive.My favourite thing this time around would have to be the Monster Turf Wars. There's nothing quite as satisfying as watching two huge creatures duke it out over territory. The engagements are vicious, and often end with one monster SORELY regretting its decision to pick a fight with whichever other monster whose territory it waltzed into.Between the combat mechanics, the vast array of creatures and the ability to customize your setup to suit your weapon and playstyle, Monster Hunter: World presents you with the opportunity to feel like a badass in your own right.When other people tell you that MHW is the "easiest" title in the series because they solo'ed the "story", pay them no mind. Yes, you finished the "single player" aspect of the game. Now, go on and try your hand at the new challenges and then tell me just how "easy" it is. If your reasoning is that MH: Generations on the Switch will be harder because "insert vague reason here", remember that they actively made this title more ACCESSIBLE to new players, not easier. There's a big difference between dumbing the game down and allowing newer players to the series to ease themselves into the difficulty curve. And dumb it down they have not.9/10 - Sure the game's a little demanding, but it is BEAUTIFUL and no one can say otherwise.9/10 - Between monster roars, battle music and the sound of weapons cleaving through flesh, the game's got GREAT audio.10/10 - Easily the best gameplay of the MH series so far. So much to do, many ways to approach a situation and visceral combat make this a fantastic title.10/10 - They got this just right. Preparation and knowledge are half the battle. With the new "internal monster wiki" at your disposal, you can set yourself up for success ahead of time and go into a fight prepared for the worst situations! However, the monsters are not slouches. Even if you've brought everything to make a monster's life a living hell, it can also return the favour tenfold. Never underestimate any of these creatures, as they will chew you up and spit you out without the slightest hesitation.9/10 - The controls are fluid. Be it mouse and keyboard, or gamepad. Your attacks flow together seamlessly and dodging feels responsive. Knowing when to use your big attacks that lock you into animations is the biggest obstacle, but once you figure it out, you'll be pretty good!10/10 - There's a lot there, even after you "finish" the main story of the game. After completing practically all of the available content, I can say for certain that it's got a 10/10 rating from me.9.5/10 - With this game being the way it is, after Capcom has rectified the majority of connection issues, it deserves to stand as a titan of a game. It is, without a doubt, the best Monster Hunter I have ever played. And I have played all of them up until 4 Ultimate (I skipped that one onward until MH:W released on PC).Bravo Capcom, bravo.I can wholeheartedly say that I recommend this game. HANDS DOWN THE BEST MH to date!EDIT: Updated my review to change "Content" to a 10/10 since the addition of Iceborne.

author: Kaptein Koenk
review: With Monster Hunter: World being one of the few games I was honestly hyped for when it would release on PC I was greatly looking forward to the PC release. With the release already happening on consoles, I knew I had good content and gameplay to look forward to when I would get my hands on my PC copy.I disagree with most reviews on Steam - while the game definitely has it's issues and the port is nowhere near perfect, the game still delivers. With the occasional connection error (which has now been patched effectively) frustration would arise, having all your friends watch cutscenes separately before you can co-op story missions is a pain but this issue was already known on the consoles too and can be worked around relatively well.Apart from these minor issues, the game delivers everything you hope for. A slamming orchestral soundtrack blasting as you and friends, each equipped with one of the 14 different weapon types (which all deliver you a whole separate game experience), as you track and hunt enormous monsters within the New World. Having zero respawns left and coordinating with your friends as you work together tactically to mount and knock down the monster, just to have your friend with the big-ass hammer pound the monster on it's head, it's moments like these which make this game such a beauty to play.If you can get a few hours into Monster Hunter: World, you'll be sucked in a universe where each monster kill will get more satisfying than the previous one. I highly recommend this game.

author: Storm
review: This game is fantastic. I've heard of people having fps/graphics issues even on great rigs and while that will certainly detract from the experience I can't comment on it because i haven't really seen these issues as of yet. Connectivity issues seem much less frequent since the last patch if not gone altogether (again that's just my experience, some people have claimed to still have issues but it doesn't seem like nearly as many). Honestly these are the biggest issues i can see with this game and I myself have barely dealt with them, that doesn't mean they don't exist however so people complaining about it is totally valid and I can see where those come from.That said if you can get the game running stable and play with friends or even randoms this is a truly enjoyable experience. It isn't as hard as previous MH titles and there aren't as many to hunt as you could in other games but this is also a title attracting a lot of new players to the MH franchise so honsestly I don't see those as horrible points. If you are new to MH this is a great game to start with, don't be discouraged if a monster seems to take you a long time to kill or even if you fail to do it a few times. You'll find that it's all about picking the right weapon for you ( 14 to choose from and they all feel great for their own reasons!) learning a monsters moves and how to work around them. What might start as an encounter you fail several times will with practice turn into something you totally tear down, and it will feel great and get you hooked I promise you.

author: Gog
review: This is a very good game that had a very rough start with major connectivity issues and minor technical issues. As of yesterday the connectivity issues have been fixed. Most negative reviews for this game are based solely on connectivity issues, and most of those reviews will not be updated to reflect that those issues have been resolved in the most recent patch. A large number of negative reviews are based on performance/technical issues, some of which are valid, but I highly suggest taking the minimum and recommended system specifications (and note that they are tested at 30fps) to heart before criticizing the performance of the game. +Same classic addictive gameplay as previous titles.+Now patched to provide a fantastic multiplayer experience.+Many free content updates to come.+-DLC purely cosmetic and not gambling.-Game may not run as well as you might expect on your machine.-Your favorite monster probably isn't in the game (yet).

author: Bakapito
review: After finishing Dark Souls ,Bloodborn,Nioh,Horizon Zero dawn i have to say that this game is Very good in terms of Content and gameplay.- The game is hard and it has its own unique gameplay based on how expirienced u are with your weapon and Very Focused on the items Use.You can use item for every situation and make your life easier or even to make things possible.- Sole reason of the game is to farm and grind, thing is farm is not like afk easy run like Diablo 3 etc, Its more like killing Dark souls 3 first boss but with the chance to get invated by one , two or sometimes even 3 other monsters + the Enviroment.- You dont have to worry about Game Content as it is enough for start plus there are Events with unique rewards at full time changing every now and then, and the fact that u know expansion patches will release to reach ps4 content.- Playing with Friends is very fun and there are even Arena challenges with ladders u can duo to.-Keybindings for Keyboard are not good but u can change everything. Controller gameplay is very good like every game that is released on Ps4.Overall-Gameplay 9/10-Content 8/10-Graphics and performance 6/10-Controls 7/10-Online Content/replayability 10/10

author: A Feather!
review: I want to recommend this game, I really do, but if you're looking at this to play with friends? STAY AWAY. Multiplayer is unplayable with constant connection drops, and difficulty scaling doesn't decrease back to solo after your party gets disconnected. The game has been out for almost two weeks at this point and we haven't even had a hotfix.This game was my first opportunity in YEARS to get in at the ground level of a game with my best friend, but we can't run even a single quest together without being separated immediately. The quality of your service is a disappointment, Capcom.

author: Sammy Killer
review: Alright, this will be a long one but bare with me.First of all, I played this game for 554 hours on PS4, HR 215 and numerous solo/CO-OP time attack runs, I can kill Tempered Nergigante solo in 2 minutes and 30 seconds avg with a Greatsword build. I know a thing or two about this game.So when the PC version finally released, I wanted to see what 4K 60FPS would look like, I bought the game and played with the following specs:8700K at 5ghz1080ti at 1950mhz with temp target set to 70C16gb ram500gb SSDPS4 PadI play with the following graphical settings:4K resolution, All settings maxed out, Volume scale OFF, AA OFF, Graphics settings: Variable (Prioritize Resolution)So, the game itself looks spectacular on PC, it runs at a solid 60 at all times with a 1080ti on the prioritize resolution setting, I find that the High graphics setting does nothing for the game on both a big 4K tv and a 32" 4K monitor. the LOD graphics setting is important as it changes the way the game looks as a whole, Disabling Volumetric fog is a MUST, having it on hogs performance and makes the game look terrible and washed out. The game runs super well, Having played for 10 hours in a row testing for any instability, I didn't see anything that would detriment gameplay when it comes to the core mechanics Vs the PS4 version, if anything, running at 60fps all the time makes the game super enjoyable and exciting. The online functions need some work, randomly disconnecting from games with people but I mostly play Solo, as I do better that way and people usually just get in the way. Things that the PC version would need tweaked:-The ability to choose in what monitor the game should be displayed, having multiple monitors, it will default to the main monitor.- Being able to chat with other players without having to open a chat menu, something like a traditional MMO where you press Enter and type a message would be fantastic.- The ability to make Squads, having a Squad session would be great for friends to jump in and out quickly of your games when working on farming items.- An in-game FPS counter or technical data, the game won't even support steam's FPS counter.Aside from some issues, the port feels great compared to the PS4 version provided you have the hardware to back it up. I'm a bit sad people are reviewing the game so negatively as this is one of those games where the real enjoyment comes after investing 50 hours on it, if you can't invest that amount of time I wouldn't be able to recommend it to you, as only playing it for the story or to see the monsters but not grinding for gear and honing your skills and challenging yourself to do better can only take you so far.Overall a very enjoyable experience so far, Highly recommend the game if you are looking for a challenge or like grinding for items in a Destiny 2 esque-way.

author: 阿涵是小仙女

author: CKTofu
review: Monster Hunter: World is a great Monster Hunter game, with some issues that are rightfully criticized, and some that are overblown.Pros: - Monster Hunting is great, the gameplay is great. Combat is very methodical and punishing if you aren't learning the monster- Performs acceptably. From my experience playing on PS4, getting a around 60-70 FPS at max settings 2560x1440 on a 1080Ti. Turned down the volumetric fog from Highest to High to gain another 10 ish FPS without significant impact on the graphics- Great load times vs my time playing on PS4, SSD or no. The PS4 load times were a constant (minor) source of frustrationNeutral:- Maybe not as optimized as possible, but personally I think the performance is adequate- Pretty CPU-intensive. I have an i7-6700K @ 4.4GHz and I'll get about 60-70% load on max settings. Manages to use more than 4 CPU threads, unlike many games. All 8 threads of my 6700K get involved-  Oh, the sweet lord Raw Input has arrived, looking forward to giving m+k a go now that raw input is available.- The best UX in any Monster Hunter game (not saying much since the UX is still pretty painful at times)Cons:- Missing some graphical options I wish were there (Primarily disabling depth-of-field and motion blur)- - A Patch has been put out for the networking issues. I personally haven't had any disconnects since the patch, and I haven't heard of any issues from friends who play the game, so everything seems far more stable, and any networking bugs that remain appear to be fairly minor.- Disconnecting during a multiplayer match just leaves you in your hunt, but suddenly solo. No re-loading or anything, your monster is at the same %HP it was before your disconnect, but you're suddenly not in a group and fighting the multiplayer-HP version of the boss with your Palibro. You don't get kicked out of the hunt or anything, but it definitely sucks that the monster doesn't drop back down to the same %HP but with the Solo HP maximum. Generally not a big deal, but it sucks to restart your hunt if you D/C off the bat. Hopefully a minor inconvenience now with the new networking patch.Would I recommend this game? Yeah, I would. Monster Hunting is a good time, and I think anyone who thinks they might like Monster Hunter will enjoy this game. Hopefully the networking issues are resolved quickly, since they're definitely the biggest problem.

author: Dark Ranger
review: I'm one of the lucky ones who hasn't had any problems with performance. However, I am not lucky enough to be able to dodge the bullet that is this game's wacky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ servers. It is borderline impossible playing this game multiplayer most of the time because of how spotty the servers are. It's a huge shame considering how co-op focused this game is.  If you're on the fence about buying this, I'd definitely wait until the performance and server issues are fixed. However, I've been having a blast with this game solo. This is my first real experience with Monster Hunter and I've not been disappointed thus far. There's a lot of depth to this game. Yes, it can be very confusing. Yes, it's grindy, as Monster Hunter has always been, but the experience you get from actually participating in hunts pretty much negates the tediousness of any of these factors. It all comes down to the monster hunting, obviously. It's split into a couple of phases. First, you have the prep phase. This occurs in the town hub where you pick up the quest, upgrade your weapons, buy supplies, eat food for certain buffs, etc.Once that's done, you depart on your quest and move to the hunting phase. The hunts themselves are paced really well in order to give you plenty of action while also allowing you to recuperate and regroup as the hunt moves from section to section. During this phase you usually have a time limit of 50 minutes, but it can be lower depending on quest modifiers. Once your prey has been hunted, you enter the final phase of the hunt, the looting phase. You have 60 seconds to carve up the monster for any loot you can find, as well as picking up anything else you might want from the environment. After the timer is up, you're teleported back to HQ to repeat the process. The most rewarding thing about this whole process is once you start to learn monster patterns and behaviors, you can start applying that knowledge to both prep accordingly and exploit patterns and behaviors of the monster. Eventually you start taking down the monsters faster and more effeciently. It's an RPG where you, the player, start to feel like a more experienced hunter as your character progressees.The game allows you to pick from 14 different weapons as well, each accomodating to a different playstyle with unique combos and upgrade trees. I hear the game's combat often compared to Dark Souls, but I feel like it's a little Dark Souls mixed with a fighting game. Using the right combos at the right time is key. Add the player's wide arsenal with the diversity of the many monsters in the game, and you have a very challenging and engaging combat system that's up to the task of keeping you interested well past the 100 hour mark. It's also important to note that while this game is great solo, it truly shines when you're playing co-op with a team. Difficulty scales with how many players are in your party, so coordinating with your friends to take down a monster as effeciently as possible adds even more depth to this already endless pit of a game. However, this game does some very strange things with multiplayer. If you and your friends are on the same quest in the story, the game simply won't let you depart on that quest together, telling you that you're not far enough in the story to join them. Good luck even getting into a session with your friends, though, considering how trash the servers are right now.  Overall, I'd recommend this game. As I said, if you're on the fence, just wait until all the server and performance issues are sorted out. This is a game that really shines when you're teaming up with your friends, but as of right now that's not very reliable.

author: Mitchie LOL
review: I've played this on Xbox One and after the many 100 hours I poured into this game, I realized the truth about.That the large monsters that we have been hunting, the very things that defined us Monster Hunters, aren't the real monsters.It was us hunters, who are the actual Monsters.It has been months since I've became a new Hunter. As each Quest I took with my fellow comrades, little by little, I started to see what we have become into.We had plundered into a New World and started to exterminate one by one the creatures that live there in that once-undisturbed ecosystem, cooking their flesh in our meals, and using their skin and hides as our clothing and armor.And we keep continuing this cycle forever.Maybe even until they have gone endangered.The day that it made me finally realize was when I saw another group of hunters were fighting a Rathalos and a Rathian protecting its newly-born and right when both were killed, so was the new-born as well. Just for the sake of upgrading their gear.Not only us have lives to protect, but so do the Large Monsters of the New World too.

author: TAI
review: My first thought so far for the PC version:- At first I was lagging when in windowed mode, but was peachy when I play this on fullscreen so no problem there. - The game itself is fun to play with others online once the servers stop bugging out or remove Denuvo.. PERIOD.- Game is still fun solo, good to warm up before going in with people who are more experienced in the MH world. - Dang, I really enjoy the graphics, the enivornment and how each monster type deals with each other within its own ecosystem. Is the game bad upon launch? Nope, I've dealt wit worst newly launched games and they were poorly ported, more so than others would deem so in this game. It wasn't bricked upon launch. (coughs, Batman:AK is an example)I'm giving this game a chance because I actually like the Monster Hunter franchise and the game devs poured a lot of heart and soul into this. I can understand this would be maybe their first or 2nd time porting their game into the PC and with with working online functions. I know for sure there will be a hotfix patch soon to iron out the issues. But if you're still weary about the game, you can wait for a week or a month. I still say this game is a great buy. Just remember that when it comes to the online functions, there's bound to be probs especially when their servers are over filled. Just like any online multi-player game... That or it's just the Denuvo.. Prolly that.

author: 鮮やか
review: Try not to let the influx of bad reviews sway you too much. The game has just come out, people want to be mad about something, and most people I know had played it for 16 to 20 hours straight because they loved it so much. Those people aren't reviewing it. It's the people who want to be mad who are reviewing it.Now onto the port. The port isn't great. For the 6 months we had to wait for it, it could have been better. But the DS1 port was god ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ awful and people still found ways to play it. The loading times are crazy fast, the graphics are super nice (although you need to disable a few things for optimization and that sucks) the systems that made sense on console have been changed to make sense on PC instead, so they definitely thought about "does this feature make sense on steam? How should we change it?"The game is a typical Monster Hunter. You fight monsters so you can farm it for a set that allows you to fight another monster, which is just a stepping stone to a third monster, ad infinitum. The combat is fluid and rewarding of skill and mastery, and those who learn the ins and outs of their weapons and the monsters will be rewarded. I personally feel some weapons came out worse than previous games with their changes in mechanics or moves (Sword and Shield, Dual Blades) but most got much, much better when compared to the previous games with what was added to their arsenal. What makes this game such a definitive version over MHG on the 3DS or MGU on the Switch is the absolute colossal amount of Quality of Life changes. Gathering is faster, so many of the crafting recipes were streamlined so you weren't farming for hours to make an ends game worth of one tool you needed. Things you needed for every hunt are always on your hunter at all times, and don't take up inventory space. The new Charm systems, the Armor and Weapon upgrade system, and the new Armor Skills systems are all such a huge improvement over the old ones. The maps are sprawling and large, without the loading screens that plagued the game in between zones of the same map in the old games. This is both a plus and a minus, but they changed the potion drinking mechanic to account for that minus. It is clear Capcom put lots of thought and attention into this game. But it isn't perfect. In the old games, it was impossible to do the main village quests with other people. Those were always solo offline only. The quest pool was separated, and lots of things in the game were locked behind your solo progression in the game, even things you needed for online play. They changed it, and even though it is better than it was, it's not as good as it should be. People who are complaining about the "difficulty" of playing with friends are blowing it so far out of proportion, maybe they should seek a different game if figuring out how to play with friends is that hard. Also, currently the servers are dying, and you need to re-host your game server occasionally if a friend gets dropped or you need to add a new one. Otherwise, the game was amazing on the PS4, and it's even more so on the PC.

It's my all time favorite Series since Freedom Unite and I HIGHLY recommend this game to you and friends.Seriously if a friend can play it and connect to sessions on a potato of a laptop and internet. author: Immane
review: Do you like learning how to take down boss monsters, doing so, working your way up in gear and skill, and then feeling like you're on top of the food chain because you deserve to be?  Then get this game.  If you dislike learning and applying knowledge, this is the worst game for you.  Lots of people like comparing every other hard game to Dark Souls.  This is similar to Dark Souls only in that you must learn and apply what you've learned.  Sure it's hard, but not in the same way.  There isn't much tutorial and this is a pretty hardcore game.  Every mission is a boss monster you have to kill.  Every boss monster gives you loot with which to upgrade your gear.  You start in "low rank" where mistakes wont get you killed, before moving to "high rank" where it will.  Low Rank is the "tutorial".Each "hunt" takes on average 10-18 min to or ranging between 2-50 min based on player skill and equipment. If you've never played a monster hunter game before, this one is the most accessible one.That doesn't mean it's very accessible.  The required knowledge is kind of like a wall.  Not kidding.  Be ready to not know what your doing, and find out 30 hours into the game that you should've put an armortalon in your inventory the entire time.If you HAVE played monster hunter before, this is the easiest monster hunter yet!  You don't pose after using items!  Your character acts like they want to live! You can dodge backwards!  No more paintballs, you have scoutflies!You really don't need to learn very much.  One fighting style per weapon, maybe one new move.The slinger is new, but that's rather intuitive.  Also, MH World weapons are designed to not look as cool as lower res MH weapons for some reason.  Also, Tremors now makes you stumble for half an hour.Co-Op (up to 4 people per quest) was spotty for me on release, it seems to have been fixed or something because it's fine now.  I heard some news about your save file possibly corrupting if you ALT-F4 while it's saving, so back up your saves. (didn't happen to me).  On the topic of Co-Op this is a super friendly Co-Op game, unless you die 3 times in a row.  There are multiple ways to fail a quest, but only one of them really ever happens.  Someone who is not prepared for the quest comes in and uses up all the teams lives.  Don't be afraid to play safe.  Overall, this is the:Best Looking, Smoothest Character and Weapon Usage, Shortest, Easiest, Most Accessible, Least Rage Inducing, Least Grindy, Least Endgame Content, Most Realistically Toned, Overall Best, No Tutorial As Usual, Meh Music As Usual, Copy Pasta Recolor Monsters As Usual, Least Healthy MonstersMonHun game out there.10/10 for meDefinitely not for everyone.Can't stress it enough.  If you like learning mechanics and applying what you know, this is your game, and visa versa.

author: J
review: 40% positive on Steam, a score of 90 on Metacritic with a 8.6 user rating.Monster Hunter World is both a great game in its own right, and when paired with Steam, has demonstrated how grossly devolved PC gamers have become. We used to take pride on having the best platform to run our games and having the knowhow to keep it that way. To be fair, Monster Hunter World far less friendly or appealing to 'casual' players, but at this point it's gone far beyond personal taste. Anyone who can't take more than five minutes to learn a mechanic in a game shouldn't be reviewing PC games.Now, players can't even be bothered to figure out how to use a multiplayer lobby, or even read a guide, before they write negative reviews and drive titles into the ground because they don't provide the child grade accessibility and instant gratification of games like PUBG or CSGO. In such cases, these games are designed with accessibility in mind to make it easier for you (and children) to spend real money on their loot crates and other microtransactions.If you are reading this review, and you are a competent PC gamer, you have almost nothing to fear from this port of Monster Hunter World. If you can rollback your drivers, are within recommended spec, and know how to optimize your graphics options beyond "low-medium-high", you can easily dial in a smooth experience. The server issues have been almost completely resolved, with no more disconnects during missions. With proper setup I've managed 40-60 fps on high settings with my modest GTX 970/i5 rig at 1440p. The biggest issue I had was not being able to start the game within the first days of launch because Denuvo servers were not responding, but that's been fixed for a while.

author: [PBIV]Rinzler
review: Genuinely some of the most fun I've ever had on a game.There's lots of complaining going on right now, and while I'm tech savvy enough to apply some of the fixes or to know what to adjust to fix the problems, I haven't had to. On the other hand of the spectrum, my friend has issues with basic computer functionality. However, both of us have had no performance issues at all, hunting monsters through the forest at a relatively stable framerate, with none of the surprise game-killing drops that everyone's been warning of.Likewise, the controls that everyone has been so vehemently against have been a non-issue, with the both of us adapting and getting better at our usual speed.Don't believe all the complaining: this game is a fine game, and a beautiful addition to your steam library, even with everyone whining in the background.

author: Solace
review: Works with the 8bitdo SN30 Pro in all input modes. im using the Switch pro controller sync option ( Y+Start )   it gives the proper button layout  too  (A=A,  B=B, Y=Y, X=X)you can even set it as a profile in Steam Controller options.AMD Users make sure you update your drivers to the newest Optional build or your game will crash on startup.Not much else i can say about the game, its an open world MH with much needed and asked for mechanics go play it,  happy hunting. Don't be too harsh on Multi PlayerRIP Dauntless.

author: Jayson
review: This game has been so awesome so far. The port isn't perfect (mostly network issues), but it is so much fun and sounds like it runs better than the console versions. I'm playing on a Nvidia GTX 1060 6gb with an i5 4590 and it's running at a stable 60 fps for me with minor adjustments to the settings. If you're a fan of games with a ton of replay value, can enjoy possibly replaying different things or trying to hunt down specific monsters for particular upgrades that you really want, and limitless co-op options, along with the pace of this games combat and preparation systems, this is fantastic. There is nothing else that comes close to this for me on PC. Toukiden and Dark Souls kind of scratch a similar itch, but there's something different about Monster Hunter that those games have never been able to reach for me.It's got a pretty interesting story so far and the game looks absolutely beautiful to me. The changes that have been made to make the game more accessible are really neat too. Things like no longer having to equip a map, not having to worry about using paintballs to tag monsters so you can track them between zones, the fact that each zone is one big world, and even the concept of these larger online lobbies is awesome. They've put a lot of work into making this game and this port great, and I think it shows. I'm only using a 16:9 monitor, so I can't speak for ultra widescreen or super high refresh rates, but I really do think this is truly special and worth a look if it sounds interesting.I am a gigantic Monster Hunter fan, but the only current gen console I have is a Switch. I bought the japanese version of MHXX on Switch, thinking it was the only new Monster Hunter game that was going to happen. Shortly afterwards, they announced MHW with a PS4, Xbox One, and later PC release date. I've been waiting all year for this moment, constantly checking the release date, and I am so happy this game is on PC, running as well as it is, and even though it currently has a mixed score, there are consistently over 200,000 players online. That is insane, and it's like I'm watching my baby go out into the wild and getting the opportunity to see how well it's being embraced by old players and newcomers alike.I'm looking forward to see what kinds of patches they do in the future, but besides the network issues, this is so cool. Check out Digital Foundry for more information on how things are handled between the PC and console versions of this game.

author: Muppet Toes
review: One of the most fun games I have played in my life. This is one of gaming's must plays. Great intro to the series. It fundamentally changed how I played video games as a whole.

author: Zant
review: Monster Hunter: World, the ultimate game to play with your friends. It's just simply the best and absolutely better than all the rest. Must buy.

author: Enraiha
review: Fixed connectivity issue somewhat

author: Jeffez
review: Very Good Game, Like all the MH Franchise.If you are asking if you should buy it, the answer is YES.

author: beech
review: It is a fun game. Please fix multiplayer so I can play this fun game with people without wanting to end my own life. Thanks.

author: Eye See You
review: This is one of the greatest games I've ever played. The graphics, the mechanics, the amount of weapons and playstyles, the monster designs and details! I just love it all! It's easy enough to get into, complex enough to stay and difficult enough to enjoy the lategame for many many hours. The multiplayer with its scaling difficulty is not making it too easy.Lastly, with the new DLC coming out, the amount of individual monsters will be DOUBLED with many favorites from the series returning! At the time of writing this, MHW is 50% off in the Steam summer sale. You'd be stupid not to buy it and try it out!

author: Majickmanbob
review: I had so much fun finally experiencing a game from ground 0 again. For so many recent games, I spoil the experience by watching videos and reviews on the items. MHW is a game I knew I was going purchase as soon as I heard it was coming to PC. Learning all the environmental hacks and experiencing the turf wars - MY GOD THE TURF WARS - is what makes this game such a joy.Hunting with friends on PSP was the bomb diggidy and finally there was one that enough of my friends wanted to get (thank you Dauntless). Get some friends and play. If you are the friend without it, don't look anything up, don't watch guides, and dive in. If you don't want to blow money on a new game archetype, go try Dauntless (f2p btw) and then come back and pick MHW up.

author: dave
review: EDIT: The recent patch which addressed online issues has drastically cut down on disconnects and in my case, took away the disconnects. I am now switching my review to a positive as a result. However there is still a glaring issue with the game's optimization. Namely utilizing a large amount of the CPU for no apparent reason, and having weird graphic hiccups on some monsters with extra special effects (namely the one elder dragon with the wind).The game is amazing on PC. Controls take a little bit getting used to, or you can always plug in a controller. However I do NOT recommend the game in its current state due to the fact the multiplayer constantly cuts out even in the middle of a expedition/hunt. Which leaves you soloing a boss that you may not have the gear for or the experience for. I will change my review to a positive when they fix this issue. You can still have fun. Everything else is as a Monster Hunter. Everything else is somewhat positive. But I have lost many hunts, and hours of time from online dropping out.

author: #TDG Hololand3
review: Nice concept, Nice ideas and I love the core principles behind this game. However the state that this game is in makes it far from worth the £50 price tag associated with it. Let me list a few of the initial things that have really annoyed me with this game.Pros - - Great concept with fresh idea's and something I really want to try out- Good amount of content and continued updates and support- Cool features and I like the Palico'sCons - -(YOU CAN'T EVEN DISSABLE MOTION BLUR OR THE CUSTARDY MOUSE SMOOTHING WITH CONSOLE AUOTAIM ENABLED BY DEFAULT ON PCCCC?- Unintuitive and horribly clunky controls (and this is coming from an avid Arma player)- Akward and broken networking and matchmaking. (for the price tag this game boasts it should have consistend solid multiplayer and the social hub should at least be expanded to the whole of Astera.) - Dodgy quest recognition in multiplayer (I had to repeat a quest TWICE because it never recognized the first completion of it as I did it with friends???!!?)- Invisible walls literally everywhere and generaly a restrictive environment (Purely to make up for a lack of good world design)- A one hour long tutorial that rips the camera from your hand every 30 seconds to point it at something you don't necessarily want to look at).- Bad performance considering the mediocre graphics the game provides.- Some classes are so badly ported that 50% of your actions cannot be cancelled and result in you just watching as your character gets slapped about and killed.- To give an example of how convoluted this game can be. If you want to play a quest with a friend. You must first join their server which may fail a few times, You must then do the quest yourself just untill you finish all the cutscenes. After that you must abandon your quest and join theirs after they have watched all the cutscenes (this make may fail to connect a few times too), After that you both ready up and hope for the best.TL:DR - This game has some good ideas and would be amazing if it were a £20 game. But for a £50 game it is clunky, unfinished, uses outdated mechanics like invisible walls, has horrible networking and matchmaking, has poor performance for a mediocre looking game, and is ported poorly.

author: fieon~``
review: Needs more big monsters! like those monster in the recent games of the franchise! Please capcom... Very Fun game to play with friends! And it's so addictive well for me since I play this franchise since 2007.

author: The Munch Guy
review: I've been a fan of MH since Tri, back like in 2010, and I absolutely love the series. Stepping into this game was a huge surprise after all those years of hunting! - For one, the graphics are astounding! They don't look like they came from the PS2! (Which isn't a problem, since I also love GenU right now as well, but y'know, it's nice)- Quality of life changes are great.        - Now, you don't stand in one place consuming things, and then flexing, which is great for versatility.        - Whetstones are infinite        - The map is all interconnected! Now you wont go flying into a loading screen if you get hit near a loading zone for the next area!         - Gunlance, at least in my opinion, got some major buffing, which is awesome.- The environments are gorgeously crafted, and i love exploring. Monsters are almsot treated as actual living things!- No weapon or playstyle is dicernably bad compared to any other one - Basically endless gameplay! I know I still need to clock in a lot of time!- Still really great multiplayer- Content updates, and possibly G rank DLC? (Iceborn) Hell yeah!Now for some cons, however- Weapon and armor design is not super unique and varied compared to earlier entries, there are some exceptions, though.- Story multiplayer is weird, you've seen it before... You gotta watch the cutscene first before you can make a mutiplayer story quest.. yadda yadda- The game requires a pretty hefty cpu if you want it to run smooth(er)- Some bugs here and there, though not many... at least from what i've seen. I can't say what it'll be like for others. Capcom seems pretty on top of patches, though- SOS flares are a gamble, it's either very helpful hunters, or dudes with no armor and a hunting horn only playing music in a corner, it really depends- RNG, which gets pretty frustrating sometimes- Monster variation. Don't get me wrong, I love the monsters right now, But it's all just reptiles and stuff. We need like Nerscylla, or the leviathan skeleton or something.- I wish you could just craft your decorations insteadOverall MHW is a very solid entry, and i'm super happy that Capcom went with the next gen market with this game! Great hunts, great maps, great hunters! Grab some friends (or not, you can solo, too) and get out there! Guide our way, Sapphire Star!

author: maidenless
review: Great game, awesome textures, runs ok on highest settings with a gtx 1080. Everything is great except for denuvo, and if your CPU doesn't support fma-3 it instantly crashes. Awesome game ruined for many by a stupid "feature", hopefully Capcom will change this soon. Personally I don't have a problem and gameplay speaking wise it is a fantastic game.

author: BlockBadger
review: As someone new to The Monster Hunter titles, I was very apprehensive to get this game. As I hate oversized weapons and near all of Anime culture and art.However MHW was a pleasant surprise I’ll get into later.What is making write this review now is how much Capcom has listened to the community and fixed the major gripes with this game that really made it unenjoyable to play, such as being able to remove the virtual joystick for camera controls, and be able to remove effects such as motion blur. Without those changes, I could not give this a positive review.As for the gameplay, I love it. Smooth flowing, but really punishing if you mess up, but gives you the chance to retreat, heal and reassess. Bar a few difficulty spikes and the low rank (start of the game) being somewhat easy and VERY short, its solid.High rank (mid game) is where the fun and buildcraft starts. Where skills, weapon and then what monster you’re fighting really start to matter. Along with player skill.I massively enjoy the grinding and perfecting mentality of the game, coupled with the somewhat basic building system for your equipment. It’s a shame you’re often stuck with bad looking armour though, but there are a few ways around that.The story continues through high rank despite being much more lacking till you get towards the end, where it picks up again.After the story, some more options open up to you allowing you to progress and develop your armour and weapons. Some of these fights can be quite hard as a group and really shows how Capcom missed the mark with their scaling difficulty (solo is easier).Overall well worth the price, even if the massive lack of monsters really make the game feel hollow after a while. I would have much preferred to have more non elder dragons worthy of my time and energy, along with more of those in game have tempered versions.

author: Mogelfur
review: Keep in mind that currently I am mostly playing Singleplayer and have done so since Monster Hunter Tri, 4U and so on for the 3DS console system.This game is a monster hunter game which eliminated a lot of hassles normaly (and silently endured) encountered in the other games. You don't have to carefully handpick needed objects before the start of the quest since you always bring your Box with you to a quest, buffing by eating a cooked meal is also possible on the fly and you don't have to stand still to consume items. So far, so easy.Monsters are still challenging, although I fear that the game itself might have become less complex. Which is okay in my opinion, since the quality of the game itself is still quite high. The game conveys a much higher sense of a breathing and living ecosystem than, for example, ARK. Ever watched a scaled wyvern-like huge reptile taking a bath and giving its best impression of a pidgeon in a small pond? Now you have the chance to do so.Controls for uninitiated are usually difficult to learn and to master and if patience is not your virtue, you might not get a kick out of this game. Especially since Multiplayer is still very wonky. However, I frequently make similar experiences with my 3DS system, so I don't care that much about MP disconnects and inconveniences on this matter. In my opinion this is critique on high levels.Recommended!

author: Rokhiel
review: Monster Hunter world is an excellent start for new players of the franchise, the devs made sure it was more friendly for them as it was in previous titles, and with the upcoming DLC: Iceborne. I'd say this game is doing a wonderful job at luring more players to enjoy a game that has you hunting the same thing, but making each battle feel different and enjoyable.

author: Slightlyoff
review: Some people have had problems with the game performance. I really haven't. Yes it's not well optimized and yes my cpu usage is high but it's not so bad that it deserves a bad recommendation.Why you might ask? Because the game is amazing. There are so many different and challenging monsters to hunt. The 14 weapons all play so differently from each other that you could play the game through 14 times and it wouldn't feel like you were redoing it. And because of this the grind takes a very long time to feel like a grind. I'm at 123.4 hours and I'm just now starting to feel it but I have so many different weapons to explore that I am okay with it.The world is beautiful and feels truly lived in. The soundtrack is pleasant and appropriate.Yes, the game has problems and for that I would never give it a 10/10. The port has problems. The mouse controls aren't optimal however I find them acceptable never feeling like I NEED the controller. I have used M&K for all 123 hours. If the port was perfect though. It would be a 10/10 without hesitation. One of my favorite games ever and certainly my favorite monster hunter, although full disclosure the only other one I played was the Wii one.

author: Nas
review: I am not that good with socializing with people. Not that I said I am an introvert, just not that good at socializing. But being in this community is one of the amazing experience I had with gaming so far. So many nice people that I can proudly say they are my friends, I can say family even. Worth my every penny, time & effort. ><

author: dirtyCAT
review: Just the best.Should be text book for any game designer. Bungie needs to take note. This is how you make grinding fun. This is how you give people things to do. Just a great game and even better at sweet buttery smooth 60fps on the PC

author: OtomeLife
review: I started playing my first Monster Hunter with World. It was a hard game for first timer, but I learned and improved a lot. I love it. I even picked up another Monster Hunter after this game. This game is tough, but so rewarding once you found out how to defeat the monster. However after Iceborne, I didn't really like having to tenderize every so often. I think the game would've been better without the Claw stuff. I hope they keep improving the game and making it rewarding for the players.

author: A Fancy Fridge Magnet
review: This is my first Monster Hunter game, and I absolutely love it. I played half of the story missions completely solo (well, I had my palico with me), and while my progress was slow at first, I always felt like I was learning and becoming better at combat. The combat is generally slow and methodical, as many weapons tend to have slow but powerful attacks. You absolutely cannot button mash in this game and be successful.There are many types of weapons, and learning how to use all of your weapon's moves is important, but it's even more important to learn each and every monster's moveset and attacks. Proper positioning and dodging is crucial against tougher enemies. It sometimes took me many, many tries to be able to defeat a new monster for the first time.. but once you have a lot of experience, you can kill the monster in minutes while laughing in its face. It's a very satisfying experience.This is a game where you will fight the same monsters many, many times to get their materials in order to build better armor and weapons. You don't want to be greedy with materials or money, since farming them becomes MUCH easier with better gear. You can even craft and learn to use items to make fights more manageable, but unlike most games, the grind for materials and resources is effortless and not tedious at all. The armor sets are beautiful, and it feels great to farm a monster for its weapons/armor set. There's no real end-all-be-all build like most games have. Your playstyle dictates what gear would be best for you, and not the other way around.Playing online with friends or even strangers makes the game so much better. You can then rely on teammates to help you out, and comboing with others is a lot of fun. The community is extremely nice and everyone is always looking to farm monsters.I have a handful if nitpicks about the game, but nothing that ruins the experience. The biggest, and only real complaint, is that the ENDGAME grind is kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ because it's almost completely tied to RNG... even worse... multiple levels of RNG. You upgrade your gear with decorations (jewels) that give you special skills, but some that are very powerful and unlock the true potential of weapons are locked behind extreme RNG... to the point where 450 hrs in the game doesn't even get you one of every decoration. And some of the skills require multiple of the same jewel to unlock the true power. As an example, to augment your weapon you might need TWO of a rare item. The item drop rate itself is low, but you also need to get one for the TYPE of weapon you're using, and also the RARITY level of the weapon. It's absolutely painful, and in a lot of ways you're better off using weapons that compliment the items you've acquired as opposed to trying to wait for a drop that may never come. This design also goes against the ideals of the game, where you're supposed to swap out a weapon for one that corresponds to the monster's elemental weakness, but your strongest weapon will always be the one you augment with rare items--meaning it's just better to use that than to think about elemental weaknesses. You absolutely don't need the upgrades to be successful, but they can definitely enhance your play... you just are at the mercy of RNG.The PC version of this game on release had some problems (namely major server issues), but the game is very stable and gets patched frequently with new content and features. This game absolutely deserves at minimum an 85% review score, and I believe most players have not updated their scores to reflect the server patches. That's not to say the servers are flawless, because some days the servers are bad, but for the most part there's no issue.

author: Tri-Dent
review: I wish i could wholeheartly recommend this game - I cannot.This is mainly due to Capcoms inresponsiveness to their horrible multiplayer experience. You either fail to find or establish a connection to your friends lobbies, or you suddenly lose connection (yes, this does happen while questing - alot) and are unable to reconnect because the game keeps the slot that you left reserved for you but failes to recognise you the second time. This is especially frustraiting when playing with four players, since the propability for any form of connection error are near to 100%. This does not mean you are not able to play in muliplayer - it means that it is a very taxing and tedious experience. A second mayor problem concering the online multiplayer feature is capcoms lack of integration for storyrelevant cutscenes and multiplayer. Let´s say you are four players who are all building a new character. Now let´s say you want to play one of the requiered story quest together - all four of you are now requiered to start the quest in single player mode, play until you have watched the cutscene (and are informed that you can now use SOS flare) and then quite to post the quest again and have all players join. You might be inclined to think "Hey let´s just wait till three of us are finished and joint the last of us when he has seen the cutscene" and yes is you are a fan of gambling this might be an option for you , since it seems to be totaly random if you are able to connect to a quest where a cutscene was watched.Even if you play in singleplayer and are just sometimes in need of help (SOS Flare) you are in for a disappointment. Help is not guaranteed - if you fire your flare in the first 20sec you sometimes do not recieve any help. This is not due to a lack if players (almoste 300.000 when this review was written), no, this is mainly due to the flawed multiplayer feature. It happens more often that you recieve support but only in the last two minutes or so - to late for rewards or proper help. This would be acceptable if there where less players but three players joining at the same time in the last two minutes of a quest seems to be rather odd to me.Beside this there are obvious problems with the FPS. To get to stable FPS (on any PC) you actually had to revert your Driver - even then FPS sometimes drop below 10.All in all Monster Hunter World is a good game. The fights are fun, a new armor part or weapon upgrade gives you the feeling of "pride and accomplishment" (and that all without pay-to-win DLC)  and the characters are somewhat likable (except for the Handler). But still, the technical flaws reduce actuall playtime and therefor fun alot. Since these problems have neither been fixed (since release) nor addressed by capcom I do not recommend this game.

author: Dralek
review: This game got me into Monster Hunter.  Got me to go grab Generations Ultimate on the Switch.  But that's besides the point.  If you know what a monster hunter game is, this is that, just with much smoother gameplay.  This lacks the jankiness of the original series' control scheme and movement, making for a much better experience overall.Out of any game I've ever seen, this one blows every one of them out of the water with how the wildlife and ecosystem is explained.  This is imaginative realism to the T, and it's constantly reinforced as you play the game.  Even old monsters are explained as to why they have the abilities they do, with a bit of far-fetched fantasy added in for the most powerful of all Monsters, the Elder Dragons.

author: Kyshion
review: Took me two hours for character customization. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.. I have to customize my cat(palico) as well?

author: Memori
review: This is a beautiful game with amazing animations and astonishing immersive UI. The audio is okay too, though not the best I've experienced. I'm having tons of fun playing with friends. The game's launch was riddled with bugs and other technical- and gameplay issues. Recently I played the game again, which allows me to revise this review.Original recommendation: [👎No] (found helpful by 9 people)New recommendation: [👍Yes] (developer has fixed most troublesome issues), although the game cannot be played during Steam maintenance and downtime. while progressing through the story. You constantly have to go into the mission, watch/do the intro/cutscene, and back out again just so you can start the mission with your friends.. There doesn't seem to be a noticable input delay anymore and the FPS doesn't feel choppy on my 144Hz monitor. although you do have to manually find this option and toggle it. By default, the mouse input is emulated as a controller joystick. means you can often spend way too much time trying to collect the materials. Fix this for a much better UX. after a while. If you're not quick enough, you can miss out on the loot. This is really bad. Parts and materials should stay until the end of time. This is very important to relief players of the pressure of having to pick up or harvest. to it. There's only a notification on the chat area. Monster Hunter's World competitor Dauntless does this much better. and cannot be configured to attack in the direction of the camera. You cannot even steer a bit during the combo while I feel like you should. You often find yourself hitting nothing but air with the monster "behind" you (but in front of the camera). You may call it difficulty, but it is artificial, non-intuitive and the margins on the input are way too long. This one is my opinion; other games (especially other monster hunters and fighter games) do have this too.. Allowing to do this while using an attack, while mid-air, or while stunned would save a lot of headaches of seeing that red-buff turn into white or orange just because you were doing an animation.

author: nemu

author: Dark_Messiah
review: The game is a true monster hunter experience, and i recommend that you get it, just not yet, and here is why:The game has some glaring issues, like inadequate keyboard and mouse controls, missing options for fov, motion blur etc., and multiplayer has some issues.Most improtantly is the fact that the game's performance doesn't live up to what is written on the front page of the game. My specs are well above the recommended and i was promised smooth 60 fps everywhere on 1080p, yet it frequently dips way below that, especially when looking in certain directions. Though after rolling back to a previous nvidia driver, the situation improved a bit, i still get sub 50 fps every now and again, though with much less frequency.So, i recommend that you get the game, but wait until after the first batch of updates to fix these issues are out.

author: pink bean
review: this isnt going to be as detailed as i'd like it to be but here's just my personal thoughts.my lapop isn't exactly the best but runs it mostly fine on low settings and 30 frames capped.story: not anything too spectacular, but coherent and provides for a fun time of overall hunting with friends. it goes along smoothly and there's still a bunch of endgame content you can go through with friends. overall i give the story aspect 4/5gameplay: so far very good. its engaging, has a better playstyle than MHO, has a lot of diffrent monsters to fight. i would only recommend having more different maps to fight in, i like that theyre big and open world but eventually you go through all of them and then you have nothing much else to discover. the new weapons are fun to play and all the cool palico stuff, little tricks like drinking too much and passing out are nice touches to the game. music: not necessarily something i paid much attention to and isnt too important for me, but overall very good. the music when you fight big monsters and wyverns are fairly memorable and badass sounding (> fighting big monsters at wildspire). 5/5and the part everyone wants to know; the technical aspects. a lot of connection issues. get kicked from sessions randomly in the middle of fighting elder dragons, friends get separated. this is literally the worst problem in this game. not only that, but there are also a lot of quest join failures, sometimes it wont let me join my friends quest if they posted it while i was in a quest and tried to join after when i was done, resulting in my friends having to repost the quest. not only that, but sometimes they have issues with the actual sessions themselves; they dont show up and we end up having to remake sessions all over again. when im trying to matchmak to find sessions, most of the time it doesnt even let me into a session and gives me constant errors. a lot of my other frieds have expressed having apparent errors when it comes to graphics, saying there is a glitch in the graphics, gives them errors, and kicks them off. i personally dont have this issue but my friend who has a way higher spec computer than me is having those issues. however i do think i have noticed a couple improvements in the last few days that its been released, so ill give it a 1/5. hopefully they fix the rest of the connection issues because thats the brunt of the problems right now.

author: Eat n Squeak
review: It's not that I don't like the game, I have some gameplay gripes, but nothing really major at the moment, so I think it's pretty alright, but the sheer difficulty in playing through the game with people is kind of baffling.You cant:- Join friends or people who are on the same (new) quest as you, because progress is logged on a per cutscene basis, meaning that to get the ability to join your friend on a new quest, you have to start the quest yourself, play through until you've triggered all the cutscenes in it, then quit your quest, and then join your friend.- Join friends or people who haven't triggered certain cutscenes in their quest, which the game will explicitly tell you (can't join party because leader has not viewed all cutscenes, or somesuch).- Apparently can't join friends or people on expeditions, at all.You have to complete a quest first - then opt to return to camp (not base/HQ) and start an expedition this way.You are out of luck if you just want to do an expedition, or join a friend in this.- You can't reconnect to a game if connection is dropped (this will happen a lot, especially this early on), because you cannot start an online session while in a quest.This is especially hilarious for support roles or generall ill prepared players who suddenly find themselves either having to solo the quest, or quit it altogether and start over.Now ultimately what this means, is that a lot of your time with friends (or anyone really) will be spent with you or someone else waiting and loafing around, waiting to even have the ability to connect to your friend, or playing through missions by yourselves in parallel, rather than - you know - playing together.And that is just, super bizarre for a game that seems so heavily built on it.Like, the ability to load a map with cutscenes and mission triggers with more than one player present is not some new and mysterious technology that was only just discovered in 2018, we've been able to do this for some 20 years now, so what exactly was the problem in development?Game came out in January guys, there was plenty of time to do something about this.

author: Shin
review: One of my absolute favorite games on PC right now, even tho it lacks alot of content compared to earlier titles (Yes I am looking at you Generations). Would recommend this game to everyone who likes action combat and planned methodical fights. You could go all "Leeroy Jenkins" in this game but you won't make it past HR then. However at the state the game is in I won't recommend it. It is plagued by terrible port probelems, console content is flat out missing and Capcom decided to "give us the same experience" which basically means they want to inflate the games life span artificially by releasing the DLC in a timely fashion. The good? The core game. Very polished, very nice gameplay, best MH game to date. The bad? Endgame content is missing/Console DLC could've been shipped with the base game but they didn't. The port is so bad that it makes you wonder what they did in the 6 months. The ugly? Poor optimization, has problems from being a port, connection issues are beyond frequent if you play outside your closed session. This will drive you mad, if you are even able to play it.Only buy this game now if you know what youre getting into and if you are fine with technical problems / connection issues.Will turn this review to positive once the issues are fixed.Edit: They fixed my issues with a patch. Game runs smoothly now and I dont have any connection issues anymore. Capcom please hurry up with the extra content. I recommend this game now, has a solid 100 hours of playtime if you play fast.

author: Kosher Pork ✞ Jesus Saves ✞
review: Yes, Yes, a hundred times yes. As a veteran who's owned MH games from nearly every generation starting from the original PS2 title, I will say that this is, in my opinion, the best monster hunter game ever made.It maintains all of the challenge and fun of its forebearers while making the game more accessible by pruning out the fake difficulty and tedious features present in previous titles, cutting out hair-pulling RNG mechanics like the old charm system along with making collecting materials for potions and joining quests significantly quicker - letting you spend more time actually hunting monsters. The grind has been cut down with the introduction of material melding, allowing you to get materials like the infamous plates and gems without pouring several hours into killing or capturing the same thing over and over. A slew of new features have been added to enrich gameplay such as mantles and boosters, permenant tools with cooldowns that confer benefits at no material cost to you that can range from producing a healing field or camoflauging yourself with a ghillie suit, and much more. The new scoutfly mechanic is something I never knew I needed, it's just so convenient and gives the sensation of becoming a more skilled tracker as I upgrade them with every quest I embark upon. Both fun and much less irritating than paintballing. Never before in any MH title have we had such freedom with exploring. Every map is open ended, and you can climb and crawl around nearly anything and fast travel to unlocked camps all over the map provided you aren't in combat. I have been spoiled for any other MH title with the new pace of gamplay and convenience these features provide. You even have a canteen at the campsite and access to ALL of your equipment and items inside the camp tent. Remember those times you cried inside because you forgot to replenish your items or eat before embarking on a quest? No worries here!For those new to the franchise, this is a great way to get introduced to it. It's a challenging game with a wealth of different weapon classes with their own distinctive playstyles along with epic monstrous creatures to track and hunt, and this is the most accessible title thus far.

author: Keane
review: A Monster Hunter Review Worth Reading:Pros:  - It's Fun AF - Having some buddies and hunting ♥♥♥♥ and just having a good time. - Even going in solo and exploring/ breaking your limits as a player / trying out new weapons and glorious movesets.  - Not worrying about completing all the content in 10 hours so you can have a build you found on YouTube that looks cool and does all the things and is "Broken OP" etc so you can finally impress Veronica in your Discord Call with this new thing you do better than others around your friend circle jerk.  - It's Fun AF - Nice Events and new content. Increasingly harder challenges with the monsters you've come to learn and battle against. - ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Cats that fight. - Being able to just think of some rando idea / make a build around it / Not worrying about if comparing it to the meta online will shave off 4 seconds of enjoyment and ruin your life.  - It's Fun AFCons: - Crybaby ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that want to 1 shot everything in a game and then complain a game is "super easy" for some random internet status.  - Idiots that want to sound important on the internet / People too lazy to either customize a control scheme to their taste and/or too brain dead to try something new like a controller for a different and even potentially better gaming experience. -  People scared to fail, learn, and then succeed.  - Having the powercharm etc in your inventory because I want to gather more ♥♥♥♥ in the world. Yeah, botany exists. ♥♥♥♥ you. This is my review.Suggestion Box: - I want all the transmog for all armor sets no matter what set I am wearing. The art on some of these sets are amaz-balls and it would be neat-o. - I want more cat gadgets that just do rando stuff for the luls. - Make more of these games for PC please.If you are someone that didn't get triggered like some kid and you are not obsessed with the things above. author: Goilveig
review: Summary: Overall a fun game, but currently (week after launch) there are some network issues with co-op gameplay.  If co-op with random players is a key draw for you, you might consider waiting a week or two while they iron out the kinks.Basic Gameplay:Mostly this is a game where you hunt huge monsters for loot, craft gear with that loot, and repeat.  There are also many gatherable materials throughout the world which you will use to craft consumables, however you will have the opportunity to automatically gain 1-3 different types of plant or insect materials after each quest, so you typically won't need to grind for gathering spots too often.The overall monster hunt combat is an ARPG-style fight where you will seek to hit a monster's weak points while avoiding its attacks.  Combat is not quite as fast paced or fluid compared to ARPGs such as Nioh, but it's still quite fun.Pros: - There are a large number of weapon choices, each has a lot of depth to master, and the playstyles are very different, from the lancer carefully engaging from behind the shield to the insect glaive user doing aerial acrobatics and riding on the monster's back.  None of the weapon options are a bad choice, and you'll find something here to fit pretty much any playstyle. - Combat is challenging enough to entertain while being more accessible than the extremely hardcore ARPGs. - There's a lot of different consumables that can support different playstyles as well.  Except for elder dragons, any large monster in the game can be either killed or captured, for identical rewards. - The game can be played single-player (you can always have an NPC companion and can recruit up to two others during a mission), or with parties of up to four players.  Two-player is the hardest in terms of scaling, but I have played a lot of the game in that mode and it's definitely been doable.  You can play with specific other players or easily recuit (and be recruited) for random matchmaking. - Some of the fights can be pretty epic, even for the action RPG genre which is no stranger to over-the-top fights.Cons:  - The biggest cons so far are connectivity issues.  While I've had zero issue with friends whose online sessions I joined, playing with random players through the SOS system has resulted in about 10-15% of sessions disconnecting before the mission was complete.  This is likely to be something they fix soon. - Story is pretty minimal. It's there, but don't expect a masterpiece of storytelling.  At best the story is "passable".  There was never a point where I was excited to learn more about the lore or the world, though, which was disappointing as I usually like to get into game lore. - Combat isn't quite as fluid as other ARPGs like Nioh.

author: Edward C!™

At first I thought the controls and weapon drawbacks were stupid but I realize they are in place to preserve balance. The game does an excellent job of the scale of the monsters and the destruction they cause. The voice acting is a little corny and the story is kinda weak, but it gets the job done. You don't really care about about the story anyway- it's all about the hunt. Internet connection issues plauged my online gameplay from the start and the in game voice chat sucks, but most of those issues have been fixed as of late. It's cool to solo (to learn how the weapons function and study the monsters' behavioral patterns) but better with friends for the bigger and harder hunts. Get some friends.

author: Ian / Zee!
review: When I picked MH:W up in the early days of the pandemic, I didn't really know what I was getting into. I was looking for things I could do with my partner. We were looking for something more exciting and engaging than hanging out at each other's islands in Animal Crossing. I'd played some Monster Hunter Tri (on the Wii) in the past, but hadn't really kept up with the series.What I found was a beautiful experience of playing together. As others have pointed out plenty of times, co-op through the story is a hassle because you need to get through the cut scenes before you can co-op a story mission. But outside of that, there were so many opportunities to just get into the game and punch monsters of every shape and size. We tried out different builds together, we tackled everything from Anajanaths to Kulve Taroth as a team. We had so many exciting and thrilling moments of exploring the world, working together, and just delighting in all the interactions we had over it.I'm just sad we weren't able to carry that same love and enthusiasm over to the next game in the series. Maybe one day there will be a MHW2 I can look forward to spending hundreds more hours in.10/10, this game changes lives and builds relationships.

author: Chickenori
review: Monster Hunter World is a very fun game where you,  ; hunt monsters. The major gameplay loop has you hunt monsters, use their parts to create better armor and weapons so that you can hunt bigger and tougher monsters.  You have 14 different kinds weapons to pick from, making it perfect to experiment and find the ones that fit your play style. The combat is really solid and makes it very satisfying to master, though it may take some practice. After fighting a monster you can use parts carved from its body to forge new weapons and armor. You usually wont have enough to make it after fighting it once so you will need to grind for the gear you want, but that isnt a bad thing, as it makes it feel extremely rewarding when you finally get the gear you've been wanting. Getting new gear is a great reward that will keep you coming back. The world is very well built and fun to be in. Youll start in the research base Astera as part of the research commission, where you are tasked to solve the mystery of the elder crossing, a mysterious phenomenon where elder dragons are crossing the sea every decade to go to the new world. It an epic story and it makes your hunts feel as if you are contributing to something bigger every time you solve a mystery and report it to the commander. The New World itself if very beautiful and feels lives in by all the monsters in it. The ecosystems are all very well though out and you can use the environments to your advantage as you hunt. This is a very solid game with hundreds if not thousands of hours of content. Some of the fights are very tough and you'll want to bring a friend, but you can do it by yourself too. The graphics are probably the best in the series and it is a very complete game. And that's not even taking account the dlc witch adds a whole new games worth of content on top of it. While the game is not getting updates anymore and is no longer the most recent game in the series, it is an absolute masterpiece that is worth every penny. (and you can find it on sale often)I highly recommend it if it looks interesting to you, you will not regret it.

author: obtv123™
review: Monster hunter, one of the most prominent RPG game series to have ever been made, have finally made its debut on PC platform for the very first time in the form of Monster Hunter: World (MHW), presenting us with an insanely high graphic quality, alongside an addictive game-play that retained the charm of older games in the series combined with a relatively big and complex open world maps to play in, wield cool massive weapons and dive right in to hunt gigantic beasts as the master hunter of the fifth fleet!MHW is a game about, well, hunting monsters, and for people not familiar with the Monster Hunter series, it is not what you would expect from most other RPGs where you go in and grind away at small monsters to level up your stats then face off against the boss, instead MHW makes the player square off against what most would consider a boss enemy one after the other, and then repeatedly grind said “bosses” to get their gear to improve your stats. The learning curve of MHW can certainly be challenging, the difficulty jumps can at times be overwhelming, it did take me over 3 tries and 8 deaths or so to make it past the Anjannath. Aside from mechanical difficulties of the game, there are many concepts you need to learn to play the game properly such as how exactly does the canteen work, what are all these slinger ammo, where to find these materials, etc. All of which could be tedious to learn if you dislike reading a lot of texts, as there are only text based tutorials available. Although difficult, learning the game is sure to be rewarding as it expands on the amount of things you could do, and fun things you could try.Every large monster in this game has their own unique and complex move-set with an iconic look to them, making nearly every fight memorable, and even if you have beaten them, you could take some more time to fight them again to learn their pattern and get better at the game. Aside from the variety of enemies, MHW also offers 14 weapons of choice, all of which are unique, playing each one feels like playing a completely different game, not to mention the skill cap of these weapons which are very high, therefore rewarding us for actually spending time with the weapon to master them. Combining the high skill level and variety of content, makes MHW one of the most re-playable games, being fresh and entertaining even after clocking in hundreds of hours.All in all, MHW’s main selling point is in its complexity, the deeper you go, the more you find, even idly sitting by to customize your build is fun as there are limitless amount of combinations you can come up with, and its rather organic and non-snappy controls offers a challenge unlike most other games. This very strength of MHW though is also probably its weakness that kept it from becoming a mainstream appeal, as the organic control could feel clunky at times, and the depth that MHW offers can certainly be overwhelming, though I certainly urge you to at least give this game a try, spend some time learning, and if you do like it, MHW will give you one of the most satisfying and exciting game-play experience a game can offer.

Once you understand the mechanics of the game, things to collect, to achieve and expand stuff, it'll be so fun. This is where Side-quests are important and gives you back something. Players with the same HR (Hunter Rank) as you might drop in and adds some help, but MOST OF THE TIME, IT'S A BORED HIGH RANKED PLAYER THAT'LL HELP YA. Either way, community seems like a bunch of good people. There is so much DLC's too choose at and yeah, if you want more storyline and different things after MHW's New World, try out Icebourne. Buy at your own risk but I'll tell ya, I'm a supporter of Monster Hunter and DEFINITELY TRY THIS OUT! Have fun and just ask google or reddit if you got questions on how to do this and that, how to find this and that, what's the weakness or whatever a lot more stuff this and that. Have a good one and good luck Future Hunters!
