author: ✪V1cisiouS
review: Starting of with the story, It's real fun to know new monsters as the story progresses but as we move on it really gets challenging as their ability enhances. Simply put, if you like the essence of grinding, then, you'll love the game in general. If you are only here to finish the story, then, it can be achieved without much grinding but keep in mind that, the story of Monster Hunter World is there only for the sake of being there; it's nothing extraordinary & shouldn't be your only reason to buy the game. That being said, grind is a must if you want to venture beyond the story & lust for some of the best gears & late monsters in the game. Now, the core strength of this game undoubtedly lies in the various monsters that lurks around the world. Monsters are effing brutal, each with their own distinct characteristics & abilities. Each & every of them feels like a boss fight. Prepare to spend good 10-15 mins to take down a monster as they are quite tanky but the pleasure of besting them surely feels incredible. Apart from the monsters, the gameplay mechanic is solid as rock, coupled with the gorgeous ambience. The game sounds good, looks better, plays best. Total of 14 different types of weapons with skillsets, playstyles & combos that's unique from one another. Freaking tons of badass looking armors, deep customization system & crafting options are at your disposal to make your life easy when you take on those mystical creatures of doom. If you want to solo only, albeit surely possible, it may get a bit difficult or tedious. Best played with mates of course, and, the multiplayer system is being implemented in such a fluid way that you can join others very easily without any hassle. No server issues anymore as well. Only gripe that I have is that joining the story quest in multiplayer isn't as seamless as joining those optional quests. I had to reach a certain point of every story related missions & only after that my friends could join which made my experience a bit disjointed. Also, some quests where I had to search for monster tracks felt really exhausting & monotonous beacuse I had to return to hub & come again repeatedly to search for it to fill the bar.So, overall, I would recommend this game if grinding is your cup of tea as you'll be battling with the same monsters again & again for those exotic loots. If not, I would still recommend it to buy with your friends to experience some epic monster fights in co-op, but on sale.

author: Lerin Gotchri
review: As an "OG" fan of the series, starting on the original PS2 release back in 2004, there is no way I could not recommend the game to friends, or really anyone curious about it. The combat systems are in general the same across all the series, with little bonus mechanics added in/taken out of each installment. This game allows you the freedom of choice for weapons, and they all are absolutely amazing when played properly. Each one has specific playstyles, or even cater to specific groups of people. Of course, there are 'metas', like the Longsword and Bowguns, but that doesn't make the others any less viable. Of course, the MH franchise also has a great learning curve. I like to compare the combat to Dark Souls, as more people know/have heard of it, but with a lot more gradual, eased in learning curve. You're not just plopped into a 'tutorial' boss that'll mop the floor with you, you work your way up to those creatures, learning your weapon(s) along the way. It's really, REALLY well done for teaching people the combat system, and even the dodge mechanic. Even if it has way less i-frames than any dark souls, heh.Last but not least, unlike all the previous MH games, World actually feels ALIVE. Open world maps, creatures that fight against each other and not with each other like all the past games, even the use of scoutflies is great. As the old way of tracking didn't make all that much sense to me personally (paintballs). Even invasive creatures interrupting your fight feels more natural, as they usually have turf wars, some of which are absolutely awesome (rajang vs jho). So yes, I 100% think everyone should at least try MH, if it catches their eye.

author: Definively Not Alchman
review: MH is a game about killing monsters and using their parts to kill stronger monsters. there really not a story... is more like a setting really.the closest game i always compare it to is diablo, except there is no levels everything is gear based, you are mostly* not relying on RNG loot drops for gear as you craft everything and it never falls on that dull grinding where you shut your mind off and a week latter you can't remember out what you exactly did for a whole week, since is always bosses all the time and you always learning new things.also, because the worse that happens if you fail is lose 10~20 minutes, the game does not pulls out any punches, it doesn't treat you like a baby or give you a pass because "oh is not fair if the player doesn't see the end of the story" it is free to get hard and unfair as it wants (and it sure does it)people play it because... well the game is fun, the fights are fun, the monsters are incredibly cool, getting better at the game is the kind of rewarding experience most games lack nowadays, there are 14 different weapons that play completely different from each other and a bunch of side stuff as well. so there is always something to do or to try or to learn.and don't get too worried about end game, yeah it exists. but is literally the same as the rest of the game, this is not a mmo where you do something and the end game is where things really begins. there is a lot to do, to try, to learn... take your timewhat iceborn mostly adds is a new difficulty level, the base game has low rank and high rank. iceborn adds master rank and it has new places and monsters on that rank. but you still fight the monsters from previous rank in stronger forms sometimes with new attacks on higher ranks.and don't bother with defender/guardian weapons, it just a way to bypass the low and high rank with overpowerful weapons. mostly for people who don't have their original saves anymore when the expansion came out. with them you are skipping the hard part of the game and going right to the very very hard part of the game. you can see the issue with that right?

author: Dylki
review: Monster Hunter World was my first step into the franchise, so while I can’t speak with the wisdom of a veteran I’ll give my two cents as a greenhorn. In short, MHW is not an easy game, but I think it is easily the best one I’ve played. It rewards patience and practice, and conquering a difficult monster is one of the most satisfying feelings in the world--before you inevitably hunt said monster into extinction because you need more of its teeth and a piece of its frontal cranium to stick on your funky hammer that looks like a bastardized axe for your own amusement.TLDR: Demanding but highly satisfying learning curve for both weapons and monsters, diverse large maps to explore and environments to use to your advantage, attention to small details like capturing endemic life and thoughtful NPC interactions. I started out really badly, missing hits and getting whacked around constantly by even the earliest monsters. As an old Warframe player, the lack of mobility in MHW was quite jarring, shown by the countless times I’ve tried to dodge and failed miserably. After the initial battering, the next step is about perseverance, revisiting monsters to farm materials to get stronger armor and weapons. It’s an uphill battle, especially if you need to repeatedly do a monster that took 30 minutes and 2 faints the first time you tried. It’s about fighting the monster and yourself, as you really need to think one step ahead and pace yourself according to the enemy. The diverse range of weapons the MH franchise offers is no secret, giving players many different ways to fight the same monsters. In my opinion, every weapon is great and fun, and while it takes a lot of time to learn and master certain ones, it’s never a bad idea to have multiple main weapons to see you through different hunts. I love the insect glaive like nothing else, and I’ll die on this hill. (not literally) But for monsters that are more ferocious, I tend to approach them more cautiously with the lance or charge blade with their incredible mix of defensive and offensive capabilities, for example.This journey of constant learning and relearning forms the bulk of my MHW experience, and even as I’m gearing up for the final boss I’m still working out the moves of monsters I’ve already conquered, and learning new weapons. I found this process of self-improvement to be the most satisfying part of the game, and something I haven’t been able to find in any other franchise to date. There’s no better feeling than greeting a monster like an old friend before you kick the ♥♥♥♥ out of each other, with a fast-paced fight that makes you feel almost invincible as you dodge, weave or just walk out of the way of attacks that used to rend the flesh off your bones.MHW has seen me through some tough times as well, so the sense of achievement I attained from overcoming great beasts here has also kept me going in the real world.As the name implies, MHW emphasizes the world it has created, giving players several maps to explore. Besides being pretty, these locations provide diverse areas to fight monsters in. As you chase monsters from one area to the next, you’ll find no shortage of ledges, slopes, vine traps, loose boulders or even cannons to gain the upper hand in a battle. This is something that’s very much less present in older MH titles, something I realised after playing MHGU a month ago. While the same few maps can get old after hundreds of hours, I think that it was very thoughtful to have such features in the first place that spice up the fight more often than not. Moreso, I enjoyed the exploration itself, running around freely in expeditions to collect mushrooms, look for shortcuts or befriend the local cats--who can actually help out a lot in hunts. Befriending the Grimalkyne tribes in each map means they may set up vine traps to ensnare a monster, or even drop a whole firing squad to give you a chance to brutalize your quarry. I also enjoyed collecting the endemic life, though it is a much smaller part of the game. As an animal lover, I was stunned when I threw my net at a random bird on the beach and got to bring it home as a pet. Almost any creature you see in the wild is either a material or a potential pet to let loose in your room, and I have spent many hours hunting down fluffy birds to keep, or fishing for majestic fish in the frozen bowels of the arctic. This is not compulsory unless you’re going for 100% achievements, but I feel it’s a very nice touch to the game, making the world seem more alive. While nobody ever plays Monster Hunter for the story, I feel like MHW had a decent storyline, following abnormal behavior of a great dragon and pioneering exploration into the New World to uncover the secrets of the land. While not terribly emotional, I feel that it was linear enough to be clear, and gave story quests some meaning. I do feel that the NPCs were crafted with a lot of thought, seeing how different fleets were sent to the New World every 10 years, each with different specialties like engineering, resource management, research or hunting. This does shape NPCs’ attitudes and lines, especially if they hail from different fleets. Moreso, MHW gives presence to the player, as NPC voice lines change according to the recent quests players have completed, or if the player is about to square up against a tough foe. I remember the day I completed all the optional quests in MHW, and I was presented with a bonus quest to hunt 4 challenging monsters in a row. After my success, every NPC in the hub presented me with a short congratulatory message, and it differed significantly between everyone, from the novice hunters strolling around to the resident botanist, and even the sailors who helped out at port managed to get a word in. I recall walking to the highest point in Astera and speaking to the Admiral, who had quite the speech prepared. I screenshotted the whole conversation, and I still look at it from time to time when I'm feeling sappy. It’s a small detail, but I have heartfelt appreciation for the team that decided to implement it, giving some weight to my actions, and making MHW even more immersive. All the NPCs are now clamoring for me to face off against the final boss, so in a way I feel like their hopes and dreams are on my back too.It’s a long review, but I feel like I couldn’t have discounted my feelings for this game with less words. MHW remains my favorite game of all time, and has even encouraged me to delve further into the series with other titles like MHGU and MHR, and now I eagerly await the release of MHST2. If you have any doubts about buying this game, it’s never too late to start. It’s more fun with friends (though I insisted on doing mostly everything solo) so grab your buddies and don’t hesitate to call on pubs if you need help--some randoms are actually really good!Happy Hunting!Edit: I beat the final boss for the first time, and on a solo hunt! I finished the quest with 30s left on the clock, but it was really satisfying to get it done, and go through all the NPC dialogue at the end. There's a cool nod to characters from the previous generations as well, which is a nice touch!Second edit: The endgame grind can get droll, but it's still a blast to play, and a means to pass the time while we all wait for MHRise's PC release, and Sunbreak! I've managed to solo the final boss 15 times now, and while not perfect these hunts have given me some seriously hair raising thrills. I look forward to the challenges I'll find in other games of the series!

author: Forgiveness
review: I have thoroughly enjoyed this game and will continue to. I played Monster Hunter World before Iceborne was released on the PS4, I would guess my total hours in the game is closer to 800 if that counts for anything. I'm going to do something a little more unique with my review, I'm going to give tips that will save you both confusion and frustration before giving my actual review.#1. Make item loadouts. This will minimize time spent in item management menus, and more time actually slapping dinosaur pickles (that's not an innuendo).      a. If you go into your menu you will see an option to customize radial menu. Set up your radial menu for          access to quick crafting of items while on hunts. You  find yourself needing more megapotions,         more traps, more flashpods, more tranq bombs, etc. (There's an option for controllers to change how         you select items on the radial menu to be a click of the right joystick, which I highly recommend.)     b. If you go into the menus and go into your item pouch, if you hit Triangle (PS), Y (Xbox), or X (PC), you         can rearrange your item bar so you can organize your consumables as you cycle through them.     c. Anytime you make ANY changes to the item bar, or radial menu, or item pouch, SAVE THE LOADOUT         AGAIN OR IT WILL BE REVERTED WHEN YOU SELECT THAT LOADOUT AGAIN. Don't be this guy, who        did his item loadouts countless times because I didn't know this. #2. You can capture monsters. If they start to limp and run away, they are capturable. This will take either a pitfall or more commonly a shock trap and 2 tranq bombs. I recommend using the tranq bombs before the traps. Once you have used the tranq bombs just place a trap and boom, hunt complete. You get bonus rewards for capturing and also save time from having to fight the last 20% or so remaining hp of the monster. #3. Always carry flashpods. They can be made with flash bugs, and will briefly stun and blind a monster. This can give you and/or your teammates a safe opportunity to heal if you find yourself in an "uh-oh" situation. Additionally, any flying monsters, (with  few exceptions) will be knocked out of the sky and stunned should they be flashed while flying. This gives you and your teammates an opening to freely attack the monster, and prevents most flying monsters from doing their most annoying attacks, particularly for melee users.#4. Go into the training area as soon as you can and try every single weapon. If you find yourself liking a weapon watch a youtube video showcasing the weapon and all the things it can do. Many weapons have some special mechanics, that the game either doesn't explain at all or doesn't do it very well. Don't let these videos overwhelm you, and don't worry about memorizing every single mechanic right now, use it as a glimpse of what you'll be able to do eventually. Every weapon is a tool for you the hunter, and like a tool, each one has it's uses and it's strengths once you learn to use it properly. Find the tool of death and destruction that works for you. Should you get MHW? Well, I guess the thumb at the top has spoiled the answer, but yes, I believe the game with Iceborne expansion package is worth full price. The game has many fantastic parts to it, in my opinion, but I will not refuse to acknowledge some of the problems this game has. So lets just get it over with. Unskippable cutscenes. Probably my biggest gripe with this game my first and second time playing through it, but granted I played through the base game already on PS4 before, so it was probably particularly painful for me. It wouldn't be as bad if some of the cutscenes weren't Final Fantasy length, going on for 3 to 5 minutes at points. Another problem, is that there can be some very annoying mechanics, mainly in the early/mid game which can definitely hurt enjoyment of the title. The first thing that comes into my mind are stuns. Nothing has caused me more frustration then getting hit, taking a nice 3 seconds to stand up, being stunned another 3 to 4 seconds, then before I can recover from the stun, the monster recovers, turns and goes for another swing which has lead to countless deaths to not only me but others as well. However, while this will lead to a positive for the game, it the game much harder and more frustrating to new players, which can turn people off to this game before they get to the parts that really make the game great.If you're not careful, and to a point even if you are careful, your time in the game can quickly become primarily spent looking at item management menus or looking at the blacksmith comparing new armors and weapons to what you currently have. Monster Hunter is very much a game that's hard to learn and even harder to master. However, much like a game like Dark Souls, the difficulty is heavily influenced by the player's experience and knowledge. And with that, MHW is a very rewarding game to learn. I learned an ounce of preparation is worth a pound of brute force. The simple act of bringing flashpods to the first Rathalos fight can turn a 35min hunt into a 15min one.  Which brings me to talk about how knowledge overcomes many of the annoying parts of this game. Tired of being poisoned, stunned, interrupted from the monster roaring? Get some antidotes or equipment with poison resistance, get equipment with stun resistance, get equipment with earplugs. You know you can roll to dodge monster roars with the iframes it gives? It's challenging, but entirely possible and it's a step toward mastery. If ever you're fighting a monster and you find yourself thinking, "this is really annoying" there is always something you can do to either mitigate or negate it. It's all a matter of thinking about how you can, and inventing or adopting new hunting methods. Over time you'll learn more and more options through discovery on your own. Many special slinger ammo can interrupt a monster. You can cancel annoying attacks before the monster starts them. You can utilize environmental traps, or small ledges to do jump attacks and mount the monster. After 800+ hours I'm still learning little things I can do against monsters I've fought a hundred times. That to me is what makes this game awesome. There's no singular right way to play, you have freedom to do things as by the book or as unorthodox as you want. It's that same freedom that allows you to tailor your equipment and playstyle to counter anything you personally find annoying. There are countless strategies for each monster and each environment. All of this paired with interesting equipment options, tons of options to use on monsters in hunts, powerful hits that FEEL powerful through a computer screen, and that sense of satisfaction that comes from overcoming challenges that can sometimes feel like a mountain. I love this game, and while it's not for everyone, I think everyone should at least try it.

author: clare
review: I had two friends put pressure on me to give this game an honest try for over two years. One of them even gifted it to me on console and I STILL hardly played it (kinda messed up lol I know oops). Fast forward to 2020, and I decided to give the game an honest try. As one might guess from the amount of hours I ultimately ended up putting into a PvE game, I've gotten more than my money's worth. I enjoyed this game so much that I even ended up posting speedruns for my favorite hunts online. I made a mistake by not playing it earlier. Monster Hunter: World is at its core a quest-based cooperative PvE experience where up to four players kill or capture various monsters. The durability of a monster scales with how many players are in the hunt, having one, two, and 3-4 player scaling. The game tells its story primarily through quests featuring a hunt with accompanying dialogue. To prepare for these hunts, players can upgrade their weapons as well as their armor through the collection of various monster materials they collect on the field. They also can prepare item pouches prior to setting out that can benefit them during a hunt. This is not the game for you if you're specifically looking for a game with a deep, insightful plot. While the story is not at all bad, it stands out in neither its delivery nor its quality. The main questline serves most importantly to the player as a way to keep them invested in the core gameplay loop: hunting monsters.  As the game progresses, knowledge of the monster you're hunting becomes more important. "Should I use an elemental weapon, and if so, which element?" "How can I get this monster to slow down?" "Where's the weak spot?" If you don't know the answers to these questions, you'll be making the hunt that much harder on yourself. There's a monster in the Iceborne expansion called "Barioth" who has a reputation for serving as a "wall" for players who are unprepared for him due to his swiftness. However, if you know or figure out that you need to break one or both of his front arms to decrease his speed and give yourself more windows to attack him, the hunt becomes significantly more manageable. Knowledge of the monster's moveset combined with familiarity with your weapon also is an important part of combat. Attacks such as the Sword and Shield's Perfect Rush, Longsword's Helmsplitter, Greatsword's True Charged Slash, and several other attacks initially seem difficult to effectively employ in combat unless the monster is trapped or toppled. However, as you grow more familiar with a monster's attacks, you'll begin to see more and more windows to land your strongest attacks that at first you struggled weaving into your gameplay. As you play through the game, you will discover new monsters, and every monster has its own unique set of armor players can craft. The base defense of armor can be upgraded through "armor spheres." Different armor sets also come with different "skills" preloaded to a certain level on the armor. You can increase the level of a skill, and therefore increase its effectiveness, by equipping "decorations," usually called "decos" by players, to your armor pieces. Decorations are earned primarily by hunting "tempered" monsters, which are souped-up monsters that deal more damage and have more health. There are also various armor set bonuses that one can only benefit from by equipping a certain amount of armor pieces from a specific armor set. This system of armor progression combined with the fact that there are over 100 skills in the game allow a great amount of creativity with your builds. There are an equally numerous amount of weapons in the game. There are various crafting trees that allow players to produce a variety of weapons that are capable of a litany of effects, from statuses like paralysis and sleep to elements such as fire and ice. In short, making builds is an integral part of the game as the player progresses, growing more vast in scope as more monsters and their materials are introduced. There are also various sidequests in the game that unlock special tools, meal ingredients, garden slots, and more. Co-op, while it might not be the most efficient way to play the game, is without a doubt the most fun. The hectic-yet-controlled nature of multiplayer hunts make them memorable experiences, and I spent countless hours helping other players out with difficult hunts purely just for the fun of it. To play with other random people, you can either shoot an SOS flare ingame for other players to see, or find SOS flares to respond to yourself through either your quest handlers or the quest board. That being said, there are some hunts particularly in the endgame where having multiple players can make losing more likely. There are some hunts in the game, especially in Iceborne after the main quest, where the players are expected to understand certain mechanics that, if they don't know them, will almost certainly doom the team to losing. The most fitting examples of this are  However, even when I've played with random people and lost, I've still had fun; the gameplay is just that good and satisfying, and it feels all the better to be able to help someone out who was struggling on a tough fight. When I played through the base game's main storyline, I was underwhelmed with the difficulty. While it's by no means easy for everyone, I was expecting more as we reached the main questline's conclusion. Even if you end up having a difficult time in the base game, you can always craft the "Defender's Set," an armor set designed to speed players through the base game so they can reach the Iceborne content. However, as tempting as that might be, I'd recommend against doing this; you may inadvertently skip over and miss a lot of important aspects of the gameplay due to being carried by the busted armor set, and Iceborne will rudely awaken you. Iceborne's content introduces "Master Rank," a tier above the base game's "Low Rank" and "High Rank Quests" and having monsters just as strong to match. The typical monsters in Master Rank are on par statwise with arch-tempered level monsters in the base game while also introducing new monsters and a new region, while also having tempered variants and in some cases arch-tempered variants of those aforementioned monsters. Iceborne will certainly pose a unique challenge especially initially, and even players who were unchallenged by the base game will at least see the times it takes to complete each hunt become significantly longer. The endgame is a unique beast. I've fought Manus and the Nameless King in Dark Souls and DS3 respectively, and was able to beat those bosses blind pretty quickly; in comparison, it took me several hours to get my first win against the final DLC monster blind. There's something in this game for everyone regardless of their skill level.I could go on forever about this game, but I'm literally running out of space! :( Essentially,  get this game if you want:- a cooperative PvE experience- boss rush-style gameplay- skill-based combat- in-depth progression and build-crafting- progressive difficulty- a gorgeous New World to exploreYou won't regret it.

author: LiliumDaemon
review: So, this game is pretty good. Nothing too special but definetly no trash. What I love most about it is the graphics and design of armour, weapons, especially the monsters, buildings, etc. they look stunningly beautiful! I also enjoy being able to explore the region on my own before actually fighting the monster and having to track the monster in advance is also something I really like. The game gives you a variety of weapons to use with different aspects and fighting techniques, you can choose whatever fits your fighting style best. Though the fighting itself feels realistically heavy no matter which weapon you use. You will have to calculate the duration of the cooldown after an attack when fighting a monster in order to have enough time to evade the monsters' attack afterwords (you can literally not move for a while after attacking no matter how much you press evade :D). Also using attack combos to deal more damage will force you to move in one and the same direction through that whole combination which leads to hitting the monster maybe once or twice and after that you moved through the monster just to set the most powerful slash of your combo in the air :D. You can't really change direction during a combo. So yeah, fighting can be reaaaaaaaaallly annoying due to little mobility. Also the hitbox of the monsters' attacks is not very realistic because it litterally hits you even when you are 4 meters above the monster in the air. Fighting is pain. But let's be honest, it probably would be like this (with the cooldown after an attack) in real life, too so it's just realistic fighting mechanics I guess. But the great looks make it worth for me :) Also the story isn't too bad and the characters are fun ^^

author: Pinobbi
review: As someone who had never played a game from the Monster Hunter franchise before, I must say this game made me want to go back and play every other MH title. The story: meh, not the forte nor the focus;Gameplay: very diverse, open to a lot of different playstyles and no two fights feel the same, and while every weapon is relatively easy to pick up, they have high skill ceilings;Music: just wow. the battle/monster music just fits each monster so well and does an amazing job of putting you in that moment;Multiplayer: I really wish it was easier to progress on the story on multiplayer, which is still a bit of a pain in the a$s, but aside from that, the multiplayer, to me, is one of the best aspects of this game and hunting with friends is so much more funOverall, an incredible experience, I was never on the Monster Hunter bandwagon but playing this game made me realize why it is Capcom's all-time sales leader.

author: Stealy'McGrabsalot
review: Not my first Monster Hunter. I've been playing since TRI. Am I considered a MH Veteran? Maybe, I dunno. I just know this is ALOT of peoples first Monster Hunter and that's SUPER exciting. Welcome aboard. Thank you SO much for trying it out. Previously to World; MH had a secluded niche and small following that had a rough start in markets outside of Japan. Alot of the time the games weren't ever guranteed to make it to the US or EUR. World is the first installment to a series (thats nearly 20 years old) to have extremely positive sales so I'm hopeful for the future of this series even more than ever. Thank you.Honestly, I'll consider this my favorite franchise. Monster Hunter has been all I've been playing as of late. This one, even the older ones, are helping me fill-in the "I must play rise" illness I've contracted. I'll make bold claims. I don't need any other games. This is fun, oddly calming, and rewarding. The premence is simple. The gameplay is seemingly endless and challenging as it does get gradually harder and harder. You beat up dinosaurs and dragons with big weapons. Harvest their skins for even bigger weapons and then fight even bigger and stonger monsters for even more stuff. Thats really all it is. You can clock 100+ hours easily in these games, and yes, If you have friends to join you they can always join since Monster Hunter has always been about taking down hard Monster with friends since the beginning. MHWI has treated me fairly good. MHGU treated me good. MH4U treated me good. MH3U treated me good. And, MHFU has treated me good too. I can't wait for Rise; Will it be just as good? Probably. I dunno but I've already preordered it for switch. And gosh,Has it been a painful wait.

author: Cravol
review: This recommendation comes with a caveat, described the third and fourth paragraph. If you check my other reviews, you'll find that at the time of posting this I only have one other review. Outside of one of my favorite games of all time, it is rare for me to take the time to review steam games. However this game has had a long history on steam of mixed attention, and I want to shed my light on it. I would also like to stress that, at the time of writing this, I do not own and have not played the Iceborne DLC.In terms of gameplay, I cannot recommend this or any other Monster Hunter game enough. Monster Hunter consistently has the most content for the price imaginable of just about any game or franchise out there. This content is packed with deep gameplay that will fill any player with a sense of mastery and skill, and a myriad of playstyles to pursue. I grew up playing Monster Hunter games solo, so while I'm very glad I've had the joy of playing this game with several other friends, I honestly think you wouldn't be missing out to buy this game and just play an hour or so solo at any given time. I would go further to point out that this game has more solo play support than many of the Monster Hunters I played as a youth, including features I didn't discover until much later in my play time messing around on days my friends were busy and I wasn't. The majority of negative reviews are pointing to major tech malfunction making the game unplayable, and I can attest that this is occasionally the case. I personally was unable to play the game for several months due to a behavior between the software and my antivirus. Most of the stories I have heard are similar situations; a particular piece of software having core issues with MHW and preventing it from loading properly. In light of this, I would not recommend this game to anyone who will get frustrated about major tech issues or who cannot troubleshoot on their own. For me, I play a lot of games, so I was able to simply set the game aside until it was fixed, but I completely understand the frustration of people who spent $60+ on this game being unable to play it for time periods of that length. I will humbly state once more that I believe the challenging-but-fair gameplay of MHW is absolutely worth it for me, but you will have to decide if you are willing to run the risk of this type of tech frustration.

author: BlueMercury
review: I first started playing MH games when I was younger, back when Tri came out on the Wii. I remember being so amazed at all of the cool monsters and the awesome weapons that were totally too big for a person to actually use. I sucked at it and was super intimidated by monsters as weak as Great Jaggi, and it took me a few weeks to clear even the first few quests in the village. When I finally started to get the hang of it and learned the mechanics I was completely infatuated with it and couldn't put it down. Every fight felt like the toughest battle I'd had up to that point. I loved the game and became a massive fan of the series, which led me to purchase just about every console that the next game was coming out on. I've stuck with it from Freedom, Freedom 2, Freedom Unite, Tri, Portable 3rd, 3 Ultimate, 4 Ultimate, Generations, Generations Ultimate, World, Iceborne, and soon, to Rise. Needless to say, I'm biased af, but Monster Hunter World truly is a revolutionary entry in the franchise with so many new features and mechanics, new monsters, new story, and a new generation. This game made me feel like I did so many years ago. That feeling of stepping into something brand new with wonder and amazement, only this time I actually knew how to upgrade weapons! If you're a Monster Hunter fan, you probably don't need a positive review to make you buy the game, but to those who are jumping in for the first time, go for it! It's got plenty of content in the base game alone and Iceborne may as well be a sequel. 10/10 Would recommend.

author: gant12000
review: Like many others, monster hunter world is my first foray into the world of monster hunter.  It is an incredibly successful series though, just not one I have really ever had a chance to play.  Most of this was due to the fact I just didn’t have the system it was available on, or some other excuse. That all changed with this installment though.  Finally it is on pc, so therefore my excuses didn’t hold up weight anymore. A friend even had to buy it for me to insist I played it. While I am not familiar with any other games in this franchise, I can say from a gaming background that this was one of the most frustratingly enjoyable glorious pieces of game I have ever sank time and effort into.  The mechanics were simple at first, to me.  Just hack and slash at the monster.  I cam into it thinking I could just attack and be fine.  Like a child with a stick pretending to be a knight, I attacked the enemies with reckless abandon.  For the newer player such as myself, this is where all the mistakes happen, and the joy of the game really is lost.  While you do in fact have giant over sized weapons, the game rewards players that think before they act, utilizing more defensive methods to open up the giant monsters in the game for attack.  If you are planning on just smacking around things, you will not get far and find the game quite frustrating like I did.  With a vast array of weapons that range from giant simple hammers, to large projectile weapons, every piece of equipment presents a completely unique strategy and element to fighting the monsters.  Some weapons will click with a player, while others will make them want to punch the nearest alligator in the face.  It is patience that makes this game shine.If you are a player that likes to feel a sense of accomplishment with using a piece of equipment over and over, a sense of victory when you finally beat that one level that just was driving you nuts.  This is the game for you.  If you are unfamiliar with the franchise, expect a learning curve.  If you have played other monster hunter games before, they why are you reading this review? You probably already have this game as well.

author: LazyJack
review: This game is amazing! If you are an achievement hunter and don't mind hard to get achies, this is for you.You pick a weapon and hunt different kind of monsters. You can change your weapon any time.More builds you create, the more you have to grind. There are some insanely hard monsters too, what WILL kill you. How to deal with them? Die enough times to learn the attacks.You can also explore the map, collect materials and craft useful items. You can also hunt for rare small creatures.There are many many side quests. By this I mean optional quest and quest lines. You can ignore all of them if you wish.If you only focusing on main quest, the game is not that long.If you want to complete all quest, the game becomes 5 times longer.If you aim for all achievements, I dare to say it will reach 500 hours with the DLC of course.I suggest to get at least one frend (or 3) because it will make the game much better. But it is also fun solo. You can play with randoms if you'd like.Overall this game is the best I ever played. 10/10

author: killersaddy
review: The gameplay is very simple yet complicated - like most modern games, the player starts with the most basic of armor/weapons and eventually progress by defeating stronger monsters,thereby getting better weapons/gear. You get 14 weapons to choose from, each with lots of moves and some even have different play styles among them. Though the story is relatively bland, it's far from the key focus of the game. The repetitive grind-fest that Monster Hunter becomes late-game is ironically what makes Monster Hunter so great. For a real hunt, multiplayer is the way to go. This game is meant to be played in a group and trust me you won't realize the hours that have passed while you are hunting with your mates.Also, cool festival outfits xD

author: MistaKimchi
review: Time commitment and the learning curve are the biggest wall to this game. Monster Hunter World isn't your typical RPG with linear progression and predictable power scaling. There is a deep depth to mechanics and game-play involved, like learning monsters' movesets, your weapon's mechanics, and item utilization. Monsters will seem impossible to kill at first because of a combination of your armor, weapon, and lack of knowledge. However, the reward comes with the satisfaction of learning a particular monster and using your weapon effectively. If you desire casual gameplay with flashy graphics, this game is not for you. Even after nearly 260 hours on this game, I am constantly improving and optimizing my hunts. There are the typical performance bugs at times, the plot and English voice acting are cringe, and certain weapons (looking at you bowguns) straight up just make the game a cakewalk, but you will still have a satisfying experience with this game. The Iceborne expansion is highly recommended, and even necessary in my opinion, to enjoy the full potential of this game. The value you get from the expansion puts all other DLCs to shame. The amount of work devs have put into this game years after release is refreshing to see.The entire game is essentially a grind. There is no tangible "end-game", so the satisfaction rests on yourself and knowing you are a better hunter than you were when you first started. For me, part of that satisfaction came from fighting monsters I faced when I first started and completely obliterating them.

author: Nova Hydrak
review: I can't recommend this game enough. If you like open world, mission based, grind for great loot, and multiplayer games, this game is for you for sure. I'll spare you with what the game is about, this game is really fun with a bunch of people to play with. If you don't have any friends, you can still fire a SOS flare which calls for players. So far from what I've seen, people in the MHW community are so nice and if you are just willing to ask for help, people will certainly help you (probably because they don't have anything else to do but help people and that gives them enjoyment and rewards for doing so as well!). The game is easy to make friends with.My negatives about the game:-Difficulty: (This is just in certain conditions.) This depends on the gear you have. The more grinding and better gear you make for yourself for the specific monster you're struggling on, will make the monster easier. I'll discuss why it's a bad thing in the multiplayer negatives.-Story: The story is pretty bad, not gonna lie. It consists of "This monster is doing bad things to the ecosystem! Hunt it!" then you as the player goes adventuring a bit and it just so happens in the most convenient timing, that the monster shows up. This isn't a big issue as probably less than 10% of the community cares about the story at all, you're free to not pay attention as none of it is important. Just get better gear and fight stronger monsters.-Multiplayer: Multiplayer is a big positive in this game, but I'll talk about the negative parts such as how the story missions are all cutscene locked. Meaning you cannot skip ANY cutscenes in the game, and other players are not allowed to join your mission until all cutscenes have been watched. This is super annoying and I have no idea why any game company would force their (pretty bad) story on the player. I recommend that you blast through the story ASAP so that the real game begins. The game has a pretty complex way of understanding how multiplayer works but, once you understand it isn't that bad.-Cheap hits: Dodging is crucial to the game, but your invincibility frames are very low, giving the game a form of Dark Souls difficulty feel of it. It mostly requires you to know what the monsters next move will be and dodge when that attack strikes, so there's a learning curve. There are difficulty spikes everywhere in the story and it can disencourage players from coming back (that happened to me after Rathalos), but if you keep trying, or find help from other players, you will pass it and become much stronger and more capable of doing it again.My positives about the game:-So much stuff to do!: There is a lot of things you can do in MHW, from customizing your room, to placing pets down, to making vanity armor, to capturing monsters, to arm wrestling with your friends! The coolest thing about MHW is the multiplayer Gathering Hub, where up to 16 players and their palicos can all be in one session at once and they can even pay for everyones meal or just emote and communicate freely.-Hunting: The main part of the game is hunting monsters, whether you kill or capture them, you're going to learn how to take them down the fastest way possible and learn all the techniques on what that monster is weak against, what it drops, and where its weakspots are. Before each hunt, be sure you prepare at the canteen and manage your items before taking off to fight it.-Weapons!: There are 14 weapon types in the game. Each one isn't just a different thing to swing at the enemy. No, each weapon acts as its own class. From Dual blades which are two fast swinging swords to a heavy bow gun which is essentially Heavy from TF2 to the greatsword which is ironically heavier than the hammer but pays out with its massive damage it puts out. It is all up to you on what classes you want to main in the game. You can play one weapon or play as all the weapons.I could go on and on about the game. It is 100% worth buying this game and the iceborne dlc (as it is pretty essential to also have at this point) if you want a new game to love and cherrish.May the Sapphire Star guide your way future hunters!PS: Be sure your PC can handle very large games. MHW is notorious for being a very hard game to run. Please do check your PC stats before spending money on it.

author: Brendan||nabnerB (AFO)
review: Monster Hunter: World is the first monster hunter game I have ever played. I didn't grow up with Playstation or access to any of the other monster hunter titles. Being a born and breed PC player since I could trick my dad into letting me play Red Alert, I never even knew of monster hunter. I asked some friends who owned World on PS if it would be worth picking up on PC when it came out. They gave me a resounding NO. The port was terrible, it was laggy, featureless, and the servers were absolute garbage. I bought it anyway. Monster Hunter: World is a labor of LOVE. The devs poured their hearts into this game. Every pixel, every conversation, every armor crease was someones passion brought to life and it SHOWS. The detailing in this game from over the top enviroments that give you awe just to wander around in expeditions to mine rocks for 4 hours; to the way the world feels like it breaths with you while you hunt with tiny insects and animals scurrying about their lives while a fire-breathing T-Rex rains fire on them. Every monster feels like, albeit fantasy, a living thing. The pure adrenaline of a hunt is mesmerizing, addicting. You fight a monster and think "Holy cow, that was so intense and took so much effort. That was the hardest monster ever." Then y send something even crazier to fight. The "grind" and gameplay loop is rewarding as you don't need to sink your life into spending your hard earned money on in-game items and you can play at your own pace. Some events in game are "limited" but they almost always comeback on a rotating event schedule so you never have to choose between your life and your hunters life. This game offers as much or as little immersion as you choose. You can role-play one of your favorite characters form a show or novel or just be a complete Meme character and still enjoy the game. The weapon selection is massive with 14 unique and enjoyable weapons that cater to any playstyle from range combat with bows and bowguns to in your face style hammers and greatswords, tanks that spank with gunlances and sword and shields, and glorious nippon steel katanas. This game is a hidden gem in a never ending surge of unpolished and generic titles and one of the best investments I ever made. Iceborn is just more cake on top of your cake with some cake sprinkled on.

author: lividjesmar
review: At first, I was unsure about the game. It's not a game that's very friendly to newer players, luckily I had a friend who was able to walk me through things and I understood way better that way. The starting area and the skill trees, for example, are quite overwhelming when you're new and it's not the easiest to understand.Once you get out into the field, things will get MUCH better. I got Iceborne nearly right away, and the clutch claw has been a LIFESAVER for me so far. It's allowed me to get more hits in on monsters I can't get close to with my dual daggers.  Fighting monsters has a nice challenge to it that makes you feel powerful once you defeat them. When you fall in battle, you will understand what not to do. I highly recommend this game, it's slowly becoming one of my favorites because I just love the world surrounding it. There's so much to this game that even after 70ish hours of me playing this (as of this post) I feel like I've only touched the tip of the iceberg! If you're getting this game, you should definitely get Iceborne, as well. There's so much content that gets added after the main-game and more challenges.EDIT: Yup, like 500+ hours later, I very much enjoy this game and am looking forward to when MH Rise comes out. This is my all-time favorite game, there's just so much to do! I've learned several weapons by this point, my favorites being Insect Glaive and Light Bowgun. This is a game 100% worth trying and pushing through the hard parts, it's very rewarding in my opinion.ALSO, if you're having trouble running the game: My previous graphics card was a GTX 1650, and the game ran barely 60fps before, this is due to a bunch of unnecessary processes that CAPCOM implemented, and there are a few mods that help with this issue. On Nexusmods, search for Strackers Loader and Performance Booster and Plugin Extender, after getting those two mods it made ALL the difference and I had consistently very good frames.

review: One of the most frustrating games I've ever played, even harder than all the soulsborne series I've played when reached master rank, if you are trying to solo. But the reward of learning this game is like nothing else: satisfying, highly coordinated and refreshing combats especially with one or three other friends while having countless play style and build options in end game. If you are looking to play an RPG that has much depth and constant progression, look no further. There are grinding involved, so be warned, but this game does not rely solely on grinding for its replayability.

author: Kenetoy
review: I am long time fan of this game way back since it came out of PSP (Freedom Unite) I was like 13 yrs old back then and did not know the point of the game. I often get frustrated because the game play feels clunky and heavy compared to other game during that time but as I grew, I learned the mechanics and fell in love with the game. I stopped playing for a while until it came out on Switch and started playing again. When I found out about Monster Hunter World and saw the game play and new mechanics, I became a bit salty because it added a lot of new mechanics and made the game "easy" which by far is the polar opposite of the original series which gave it the branding that it has now. I did not play it at launch and continued playing the classic versions on the switch for a little while until I stopped playing again because my friends are now playing MHW. That was my story with this game. Now i got this game just 2 weeks ago and I am already at Master Rank TLDR; change is not easy to accept but thank God I threw away my purist attitude and gave this game a shot.Thank you to all developers who made this game and to those who have been working with the series since the classic ones :)11/10 would Recommend.EDIT:JAN 2023 -I've started playing this game again after finishing MH Rise. Somehow, it hits different. It feels more modern than Rise. I'm jumping back into a new game! Oh by the way, I'm playing it on my steam deck and it's like a dream come true! PORTABLE MH WORLD!

author: Wあrmあchine
review: Like a lot of people, this is my first monster hunter game and what a way to get into the series. When I first got the game, I couldn't stop playing it and was excited to get back into it every day. This was way before Iceborne was even announced and goes to show how good the base game was. The thought of a game with only bosses is a concept that will appeal to almost any souls-like fan.Getting straight into the combat and main gameplay, we have a variety of weapons to choose from. Each weapon feels unique and has a number of combos to be learned. This makes the game stay fresh if you are the type of person to try everything and makes mastering a particular weapon very satisfying. All the weapon types are viable, so there is no need to worry about a certain meta or weapon class that outshines the rest completely. They are comically large which might be off-putting to some, but I like how it displays them and gives every weapon an amount of impact. Besides the weapons, the main gameplay is a dodge and attack style, which is why I said that it might resonate with souls fans. You get healing and buffs to aid you in your fight against monsters. This game is certainly challenging and if you aren't paying attention, then you will fail your missions. Almost every mission has a total of three faints, which basically amounts to three lives or respawns before you fail the quest and have to start over.Now moving on to the main stars of the game: The monsters of course! There are quite a selection which helps keep the game alive and gives you something to always upgrade towards. The monsters act like real, living animals taken to the extreme where it is survival of the fittest and smartest. The world feels alive as you battle them and can even be used to your advantage. A new monster is added with almost every free title update which also helps expand the story and the reason why this monster is in the new world. Almost every monster has their own armour set and weapons that can be crafted which embraces their characteristics. With such a large amount of monsters, you are bound to find a favourite among all the other annoying ones.As for the story....does anyone really care. It is mediocre at best, but gets you to where you need to go. They could have just let you go wild and kill every different monster the new world has to offer, because that is basically the story summarized. There is a big bad monster at the end of both the base game and Iceborne that threathens the new world itself, which you go and kill. Not really a gripping tale. Just a hunter that has an insatiable thirst for blood. To add the cherry on top is the handler. I won't say too much about this character, just that almost nobody can stand her stupidity and annoying dialogue. Best character in the game is Grandma Kitty, who cooks great food for you with a smile. Most spoken to character is probably the smithy, as you will visit him a lot.The graphics looks good and still holds up after two years. More importantly is the soundtrack in my opinion since that is my little pleasure. A great soundtrack gets extra points in my book and does this game deliver, having me beg for more. Just like Dark Souls 3 and Bloodborne, the OSTs for some of the elder dragons are simply fantastic. It really gets you in the mood and makes you feel like you are fighting something majestic yet powerful and deadly. That is just my opinion of course.All and all, Monster Hunter: World is a great game and its expansion, Iceborne, is a must buy if you like the original. It adds and expands the base game so much that you won't be disappointed. Even when I might get frustrated because of certain mechanics and monsters, I still come back for more. It is just such a well polished game that is great with friends. The developers are also great and keep releasing great updates to keep everything fresh. Plus there are mods on pc if you want something more out of the experience. Including a Giorno's theme for the hunting horn. Need I say anymore.10/10 would kill Great Jagras again.

author: Lonegan
review: This game has monsters in it so if you are afraid of monsters you can either confront your fear of them and try to kill them or you can simply talk to all the kind people in the gathering hubs located within the two main cities. Outside of the gathering hub has really nice people that will help you with pretty much everything. There is a lady with a magic pot, there is a blacksmith, a cook for when you get hungry, people who study monsters and even have a place for the monsters to nap if you trap them, a pig that is kind of like a puppy because it gets so excited to see you and if you pet him and carry him around he will dig up treasure for you. There is a merchant that has various wares for sale and is always willing to fence any goods you don’t want. There is a botanist too, I think his name is Andre Argosy but that is not important. What is important is that you frequent him or the other people that have the same operation going because you can collect whatever you want to harvest and even purchase stuff from the pirate ship. It might just be a regular merchant ship but it seems to be pretty full of random things that could have easily been plundered from other boats. You also have a cat thing for a pal that helps you sometimes but you may have to whistle for him multiple times because he is handcuffed or something. Oh, and if you don’t like the way you look you can cover your armor up with more aesthetically pleasing attire. Worst part is the handler, she gets in the way and is pretends she is helpful. However, the arena gal in the gathering hub makes up for it because she is nice and cute. The main quest lady there I think has a crush on me and seems nervously excited when I interact her. I recommend playing this game with friends because some of the monsters and the quests/challenges are twice as strong as normal. Ultimately, if you decide to embark on slaying monsters there is a support group of townsfolk that will help you and hopefully if you don’t have any friends you can fire a SOS flare and get assistance from someone else from anywhere in the whole wide real world (hopefully Asia though).

author: mon
review: if you consider yourself a story person, dont buy this game. It has little to non story and lore and just comprise of mainly hunting monsters, get it's materials, craft a new hat(armor) and weapon, fight stronger monster, rinse and repeat till end game. In the end game, you may start to feel dull and start on trying out new weapon and playstyles . You may go through it earlier but this is how it worked for me. Playing alone could prove to be boring when it drags on hence having 3 other hunters in a party feels much more fun. If you feel like playing, i cant stress enough that it consist of HUNTING MONSTERS for 80% of the game. If you are still feeling like it, then i recommend buying iceborne also. Back then (pre-iceborne) having base game is enough as there are only 2 different ranks which is low rank and high rank. Post-iceborne, they introduced master rank which features much stronger weapons. If you like coop play and wanted randoms go into your quests, you're probably end up with Master rank players breezing your quest in 2 minutes instead of 10 minutes or more (usual hunt time per quest).  So, overall, if you like slaughtering epic monsters with 14 types of weapon and many more kind of play styles, then this game is for you. But if you are able to get bored by it, then i would not recommend as both monster hunter world and iceborne could be pricey. Maybe buy it during sales, that would be a far better bargain. Enjoy!

author: coteries
review: Keeps everything that is good about Monster Hunter while still updating it to be more accessible. This is one of the best action games I've ever played. Very deliberate combat, and yet you can play it for hours upon hours. Every weapon takes actual skill and practice to master, and every monster is a new challenge.My main complaints are that the amount of content is low for a Monster Hunter game (without Iceborne) and the decoration grind is stupid since certain weapons are dependent on decorations for their full potential. Just cheat them in and have fun. Iceborne fixes the content issue, adding tons and tons of new and fun fights, so it's definitely worth getting.UPDATE: Alatreon is the greatest thing ever (no sarcasm). I honestly am in awe of the developers of what a great job they did. The sheer level of salt this fight generates is amazing, and just speaks volumes to how bad some people are at adapting.Kudos to you, Capcom. And to those reading... Don't listen to immature people who are crying about being forced to adapt to a new scenario. Alatreon is quite possibly the best monster in the entire franchise and his fight is as close to perfection as it gets.

author: Crossbreed
review: Let me start off by saying I love this game. I started playing the Monster Hunter series back when the original Monster Hunter was on the Playstation 2. I loved it, even though I didn't realize I could change weapons halfway through the game and I played after they shut down the online portion of the game. This is one of the few "grindy" games I can get behind playing. The gameplay, combat, and mechanics are just THAT good. I've also always enjoyed the Dark Souls series and love stamina-based combat.The gameplay is great. That's a given. I can definitely recommend this game, HOWEVER there are things people have to be aware of:- Lots of computers have CPU issues with this game. It's very intensive on your computer, to say the least. Be aware of this and make sure your rig is prepared ahead of time.- Some lower end specs can run the game, but it'll have issues for sure. My Girlfriend plays this game on a pretty low end comp but has stuttering issues and the game freezes if someone carts.- Sometimes this game will have issues with the anti-cheat causing problems. There are a lot of potential fixes online if this happens, but nothing is guaranteed.- My game had an issue where my computer started freezing. I did a deep cleaning of my computer and replaced the thermal paste and it started working perfectly fine again. If you have freezing issues, try this. There are other issues with the game that you may encounter, but it's a dice roll. Some people have issues others don't, etc. If you have a strong gaming computer you're likely not going to have any issues. If you're more along the average computer specs, you may have issues.

author: Cam Porter Bridges
review: As someone who first Monster Hunter game they played was World (Besides playing MHGU as a kid and not understanding what to do which dosent really count cause I was dumb as ♥♥♥♥ back then.) Monster Hunter World is the best game to get into for anyone who is thinking about trying out a Monster Hunter game for the first time.  This is a great time to pick this game up, as well as the DLC Icebourn. The PC version of this game has bugs like any game which is not bad until they happen to you, but that like everything in life so it's not really a big deal. The game visually looks nice, since it was released on December 2017 but its visuals are nice. Its the most westernized version of a Japanese title so just google some photo or videos and check out the armor or weapon to see if your like them. The game is fun, the gameplay loop of hunting monsters to make more powerfull weapons and armor is tried and true. You can play with up to 4 friends or less. As well as play by your self, which is the way I prefer to play. I say that because there are hunts where they are designed to be played with 4 players, which is kind ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ annoying when you've been playing the game solo the whole time. But unless your really give a ♥♥♥♥ about those hunts can be done on your own but are not designed  to. You can do them with random people but of makes those hunts harder cause there designed with communication in mind. A fun feature is to fire a SOS flair which random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ people into your game, which is the funny ♥♥♥♥ sometimes all the way to absolutely enraging at other times. Its a fun game but is slowed paced so it could be hard to make a judgement about it in like two so if you buy it make sure you like rough idea of the game before you buy it. And that pretty much all I have to say except one last thing wigglers are the cutest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ thing in this game.

review: awesome game with unique and interesting mechanics 10/10 amazing gamenow after another 336 hours after my first review i can say this is hands down the best game i have ever played in my life, the combat is fluid with a huge range of available weapons, the monsters are diverse and the lore gone into each of them is very impressive, i have played through the game 3 times now all the way through iceborne too, the only con i can think of is the story telling which is mediocre at best.i really cannot recommend this game enough

author: Xfearior
review: If you're already a fan of the Monster Hunter series, you should've gotten this masterpiece already.If you are new however, the amount of content in this game is worth its cost, even more so if you purchased the DLC. There are lots of monsters to fight, lots of weapons and equipment to acquire for both you and your cat friend. It's fun with friends, but you can still get help from random players (although some of them can be more useless than helpful).The base game has a nice start, allowing you to fight monsters willy nilly, but it can become grindy once you are introduced to special track quests. After those however, it's smooth sailing from there, and no more from the DLC.The difficulty of the game starts of easy, but progressively gets harder, and learning skilful dodge timings and proper weapon use will make the fights easier and rewarding. Each monster has a unique attack pattern and cool designs that also provide awesome looking weapons and armour.There are collaborations with other games such as Final Fantasy and Witcher, which spice up the gameplay, but you should expect a lot of repetitive grinding if you want a specific set of armour and weapons.Overall, I rate this an 8.5/10 game

author: Markzerow
review: Incredible experience within the franchise, a solid 9/10 for me and a big recommendation to everyone who wants to play it (at the time of this review, I found small bugs regarding the graphics, but those have already been fixed, so I can even go 10/10).The base game is incredible, be prepared to put many hours into it (hunting, crafting, understanding).The Iceborne expansion brought a lot of monsters from the previous games (with a great balance to their mechanics) and it also delivers more fun and customizations to the already great game.It's on sale every now and then, so keep an eye out for when it happens.This is a must have for any fan of the franchise or anyone interested in this game's style.

review: I've played about 1000 hours on the console version as well, and I couldn't recommend enough. if you like fighting big ass monsters and slowly climbing up the food chain until your fighting elder dragons that eat other elder dragons this game is for you. There are a huge variety in weapon selection to choose from, there are 14 different weapons all with different play styles. the RNG with the decorations for certain abilities was kind of rough in the start but they've added a few different ways to farm the decos that are very reliable if you have Iceborne. Also they've added like 7 new monsters in free title updates since the game came out. (it's going to be new monsters 10 by the end of April) But if this your first time playing a Monster Hunter game then be prepared for a bit of a learning curve, it will seem kind of overwhelming at first but once you get the hang of it it becomes an amazing game. Honestly it might be my game of the decade.

author: EFG.Wenex ヽ(´ー｀)ノ
review: I have never played Monster Hunter before and this game is just pure awesomeness. Since I bought it like a week ago I have played it literally every day and I keep on finding new stuff in the game (even 40 hours after I discover new items or ways to fight monsters) which makes the game more and more interesting in the long run. I think I actually might be addicted.Overall I would say, that if someone likes the idea of hunting "big monsters" while having lots of variety in weaponry or abilities that change the way you fight them, then this game will definately be worth your money. For anyone who is thinking about buying the game, I recommend to buy with Iceborne expansion. I made a mistake and bought Iceborn after I progressed quite in the story and I missed on the new stuff Iceborne adds. Like new weapon movesets and Clutch Claw which changes the way you hunt the monsters. So if you are deciding to buy the game, buy it with Iceborne.If I were to rate the game on the scale of 10, I would prolly give it 9.5. I feel like the only thing that this game lacks is better online matchmaking. The game has dozens of thousands people playing at the same time, yet sometimes it's really hard to find SOS signals or busy lobbies. Like the numbers just doesn't add up, or the game is very region locked for some reason. I believe it's the latter or the game just has poor matchmaking/lobby system.But in the end I recommend it very greatly. Get this game you won't regret it.

author: Vy
review: Its a game about hunting monsters. And I love the monsters and the hunt. First off, there are some complaints I have.The first four hours of the game sucks. A LOT. I would pay money to skip the first four hours. The story intro is quite bad, the game mechanics aren't properly explained which leads to people turning away from the game. The game fully ramps up a couple hours past the refund timer, which some people often get disappointed during. Lastly, there are some mechanics that aren't really necessary, its just there as a homage to older entries.Monsters start ramping up in difficulty and diversity after that. And by that time as well, you start to get a hold of the weapon you're using which I say is a good difficulty spike. Around here, you start to unlock sweet looking armaments which I would say further pushes players to grind for that sweet looking gear, and the gears aren't just all looks, they're plenty customizable (after a lot of grind). Your playstyle will dictate your gear, and there's plenty to choose from. From weapon choices to specific buffs, there's a lot of way to make head in this game, there's not many weapons that are considered "unviable", most of them have equal footing and have matchups they're good or bad against.TLDR: Pick it up if you watched a youtube video showcasing the first 2 hours and accepted the gameplay that comes afterwards. You really aren't losing too much. Story bad. Game good.

author: Theosaur Rex
review: The title explains the game itself. An action RPG about hunting monster. Definitely MUST play, especially if you're a fan of the genre.The idea is basically like this:1. You hunt big weird reptiles.2. Scavenge materials from them.3. You create new weapons/armors with it.And repeat.The formula sounds simple, but it's fun and addictive. The battle system itself is so engaging and challenging. You also can go multi-player with friends here to have fun.Just go get this game and have fun while get tossed around by giant lizards.

author: Zenthronex
review: WORLD:I was skeptical at first; being my first Monster Hunter game after refusing to play all the previous ones due to their complexity.A friend convinced me and now I am a HR 100+ hammer main. My advice for beginners, try every weapon. You'll find that some are complex and require precise timing while others are forgiving and simple. Regardless, you can use any weapon and still dominate; so play with what you enjoy most!ICEBORNE:If you enjoyed MHW, Iceborne is worth every penny. Iceborne will connect you to older Monster Hunter games through the addition of older wyverns in addition to new ones to the series.In other news, I'm now a great sword main. Someone's gotta chop those tails!

author: SW4N
review: This is the Monster Hunter game I have always wanted to play. Loyal fan of the franchise since MH2, and I can easily say that this is my favorite to date. At first glance, this game can seem awfully repetitive, but let me assure you that once you start playing, your experience will be anything but. The monsters move frequently throughout their beautifully crafted ecosystems, giving you a variety of different spaces to fight them in. There are environmental traps to look out for, endemic life that can both help and hinder you, and of course; other monsters roaming out in the world that will happily interrupt your experience in the hopes of an easy meal. While the objective of your adventures will undoubtedly be similar, no two fights play out the same, as you never quite know what to expect; making the overall gameplay almost organic in nature and wonderfully replayable. All 14 of the unique weapons are a treat to use with deep fighting mechanics that will have you pushing to master their most powerful techniques.The monsters themselves are a sight to behold. Some of them are absolutely terrifying and relentless in their pursuit of destroying you. The end game monsters have the toughest A.I. I've ever had the chance to face in any game, and will challenge the skill and composure of even the very best of players. That being said, the thing I love most about them is their distinctly unique personalities. One of my favorite non-combative things to do in the game, is to follow the monsters around their habitats just to watch their behavior, diet, and interactions with the other monsters and endemic life. The amount of detail and thought that have been put into Monster Hunter World is breathtaking. Thank you so much for this game, Capcom. Can't wait to see what they've got lined up next.

author: /Sneaky/TiKi/
review: Absolutely in love with this game, and will continue to recommend this game to anyone.I have played and experienced EVERY MH game to date, but this particular game takes the cake for gameplay, QoL, and visuals.   It's story isn't anything special unlike Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate, which had a pretty great premise in comparison, but thats hardly the point of this game. You get in there crewed up by yourself or 3 other people with your weapons of choice, beating up large monsters till they fall.  Every monster in this game is treated like an unscripted boss battle, its just you, your weapon, wits and skill.Monster Hunter World greatly rewards players that attain precision skill for evading and guarding, learning the movesets of the monsters you hunt allows you to greatly punish them for attacks that they otherwise would have hit you with prior. I find that if you've ever seen a speedrun for this game is a great example of this.  Now this entry in the series is much easier game than past titles but it can still challenge you in various ways.  I play monster hunter for the high skill ceiling it offers if you choose to speedrun monster hunts,  but this game doesn't have to be played this way or by meta, you can make various skill setups to suit your needs during hunts and to just have an overall fun time.But while armor skills do help, I strongly urge that upon playing this game you spend some time really getting to learn the in-and-outs of your weapon you choose, it doesn't matter if you have the most damage possible if you dont know how to handle your weapon and positioning, and don't shell yourself into using just one weapon if you can, every weapon in this game are quite fun and i always encourage you try each one at least a few times.Feel free to poke me if you have questions.TL;DR Buy this game if you love darksouls-esque boss fighting as a game itself with co-op.
