author: Necrotech
review: At the time of writing this I have 587 hours in this game, and I regret very very few of them. You might think "Wait, shouldn't you not regret any of them?" and no, because the game isn't perfect, but it is very very good!Pros:+The game looks great!    The game is generally great looking. I'm not a huge graphics afficiando, but it looks good.+The combat gameplay is fun!    The gameplay is fast-paced and skill oriented. I've heard some people describe it as souls-like, and that's not totally accurate (attacks don't consume stamina in most cases), but it's also not totally wrong. Like Dark Souls, when you break it down this is secretly a rhythm game. You have to think about how long your attack's animations take and what options it'll give you compared against what attacks a monster has. Dark Souls is the same way! However, this game's stamina management is largely not based on attacks, but instead is fuel for dodging. There's a few attacks that do consume stamina, and some weapons have to think about stamina management more than others.+There's a variety in play styles!    So, a lot of people pick up this game, grab a weapon, have a bad time, and decide the game isn't for them. However, each type of weapon is essentially a 'class' in another game with it's own whole set of abilities, mechanics, and sometimes even minor details that long-time users of the weapon will know how to get the most out of but won't be apparent to a new user. With my 587 hours, I can confidently say that I have 'mastery' of about two weapons. If you don't like a weapon, try another one! Greatsword too slow? Try out Dual Blades. DB Reach too short? Try Longsword! The game almost entirely changes, and sometimes you may find that one weapon type has an easier time with a certain monster than another. Some weapons are low or high mobility, and a lot of weapons may seem one way until you discover a technique that totally changes your playstyle. The Lance is renowned by many to be a slow weapon because your walk speed gets agonizingly slow, but once you realize that a Lance is never intended to 'walk' but instead Guard Advance, Charge, or Dodge in a direction you can discover that it's the second or third most mobile weapon in the game when used properly. Similarly, the 'support weapon' Hunting Horn has some of the most single-hit damage potential around.    Best of all, no weapon in this game is 'non viable'. If you find a weapon or playstyle that works, even if some people (myself included) will regard it as 'suboptimal', you CAN play and beat the game effectively with it. +A high skill ceiling, but a low skill floor!    This game has a huge amount of room to improve if you're willing to put a lot of time into the game. However, don't let that scare you off! I have plenty of friends who are 'casual' hunters who get by just fine. You don't have to put several hours into watching guide videos and researching builds and mechanics to be good at this game, but that option is there if you want it and there is ALWAYS room to improve your hunt.    As a quick word on that, some weapons are more complex than others. The Charge Blade and Heavy/Light Bowgun are a good deal more technical and require a lot of thought, while something like the Bow, Hammer, or Greatsword are actually quite simple. Don't be fooled though - there's plenty of room to refine gameplay even in 'simple' weapons. The Lance is considered a relatively 'simple' weapon and I still discover something once in a while.+A large and mostly friendly community!    This game has subreddits, a plethora of YouTube videos, and more! If you like engaging in fan communities or reading guides and whatnot, this game has that. It's not exactly an MMO, but it is very multiplayer friendly. I mostly play with friends, and you can also matchmake with randos or browse public open groups. It's a good time!    While you CAN cheat and mod this game, I have only very rarely heard of someone cheating. ~Gear isn't the be-all end-all in this game!    No matter how good your gear in this game, if you aren't learning from the gameplay you will get curb stomped. The biggest upgrade you ever get in this game is what you, the player, learn from your hunts. That's not to say gear doesn't matter, it just means that you're almost never going to find yourself totally unable to go on because you need to gear up. Cheating in gear won't make you win the game, and it'll only make hunts marginally easier by the time you hit High Rank. That being said, paradoxically this game's progression IS entirely in gear. Some players may love this, others may not. Just don't come in expecting level ups and player characteristics beyond appearance.~Mod support... kinda!    So, this game has a weird relationship with mods. There does appear to be an anticheat, but as far as I (and anyone else I've asked online!) nobody has actually been banned by it. Even obviously cheat-y mods like Trainers/instant kills/every items is buyable in the shop seem to be totally fine. This also includes some mods that do things like change appearances, make items on the ground easier to spot, etc. There's a Nexus Mods section for this game, though you should be aware that not everything there is going to be compatible with the latest patches.    No judgement if you decide to cheat, but remember to respect other player's wishes and keep things like insta-kill cheat or invulnerability to single player or with buds who are cool with it please!~This game can be a little grindy, and the central gameplay loop isn't for everyone!    I did say the game isn't perfect, and it's true. The game's central gameplay loop is to hunt monsters to get parts to hunt monsters and repeat. The game is about perfecting builds, improving as a player and a hunter. That being said, if you don't like that central gameplay loop, this isn't going to be a good time for you.    The game isn't too terribly grindy, though. Once in a while you'll struggle to make a monster drop a part, but usually that means you have to attack a specific part enough to break it for any real chance at rewards. There's also a lot of mechanics in place to give you alternate ways to get materials, or to make the grind a little less intensive. -The first 20-30 minutes of this game are rough!    Monster Hunter games almost have a tradition of having bad early games. You have a couple of really uninteresting quests you have to do early on, and that may turn some people off. Give it until you finish the Great Jagras hunt - if that wasn't fun for you, that's when you should decide how you feel about this game. Maybe try to re-fight the Jagras with a different weapon and see how you feel first though - they really do all play quite differently.-Nitpick: Weapon appearance variety isn't what it used to be!    Newcomers to the franchise might think there's a decent-ish variety to weapon appearance, but in past games every single weapon had a completely unique model with almost no reused/modified assets. MHW does. === FINAL SCORE ===Overall, if I had to give the game a number, I'd say it's a 9/10 for me, but on the whole is probably more a 7.5 or 8.5/10. But also numbers are totally meaningless , and the rest of the review is overall going to be a lot more comprehensive. I'd say if nothing else, it's worth trying this game out.

author: Kars
review: Monster Hunter World is the series first foray onto PC - and while a rough transition, its still an incredible game. Simple but rewarding game loop, a huge world to explore, dozens of monsters to fight, and hundreds of armor pieces only scratch the surface of the things that can be done. The combat is tight and responsive, the weapon styles varied, the monsters a mix of challenging and annoying in the just the right doses to make a fun action packed time. Optimization is a little wobbly due to this being their first venture to PC, and the games are nearly as jam-packed with content as the handheld games which could use models from previous titles to reduce work load, but with their constant updates and most recently Iceborne being released, there is TONS of content to enjoy and hours to sink, and thats before even getting to the new lands and mechanics of the DLC.Overall MH:W is a great title, a fun piece of action you can sink dozens upon dozens of hours into and still not be done. Lots of content, and lots of fun.

author: Civ_Es
review: Highly recommend this game; at first I was hesitant to try a game with such a generic name, but honestly Monster Hunter World blew away my expectations. Graphically, the game designers did a great job at making the environments, every single detail being accounted for makes for a beautiful immersive surrounding. It's easy to just look at the sun set in the Ancient Forest, or watch the waterfalls in the Wildspire Waste. However, the environments pale in comparison to the gargantuan dragonkin that you're going to be facing off against.  Gameplay wise, the combat is engaging and rewarding, it pays off to be patient, and learn the monster's behaviors before going aggressive on your openings. Each weapon feels unique, and that gives a unique perspective of the game; using a large blunt weapon like a hammer, requires a drastically different playstyle, that using a long range weapon like a bow. On the other hand, the gameplay loop can get stale, no matter how diverse the weapon roster is, so it's up to you to enjoy the crafting progression, and set goals for yourself. Story wise, the game could be better, although it has vague approach to storytelling, the funny looking cast of characters contrasts against the severity that is a massive elder dragon threatening to disrupt the natural balance. The game contains a very loose, but clear message of being cognizant of the environment, and how everything is linked through the natural order from the lowliest herbivore to the massive apex wyverns that make home in this universe. Overall, I rate this game highlyGraphics: 4/5Gameplay: 5/5 (or 4/5 if you don't enjoy the crafting aspect of it)Story: 2/5

author: FrontalSpy
review: Capcom's most finest gameplay focused franchises finally comes to the PC.Monster Hunter World is  the most accessible game in the franchise, perfect for newcomers to join and play. The graphics are great, but its the living and breathing world that takes the show. Monsters and animals have their routines and go about their lives until a hunter slices them in half.The gameplay is very tight with lots of precise movement and attacks against monsters, whilst knowing their pattern to prevent getting hit. The main gameplay loop is very satisfying, hunting monsters, gathering loot and trying to craft better armour/weapons. Co-op is very fun and can get a little chaotic sometimes. Coordinating  attacks, planning traps, and saving your teammates in the heat of battle gives an adrenaline high. This PC port isn't without faults. The opimisation is quite poor, requiring some serious hardware to get 1080p 60fps (it is very CPU bound). The co-op structure for mainline quests is barbaric, requiring all players to start the mission and watch a cutscene before joining. Also, the PC game is months behind the console releases in terms of content. They said it would catch up, but don't believe their lies.

author: Feyreth
review: TL,DR at the bottom. :vBefore playing MHW I'd only ever experienced anything like it through Dauntless. I'd played that with friends and whilst it was fun we all slowly got bored because of how much of a grind it was to go against certain monsters early on; we basically hit a wall and didn't feel like it was worth playing on with.My experience with MHW as been mostly solo, and whilst man monsters definitely hit you hard and make it slow to progress, it never felt like you have to grind your ass off to beat them. To move on from the comparisons; the game feels alive. This was something that really stood out to me when I beat the first couple monsters like Great Jagras and Anjanath; they all behave differently and respond to things in their surroundings. Encountering the next monster is always pretty cool, and I enjoy learning how to fight them and how to read their attacks this way before going against them again later. The game itself looks amazing, even with mid/low settings it's quite wonderful to look around and explore the various regions. Playing with friends is also great, makes some tougher opponents easier, but not without them being entirely cheesed. I do have a few small gripes with the game, but nothing that really ruined the experience for me: menu's are a bit confusing to navigate at times, the default control layout for keyboard/mouse is a bit... Odd to say the least, and for some reason, no characters have names. Weird gripe to have, but I find it so bizarre that no one has an actual name; they're all called stuff like "serious handler" or "easygoing fiver". It's not something that would bother me normally but it does sorta take me out of it sometimes.TL,DR; the game's good, fun with friends, and palicos are adorable give me 20.

author: Skyway
review: Nice game

author: [LsrW] Nathan
review: Absolutely amazing experience. You can very easily throw 200-800 hours at this game and get so much fun out of it. The game-play is typical of a Monster Hunter game but improved so damn much due to all the quality of life changes they have introduced, such as the Slinger and just in general changes to the character controller and monster behaviors to further emphasise the fluidity of a modern game. The game is a masterpiece and certainly stands high in my favourite monster hunter list. All changes to all 14 weapon types are fantastic, and I haven't found anything in particular I dislike about the game. Perhaps I'm biased as I've been a fan of Monster Hunter since 2006 but I simply can't not recommend this game. The sheer amount of detail put into the assets, animations (ESPECIALLY the monsters) and shader-work is mind boggling, small things such as muscles jiggling when monsters step and fur moving aside when a monster moves or scarring appearing over the body to indicate damage, it's amazing and truly goes a long way to create an immersive experience. Honestly, the only thing I dislike is that some of the weapon designs are absolutely subpar at best in comparison to older games such as MH4U on the 3DS. In fact, the weapon designs are pretty inconsistent, with some taking the designs from the older games and some which are supposed to have cool designs simply appearing as a piece of bone with some feathers attached. Despite its faults, I fully recommend this game with all my heart. Of course, Monster Hunter is not for everyone but World is certainly more accessible (and arguably much easier) than most of the older games. Especially with Iceborne out, the game certainly has me hooked!

author: Ninja Beetle
review: ok somonster hunter at its base is an incredible experience, especially if you adore the gameplay type that it has, of continually improving against a monster, over and over, of reaching the power fantasy of the “perfect hunter”The base game without iceborne has incredible moments, for example, the first time i was in the desert area I can tell you truthfully I did not expect the monster I was hunting to get john cena’d into a cave below the desert I had no idea existed, and this goes to show that you may be a hunter but there are other apex predators hunting what you are going for as well. The base game is a special experience especially if you have never seen these monsters before or if this is your first monster hunter game, like me. The turf wars between monsters is always exhilarating, and it gives a breath of life to the monsters and their environment.Iceborne is a great improvement and merely calling it a dlc feels like a disservice considering it feels like a whole new monster hunter game with how much was added. Iceborne to me really drives in the point that there is always a bigger fish. It is deceptive how much content there is to cover and once you finish one story plotline, something else will come up and there will be an even greater threat to the area that you must hunt. For instance, as of writing this review, I have finished what I thought would have been the final monster hunt/final quest only to be sucker punched by a ‘seething bazelgeuse’. I can only wonder at what other fresh hell awaits me further down this dlc, especially since they are adding in new supreme tier rip-your-heart-out monsters in free content drops.tldr, ♥♥♥♥♥ pretty damn good chief11/10 would get vaped on by deviljho again.

author: that girl thing
review: Monster Hunter World is a game that action genre players will enjoy, but grinders will love.  There's no hiding that these games require you to like the constant hunting of the same monster multiple times for parts, but the game play is exciting, active, and engaging enough to make every hunt worthwhile.  But many people have talked about that to death, so what makes Monster Hunter one of the greatest games of all time?With the Iceborne expansion, the game has risen to new, greater heights.  You have a new house that you can redecorate to your heart's content--decorations, wallpapers, furniture colors, a metric ton of tiny pets you can shove in your house, and a personal hot spring that you can press Y to splash water and Up on the D-pad to frolic in.  Fashion Hunters can rejoice, as the Master rank armor introduced in the new expansion hark back to older designs, looking bigger, fancier, and more daring as opposed to a majority of the sets the game began with, which were made with a bit of a same-y feel.  You too can hunt giant chickens that throw rocks while looking like a technicolor cowboy-ninja fusion.  There is a new camera feature where you get to take pictures of cats doing normal things, so you still get to enjoy the feeling of Instagram without leaving the game.  Or, meet up with other hunters in multiplayer, choose any of the new pose emotes and take a hundred selfies before you bother even picking a quest.And, as always, you get to pet your cute pet pig and dress him up like a bumble bee.10/10

author: MusTardCat
review: Great game with lots of content to enjoy even after the story mode is complete. Monster Hunter: World brings a fair RNG system that isn't unfair, instead, it gives you a side goal to look out after while you're grinding for that new piece of armor. The armor system is very fun, and creating your own combinations of different armor pieces to allow your weapon to deal the most damage, or make your support palico kill monsters solo in 20 minutes. It's a fun and complex system that allows players to customize their hunter to their liking. The most recent expansion, Iceborne, brings with it a lot of content as well, and feels like a great, finished product that the developers put time and effort into. Overall, I would say that MHW is a game worth playing, and if you like it, i would even recommend the Iceborne expansion.

author: LeonFinal
review: A Monster Hunter Veteran. I have been playing this series since the release on the PS2. MHW is an absolute joy to play with thousands of hours of content for a collector, and still a wealth of content for those looking for fun or a challenge. This being said for other veterans,  World is by no means the traditional Monster Hunter experience. If you are looking for how the original series plays, I suggest Monster Hunter Freedom Unite for phones if you are able to get a controller going, or for 3DS/switch's most latest entry has an amazing feeling with Monster hunter Generations/Ultimate. This being said, World is not a bad game. it is absolutely amazing, just a new style of monster hunter. The systems are very streamlined and much more focused on crazy nonstop action, and less on Strategy and focused thinking.  I would always recommend this game for people new to the series. I feel like as time had gone by it became more and more difficult to introduce people to this series, but World is an excellent starting point now. I am hoping Iceborne will bring even more amazing mechanics suited to the new World style, and bring even more joy to those playing.

author: gigabite
review: Monster Hunter World is a mechanically solid game that incentivizes growth as a player. Stellar combat has always been a hallmark of the series, but the devs have gone to great lengths to ensure that World's is the smoothest to date, and when you account for the plentiful (and much needed) Quality of Life changes made it becomes clear that this is also the easiest game in the series to dive into at anytime. Initially it was lacking in terms of content, (monsters, really) but at this point in time, even the base game does a good job keeping the average player's attention (meaning without the Iceborne expansion on PC), though it still struggles in the end game when key event quests aren't in rotation. Legacy skill transfers over well but isn't needed, however series newcomers will still find the finer details of the game challenging to grasp initially without guides, even though more info is available to the player through simple gameplay than in previous installments. Thankfully there are a large number of creators in the Monster Hunter community dedicated to showing newer players the ropes, in addition to helping the general community understand the meta, though that's not an excuse for fundamental information to be obscured (Give us the option to see a weapon's true damage, damn it). I would strongly recommend this game to anyone looking to get into the series.

And Iceborne is on the way so you can look forwards to many more hours of play!

author: B4C0N5TR1P~[GER]
review: I have round about 1400+ hours in previuos Monster Hunter games: Monster Hunter Tri (Wii) , Monster Hunter 3 Ultimate (3DS), Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate (3DS).Apart from my own favorite monsters missing in the basic game (Barrioth, Brachydios, Agnaktor), this is the best Monster Hunter i´ve ever played.The graphics are awesome and the old monsters are looking pretty good as does the surrounding envirement. The old monster also got some new moves, but when you know how to read the monsters, you´ll have an easy time.The handling of the weapons is good too. You have different playstyles with every weapon to keep the experience fresh (or you stick to your favorite weapon and finish the game with that type *caugh* gunlance *caugh*)The design of the weapons and armor is also very nice. You can also have an armorskin, but these are the armorsets from the events, but this isn´t something to pick on. Fashion is endgame anyway. I own this game since 6th Dec 19 and it has consumed my life. At 74 hours, i "finshed" the game (Credits). Of course i´ll kep playing, next month is the release of MHW: Iceborne (where Barrioth+Brachydios will be added) and i´m lokking forward playing it.If you are not sure if you want to play a RPG with an endless loop of gathering and upgrading and you don´´t want to pay this much money (where i think that this game is worth the full price) try Dauntless first. Its a very downgraded version of Monster Hunter, but if you want more realisitc graphics and don´t want to hit cuddly big teddies, come back to this game.

author: Xorbah
review: Another great installment within one of my all time favorite game series. The graphics are beautiful and the gameplay is what you'd always expect from the monster hunter franchise. Some nice new additions to the game mechanics-wise in this title, such as interactive and destructible terrain. The game feels like it's lacking content to me in contrast to previous titles like Monster Hunter X. There's a noticeably lesser amount of monsters to hunt, but it doesn't subtract from the enjoyment of the game in this instance since I feel like they were trying to go for a different approach with MHW. If you've come to play this for a story, don't expect too much as it's very baseline in that regard. With everything in mind and taking into account graphics, gameplay and plot, I give Monster Hunter: World a 7.5/10.

author: Aacryon
review: In broad strokes, Monster Hunter: World is a perfect blend of challenging combat, gorgeous environments and deep mechanics and it rewards you on so many levels. The fluid combat is satisfying and the need to learn about, and prepare for, each encounter doesn't get in the way of this. Each monster you fight presents the player with a new puzzle to figure out - enhanced by the fact that you will normally need several encounters with each monster in order to learn everything about it. All discoveries about the life that inhabits the complex and dynamic environments are dutifully logged in a fantastic and well-presented journal which you can access at any time.To call the combat "like dark souls" does it a disservice to an extent. It’s what dark souls aspires to be - precise, meaningful moves of a fighting game combined with a sense of grace and fluidity creates something that is very visually pleasing and satisfying to master. Speaking critically for a second, the combat can become a bit of a cluster**** when there's four players and multiple monsters in the mix, but this really isn't a big issue.A word on playstyles and gear. Each weapon has a very "easy to lean, hard to master" ethos to it. You can play through the game with any weapon although you personally might enjoy a certain weapon's mechanics over another. Some are more for support than direct damage, but the game doesn't force you to constantly switch weapons even if some choices make some monsters a harder fight. You are expected to customise your gear BEFORE starting a quest, but you are able to change your gear on a quest (although not quickly or easily or in combat). I like to think of each weapon as a character in a fighting game, each has strengths, weaknesses and a unique move set which combine to give a completely different gaming experience. There is a heavy amount of customisation available and a huge number of options when it comes to both weapons and armour and skills.The game is a long-lived, complete experience which feels very polished and complete. It was very competently put together and even though the controls make it feel like it was designed with a controller in mind, the level of customisation lets you change things to suit your setup. Expect to finish the main campaign in around 50 hours, which obviously will vary hugely depending on a number of factors.If you don't like a challenge, you might quickly find yourself frustrated by the intimidating, unforgiving combat. The game is all about persevering, honing your skills and knowledge of the mechanics in order to beat the ever-increasing threats. There are no difficulty settings to be found, but you can always call for other players to help if you feel out of your depth.A word on the multiplayer. It's unconventional - just like dark souls. You can form a party or call for help during a mission if you feel like you need it. You can play through the whole game solo if you prefer. For the more experienced players you can answer S.O.S flares and join a player's game to help out. There is no PvP however.Is the game a grind? Expect to fight the same monsters quite a lot. Some of the monsters are just the same but in a different color with different A.I. If this bothers you, there might be enough content to make you feel like you've gotten your money's worth anyway. With over 20 unique monsters to battle. Take that with a slight pinch of salt however, because there are only about 4/5 monster skeletons, so many of the differences that make a monster unique are pretty superficial. However, it's not as bad as some RPG's that are truly shameless (I.E just changing the color and the numbers). There are about 5 environments, all of which are enormous, believable and satisfying to explore. The plot is virtually non-existent and since you're expected to repeat key plot missions, the sense of a plot moving forwards is undermined somewhat. So the story does take a back-seat.To wrap up then: An enormous amount of effort and love has gone into this game, and if you enjoy games like Dark Souls, The Witcher, Shadow of the Colossus or any of the previous monster hunter games you will find something to love here.

author: Dr.M
review: The 2 faced medic after a long day brings back another patient as the christmas heavy points him in the direction of a resting area, however the 2 faced medic is, not so, but still is ambushed by "skinny fat". When the 2 faced medic appears in the resting area all of the co-inhabitants of the resting area are thoroughly impressed and applaud. The 2 faced medic sniffles because he still has work to do and checks his papers. He then makes a clever joke about there being paper on his face which one sniper found to be quite shocking, but all the others are yet again thoroughly impressed. When the 2 faced medic switches persona's he is quite musical, and the snipers begin to jive to this groovy beat. However the shocked sniper from before refuses to take part of the festivities and is revealed to be an engineer infiltrator. He is punished by being turned into a snipers hat, all of the other snipers didn't think this could happen and that this was a fluke and are quite appalled at the 2 faced medic. The 2 faced medic then reasserts himself by stating "my HEAD on my face". One sniper off in the distance discovers how to fly, the 2 faced medic tells him not to do this. The 2 faced medic switches back to the funky side and starts to play another beat orchestrated by the hat. The not so groovy side of him tells the groovy side that the hat is stupid and then takes control of the body once more. Another engineer is fed up with this because he was just starting to get down with it and challenges the 2 faced medic. He is punished and turned into 2 snipers hats, all of the snipers couldn't believe he would actually challenge the 2 faced medic and mock him by laughing at him. One sniper is absolutely astonished that he has an unusual hat and a pyro is accidentally teleported to the resting area. The unusual sniper sees this and decides to watch on. The pyro is flabbergasted and drops his flame thrower, he then pulls out his trusty christian brutal sniper extinguisher unit to combat the 2 faced medic. After a long battle it is a draw and the medic has found an engineers hat and begins to show it off, telling everyone that he is contempt with this hat and is "good to go", many of the snipers look on in awe at this most auspicious of occasions. The restless 2 faced medic finally finding bliss ascends to the heavens where he meets the christmas heavy who tries to warn the ascending 2 faces medic of the inbound skinny fat, this was not on purpose as they both scream at the realization that they are going to collide. They collided creating a catastrophic explosion killing everyone. The End.

author: JMapes
review: To say I suck at this game would be an understatement. At first, I was very hesitant to play this game due to some pictures of UI I've seen and it looked very intimidating, almost MMO like at a quick glance. Despite some initial reservations I booted it up and started playing. I was immediately hooked on the world of Monster Hunter. While the story doesn't present anything too crazy and most of the characters are relatively generic, the set pieces and monsters in this game are top notch. The UI I was so worried about wasn't actually that bad once you got into the game. I learned that this was because Capcom tried simplifying a lot of aspects of this game compared to previous entries. With that being said, the crafting systems and the various different types of ammo, traps, and weapons can be disorienting without looking up an online guide of some kind.With all of this in mind though, I still recommend this game without a shadow of a doubt. The gameplay is extremely fun once you start an expedition and the grappling hook that comes with Iceborne is incredibly fun and I wonder why it wasn't in the base game. Killing the Anjanath for the first time had me popping off and I really felt accomplished. After spending upwards of 45 minutes on a mission it feels great to finally kill that boss monster you've been hunting.The Handler is as annoying as I was told8/10

author: Blorg
review: The game's good. You have to study the monsters you can't defeat, learn their moves, and how to counter them. It's an open world, and you can do whatever you want, you aren't railroaded through a line of quests that you have to do. Best of all, you can get other players to help you, too! Oh, as a cherry on top, you get an anthropomorphic cat friend to help you if you have no friends.

author: Ma'vina
review: Wonderful gameplay. You'll never run out of fun things to do plus it's even better with friends. Best to try all weapons and see what fits you. You can main one weapon but you're not limited to it. Graphics and sound are great too. The game's just awesome plus the community is friendly and helpful.

author: jolttt
review: This is my second copy of monster hunter world. I played it for about 100+ hours on ps4 and it was my favorite game on my playstation 4 hands down. Mind you im an action rpg junkie and i appreciate depth in my combat and alot of control. Monster hunter world gives you WAY more than you can handle and after a long period of silly clumsy mistakes which can coincide with your playthrough of the campaign.As you can see I am nearing 300 hours and will hit that before iceborn releases which I assure you i will squeeze atleast another 120 hours out of.Here is a quick version graphics:8/10 (10/10) hd pack Sound:9/10 Even the load menu music is enthralling. think kingdom hearts/finalfantasy, maple story ,wow or any favorite game sound track. They went above and beyond.Veteran hunter can really know a monster just by its roar and maybe even its steps.Combat: 9/10 I can't say enough good things about how impactful, dynamic , and EFFECTIVE every move is in monster hunter. The animations the monsters being knocked back, stunned, poisened, trapped, mounted , flying, jumping, climbing, swimming, floating( yes different from plain flying ) all server to completely immerse you in the hunt. want to be an agile ninja got you covered. want to be an untouchable archer god filling the air with a hurricane of arrows gotcha covered. want to basically have a howitzer? covered.Obligatory huge FF7/beserk great sword? Dude we put rockets on it. want to be able to live in the sky like a circus clown insect glaive...Warning story:5/10 not the worst but truely not a selling point. Trying to multiplay through the story is exceedingly frustrating also. You are probably going to hate the handler. and get used to being the only hunter in Astera*.Multiplayer 7/10: Though monster hunter itself is a dam near perfect game, match making is be very bad.getting dropped mid hunt leaves the difficulty up and faints (deaths before the mission fore fails) are shared amongst the group. As you may have gleamed from other Accurate reviews playing with randoms is truely a random experience. If the internet conection stays stable though i wouldnt trade the experience for the world GO team up with some people or go watch team Darkstar or Rurikhan play with people.Longevity 8/10: The elder game and late game is simple and repetitive but this is what games are . if you like fighting boss monsters in other games more than "trash' mobs or non elites and just wish you could have that be the focus while looking super bad ass and wearing your kills body parts get this game. If you think dark souls is to hard DO NOT get this game.I hope this game gets cross play at some point and if you need help feel free to ask if you see me online.this game and community are fantastic and more games should be as passionate and polished as this.if yyou even think anything in this game looks cool and you like a challange come join the 5th fleet you won't regret it! happy hunting!

author: Dea
review: As someone who has not played any Monster Hunter games previously, I found MHW to be a fun game with a good progression system and interesting monsters to fight. I think the Decoration farming and Streamstone farming can be pretty annoying considering how time consuming it is and how RNG heavy the system is, but even considering that you can get a lot of playtime out of MHW before that system annoys you. Overall an enjoyable experience solo or with friends.

author: Sky 💜🔞
review: Great game although I have some Issues:I personally believe there needs to be other weapons added to the gameWeapon Designs are very repetitive and aren't actually hardly any difference between weapons designs.RNG chance on the decorations are way too low I mean a 0.83% chance to get a decoration you need is actually insane.I don't like how it's going to take them an extra 5+ months just to add Iceborne DLC to this game. Even if you have to optimise this game for the PC it doesn't take that long.FPS Drops: Now FPS is kind of an issue in this game especially when you:Accept a quest and in the Depart screenWhen it's rainingJust after you kill a enemy and the quest is completeeffects - play a big part in why the FPS is so low in this game sometimes, and there needs to be an option to be able to remove the effects NOT all the way but remove some layers of the effects to reduce FPS drops for example like if 4 people are attacking at once the effects can get a bit hectic and cause low FPSAlso for some reason when you're in a game and going to disconnect the game drops half of its FPS.. And I dont know why.Other than those issues I think personally this is a very good game and would recommend it to anyone.The Online system is pretty weird and it should be easy to be able to play with your friends but other than that thank you for creating a brilliant game for me to play Im sure my playtime will definitely be in the 1000's

author: Selrate
review: This is quite possibly one of the funnest games I've ever played. The progression is incredible, every new monster is a good challenge. The depth of this game is amazing, and multi leveled. In the early game, you learn about your chosen weapon and how to generally battle monsters. In the mid game, you learn the in-depth combos and strategies of your weapon, and the right tools to bring to the right hunt. In the endgame, you have 13 new weapons to master, as well as armor skills builds which can keep people going for hundreds of hours.Was on the fence about buying initially, but after playing for this long I instantly pre-ordered Iceborne because I knew that it would bring so much more to this already amazing game.

author: Asminoid
review: I have never thought I'd become so obsessed with the game. I have seen multiple MH games before and always found those ugly or borderline ridiculous. Smoll pipl swingin' big Club-shaped swords at giant monsters.... Huh? Really? Then I tried MHGU demo and was completely and utterly repelled from ever picking it up... Until I've seen a friend of mine stream MHW. I found both  the graphics and gameplay engaging and decided to buy this game while on sale. The beginning was slow... Running around, looking for some mythical turtle... Oh well... Then the High Rank hit hard. That was something amazing, now I had to fire SOS and call for help, now I could not just rush through the fights solo like I used to and that was the point where I found it so much fun. interacting with other players, having those moments of terror when some of your teammates, let alone you, gets stunned while having aggro. Rushing to teammate or being rushed to to prevent fainting and then mass fainting, both stunned and the one rushing for help... Love it. Every second. And it does not ever feel unfair. You die - your fault (does not apply to Hunting Horn, keep up the great work, I am looking at you, Longsword...). And then out of nowhere the game decides you are no longer a baby and throws Pickle and Bomberjet at you. So not only do you get slam-jammed by a pickle, but also get blown to pieces (keep a big pile of sh*t in your inventory). After all that and the grind you become a literal Dovahkin, I mean, what can be more amazing, as trying to lay the hard hitting boi with the team full of Longswords (who all seem to have either mental disability or are Genji fanboys) ((I don't judge, I am myself a Long sword player, because it looks like Nodachi *excited weeb noises*)), you manage to defeat the boss with one attempt left, start carving and one comedian decides "No loot for you today" and interrupts you for the whole minute! Haha! Very Funny!I give this game 4 Longswords out of 1 possible Teamwork.

review: Feels a bit grindy at the beginning, but then you become addicted. Amazing soundtrack, amazing boss fights. There is nothing more to this game. A whole life is not enough to complete this gem.

author: Dod-Regnbue
review: I honestly love this game, and the series. I picked up Monster Hunter back in 2004 on the PS2 and I have never looked back. MH: World is (compared to the others in the series) very new player friendly, but it still can be quite jarring. Think, Dark Souls bosses on repeat. Although I wouldn't suggest aligning these two games, that is, essentially what it is.You are fighting bosses. Hard ones. Repeatedly. There are a lot of in game mechanics and builds that YOU need to figure out, also know what skills work with what, not everything is a blanket and works on everything. The game actually does very little to help players out, such as tutorial and hand holding (go here to find X thing), most missions are 50 minutes, so be prepared to spend 50 minutes finding and fighting the monsters. Once you have done it a few times, you remember locations and patterns, and have hopefully geared up a few times, these 50 minutes get whittled down to 5. There is a issue with multiplayer, particularly, in the early game. I have seen many posts in the reviews saying that the game is 1/3 solo, or you have to do so much solo before you can join friends. I played the main story completely Co-Op with my wife. Literally hit about 200 hours with just Multiplayer. There are 2 missions at the start you must complete before Multiplayer is unlocked from here, all you need to do is see the cut scene for each monster. So, enter a mission, see the monster cut scene, leave mission (leaving a mission does not penalise the player) re enter mission with your party. This is Capcoms null attempt to stop people getting carried and not experiencing the game, at best it is mildly frustrating. In total there are 14 different weapons types. From the quick and nimble Dual Blades, the hulking wallop of the Great Sword, or maybe range is your style, so pick up the Tactical Nuke Machine that is the Heavy Bowgun. So I am sure there is something for you to get a long with.  As for the story . . . Well if you want the complete picture, there are about 10 other games you will need to get and play through. But there are a few Lore Websites you can just look up. World is but a small part of a very large picture, and unless you really care for it, don't worry. Most Monster Hunter Veteran players refer to the story as the Tutorial, to further put it into perspective, the Story Finishes are Level 16 (or HR [Hunter Rank]). I am currently Level 870, and the Cap is Level 999. That is how little the Story has a part to play in each individual game.If you like Loot / Grind Games, with a challenge then this is for you. There is a HUGE expansion coming soon which will basically double the games size and things to do, with all new mechanics and Monsters to fight. So what are you waiting for Hunter? Join the Expedition!

author: Z̵҉̴͝͞arosg̴̨̛҉uth
review: What can I say? I think the amount of hours I've spent on this game speak for whether I'd recommend this game or not.While it had to endure a bit of a rough start due to connection issues, nowadays communication errors are few and far between. And if you're more of a solo player like me, that's even less of a problem.Otherwise in my eyes this game is the pinnacle of action games. While the game starts off a bit slow due to unskippable intro cutscenes (my only major gripe with this game) once you go out on your first few hunts as you learn what the game entails, it will just grab you with its talons and bite into your with its teeth and this is one monster that will not let go. So you'd better be ready to beat it over the head with the weapon of your choice (and with 14 options, there's bound to be something that suits your tastes) and beat this beastie into submission.Combat is Monster Hunter: World's main and pretty much only focus. And it does combat well. From basic movement to the distinct playstyles of each weapon, there's a flow that just feels incredibly satisfying once you understand it and go with it.And when you're not looking to beat up some big monster, instead go on an expedition and just observe the world. Observe the monsters as they patrol their habitats and hunt or scrounge for food. Or go and catch yourself some endemic life to get some pets for your room. Or even just collect some basic resources that can be found in the world to prepare yourself for your next big hunt.It is clear to me that the development team put a lot of time and effort into all of the game's aspects and it shows. Not much else to say but I wholeheartedly recommend this game.Happy hunting!

author: Gruz
review: Monster Hunter: World PC (MHW) has the strengths of the MHW, but all the downfalls of a console to pc port. It is clear it is a port, so if you intend to play with mouse and keyboard expect to see and feel the limitations. 7/10 on release, 9/10 as of this review.On release I would give MHW a 7/10. Gameplay, progression, flow and feel of combat, visual aesthetic, sound design are all top notch. Story was greatly lacking, hud, interfaces, social options, and menu interactions were also poorly implemented. But the rating I would give MHW now is a 9/10. As the game has progressed since it released, it has received constant and substantial love/development from Capcom. Optimizations, more pc controls & graphic options are added frequently, themed events and anniversaries are high quality. New content is patched in on the regular, whether its a massive expansion like the upcoming Iceborne DLC, or even if it's just a new monster variation there is always something around the corner to look forward to. If you enjoy epic worlds with tons of things to explore and environments to hunt in, MHW is a great addition to the Monster Hunter Franchise. Great for veterans and newcomers alike.

author: ぜつない
review: Back then when Monster Hunter released on PS2 I'm very excited about the freshly gameplay mechanic that they're implement on this game and since then I'd really addicted to this series until I play MHP3rd. But, sadly I can't feels the MH4 and MHGU seris coz I didn't make to afford 3DS. So, when I heard CAPCOM planned developed MH on PC i tought it was Nation lock again like MHFrontier series & MHO, but I was totally wrong. It announced on TGS 2017 that they're announcing MHW!! For the first time, Ryozo Tsujimoto want to release MH series on PC except MHFrontier and MHO tough (I dont expect mobile Spin-off too) and this game got our MH Fans heart like it was a dream.So, they're make a realistic photorealism character unlike the previous series (such cartoonist), they're add some new mechanic like slinger, Open world (we're not have to waiting loadscreen if we move forward to another area), Scoutfly (similiar to paintball but little annoying), and many more.So if you a new player to this MH Series, I should recommend you to play this game coz this time, MHW doesn't feels like very difficult at all compared with previous series :)Vice versa, I do like all CAPCOM give us from this game coz they have not intend to put some pay to win mechanic (just like ol' times) and they're keeping put some old flagship monster on this game, feeling nostalgia haha and some many more that details will keep me love this game very much.Aaaannndddd I don't think if they put some facial animation for the cast character coz like the character lipsync is not synchronized with spoken language at alll. Overall, I love this game. And for everyone whom read my reviews, lemme say Thank You Very Much!NB*  Thanks CAPCOM for made my childhood was better until now. God Bless.

author: aezzoc
review: Great game.Combat and grinding feels and is amazing, it's really fun to build a nice little set in this game for dps or just comfortable hunting. There are many weapon types to choose from so there has to be at least one that you will like.The MH community is steadily growing and welcomes newcommers. The game is awesome but there are some flaws with it.The endgame is kinda lacking, all you will do is grinding for rare decorations that you will probably never get. But making an budget build without rare decos is also an option and you will at least get some rare ones. The only issue I have with the deco and stream stone farming is, that the tempered investigations you have to grind get kind of repeatative after a while.Kulves rare drop weapons will also likely not be droped after like 30 sieges.Compared to older MH games in world there aren't a lot of large monsters to hunt, which is one of the reasons why farming decos become reapetative fast. But the monsters that are in world are pretty nice, just the tempered investigation system makes it a bit tedious. Iceborne will add a lot more monsters tho.Tho, those things kinda make the game unpleasant, I have to say that all in all Monster Hunter World is still amazing and one of the best games I have ever played.With the Icebornes DLC coming sometime next year for PC, those problems will be hopefully fixed. Capcom did say that the Iceborne expansion will rival/surpass (don't remember well) previous Ultimate versions of MH content-wise, which sounds great. Having played some older MH games, it seems that iceborne will be pretty sick.Have fun.

author: Capt.Wulfz
review: As a fan of the old Monster Hunter games I can say that this is a definite buy. Although it isn't as hard as the old games, but that could be attributed to my past experience in the old games as well as how well you're able to move in this game, it still presents a very nice challenge for veterans and newcomers alike. Very welcoming to newcomers to the series as well, in fact I was able to persuade some of my friends who've never played a MH game before to give this a try and they enjoyed it.

author: Russo
review: Great Monster Hunter game. Probably not what veterans expected, but very good still. Compared to other MH games, it has new features that make our lives easier, like the scoutflies, wingdrakes and the slingshot. But is it easier than other MH games, like every single veteran complains? Well, it is at first, but when you reach the endgame it feels quite challenging. If you've never played MH, then by all means buy MHW. But if you've played before and you're considering if MHW is as good as the other MHs, here's my list of pros and cons:Pros:+ Absolutely beautiful graphics+ Gameplay feels more fluid than other MHs+ Doesn't have Hunting Styles bs+ Huge maps with no loading screens+ Scoutflies and other things that make your life easierCons:- Builds are not really challenging to build and the META doesn't really have more than 3~5 builds for each weapon- Weapon designs are pretty lazy- Iceborne is paid DLC

author: Muffinwild
review: Monster Hunter: World is by far one of the most fun and challenging games to play alone or with friends. Combining Dark Souls-esque combat with unique environments and monsters, Monster Hunter: World tells a great story about adventure and the troubles that can come with it. While the game can be repetitive in a sense, there are enough variations of monsters to keep things interesting well past the main story, which depending on how much you grind for gear, can take anywhere from 50-90 hours to complete. However, once the story is over the real fun begins. With weekly challenges and bounties, as well as multiple big events throughout the replayability of this game is second to none in recent years. As I mentioned prviously, the combat is in a sense similar to the Dark Souls game. By that I mean timing is everything. Overall one of the most fun games of this generation!

review: While I've poured hundreds to thousands of hours into previous entries (4U being my favorite) I just found myself constantly frustrated with this iteration. The worlds are beautiful and feel like they are breathing life, but that same expansion in size and scale is a detriment as tracking down monsters and chasing across the map seems to have added tons of trekking that feels exponentially longer compared to the previous smaller area-based maps.I still recommend this though as it is a good introduction into the series and has undeniably opened the door to new players to understand why this series is so damn good.

author: Jøn
review: I have played many of the MH games starting with the release of Tri somewhere in the year of 2012 on a friend's Wii.I adored the skill required to actually kill monsters instead of a constant mindless grind, you get invested in a fight.Therefore I am glad to say Monster Hunter: World captured this same feeling for me.The combat is solid and smooth and I rarely if ever encountered any performance issues running it on my decently powered PC.One small note of criticism would be the grind at the end of the game.In all other (to my knowledge) MH titles, there has been an RNG value set in place to give the games a proper endgame in the form of charms, I feel like this is a bit lacking in Monster Hunter: World seeing as they have switched the roles of charms and decorations up.It felt like a nice refresher till you began to notice how rare it is to get some decent decorations without waiting for an event quest every quarter of a year to show up. I realize this is to promote the longevity of the game, to keep players.. well.. playing.Though (like in previous titles) there is not surefire way to really grind for parts.Grinding on RNG has been made more fun with expeditions, so you don't feel you're solely hunting a monster for decs instead of having to do mining trips like in previous titles. I just feel like after a certain point, fighting the same Pink Rathian over and over again, having farmed all its parts already, that the grind feels like as much of a chore as mining for charms like in older titles.The main difference being that in 4U/G/GU etc. there were 'exploits' so to speak to grind them a bit faster (not more reliably to get amazing charms) but when playing these older titles nowadays, doing a quick charm run feels far more rewarding that doing several purple investigations in World. This might just be my opinion, but I sure do think that when the Iceborne expansion comes out, with new monsters to fight, more difficulty to add, that it would be wise to implement a better form of RNG endgame.(note: wrote this in a bit of hitch and I know what I said has likely been said before in a better format and with better spelling/grammar etc. But hey; if you can, you must)

author: Talen56
review: I think this is probably one of the best games I've ever got my hands on. I've played since day one on console and then got my hands on it for PC a few months later. And even when I had to completely restart from the ground up on a new platform, I enjoyed the playthrough just as much as I did the first time.Pros: - Smooth, enjoyable combat system once you get used to it; Each weapon having it's own unique playstyle, niches and moves - Awesome monster design; Each monster is designed to be both a plausible animal in the real world, as well as an awesome and engaging enemy as a boss fight, coming together to make each fight actually feel like you're hunting a giant animal - Immersive, and incredibly detailed maps and ecosystems; Even the little tiny animals that you originally thought was just for detail has some sort of use or unique place in it's environment - A lot of backstory and lore if you're into that kinda thing - Power creep is engaging and satisfying to climbCons: - Sometimes RNG in obtaining a certain part is BS- At first the combat system will feel wonky- In game tutorials and hints barely cover anything, so you best do your research when you need to- Tremors (Seriously who thought that was a good idea?)Overall I think this game is phenomenal and I would 100% recommend this to anyone who's looking for an MMO that's refreshing, posing a new way of taking on the genre. As well as anyone who like the idea of fighting giant dinosaurs and dragons.

author: Arwy
review: Admittedly one of the easier games of the series, MHW is still a great modern adaptation. Gameplay and controllers are a lot smoother and sped up making it a joy to play. There is a steep learning curve as the game does not hand hold but it's satisfying to learn and master. Not to mention, one of those games that is very fun to play with friends. But also fun in solo too. Although the price tag is a bit much, I would recommend it to anyone that likes the strategy of boss fights on a bite size.

author: True Path
review: The Gameplay: Possibly the best feeling Monster Hunter to date. The control of your character is great and the pacing I feel remains generally undisturbed from what previous entries have tried to do.The Story:Is not going to make you question the intricacies of life, but it gets the job done. There is also a good amount of attention to detail on one particular level to the story which is a nice touch.The Visuals:The environment, the monsters and the players are a pleasure to look at. BUT THAT FOOD THOUGH!!The Sound:The music is actually pretty good all around, and the monsters roars are superb.The Experience:I remember getting the DS version of Monster Hunter and just not liking it because of how clunky it felt. It also had some stupid things like the need to flex after you drank a potion. This game fixes a lot of that while also keeping true to what the hardcore fans really want from the game. You really do feel like a specialized hunter when playing this game as every item and statistic has meaningful weight in regards to fighting any given monster. The game looks, sounds and feels great. Good Game!

author: anomolie
review: I waited to buy this game because I'd heard of all the issues people had had - and gotta say I love the game, all in all, but nothing is without pros and cons.Pros- Playstyle.  Don't like the sword and shield?  Try one of the others, any really, they all play so differently than each other that there's something for nearly everyone in there - Light Bowgun and Heavy Bowgun are the only ones that feel like you're playing even close to the same weapon, and even those have some basic and noticeable differences.- Content.  Between getting your dream armor for looks, to getting that perfected set, for damage, there's a lot to do after the story.  Even when you feel finished, you might find yourself wanting to build a new set for a weapon you want to pick up.  After that, there are plenty of event quests that rotate on a regular schedule, and then on special festivals even more event quests come along.- Community.  For the most part the community is very helpful and friendly - I've yet to encounter a rude player, but then I've also not encountered everyone.- Connectivity.  I only include this because though having a good connection to the game is expected for most, this needs noting as part of the rumors that kept me away for a while was the terrible connections so many people were having to friends as well as to just the servers in general.And now on to theCons- Grind.  Though there is plenty of content to go through and getting that armor set or weapon or Warrior's or Hero's stone you've been after feels fantastic, getting there can sometimes feel like you set a stone wheel spinning and have placed your face directly onto the surface.  Fine if you don't mind a grind, especially ones that can be (slightly) mixed up from time to time to stop it from feeling too old, but not for those who hate having to grind for their armor.- Hunter Ranking.  This is on there because, even though up until about 140 (I think) you get rewards, eventually the HR level is...pointless.  About all it does after a certain point is show how many hours you've put into the game, there's nothing extra for reaching those upper levels of 900+ besides personal satisfaction, which kudos if that's your thing.- Events.  Events are the spice of life for this game - don't get me wrong.  From Extreme Behemoth to Kulve Taroth to Greatest Jagras, they're great!  But...they have a major downside.  Events are rotated in and out and even then some events are bound to certain festivals/times of year, which is a major bummer for people who want something from those.  And even for the ones that rotate in and out, if you fail to get everything you want from an event before it ends, it can easily be several months before you get another shot.  The only thing more infuriating than a grind is a grind you want to do but can't because it's locked away.All in all, I do have to recommend this game.  Even with it's faults, it's a great way to just go in, feel powerful, face wonderful monsters, and just generally have a good time.  So if you're interested, come in, join the community, get your butt kicked by something you love, or love to hate, and hunt yourself some monsters.Happy hunting!

review: The game is fun with stylish moves and epic boss rushes. The only barrier of entry is learning the weapons. With 14 choices of weapons, pick one and slowly learn the moves. Take every victory as stepping stone to grow your stylish armor and weapon collections.As a Hunter! Remember to always be prepared with flash bug, healing items, damage buff and defense buffs. So cultivate your drugs and bugs.PS. Don't expect to be beating down a monster, take small steps learn their moves, their weakness and plan accordingly!Icebornce, add lots more to game, recommend to pick it up after finish World first!

author: infernochim
review: This game has stunning graphics and amazing fighting and it really lives up to the hype. While the game might not be up to par difficulty wise compared to other monster hunter games it still manages to be challenging and fun. The game runs great on pc and the systems transfer nicely to pc. This game fixes so many issues that the monster hunter series has had since its creation and really opens it up for newer players.My only issue with this game is how tedious the endgame is. Once you finish the story mode which is a good 100 ish hours of gameplay your gameplay consists of just grinding out the same set of monsters that will give you the gem you want and hoping to god that you get it. the drop rates are pretty bad and you need multiple to make a good set. Then with these gems and your perfect gear you fight monsters that you've already fought thousands of times before that are just a little harder. Hopefully this issue is sorted out at the launch of the expansion but even now the base game is worth recommending just for how unbelievably fun it is.

author: Toxic Fuel
review: After reaching the 100 hour mark, I wanted to finally write my review for this game, even if it's not super in-depth. I'm mostly disappointed to see that it still only has an overall "mixed" rating because this game is truly spectacular right now. I wasn't playing at launch so I never experienced any woes that might have come with it, but this game has exceeded my expectations, and I wish I had bought it sooner (shout-out to my friend that gifted it to me!). Anyways, onto the rest of the review.MH:W is the first MH game I have ever played, and I guess it's because I was never familiar with the series previously. But I finally understand its popularity. The excitement of going out to kill giant monsters with a sick weapon that fits your play style is really something. Normally, I wouldn't play this type of game. I tried out a similar free-to-play game called Dauntless, but I just couldn't get into it. This one, however, is much different and much better to me. One of the main things that pulled me in right away was actually the learning curve, and just wanting to become better at games like this. I won't lie when I say that it's one of the more difficult games in my library right now, but in a good way. I love that feeling of finally defeating a monster I've struggled with, or becoming proficient with a weapon I thought I wouldn't do good with. There is just so much satisfaction that can come from playing this game.To add to the excellent gameplay, the graphics are also nothing short of amazing, even on "medium-ish" settings on my mid-range PC. The high-resolution texture pack really adds to it of course, and the only thing it really affects is my VRAM usage. There is little to no FPS drop. All for free as well! I only wish there was a dedicated camera mode for taking better screenshots.Lastly, the community, along with the continued support from Capcom has been great, and I've only been playing for a little over a month now. The fact that I already get to look forward to a MAJOR expansion later this year really gives me hope for the future of the game. I almost can't believe I'm saying this, but to me MH:W would have been worth it for me even at full price. I'm very thankful this game was given to me, and I highly recommend you to try it out, even if you may be hesitating like I did.

author: Gmno
review: Pros:-If you die, it isn't the games fault it is your fault.-You'll become addicted too the game early on, once you get through all the content it's still fun to just pick up and play for a few hunts.-It is beautiful-Monster's have their own life, you can follow them around to watch how they interact with the world and other critters.-Every weapon is different and is a different style of gameplay, swapping to a different weapon class will extend your enjoyment of the game.-Nice soundtrack.-Free DLC updates with new monsters and beefed up current monsters.-Dedicated mod community.-Hunting Horn.-Not a cash grab.-Dodogama.-Creates enjoyable moments that make you feel like a bad-ass or will make you poop yourself.-One of the better ports.-Crossover events with other games. -Hilarious/Cool outfits.-Custom automated messages when you do actions, which is really funny what people say when they mount a monstie.-Collect rare pokemans and make them wander around your room.-Largely a good community.-No hand holding, read guides and learn. Good luck.Cons:-It is highly recommended to use a controller.-95% of the time it has a stable connection, but it really picks the worst times during the end of a hunt to drop people.-Long Sword Users.-Solo speed running streamers who "insire" newbies to play hard, high skill ceiling builds. -Doesn't know how to play cut scenes with multiplayer, basically you solo until you get the cut scene of the next monster and then have to join in on your friends quest after they see the cut scene. Once the cut scenes are all seen its never a problem.-Console gamers think they are better because they get new content before PC. Make sure to tell them how you don't have loading times and we're almost caught up anyway. -No nier crossover, no 2B costumes. :(-The wait for Iceborne, the expansion, hurts my soul. Please give asap.It is worth the money even at full price, even more so if it is on sale. Look for a free week-end to try it out if you're on the fence.

author: MinhNghiax
review: It’s been a year for Monster Hunter World since it first came out on PS4. After 800 hours on PS4, I can say this is the game that I love the most. To start off, I’m not a Japanese-games lover, so when I started I didn’t give it my full attention, which this game might be my next kind of “Try and Drop” game. But later, I got hooked on the action and it exceeded my expectation in every way. The game is basically you kill the monsters, get the materials, craft better gears, fight harder monsters, replay it until you master your weapons and dominate the monsters. The grinding is real, but the rewards are worth your time. When you finally figured out how to beat a monster that you’ve been struggling for a long time, that’s when you figured out how satisfying the game is.This game looks gorgeous, everything is perfect and detailed. Also, the performance is absolutely beast, I rarely seen any hiccups or lags either. Furthermore, the monsters are very detailed, it has footprints and different features like special animation, moves, patterns, auras etc. I have to say that this is the most polished Monster Hunter I've ever played. The game has plenty of weapons to choose from, so you won’t get bored in anytime soon. Each of them has different playstyle and requires time & dedication to master it. The combos are pretty amazing, some of them are based on the previous Monster Hunter game, but this time, they expanded it furthermore with much more useful & complex attack skills. Take Long Sword as an example, now we have a more detailed Fade Slash and we can also do a following up Spirit Blade to build up the gauge. Not just that, Helm Breaker is an absolute beast skill to use where it jumps up and ends with a high damage slash. In addition, there is a skill called “Foresight Slash”. It’s very hard to use and requires you to be in a mid-combo. After a while, you will figure out the monster’s patterns, it gives you a sense when the monster's going to roar or attack you, so that you can use Foresight to dodge it and gain spirit gauge faster. Not just LS, but the other weapons also has special/new moves that gives you advantage if you know how to use it correctly/timingly. For instance, Guard Point of Charge Blade, if you do it at the right time, it can knock the monster out with KO damage; just like LS’s Foresight Slash, it will dodge the attack and you won’t lose any health. Each weapon has an important role in some situation. There is no perfect weapon or the best weapon to choose, but in some cases, some weapons might give you an advantage over the others. For example: If I want to play safely, I would choose charge blade or gunlance, which give me a shield to straight up dodge the attack easier than using LS’s Foresight Slash; or if I want to play aggressively, then LS or Dual Blades would deal much higher damage; or if I want to attack the monster at a distance, then Bow would be a better choice.The weapons have different paths to upgrade depends on the monster and the elements. It has different element to choose from: Ice, Thunder, Dragon, Fire, Raw damage, etc. Most of the monster will have different weaknesses and if you choose the best one, it would extract the most damage out of it. For example, I mostly go with raw damage (no element), since I’m kind of lazy to change up everything, and raw damage is perfect for most of the situations. When you fight Elder Dragons, they have a special feature called “Elder Seal”, which is their special aura abilities that protect themselves and enable them to enrage some special moves. So, if you use a weapon that has Elder Seal from Medium to High, it will suppress the Elders’ special skills. For example: Nergigante has a special move called “Dive Bomb”, that it flies up and tries to kamikaze into you causing high amount of damage or maybe instant-kill. If you or your friends use High elder seal weapons, it will take a longer time  to regrowth its nails on the back (a sign to tell when it’s going to use the special ability) and the ability to do the “Dive Bomb”.  So, if your team doesn’t have any weapons with ES, you will see its nails go black faster and do dive bomb more frequently. That’s the reason why you must have the patience and time to understand the monsters:the patterns/features, where its roams, where its sleep, etc. On the other hand, the monsters are also very balanced, you might feel overwhelming at the beginning but after a while you will eventually get it.The armor system is pretty good, where you need to mix different monster’s armors to gain the best skills out of it. Each armor has different skills to go along with it, the upgrade will just be for the base armor stat, which help you withstand the damage from the monster’s attack, and nothing else. So, the best build is the one with great skills set, not with a high armor number. Some weapons require specific skills set to make it better, so you might want to grind for multiple monsters to build the best one that is suitable with your weapons. For example: Long Sword requires high affinity and damage to be able to get the best out of Helm Breaker skill, so Nergigante’s helm might be the best helm because it has 2 Maximum Might skill and 1 Attack skill. Maximum Might give you more affinity (Crit Chance) while your stamina is at full. But for dual blade, this skill is useless, when most of the attacks/combos require high usage of stamina, and barely be able to keep full stamina for a long time like Long Sword’s players. That’s the reason why you need to build a set for each weapon specifically. The other way to obtain skills is to use decoration and put it on the armor. The higher rarity the decorations are, the better skills it gives. Also, different decoration gems have different level (size) and only fit to the same size or bigger to be able to use it. The size ranging from 1 to 3 with 1 is the smallest and 3 is the largest. For example: Attack skill gem is only size 1, Critical Boost is size 2, Handicraft is size 3. The armors will have different gem slot with different sizes. Decorations are very hard to find, which the rarest will or might only appear in tempered threat-level 3 monsters fight, and of course, it won’t be easy; and the result is also based on RNG which you might have to replay a thousand times just to get a second Attack Gem. But as I said, the reward is very satisfying, and this is one of the reasons. To be able to build the perfect set with the perfect decorations, it will take you hundred of hours to complete it.-	Developers are constantly updating the contents. Ice Borne DLC is coming and I can’t wait for it.-	Other DLCs are just cosmetic and stickers to chat with the others. It’s an option and you don’t have to buy it. I just want to support the developers a cup of coffee for this awesome game and also be able to get something for myself.-	You/your friends must watch the cutscene to be able to join others.-	Snap Head during fight when the monster appears.-	People leaves mid-battle; the monster’s health is still scaled, and the others are not able to join.Fight the monsters. Failed. Try Again. Replay it. Get better gears. Try it again. Killed the monsters. Advance to higher monsters. Master the weapons. Build the best set. Try out different weapons. Find the best decorations. Dominate.I would gladly give this game 10/10 and this is my personal 2018 GOTY. It’s been a great year so far and with the Iceborne DLC is coming, I might be able to put in another 1000 hours in 2019.

author: Nhan
review: I have over 600 hours on the PS4 and the PC version is slightly behind on updates.Its a pretty good game, reviews do not reflect the current state of the game.It had a rough release due to its poor port/optimisation however it's been fixed.MHW is not a game for everyone, its a straight forward game where you hunt monsters, get/upgrade gear and weapons. However with every monster or quest you complete, it always feels rewarding. There's no heavy RNG, just hard work, if you earned it then you earned it. You feel a great sense of progression and accomplishment after beating a hard monster.The end game is what you expect from a typical grind genre, its all about the gear, weapons and decorations (think of them as enchantments but they are reusable). The weapons each feel unique and fun to use and the armour abilities have great deep customisation.In the future there will be an update around autumn 2019, this will introduce G-Rank and an ice map which is a very huge content for players. G-Rank is a very hard difficulty where even having the best armour in the game, you can still get 1/2 shot to death. I guess a lot of us are masochists if we enjoy this sort of stuff...The game is definitely worth giving a go if you enjoy this genre or looking for a challenge. This is also a great co-op game for up to 4 players if you have friends to wack with. Its nice seeing free content given which keeps the game fresh.
