author: Eucli
review: Great Jagras is precious, protect it at all cost.And also, attack jewel is the rarest item among all other items.Personal updates on 14th April 2020-Attack jewels are no longer rare, attack jewel 4 is -The "beginner" weapon has been buffed into a great sword, Long Sword helmbreaker still kinda bugged out sometimes(from what i have heard)-Sticky is the new pre-nerf slicing ammo.-Flash pods are no longer as useful as it was since IB launched, but some players still use it, pretty cool.  Dung pod is a must bring tool to encourage social distancing and prevent clustering  between monsters.-Lunastra is not that bad to fight come on guys.-Caught all the rare endemic life, doing so will make you spend an additional 100hrs if luck isn't part of you real life perk. Since they make my room looks cool, it's totally worth it.-Barioth has the biggest hitbox that can reach you in any distance,but not more than Nerg.-Synced contents and title updates with console, wow-is still a fun game to me i guess

author: Distance Of Shadows
review: Started playing this game when it was first out on the PS4 and its awesome. Controls took a little bit of getting used to but after that it was so much fun. Its a beautiful game with an awesome eco system and once you have worked out how to use the weapons effieciently, combat has a good flow to it, especially with the Switch Axe, my main weapon of choice, flashy and great damage. Some cool things about the game:- Palico, your adorable cat companion who fights by your side is very useful especially when you get a certain gadget for it which helps harvest parts of the monsters- Monster Behaviours and Parts, I like how certain parts are breakable, others are extremely tough and you can sever tails. Its makes you think more about where your placing your attacks and what weapon you will be bringing, as well as learning when and where to block or dodge.- Weapons large variety of weapons with cool attacks. There will probably be at least one weapon you love. While some of the weapons look meh at low rarities, at rarity 7 and above they start looking awesome if they dont already.- Capturing monsters gives you more loot, so if you break and sever all the parts and capture it, its more effient than purely killing everything, also reduces some of the grind.- SOS, while I am a solo player. Trying to leave out spoilers but: The monster you face in the Collossal Task quest is easy but there are breakable hidden in plain sight parts that will increase the drop chance of the rarest drop from that monster. Firing an SOS really helps get that item for when your farming the monster and the SOS flare gets a lot of attention fast.- Turf Wars, its awesome to see the large monsters fighting for territory and as long as they dont both target you, it can work out in your favour.- Mounting, fun, looks badass and knocks the monster down if you dont get thrown off. (You have to do a certain amount of damage before you can mount again, worth knowing if you play with an Insect Glaive)- No fall damage, hitchin a rides on wind drakes, mantels that lets you glide or do other stuff is funThere are a few cons:- Handler/NPC Partner (She's funny how she gets into trouble but a lot of players think shes annoying)- Combat is tougher with others which can be a con for using an sos flare and the money/Zenny is divided between players, also if someone faints it reduces the overall money so if you need more coins. (Although when your at a certain lvl there are easy quests/bounties that do give a lot of zenny. One about killing Coral highland Shamos and one about getting fossils from the place you unlock after the Coral Highlands.)- If someone gets knocked out the whole team pays for it. If you play with others and someone on your team isnt doing well and keeps going down the team will fail the mission which is a bit harsh, especially when helping lower lvls or if someone hasnt really played against that monster much.Things to note:- I've spent countless hours on the PS4 but only just started playing on PC, the PS4 controller works completely fine on the PC Steam version but the control prompts are Xbox. There is a Dual Shock mod on Nexus mods if any of you prefer a PS4 controller, no install, just replace a folder with the folder you get from Nexus. Also note that the share button is actually the touch pad symbol and the touch pad is the R3 button.- There aren't actually that many monsters, some monsters sub catagories of other monsters so basically a different colour and maybe a different or additional element. However, the tempered versions and events do give good rewards, plus if you want full sets of armour or fully upgrading your weapon it can be very grindy so you may be too busy to notice this until you reach the end game ranks. They do also add in more monsters every now and then, like in the Witcher event quest and the Final Fantasy Cross over. Heard there will be some Monsters from the previous games may be making an entrance at some point too so over time the not many monsters statement may slowly change over time.- If Poogie, the cute pig in Aestera that you can pet, dress and cuddle, is happy enough, it can find items for you around Astera if you put it on the floor when its bouncing in your arms. You can find all sorts around the tradeyard and somewhere there is a meal voucher if you want to eat for free ;)I brought the Deluxe version on the PS4 when it first came out and then recently got it on PC so definitley recommending this game.Edit: Removed Graphics con as they recently did a graphics update for PC which is awesome :)

author: Legion495
review: -a big improvement to previous games- if you ask me.I played an older type of Monster Hunter and came very fast to the conclusion that this game is way more streamlined for players. Some may hate that, but in reality it makes the game way more accessible to the mass.Now I have to add that the initial release was a mess. Clearly the game is not really made for PC but we have seen a lot of improvements. I could not run the game smooth at 60FPS with a beefy PC well that changed with up to 20FPS+ on 1080p. I personally dislike the Keyboard/Mouse controls and strongly suggest using a Gamepad but it is still playable with those. But expect to adjust key bindings to your liking (at least that is what I would do).Recently we got a update that added 21:9 support and behold it is not so cheap as Fallout 76s 21:9 solution.If you are into that you can even tweak the config to display any res you want, that is what I am doing it will add bars depending on your selected ratio tho.I think the UI is horrible (especially for decorations) and there could be better solutions. The radial menu is a bit touchy (I am surprised they did not make it full screen transparent), your menus save with your item management (which is annoying) and several parts of the game UI could really need some kind of search bar. You tend to lose the overview. I would say this is one of the few points the next game could improve a lot upon. Then we have Multiplayer. First off I have to mention that it is weird that you only can see players in the gathering hub. That there is no "Friends only" join option for Steam is weird (maybe I missed it) which then requires you to use the session ID. It is a bit of a hassle this way but acceptable. Also the requirement to open a session to play the game is strange, but it is offline playable if you so desire. Keep in mind event quests and such things update frequently.Beyond all that there is this terrible issue the game has. It scales to 4 players once you are 2 or more players. If you are 2 everyone gets his palico. If you are 3 no one gets a palico and you play for 4 players. The balance is clearly not in check. I wish they would at least add the quest hosts palico for 3 players (or let the players decide).Be aware that almost all female Armors look rather stupid, same goes for layered armors. So you should check Transmog from Nexusmods, because late game very likely forces you to mix-up armors which tends to look horrible.The game gets frequent updates and a huge DLC is being worked on. You basically can ignore all the DLCs they offer right now as nobody cares about animations and stuff. I suggest the base game version. The devs clearly have their own idea how things should look and be like and you notice that a lot. I am okay with it but some people may dislike it and the game has a surprising depth to it regarding weapons and skills.

author: dxm prod
review: Monster Hunter: World is easily one of the best games I have ever played.This is my first experience with the Monster Hunter franchise, and after experiencing this game I can say that I'm hooked. At just over 60 hours played I haven't even encountered every monster in the game or tried each of the 14 weapon types out. The sheer amount of stuff in this game is mind blowing, and it seems that every mechanic has been incredibly well thought-out and polished. Most of my playtime has been solo but this game is also a riot if you have friends to play with. Getting started is a little bit slow and learning new monsters can be incredibly frustrating, but it is immensely satisfying once you finally learn a monster's attacks and down it, only to go back to the base and spend all of those hard-earned bones, hides, and other miscellaneous pieces on a sick new piece of armor or weapon upgrade.Easily worth the full $60 pricetag, and I would recommend this to anyone who might like a mash-up of games like Diablo and Dark Souls with a sprinkling of fighting games. Go buy it. Right now.

author: Abo
review: Monster Hunter: World is another game in the Monster Hunter franchise, whose sole purpose is to hunt monsters.This franchise has always been known to be for select audiences, so this game might not be for everyone, but it sure hell is for me. I've been an avid Monster Hunter fan since 3 Ultimate, and my favorite game in the francise was 4 Ultimate, until this masterpiece came out. I usually buy a monster hunter game, finish HR in a week, and finish G-rank the other week and ditch it, but this game has ruined that cycle.I thought it was going to be your average yearly Monster Hunter game, with many returning monsters and a new flagship monster and that's it, but this game is very different.As most of the monsters in the base game are completely new, not to mention the graphics that clearly outmatched the rest of the MH games.The gameplay has never felt so smooth in all of the other MH games as well, which just adds to all the positive things to say about this game. The only semi-bad thing about this game is the intense grind for decorations, get this game if you like the gameplay!

author: Tahomas
review: I personally love this game, but that's because I enjoy grinding for better weapons and equipment. There’s a decent amount of different weapons to choose from which all play differently than the other weapons (with minor exceptions because I think the bow guns more or less play the same). author: ChaserTech
review: As an avid Monster Hunter fan, this game is by far the best co-op game I've ever played, hands down.I started off playing Monster Hunter Tri back on the Nintendo Wii and eventually became hooked to the game. On top of that, I've also played 3U, 4U, and Mon Hun Generations. Throughout the series, I have loved playing this with friends of mine and World has improved almost every aspect of Monster Hunter as a whole.While flawed, the story is a definite step up compared to the previous games. The cinematic cutscenes of monsters returns in this game (seeing how it was absent from Mon Hun Generations). Not only that but you feel more involved with the game's plot because the surrounding characters acknowledge the player throughout the story. With the addition of voice acting, while kinda subpar, is a nice addition. And even if you don't want actual voice acting, you can change the voices to the old MonHun grunts from previous games.The visual artstyle of World is stunning. I nearly spent hours just walking around the world in order to check out very minor details. Every area that you come across is filled to the brim with life. Creatures such as birds, fish, insects, frogs will all be placed along the landscape as you venture in the world. Also the design of each worldspace has been carefully handcrafted to feel as if it's a actual ecosystem. However aside from that, World doesn't perform very well even on high end PCs. I found myself going through framerate issues a lot. When fighting monsters, ANYTHING that uses any particale effect will drain your fps. Lightning, fire, water, you name it. Not only that but World has insane CPU usage compared to other games as well.To put it in perspective, I have the following:Even with this, my rig barely manages to get 60fps unless I turn off volumetric fog as well as some AA options. I find this to be the biggest issue I've had with this game.Networking issues can be iffy depending on your netcode and the people you connect to. I never had any issues AFTER the patches for MHW were released shortly after launch.BEFORE launch, the netcode was downright terrible and was arguably one of the worst experience I had when it comes to online matchmaking.Now since the patches were released, the connection issues I previously had diminished to a point where they are almost nonexistent. There are still some hiccups here and there but it's leagues better compared to before the patches that were released.If you're a returning veteran to the series, jumping into Monster Hunter will feel a whole lot better in comparison to the previous games. The controls feel very responsive and is easy to get into even for newcomers. All of the 14 previous weapons return in Monster Hunter World, with upgrades that make them even more enjoyable to play with.Monsters (even though there's no G Rank) are pretty difficult endgame and the additional content that gets added with World continues to breathe life into the game. So players have an incentive to continue playing, especially with events and rewards that give the players extra points and armor spheres.Most of the improvements with MH:W comes from the quality of life changes that have been included. Stuff such as:There's a lot more that they have added and changed that I didn't list because there's just too much to talk about.The monsters that return to World have been upgraded with new animations, moves, and AI behavior. And the new monsters that are introduced to the series are all uniquely designed, with their own moveset separate to the previously existing ones. Monsters also engage in turf wars under specific situations which can turn the tide of the battle. And as I previously stated, you are able to use scout flies to track the monster since it replaces the paintball system. However, to track them, you collect footprints, hair, mud, scales, and etc. This can be brought to the research center to level up your progress in studying a specific monster. Doing all of this makes the monster easier to track, enabling you to immediately pinpoint it's location within the map the moment you start a quest.Pros:Improves on previous elements of the series and adds new mechanics/gameplayGreat visuals and stunning world designSolid Co-Op gameplay (post patches)Cons:Performance issues tied to framerate and high cpu-usageGreat co-op experience, especially with friends. I highly recommend buying this game if you have people to play with. If not, playing solo is still really enjoyable.

author: Dr.Heart Stealer
review: Great game ! I recommand it even if the hit boxes are freaking broken just because Capcom wanted the game to be a little bit harder, it's kinda frustrating to be killed when you saw that the attack didn't touched you. Anyway I still love this game, one of my prefered game ever !- Great game- Nice graphics- Multiplayers 4 (friends or randoms)- Many things to do- Quite a long story game + ICEBORN- Battle monsters, take some popcorns- Nice armors/weapons/layered armors- Many events- Many side quests- POOGIE !- And how can you forget you are on PC, MOOOODS ! But beware you can get bet ban if ⠀you use some mods like  -> Yukumo armor or⠀mods like . It's at your own risks.- Multiplayers (randoms diying 24H/24H)- People who leaves middle game or after the first death- Farming the crowns for the achievement (a pain in the ass)- When you are stuck in  tornados - The Barnos who drop you anywhere else on the map but the Camp you wanted to go- People who think they are better than you (start to cry/flame)- Bug that make everyone leave the quests or just you and put's you offline- Big hitboxes- Random bugs- (Some) hard achievements----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Super jeu ! Mais sinon j'adore ce jeu, c'est un de mes pref !- Bon jeu- Jolis graphismes - Multijoueurs 4 (entre amis/avec randoms)- Beaucoup de chose à faire- Histoire assez longue + ICEBORN- Les monstres qui se battent ensemble, prenez du popcorn- Jolies amures/armes/costumes (armures spéciales)- Beaucoup d'events- Beaucoup de quêtes annexes- POOGIE !!! - Comment peux-tu oublier que tu est sur PC, MOOOODS ! Mais attention tu peux te faire ⠀ban si tu utilise des modes pour avoir ⠀comme le skin Yukumo par exemple ou des modes du genre . ⠀A tes risques et périls.- Multijoueurs (les randoms qui crève H24)- Les gens qui quittent au milieu de la quête ou dès la première mort- Les couronnes à farmer pour le succès (un cauchemar)- Quand tu reste bloqué dans les tornades du - Le Barnos qui te drop n'importe où sur la map sauf au camp où tu voulais aller- Les gens qui se croient plus fort que toi (commence à pleurer/flame)- Bug qui fait quitter tout le monde ou juste toi de la quête et qui te met hors ligne- Grandes hitbox- Certains bugs random- (Quelques) succès difficiles

author: First Mate Jake
review: Having played MHW on Xbox One for over 800+ hours I can tell you that this game is definitely worth the pick up on PC. Going into it, I was thinking the controls for KBM were going to be awful but turns out that it actually feels really good. The connection is almost perfect to the servers. I've seen alot of reviews talking about alot of disconnects and laggy connections and I'm yet to encounter any of those things. If you're still on the fence about taking this title for your PC then I'd say go for it, it's a great game and is definitely worth full price though a sale is always nice.

author: ard
review: As a long-time fan of the Monster Hunter series (I've been following since near after the release of MH3 Ultimate in North America), I felt utterly compelled to write a review after my recent experiences with the game.This is more aimed at veteran Monster Hunter fans, but I feel like there is still a lot to take away from this review as a newcomer, so I'll try my best at explaining some stuff.--------AS A MONSTER HUNTER FAN--------    If you're like me and have taken an extreme liking to the atmosphere and general charisma that Monster Hunter titles have historically had, then you  somewhat disappointed. I won't beat around the bush; the game is a little 'grittier' than the previous titles, and that's not necessarily a bad thing. But if you've grown to love the "So tasty!~", your lances that look like sharks, your dual blades that look like a fork and knife, your hammers that look like blimps, then I can tell you that there isn't very much of that. Capcom, from what I can tell, has chosen to opt-out of the wackyness in favor of a more accessible, familiar realistic art direction that honestly is pretty good, but is certainly not what you're used to. Just be warned. , I personally think the new art direction does wonders for the monsters they've chosen to add, in particular. The monsters almost look and behave like they could exist in the real world. in that regard, this game is a HUGE step up from the previous titles. Not to mention the overwhelming attention Capcom has put into this game's environments. Gone are the segmented puzzle-piece-like maps of old. Instead each map is one great big sandbox, each with it's own theme and structural style. The environments truly make this game feel like a  instead of a weird stitched together mess. You have areas like Ancient Forest and Rotten Vale which are visual spectacles (even on the lowest settings) and focused on emphasizing verticality and height, and you have areas like Elder's Recess and Wildspire Waste which are more focused on large open plains and craggly rocky paths that make you really feel like you're there. My point is, each map is easily identifiable, memorable, and very distinct and unique from the rest. Not to mention extremely gorgeous in their own right.My favourite change in the entire series has to be with the environmental interactions that Capcom has introduced in this game. Maps in the previous games were basically just a stage with props; essentially, just a background for where you fight. Monster Hunter: WORLD, however, decided to really bring the idea of "WORLD" home. The environment is so alive, there's so much to do besides killing monsters with big swords. There are lots of clever traps and goodies scattered throughout each and every map, that learning a map is almost like learning the patterns of a monster. Some maps have boulder traps that let you drop a big boulder onto the monster if you position them properly. Others have vine traps that let you pin the monster down for a ton of free hits if you pay attention and play well. Are you a heavy weapon that struggles to do any aerial hits, yet you long to slap monsters with a gigantic sword in the air? There are cleverly placed beetles throughout the maps that you can use your slinger on (basically a multi-purpose arm attatchment every hunter now has) to launch into the air and reposition for some aerial damage.  It's so rewarding and fresh compared to the previous games that, honestly, I can't ever see myself going back to the segmented boring map style. There is nothing like learning the ins and outs of a particular map and just absolutely decimating a monster with that knowledge. It just adds yet another layer of skilled play that is just incredibly rewarding and fun. The next best thing they've done in terms of gameplay is flesh out each weapon's gameplay styles and movesets, and it's honestly the direction I hope they keep going with in the future. If you've played MH before, none of the weapons should feel foreign whatsoever; Their core moveset is more or less identical to the previous iterations. However, it feels as though this time Capcom took inspiration from the Hunter Arts / Styles (a mechanic from a previous Monster Hunter title, Generations / Generations Ultimate that let you perform big flashy finishing moves or change the way a weapon is played) and simply wove those ideas into each weapon. Essentially it feels as though every weapon has a unique "special move." For instance, Long sword now has a counter-attack built into it's moveset (which was previously a "Hunter art"), and a special "Spirit Helm Breaker" special move that changes how you look at your spirit gauge. Bow now has a "Dragon Piercer" special move that changes the way you think about how you position yourself when monsters are vulnerable (On a slight tangent, the ranged weapons have been incredibly streamlined and have never been easier to get into and play). That isn't to say the weapons weren't varied in previous titles, but they quite honestly feel more set apart from each other than they have been in the previous 4 games I've played. And some weapons felt woefully complicated, even as a somewhat veteran player, in the previous games. That is more or less completely gone in this game, and I am incredibly thankful for it.So if you've played a ton of Monster Hunter before and are worried that you'll get bored of the weapons, I wouldn't worry at all. Every weapon feels  to play in this game, so familiar yet new, that I think you can fall in love with your favourite weapon all over again, no matter how many hundreds of hours you've sunk into it.This one's kind of a big deal if you're a Monster Hunter fan like myself. I touched on the monsters a bit earlier in my visual direction section, but I feel like they're such an important topic that they need a paragraph of their own.Monsters set the tone of the game. They make or break the environment. They determine the look / feel of your weapons and armor. They're what you're going to be seeing all the time, seeing as you're a Monster Hunter. So they'd better be good right?I can tell you that the choice of monsters in this game is, while wonderful and interesting, pretty lacking as well. There are just not a lot of monsters in the game compared to previous titles, and I don't feel as though they're quite varied enough in terms of body type and their fantasies. Previous titles had tons of crazy outlandish monsters that were just so unique and cool that you had to fall in love with them. Monsters like Zinogre, a thunder wolf that channels lightning (he literally strikes himself with it from the sky) to charge up and essentially go full super-saiyan, are so fantastic and mystical, which I feel is the kind of thing lacking in this particular title. Granted, their choices of Elder Dragons like Teosta, Kushala Daora, and the brand new Elder Dragon Val Hazaak are more or less in line with the fantasy vibe I was outlining earlier. But those are Elder Dragons. They are  to fit this bill. But even the previous games had some engaging, fantasy-yet-believable regular old monsters: Brachydios with his explosive saliva that he coats his almost boxing glove-like hands to punch and blast you with, Qurupeco with the ability to mimic other monsters' cries and just call on any monster it wants. Those are just a few examples I could name off the top of my head. Bazelgeuse definitely stands out and fills this void though.I'm actually at the character limit surprisingly (I have a lot to say lol) so I'm unable to talk about the rest of the game. I think I hit the key points however. But as a fan of MH overall, I cannot recommend this game enough. Please give it a try, it's absolutely worth your time. Thanks for reading.

author: Virtual_Fleeces
review: Technical issues:Before getting into the actual review, I feel that I would be lying if i said this game is completely done baking, but how many multiplayer games ever are in all honesty.  In my personal experience, I've only ever had two crashes, and those were some time ago. One, when I was fighting a kushala doara in the rain. The compounding weather and special effects resulted in a "graphics device crash." I closed the game, updated my drivers, and have fought numerous Kushala's in the rain since. So it would seem the issue is resolved. My pc isn't exactly a NASA quantum computer, but my 1050 and my intel processor can run world at around 30 frames on lower settings pretty well. I have ambient occlusion on with the rest of my things on low, (because it gives the game more tonal variance) and the game still looks amazing. But anyway, capcom aren't masters at pc game development, and sometimes it shows. Overall not that big of an issue for me though, and should only be getting better from now on. I still would have rather gotten the game premature than have waited any longer for the release.Actual game:I have been hunting monsters for a few games now, one was an actual entry and the other was generations, a kind of passover project to buy time for the development of the collossus of a game that nobody would have even imagined the series could become; Monster Hunter World.    Every single monster hunter game i've played has had seemingly endless playtime value, I managed to get up to 200 hours in 3 ultimate and 500 hours in generations. I'm still mastering world past the 300 hours mark at the moment. A large reason for the replayability of the monster hunters is how many different weapon classes there are; fourteen wildly different weapons to learn, with different playstyles for every one of them. I could go into all the different items you'll use or weapon types and subtypes, but this is not supposed to be a game guide, lol. Just know it's more than you'll probably ever get around to.Environment:Every monster hunter game i've played has featured beautiful environments that functioned as the perfect sandbox to create almost whatever battle you wanted. World has taken this, and quadrupled it. I'm not sure if theres a single other game out there with map design that can rival monster hunter world. Just one expedition into the ancient forest and you will understand, the game feels real. The environments seem organic, yet they're perfect arenas. Openworld isn't quite correct, because you'll really only go someplace when you have a quest there, but it is an option to just go out to whatever area you want, find a random monster wandering around minding his own business, and end its life, or even capture it! Expeditions are not the economical decision, but if you're a savage that enjoys that kind of thing, you'll have a field day with this game. Even I find myself doing them every once in a while.Quests/Storyline: The premise of the game is that you're a settler/researcher who has chosen to come to a newly discovered land in search of adventure. You will find it. The story, while seemingly tedious, is an important tutorial for the actual game, which you'll get around to after clashing twice with an enormous volcano tortoise, (a fight that can be fun, can be tedious, but you don't need to do it too much anyway) and slaying a colossol newborn dragon that could potentially destroy civilization. While not exactly the most engaging thing ever to a veteran like me, the fights were cinematic and intense. The monsters included can be challenging for newcomers. The story is really a tutorial, but don't get me wrong; There is noticable effort put into the plot. Some characters you may like. As a cynicist, i found a lot of them annoying, but still, characters like the chef or the admiral i had to have respect for. I mean, I'm pretty sure the admiral fights monsters bare handed. anyways~Endgame:What you'll be spending most of your time playing if you choose to truly give the game a chance.When you finish the storyline, you'll probably have 1, maybe two equipment sets. That's cute. at 300 hours, I have around 50 sets, about which half i actually use. There are so many different playstyles this game has to offer, and every one of them makes the experience feel new in an undeniable way. You'll make a set for dishing out damage, a set for paralyzing, a set to take damage, a set to recover health, a set to evade, a set to heal your teammates, a set to buff your teammates, sets just for collecting materials, and sets i'm not thinking of, the possibilities seem endless, and most of these you'll have different ones for different weapons, and you'll end up with unique blends of armor skills to suit your playstyle. And when you have it all built, you'll find yourself teaching others while waiting for the ENORMOUS EXPANSION COMING NEXT FALL. That is if you manage to get through all the event quests and new monsters that the game throws at you.Gameplay:disclaimer, if you're playing with default settings, of course you're doing it wrong.  I prefer my camera as far back as possible, of course auto-sheathe off, and some other bs i'm sure you can figure out.Also, there are a number of mods that enhance the game, make navigation easier at home base, change textures around, put light pillars off of items, adjust decoration drop rates to reasonable numbers, reduce the bloom of the scoutflies, things that are just no-brainers. As far as I know, there haven't been any bans to date. I would highly recommend modding.Many people try to play Monster hunter like other games, mistaking the point to be to collect as many pieces of equipment as possible, but this is wrong. If you play it like this, you will never truly experience the satisfaction the series has to offer. Monster hunter is about developing your skills as the player: knowledge, and instinct. If you open your mind and pay attention to the virtual world immersing you, you'll discover that what you're actually playing is not a free for all monster bash, but rather a fast paced turn based game with some obvious and some not so obvious shortcuts. If you refuse to bend, you'll break. But once you learn to dance, the world becomes yours. Monster hunter is first and foremost an action game, but it allows you to come at it in nearly any way you could imagine. It's a game that will test you as the player, rather than just your gear; that diablos tyrannis is no use to you if you get swept up in the monster's rythm and miss all your big moves. Conclusion/TL;DR:If i were to ask of anything from the game, (besides better optimization) it would be more monsters, and the developers are working their butts off to bring us just that. So all we really have the right to do is to say thanks and wait patiently for more, because it's been coming and still is. I'm just grateful that theres no pay to play aspects in the game whatsoever, even as the series has gone to the big leagues, all dlc is truly cosmetic. Yes, I would absolutely recommend the game. If you like an honest challenge that comes in a gorgeous package, theres really not a whole not of competition. Monster hunter is the trailblazer of it's genre, as well as the best in class. Like a slightly more forgiving nature themed darksouls or something. Just have fun! phew, that ♥♥♥♥ was long~

author: Stregaa
review: In terms of QoL changes and graphics, MHW easily blows previous MH games out of the water.  If you've ever enjoyed any games of the monster-hunter genre that this series has basically created, do yourself a favour and play this game.  Even if you haven't, you should still give it a go with the free trial that's available at the time of this review, or if not, just look up videos of gameplay on youtube.  The combat is immensely satisfying, every move is weighted appropriately, and there's no greater satisfaction than just becoming better at the game, beating monsters you couldn't previously, and crafting new gear and weapons.  The online community is great and active as well, which is a HUGE plus.

author: Toleot Rex
review: Actually I never cared so much about this game, because I never played any of Monster Hunter series game before and I read about how grindy it is, and do nothing but hunting a monster. I bought it because my friend never stop telling me how wonderful this game is, and it's on sale (black friday sale). Well I am happy that I was wrong. It's a well crafted game, with a lot attention to details, for example: if you spent some time following a non aggresive monster, you will find that it's doing it's thing just like real animal doing (sleeping, searching some food, even it will take a dump (kinda gross). fought another animal, fleeing when badly hurts and so on). I also read how buggy this game was when it launch on PC, so far I never had a glitch or crash. Several connection problem when playing with my friends, but I guess it's normal because internet connections in this side of the world are just like that (Indonesia). This game is very unique, I can't describe it though, it's not a usual action RPG such as Grim Dawn, it's not a JRPG either. The story is very weak though.

author: Raijin Goto
review: THIS IS MY REVIEW FOR OVERALL MONSTER HUNTER WORLD. I bought this game during VGA 2018 Sales. It's Totally Worth if you're Monster Hunter Vet or liking repetitive grinding hell of Material, Challenging Boss Hunts, this is your type of game. I Played almost 2,200+ hours, this game is my most addicted of all time. From the base World until the Iceborne DLC, for me it's very innovative with motivated to grind with new addition monster plus you will get FREE CONTENT UPDATE in these 2 years until 2020. Hey after this, the collaboration of MONSTER HUNTER MOVIE.  The Base World Pros :- The Day & Night Cycle. - The new feature "Expedition Mode" free roaming with no time limited while not taking any quest at all. - The Co-Op always be priorities in the series with huge changes known as the 'Fire SOS flare' calling all hunters to help your quest to slay the monster. - Using the environmental protection against the monster is a huge step up since it just a barrel wasteland from the previous game. - Most of the tutorial is well translated and the weapons with new adapting skill and learning new curved. - The tracking monster system saved up your time and feels like a hunter you supposed to be but the monster can tracking you back in return and yes that's scary part. - The clashing monster is very well nice in pace to make a time to recovery, usually they are always gang bang you up. - The damage number is good to know and the combat gameplay is satisfactory on monster.   The Base World Cons : - Lacking the Old monster to fight with like Nargacuga, Zinogre, Lagiacrus and Rajang. - There's no sea exploration in the WORLD and that's bummed me up. - The camera sometimes clumsy when it comes tight corridor places. - The story is lacking with no development character at all but the MH is always no go about the story.   The Iceborne DLC Pros :- New frost locale plus new massive locale aftermath of story. - Additional of Clutch Claw in new skill against Monster. - New Move Skill for each 14 weapons.- New Seasonal Decoration, Outfit & Mission Event.- New Free Monster Content is Safi'Jiiva as Siege of Master Rank, Rajang, Furious Rajang, Raging Brachydios, Frostfang Barioth & Alatreon. - Giving New Room & New Music Player for listening while relax.- Resident Evil 2 Remaster Collaboration.- The Final Update Monster Content is Fatalis, the Original MH1 Boss Online.  The Iceborne Cons : - Terrible optimization during first launch. - Lacking deeper customization colors on armor set pieces. - The grind of jewel decoration is still 11:EH. - Lots of problem on hardware plus you need a mod to fix the multi thread cores if stutter.- The camera still clunky and not fix at all but get used to it. Gameplay : 8/10Graphics : 8/10Performance : 7/10Controls : 8/10Story : 2/10Multiplayer / Community : 8.5/10 Sounds & Music : 8/10 For Recommendation about this game? YES! MUST BUY FOR THE FANS OF MONSTER HUNTER... IF YOU REALLY DUNNO TO CHOOSE, PICK THE MASTER EDITION FOR BOTH CONTENT.P.S. I Played since Monster Hunter Freedom Unite from PSP."The Best Action RPG Game" - The Video Game Awards 2018. "The Best Co-operative Game" - Golden Joystick Awards 2018.  "Game of the Year & Excellence Award" - Japan Games Award 2018. "Fan Favorite Role-Playing Game" - Gamers' Choice Awards 2018. "Role-Playing Game of the Year" - 22nd Annual D.I.C.E. Awards 2019. "Game of the Year & Excellence Prize" - Famitsu Awards 2019. "Best Ongoing Game" - Gamescom 2019. "Franchise Role Playing" - NAVGTR Awards 2020. GIT GUD!!!

author: Debs
review: - This game is marvelous and it must be approached on its own terms. -This is my first Monster Hunter game. When I first started playing I liked it, but it didn't feel "smooth". The combat felt weird, the quests seemed a little obvious. I was pretty satisfied, but that was it.Upon reaching High Rank and getting my ass kicked by one or another monster, everything changed. Even the things that didn't change at all.Let me explain.MHW is a game that you'll only fully enjoy if you dive in with intention to learn. It has a formula of its own and it's useless to try and play it as your previous "a little bit similar" game. Weapons are so different you have a whole new gameplay style when you change it; the use of skills and the way to make your build are also very unique; new game mechanics keep on appearing very late in the game, so it takes a while to have that feeling of "I finally get this whole thing".The best way to enjoy Monster Hunter World is letting the game present to you it's way of doing things. It might seem a little bit too much information in the beggining and maybe you're used to a more fast paced, roll-strongattack-roll combat with quick addrenaline rushes. But if you're the kind of peson who likes games to be very refined, with beautiful animation, very elaborate and complete combat system, endless itens and a great learning curve with mastery as your ultimate prize: Monster Hunter World is the right game for you.

review: I was a complete novice to Monster Hunter, and I was ready for as messy an experience as I had been warned about.Instead, I've had some of the most fun and most intense moments I think I've ever had in gaming. I've not had any difficulty and weirdness with the optimization, and the online matchmaking for me has been pretty easy. author: JohnnyOnTheSpot
review: This game is incredible. In fact it is so great that I am writing a review before even finishing the game because I want to recommend it to people as fast as possible. Great graphics, action and a lot of it, a decent story ( I prefer gameplay-driven over story-driven games, all I want from the story is to not ruin the immersion), fun gameplay and a lot of content and variety. I cannot recommend it enough to people. The only bad things I can see in this game are: 1) The crazy, useless girl aka The Handler which is always talking and never helping ( Somewhat like navi from Ocarina Of Time) and 2) Relatively high requirements for high settings 60fps. If you like action ,get this game, it is well-worth the 60$ and if you ever find it on sale, DO NOT EVEN HESITATE GET IT. Also have fun.Update: I am now on 342 hours. I will update the game again on DLC release, however, note that even though the endgame might seem stale, try to change weapon types. It really helps.

author: Nier
review: Materials hunter's world is a fun game for either solo grind or grinding with friends/randoms. Playing while knowing you will always get something good after the grind progress is always a good feeling which the game can provide to you( some games you grind but its not 100% you get something good out of it..). Except when you reach to the stage where you farm decorations, augmentations which are end game stuffs, a real pain in the ass trust me i've been with it for more than 100 hours just to get my charge blade build completed... Grinding for items/materials other than the "end game stuffs" in MHW is always a chill farming process, not as tedious as some other games i play for example: Warframe has its RNGesus beats the heck out of you;  Borderlands 2 requires you to get save editor so you can get a gun with the exact attachments you want unless you wanna spend hundreds of hours to get what you want. I really recommend getting this game, especially when you have your gaming fellows that are also your class mates, you can always hop on to MHW to test out crazy, fun builds with your friends, or speedrunning through the quests as the challenges you set up for you and your mates.

author: arborella
review: This game takes the classic Monster Hunter formula and puts it together with a semi-open world and a lot of quality of life changes. It's definitively worth to try if you like grindy games and hunting monsters. The real game starts after completing the main story which might take more or less time depending on your playstyle. It might not have the amount of monsters of other MH games but it has way richer environment and the monsters also have things to do when you're not around and don't only exist for you to kill them. This game is a good entry point for everyone who's been interested into the MH series but were turned off by the graphics or the "handheld" experience.We need more dooters too! So join and become a Hunting Horn main :^)

author: IDiivil
review: I'm so happy that Monster Hunter: World was finally brought to PC. Pros: - You can finally play the game and see it in full detail (unlike, for example, on the 3DS). In case your rig isn't able to handle the graphics, there's plenty of options that can be changed to give you a smoother experience. Early optimization issuess have also been addressed (for example, lightning weapons killing FPS has been fixed).- Devs have addressed issues in multiplayer matchmaking and the like. It's very easy to team up with people and play now compared to on release.- Controls are significantly better compared to the old days of using the crazy claw hand like you had to on the PSP. I particularly enjoy using my Steam controller for this game, and keyboard/mouse has been improved for ranged weapon players who would prefer not to have to fumble with a joystick.- Some quality of life changes have been added to MHW compared to previous MH titles. You can save loadouts, gathering has been sped up, your inventory now comes with fishing/etc so you don't need to put them into your inventory each time, and you can use the camp during hunts/quests to fix any equipment mistakes or otherwise instead of trekking all the way back to the lobby/town. There's likely more examples of how MHW has improved over prior MH games, but this is a small list of examples off the top of my head.- Console updates are being honored on the PC. We're receiving events, updates, and patches just like everyone else. Because of the devs attention to this port, there's a lot of fun content, though this is a newer pro for me since the addition of Lunastra, Kulve Taroth, etc has changed the game up and allowed me to do different things instead of just grinding the same tempered elder dragons for end game.Things that can be improved, I suppose:- The mix and match of armors to get the best stats leaves a lot to be desired when you look at your crazily dressed characters. Fortunately, MHW is rolling out layered armor settings now to help you hide your hideous appearance. - Sometimes, the grind bothers me based on items' chance to drop, but when has an MH title not had grinding?

author: ChilloutNitro
review: Monster Hunter World is a game where more or less every fight is a boss fight. Each and every single monster is more unique than ever before with several new additions to the roster and plenty of the old favourites. The environments and monster designs are far more distinct and beautiful than ever before due to the transition from portable consoles to the more powerful consoles and the pc. The various armour and weapons also look outstanding.The game retains the cooperative experience the series is known for with fights that may be difficult and long to solo becoming shorter and easier with allies, however this relies on you and them not falling to the foe. While the game is focused on the multiplayer experience, you can still find enjoyment without friends as you can still tackle monsters solo or find people online with similar goals using the sos flare. The game also retains it's focus on the craftable armour and weapons which can allow for a wide variance in playstyles (especially with the new way skills are handled) from sets focused on status effects, pure damage sets, support sets and whatever you own personal style is. This allows people who enjoy minmaxing to get the most out of the game.The gameplay just feels right, it has the movement options, the satisfying combat and and so much more. Movement in a Monster Hunter game has never been as good as in this one: you can evade out of most moves, healing while on the move and the grapple can get you around some areas somewhat quicker. When it comes to the combat, each of the 14 weapons feel satisfying use with each hit carrying the weight you would expect. Furthermore there is basically a weapon type for everyone with each one being unique from one another. Returning from Monster Hunter 4 onward is mounting monsters from air attacks which can lead to powerful beat downs once a monster is knocked down. Finally, When it comes to combat, the game is fair and rewarding (with some exceptions). When you miss or get greedy and get hit, it is your fault rather than an unfair quirk or attack. On the flip side when you cause a monster to flinch before it's attack or knock it down, you are rewarded for your hard work with an opportunity to let loose your most powerful attacks into a monster which becomes more satisfying with a team coming together to pummel it. My only complaints when it comes to the gameplay are that the grapple is criminally under used and the odd actually unfair moves some of the far later monsters have.Simply put, Monster Hunter World is an amazing game and a great follow up from the previous games. The game is the most accessible yet without compromising the core gameplay of the series. There are many quality of life improvements that really help. The graphics are gorgeous. The cooperative play is satisfying and rewarding.If you don't like longer fights in games against sort of damage sponge enemies then this game may not be for you. Also if you came to a monster hunter game expecting a story then you may be a bit lost, it exists and is better than the plot of most of the games in the series but it's not majorly impactful. Otherwise I strongly recommend giving the game a shot as it is a rewarding experience with many appealing aspects.I give it a 'Rocket Powered Greatsword/10'.

author: Lyresia
review: Being someone who started on generations on the 3DS and was hoping for the PC port to do me justice, I can say I am pleased with how it handles. It's responsive and I love the environments that are in this game. My hours on this game are short, but rest assured this game is beautiful as well as fun. Find friends. Start a community. It's out there in this game.

author: Raiju
review: For those who enjoyed the classic Monster Hunter, Monster Hunter World is a step backwards in terms of content and difficultly. However for those new to the series, it's a really good place to start getting into the game. I've played since the original Monster Hunter on the PS2 and still had a really good time despite my concerns.World introduces a ton of quality of life features that really make the game much easier to play. Things which stand out are definetly the radial menu, pod system, and decorations. I do somewhat miss the old system of skills where it was much less fire and forget and had much greater capability for customization. Due to the homogenization most people wear the same piece of armor for most sets which get's pretty old real quick. There's a lot of power creep happening too with the new updates.Onto the gameplay. The weapons are all back with some new toys. However the lack of variety in play styles seems to be a pretty big issue. Previously in older MH games it was pretty common for each weapon to have about 3 different play styles. Most weapons in this game really have one optimal way to be played. 90% of them involve slapping on healing augment rocksteady and healing to just tank through the monster. Since monsters have much less health now the kills times are much shorter and it's pretty simple to just outtank them. Weapons like SnS, CB, and Bow definetly seem much more flow diagram heavy than the rest. However DS are now fun as hell and GL, Lance, Hammer, and GS have had much more flavor added to them. Mantles are good but probably too strong.Some of my favorite new additions to the series are Bazelgeus and Vaal Hazaak while certain old monster have had some new life breathed into them. I know people generally ahte Bazel but I kinda appreciate the chaos he brings which feels more reminiscent of the old series. Vaal Hazak could probably be much faster and have a less annoying fog but is interesting flavorwise and pretty cool designwise. Monsters do tend to target each other more now rather than focusing on you which brings the annoyance factor down by a lot. With the recent Kulve Taroth update, I feel like Capcom has finally figured out how to do siege monsters compared to the jhen and lao of past games. At least if you try to 1 phase it. Gogmazios is still probably the most difficult/fun to do though. The first time I 1 phased KT was probably one of the highlights of playing mhw. Playing online solo is pretty disappointing as the HP is scaled way too low. As usual 2 person MH is the max difficulty/enjoyment while 4 person is just a chain disable fiesta. Monsters are also much slower and signature moves like supernova are just laughable compared to before.Overall although Generations is the game with much more content and more replayability I'm still enjoying MHW a lot and hope that they will announce an expansion soon as the lack of content is the biggest problem at the moment. I will definetly be playing as long as they keep having updates for it but considering I've been here for so long I'm probably just a sucker for the series.

author: Seraphii (real)
review: Monster Hunter World is the most accessible and fun MH game ever! I have played a few others in the past, but the jump to consoles could not have been better executed. The monsters are strong, sometimes unfair, but persevere and you will come out on top. There is basically an endless amount of content : From all the different weapons to master, to the different combinations of armor, there truely is nothing to dislike about this game!10/10 would hunt monsters again

author: Xpray
review: In short: Easy to learn, hard to master action game with light RPG elements, beautiful graphics, superb monsters design and surprisingly enjoyable grinding that will keep you busy for a long time.Performance-wise, the game has been patched a few times after its release and now it's very stable in its current state.

author: EddyOZ
review: MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD is the best Action RPG I've playing constantly since the PC release in August 2018 and keep playing until the Iceborne expansion PC release in Jan 2020, the expansion was even better, I've had a fantastic experience that I've never experienced before. If you never played any Monster Hunter game and you're interested, start with this one, and DON'T forget the expansion, it's absolutely amazing.

author: r4k
review: Good fun, both solo and with friends.Pros:+ 14 weapon types, each with different movesets and numerous subtypes - really allows you to customize way you fight+ tons of gear with different perks - great for people who love working on their characters and builds+ different types of quests (hunting, capturing, arena, timed events and special events)+ lots of background humor and puns+ CATS - have I already mention that half of this world is sentient cats using tools?Cons:- random grind. Endgame stuff depends on RNG so you have to grind hard to get itIn short: go buy it and start hunting. Now!

author: Barc
review: This is one of my favourite games or the year but it isn't perfect, the game has an older style multiplayer joining system seen more often years ago, also has the biggest grind in any game that i have played. The game itself though is enjoyable enough you pit yourself against a variation of monsters with your weapon of choice to slice & dice your way through the game making more powerful weapons & armour. This is my first entry into the series.Capcom are finally adding the content that the consoles have had for months & are slowing catching up so in the coming months new content will be released at the same time.  If you like the idea of hunting monsters & joining the grind, then give this game ago.

author: Thai Fighter
review: Great game that has stood the test of time. Since its first game on the Playstation to the current iteration, Monster Hunter's gameplay has improved to what it is now: A challenging game for both solo and group play, yet easy enough for beginners to join in. Introduction of the item wheel was a game changer, allowing up to 32 shortcuts to items, crafting, emotes, etc for quick access in the heat of a hunt. With 14 different weapons to choose from, each with their own mechanics, the game feels refreshed whenever I learn a different weapon.

author: Vauche
review: Monster Hunter: World is THE game among games. Every weapon, every piece of armour, every attack, every monster, and every environment are seeped into the core of this game. Your foresight, reflexes, and choices are the sum of your game, and min/maxing that sum to refine how you lay waste to monsters over the course of thousands of hunts will be your journey. Monster Hunter isn't just a game, it's the way of gaming.

author: ShadowGeckoX
review: I don't pre-order often but something about this game caught my eye and it did not disappoint. The game is very well optimized, great graphics, tons of content added on a regular basis. Even with rarely random connection issues, I like the fact that the mission is not canceled and I still get a chance to complete it solo. Huge assortment of weapons and armor lets you play anyway you want and specially great for collectors. Cool crossover events add to an already fun and challenging game.

author: PewPew
review: If you're a fan of MH series, skip this and buy it already :))TL;DR: 8/10 for me. First game I've bought on pre-order and don't regret it.** Scaling **Good (+) Meh(~) Bad (-)Gameplay+ Same as all MH series, you hunt, you run, but above all, you craft. + Unli-Grind+ Occassional events with event items; even shops go on sale+ Controls are streamlined. The addition of Radial Menu (or KB Shortcuts) is sleek. You don't have to panic run and search for pots. + Camera view has been a pain since PSP days on Portable 2nd G, MH3, etc since 1 analog is only present. Using a controller with 2 analogs now or a mouse for camera movement is heaveeeeeen. + Addition of side quests like bounties (weekly, etc) makes it unexhaustive.+ Increasing the cultivation slot to three was very nice. I think it was only one or two before on previous installments. + Some noob walls ahead. Game is very easy to learn but very hard to master. Utmost patience is very needed+ More plus if you play with friends! Panic, shouting, and bashing over discord!- Consecutive Item usage and fast switching of controls (e.g. sheathing a weapon then using an item) is quite slow. You have to wait first some milli sec/s before you can do the succeeding desired actionAudio & Visuals+ JP Audio plus Eng SUB, perfection.+ Different sets of audio setting. I love the more realistice preset (wider) but it kind of lowers the sound output drastically. Separation is quite nice though especially on a wider soundstaged headphones.- Voice is not synced with the animation. It's like someone's chewing with open mouth then you hear some words.~ Ultrawide is supported via Mod~ Visuals are good. We've seen better, admit it. And Capcom too is aware of this. Just that the framework chosen is already old. Images are compressed and colors are slightly washed out (can be fixed using some Mod). But on the bright side, some scenes are just breathaking (Hi Credits).+ Effects are awesome. Lightning and flare effects are the bomb. Fighting elder drags have never been more awesome. Sometimes you can just lie down and watch Teostra do its thang; kill your FPS. Optimization- Bad. Upon bumping into some threads, could see that one issue is the CPU Utilization (which can be fixed by K's mod) and probably the framework itself. At somepoint, you'll just hit 60FPS-ish from 100 on some scenes (1080Ti @ 1440p, Max, volume rendering and the other ??? setting is off)+ On the bright side, community is there to help. Some issues can be fixed. Some are not. But, it is very playable even on an entry level gaming setups.Story ~ Story is a bit short but that story is just a tutorial to get you on-boarded on the game. ~ around 50 hours of game time to complete the main story lineSupport+ MHW:PC was off on a rough start. But devs have been patching things every now and then. Monthly? Bi-monthly? Enough to feel that they really do care about its players and wanted them to stay immersed. Initial launch, you can't even play multiplayer properly because of the DC issue. But it was addressed as needed. And they have been constantly picking up feedbacks from the community to continuously improve performance, controls (like the mouse acceleration, key binding shortcuts, etc). They are no superheroes like CD Projekt Red. Still, they try to do it right.+ Community is starting a bit ok given that it just got released recently. Good mods (prettier handler, eyes, HD texture which is a fix on the compressed GFX, etc). Just do hope that Capcom won't ban it.

author: Lemongrrass ™
review: Loving this game. It doesn't feel as grindy as I thought it would. I can have hours of fun on my own, but when playing with friends it gets even better. Chillhunting, tryharding elder dragons, crafting all weapons, name it. This game keeps me busy and I'm loving it !

author: Leico
review: You like to see numbers showing up everytime you hit something?You like farming and grinding but you don't want it to be repetitive?You like SMASHING THE HEAD OF THAT GIANT-ASS DRAGON just to get his weapon and armor set?Then this game is for you.Seriously though, this is my first Monster Hunter game and i find it is fantastic, played alone or with friends, it still keeps his fun very tight, making it NOT frustrating when playing with other players you don't know, luckily the community just wants to help eachother, which makes this game even better.Grinding and farming is not boring, yes, due to the variety of monsters, and weapons, and armor, and companion gadgets, weapons and armor, you will never get bored, wether you like to use B.F. swords or daggers, or maybe you are a ranged kind of guy, with ballistas, bows and fricking sniper rifles, so cool.This is not a very very easy game, but still (unlike the others Monster Hunter it seems) it gives you most of the information you need to play at full potential, which you can expand even further by consulting wikis and youtube videos, the game gives you the choice of playing it very easy (with very easy and effective weapons) or a little harder, with weapons that wield various types of ammo maybe.Enviroment is gorgeous, it's not an open world game, but instead, there are very big levels, both horizontally and vertically expanded, that don't have any "dead space" inbetween, there's always something to find, to farm or to slay in every corner of the map.Performance is not great, but i have a 4-year old selfmade PC and it still goes decently (AMD FX-8320 and R9 270X, 8GB RAM) at 50-60 FPS with most settings on low, it seems that this is the worst aspect of the game, but i don't agree, it could have gone WAAAY worse.TL;DR: slay monsters, get weapon, slay bigger monster, repeat, spin like a beyblade with a giant hammer on a monster's face. 10/10

author: Jackie-bot
review: ever want to take an oversized sword and stab a dinosaur with it? ever want to take a bow, a bunch of cannons and a massive spike and take on a living mountain? ever want to wear clothing made from the things you have killed?This game will allow you to do all of the above things. the story like all monster hunter games is little more than big thing is scary, stab till it dies so we can "research" it but the gameplay and armour and weapon systems and classes are well thought out, fun and powerful (all hail the bow master-race, not biased at all) and have enough depth to take a decent amount of time to get good at and a long time to master perfect dodging of moves and learning each monsters attack habits.the environment in this game is detailed and impressive, if you dont use the map you can easily get lost in the forested area until you have every path memorised ( i still rely on the games guidance mechanics to get around) and i have spent a not insignificant time exploring each one and seeing the sights each area has to offer.all in all a very good use of your money and can potentionally give hundreds and hundreds of hours of fun

author: Grotix
review: I'm a sucker for Monster Hunter games, so take this with a grain of salt.The introduction of seamless maps with no loading screens is a nice touch. All of the weapons are fun and feel unique, and despite individual hunts only taking 5-10 minutes once you get into the swing of the game, I find myself easily spending hours and hours on end playing because "just playing one more won't take me very long!"Before you buy it, it's worth looking online at some gameplay from the weapons so you can see whether or not the actual combat looks entertaining to you. If the combat isn't that fun, then this probably isn't for you. The story doesn't have a ton of depth. This isn't a game where you explore much. There are some fun odds and ends you can do in your downtime like hunt for pets and fish, but this is Monster Hunter. You hunt monsters. If that's not your thing, then this probably won't be very fun.

author: Savergn
review: First off, this game definitely deserves a better ratings review.Early on, the game had it's fair share of issues, but Capcom did a good job of fixing most of it. Could it be better? Of course, but we have to draw a line somewhere, and overall I'm just happy that this game is even available on PC.I think the thing I enjoy most about this game is the playstyle reminds me of good MMO games, but it can be played all Singleplayer, or Multiplayer or with friends.The core gameplay loop is: Find new monster, hunt said monster, harvest monster for it's parts to make yourself stronger, rinse and repeat. Sounds dull in writing, but it is very good. MHW does it better than other games with a similar model, and the continued free updates are a cherry on top.I've heard from Monster Hunter veterans the game has been.. altered, to appeal to a wider audience. I can't speak to the truth of that, as this is my first real Monster Hunter game that I've played for more than a couple of hours. So maybe, this game is for a more casual audience, but that's fine, because the changes made me stick with it, compared to previous MH games.The game is worth it at full price. I was hesitant at first because I don't buy many full-priced games, but it's more than a port. They have made PC specific improvements, and it will get most of the content updates that console players have already got, for free. I much prefer the pay once + optional purchases to support ongoing updates, over Game + DLC + DLC for DLC + Microtransactions that some games use right now.Buy the game, play it with friends, have a good time. Even if you stop playing eventually, the new events + monsters that show up for free will keep you coming back on occasion.

Best played with friends, up to 3 people.Game still getting updated with new events and quest every now and then.A little grind, but worth it when you realized how stronger you've gotten.Recommended!

author: NotNelkey
review: Late review, wanted to do this for a while so decided to still write it!MH3Ultimate was the first Monster Hunter game I played and I instantly fell in love with it and having over 500+ hours in I still can't let go of this beauty. Finaly being able to defeat the Zinogre felt like a life time achievement, grinding dozens of ours to get that one special item you need to finish a armour set or make that awesome looking badass hammer to crush more skulls with or teaming up with other players to hunt the most dangerous monsters out there! It still gives me a rush everytime I start up the game!Unfortunately, I can't say the same about Monster Hunter: World. Don't get me wrong, it's a good game but doesn't give me the same feeling as the previous games. After being hyped up for it and reading very good reviews I decided to pre-order the game earlier this year. I played it non-stop and was completely addicted once more and had an amazing experience playing. Still, I felt like something was missing.After some intense monster fights I reached the endgame, time to fight the elder dragons! Nergigante is one the best monsters ever created! It doesn't give you a chance to rest at all and after finaly killing it I felt relieved and drained from the fight. The other elder dragons also have a amazing fight but here does come my one of multiple problems with the game. Xeno'jiiva. Yes, the last elder dragon in the main story. After seeing its cutscene I was so hyped up for the battle...! But then the battle starts and it becomes a very boring and straight forward battle with the monster. Easy to avoid, does a lot of the same attacks in a row and overall doesn't do anything special. It looks majestic though being the biggest monster in the main story if not the enitre game! The music for the fight is also very very very good and it adds a nice feeling to the fight. Of course, I don't have anything bad to say about his armour, its the most beautiful armour in the game.After this brief introduction, let's sum up the Pros and other Cons!Pros:* The game looks stunning! Unfortunately my PC isn't able to run the game on maximum settings so I had to push it down to medium/low. Even on these settings the game looks pretty neat! And since the game seems to be a heavy thing to run, thats good new for the people who have budget PCs!* The combat in this game is amazing. Very smooth movements, amazing weapon combos. Honestly, I don't have any complains about it* Sherlock, of course the monsters are great. It's a Monster Hunter game! Once again, CAPCOM did an amazing job on the design of them! My personal favorite design is in fact the Xeno'jiiva eventho the battle sucks, it gets saved by the design of the majestic beast!* The multiple areas are pretty fricking good! Again, nothing bad to say about the design at all! Ancient Forest can be a maze in the beginning but after a few hunts you can locate yourself pretty nicely through the forest.* I will seperate the Weapon and Armour designs in this review. The differents armour sets looks absolutely beautiful. You can instantly recognize what armour set belongs to what monster. Well done CAPCOM once again.* I really loved building multiple builds from multiple monster armour pieces. After being able to get a 95% crit on weak parts I was satisfied with my build! That's not my only build of course, I have multiple builds in my box and all of them are endgame viable! Figuring out if I need to sure Alpha or a Beta piece pulled me in more!* The crafting is amazing as always. Nothing to add, just awesome!* The multiplayer is great. Starting a hunt, sending out an SOS flare and people start joining instantly! I've had a few connection issues in the first week of release but never had any problems with it after. Good job once again CAPCOM!Cons:* Oof... oof... oof... Weapon Designs... Yea, that doesn't sound good does it? Well, it shound't sound good. I was very disappointed with the designs. Many of them looks the exact same for the majority of the game. They finally change when you reach the second to last or last rarity of a path. This is something the previous MH games did right. I hope they will add more variety to the next games.* The monster may look amazing but there aren't a lot of monsters. Only having 31 large monsters on release wasn't enough. Of course they added the beloved Deviljho and are about to add more to the game it, still the game felt over very fast because of this.* The game looks awesome but game performance is something else. It's not very good all of the time. The Kushala Daora fight is suck a fricking pain in the ass when it drops all of his tornados and the FPS goes to ♥♥♥♥. This frustratred me a lot. Also having some frame drops here and there were annoying sometimes.* To me, the game is to easy. I am used to this hardcore experience, needing to bring everything with me on hunts, even whetstones! MHWorld just gives them to you and they can't run out! No need to bring pickaxes, no need to bring nets to catch bugs. These kind of features took away the hardcore experience for me.* MONSTER HUNTER: WORLD is a good game. Not flawless but it's a good PC entry for the series! If you are looking to get into the series, MH World is a good choice but it doens't reflect entirely what the series is about. Is it worth to buy the game at full price? For me it for sure was! If you are not sure, wait for a discount and buy it! This was my first review on a game on Steam. Hopefully it helped you to with your decision to buy the game or not.

author: Dogbowl
review: In Monster Hunter: World, you smack giant monsters over the head with giant weapons until they stop moving. Then you carve up their corpses to make better armor and weapons to make them stop moving faster. And it's amazingly fun. I've been with this series since Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate and a PC release is what I had always dreamed for.Positive aspects (in my opinion):- The graphics are absolutely gorgeous. It takes a pretty hefty rig to get a stable 60 fps, but it's worth it.- There are 14 different weapon archetypes to choose from. These include 3 ranged and 11 melee options. Each weapon type is greatly varied from the last, so looking a tutorial for the type you want to use, or at least practicing with it is a must. Once you learn how to use a weapon, it becomes amazingly fun and satisfying to use.- Armors give different skills, so building up an effective set is important. Skills can be mixed and matched to find a set that is effective and fun, but also one that looks good.- The monsters (both new and old) are fun to fight. Learning their attacks and openings is required to be effective in killing them, but once you do, it's very satisfying to fight them.- You can hunt with friends or randoms via SOS flare. Connection issues occur on occasion but they have been mostly fixed at the time of writing.- Worth a mention, you can fish and capture pets to place in your personal quarters. There's a round fluffy bird and it's adorable.Negative aspects (in my opinion):- Previous games had much more monster variety than World. More monsters are being added to this game, but the variety still doesn't come close to that of previous games.- The weapons for any given archetype all look very similar. They basically used a couple different base models and put different monster parts on them to differentiate them. This is a purely aesthetic thing, but again, previous games had much more variety in this department.TL:DR; most of the negatives of this game stem from lack of variety. But that issue is mitigated by how immensely fun it is to just beat up the monsters.

author: airo
review: A very fun Monster Hunter experience. I see a lot of people complaining about the servers, but I never had a problem and I preordered the game. (Yes, I have little to no hours, but all the hours I played - I enjoyed.)Would recommend if you are up for grinding experience and smacking some monsters up.

author: Henry
review: It did had some serious issues when it released at steam however it has been fixed, the game has constant free updates and events with new quests and armor and the community is overall really friendly.For veterans of the serie while MH:W may not be the most content rich in the series, the way the monsters act and attack makes them feel a lot more real and natural to the world, every monster is insanely detailed and some even interact with each other instead of just focusing on you, it completely make up for the fact that there aren't as many of them.Tl;dr: Should you buy Monster hunter: world?If you want to hunt some big dragons then hell yes!

author: blindSPOT
review: I cannot recommend this game enough. If you are looking for a game to grind with friends, then you have come to the right place. Get together with three other friends to form a group for a HUNT! Some people say it gets old fast after you reach end-game since the principle of this game is endless grinding on the same monsters. If that is the case, then it is time to switch it up to a new weapon type. Do not stay with one weapon forever because you will get tired of it after 100 hours plus. I will stay away from this game if you hate grinding or timesink type games.

author: JessBasic
review: With a bad launch on the PC version, Monster Hunter World is still a game I would come back to. With every patch they are fixing and bringing in new/old content in to the PC version of the game which gives players more things to do (plus the updates are free). It will also give players a reason to come back to Monster Hunter World every once in awhile for those new/old monster or event kind of updates that the devs have been putting out for the game. Hopefully devs will continue to support this game and bring newer/older content to the PC version but we will just have to wait and see. With all that in mind I'd still recommend this game to anyone looking for a monster hunting co-op experience but with 60 dollar price tag I'd recommend you get the game on sale, it is bound to be on some steam sales in the future.

author: Flipper
review: This is my first Monster Hunter game and it was quite the experience ++ Swinging giant phallic weapons made out of severed monster parts+  Slow paced meaty combat, with each creature feeling like a big boss+  Creative character/equipment design. You can tell the designers had a good supply of     shrooms+  Weird sense of humor throughout. Cats!+  Decent graphical fidelity on max without any hiccups (GTX 1080)-- Connectivity issues, I solo´d 75 % of the game since it would keep disconnecting when     playing with friends. Somewhat repaired with recent patches, though it´s still not great. I     just want to easily connect with others and hack things to fine paste-  A bit inaccessible to newcomers, had to search the web to understand some things-  Inconsistent camera controls/angles. Can screw you over in a bad way-  Playing with a controller, the controls feels a bit clunky especially switching from    running/drawing weapon-  The late game becomes a grind fest to get the rare drops for the best weaponry/armor. Be     prepared to fight the same monster 10 timesAll in all I found great enjoyment in this game despite these flaws. If you are willing to spend time to learn the quirks, you will probably enjoy it too! 7/10 paws
