author: BurgerKingBurgerDeluxe
review: Monster Hunter World is a fantastic addition to the franchise. It has the ability to be the best game in the franchise, but there's just one problem... There's nothing to hunt. There's no G-Rank. The game has performance issues.   If they were to fix this problem, Monster Hunter World would be by far, the most fun game in the series. Until then, the game is lacking, severely. If you are a veteran hunter I wouldn't recommend this game for the lack of content, but as for you newcomers, this would be a great game to start with on your Monster Hunter adventure!

author: Barbarossa
review: With one word: Phenomenal.My first-ever Monster Hunter Experience since I don't play console. Was quite upset that we had to wait 6+ months for its release on PC. However, after playing it for more than 3-4 weeks now, I can say it's Well-worth the wait and the money. What I appreciated the most, is the depth of detail and complexity in this game. It tells you a lot during tutorials but there is much more that you can to discover by observing the environment. The beautiful thing is, you are not forced discover everything but when/if you do, it feels amazing. Plus, it helps you a lot.From zones to monsters to 14 different weapons, you can clearly see many things are well-thought in this game. Not to mention the fact that each weapon offers unique and different gameplay experience. (Unlike 90% of the games I've played). They feel that unique and deep. I'm not used to saying so many positive things about a game. I don't know, maybe it hits all the right spots for my taste. Maybe you won't like this game as much as I did. Regardless, at the very least, definitely worth a try in my opinion. Especially nowadays that many people make games not out of passion but for money. (Recent Diablo Immortal Tragedy being one of the prime examples). This game is definitely on the side of the passion, which I deeply respect.

author: SotiCoto
review: It is pretty good for a short while...  but it needs more content... desperately.  Monster Hunter Generations Ultimate on the Switch just comes across as a much better game because it has VASTLY more content. I hope G Rank is something they either patch in or sell as a DLC upgrade later.  The thought of having to start over with a whole new game file does not fill me with confidence.

author: HotSoup
review: It is a really good game and great entry point to the monster Hunter series. What was once a niche game that appealed to people with a penchant for spreadsheets comes to PC and you don't necessarily have to use a spreadsheet sheet anymore. I'm very much looking forward to seeing what new features and content will be added. I hope to see this game become a living and thriving community.

That's okay for me, doesn't bother me much.Mouse/KB control and camera view is good, love it. It's a grind-repeat game, so don't expect much! But i love it!

author: yourHighneszs
review: Don’t judge the game by its reviews! Well not this one in particular. The game had a rough launch and most of those who downvoted it are those complaining on the online connectivity issues back at launch. And that was a lot because it lasted for a long while. The game itself is great, if your not playing on a potato, and the online issues are fixed now. Heard there was some keyboard issues too but I play with a controller so i don’t know. K back to the review. This is my first game in the franchise. I’m really more into rpg action games that has great stories but this one’s actual combat caught my eye. It’s story was meh...whatever. What motivated me to continue the game was fighting new monsters. And the grind. It is a time consuming game, I play it when I have spare time (or when I’m supposed to be doing other things <.<) The combat definitely has a different feel than most games and you have to experience it to know that feeling. Probably the most satisfying combat I’ve played... ever.... Definitely going to play in the upcoming events and looking forward to their next game in pc!

author: StickyStallion
review: I really want to love this game, It has so much going for it.  But the progression system in this game sucks.  In the old games you used to have to level up your hunter rank to unlock new things so it gave you goals and objectives to achieve.  In this, half the armors in this game you just skip over since you progress so fast basically making them worthless.  Then on top of it there really is no point in getting better armor since the difficulty of the game is sub par.  So basically you get this better armor for nothing since there is no end game objectives/goals.  You can also restock your items in camp just making the game to easy.

author: tvp2000
review: I will be honest, this game has a few glitches, the tutorial is not very useful, and you are basically shoved in blind. The reason I love this game is because it understands that being successful at this game is built through experience. You start Monster Hunter World doing low rank quests that give new players time to learn about the world and quests that give you direction if you do not know what to do next. People are also complaiing about the PC port, I have not run into any major issues personally, and if you are like me and don't play a lot, the development is probably going to move faster than you progress through the game. If you are going to get this game, expect to have to invest some time before it really feels right.

author: ✪ Mahiru NGANTRI TURNEY
review: Monster Hunter: World is a third-person action game about dominating the food chain and looking good doing it. It's renowned for its endgame grind, where you go on ever more complex and challenging hunts across diverse, tangled open worlds in search of rare items needed to craft an armor set that’ll no doubt crown you the min-max champion of the world. But Monster Hunter’s essence and greatest strength are its tense, desperate, and tragic fights with beautiful beasts that can go on for the better part of an hour.It is also about the gleeful colonization 'new' lands and the slaughter of native species. Monster Hunter is a grotesque fantasy, but if you can stomach the merciless, repeated slaughter of god's beautiful dragon children, you'll find an excellent, endless action game that tests reflex and intellect in equal measure.Unlike the story, murdering World's dozens of intricately designed monsters has a point. There’s no leveling up and skill point allocation in Monster Hunter, so crafting armor and weapons is the only way to permanently buff your stats. Gear crafted from monsters reflects their strengths and weaknesses, so if you’re having trouble with a thick-skinned fire type, you’d best go take down the thicker, hotter Ratholos for fire-resistant armor, and maybe seek out a poisonous monster for a weapon that does a bit more damage over time. Clear affinities between behavior, aesthetic, and the hard numbers that govern monster stats make deciding which monster to hunt next and which gear you’ll need to ruin them relatively easy to determine, though a few endgame fights might require some careful menu digging.All 30-something monsters (with more on the way via free updates) have distinct personalities brought to life through realistic animation, observable behaviors, and detailed models. My favorite, the Paolumu, is a fuzzy pink and white bat creature that balloons like a blowfish when threatened. The Kulu-Ya-Ku is a big dodo bird that uses big rocks as its first line of defense. The Anjanath, a fire-breathing, chicken-winged T-Rex, would be the final boss in most games. Hitting one until it stops moving for the first time is an immense, sad accomplishment. And then a Rathian plunges from the sky and captures an Anjanath in its claws, flailing your former final boss monster around like a ragged teddy bear. Somehow, they get bigger yet, with creatures that resemble fallen, very grumpy gods.  Gods or dodos, hunts work the same throughout the entire game. You ‘post’ a quest in Astera, the busy hub area, eat a quick meal to buff your stats, and if you’re playing with friends, you and up to three others embark to a particular biome. From there, you’ll wander an intricate environment in search of your monster. Scoutflies, sentient compass bugs, will point you to nearby crafting materials and monster tracks, always nudging you towards an inevitable fight. Problem is, biomes are populated with monsters besides your target, and they’ll probably interrupt your fight. Letting them duke it out while you hide can work in your favor, sure, but staying out of the way isn’t easy. Environmental hazards complicate hunts further. Do you try to lure an Anjanath beneath a massive boulder strung up by vines above? Loosing it with your slingshot could flatten you too.Monsters have no visible health bar, but they’ll appear tired and increasingly scarred the weaker they get. At certain intervals, they’ll make a break for it and try to find a place to sleep or prey of their own to eat in order to build HP and stamina, turning hunts into frenzied chases. Knowing your environment, where the monster might be headed, and the fastest way to get there only comes with experience. That’s OK because World’s combat is strongest when it feels like a struggle. Swings with the greatsword take literal seconds of animation, the hammer requires getting too close for comfort, and even the mobile ranged weapons feel like unwieldy, clunky machines. I’m partial to the switch axe, a weapon that stores elemental damage in axe form and releases it in explosive bursts after transforming into a glowing sword the size of a teenager.It still looks tiny to a burrowing sand wyvern or electric flying squirrel lizard. Big sword or not, you can and will get poisoned, paralyzed, burned, stunlocked, put to sleep and become subject to every attack your quarry can muster while you're helpless. Swings and shots from your friends can interrupt your own, and your every attempt to exhaust your movement abilities will also exhaust your character. For example, if you jump while sprinting to dodge an attack, your character will always leap forward and fall flat on their face. Remember: this is not your house, and you are very small. Combat isn’t fun in the way it is in Dark Souls or Devil May Cry, which reward constant, fluid combos and perfect timing, but it is always tense, and often hilarious. And when you can walk the line and land a rare, righteous combo directly on a Rathain's scaly dome, the feeling is euphoric.But so much gets in the way of that crunchy feedback loop. If the intent of crafting and gear management (the usual downtime activity between hunts) is to make you feel as if you've cultivated food, curated your looks, and performed the proper research required to take down whatever big boy is next on the list, then abstract menu interactions aren’t the most inventive or satisfying way to go about it. When the hunting portion of Monster Hunter is so vividly rendered by massive, believable creatures and lush environments, digging through menus to turn herbs into potions and potions into mega potions lacks the same ceremony. It's fine, in the end, because the menu interactions are streamlined enough that they're not impossible to parse and rarely tedious. Still, for as busy and complex as the crafting and item management appears, it’s painless in practice, simplifying the series’ formerly complex systems to such a degree that they don't even resemble the systems they're simplifying. Why not reinvent them at this point? Monster Hunter: World also opens by bashing you over the head with text-heavy tutorials. You'll learn how to craft dozens of items immediately, most of which won't matter until a dozen hours in. Nearly every character in the Astora hub spews text about economies and changing item types, placing the fantasy of preparation on equal footing with filing taxes. Vital tips are glossed over too, like how you can use piercing pods to prevent monsters from running away, or how to craft some of the most essential items. I appreciate withholding information from the perspective of a role-playing hunter, where only battle-hardened vets will have obtained the most arcane knowledge. But the bulk of World's inner workings are only accessible through wikis and hearsay, the assumption being that you'll figure some stuff out on your own, or collapse and turn to Google.In the early hours, all you need to know is how to swing and dodge. It’s only when high rank missions are unlocked that you’ll need to do some research.  Source: PC Gamer

author: Veritasx626
review: As a huge fan of the series I'm glad to see the series finally come to mainstream consoles in full glory.Yes this game is easier than previous titles and has less monsters but the flip side being that you have so much more control over combat. I repurchased the game on pc after owning it on ps4 since launch, while not being able to skip the cutscenes can be a little bit of a slog the game doesnt really start until after you complete the story either way and youre farming monsters. Every weapon is viable and well balanced with different weapons spiking for damage at different points or allowing for more sustained damage.To those complaining about poor optimization, I think its time to upgrade for you fellas. I'm running the game on a 3rd gen i5 8 gigs of ddr3 ram and a 1060 3gb version and the game runs flawlessly.I highly suggest using a controller, the keyboard and mouse controls arent bad but the controller controls have everything you need with ease of access. If youre a fan of the series or someone looking to try something new I suggest taking the dive and picking this up you wont regret it. Happy hunting!

author: Santiago
review: That’s the predominant loop of gameplay in ’s . Take down the big, bad monster and harvest every part. Use that to craft better gear, kill a stronger creature and harvest better stuff, et cetera. This simple formula gets carried by the interesting diversity of weapon mechanics and character builds on offer.I haven’t played many games like this. I tend to steer clear of clumsy ports from console to PC and/or games that heavily show eastern roots. MH:W exhibits both of those things in a variety of ways. The dialogue, story, character appearance, emotes, combat, and more are rife with non-western influence despite what I estimate to be a decent effort at localization. Even the little hop animation your character does when grabbing a transport during area transition cutscenes sneaks in a K-Pop-esque move! This influence is neither good nor bad, just worth pointing out.As for it being a console port, the game unquestionably favors controller input over mouse and keyboard, but thankfully you can get accustomed to and partially remap the (undeniably awkward) control scheme so that it better fits M+KB.The game feels polished despite so obviously being a port. Very few bugs or glitches encountered from day one. The issues seem to be more at the design level than the technical. In terms of art and visuals it’s a beautiful looking environment with lush landscapes and exotic critters, great and small. The soundtrack does its job well, but the right music doesn’t always cue up at the right time.The UI and many, many menus a player must navigate are not user friendly or accessible at first. It all takes time and exposure to become proficient with. Even then, I don’t think it’ll ever feel fluid on M+KB. I’ve yet to experiment with controller. The camera is a bit stiff, kind of fights you, and doesn’t stop on a dime. System settings can mitigate this a bit, so be sure to look through  settings and optimize from the start.Multiplayer and grouping are a huge pain. Rarely have I seen a multiplayer system more poorly designed and implemented than this, which is baffling when it could have been so much better. Total lack of explanation of systems, so you’re more or less on your own figuring it out. Frequent disconnections, inability to connect or reconnect to other player lobbies, pointless restrictions on which missions can be played together, hassles over the simplest multiplayer activity such as getting into the same instance of an area to free roam. No shared space in the main hub where you can see other players outside of one small portion of town, in which a very limited range of things can actually be done. Pitifully small number of actions you can actually do to interact with others or express yourself, socially speaking. Just baffling!When you do manage to get a good multiplayer session going however, it’s an absolute blast to play with friends. Many situations will scale difficulty based on the number of players present, which is critical to keep in mind. Some missions also can only be performed solo or with a max of two players. The normal cap is four players. It’s nice to roll with a group because it will feel like damage output is comparatively lacking when solo. It just goes faster in a group (as long as everyone is contributing).The single most impressive aspect of  and the biggest draw for me is the sheer number and variety of weapons (playstyles) in the game. 14 distinct weapon types that each dramatically alter your style of play and approach to combat. I recommend not getting pigeon holed into one, but rather becoming proficient in several.There’s an equally interesting variety of dangerous monsters. Each of them has unique strengths and weaknesses. Sort of like the witcher Geralt of Rivia, you as a monster hunter must bring the right tools to every new encounter. That’s the core of the fun here: learning your weapons and discovering what build works well against which critter. That said, you can essentially build an all-purpose general monster slaying character and never change a thing; but that’d limit your potential (and the fun) significantly, not to mention leave you with little to work towards in endgame.You’ve got to hand it to the devs; with such different control schemes for weapons, this game forces the development of player proficiency – actual player skill. The downside I suppose is that it’s a bit annoying and overwhelming to learn so much at the outset. This is why I stuck with three or four fairly different weapons.The key to creating a build is not just weapon choice, but (arguably more so) skill choice. Skills are attached to specific weapons, trinkets, armor pieces, and jewels (that can be socketed into your gear). Certain armor lines also have set bonuses that provide totally game changing properties. You can render a particularly tough fight with a tempered elder dragon into an almost trivial affair if you bring precisely the right build! However, crafting the gear/skills to complete said build ironically often requires killing that very same creature it’s effective against. Have fun with that!There’s plenty of RPG goodness to sink your teeth into when creating builds. Make a lightning fast, high elemental damage dual blades. Or a tanky, virtually cc-immune lance that can block every attack in the game. Or anything in between. Your strategy can take into account raw damage and defense, element type, resistances, status ailments, movement speed, dodging, blocking, healing, support, mounting and aerial capability, crowd control, item use, ranged and melee effectiveness, unique mechanics from set bonuses, and of course the attacks and mechanics of individual monsters. If you wanted to go off the deep end, you could create a build for every single encounter in the game…That’d take a while.Came in not knowing what to expect. Definitely wasn’t sure about this one starting out, but I ended up having a really enjoyable experience. I highly recommend this be played with friends; still fun solo but I believe the experience is diminished somewhat without the group dynamic. In the next installment I hope the cute but weirdly human-like animal companion at least is a choice between dog and cat…But those cat armors are truly the stuff of legend.-TIP: Proceed directly through the main story missions rather than farming or dallying too long on other content. The game flows better that way. You want to unlock high tier armor lines in good time so you know what to work towards. Doesn’t hurt to complete optional quests as they come up along the way.-TIP: Armor upgrade spheres come often and easily (from bounties), so for Pete’s sake use them on whatever you’re wearing. Or you’ll be squishy, very squishy.-TIP: If you find yourself short on currency due to crafting/upgrading weapons and armor, go to your item box and sell superfluous crafting materials for a fast source of income.-TIP: Optimize your entire game right off the bat rather than doing it halfway through the game and having to readjust. There are settings that improve just about every aspect of this game for PC users, and the developers continue to work post-launch towards PC optimization. For item hotbars, the F1 through F4 setting works better on M+KB than the radial menu.

author: Smarticle
review: is one of my most favorite RPG games that I've ever played. This is my first entrance into the Monster Hunter series and suffice as to say, it delivers on a whole lot. This is by no means a perfect game, in fact there are some glaring flaws in terms of gameplay and control optimization, but once when you settle down and get used to everything, there's fun to be had. There's a ton to learn and even more as the game progresses. I feel like the 60 bucks that I spent on this game was well worth the amount of content that I was given. Not to mention the fact that Capcom keeps adding more monsters and other content into the game for FREE! There's a lot I want to talk about on every angle of this game on why it's so great that it overwhelms its flaws, however, there's way too much to talk about that when I wrote an original review, I went past the word limit for the review box. I highly recommend this game, however, be warned that this game requires a lot of patience, willingness to learn, and a sound mind. This game isn't easy but it's nowhere near Dark Souls. Speaking of Dark Souls, some Dark Souls players might be familiar with the flow of the combat in this game.  The game WILL punish you and will test your mental stability.As for most games, this game is indeed fun with friends, however, there's issues when it comes to social interaction in the game and I believe it still needs some fixing. When entering an instance, the entire hub area is only instanced for yourself while a small room in that hub area serves as a hub for social interaction which makes no sense in a game that should feel more open and robust with life through friends and other gamers alike. There are guild cards which just tells you stats of other people but doesn’t have anything to do with guilds and there feels like less encouragement to actually interact or socialize to make the game a little livelier. However, it’s fun to play with random people who know what they’re doing sometimes and that’s the general quirk of multiplayer for all games, but this one, it gives a unique experience.Anyway, this game gave me one of the greatest experiences and there’s a whole lot to do. To this day there hasn’t been any loot box nor intrusive microtransactions in the game. The furthest microtransactions go for the game are just mere store costume cosmetics but that’s pretty much it. The updates filled with large content that are coming to the game is FREE. Again, I personally felt like the $60 I spent on this game was most definitely well spent, and I spent nearly 200 hours on this game, and I feel like I haven’t learned about everything this game has to offer. That said, this game is phenomenal and can't wait to see what Iceborne has to offer.

author: Rose
review: After the whole multiplayer connection issue was fixed after the games release, this game has been amazing. As a first time Monster Hunter player I have to say it's been a blast.

author: Koroke
review: Bad launch, currently a great game.Network issue fixed,Now support not controller emulated camera control.

author: Ains-Ooal-Gown_
review: instead of that handler everything is awsome :'D

author: Lars
review: My first Monster Hunter game, but definitely not the last. 's pretty gud

author: Jesterbooty
review: This game is good at introducing new players to the monters hunter genre. It allows them to experience the pain and frustration of wanting something but not getting it even though they have made it easier than the old games.

author: (=｀ω´=)✨💕𝓚𝓪𝓽
review: I played for atleast 12 minutes, and I gotta say this is by far the best Pokemon game out of all of em, Nintendo's really on top of their game with this one, good graphics, great sound, and amazing gameplay/fun. It may be a little different from the previous Pokemon entries like Firered or B/W, it's still a great game. I recommend to any and every Pokemon fan out there.

author: Yiinda
review: Now that almost all issues are fixed, such as multiplayer errors, etc. the game is very enjoyable.300 hours in to the game i do get a bit tired of the niveau not being super hard, i need more of a challenge!!only the tempered devil jho is a bit of a challenge in multiplayer.All in all i give the game an 8/10!

author: Malaphor
review: I honeestly find this game extremely fun. It's challenging, interesting, fun to learn, and beautiful. When playing with friends all of this can multiplied tenfold. That said, like every game, it has it's issues. I've personally never enjoyed repetitive grinding, and this game as this in spades. To get the armours, weapons, and upgrades you need you'll have to grind for hours. Granted this game has put a lot of effort to make it enjoyable, levels are fun to traverse and there are plenty of ways to gather what you need, but in the end it's still a long grind.All I can say to people who might want to play this is - Do some research, it's a complex game, and just give it a try. and rest assured there will be more than enough gameplay to cover the cost.

author: Zakkusu
review: Two of my friends and I spent 200 hours looking for our friend, Don. We inquired with every monster in the New World for Don's location. Some were more stubborn than others, lethal even.The pieces came together. We found Don. Hardest hunt ever.Where's Don/10.

author: Androshi
review: This is one of those MMO games that isn't your average fast paced easily fightable boss fight games. This is one of those games where you need to learn how to dodge to survive, you need to conserve your potions wisely, need to learn how to interact with your environment because it will turn your dire situations into less giant dragon chasing u through the jungle to devour you. There are limits to how much you can carry, limits to certain items that can be brought and that's fine by me. The game has astounding visuals and graphics it's quite hard to put down once you start playing. Although, once you finish the storyline you'll end up mostly just hunting monsters to craft end game tier gear and grinding tempered monsters for gems to put in your armor and weps. It's a fun game overall and a nice change of pace of MMO's that usually have typically boss' that have obvious attack patterns. DIfferent feel. different game I'd give it a shot when you have the chance~

author: mayth seragon
review: Far more stable than on launch, the client doesn't drop groups or drop connection randomly. The combat is impressive, in depth, and takes a while to master each of the 14 weapons (what would otherwise be entirely different classes in other games in the same genre). Visual and stat customization have a bit of depth to them, where you can specialise into full on DPS, niche forms of combat like jump attacks or mounting, or support builds with the option to do a bit of each without hurting your overall enjoyment. The monsters are varied, with just enough in common with each other that you can pick up tells quickly, but there is always the risk of getting caught in a lucky hit and going down anyways. Fun base game, fun with a team, stole way too many hours from me.

author: vardgo
review: Having played this game for a while now, I can say that I genuinely enjoy this game.  As my first step into the Monster Hunter franchise it was a little odd at first getting used to the mechanics, and at launch the game had more then a few bugs (though I had only crashed twice that I recall.)  but now that many of the bugs have been worked on as far as I can tell I belive this is a game really worth getting.  The monsters are fun and mostly unique, making them interesting and I forget I am grinding for their parts half the time as I just enjoy the hunts.  Story is interesting, nothing special but enough to keep you going and add some wonder I guess.  the world itself is pretty, and I have spent time just wandering around to see how each area shifts as you walk around.  The weapons are interesting and fun to play around with.  And the game has just enough of the "over the top" feeling to accompany the core of the game, the hunts themselves.

author: Vordat
review: I heard you wanted to play an in-depth RPG, adventure, hack and slash, giant monster slaying, big♥♥♥♥♥♥simulator, big♥♥♥♥♥♥dino, in your face, video game. If you have this is the perfect game for you! This RPG experience is something I have always dreamt about but never knew was available until recently. With giant monsters to slay to cute kittens as companions, this game is my dream come true.Your first experience with this game is on a boat running from a goliath beast, taller than most of the New York City skyline. After you wake up from probably the worst head injury in the history of ever, you awake on the monster! After your epic getaway from the beast, you finally get on the mainland and get a taste of what's to come. And after that quick description of the game here is what I think of it. The graphics are beautiful. From the amount of flora and wildlife to the huge creatures themselves the game feels like it was painted by Picasso himself.From great to bad now. One of the biggest issues with the game at the moment is doing quests with others and connecting with friends. Seeing as how most games connectivity with others is fast and simple, this game really falls short. It should take points with other games and make an actual party system for you and your friends to join quickly in the hub. And on another note, make joining people before they see a cutscene possible. Combat is as fun as it gets. With combos that feel natural and weapons that can switch from a giant ax to a sword, combat has never felt as good in any game. Crafting is cool and unique. With dozens of materials, you can use to make potions and mega potions. With later on in the game, you can grow materials you need for more complex items which max out your health and stamina.Weapons and armor are varied widely. And with the equipment saving feature it allows you to transition between weapons, armor, and your pouch inventory. Also to add to that, there are whole lists of different weapons and armor with awesome skills, it makes every armor piece and weapon feel different and useful. I'd say this game is GOTY contender for sure. And despite the flaw with the multiplayer, it's definitely worth a buy, especially on sale.

review: MH FAN? yes=buy no=buy also

review: They patched a new PC mouse control option

review: lavasioth is my favorite mnoster

review: Game good.

review: I kinda loved this game and I don't even know why. I can play it 24/7

author: LordBatas
review: I suck at playing the game, but I have fun. Die and die again.

author: Amethyst Rose
review: The game was so worth the wait, i just wish it had the updates for the system versions as soon as it came out, but all good things come to those who are patient. #BESTMONSTERHUNTERGAMEOUTSOFAR!

author: Cartiledge
review: Fantastic game. There was a lot of server connection issues but those have been resolved now. I'm excited for the new update!

author: Chrome
review: Dont get discouraged by the mixed ratings. most of the errors, disconnections and bugs on release was patched recently. there's still few minor fixes left, but the game is still progressing as long as there is patches the game will get better and better. 10/10 - excited for future updates and releases <3

author: drakcorian
review: you basically kill things to get stuff so you can kill things to get stuff... faster.the reviews on the pc version are mixed probably due to the connectivity issues during the first few weeks of release. as a ps4 immigrant, i would encourage first-time players to stay on for the upcoming content, it will be worth it.

author: Ryuu Jawzahr
review: As someone who has been playing the series since i was a kid, i can say that this game is pretty gud, if you like RPGs give it a shot, and if you don´t do it anyway, because this series are their own genreDopamine go brrr/10

author: The Bleurose
review: I highly reccomend this, and I'd like (and buy) more games like it - with more lore and worldbuilding for those who enjoy that sort of thing.ONE THING I WILL SAY THOUGH: I'm unhappy with the gender specific armour. Why can't it be like every other armour? I know I, as a masculine person, would not mind being a killer butterfly.

author: hey, ik zeg je iets
review: Note: I am not good at writing reviews, but I wanted to review this game because it's overall is mixed partially due to an error (which rarely occurs for me nowadays) and I think that one is a bit unjustified. And the other main reason being unable to fully play multiplayer, as you as a person first need to see the cutscene of a boss before being able to play with friends. And this one, yeah, it's annoying but it's still (in my opinion) very doable as your friends can immediately join the quest after you've watched the cutscene.This is one of the first games where I bought it on release and didn't look at any content before buying. I went in blind because a couple of friends I know did as well. And to say the least, the game thus far hasn't been disappointing at all.Graphic wise I think the game is gorgeous. It visually just looks so appealing to both the people that have and have never touched a Monster Hunter game before (like me). With very diverse landscapes that don't get tiring very quickly. I've been to the Ancient Forest plenty of times but still every time I go there no matter for what I still think it looks great, same goes for all of the other areas that MHW has to offer. The gameplay although sometimes a bit repetitive when it comes killing a boss (e.g. having to grind the same boss for a specific weapon/piece of gear) or looking for tracks (e.g. Pink Rathian or Nergigante) it is still very diverse in my opinion. There's plenty of bosses currently and there's still bosses that are going to be added in the game of course, seeing Deviljho already added pretty soon after the release. So I don't see why other bosses won't follow soon. But even killing the same boss is always different because there's always different scenarios that can play out (e.g. different monsters that interfere in your fight *cough Bazelgeuse*, turf wars, etc.). Also once you've got your hands on a certain set of gear that you want to use and start griding for tempered monsters (which you start doing a lot once you kill Xeno'Jiiva) you will always be killing different tempered monsters (at least that's what I found myself doing) instead of constantly the same monster. That's because all tempered investigations have the same purpose: Grinding augmentations and decorations. Speaking of gear, the weapons make the bosses even more diverse as there's plenty of viable weapons in the game that are in my opinion a lot of fun and all play differently. Even though I haven't tried much apart from the Great Sword, Insect Glaive, Bow, Charge Blade and Dual Blades myself, I've watched a lot of people play the weapons and it looks very interesting to say the least.TL:DR, I could go on forever but I hope this review says enough. The game is great in my opinion and to see a game like this with still approx. 100k+ players every day is really satisfying (as not a lot of games have that nowadays). I'd recommend you buy it even if you've never played a MH game before (that is of course, if you don't mind the first two things mentioned which to me are just minor annoyances). Even if the concept just sounds interesting to you, I'd recommend it and say that in whatever way possible you should try out/buy the game.

author: ScorpionGod
review: Never thought I'd play this type of game before watching PS4 version gameplay on YouTube. I pre-ordered the PC version a week or 2 before the actual launch. Funny thing is, MHW PC was my first game on Steam, first game I ever pre-ordered and first game I played on Steam.My experience is so far AWESOME. Even though this is my first ever Monster Hunter game, I was able to quickly catch up with most basic and repetitious stuffs. I played fine all alone till Anjanath came out of nowhere to faint me twice and that's the moment I tried playing online.Connection wasn't stable in the early days and today I rarely see any issues in online play. I love this game and that must be why I was doing late nights ever since August 9th slaying monsters. Playing solo is hard for monsters after Anjanath the first time, but once you catch up with their pattern, it's not a big deal. You can ENJOY a lot when you play online with friends and random people. I mean when you slay big monsters in just 2-3 mins, that's amazing and fast.When you use Dual Blades, it becomes SO FAST!!BTW, one thing I dislike is the font used in options. When you compare that with other games, you feel something is missing. ;)

author: magurow
review: if you ever felt you needed to practice fire escape drills for spontaneous air raids, this is a good place to start.

author: Latvian Princess
review: Brilliant game, well worth your money, easily 100+ hours into it. Most of the launch issues are fixed. Had no serious problems from day one. I can run it well with my old PC. Always new and FREE content.

author: psychomantis
review: It's like dark souls but with only bosses.

author: Friendly Caique
review: A heavy grinding game, but addicting!!!Someone help me.....

author: Patrón
review: Best game ever so far, And please bring back TIGREX!

author: Atipico
review: I played almost every games in the series, "Monster Hunter World" is, in fact, one of the best games you could ever play on PC: gameplay, story, online coop...They fixed the connection problems rapidly and more minor fix will come soon.Vote 9.5/10

author: Jor
review: in August the connections to parties with other users was frustrating. However, since its update in September this has been solved. This game is fabulous, very fun and challenging. I read a review that says. "once you get high ranks and you think you have everything, that's when MHW slaps you in the face to shows you are totally wrong". That's true, it's there when many more things are added, the double crafting, more challenging monsters, more armors, etc... The only negative thing i see: low ranks should not be mixed with high ranges, this makes players without experiences sometimes make the whole team lose the hunt.MHW is one of those titles that gave me a pleasant surprise, I had no idea that I would enjoy a game so much. At the moment I have 113 hours. I finished the story, and I saw that I haven't even reached the half of the things that this game offers. 9/10

author: Silver
review: First game of this series that I've ever played and, aside from the occasional problems that were in during launch (such as frame drops from Teostra/Kushala and Disconnections), the game has been really fun so far! Definitely didn't expect to spend so much time playing this. There's definitely a lot of content and learning in the early to mid game to occupy a hunter. Even as you're nearing towards the endgame builds with decoration farming and such, there always is more to learn with the wide array of weapons to choose from. Each weapon I've tried out has such a different feel to it and I can notice my playstyle changing based on what type of weapon I have on.Overall a really fun game. I just hope more content comes in the future!

author: Steve_Taro
review: Monster Hunter World is an amazing game on PC. It seems to be repetitive, but it is repetitive with quality. Game itself will attract you with tons of item you have to harvest, and intelligent AI that you cannot predict their behavior. I would recommend this game if your computer spec can reach the point. Playing with friends is main event for this game, but it is also possible to hunt alone.

author: Augell
review: Monster Hunter: World is one of my most played games on steam and I absolutely love it. I've played a couple of the other games in the series on 3DS, and from getting into the series from playing those games mostly singleplayer, I quickly got interested in this game due to it having better online functionalities and being on PC which is my primary platform for games.The part that got me hooked on the series is the crafting of weapons and armor. Crafting new weapons and armor from the parts of the monster you've recently hunted, to be able to face even stronger monsters, to then repeat the process is a very satisfying gameplay loop. Being a bit of a completionist I've found myself trying to get every piece of every armor set, and every weapon of my main weapon type, and I love it.The gameplay of Monster Hunter is a lot like the Dark Souls games. going back and forth between the two always gets me confused with the controls, since there are so many simlilariteies. You play with a third person perspective and fight monsters while dodging attacks and trying to get into position to fight back. Sticking to a weapon throughout the game will make you really feel like you've become an expert with it after a while, and knowing how to make use of your weapon and it's moveset is a necessity for the lategame.The game has some connection problems and demands a lot from your computer to play without any lag. I've found that alt-tabbing out of the game while in a session has a chance of disconnecting me if I do it too often, so be careful with that. Other than that I haven't had any huge issues with technical problems. The game has also got a lot of updates since it's release and is now a very good and polished experience, especially with the Iceborne expansion.I'd recommend this game to anyone who's up for a challenge and doesn't mind a bit of grinding for materials. The story is decent, but I wouldn't use it as a main selling point. The best parts of this game is the monster hunting parts and the process of crafting and upgrading your equipment.

author: DeathWithU
review: Its good and fun been playing on ps4 since release not much issues now.

author: ThaDah77
review: This game is amazing! Gameplay, multiplayer, monsters, variety of weapons and armour you can craft. HIGHLY recommended!

author: FANS
review: Runs on my old GTX560 1GB Athlon II 640 x4 setup in a playable state so im happy with it.

author: Snow Mandalorian
review: Most of the negativity in the reviews for this game have to do with launch day connection issues. At the time, they were justified and appropriate. Capcom has slowly been working on fixing the problem, and I can't speak for others, but the issue has completely been resolved for me. The game is fantastic, and you're in for hundreds of hours of content here.Wanted to give the game a good review since even if the issues are fixed, not all of the initial negative reviewers will come back and update their reviews accordingly. At least this will help balance that out a bit. Hands down recommend this game for any fan of looters, min-maxing, Dark Souls, or just looking for a great co-op experience with friends in general.

author: Quiteblank
review: Like any Monster Hunter game, this game requires some amount of patience to play. There will be a time period where you need to get used to the mechanics and learn how it works, during which time some might get fed up and quit. But if you stick it out, you're bound to have a blast with this game. The graphics, gameplay, and sheer amount of fun you can have with friends leaves me loving this game. It has several flaws, particularly around the strange online implementation (and now-fixed online issues when it first launched) but it's the same Monster Hunter I know and love with oh so many improvements.tl;dr: I highly recommend this game to anyone who can stick it out past the surface-level flaws. It's just a ton of fun to play with good friends.

author: SemtexVa
review: Monster Hunter World is Amazing, don't be discouraged of buying it just because of the bad reviews at launch, those were because the game had a poor online system and people couldn't play with friends for more than 2 minutes without dropping out of the session, but it is fixed now. Other than that there are a few frame drops with some particle animations but nothing that would stop me from buying the game again. I played the whole game from start to finish with the "Charge Blade" weapon, but there are 13 more types to choose from and I am starting to use all of them and really enjoy the different playstyles. All weapons are good and changing from one to the other makes the game feel fresh for me, monsters that I had completely destroyed with one weapon might be difficult with another weapon and that really ads replayability to the game.tl:dr: Fun game with high replayability, you should buy it

author: TaliaNova
review: This is a great game. I could write an entire essay but I don't have enough english words to express my love, believe me, I've tried.

author: peperonihead
review: I like it

author: Whatever it takes...
review: Download Nvidia inspector. Delete MHWorld profile. Solved most FPS issues for me.

author: Quendorsof
review: TLDR:Single Player is amazing.Multiplayer is okay but has room for improvement.Monster Hunter World is ana amazing game for doing exactly what the title tells you. Hunt Monsters. While at times it is a bit too obviously a console port with its incredibly awkward default keybindings or it not making use of the keyboard having, y´know, lots of keys, and making you first press one key to bring up your hotkeyd items bar and then another key to actually use something on it instead of having just one step for this or actually having changing bindings for the same actio thoughrout the game, left click for interacting with things in town and right click outside of town, what?None of these things take away from the fact that it is great to finally be able to play a monster hunter game with my mouse and keyboard instead of always being forced to have to deal with a controller. That said I would certainly hope that in the future more effort is put into making the PC version of the game at least feel like they tried changing it somewhat to adjust for it not being on a console.As for the gameplay, it is amazing to be able to fight the monsters on a big screen after several monster hunter games on the 3ds though after having played the ultimate versions of the previous games Monster Hunter World does feel a little bit lacking in the amount of monsters and would certainly be helped by having at least 5-10 more species or even just subspecies that are different enough to the current monsters. That said none of this takes away from the joy of fighting the monsters that are in the game currently.Sadly despite all the good things the one thing I really haven´t felt much enthusiasm with in this game is the multiplayer. When doing the main story quests all players need to play solo up till a cutscene for most quests before abandoning and joining on one if they want to play together which is clunky to the extreme, in addition to this sometimes joining mid quest doesn´t work with people in your session and we´ve also had frequent disconnections in the first weeks after launch though these have since reduced. SOS weirdly seemed to work better than joining mid quest on fellow session members though that can bring in random people which you might not want if you just are looking to play with some friends. Especially as it can happen that these random people will use cheats to for example instantly kill the monster to be hunted which kinda ruins the entire point of the game. So all this leaves multiplayer a bit of a mixed bag.All in all I would still recommend this game especially if you´re fine with playing single player part of the time as I have definitely thoroughly enjoyed it even with the rather low FPS my below minimum requirements PC managed to produce, but if you are mainly looking to play with friends do take into account that you may occasionaly have to deal with the game sometimes just being a bit of a pain for no reason.

author: Severige
review: The core game itself is fantastic! Every hunt is different, grinding gear is not too difficult to be swayed from it, and playing with others online remains makes it even better. Online, still, has various connectivity issues that initially bugged me and many others upon release. However, the patch has fixed almost all major issues, and any minor issues remaining can now be worked around. Hopefully Capcom can finesse those smaller issues, then the game surely can have no complaints! One of the best gaming purchases I have made!Now that the events are arriving this game will only get more worth and enjoyable!

author: Mir
review: This is my first Monster Hunter game and I love it, but the issues ruin it.I have been keeping myself from posting a review about it, but I guess this is the right time to do it.The game is fun, grindy (obviously) but fun, okay-ish story (again, obviously) as story isn't a big part of the game.The whole hunting / gathering has always been my favorite thing in games like this. Buidling yourself to be stronger, faster, and better.The game itself is fine, but the issues make it hard to recommend to other people. I enjoy it, will probably play it until I can't stand seeing the name on my game list, but as it stands now? Don't buy it. Wait for them to iron out most of the issues before you think about it.--The game still has a few issues here & there, but after getting rid of the online problems & constant crashing I have to turn my review to positive. Have fun, everyone!

author: Kaiser
review: Look I'm gonna be straight forward with everyone. Most of these negative reviews are about issues that have already been fixed. Ignore the negatives. People are gonna complain just because they wanna complain. The game is a blast. I've got about 218 hours in it. In the beginning there was connection issues but that is to always be expected with a game that just released. If you think a game is perfect on release day then get off your computer and go find something else to do. The graphics are great. The combat is awesome. I have no issue navigating through any of the menus. Should you use a controller for this? Absolutely. So if you're really a PC gamer then you should already have a controller ready to go. It's a great version of monster hunter that came out. I'm looking forward to seeing more monsters and updates added to it. Worth buying now. If you're waiting for a sale then wait but this game is worth its price.

author: General_菩薩
review: I can honestly say this game is fantastic. Utterly splendid to look at, lots to do and a good learning curve that makes you proud when you start to notice your hunts transitioning from a messy struggle to a cool and calm takedown of mountainous monstrosities. The grind (that's part and parcel of what seems to be any MH game, not being a veteran myself) is actually completely glanced over because the core hunting element is just so much fun and diverse I imagine getting bored a struggle even downing the same monster for the umpteenth time. Not to mention the plethora of available munitions that each have a unique feel and approach.The main complaints are based on graphical settings and network issues, the latter having been sorted out in an earlier patch (and having some of the worst access in the world in South Africa, I can vouch for this unequivocally). The former I feel are snob and nitpicky complaints, I understand they had the time to foresee this but clearly none of you have ever played other Japanese titles i.e. Nier:Automata and the like that are games without comparison that suffer from similar small flaws but are just quashed by the quality of the game. And even worse, it's Capcom people, what in their track record made you think this would be the first-ever issue-lacking PC port from the cornucopian console company exactly?By all means, go live in that little warded off bubble society of "perfect games", impatience and unrealistic standards. I'll be here with actual gamers, having fun.

author: Havocs
review: Great Addition to the monster hunter franchise.

author: Hyatse
review: Shut up Handler

author: cats_are_cute
review: Really fun game that got hammered for connection issues on launch, which have since been fixed. Most people who left these reviews didn't bother to edit them since the update. Other reviews claim the game deletes saves, which have been proven to be an issue with improperly maintained editions of Windows. If you're curious about whether you might be affected, there are a few threads in the discussion forum which can explain it better than me. My advice is to ignore any negative review focusing on these two.There are genuine issues, such as unavoidable frame drops from certain particle effects and poor textures in higher resolutions. Cutscenes will keep you from playing through the story missions simultaneously with friends without dropping hunts and requeueing after seeing the cutscene play. NPC's are incredibly verbose and sometimes take five or more lines of dialogue just to access a barrel right behind them to pick up four mushrooms.The problems that do exist in the game don't keep it from being great, or at least well beyond the score it has. There's enough content to keep you busy well past a 1:1 ratio of dollar to hour, which is my metric for purchases. You can easily go past that if you enjoy the endgame grind hunting tempered monsters. Content is guaranteed to keep coming, as Capcom has already announced that everything already available to consoles will eventually arrive on PC.If you do purchase the game, don't forget to pet Poogie after you come back from hunts.

author: Wiz4rd.
review: awesome fighting skills

author: Mepeet
review: Just coming back after a long break of the game and it is still as glorious as it was back over a year ago. So worth playing and the new expansion is almost upon us.

author: Sabre3999
review: TL;DR: Monster Hunter on PC, what else is there to say? Instabuy.At 100+ hours into the game, I'd like to think I'd seen quite a bit of it, as I'm in the endgame. There's certainly a lacking variety of monsters, and network issues were abound early in the release cycle... then there are the performance issues (I have SLI 1080ti, and some of the elder's particle effects kill even my frames!) But honestly, these are things that have either been fixed (the networking issues) or will be fixed in the future (continuing content updates, optimization patches, etc...)Honestly it's a good game. All the PCMR idiots scream about Denuvo, lack of 21:9 launch support (still missing at this point and this affects me, but I don't care because the bars don't bug me) and various other gripes, but IMO its just a vocal minority REEEEEEEEEing about stupid things that don't matter. I bought at release, I weathered the storm with a bunch of my friends, and I've had a ton of fun with it. I'll continue to have fun with it. Plus all of this will have been for the better...We've shown Capcom that MonHun on PC can be successful. Next time, we may get a simultaneous release with console, perhaps even (GASP!) simultaneous east and west release dates. Sky is the limit because true fans of the series have spoken with their wallets - and the voice was a resounding "Yes, we want this."

author: Astro™
review: great game to play with or without friends

author: Nights
review: Great

author: Jenny Quantum
review: Countless hours huddled together with a few friends, wide-eyed poring over the small screen of the PSP. The thrill of the hunts, the lure of progression, the beauty of the scenery, the dismay of failure. I was reminded of the good old times when I heard MHW is coming to steam. ARE U ***KING KIDDING ME?! I was never a 'console' person, and that naturally had me anticipating.I was playing solo exclusively when the game was released on steam (I had no idea the game was having connection issues), the game is stellar across the board, graphics is excellent, the music is pleasing, Coral Highlands look so enchanting, exactly what a Monster Hunter sequel should be. It was until approximately two weeks ago from the time of this review that I wanted to try the multiplayer aspect.I was disappointed by how much the multiplayer aspect failed, of this otherwise perfect game. I only managed to connect to an online session briefly ONCE, even though it was two to three weeks after release. The developers released a patch (on 23rd Aug, I believe) which supposedly should resolve the bulk of the connection issue, yet the problem persisted over at my end. It felt like capcom does not care if the game is broken. It felt like the connection issue was never gonna be resolved. It also felt like maybe the whole world is enjoying multiplayer, except where I am from.LO AND BEHOLD. I was so terribly wrong. From approximately 4 to 5 days ago, I can consistently connect to an online session, post quests with players joining me, join quests, respond to SOS flares, send SOS flares AND receive help from other players. Apparently the developers are working consistently to correct the connection issue. I believe this game can finally redeemed itself and meet the expectations of the whole fanbase.

author: Raisins
review: The first time I ever played a Monster Hunter game was back in my PSP days with "MH: Freedom Unite" and I always wished for a console/PC release. Now we have it, and it is glorious!For newcomers, this is basically a continous Boss battle after Boss battle, no fluff (well very little to make money on the side) and right into the action. 14 weapon categories that will make you feel like a badass every, single, time and best of all, they are all useful and have a different feel to them. I just love how it feels like you are playing an entirely new game with each weapon.This game also has an ncredible way to reward your victories and makes your toughest battles give you a huge sense of accomplishment.The controls are very tight and responsive, but I have to say it, better play with a controller since the KB+M control scheme is a little strange, which brings me in the negative side of things. There is not much you can do in regards to customizing your KB+M functions since there seems to be several functions linked to the same button (non combat and combat) which makes it very difficult to set up your key map in a way that helps with Ranged combat and melee.I also find the menu and chat menus very unituitive for a PC version/port, it' almost like they carbon copied the inability of a console or handheld device to be able to be used as a communications/computing device. If you expect Enter to bring the chat window, forget it, if you expect "i" to bring up yourt inventory, don't even think about it.The combat controls are also very challenging for a KB+M set up, most functions are so spread out throughout the keyboard that making a simple Y+B button combo in a controller becomes a R+N kind of thing, makes no sense. Why not a LMB+RMB? I am sure the next title, will take all these woes into consideration and maybe give us something a bit more KB+M friendly. Anyway, if you can get past the "need for a controller", you will have a blast, I promise you. I also think it was a great attempt by the MHW team at Capcom to this for the first time on PC.Happy hunting! >:)

author: Chii
review: It's Monster Hunter. It's a good game. Get it. Port is far from good, but it works. Online has been mostly fixed.It's also not Monster Hunter anymore, it's super easy, plot sucks ass, town hub is unnecessarily large, multiplayer is worse than in previous games, monsters aren't great, monster roster is really small, the game switched from a anime-esque style which worked perfectly and had excellent visual and audio feedbacks to a realistic and not very readable style, the areas are too large and mostly empty, scoutflies are a trash mechanic, weapons look like garbage, loot rates are criminally high, tempered and arch tempered monsters are just normal monsters but they deal too much damage to be actually fun, the two "final" bosses are garbage, the new skill and jewels system is really bad, etc etc...But it's still good. It's still Monster Hunter enough that it's enjoyable. There's patches / event rotations with its and bits of content being released regularly. And playing with friends is kinda cool. But it's not the same as the previous games.And if you've never played a Monster Hunter game before, start with this one, but also make sure you know what you're getting into, else you're going to regret it.

author: Phuc
review: First let me get this out of the way, I'm a big monster hunter fan, played it since the PSP days. Now ignore the mixed review on the overall reviews. Most of the negative comments will be about the hitbox of Monsters and what not.Pros:-No micro-transaction-all new monster or maps would be available for free-interesting loop (for those grinders out there)-great overall map design, you could even get lost in it when you first play it (ancient forest and coral highlands)-Monsters with interesting and somewhat varing move sets-armour and weapon progression is interesting and worth the investment-you could literally play for hours without the game feeling repeatitive -breath of fresh air-great eco-system with monster turf wars and small monsters attacking big monsters when they are weak-14 different weapons styles each varying in their own unique wayCons:-only apply to a certain niche of people-Monster hitbox is questionable (you get to play around it once you figure the move sets of each monster)-small rosters of monster (including the ones that was released on the console)-UI is extremely fustrating-controls on fit for controllers and not mouse and keyboards-you have to change radial menu items every time you change loadout -poor optimization for the PC port (again temporary, will update if any changes were made)Overall, I would recommend the game, BUT when they fix issues like proper optimization for the port. Its worth your wallet, IF and only IF you don't mind the grinding, and the loop of hunting one monster multiple times to get one material, I'M LOOKING AT YOU VAAL HAZAK FANG+!!!!

author: Mogli
review: This Game has the potential to be the best Game i've ever played... sadly I can't recommend it in its current state. I am a die-hard MH Fan, I have played like 3000h across the whole franchise and since January of this year I have been counting down the days till PC release. It is just sad to see the whole PC community is treated like trash with this mess of a "Port". The connection issues and performance problems are a damn joke and with every Teostra Supernova I am asking myself "what has CAPCOM done within the 7 months since console release" I wish I could just drop this game and start over again when the issues are fixed but I just cant... THE GAMEPLAY IS JUST TOO DAMN GOOD!!! So... I'm begging you CAPCOM please safe this game for me and the PC community... It breaks my heart but for now I have to give this game thumbs down (this will be immediately changed if the mentioned issues are adressed).They fixed multiplayer and Teo <3 now I can recommend the game

author: HakujaOfTheWest
review: So it seems that most of my mutltiplayer issues have been solved but i still experience issues with drops on uncommon occassion.My biggest gripe is that although I love this game, I'm dissapointed by how muddy the armors and weapons look even at max settings, the Monster Hunter team at Capcom really needs to go back after fully fixing the multiplayer issues and really address the terrible textures by cleaning and enhancing them, any armor or weapon you or your cat use look incredibly muddy and its what you stare at most throughout the game aside from the monsters you hunt. Hopefully they fix all the armor and weapon textures for both the hunter and the palico.The game overall is great though, dont just take my dissapointment rant as final. I've played 300+ hours on PS4 cuz I couldnt be patient to wait for the PC version since January. Solid missions, combat, multiplayer, and overall enjoyment when it all is working properly, it actually is quite the looker too when the textures arent botched up.Please fix these issues Capcom, you made a solid, well loved game. This was your chance to leave a huge positive impression for the PC community and you dropped the ball. Once you fix multiplayer and texture issues. This game will be a 10 out of 10 on PC.

author: HEIDI & MEL B KISS
review: I didn't play this on console so I have nothing to compare it to. I have an i7-2600k that isn't overclocked, mostly because of my motherboard. I started off my mh journey in mh4 where I clocked in around 700~ hours. Then when mhgen came out I played it for around 300~, and I also played mh3 on the wii u for a little bit. This series really grew on me, and when I found out it was coming to pc, I was ecstatic. So far it is the best monster game that I have ever played, but not perfect. Some things I want changed is a optional tutorial, skipable cut scenes, and for the game to become more gpu friendly. Having to put all the stress on the cpu makes for a lot of problems for me. When I'm playing a game I might pull up a video just to kill time, which is pretty hard to do when my cpu is always close to 100%. None of these problems made my experience (so far) less enjoyable. I hope people can stop negative reviewing this game on the reason of not taking the time to learn the 14 unique weapons and mechanics. I love this series and if your new, take some time to see where this series came from and be grateful that CAPCOM did something as wonderful as this.

author: Verd
review: The Good:Combat feels very satisfying and weighty, and offers a play style for everyone via the fourteen different weapon classes that can be switched to freely between missions. Attacks can not be animation canceled so you have to be more calculated than in other action games which I feel is a nice change of pace. Overall the core gameplay loop of gathering materials, hunting monsters, and crafting/upgrading items and gear is quite fun. There's always something new to build toward or a new personal goal to meet. There's a lot of character in Monster Hunter World, from the weapon and armor designs that tell the story of what a given hunter has accomplished, to the silly animations when diving or cooking just to name a couple of my favorites. Overall the game is very charming in so many different ways. Hell, I can't stop humming that damn tune that plays at the HQ. Iceborne is mostly more of the same in the best way. The biggest addition for me personally is the expanded glamor system, which adds a whole new reason to play.The Bad:Cutscenes are unskippable even as of Iceborne and doing co-op in story missions is a moderate pain in the ass since each person has to watch the cutscene in their own mission, back out, then make a new mission. The cherry on top is that the story itself is completely throwaway. It's not terrible, but a story that evokes nothing is often times worse than something truly awful in its own way. Performance after Iceborne has dropped for me personally, getting a consistent 60fps at 1080p is somewhat difficult on an i5 6600k 3.9Ghz and a GTX 1070. The handler is still a dumb c**t, but she's bearable in Japanese.Verdict:Monster Hunter World has a few annoyances, but overall it's a blast to play. It will only get better as the free updates roll out. This is my first Monster Hunter game, and I've bought it three times. Once on PS4, once on PC for myself, and again on PC for a friend. I would not hesitate to do it all again.

review: No longer feels like a port but a really good standalone game.Now there is raw input for mouse, though not by default the game feels much better. Seems we have to whine non-stop to get basic features.Basic controls are trash and you have to rebind all keys to make it playable (kb+mouse).Game looks like vomit now only <5% of the time. Mods can improve it dramatically.Absolutely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ retarded coop system, you can play together, albeit by jumping through the hoops. For the first 70 or so hours every player has to watch a quest cinematic in his own single player before even attempting to join a quest. After the story is over it's all good though.Now with 21:9 support there is not much left to criticise.

author: TotallyScen
review: I am a big fan of the monster hunter series.The game itself is really fun and right now have over 120 hours on record.The connectivity issues were a big letdown at launch I can agree to that. However since the latest patch I haven't been disconnected once. So for me the problem is pretty much fixed. The low framerate issues I had came from the newest Nvidia drivers so i reverted to 398.36 and the game works fine for me now. So I cant blame the game for that issue. The gameplay is really engaging is is plenty of fun playing with friends or alone.All the weapons are viable to use and every single on of them feels unique in their own way.The maps are amazingly beautiful to look at and to explore. Even just running around in expedition mode gathering resources if a fun experience for me because of this.I hope the monster hunter team will continue to improve the PC port of the game and will have a bright future for Bringing more monster hunter games to PC !Overall I rate the game  a 8/10

author: Magestic Tertel
review: I pre-ordered monster hunter for its release on august 9th for the pc. Since then I have had a mostly great experience with some slight notice of flaws. Pros- Perfect game for hunting monsters solo or with friends. - Game looks gorgeous yes I hear people complaining about settings but still it looks great on max settings.- I have not once felt the game is too repetitive with plenty of nice things to do.- I could add more but it's best to experience it first hand for yourself.Cons- The servers were plagued with instability but has since been fixed with a patch.- The pc controls are okay for most weapons but some are just really meh.- Not as much graphical options as one would expect for a pc port.- Slight beginners learning curve but is the most accesible monster hunter to date- Takes high end pc to run- The game is not for everyone I recommend doing research before buying as you should with any gameFinal Verdict. 8/10 Could be better but is a amazing game nonetheless.

author: Turel
review: Monster hunter world is now on PC, in the beginning, it did have a few glaring issues but now some of the multiplayer problems have been patched.PROS: -Able to hunt monsters.-Able to hunt monsters with friends -New Gear-Tons of Collectables-Loads of weapons to choose from.-Cool Cat who aids you. (can customize him too)-Seeing monsters engage with other monsters-Great soundtrack-Incredible, beautiful environments and monsters to fightCons:-Some graphics settings are iffy-Not the most up to date version but will be patched to it in time-Textures on armor sometimes seem to lack-Max 4 player co-op, sometimes we have 5 players meaning someone has to sit one out. Would've liked to see bigger maps for 5 or 6 players. But I can understand for performance and balance that 4 is a maximum.

author: Ken
review: Guide on how to dramatically improve your experience in Monster Hunter: World>Properties>Launch optionsCopy & Paste -nofriendsui -tcp (Remove this text when a proper fix is rolled out) ((Can also try -udp instead of -tcp))>Friends list>Options>NotificationsUncheck "when a friend joins a game"For performance, turn volume rendering all the way off. It refers to the in-game fog, and consumes lots of resources. I've been having a lot of fun, but it was hard to get into at first, and my friends with worse internet still get disconnected from time to time despite using the fixes I've listed.

There is no such thing as the final boss corrupting your save, it's due to your PC missing or having corrupted codecs that causes you to crash on the final cutscene. So when you try to reload, it'll load you back to the cutscence causing you to crash again making it seem like the save is corrupted. You just need to install the proper codecs to continue the cutscene.

author: Pain
review: I'm sure there are more detailed reviews for this game, but this game is so massive it's really hard to really describe how addicting it is. It's sooo big, you may actually get put off by it. The game is a 'JRPG' genre game so it's literally all about the grind, so if you loathe grinding. This game likely will not be your cup of tea. But if you do, oh boi, it's a dozzie. If you never touched this franchise before then you will likely fall in love. As a first time player for this franchise, I had no idea what I was getting into, only to realize how ridiculously complex this game is. Unforunately, most of the meat of the game cannot be seen in the first 2 hours. The tutorial (there is only the beginning mission and that takes an hour) alone barely scratches the basics. You should either commit or walk away from this 'MONSTER' of a game. That's my best advice for you if you are undecided.This game has great support for PC, it is receiving all the content the consoles have been getting over the past 6 months at an accelerated rate. So in a few months, we will be caught up to the console releases in content. Which is frankly fantastic. But once again, the grind is.. REAL. It's still pretty grindy, so watch out for that, if that is a turn-off.

author: Jihl
review: My boyfriend bought me this game because I had never played any of the other games. At first I was kinda skeptical. Until I saw the Palico's . Then Actually getting into the game itself has been a blast. The Disconnects are a bit annoying but I think it has to do with Valve doing a update about the same time as the game being released . So I think the issues lie in that. I have had my steam go on and offline a lot even when I am not in game. I like the combat in the game. I play with a gaming mouse and keyboard. So I have not had any problems with delays. I have not had any graphical problems. I like the game and I plan on buying another copy for my son and his GF. I hope they get the connections sorted out with Valve. Now onto the hunt!

review: Very good game. A lot of fun solo and with friends! Devs are also working to fix this.) Those are my only gripes currently.In terms of performance the game is demanding, but is optimized well. It runs brilliantly on my rig (R7 2700, GTX 1070.)I would definitely recommend MHW!

author: Sassy Tanassy
review: EDIT: Well there you have it, I wasnt being too nice after all, Capcom has since fixed all of the disconnection issues that were hurting the game and on top of that, the community has also learned that the save corruption bug doesnt even exist. Hopefuly this game will get more positive reviews now instead of people mindlessly review-bombing something that doesnt deserve it. There's a reason this game has sold over 10 million copies and is Capcom's best selling title of all time. It's a damn good game, and a few PC-exclusive flaws are not going to change that for me. It was very close to my favourite game before, but it may be my favourite game of all time now that I can enjoy it at 60FPS.Monster Hunter has a bright future ahead. The risk they took by spending 5 years on this game in the background while carrying on the series portably to pay the bills really paid off, this is MH in the current gen, and it doesnt even matter that it lacks the content of previous "G/Ultimate" entries because everything that they made from scratch works together so utterly well that it alone makes the older games hard to return to. Of course, I will still get whatever the next portable entry of the series will be, but I can only hope it has even half of the amazing improvements World added.It may be seen as a downside by core fans to create a game with so many systems that are so intertwined, as it will make creating more content all the more difficult. making every new monster interact with the environment, and with each other, creating new zones with the depth and complexity of the ones we have now, and all of the monsters and endemic life filling them and making them feel alive. Gone are the days of plopping a monster in a bunch of different zones and saying "this monster lives here, here and here", but you know, I'm patient. And I'm already enjoying what I've been given immensely. For the money, it was 100% worth it, and I got it twice.Monster Hunter on PC is a bit broken but not enough to make it unapproachable. I can only recommend this game, and I can only commend capcom, and congratulate them on their 10 million copies sold. THeir dedication to making something more than just another port from consoles shines through in their options, even if sometimes broken, so I have faith in a fix for all these issues. If you think I'm being too nice to them, that's fine, if occasional disconnections, a broken setting or two, or feeling like you need to backup your save just in case of problems bothers you then feel free to wait a little while. For anyone who has gamed on PC for as many years as I, this is nothing, so go on, give it a shot.
