author: citruz99
review: MonHun by itself has been and still is a great game, but multiplayer being the core of the franchise weighs heavily in the $60 dollars paid imo. If an early release on PC means the delay of multiplayer, then that's fine as long as it was clarified. Some people would happily clear the solo campaign and find things to do in this elaborate open world game in the meanwhile, but promising false hope is a terrible thing to do, especially when it could negatively impact the player experience. If you treat it as a single-player game, it's great. If you want to experience it as a monster hunter game, it's not in its best condition at the moment. Also i pray G-rank would be added as a dlc... even a paid one would be fine, but please don't make it full priced again lakjhff

author: Eiite
review: Good game, the ammount of hours you can put into this game justify's its price point. Highly recommend to playthrough using a controller for ease of use and because the mouse acceleration and input delay can make it feel very unpolished compared to what most are used too on PC.A lot of the salty complaints about paid cosmetics likely haven't got into high rank to start earning layered armours. I fully welcome more paid cosmetics anyway and hope we get some options to set the game apart from consoles.I have experienced some connection issues but not as many as people have been making it out to be, you do not need a team to complete any of the quests or monsters in the game regardless of rank and its typically easier on your own anyway.

author: ^3Geriatric ^5Catholic
review: You know its sad when such a great game and series is being bent over by server issues. I absolutely hate it. A game with a main focus of multiplayer with some past iterations requiring multiplayer for High Rank hunts with server issues being this bad for this long is embarrasing. I played this game on xbox since release and the only main issues with multiplayer occured during the first week but it was fixed. It's been longer than that here on this platform. Let me review the game and you should be able to determine why I have a negative review here.Monster Hunter: World content wise is an absolutely incredible game and taking into consideration all the past MH games this is the best MH game ever released. Many elements of the game are streamlined including the tracking, questing, and general hunting which in this case is one of the best things this series could have done to attract the western audience the way it has. The game is very gripping and can pull hours and hours away from you on the endless hunt and grind for better weapons and armor and eventually even more as you progress through the game. However an important element of the MH series is the multiplayer which has been absolutely terrible on PC. With little communication or information on the issues we have a measly 2 announcements from Capcom saying they are "Working on it" with valve. It's even beginning to screw with me because I enjoy doing end game content with friends and people online. Its how I've played every Monster Hunter prior. And to not be allowed to do that without major issues is beginning to turn me off from the PC version and making me want to head back to my HR250 character on xbox but I really don't want to do that. I want to play the version of the game that all my friends play on. I mean its a problem when 300000 people are playing and I can't find any body to play with. Terrible. Not to mention how lightning weapons cause massive frame drops. I maintain 100 fps on custom setting at 1440p with a GTX 1080 and i7-6700k. Why does my game drop to 20fps when my buddy is using a lightning focused weapon? This is another issue with the game that needs to be addressed. Also how the game has an issue with an endgame cutscene that has the chance of fully corrupting your save. No recovery available. You have to restart. Thankfully you can access your save game with ease and make backups. There are even scripts on reddit that autosave and backup for you. Please use those before you enter the final boss of the story. I dont want to see fellow hunters turned off by a corrupt save that makes you lose potentially 30+ hours of progress. Stay safe hunters.These are just some of the issues that cause me to give a negative review. Once fixed you can fully expect a 10/10 from me. But even I must be a critic of my favorite game series. Score until fixes: 4/10 Of course I will personally keep playing the game. I love this game. But for a potential buyer maybe wait out for a bit until these are fixed.EditGame is fixed. Mucho fun

author: Donut-3
review: I've been playing Monster Hunter for years, and I can confidently say, save for the connection issues that occur pretty frequently, this game is the best in the series so far. My ONLY complaint that I have is the connection dropping issue, which only occurs around once every couple hours to me. This is easily the largest and most streamlined game in the series, and in my opinion, THE game to jump into the franchise with.

author: Bonesaw McGraw
review: FOR NVIDIA PEOPLE HAVING "ERR12 : Graphics Device Crashed":Rollback your GPU driver to 398.36. This can be done by going to Device Manager > Display Adapters > Double Click your GPU > Driver > Roll Back DriverThis will not only fix your crashes, but gameplay will be much smoother. I also turned off Volume Rendering and changed Max FPS to 60. Since these changes, the game has been smooth sailing.

author: Zydrate
review: This review contains spoilers. It's also very large and had to cut it to fit, and eventually gave that up and just put in a link.The benefit of playing a port months after the game initially hits consoles is that there are a host of guides available, which I recommend if you want to take this game moderate seriously (bit of an oxymoron there but bear with me). I don’t typically like games that require you to have extra study material to understand but to its credit, all I had to do was watch one video guide about the mechanics of my favored weapon, the Light Bowgun. After which I was probably fifty percent better every hunt after that. So I certainly recommend looking into that.The story begins with your highly customize-able character on a ship to a ‘new world’, previously undiscovered in other games of the franchise. Your ship gets waylaid by a mountainous “Elder Dragon” who came up from sea. His back is full of magma and volcanic spouts and you climb his back in order to escape. Once you’re in safety, you find out he’s one of many that have migrated to this place for mysterious reasons. Typically one every few hundred years, now it’s one every decade and that has caused some turmoil in the ecosystem. Your job is essentially research. Kill monsters, stabilize the ecosystem, and arm yourself while doing so.Eventually there is an extended epilogue. Once you discover that Elder’s goal and what it might mean, you enter a “High rank” hunt mechanic because the ecosystem has changed and you react accordingly. Monsters in these quests are tougher and more aggressive, and you continually work your way up.My immediate first impression of MHW was actually quite positive. There’s something I can do here that I never really could at Dauntless; actually solo monsters. Dauntless was fairly unforgiving, only giving you five (count them: five) potions per hunt. You burn through those without burning the monster down properly, and you were done. Mercifully here, you not only get dozens of varying degrees of usefulness, you can also craft more on the fly or withdraw some from your loot in various camps set up around the impressively large zones. While some monsters give me more trouble than others (most flying types can do a one-two knockout by rushing me, putting me in a twelve hour stun animation, then merely swipe at me for an instant death), I’ve been in awe at what I’ve actually been able to accomplish on my own.…And unfortunately, I am forced to do a handful of things on my own. Let me tap into some of the problems I have before diving back into the meat and mechanics of the game. Steam reviews are mixed for a couple of reasons. Bad controls and connectivity issues. The bad controls are a remnant of the fact that it was originally a PS4 game and the menus really show that. The UI itself is very controller friendly while the M/K is barely given a second thought. I had to rebind my weapon draw to left click like it is with melee because I’d find myself engaged in too many fights, frantically clicking only to find out I was actually just using my slinger and tossing useless rocks at the monster. In addition, the radial menu might as well not exist, as it is bound to your various F1-F4 keys. It’s very clunky and not at all the “quick” menu that it’s supposed to be. Frankly, I’m tired of hearing “just get a controller” from my friends. I don’t think I’ve touched a controller since 2008.There’s no direct party system, just player listings and hubs. You have to find a convoluted “Session ID” in the menus for your friends to copy and eventually join together. Someone posts a quest and everyone joins it. You won’t physically see anyone outside of a hunt unless you visit the gathering hub on top of the main town. The whole Session ID is just a pointless extra step that the likes of Capcom just love throwing in there. I am reminded of Black Desert Online. Despite being a different country, it still has the same idea behind its mechanics. One does not simply just craft or buy potions. First you have to press thirteen buttons just to get a stack of them. Then they might be put in your storage box, not personal pouch so you have to remember to take them out before your hunt. Then there’s the canteen mechanic, where you’re encourages you to eat to gain decent buffs before every hunt. Why not make that a single item you can use midhunt? Like Dauntless, pretty much every important thing in town is far apart and forces you into miniature loading screens. After every hunt you’re plopped on the bottom level but you still have to run up to the Blacksmith to fetch some upgrades. One does not simply make armor, too. In the higher levels you have to micromanage “decorations” to socket into your arms and armor to increase various passive skills. Why not just make those skills up-gradable like the armor itself? Indeed, one does not simply upgrade their armor! You have to collect “spheres” that you get from bounties and hunts in order to do so.Everything just has a pointless extra step, but I admit these are all nitpicks in what I do believe is a pretty damn good game. I have adjusted to the controls (even though it takes twelve clicks to get anywhere in the menu, but the combat is fine) and I can stomach the connectivity problems… for a time. Everything else is just a niggling annoyance that I have to deal with before I get to the real heart of the game: Expeditions and hunts.To its credit there’s a lot to do. Expeditions are the closest thing this game has to an “open world” setting. You will keep everything you acquire, gather materials and hunt the local monsters at your own leisure (though once you attack, they enter a sort of timer where they will flee the area if you fool around too much, but the mode itself will never kick you out). You can pick up quests on-site and continually remain in the zone you’ve chosen. Admittedly I haven’t explored expedition mode to a severe degree, as doing the various optional quests and bounties give me more than enough gameplay on their own. I never really need to piddle around the same zone for that long.I mentioned earlier that I was happy that I can actually solo a handful of monsters in this game as opposed to Dauntless. There’s a lot more to that, the “simplest of MH’s” claim be damned, I embrace convenience if it comes hand in hand with actual fun. You can farm the same monster a few times but I found that the game offers you a handful of armor sets that can be crafted from bones and minerals alone. You can pick up bones from piles around every map and mine at little alcoves and continually gain materials to sets that will be perfectly passable for a time. I wore the basic “bone” armor for a while before getting into the more specialized stuff. Revered is the Anjarath, the game’s T-Rex who has a fire breath attack that will absolutely one-shot you and serves as the game’s first difficulty wall. His armor, however, gives fire resistance so if you can stomach fighting him a couple times (ideally in multiplayer), then you can likely build yourself up to handle him properly. Fun fact; I’ve yet to solo him myself.Other monsters have given players trouble that have instead given me more fun. The Radobaan for example, a sort of mid-game encounter in a zone called the Rotten Vale. It is a place where many monsters go to die and their essence feeds the Coral Highlands above it. The Radobaan covers itself in the bones of dead creatures and is thus highly armored, and you must burn through that in order to do some raw damage. I know of players who find this armor annoying but his movements are highly telegraphed and he’s a fan of stumbling himself which gives me a lot of free shots at him. So far he’s honestly been one of my favorite monsters to fight.See full review:

author: Juanzo
review: This game is great, so much content in this game, very interesting monsters and fun to fight and various way to play with all the different weapon in the game that I am able to see myself playing this game for a while, worth it.

author: Sledgehamster
review: Definitely worth buying. I've hardly scratched the surface but have about 40 hours played so far.I don't do multiplayer so not going to comment on that but solo is very fun and there's a ton to do. Keyboard and mouse controls aren't horrid but mouse acceleration is defualted (patching soon). I haven't tried my steam controller because I prefer my G13 and mouse,The only negative is a lack of 21:9 support. My ultrawide monitor displays it fine but the black bars each side are annoying and there's really no excuse in 2018 not to support ultrawide.I seem to go through boughts of disillusionment with gaming lately and rarely find games satisfying. This has rejuvenated my interested in gaming. It can be repetetive - it's essentially prepare, kill, harvest, craft & repeat but I'd be lying if I said I wasn't enjoying it immensely.So recommeneded unless you have an ultrawide monitor.

author: Eviltwinlink
review: Monster Hunter world PC is a fantastic game in the series. I run the game on a setup I would consider older by now and run the game fine at full 60fps. This took some experimenting with the settings and some research. The gameplay is great if you love farming monsters for new mats to make more gear. Some downsides would be all the cutscenes in the first part of the game before high rank.     Once in high rank it becomes less of a hassle getting through cutscenes. From playing on console we can expect some really good dlc to come as well for free. The core of the gameplay is a fun addicting cycle of farming monsters, investigations for decorations, and creating more builds for playstyles you prefer.The developers have done a great job fixing up the game and providing updates. They did slow down for a bit but now they're speeding up the update process again. We were given two new monsters in a month and more are to come. Definitely would recommend buying at this point in time.Notes: I play with an Xbox 360 Controller. (Keyboard and mouse controls are not great at the moment)Graphics Card: Radeon R9 270xCPU: AMD FX-8370 Eight Core ProcessorRAM: 8 GB RAM

author: Redn
review: Pros (+)+ Players get an engaging story this time around+ Lots of monsters to hunt with each one adding a new challenge+ Beautiful seamless open-world that is filled with detail and variation+ Nice sense of progression and rewarding gameplay+ The gameplay system is full of depth and helps to create excellent game immersion+ Great weapons with tons of variety to hunt monsters with+ Challenging intense battles with a fair combat system+ Impressive sound which helps to give players critical information about monsters+ A welcoming game for newcomers but one that long-time fans will enjoy too+ Multiplayer is well-integrated and offers tons of extra contentCons (-)- Some new players may still feel overwhelmed- Can be very challenging if under prepared for battle- A number of awkward menus that could have been better designed- Hunting for rare parts may become repetitive for some- Multiplayer matches should have been easier to set up

author: Eggaudo
review: The review below this was before they fixed the issue. I will keep it as a sign that the company learned quickly from their mistakes and fixed the problems with their multiplayer system quickly. And now, I will gladly recommend this game to my friends for I can now fight alongside them. The game is very well done. What it lacks in monster diversity, it makes up for in amazing gameplay. I love the new features they added to this game such as the scoutflies and little changes to the weapons including my favorite, the Insect Glaive. The fights most of the time can seem rather easy, but there is always that mission or two that will leave me frustrated (in a good way) with how challenging it can be to slay my target.Old Review:I would have easily recommended this game to all my friends except for one issue: The Multiplayer system is absolute garbage. I played MH3U, MH4U, and MHGenerations and NONE OF THEM had as big of a connectivity issue as this game stripped right out of a horror film. I tried multiple times to play with friends and strangers, only to be told things such as "You must wait for the player to view all cutscenes", "Failed to join quest", or just having me join in the quest and get disconnected out of nowhere. I waited for this game for well over a year and given it took so long for them to release it for PC, they have no excuse for why their multiplayer system is so god awful. Also, the fact that my friends message me complaining about how I always appear to stop playing the game and get back on it (the pop-up notifications for steam) just makes this worse. Fix the system and you will get my recommendation.

review: A worthy successor to the series. Better graphics, same intense combat but with new gameplay mechanics. Music is good as always. Good game to sink hundreds of hours in, but newcomers might dislike the grind, especially the endgame grind.

author: Shaoling
review: Monster Hunter World is an excellent game that is unfornuntely held back by some technical issues. Performance is lower than it should be, there are texture issues, the mouse input is less than steller, and there are frequent disconnects, but Capcom are working on fixing the mouse controls and the netowork issues, hopefully they'll deal with the performace issues as well. There are some workarounds for some of these issues, but they're bandaid solutions and only partially improve said issues, while we wait for offical fixes.However, despite these issues I would still highly recommed the game. As someone who is new to the series, it's certinaly a breath of fresh air and one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long time. If I had to think of something outside of the technical issues that I wish was done better, it would be the UI. It's overly convoluted and there are far to many menus and confirmation screens, in addition I wish that there were customizable hotkeys for the radial menus, instead of having to press F1-F4, then 1- 8 in order to use an item. Having to open what is essentially a menu panel to access the shortcuts/hotkeys defeats the point of having easily accessable hotkeys.The story is average at best so far, but story is certainly not the reason one plays Monster Hunter World.I played the 1st 20 hours with a gamepad, and have switched over to mouse and keyboard since. While there are issues with mouse input, it's still capable of doing the job, and I prefer it to the gamepad.It's not Arkham Knight level of disaster, but it's certainly not the " beautifully" implemented port that IGN is claiming. I fear that the overall "mixed" review status will deter many players from playing a game that is well worth playing.TLDR: The issues are not enough to ruin the experience, at least not for me, but if they ever get fixed it would lift this game up to honestly being one of the best games I've played in years. I'll update this with a full review once I've "finished" the game.

author: .Stream
review: Aside from the launch day issues. The game so far has been very enjoyable. But, it is relatively obvious that it's a port. I'm actually disappointed that after this long, they managed to fail to get it right.BUT.I stress this, majority of the problems that most other reviews say are fixable. I don't deny that the servers are having issues, but it's pretty much launch day populations. In time, once the population stables out, the issues will be fixed. In fact, I've already had little to no problems with connections.For the lack of events, I'm sure that these will come in the future. Eitherway, in most cases, These events are relatively difficult, so much so that new players who haven't grinded up the gear won't be able to do them easily. So there's little point complaining about it this early on.The one thing I can't defend, is the fact that this port is complete utter hype. I realize porting a game isn't as easy as it sounds, but the least they could do is make the M+KB controls a bit more intuitive. Simply chatting (Yes, there is in game chatting) is extremely unintuitive for PC users. Not just that, you'll notice on the first time that your mouse doesn't aim exactly like how a mouse would, but acts more like an emulation of it.But, tl;dr. The game is worth the buy. You will spend way more time in it if you actually enjoy hunting big monsters and the feeling of achievement after a hard-ish hunt. Though, if you only bought this because of friends, you may not enjoy the first week or so due to server issues, but I still would recommend it to everyone I know. (Given I'm a Dark Souls player.)

author: Aspersio
review: Man was it the wait for a Monster Hunter game to finally be on PC (excluding overseas Frontier and Monster Hunter Online). This game definitely has the scalability for a variety of specs to have the game look like a 3DS, to insane levels of supersampling to cripple the best of hardware. The game is essentially series of boss fights among a variety of different monsters using large weapons and tools for up to 4 players in a quest. After fighting smaller monsters, gather their parts and create equipment from them to fight even bigger beasts to make better gear. It's a great gameplay loop for a game with very in-depth combat.The game's got some network problems of random disconnects however. The main story quests have such an unintuitive way to play in a co-op with a friend as all players need to start their quest alone and only after watching all the cutscenes are people able to join, or re-host for party play. It's almost better to avoid co-op play for the main story, and begin playing with others once that is done.The mouse has some unusual acceleration tied to it and no way to change to a raw input. Controllers are recommended as the game was originally a console release earlier this year.Overall the game is great and the hope is that Capcom will update and improve the port as opposed to other japanese developers that release a PC port and never patch the bugs or problems.Update: Since the PC launch Capcom has released tons of PC performance improvements and options along with HD textures for the enthusiasts out there. With Iceborne still being delayed, but not as long as the original, lets hope that the expansion is still optimized and that our updates catch up faster than it did in vanilla.

author: CENCOR
review: With the network issues fixed, MHW is a much more pleasant experience, albeit with the odd hiccup now and then.Being one of the latest additions to MH franchise, MHW is a great place to start if you're a newcomer to the series. The game painstakingly (if not painfully) explains every new mechanic and aspect that is introduced to you as you progress, yet also gives plenty of breathing room for you to explore and experiment with gameplay mechanics on your own.For those who have played the previous MH titles, you'll find this one provides a much easier, streamlined and less grindy experience overall:- Mundane activities (collecting whetstones, paintballs, making tools, etc) have been removed or simplified. - Environments now regenerate resources after a set amount of time.- Instead of paintballs, players now track monsters using a mechanic that allocates points for specific actions against a particular kind of monster (which is still rather tedious). These points accumulate and provide permanent benefits to the player.I already own MHW on the PS4, but I decided to buy it again for the PC. One of the easily noticable differences is that the PC version is not capped at 30 fps. Heck, you can go above 100 if your PC is beefy enough.Another one is loading times. On the PS4, everything took at least 20-30 seconds to get through. That includes loading screens, joining an ongoing quest, finishing a quest.. even just moving in and out of the Gathering Hall took forever. I don't even need to wait 5 seconds on the PC; sometimes it's immediate!The game is also slowly catching up with its console counterparts in DLCs.One thing that's new with this PC port is the introduction of player-made mods. Be it changes that enhance gameplay, or cheating your way through, it's up to you decide whether or not you're willing to take it as it is.

author: Aviticus Dragon
review: This is my first time playing a Monster Hunter game, but I've put in about 12 hours so far. From what I have read, the real meat of the game is after the main storyline, when you start taking on level 5 or level 6 monsters. I'm not there yet. What I have experienced so far I have enjoyed tremendously.Right from the beginning, the story pulls you in and makes you wonder more about these giant creatures that are flocking to the new world. Your mission is to essentially hunt an Elder Dragon, but also find out why the Dragon came to the new world in the first place.There's something about preparation and preparing to take down large monsters that makes this game enjoyable. The crafting of weapons and armor is so easy, but yet there's a lot of depth as you progress!Good:-Crafting is so easy to get into and has more depth as you advance-Combat animations, and weapon animations are fantastic-Tracking monsters is fun-Learning more about the creatures in the world is fun and the more you learn about monsters the more advantages you can learn on how to beat them.-So much to do-Graphics and sound are fantasticBad:Co Op is having tons of problems right now, but it will be fixed eventually.Definitely recommend the game, but make sure you play with a controller!

author: Kercondark
review: I'm a long time fan of the Monster Hunter franchise. I own Monster Hunter: World on PS4 and now on PC and for my computer specs: i7 4790k, GeForce GTX 1080, 16GB of RAM and I'm running game from HDD. I don't have problems with keeping 60fps on Highest and streaming I should be able to run it 120fps but the port isn't well optimized on PC but still looks and plays better than on PS4 Pro.I will start with good things: It's fun and challenging in the late game.Great improvement to the formula of predecessors.Quite good looks (no Crisis on MAX but still looks good).Great for beginners because of improved tutorial and grind time reduction.Pro tips:If you create a session and invite friends or send session key, and I know that most Steam users don't have them but if you do this then you avoid matchmaking.I recommend controller but if you want to use Mouse and keyboard then set higher mouse speed in-game (35 is the magic number)Use voice chats: in-game, discord, team speak and avoid steam voice chat.And now for bad:My first complaint is forced steam groups and networking. What do I mean? Game on Consoles uses friends system (ps4/xbox network friends), in-game guild cards exchange system and hunter teams that you create. These three systems provide ways to play in multiplayer sessions but on PC Friends and hunter teams are replaced with steam Groups/Friends that work as ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as you expect in addition to that we have steam overlay with crashes regularly, steam new networking Disconnects so frequently that if you have 10 to 15 friends you can see about 20 pop-ups in minute( I was playing with friend and Steam went so mental that it displayed his pop-up once each minute).The second thing that scrubs me the wrong way is Denuvo Anti-tamper it grinds CPU as hell.The third is matchmaking at the moment is broken and I don't know if it's Steam or Capcom fault but hopefully, they will fix it.In conclusion:I will recommend the game for solo players with an at least decent rig and If you have friends and don't have to use matchmaking then you will have a pleasant online time if not find some monster hunter steam groups join them and then find friends or go for Reddit to list of discord monster hunter groups. PS. DEATH to Denuvo!!!

author: Spanky
review: A decent game, miserable port and playing with friends is next to impossible. It's such a chore to try and play this game with friends that it's not even worth the trouble. Requiring players to have seen the same cutscenes, even requiring them to see the cutscenes from the quest they're attempting to begin together is a dumb way to lock out friends from joining one another. This game is a slog to play alone, grinding for materials to gain marginal upgrades to face monsters that are impossible to kill solo. Definitely recommend against this game prior to any major fixes from Capcom.

author: Luna
review: I'd like to start this review off by saying this is my first Monster Hunter game I've played and stuck with. A group of friends played it religiously on the Nintendo DS/Wii-U and due to the size of the screen on the DS and the lack of a portable way to play the game at a friends house (usually only 1 TV, and/or Wii-U), and the controls (Wii-U controller sucks) I decided to wait until they released a game for PC. I did play for a time on the PS4 but again, waiting for PC release.Now that the game is on PC I have a new group of friends to play with and we all love the game at its core once everything is working/functioning correctly but there are issues going that need to be resolved to help damper the frustration that is caused due to online multiplayer.Here is a list of PRO's and CON's. This'll be my second time starting MHW but on PC. It's fun and the game gets progressively more interesting and innovative as the story goes on. I haven't had any issues with gameplay in terms of skill usage, weapon/armor usage, or any other major portion of the game. The monsters are all categorized and similar based on their type but unique in their own respect with strengths and weaknesses which make them fun and exciting to fight, they all have set patterns depending on damage dealt or other factors (large/tougher monster entering the area) but they're not choreographed so watching for queues and tells is still a major part that all hunters should be aware of.The progression of hunts, and the transition of maps with differing gatherables that are unique to that area as well as some of the monsters that can spawn, the need to go back to hunt previously hunted monsters, discover new monsters spawning in the locale that are fiercer also adds to the challenge that scales with your Hunter Rank (HR) and party size is refreshing to.Overall balance between weapons, armor, skills, etc is also nice with the trend of FOTM happening in the MMO scene this puts the players play style first and foremost and makes any build viable in the long run, while also not forcing players into specific roles but also lets them know (through monster dossier) what they excel out in terms of damage output on a monster. The game also has some other issues with connectivity, I'm unsure if the game uses P2P or has dedicated servers but connections during private sessions with consecutive missions with the same party (potential with randoms too) cause a disconnect after so many missions which results in a new session needing to be made which also brings back to the point of the removal of squads and squad sessions. This issue is currently being investigating but should be noted until it has been patched.The UI isn't cluttered but the menus are annoying to sort through while on PC, console it was ok because there's not much else you can do console wise but there should be a different setup for PC. Most games allow a menu system where each thing is its own icon that can be selected as soon as you go into it (Esc/Start) although not that great for quick-select during missions it is easier when in the main hubs or at a camp. I also think they should change the auto creation to effect your item box as well if the crafting list can only be use items that have been placed in your item box.There needs to be more options for those with disabilities, such as a color blind feature or anything that allows the colors to be tweaked for certain alerts/triggers that help hunters during missions that would otherwise be missed by those who are unable to visibly see those colors, or the colors aren't what others see which makes explanations such as the BBQ Split difficult to convey or when you Brace/Move while mounted on a monster.

author: Ratbag
review: This is my first Monster Hunter game I've ever played, and I had no idea what I have been missing out on. The monsters, the weapons, the combat, the visuals, it is all amazing. I've seen many people complain about internet issues, and yes there are some issues relating to connections to other players, but it's not as frequent as everyone has been saying. Either I'm lucky or something but out of the 44 hours of playing I have disconnected maybe 5 times, which isnt an issue because you can just restart the mission no problem. The game is optimized fully, the game runs at a constant 60 with my rig, and the keyboard and mouse support is great, I thought I would have to switch to a controller, however I feel the keyboard and mouse controls are smooth and work well.To put it short, this game is amazing fun and works well. I am glad to finally play a game that I have heard so good about.

author: Thanatos
review: I've been told by friends that there is a lot to like about this game if you played the PS4 version, and/or played a bunch of the previous Monster Hunter games.  However, if this is your first game of the series, I strongly recommend against getting it.  To begin with, the tutorials are bad.  There are huge swaths of the game they don't bother to explain to you, including large parts of how the weapons work, and how the monsters forecast their attacks.  The game greatly benefits from being played with a controller, however the controller integration with Steam is a dumpster fire.  Many, many times I was playing the game, and would pull up a menu only to get dumped into some sort of controller console.  It was a blank screen where nothing would respond to the controller, and their would be a single text box with a blinking cursor.  Additionally, frequently when trying to use menu selections to add another player, the controller would just stop working.  It wouldn't just require restarting the game, but exiting out of Steam altogether, and then starting Steam up again.    Speaking of multiplayer, after several hours of play (well past the refund period), the game starts throwing challenges at you that require multiple players.  Which would be fine, if the multiplayer sessionmaking wasn't total garbage.  Sessions are constantly disconnecting, and as mentioned earlier, a lot of the functionality designed to let you invite friends just contain game-breaking bugs.  It takes a long time to get into a session, and once you finally do, and it disconnects, there is no way to reconnect; you have to leave the quest and start over entirely from the beginning, having to re-create the lobby, and re-invite the members of your party.  And if you're running story missions, you have to run halfway through the mission and get through the cut scenes before you're allowed to invite your friends, which you have to do from a hard-to-navigate dropdown menu in the middle of a monster fight.  It seems like it might be a great game, but I put a ton of time into figuring out the basics to the point where I felt comfortable playing with other people, and then playing with other people was so plagued with errors and other mechanically problems that it's a miserable slog.

author: Beakeman
review: When I bought this game I had no problems installing and getting the game to run, however, terrible FPS; during cutscenes the audio would be finished about 30 seconds before the video. The game was unplayable. I tried the suggestions others gave to get the FPS up, and they did make the game a bit better, but nothing big. Overnight they updated the game and after that, I was able to run the game perfectly on med graphics. I played the game for a couple days, and then today when I turned the game on I now have the exact same problems again, regardless of the settings.  Great game, wonderful graphics when it works, multiplayer drops giving you disconnect errors frequently, and it's a CPU hog. If they get the multiplayer and FPS issues figured out I'd be hooked.**Edit** I'm now 400+ hours into this game, they have taken care of the majority of the problems, the disconnect issues are gone, the FR seems to be better, and I'm playing the game on "high" settings again with none of the issues from before. It's refreshing how they add  new events every month to give new content, and depending on the price of the DLC, I'll pick it up and continue playing this one.

review: Notice: Game is not optimized good, so keep that it mind.PROS:- Large amount of monsters to fight.- Variety of weapon types.- Palicos are very cute.- Areas are great, and nice to explore.- Challenging, but not too difficult.- Co-op is very fun.CONS:- Bad optimization.- Have to watch story cutscenes to play any story mission on multiplayer.- The Handler is the most annoying character ever.- The game will keep telling you the same things over and over after hunts.- Losing connection happens too often.- Story is not good, and cutscenes can not be skipped.OVERALL: 8/10This game is really great, but the issues are just too big currently. author: Cone
review: a great game marred by technical issues from a shoddy PC port. however, you can still have a lot of fun with this one depending on what you are looking for and how good your system is-poorly optimized (no longer a major issue)-bad textures-unreliable online (no longer a major issue)-denuvo-difficult to mod (no longer a major issue)-doesnt have content parity with consoles yet (no longer a major issue)-no crossplay-cant disable mouse smoothing (fixed)this game really represents how consoles can hold all of gaming back. the game should have been built for PC first, then ported to console from there. but since it wasnt and the dev team has such little PC experience, this is what you end up with. i'm not surprised, but i am still disappointed. review will be changed if capcom fixes the technical issues and i really hope to see better from them in the futureedit: i have updated my review now that some of these issues have been addressed or are no longer a major hindrance to the experience

author: Vaellif
review: This is game is teh best installment of the game so far. a few point ive seen in negative reviews will also be touched apon. All in all its the same calssic monster hunters with a beautiful combat system and easy RNG based progression that you can skew in your favor. the game is easy to play and there is always hunters advalable to help you. (me included if you need a friend to help you) All the new moves and combos look and feel great without any power creep or major game breaking effects.The game looks and Runs beautifully and it does have a few frame drops but a minor tweak to your settings seems to set them straight. There is Random timeouts while in online but are very far and few between, mostly when i disconnected it is a problem on my end. Everything in the game seems very well balanced and has good barriers to prevent high level hunters from jacking up low levels into stupid high teirs. The level of Difficulty of monster, when hunted in the right order is very well done and dosent impose any major skill curves or jumps. (unless you have a natural spawn of a strong monster that you are not ready for and you deside to fight it) All in all i would have to give this game a confident and strong. 9.5/10 If anyone reading this wishes to talk about this game more indept please feel free to add me so we can talk and i can asnwer any questions you might have.

author: Boolie Coolie
review: Game has a lot of content (now) but a lot of it misses the mark of what makes monster hunter games fun,this is more based on the experience of the entire game from launch to Fatalis update.-The challenge is there but at times insanely broken or forces you to play the meta to beat certain endgame monsters. -Clutch claw completely destroys how you should play the game and forces you to rely on its usage despite being a terrible mechanic-Forced cutscenes that take upwards of 5-10 minutes of your time consistently during the MSQ, still no implemented skip option for 2nd characters-Worst monster design roster in the series (Literally went with the bus-sized iguana meme)-No leviathans purely for the sake of terrible open world design of certain maps-no bug monsters-16 player lobbies feel more empty and anti-social than the 4 player lobbies-Game had an insanely buggy launch despite delays, on top of being drip-fed necessary content from day 1 that was already previously released on consoles-too much sony exclusitivity-Waiting almost another half year just to get Iceborne (also had a buggy launch)-The story is somehow worse than 3 ultimates story despite all the effort of the game development clearly being put into it-The worst set of main characters to date (Meowscular chef gets a pass, and grandma)-Deco farming was far worse than the charm farm Theres a whole lot more you can go off of, that said, the game has some great QoL stuff (some intrusive others not so much) that make the game a little more bearable, but at that point just go play Monster hunter rise or XX

author: ♤ S p a d e Ƨ ♤
review: FinallyFor anyone that hasn't played any Monster Hunter game:The essence of this game is exploration, grind, and hunting. The world is beautiful as the life within it. You research the thick jungles for species you never met, you see them interact within their habitat and learn how they live, and how to track and hunt them. The exploration is good enough for me to be going on expeditions w/out even picking a mission, just to explore the habitats. Monsters are a blast to fight, and the more you upgrade/progress the bigger ones you hunt, which adds an ongoing excitementThe gear system is grindy, so be prepared for a long game that repeats itself, at least in a fun way. You basically hunt specific monsters from which you can extract materials for your gear, and after each mission you usually are able to upgrade your armor pieces and maybe even your weapon, but hunting monsters is your MO, so you don't have to go out of your way for mats for a big part of the game, however approaching end game will have you grinding a LOT.Combat is awesome as expected. You have a satisfying balance between swings and mobility, meaning the game has a fluid and strategic combat flow, not favoring mashing at all. Monsters have their own habits and approach, and you can exploit weaknesses (like breaking their legs) or use various tools (like paralyze shots) to take them down, all of which fun to do. They all have different ways to defend themselves as well, adding complexity in the way you approach and fight each one. The weapons are ridiculous and fun to use due to vastly different playstyles, so much so that it feels like a different game with many of them. The story is beyond me, as with previous MH games tbh. I get the main part, but I ultimately don't care, cause it's kind of poorly represented, and everything else is way better, keeping my mind completely off of it. That and the fact that it randomly disconnects are my only complaints so far, but tbh I been doing all my missions solo, and it's perfectly doable, so not really an issue for me, just a nuance That being said, I can definitely see many ppl not liking the type of combat, or even game it is in general, so be cautious. This is one of those games that you'll either love, or be completely indifferent about. Definitely recommended to ppl that already know the series and like the combat style

author: The Cassius of Narnia
review: I've been a Monster Hunter fan since the original PS2 release way back in the early 2000's. The series has come a long way since then, with numerous incremental improvements and QoL changes to make the hunt feel more engaging and exciting. Unfortunately, sticking with the exact same formula does get stale, and after 12 years of playing these games, I even began to get bored. Monster Hunter World changes the game pretty fundamentally; sure, you're still running around slaying big badass monsters, but the tools the game provides you with are vastly different this time around. If you like the tactical combat of Dark Souls or Bloodborne, a progressive, farm-oriented loot system, and a game that oozes style and individuality at every turn, Monster Hunter World will resonate with you. They have managed to meld the Eastern core of the game with Western sensibilities and crafted an experience that everyone can enjoy in their own way. There are some issues surrounding connections and the multiplayer implementation could have been slightly more refined, but if you can look past some clerical errors (that should be resolved in a week or so - the uptake on this game has been staggering), then you'll be rewarded with a deep game that has hours upon hours of content and some of the greatest cooperative multiplayer action available. Period.

author: Lucious
review: Changing my review on this game as the devs finally fixed the connection issues. Although there is still occasional disconnections, its still far better than it was on release date/week. The events are fun, specially with friends. Hopefully sometime in the near future they will remove the slight motion blur and improve perfomance... maybe add an option to either use GPU or CPU? idk :) I bought a 1070 specifically before this game launched but kind of disappointed because this game does not even utilize it (3% gpu usage and 80% cpu usage according to task manager). To conclude, I will be regularly changing my reviews about this game as this is a dream come true for the PC master-race. I just hope devs wont get lazy fixing this game and leaving the performance issues as is.

author: morisa | (つ ◕_◕ )つ
review: I spent the whole weekend nearly non stop on the game together with friends.First of all, This is the first ever Monster Hunter I played and it immediately got me captured. I'm playing together with 2 others in a group of 3 and most of the time we paly together (yea makes it harder to kill/capture the monsters but hey its fun ^^). I'm playing on the highest setting on constant 60 fps.Hardware is:-I7 6700k-GTX 1080 HOF with 8Gb GDDR5X-16 GB Ram-Win 10-M2 with 2 Gb/s read and write Constant 60 fps and basically no loading time at all. MHW is a resource eating monster(hehe get it?) though, CPU is at about 40 ~ 60% and GPU at ~80% yea getting pretty hot here.I've seen no lags at all (though I don't run the latest Nvidia driver since most of the time it doesn't work well ..) and also the issues other players get didn't for me (except buggy multiplayer but later more) like the crouching upon opening the chest. I tried playing with a controller works well but I prefer keyboard and mouse its more comfortable (at least melee weapons, ranged are rather badly set up at least the predefined keybindings).Now to the multiplayer disconnect problem. Sessions break apart sometimes but rather rarely you'll have to close and reopen the Session to play with others again. Sometimes you cant join a Quest the quest host will have to leave the quest and reopen it (once you're in you're in only the Session disconnect can mess it up now or you close the game ...).This problem is Indicated by Steam though if you're friends on steam with the people you play together and see the notification "... is now playing MONSTER HUNTER WORLD" pop up while your partner sets up the Quest (or is already in it) and you didn't join yet hell have to reopen the Quest or you won't be able to join (This is at least a workaround!!!).Tl;dr: It's a great game and at least I'm loving it! Though it has some multiplayer bugs that are rather nasty, there are workarounds!Good luck on your Hunt fellow Hunters!

author: Skrinkus
review: I built my computer a year ago specifically because this game was annoucned. That being said, this is a rough port. There are definitely some performance issues as many have stated, but I want to talk about gameplay. a Ryzen 5 1600, 8GB of RAM and an SSD. The CPU and RAM both have a mild OC on them. Everything I have played in the past year has run beautifully in 1080p, 60+ FPS. It's something thats become kind of the baseline for PC gamers, and so when a game has trouble hitting those even on high end, some red flags go off.The first thing you should do (read need) if you're playing on a "mid range" computer is turn off Volumetric Renderign and SH Diffuse. If you're still not hitting your desired FPS, you'll have to fiddle with the rest of the settings. I've been lucky in that I've been able to maintain 60 FPS on High settings for the most part, but in later areas I've hit 45 - 50 FPS. I say lucky, as I've found that people with very similar builds have been getting wildly different results.Textures are low resolution, and don't seem to scale up even when set to high. This is confirmed by comparing the Xbox One X  version and seeing that even on High, PC textures are way lower resolution than their counterpart. LOD level also seems to have this issue. The bread and butter of Monster Hunter, killing monsters with your hunting bros. It works... sometimes. Besides the clunky route you have to take with others to get into a quest together to progress (more on that later), the servers can decide to kick your friends out halfway through a fight. This means you're stuck soloing a monster that has been scaled to have 2.3x more HP. You also have issues with private sessions and not being able to directly invite people, "failed to connect" messages for SOS flares and assigned quests alike, and the need to quit the game entirely to reconnect. I put this here because some veterans of the series will be dissapointed both with the small monster roster and how quickly you can take down some of these monsters, especially in multiplayer. Monsters stagger way more, leaving opportunities to wail on them. Mantles provide get out of jail free cards, negating some nasty effects that could turn a fight in an exciting and nail biting way.All that being said, I'm personally okay with the difficulty as it means my friends who are new to the series won't drop the game immediately because they got steam rolled by a body slam, and I can experiment more with the weapons. First, you and your friend have to start the quest you want to do separately. Then you both have to get through all the cut scenes, even the ones at the end. Then one of you has to quit, come back to camp, hope they don't get kicked or a "failed to connect" message and join the other in their quest. It's just clunky and annoying if it doesn't work with the servers being on fire because it means you've wasted time fighting a monster and now both have to quit the game and reset.These asignment quests take the place of Village quests, so where you used to not be able to play them co-op at all, you can now play them with a friend which is a step up. Joining quests midway through is cool as well, whether it be with a friend or a random person via the SOS flare. When was story ever important in Monster Hunter? I do applaud Capcom for risking something new(ish), but please give me a skip button so i can get to the action if I choose or if I've already seen it before. Voice acting is iffy and most of the time the lips don't sync up. A minor gripe and personal gripe, but just go look at some of the older games. The wepons look awesome. These just have different monster parts taped on to them. This was probably because the devs had to do everythign from scratch, as well as trying to fit the aesthetic of the game. I understand, just a bit dissapointed.It's. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Monster Hunter. ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, it's finally here and it is awesome. The weapons feel and sound amazing to use, the monsters are fun to fight, the turf wars give amazing "♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥" moments and actually instill a sense of cautious admiration for the monster doing the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ up. No more gathering quests, more QOL changes than I can list, less grind but with the same feeling of accomplishment when you finally get that piece for the gloves for that armor set you've really wanted. Exploring the world feels rich and fullfilling, the world itself is beautiful and scary in the same stroke, and all the ways of traversing it feel fluid and natural. I couldn't have asked for a better foray onto PC, beyond the glaring issues of performance."So what's the deal, are you reccomending this or not?"For me, personally the Pro's outweigh the Cons. I've been waiting 10+ years for a monster hunter like this. We're still in launch week and Capcom can still redeem themselves if they patch the issues. The accelrated release schedule for the DLC and event monsters actually bodes well, as it means they'll be forced to update the game and hopefully address the issues a lot of people are having. If not, well we can always hope the moding community pulls through, even with Denuvo.A really special game burried under some unfortunate performance issues. If you're a die hard monster hunter fan with a good rig, you'll be able to look past the flaws and cross your fingers that Capcom patches the issues.If you're new to the series, wait on this one. This is the best entry point to date, but wait for either community patches or for Capcom to fix the bugs so that your first Monster Hunter experience isn't marred by them.

author: Marky
review: While it's a great game.. The port is horrendous no way should a game this average looking be as taxing as it is.What did they do for 8 months? sit around twiddling there fingers? Was the port done in 2 months and you guys at Capcom just wanted to milk more sales on console?A quote from an article on eurogamer - - Network has been a bit iffy, but it's a new release I'll give them the benefit of that.- Co-op is poorly implemented for the quest story missions, I couldn't join a friend due to him being in a cut-scene but when the cut-scene was over I was just greeted with an error message..- Full-screen 1080p has black bars? What, why? Consoles run it at 1080p why is this a thing..I just hope they can do some patches that improve things in the weeks to come.update - 26/08/2018- Network is better however still not perfect, get multiple errors trying to create an online session and sometimes when playing co-op 1 or 2 persons might be disconnected. - Frame rate during certain bosses, most notable in Teostra fight with all the particle effects can drop fps from a smooth 60fps to 20-30fps. We need an option to lower particle effects, they seem to be a main problem of FPS drops.- Running Borderless Fullscreen removes the black bars, so the game doesn't run fullscreen correctly?- After killing Xeno'Jiiva to complete the story, the credits roll however for me the game didn't allow me to accept the fact the Hunter Rank has been uncapped.. Resulting in me having to re-watch the credits that are un-skippable.. Why?- SOS Search is a bit strange, searching without filters can result in maybe 1 or 2 missions, if you add filters you get a lot more results.- I've noticed some stuttering in Elder Recess after the network patch, that was not present before that.

author: LordThunder
review: It's a pretty good game. For me, it pretty much combines all of the elements I like in games: Coop multiplayer, action combat, not too much hand-holding, pets and my favorite: Dress-up dolls. ;)I hear a lot of negativity here on Steam. My current experience is that it runs absolutely fine. The game is interesting, if not overwhelming when it comes to the amount of things you can do. I don't like to put that up as a negative though. I've already sunk in more hours into this game than may others on my Steam list. The menu system seems somewhat convoluted, but that isn't a problem of the port. It looks pretty much the same as it did on the console (from what I have seen of it) except maybe that the PC version has a couple of more dails to turn.I have to agree with most of the youtube reviewers that this is a pretty decent port that doesn't really suffer any faults other than the ones also present in the console versions. Though some detailed effects seem broken on PC such as the dynamic reflections: I don't see anything of the monsters reflected in the water, like on the Xbox. (check youtube if you want to know what I am talking about)If I have to put up any real negatives though, then it's the lack of ultra-wide monitor support. It will run just fine, but with two black bars on the side, as if you are playing on a 16:9 1440p screen. For competitive titles I can see how the extra FoV would give ' gameplay issues', but this is a coop game ... I don't really see why UW didn't get any love. 4k did.All in all, I would still recommend the game.

author: Riakon
review: First off, fantastic game marred but modern AAA title problems. The game may be suffering from network problems (same as xbox one) and for people picking up the game is a huge issue not being able to take part in multiplayer hunts, but even with the xbox launch the network issues did get corrected in time.As for game performance i run an ancient yet rather high end machine from 2011.3960x at 4.632 gigs of ddr3 1866.Titan X maxwell (think 1070)Evo 850 pro ssd.Even though the core is 7 years old, i was able to run the game at 60ish fps on 1440p with most settings maxed out (volumetric lighting is a hog on resources, so turn it off) and I will agree with others that being a pc title, there is far too little configuration settings for various aspects such as graphics, sound, input, etc. But performance was less of an issue than i expected.As for the game itself, the experience on pc is still more enjoyable to me than on console due to framerate and load times. 2 seconds to load anything is great while also having high framrate with mostly max visual settings make this title more enjoyable compared to the console versions.The gameplay is what you might expect for a monster hunter veteran, But for the new players, monster hunter is a game that focuses on player position and timing to be effective in combat. Weapons are generally slow and ponderous and require commitment to make a hit. Learning the monsters movesets and tells will be the best way to be an effective hunter. Knowing when to attack or evade is just as important as upgrading your gear.The world is wonderfully detailed with amazing scenery and interesting locales to view. Each of the many maps have far reaching themes from jungle to volcanic craters and everything in between. Monster hunter world introduced many ways to interact with the environment which added a new dynamic to the hunt where depending on the location you may be able to take advantage of various map hazards to snare, damage or otherwise affect the target. As for the monster new and old lots of updates were made.The creatures still use the same skeleton rigging from older games but the animations are far more fluid and detailed giving a more life like appearence to the creatures that animate realistically. The monsters also have a life of their own, and they will go about there lives, foraging for food, water, fighting with other large monsters and a mutlitude of interesting interactions with the world itself. All things considered Monster Hunter World is a fantastic experience that is marred by some network issues that will be corrected in time.

author: Leon Asra
review: Lets be honest here and get the negatives out of the way. Poor optimization gives you poor fps rates enough to cringe a pcmr member myself. With a gtx1070 + ryzen 5 2600 processor i still cant lock 1080p60fps. Rediculous considering that the this game's textures are very muddy at some points. Also, connectivity seems to be a major problem currently since the servers weren't prepared for the amount of people entering the game at launch causing their servers to fry like eggs.The thing is, these are fixable problems. This game has the solid foundation that it can thrive in. I for one believe improvements to this game would come. The game itself is exceptional, with combat as its bread and butter. Yes this game IS GOOD despite its current flaws. I'm absolutely hooked with the hunting and crafting mechanics and can't wait to see what the future dlcs (which WILL ALL BE FREE) have in store.

review: All of you giving this game a negative review just for one or two problems are pathetic manchildren.Compared to the PS4 version I played for 360 hours, it has:10-30X faster load timesA higher framerate at a higher resolutionThe ability to use the keyboard and mouse or controllerSteam friend integrationFree multiplayerEase of multitasking (tabbing over to a browser to check reddit etc)By all accunts the PC version is already the superior version.Yes the mouse could have been implemented better.Yes the performance could have been betterYes the servers are having a hissyfit right nowHowever, I feel just fine playing with a controllerAlso I can turn down a bunch of settings and run at 100+ FPS just fine on a 970And lets be completely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ honest here. Not only did MHW have server issues at the launch of the console version, but I doubt that a single person will deny that a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of PC games had server issues at their launch as well.Are there issues to be worked on and fixed? Yes.But is it a complete writeoff of a port that's not worth playing? Not even close.

author: Walter Sobchak
review: PC specs: 980 Ti, i7-6700, 24 GB RAM. 398.36 Nvidia drivers. Running at 1440p resolution with about high settings and getting steady 60 fps with dips at times, but not getting any drops that makes it feel choppy.  This game does not look or run as good as Witcher 3, but I'm satisfied with the performance and overall quality. Before rolling my drivers back to 398.36 I was getting some stuttering, but I felt the game was still very playable. Best looking Monster Hunter yet. I've logged about 45 hours into Monster Hunter Ultimate 4 on 3ds, and probably about 80 on MHW for ps4. For me, the PC version is the best MH yet, but the PC version doesn't do anything to separate itself from its console counterparts.  If you're new to Monster Hunter I'd recommend this game as a must buy. I've had some issues matchmaking with friends but have been able to eventually get into games together with some perseverance. Once in an online session, very easy to join quests and complete SOSs with the wider audience. I plan to log a lot of hours into this game. Admittedly first 48 hours with the game were rocky but I'm feeling good about it on my system and have been enjoying the game regardless.

author: Jotun
review: Better port than I was expecting! Mouse + keyboard controls are great (mouse acceleration is not so much of an issue when playing a close quarter weapon), optimization is decent (running the game at a solid 60 FPS with mid range parameters with a GTX 970 and an i5 4690 and 8GB of RAM) and graphics are alright. It's not the pretiest PC game out there but it doesn't look awful. I definitely recommend it, especially if you are a MH fan like myself (I've started with MH4U and then moved to MH Generations)!The only real problem ATM are connectivity issues, especially if you want to play with friends. author: Scheming Cat
review: Monster Hunter World brings to the table the biggest innovations in mechanics in the Monster Hunter saga, and I welcome them with open hands. I've been a fan of the series for a long time, fell in love with the combat system from the start; but after years and years of releasing almost identical games (though they always introduced some new stuff to keep it fresh) Monster Hunter was starting to lose its appeal. Fortunately for us (or at least me) Capcom have finally decided to give the game a major revision.The game feels more fluid than ever while keeping its "Monster Hunter essence", we got new monsters, a wide range of weapons with new movements and mechanics, a beatiful map to hunt in and the promise of future content and events to extend the already vast duration of the game.Of course, the game has its flaws. The multiplayer is not stable enough yet, the game could be better optimised, the game doesn't have many interesting weapon designs as its predecessors, and as a lot of people have already said, the port could be better.Overall, I give this game a solid 8.5, but the game has just been released, and I'm confident the next patches and content we get will rise the mark.

author: Hilbert  Burgstaller
review: Firstly: Play with a controller, it's a lot better.+great graphics+decent storyline (something new for the series)+stunning and interesting maps with gameplay that fits them+a lot of new weapons (and some new weapon types)+Fluid Gameplay, Good performance, short loading times (since it's a ps4 port I assume)+a lot of minor changes that make the game better (infinite wetstones etc) that you'll appreciate if you know the series-multiplayer invites dont seem to work unless you join via session ID so far-the new gathering hub instead of the guild seems slightly more confusing than it needs to be (who can join what)9.5/10, I love it. However I am also a big fan of the series and played all parts on PSP and Wii that released there. I highly recommend it.

author: Steak
review: gud game

author: SixBelow
review: Overall, I'm very happy purchasing this.It's the first game that has actually had me very excited for its launch in a long while, despite being a port. I'd played previous Monster Hunter games a little on the Wii and 3DS, but never kept at it for long because I'd abandoned the platforms. But I always enjoyed those titles. I went in to this with basic familiarity with the gameplay and not much more.It's exactly what I wanted. I'm definitely getting my $60 worth, which is a pricetag I haven't bothered to pay in a long time. It plays well, has good variety, the environments are wonderfully detailed and an absolute joy to run and hunt through. I'm learning about new weapons, new monsters, new environments, new equipment, new etc... They all have their place and seem well balanced.The only issues that are of concern with the gameplay itself are some tutorials. The game provides them at every new prompt, which gets annoying after a while despite their usefulness. But the weapons tutorial, arguably the most important, isn't as obvious and waits for you to come across it by chance. It is not encountered by following the logical course of action. Being somewhat familiar with it, I didn't find much of an issue, but newcomers will. You'll want to utilize the wiki to get the most out of it, regardless. It also has UI decisions that may work for console, but are not okay on PC.Other issues are technical. I was not expecting any sort of stellar port coming from console. I was right. There is a huge amount of variation in performance reported between users at roughly similar settings. Some settings make basically no difference, others make a huge difference. This goes both for FPS and looks, and sometimes they don't correlate. Other reviewers  (DigitalFoundry) have posted good analyses of the settings and comparison to console. Technology wise, it's a bad port.There are problems keeping a reliable connection to their servers. It'll drop partway through, but as long as I'm in a private session it's no problem. It'll only cause issues when I want to invite a friend, where I have to restart the game and create a new session. Friends who are also playing will constantly reappear every few minutes with a Steam notification telling me their playing, too. There are certainly server/connection issues, but I imagine they will get resolved. Capcom might not have been anticipating the instantaneous heavy traffic.But bottom line, it's fun. If you're looking for great gameplay and can forgive (at least a little) the poor performance, it's a good title.

author: Justin
review: This game is amazing and I would recommend it to anyone. I have played every release since Monster Hunter 3 Ultimate on the Wii U. This game has a few really good quality of life changes to it and a few new mechanics that enhances the gameplay. First of all, the sharpess meter on melee weapons show the amount of sharpness is left per level, which is a significant improvement. Now, you don't have to predict when your weapon might drop in sharpness - you can just see dwindle down. Next, the open world allows for much smoother gameplay. Before, you would have to suffer loading screens between sections of maps - even if they were small - but now you can just run wherever you want, whenever you want. This makes tracking and following monsters much easier.On the subject of tracking, I thought the new footprint and scoutfly system would be a "watering down" of the formula that has been so successful, for the sake of new players. However, it's very intuitive and convenient. If you wish to avoid using this, you just don't have to investigate footprints. A lot of the quality of life changes makes inventory management as well as other things much more simple and convenient. The whole experience is fun and action packed. Aside from a few technical issues the game has, it's one of the best games to come out this year.On the subject of performance, I haven't had many issues. In fact, I was pleasantly surprised, hearing how bad it was for others, when I loaded it up on my four year-old PC to have it run nearly flawlessly at max settings. Occassionally, I will get a frame rate dip down to the 50s, but most scenarios keep me in the ballpark of 58 to 61. My specs are as follows: GPU: EVGA GTX 980ti ClassifiedCPU: Intel Core i5-4670K at 3.4GHzRAM: 12 Gigabytes DDR3Hard Drive: Standard Hard DriveOperating System: Windows 10This game is: ★★★★★

author: Turdle

This game is top quality in all respects, feels a bit like it's from 2015 or before but progress in the MH game line non the less. I can run this game on HIGH settings and I'm getting over 100fps consistently, pushing higher while idle.Review as of 1 hour playtime: As a MH game I would give this a 9/10. As an RPG I would give it a 7/10. (will update with 10-hour and 100-hour review)My specs: 16gb RAMi5 4430970GTXz97 board

author: Playblast
review: Since the latest update to fix the unstable multiplayer, MHW co-op experience is now a fun engaging experience and worth the time. So far I have not disconnected on any hunt, but there are rare moments I can't connect to my friend's lobby.I still get drastic frame rate drops especially fighting an  or a full party hunting with elemental weapons.As a hunter since MH4U,but skipped on the current gen console versions, playing MHW is such an awesome experience it really is a step-up(gameplaywise and visually obviously), BUT when you really get into the game it really shows how badly optimized this version is. Matchmaking is a nightmare, frequent disconnections in a middle of a high risk hunt, unable to join sessions, sudden fps drops in low-density area(I'm running the game on a TITAN this sucks) and more just read the other complaints. These problems can be easily fixed through an update, until then this is a thumbs down, wait for Capcom to fix their servers and optimize the game.

author: Drone
review: I never thought I'd say, "I'm really into a Monster Hunter game," but here we are.Hunting feels viscerally ~good~ when you choose a weapon that fits your playstyle (one of 14 different types on offer). The UI is a bit clunky if you aren't used to Japanese games, and the online functionality is... well, to put it generously, it was designed for consoles and could honestly have been implemented way, way, way better for PC. Co-op is extremely fun (it's really what the game is meant for), but there's one glaringly stupid issue with it: story missions can only be done co-op once everyone in the party has seen the cutscenes on their own, solo. This makes absolutely no sense.The audio and visual design of the game is gorgeous, and the New World is a very interesting fantasty setting to explore. Astera is a neat town filled with neat people, and OH GOD the cooking animations are the best.Not a perfect game, but I'm loving it so far!

author: Lucas, you're muted
review: So the main complaint seems to be about the port. Keep in mind that the game itself got a 90 on metacritic. I'm close to 15 hours in and it is clear why. The combat feels great, the open world is beautiful, and there are not enough games like this on PC. TIPS: Turn off volumenteric fog, use a controller (I know this will turn people off from the game but form what I understand the kb/m controls are feeling clunky and on a controller this game does not feel this way). The co-op is to help people progress to where you are and to do expeditions (which are really important for gear and the "grindy" aspect of the game). Also, after you complete the story chapters the game will not kick you out during the story cutscenes. This is not a port thing it is how it was on console and how the creators intended it to be. They want you to have the story cutscenes when you're by yourself. Overall it is a unique, fun game but the PC port isn't ideal if you were hoping to use PC controls. I still play ds3 with a controller and either way this seems like a controller worthy game (for me). If that is not a problem, I highly recommend it. Also, this is currently the fastest selling game on steam of 2018. There is no chance that it will not get more work and be further optimized. I'm just glad I get the chance to play it even though I'm a PC gamer.

review: If you're a diehard Monster Hunter fan then look no further than the PC version of the game. It is the best version of this game. I can fully recommend it to people who love the franchise or Japanese RPGs in general. Otherwise wait for a sale.

author: Onion
review: CAPCOMs next game should be called Monster Hunter: Connection Lost. I would say wait 6 months for CAPCOM to fix the plethora of connection issues, garbage controls, and poor optimization, BUT they've already had 6 months to "get it right". Their idea of "getting it right" is taking raw mouse input, translating the raw input into input for a joystick emulator, and using the joystick emulated output to control the camera. The same multiplayer connection errors that have been present since PS/XB launch are STILL IN GAME. When navigating any menu's, you have to press Tab for some, Spacebar for others, Right click, Left click, stand on one foot and hop. There's no rhyme or reason to any of this.I can't play for more than and hour at a time without suffering from ERROR CODE: 83-MW1 and getting dropped to Offline Mode in the middle of a hunt. I can barely control my character because of the moronic implementation of "joystick" emulation. If I wanted to use a controller, which is pretty much a necessity with this garbage heap, I would have bought it on console.Simply put, CAPCOM wanted to dig their hands into PC gamers wallets without putting a whit of effort in. Unless there is some serious overhaul work on this game DO NOT BUY IT, it's a frustrating mess and a waste of $60.

author: KeiZesty
review: I have been a mh fan for more than 10 years, my first monster hunter game played was mh freedom 2 on the psp and onward from there with 3tri, tri ultimate , 4 X etc (some titles escape my memory). Some call me a monster hunter veteran and i reflected that exact mindset going into world. Monster Hunter World caught me off guard as someone returning to the franchise, it's stunning visuals, audio design (Ambience and creature sounds/roars) and the shift in gameplay and machanics; I play world the exact same way I've played previous monster hunters and this way of playing the game works, but I now notice that thedre are alot more ways to play and more windows to try different things like with the environment and the large variety of weapons available out the gate at the start. Even after 10 years with the monster hunter series, it still holds up and manages to stay refreshing and new to veterans of the series.

author: Guilherme D'ravem
review: Lovely game, the hunt is real! Run across beautiful maps jumping sliding and runing after and from huge monsters, collect a ton of materials and monster parts to upgrade your stuff, and getting slowly better at it after every hunt, that's the game I was waiting for!Controls response are very nice both on mouse/keyboard (Been using for ranged weapons as feel better aiming at mouse) or my 360 gamepad (Need to activate it on Steam settings > Controller, first game I had to do that and now I get the Big Screen overlay that I don't like so mutch on my games while having it on, but out of that no issues). Some stuff on a keyboard could be still better, like changing selected itens on numbers (EDIT: You can actually put the custom dial on keyboard to use it on F1-4 and 1-8, not that easy to see the option to chance but very useful on keyboard), and aiming keybind could be better, but each to fix as we can chance the keybinds, it's really not worse to play at keyboard/mouse tham at controler at all.I've noticed some people complaining about optimization and not being able to run, I guess it's those issues after launch and hoping it will be fixed for them quick, but so far I'm running it very well on high, no lag or issues at all on my 2015 Win 7 64 Bits, i7 3,60 Ghz 8 Gb Ram and a kinda screwd AMD R9 200 of 4 Gb video card (Did not even update the driver to the new AMD build optimized to MHW), it's not a slopy machine but ins't that new or top notch, so I can't complain of optimization at all. Guessing may be some specific configurations having issues or maybe bad luck.
