Clunky multiplayer -  requires each member to have watch the mission's cutscenes beforehand4. No way to exit the game during a mission - you have to abandon first (c'mon it's 2018)5. Denuvo DRMOther irritating stuff:1. Really bad clipping2. Silent protagonist style3. Limited voiceovers and reaaally bad dubbing4. Walls of text everywhere

author: Parmeus
review: As a long time Vet of Monster Hunter games (started with the first one back on the PS2) there was no way that I WOULDN'T love this game, but still it's a damn breath of fresh air to experience a truly seamless hunt from beginning to end without hitting a single loading screen between zones.There are some early online connection issues, but since I have a dedicated group of friends who have been playing MonHun with me for years now I rarely ever have problems reconnecting into a group. If your on the fence maybe give it a week or so for the network issues to calm down, but either way this game is MUST OWN for any true lover of video games!

author: Vyse
review: Hi first time to post a review and english is not my native language so please understand.In my 3 hrs of playing I basically just fool around on the settings to get the highest fps and i got to say that this is really a CPU intensive game.I've run 2 setup to test thisi7-6700Gtx 950 2gb8gb ram ddr4fx 8350gtx 960 2gb16gb ram ddr3my i7 setup out perform the fx 8350 by an average of 25fps on the same settings even if the 8350 is running on a higher GPU and ram.. and i notice that i7 setup run the GPU usage on 100% while the CPU is on around 50% while the FX8350 run on 70-80%on GPU and CPU.. overall i recommend the game to those who have CPU on the recommended spec and even if the GPU is on the minimum spec. you can get 60+fps on a lowest settings except for resolution on HIGH and texture on FULL, AA on TAA, there is a few fps drop on fights.. hopes this helps..

author: Tzardok
review: I played the original all the way back in PS2, I had the ethernet adapter and keyboard for the console, it stood as one of my two favorite games of all time. I am not a fan of handhelds and the Wii game was disappointing to me. Finally, after so long, I have the Monster Hunter game I wanted. This game is fantastic and I hope they add more creatures from the originals overtime (Fatalis, maybe? Tigrex?), but the ones here are visually impressive and the animations are really good. I am enjoying it so far.If you are a veteran to the series like myself, you may notice a few changes here and there, at first it makes it look a bit easier than the originals, but the game kept all of its wonderful challenge and progression ideas while making some quality of life adjustments. I was concerned with the lock on mechanic (I thought it could make the game too easy), turns out it is not that bad and contributes to a tighter and controlled fight, while still requiring you to make precise inputs of evade, defend or attack. I highly recommend it for you. I you like easier games (open world sandboxes, especially the recent ones), that don´t require quick decision making every second, while also not very challenging, I do not recomend this game for you. Hunts are demanding and need to be so it can provide the epicness when you fell a creature you been fighting / hunting for nearly 50 min.My opinion, this Monster Hunter is brilliant and for years I did not get this excited for a game. My expectation was high, this game delivered to me.

author: Josh313
review: After coming from the PSP and 3DS games I'm amazed to see what they could do with Monster Hunter on something more powerful, almost 5 hours in and I'm loving every bit of it so far and being able to jump into other hunters quests is quite awesome. Seems like a good entry game for people new to the world of Monster Hunter.

author: Gnarius_
review: Having a blast - lots to do and explore, all the monsters I've encountered are unique and you need to be on your game or you could be defeated by the small monsters, there's some difficulty playing online but this doesn't detract from the gameplay for me.

author: Mikester
review: Where do I begin? There is so much in this game that meets your expectations when it comes to the story, mechanics and variety!About a year ago I was playing a lot of Monster Hunter Freedom Unite but on the iPad, this did mean that I had to play with the on-screen controls which I adapted to quickly. I had a break between then and now and when the news dropped about this game coming to PC I was ecstatic! Finally a port I could play on PC since I don't own a PSP to play the older games, or a 4DS to play the more recent ones.I have a slightly slower internet so I had to leave the download overnight from the day this game was finally released, this gave me an oppurtunity to check the early reviews that got out there for people who jumped aboard the band-wagon a lot sooner. I was suprised to see a lot of people complain about how the game seems to favor locked settings such as motion blur and controller support (Enable Xbox360/Playstation support in the Controller settings). By no means am I saying that motion blur is a good thing, it can get nauseating after a bit especially if it runs at a slower framerate. Ultrawide 21:9 was also an issue with many people as the resolution cannot to be set to meet the aspect ratio and I can understand why lots of people were dissapointed with this release, Denuvo Anti-Tamper had a play in this for many people as well. I feel terrible for the people who waited months for this amazing game only for their worlds to shatter with disbelief at how it did not meet their expectations, whether it be lacking better hardware or the features of the game itself. Hopefully you guys will be able to play this game once major fixes are put into action!I think I've rambled on enough, I'm just here to provide my honest opinion based on my experience playing this game with my hardware. My PC has a GTX 1060 3GB, 8GB of RAM and with a i3-7100 which may come as a suprise to some as that is most definetly a Dual-Core processor, meaning it struggles more to manage larger levels that are loaded much like the ones in this game. Playing this game is completely fine for me as long as it doesn't dip below 40-45 FPS as this is where I see the FPS that can make the experience the best it can be, going off what I knew from MHFU I loved the way this game played! The nostalgic feel of the aesthetic and the same core mechanics made this a definite step-up to the older games. So to conclude, this game is everything I wished it would be despite the hiccups that will hopefully be resolved (Best wishes to the development team at Capcom who will work this game to benefit everyone!). To everyone waiting for the fixes, hopefully you guys will all be able to play this masterpiece in it's fullest glory! And to everyone who has the game currently installed and are playing it just fine, I hope you find this message through all of this overflowed text and give support and encouragement to everyone else as I wish to give!

author: Maledict
review: If you're looking to play Multiplayer/ co-op with your friends I highly reccomend either refunding or waiting until the currently terrible system that is currently in place for multiplayer is fixed. However if you are looking for a good monster hunter world experience to play solo then it is a pretty damn good game. Optimization is a problem sadly but that can be fixed over time and it is still in a few days of release so this type of stuff will probably be fixed in the short future.      Good- Combat is pretty decent and feels incredibly satisfying and rewarding when defeating monsters.- Progression (as ive seen so far) is pretty well done not too challenging but not too easy- Customization is excellent as far as weapons, clothing, character and equipment- Cats- Story as far as I've gone into is really interesting and well made.- No crashes as far as ive played which is pretty good for a first day first PC release company.- Great experience for both a previous Monster Hunter player as well as people who may be newer to the series or never played at all       Bad-M U L T I P L A Y E R. as expressed above multiplayer hardly ever works. The system is overlycomplex, kicks people who have not seen the same cutscene and forced rejoin, and constant connection disconnects every few minutes. I cannot give it a thumbs up until at least this is fixed. The only time it has worked for me and from what I have seen from other reviews is when you and your group are in the central hub, but expeditions and quests (main part of the game where you actually do things) hardly ever work.-Current PC optimization. Made for console instead of PC, no options for motion blur and screen tearing. (assume that these will be resolved in the near future). Fairly difficult for lower spec computers to run smoothly even at the lowest graphics settings sadly-Controls. Subjective for person to person but i feel that a majority will feel the same way. CONTROLLER HIGHLY RECCOMMENDED - Mouse movements feel like a joystick and do not work smoothly. Multiple buttons for the same effect, cant use a radial menu while moving, awkward keybindings (however these can be mapped so ultimately its up to you, just the initial feel is awkward)- Lock on System. I assume this will be fixed shortly as well. The lock on system works well when fighting a single monster. Keeps you on target. However when fighting multiple enemies the target constantly changes with small movements. Deadzone needs to be fixed.Overall---It is a great game that people will definitely play and enjoy once it is optimized and better ported. I think as their first PC release it is actually pretty good despite my own and several other reviews. but until AT LEAST the multplayer issue is fixed I cannot reccomend this game. If you're looking for a good solo experience however I would reccomend this game to you. I'll change my review once the multiplayer issue is fixed--------------edit------------♥♥♥♥♥ been changed. games great now

review: Crashing on startup. We waited a year so they could "Get the pc port right" and there is no option to turn off motion blur, terrible fps issues, no ultra wide support, and my game won't even ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ start. I'm not even going to talk about Denuvo. Good one Capcom, really impressed me.

author: Loba
review: I was afraid this game wouldn't run in my pc since it's kinda dated,but was pleasantly surprised to be able to not just run it, but with high quality graphics as well. It runs smoothly at 60 FPS (the limit of my monitor).Performance aside the game is amazing. I've been a fan of the monster hunter series for a while and this one is a great installment. Several quality of life improvements and a bigger tutorial is a must in this game since it has a lot to learn. And even though the tutorials annoyed me at first I recognize they are necessary for new players. I'm ready to spend hundreds of hours of my life in this game. And if you like the challenge that monster Hunter gives you, I recommend it

author: Silver
review: Played the series since Freedom 2 on the PSP. World is a breath of fresh air for Monster Hunter. My controller worked fine from the off, but easy fixes are found in the forums/other reviews if people are experiencing problems. As for the motion blur I barely notice it - and I usually HATE motion blur in games. I also saw someone write a negative review purely for the fact that there is no lock-on feature. Welcome to Monster Hunter, I hope you enjoy your stay. (I am aware that a few of the previous releases had a camera lock on feature, but that simply pointed the camera towards the monster, not lock on to it.)I find the combat in this game fun, the running/climbing/dodging smooth, and have had no problems running it or connecting to friends, despite what others have said. Played a solid 2 hours online with no connection issues. Also, you NEED a beefy PC to run this game smoothly at 60fps. It is a taxing game, my rig was spinning the fans up to keep it cool (i7-7700, GTX 1080, 32GB RAM)All-in-all, fun game, haven't experience any issues as of yet. Would recommend, but people remember this is a polished up console port, Monster Hunter has lived on consoles (besides Frontier and Online) so keep in mind that a controller may give you a better experience than mouse and keyboard overall.

author: Fabby
review: Amazing game. Been a MH fan for a long time and I am so happy that it finally came out for PC for once. The screwed up the Multiplayer Part when doing Story missions for the first time, but other than that I am already in love with the game.

author: ϟ Sgt. Shiro ϟ
review: This is a game where you are left to discover most of the things and skills all by yourself, it doesn't spoon-feed you with a lot of information.And that is the beautiful of Monster Hunter, you have to discover and learn things by yourself.You might keep failing on killing certain monsters ( or not ) but that's the main point of the game, difficulty hunting monsters. I have spent an hour creating my character and palico. Though they could've added more hairstyles, but I guess I don't care about this as much.Kept trying most of the weapons to find one that suits me and have went with dual blade. Was kind of excited to play so despite not having my pc with me; I tried it out with my laptop. And even with low graphics, it looks amazing.( decided to wait until I have my pc with me to play; the fps count for my laptop is too bad for this to be played with comfort )# if you dislike grinding over and over again; do yourselves a favour and save the money.80/100 because of the lack of hairstyles. Female hairstyle is just too ugly compared to male hairstyles.______________이 겜은 아주 살짝만 불친절하긴하지만 할수록 더 알아가는 겜이니까천천히 하면서 뭐를 발견하고 스킬 배울수있어서 좋습니다.처음에 몬스터를 죽이려했을땐 힘들지만, 더 하면 더 잘해지니까, 계속 연습하면 되요.캐릭 과 팔리코를 만들고 1시간 걸렸습니다.막상 하니까 넘 이쁘다고 생각했어요.그래픽 낮게 설정해도 넘 이쁜거 처음...너무 하고싶어서 컴터없이 노트북으로했는데,Fps너무 낮아서, 컴터 사서 합니다.계속 똑같은짓 하는거 싫으시면, 그냥 사지마세요.솔직히 메이플 했으면 ( 누가 메이플 한적 없냐? 다 언젠간 한번 한적있잖아요. ) 이 겜 해도 괜찮다고 생각해요.80/100점을 주고; 이유는 헤어스타일 너무 없고, 여캐 헤어스타일 남캐 비해서 더 별로.

author: Arancii

author: ★Spice x Dog
review: Crack cocaine, also known simply as crack, is a free base form of cocaine that can be smoked. Crack offers a short but intense high to smokers. The Manual of Adolescent Substance Abuse Treatment calls it the most "addictive" (effective) form of cocaine.[1] Crack cocaine is commonly used as a recreational drug. Crack first saw widespread use in primarily impoverished inner city neighborhoods in New York, Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington DC, Los Angeles, and Miami in late 1984 and 1985; its rapid increase in use and availability is sometimes termed as the "crack epidemic". Physical and chemical propertiesIn purer forms, crack rocks appear as off-white nuggets with jagged edges,[3] with a slightly higher density than candle wax. Purer forms of crack resemble a hard brittle plastic, in crystalline form[3] (snaps when broken). A crack rock acts as a local anesthetic (see: cocaine), numbing the tongue or mouth only where directly placed. Purer forms of crack will sink in water or melt at the edges when near a flame (crack vaporizes at 90 °C, 194 °F).[1] Crack cocaine as sold on the streets may be adulterated or "cut" with other substances mimicking the appearance of crack cocaine to increase bulk. Use of toxic adulterants such as levamisole[4] has been documented.[5]

author: kambiing
review: First of all, The point of the game is to hunt monstersWhich means the gameplay loop mainly consist ofPick a weapon -> kill monster -> craft -> better kills -> craft -> occasional death -> repeat.Multiply that by 14 weapons. 30 - 60 hour soloable experience, more than that you'll need some friends, not because the hard content or things like that, just because you'll get bored without friends at that point.Imagine looter shooter or diablo without friends at 150 hour boring.Summary after completing the main campaign at HR 15:- Graphical performance kinda meh.- Online MP is a complete garbage at launch.- Not a good port, okay port imo.- The only pro: is monster hunter.Summary after completing HR 49 after a month:- Major graphical issues fixed- Online for the most part is okay now. Improved from 90% disconnect within an hour  to 6 - 12 hour session before disconnect.Get this only if you're got decent set up or reallly want some updated MH that is not on DS

author: DarkFrost
review: No performance issues on this side:The game looks GREAT even with all settings LOW.I'm playing on an i5-6500 with a GTX 960 on all low settings and TAA Anti-Aliasing with constant 60fps at 1080pThe game's combat is immensely fun and I haven't even scratched the surface yet. This is one to go down in the books as one of the best Monster Hunter games and it is on PC!!

author: Rhogar
review: The port is solid, some textures defintely need more polish (especially in the cutscenes) and definition but otherwise it looks beautiful. Disable the volumetric fog: the game looks better without it and vastly improves the fps count.So if you're a Monster Hunter veteran it's a must buy and for newcomers the initial learning process is well explained and streamlined, give it a try!EDIT: now that the early server problems have been fixed the game plays great!

author: carticket
review: This is a console game. This is literally a console game that runs on your PC. If you didn't want to play it on a console, you probably shouldn't buy it for PC. If the only thing keeping you from buying it before was not having a console to play it on, then you will get exactly what you want playing it on PC with a controller. The UI is horrendous. Multiplayer is incredibly difficult to get going. Mouse response is bad. Options like invert mouse Y are not available until after the tutorial is complete.I guess it looks nice?

author: NWJNS👁
review: Hi, GTX 1060 running fine here 60fps with fps caps 70fps without fps caps. Everything was set on default except texture which i change it to "Full", playing with keyboard everything feel and look just fine (yes, controller is not a need :p)FYI: online feature only activate after you finish the first quest ! Game is so Beautiful , Thanks alot for bringing this to the PC !!! <3And Yes for those who wanted to try the game out <2h is probably not enough since customizing character and the kitten already took me 1hour ++ (ikr....) and the tutorial itself too me sometime to test out all the weapon which ramp up close to 2h gametime, and yes its all being done without cutting through any cutscene :) , hope this help.There are multiple languge supported i must say its kind of wide so feel free to try it out , you can also change the voice acting ingame into japanese, english or monster hunter language ( the default one :D),and sadly no chinese ;p.Game is 16.7gb ,idk if anyone interested about this but i will just leave it here .That all most of you wanted to know i think? Hope this help!

author: Uncle_Moike
review: On launch the game had some connection issues where people would disconnect after playing in a session for about 3 to 4 minutes. A few people got really pissed off on the whole connection thing and some people didn't. I had no connection issues on some of the sessions I have joined and play, but some of them were really bad to the point that I had to restart the game and steam. Ever since they relased the patch a few days ago it seemed to fix some of the disconnecting issues for me and when you disconnect it doesn't boot you to offline mode anymore.PRO-Monster Hunter World finally on PC-Fixed some of the connection issues and no longer boots you to offline mode-Gathering is easier-High Rank is fun but could be tougher-Base Monster Hunter mechanics are still in-Somewhat easier learning curve for most weapons-Combat feels smoother in this game-Network seems to be fixed and no longer booting every single player out of the quest.CONS-Most of the content isn't in the game yet-Story is really short -Scoutflies twisting your neck around-No fighting style from the MHXX series-Poor optimization

author: {.Automata.}
review: EDIT: this has all been addressed The port is extremely mixed. Mouse controls are by far the worst I've seen in any game. The mouse camera has a max turn speed as if it's emulating an analog stick and even jumps. There's no smooth/responsive camera controls with a mouseTurn off the volumetric ♥♥♥♥ and you get "ok" performance. I should not be getting 50fps on a $500 GPU that came out the end of 2017. This is medium high settings at 1080p.Lots of hitching and fps fluctuations.Everything is just so out of whack and inconsistent that I can't recommend at this stage.CAPCOM: Fix the mouse in menus. Mouse acceleration should not be forced. Fix the mouse camera, it it should not emulate an analog stick. You took 9 months for this and we get lackluster performance with average at best visuals compared to other AAA games that run much better than this game.

author: MerlyWerly
review: As a die hard PC gaming fan, this game as usual disappointed me from a control point of view.The graphics, animation, all stunning.  Complexity of crafting and armor/weapons etc....lots of thought has gone into this.Controls changed because this is a PC and not a console? Nope.  And this is where it is a big let down for me.  Like many other console "ports" they don't think about how PC gamers interact with things or how they like the characters to move.My biggest ache was back isn't back.  Instead you completely turn around.  Errrr no thanks I can do that with my mouse.  I want the back key to walk backwards not completely turn me in the opposite direction.  I know, I know.  You are moaning because of that??  That AND the camera seems to wildy change where it wants to look at just as you are trying to dodge two beasties.Many people will read this and think you will get used to it.Many people probably will do just that.But it is enough for me not to be able to play and enjoy the game for what it is.Console port controls should be re written for PCs and not just fudged to get them working.Disappointed to be honest.

review: So I played ~ 200 hours MHW on the PS4 and roughly 1500 hours in the entire MH Franchise. I absolutely love Monster Hunter and MH:W is another stunning entry! author: Mancha
review: I'm 1 hour in and I'm loving it so far.I've dedicated ~5000 hours of my life to this franchise (mhfu, mh3u, mh4u, mhg) and I'm more than ready to invest a few thousands more. However, as a veteran who started playing with mhfu on PSP I'm not too enthousiastic about some QOL changes (damage numbers, lock-on, infinite whetstones, walking while drinking potions). They trivialize the game a bit. Having a second stick for a camera instead of using the D-pad in mh3u was a blessing that was necessary but I feel they should have stopped there in terms of accessibility.But, at the same time, those changes make MHW the best entry point ever for new hunters. So if this results in attracting and keeping more players, good. Like most things in life, MH is amazing with friends. This is where Monster Hunter really shines.If you're new to Monster Hunter, the gameloop is simple.-You kill monsters-You carve them-You craft better gear with the monster materials-You kill bigger monsters It's a grindfest, but it's so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ rewarding and fun to play.8.5/10*****SYSTEM INFO:Cpu: ryzen 7 2700x Gpu: gtx 1060 6gbGame runs like a charm on the high preset with 60fps. Sometimes it drops to 55 but it never goes lower.I have not met any controller issues with my Xbox360 controller.

author: Redbl0odx
review: ::PROTIP::TURN OFF VOLUMETRIC FOG! The game looks better without it, and you'll easily gain 20FPS or even more depending on the area.So far I have run into no issues with this port, I only have a little bit over an hour, but in this hour I have played the beginning tutorial and the first hunt.I am running 1920 x 1080 @60FPS+ almost all the time. This is on the highest settings, minus the volumetric fog.For me, this port seems to be pretty good. Not sure what the scare was about beforehand, you don't need a real beast to play this. I am sure I could get alot more frames if I decided to turn some settings down, but I am perfectly happy with 60fps. Also, Capcom said that the graphics are technically the same as compared to consoles, and honestly they're right. However, seeing the game in a silky smooth 60FPS+ makes everything look and feel so much better than console.My specs, for reference.CPU: Core i7 4790k @ 4.6ghz OCRAM: 32GB DDR3HDD: Samsung Evo 850 500gbGPU: GTX 980 SCLoad times are ultra snappy, especially compared to consoles, this is because of my SSD though, your mileage may vary depending on what you have. Note that I am also running this game on the highest settings at 1080p, with VOLUMETRIC FOG turned off. I owned this on my PS4 Pro before, and it is better on PC in every way.

author: MajinSephiroth
review: Let me start by saying I have been a fan of the series since the original titles, I've acquired and played every single version up until the 3DS. I've been wanting a PC port for the longest time and have gone to various titles in order to scratch the MH itch. In my humble opinion, this game has done an amazing job at creating the most remarkable experience for new and old players alike. New players to the series will never have to struggle with: - visiting their farm between every quest- having to be in the online guildhall in order to post quests for people to join - needing combo books to raise the crafting success chances- having to wait through gathering animations on different gathering points during missions- having to memorize where every gathering point is- carrying a map until you learn what area leads into another- loading screens between areasThe list goes on and on with everything this version has improved on over the past experiences. Graphically, the game is stunning, every map and environment feels like it is alive. The ecosystem interactions are great to see, frankly fun as well regardless how many times I watch a scripted event for territory struggles. While the game currently falls short on the networking bug that's been plaguing the community, I do not see it as the horrible experience people are talking about. Yes, it is annoying at times, but I'm still able to play with my friends regardless.Would I still be purchasing the game, knowing what I do now in regards to the bugs? Absolutely. The game itself is still the best in the series by a long shot. ***UPDATE*** Since my initial review, the game has undergone a ludicrous amount of bugfixes. I have yet to encounter any problems whatsoever with the game at this point. All aboard the hunting train!If you're new to the series and do not like a challenge, I will not recommend it to you. This game requires you to learn from your mistakes and not repeat them.

author: Trash Boat
review: As someone who enjoys the finer points of dressing cats in silly outfits, I found this game to be rather enjoyable. The initial customization options for your cat are a little basic, but do allow you to make a very cute cat. Once you get through the tutorials, the game really opens up in the cat customization options, and you can start making outfits for your cat to wear. The minigame where you have to explore the world and gather resources is a little tedious at times, but it's neat that you can take your cat out on walks with you and that part of the game does unlock more outfits for your cat, so that's cool.

author: Gigaton
review: Listen to the negative reviews. There's a reason such a high profile release is only MIXED in reviews. This game is one of the sloppiest PC ports I've seen in years. Performance wise, the only reason I'm playing it at fairly high framerates is because I have a beast of a PC built for VR. Other major new AAA titles I can run at ULTRA settings at buttery smooth framerates, but monster hunter world is just getting by.The primary problem with this game is that its' online component (which is required to enjoy the game and progress) is completely broken. You will basically be unable to stop the game from throwing Error codes in your face every few minutes as you try to play the game but lose progress and time constantly. Capcom has a history of bad PC ports with awful online network functionality, and the trend continues here. This may have been a great game on console, but Capcom lacks the capability to put out a decent PC product and appear not to have changed.Worst PC launch of 2018 for me. It's too bad the game's tutorial is so long that by the time most players discover how broken the game is, they will be long past the steam 2 hour refund period. Buyer beware.

review: An absolute masterpiece of a game with a massive amount of depth, you will need to hone your Weapon skills to stand a chance, can be frustrating at first because you feel that you are button mashing with no real sense of progress trying to learn how to use your weapon effectively. However if you persist and hang in there it will all click together and you will be rewarded with something special in Monster Hunter World. There are subtle nuances in the workings of every weapon and each feels quite unique. The monsters are varied and each has its own way of giving you different problems to deal with.A huge crafting and upgrade system also adds great depth to an already immersive experience.There is an Elephant in the room however in terms of some bugs and texture problems as well as a huge connection bug for multiplayer at launch that Capcom no doubt will fix very soon.Once the connection issues are fixed this is a MUST own on PC.

Playing with your friends is borderline impossible, with the constant disconnects, game crashing and bugs this is a flop.I have over 800+ hours clocked in on the ps4 version and most of the multiplayer issues were resolved in a matter of a few days. What makes this so ungodly infuriating is that when you go into a hunt with your friends the difficulty is amped up to give a challenge. However, if a player disconnects towards the end or in the middle of the fight the difficulty remains ramped up and all the items and traps you've used to fight w/e it is you're fighting will go to waste if you quit out.So for now I will continue to play through single player, but if you're after the multiplayer aspect stay far far away from this for now. author: Nonamo
review: Great game, but lacking many classic monsters such as the crab family of previous gens. Variety has been creeping back to the series over time, both with newer monsters alongside familiar faces. With the announcement of the final content patch however, it looks like we'll have to wait for the next MHW to see more.The game brought a number of quality of life updates, and the change to large seamless hunting grounds is a nice change. The seamless nature of the maps comes along with vastly larger areas to fight in - with some parts of a map spanning multiple levels. This in turn plays into the nature of combat changes in the game - much more mobile, and with a variety of ways to leverage verticality from pluging attacks, mounting, using the claw etc. Even simple slopes offer a change in fighting moves, offering context sensitive moves for every weapon.My one criticism of the game however, is the relatively short support life of Capcom's second foray into monster hunter on PC. Granted the game is multi-platform, and available on consoles; given the timing, I'm given to speculate whether this is due in part to the beginning of a new console life cycle. Comparatively, Monster Hunter Online, a Chinese exclusive MMO by Tencent in cooperation with Capcom, has had ongoing support and continuous content releases for about 7 years now. Why it is we can't see remotely the level of content support globally is unclear - but I would have a hard time seeing eye to eye with anyone who's had the privilege to exclusively access a Monster Hunter game for so long, and then decided to complain about Monster Hunter World this late into it's release.MHW is well worth the play through, and starting sooner than later will ensure you have an easier time experiencing co-operative play, essential for getting the most out of the Monster Hunter experience.

author: Squire Zed
review: It's difficult to recommend or not recommend this game because there are both problems and benefits that need to be balanced. Ultimately, I recommend Monster Hunter: World, not because it's perfect, but because for the price I've bought a lot worse. Let me put this bluntly: For most people this game is probably not more than a 6/10, especially with the launch issues. Add in some esoteric or plain missing instructions (nothing new for the series- in fact, this is the most welcoming Monster Hunter I've played, so by far it improves over the PSP era Monster Hunter games in terms of explaining what's going on). However, for the right kind of person, this is definitely a golden opportunity.Pros:Beautiful world with massive exploration areas, giant monsters to hunt, and tons of gear to craft.Rewarding sense of progression and tons of things to do to get better gear, new tools, and most importantly fight bigger and scarrier monsters.Gameplay that rewards skillful combat, attentive gathering, and careful memorization of locations and monster habits.Most welcoming and helpful Monster Hunter- a lot of mindless tasks and mundane busywork has been taken out, though don't worry, there's still mountains of grind to keep you busy.Cons:Did I mention mountains of grind? This game will eat up spare time and spit out gear that you'll throw away in an hour or two anyway.As of this review, the network stability is lacking. Capcom really screwed the pooch on this one. After poor network performance at launch on PS4, you'd think that they would prepare better, but they did not. Granted, sales were much beyond what they probably expected, but there's this thing called pre-orders that let you estimate how many people bought the game. It's poor design, compounded by the lack of offline play options from the menu (though you can play fine, by yourself, if you get disconnected from the internet). Since multiplayer is a huge draw, not having it work at launch is going to mean refunds and disappointment. Shame, Capcom.Performance woes. I personally have no performance issues if I'm running only Monster Hunter: World, Discord, Steam, and a few other unobtrusive background programs (though I see it chug if I have internet browsers or other resource hogs open). The optimization isn't awful, but it uses dynamic resolution scaling which means sometimes the picture looks a bit blurry. You won't probably notice this in combat, but while trying to get a scenic view, you can definitely notice the softness of upscaled resolution. While I want to believe Capcom when they say that they tried their best to optimize the game, I would like to see some basic improvements like removing Denuvo (which tanks CPU performance, which this game is poor at). We know from FOX Engine that you can have your quality cake and your framerate cake at the same time, and while not everything can be buttery magic smoothness, why saddle an engine that apparently just cannot be optimized with DRM that particularly limits the one area it performs worse? It's questionable design. Even if you want DRM, I'm sure there are alternatives that don't screw paying customers too- particularly because the multiplayer is a key component and one that only works through the (non-functional) official servers. It's disappointing because this port could use every leg up in performance, and instead it gets shot in the foot. Even though I have no major performance issues, my computer works incredibly hard- harder than it should, when even the unpolished flop of Metal Gear Survive which was pushed out Konami's door like an unwanted infant runs like a charm maxed out (on the admittedly absurdly great FOX Engine). It's 2018- optimization is a thing.They use the word "Slayed" (which is not a word) when you kill a monster- it should be slain. The monster has been slain. Slayed is a terrible word and even though it might be technically grammatically correct if you hate your soul, it just hurts me to try to say or think about or process that word. Ugh.So, after all of that, I'm still recommending the game. Why? Because I legitimately enjoy it. I had a huge grin on my face when I leapt on a Kulu-ya-ku with a bow while my Palico cheered me on, killing it with an arrow thrust through its heart. I had an experience of true terror when I ran around a corner face to face with a Rathalos (which I then foolishly tried and failed to kill). I've hunted Rathians in clearings that get torn to pieces and sunlight filters through once obstructed cannopies as monsters thrash and charge and fight. Every time I boot up, I hear that catchy tune in the home town and I know that I'm going to go kill a monster. It's fun. It lives up to expectations. It runs better than expected (with the caveats above). So yeah, I'm going to recommend the game. If you've played a Monster Hunter game and liked it, this is for you. If you haven't, but want to try it, go ahead. But if you didn't like earlier Monster Hunters, or you have a weak rig, or you want to have a buttery smooth 4k experience, maybe go somewhere else.

author: theonefrancis
review: Been following this title for a while. People around me know I'm not a fan of over-exaggerated asian styled games, but Monster Hunter World brings something completely new (or old, in this case) to the gaming industry: a fantastic, vibrant, dynamic world where enemies are not just bosses to kill. Each monster is unique and requires specific tactics to be brought down. Fighting a Jagras will never be as hard as chasing a Pukei-Pukei in a lush environment where you are not the strongest, nor the biggest. And right when you think you have the upper hand, a Rathian might come out of nowhere and turn you into a hunter roast, just because you have equipped armor that gives you a -2 resistance to fire.Hunting alone might be fun, but joining a group of people and take down one of the meanest creatures is something to remember. And nothing is as fun as using monster parts to craft weapons and armor made with the same monster parts and hunt monsters that will give you even more parts.There is something truly outstanding in a game like this. Don't really know what it is, but I will support this project a lot.So, come on friends, take your seven meters long sword and join the Fifth!Also, there are weird-ass cats around you all the time.

author: jaysnbullfrog
review: This is my first Monster Hunter game I've played and I've been smitten.  I can't say enough how much I adore this game.  From the quirky palicos to all the uniquely dangerous monsters, the expertly designed weapons to the vast amount of unique armors and skills that you can customize to create your perfect hunting builds.  This game was crafted with love and polished to a pristine shine out of the gate, a standard seemingly rare nowadays.  The story is there, but that's really it.  You won't care though because of all the fun to be had on every hunt.  Gameplay is king, and this game is the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ High-Ruler.  LONG LIVE THE KING!

author: Simistab
review: Great game, garbage netcode. Can spend hours trying to keep a single match (especially longer ones like zorah magdaros and multiple monster quests) to complete depending on who's connecting and when. Game really needs to step it up before expansion launch. At the very least, allow people to reconnect to the same session or allow someone else to connect in their stead. It really ruined the end game for me and my friends.Iceborne Update: Game still great, netcode still garbage, in fact even more than before. Capcom servers having issues? Disconnected. Someone with internet problems joins? Enjoy having 1 less spot in your party. I have two friends who can *never* play with each other. We can play with either of them separately for hours on end, zero issues, but the moment one of them joins the other it's like a nuke goes off. Doesn't matter who hosts the session, cause the moment these two beings connect the session completely dies, everyone disconnects, and you're stuck in offline mode till you restart the game. This has been a systematic issue for weeks, and we've tried every single recommendation online, from port forwarding to UDP to steam no friends ui to them hosting sessions, us hosting sessions, complete randoms hosting sessions, and literally dozens of other fixes or workarounds. I can't stress just how bad this game's internet issues are; this is legitimately the worst multiplayer gaming experience I have ever had the displeasure of playing in my entire life.

author: Hanabi
review: There is a lot that can be said about Monster Hunter: World, but I'll cover some basics first.One: This game is not an RPG, there is no choices or story changing moments with split paths, nor is it an open world romp like Farcry. You select missions and go into large zones that are populated by several monsters. At first this threw me off as I was expecting seamless transitions and a lot different than what I got. However for this difference it is not a bad game. it is very distinct, fun and memorable.Two: The Combat in this game is absolutely amazing the moves, the larger than life weapons, the feel of weight and impact. Every monster a lock, and your weapon, gear and playstyle the key. It moves both fast and with method, it pays for observational thinking.Three: The Artwork in the game is top notch, the zones are distinct and memorable, the creatures are fun and easy to enjoy visually. Never once do you feel like you're 'picking on the weak' this game does a good job of making you feel powerful without diminishing your enemies.Four: The DLC/Expansion aspect is really well done, there are some cosmetic extras you can buy, but everything meaningful has been thrown in the game, and the upcoming expansion pack promises more monsters, more weapons, more everything you'd want from the game rather than nickle and dime DLC.Five: Events, the REAL endgame of Monster Hunter world is here, the events can be as simple as refacing an old enemy, to having fun battles against 3 giant red dogs to a Devil May Cry theme trying to earn Dante's Coat, to ACTUALLY playing as Garalt of Rivia being thrown into the game vie a portal incident (This one made me want a full length RPG of Garalt exploring Monster Hunter's world.)Six: Difficulty. The game is hard, but its difficulty isn't savage depending on how you play, certain weapons have a better margin for error, but less bursts. Some monsters are absolutely savage to the extreme, others, not so much. It isn't one hit and you die in most cases unless you're enemy is hitting your weak element or you're facing some kind of super boss move. Most deaths come from a multitude of slip ups on your part, letting that monster jab you enough times to stun you right before its Haymaker, or hanging out with low health too long trying to whittle the monster. It is an easy game to pick up, easy to learn. But a LOT of your power is how you become skilled with your weapons while a smaller portion is your gear level. Things like elements, weaknesses, rather you cut, blast or pierce, all help define what monsters will be harder or conversely easier. If a complex system of measured combat is difficult to you, than this will be Dark Souls, but if you easily grasp concepts and are wary and keen, it won't be hell at all.So this is recommended. Does it have flaws? Yes. I wish it had more RPG elements, or that the protagonist wasn't just silent. Or at least I wish the game would recognize your being mute and poke humor at it. Or that everything was fully voiced. Or the UI system was more smooth and less of a pain in the ass. But NOTHING in its flaws outweighs what it does in its favor.If you know you won't like it, don't buy it. If you have doubts, and are interested, buy it. If you love these sort of games, buy it. If you love fantasy, buy it. If you're a boring person and are sad, buy it, it'll make you more interesting.BUY IT! BUY IT NOW! BUY IT ON DEAL! BUY IT FOR YOUR FRIENDS! IT GOES MULTIPLAYER UP TO FOUR PEOPLE WHICH IS PART OF THE FUN!

author: Ghostrunner
review: So here is a real honest review, after 207 hours of gameplay. First id like to say for those who dont want to read an essay, this game got an undeserved bad rep. I mean sure the game has issues but they arent ones that justify it being given a 45% total score. So let me just address the issues really quick, or at least the ones I know of that have impacted me. In the first week of release the multiplayer of this game was horrific, I mean seriously. You would queue up a quest with your friends, get about 5 minutes in and then be disconnected. The way the game works it also meant that even if your friends did disconnect, although the match wouldnt end and you would all be against the monster in your own solo missions, the monster would retain its multiplayer difficulty level and still does to this day. This means that when the multiplayer crashes, for the most part the mission is unplayable. Other issues I encountered was just how much CPU this game eats up. Like seriously, what is it doing? Its running at 97% CPU and sometimes during the handler cooking cutscene it makes my pc grind down to the point where it seems like its dying. These however are my only issues with the game, and the multiplayer has dramatically improved, however still not amazing its at least playable 90% of the time and im sure with consistent fixes it will become 100%. The CPU issue, im no computer scientist but im sure they can patch the game or do something to optimise it so it doesnt eat such an ungodly amount of CPU. Now to the positives, and they really are positive. This game is beyond refreshing to me, this game has and will continue to provide me with hours of amazing entertainment. The satisfaction levels on this game are the highest ive ever felt playing a game, whether its beating a boss by the skin of your teeth in the early game, to grinding and farming rare item drops to try and take on the tougher end game tempered bosses, the progression of this game is superb, you overcome mountains each day and consistently improve. The weapon choice is amazing, you can play the hard hitting mass damage greatsword with a slow and devastating play style, or you can go rapid damage dual blades, even using my personal favourite the insect glaive where you can do all sorts of acrobatics around the monster applying debuffs or explosive clouds. The combat truely is wonderful, there are so many different weapons and thanks to the jewels and skills there are so many ways to play these weapons which means you can play a bit of everything and mix things up so you never feel bored. In terms of monsters, yes i would like a greater variation many monsters are very similar and there are far too many damn flying monsters for my liking and yes I would love some more balancing as although there are so many armour sets, in the end game stage really only a handfull are actually viable, id love for them to be a bit more balanced and be able to run these obscure pieces without getting smashed because theyre so low defense. I think they really need to release the DLC asap to bring it to the same level as the console version as Im incredibly jealous of the console gamers having behemoth and kulve but the game hasnt been out long so i can only hope it does come out and soon enough. I think the reason this game got so badly recieved is because people just took it at face value, we had to wait 8 months for what is essentially a vanilla port that on release had a host of issues so people just took straight to steam to leave bad reviews, if people actually took a step back and played the game as it improved and gave it a chance then they would see that actually this game is incredible and without a doubt my favourite release in the last 5 years at least.

author: DT_RicoRaynn
review: Ok, this is my first legit attempt to play a Monster Hunter game. I tried a gaem cube version way back when if I remeber right and it didn't hook me. So I'll try to break down what I experienced.ProsThe Early Game: It immediately throws you into the action. The tutorial is very well done, not bogging you down with boredom as it explains the games systems.The Graphics: Not much more to say then they are gorgeous. You can tell real care went into the enviroments. The level of detail is astounding and everything you look at is beautiful. The Weapons: A large variety of weaponary at your fingers allows for every hunter to play a bit different. Moving from a bowgun to a longsword instantly makes it a new game style.The Monsters: From the first moment you engage an Anju right outside your starting HUB you're trasfixed at how epic and powerful this battle feels. Each monster is unique and a enjoyable experience to battle. You honestly feel like a bad ass.Palicos: I'm a 16 year army infantry veteran with over 50 months deployed to combat zones. This little bastards made me smile and laugh more times then I can count. They're cute lite ♥♥♥♥♥.Gathering mechanics: alot of care went into trying to hide the 'grind' when it came to gathering mechanics. You can see that. While the grind is still there, the used clever methods to try and make it less noticable from sending out palico expeditions, to gathering on the run, to buying boat loads of crap when the ships come into harbor. ConsThe Controls: this may be the weirdest set of PC controls Ive ever encountered in a video game. Seriously, these things are so weird you have to wonder if the designer was high on bath salts and watching anime when he developed them. They aren't impossible to learn and by hour 3 it will be 2nd nature. Just be preparred to struggle if you take a break or play multiple games at a time. The Zones: while the zones are beautiful there are only 5 of them. Since you will be hunting in these until ad nauseum you will get bored with them.Melee Combat: Melee combat is definetly not for me. I've seen some amazing fighters in melee, but the half ass targetting system and the weird camera angles made melee combat feel clunky and slow imo. Random Monsters: It very common due to the pathing of monsters and the 'tunneling' of most areas that some random monster you have zero interest in will wander into your fight and try to screw everything up. Because of the AI its almost constant on each map and doesn't feel 'natural'. Just bring dookie balls and chase them away.The Armor: ok, some of the sets are incredible fantasy dreams that you're stoked to try and earn. Issue is, if you're trying to design a legit build for hunting, be preparred to look like you just raided and Five and Dime store while choosing accessories at a Salvation Army. Gems: This is probably the most annoying thing about the game. You will be overloaded with gems. Issue is, most of them will be the equivalent of all those pennies you leave in that jar at home. You'll horde them because they're worth something but never really do anything with them. To get the gems you really want involves a 'merge' system which is basically a casino system. So pray to RNG gods.The Network: This is attrocious. Disconnects, random drops, broken groups, grouping bugs. Its gotten a hell of a lot better since launch but it still struggles. Combined with a weird invite system and 'instancing' trying to get a group of friends together is a headache the first dozen times. The Grind: This game is a grind. No question about it. While they have gone out of their way to try and hide some of the systems in unique ways you will be putting in the time. With only 5 zones and about 30 monsters you're gonna burn out (I hit mine around the 80 hour mark). Overall this is a quality game and deserves the praise it has been receiving. I've had fantastic moments in it and any game you can play 80 hours of before hitting the burn out is worht the price. However, its akward controls and demmanding skill game play mean this will be alot like For Honor. It will be hard to jump back in if you take a break once in awhile (and perform at the level you used to).

author: Turboshook™
review: Review to follow at a later date.EDIT:First things first. Yeah, controllers are not recognized by default yet. Yes, it is kind of annoying, but easily fixed by enabling the steam controller API. You can even disable big picture mode launching whenever steam detects a controller for good measure. There are also a handful of multiplayer connectivity issues and I can only imagine that they will be ironed out in the near future, this being release weekend and whatnot. The majority of the negative reviews for this game are because a) someone took one of the above points very personally b) there is not a certain graphical setting that they want, or c) they just don't like MH games or this particular style of combat. To entirely write off a game as massive as this within your first two or so hours of playing for any of those reasons seems foolish to me. A fully detailed review of my thoughts on this game so far would be too long for anyone to justify reading, so I will just leave my whole-hearted recommendation here for anyone who cares to read it. I am having the time of my life with this game, as I have with every MH game I've gotten my hands on since discovering the series back in high school.

author: Judy Bigbooty
review: There are very few games that I can recommend 100%, especially among AAA titles. Monster Hunter: World is one of those games.In the past, I've only ever dabbled in the Monster Hunter franchise. I own a game on the PSP, 2 on the 3DS, and I even picked up Generations Ultimate on my Switch, because I enjoyed World so much.I can say, without a doubt, the changes made in this title compared to the other games have made it not only more easy to get into, but incredibly fun and engaging. The difficulty curve makes the experience a gradual ramp up, rather than being thrown straight into the fire instead of the frying pan throughout (albeit with a few sudden stops in the form of the "walls" that are some of the early, more difficult monsters).The best part of the game, by far, is the visual fidelity. The sheer level of detail that this game has given its world and characters/creatures is astounding, to say the least, especially when considering how previous titles have looked in comparison. That, and the game actually has a story. Not the most complex story, but to have some context for what the player is doing (outside of a few, long text boxes rattling off) is much appreciated.Oh yeah, and the modding scene is progressively getting better and better, too.For all my praise, the game is not without its faults.Certain game mechanics could be better explained to players. The late-game grind for decorations, as well as the general grind for materials, can be incredibly draining at times.My main gripe would be the lack of monster and weapon variety. While there is a decent handful of monsters to hunt, after subsequent grinds for materials, it becomes more and more apparent just how few monsters there are than previous titles.The weapon variety is especially bad. Only a set few weapons have any visual difference beyond just tacking on a bit of monster parts onto the same 2 to 3 weapon models that we've seen time and time again. It can be very disheartening, as it takes away the feeling of progress, apart from just a bigger number in the stats.Despite all that, I still recommend this game to anyone looking for something fun and interesting, but a little challenging.Not sure why there are so many mixed reviews, but I'd blame that on server issues, which, speaking from personal experience, haven't been a real problem for quite some time.Definitely worth the buy. Happy hunting!

review: All in all is worth,i played MH since the old ones for PSP and 3DS, was expecting a lot from this game and the overall is positive.They definitely did it more playable and less 'nerdy', all the gathering system is a way more duable without spending tens of hours doing harvesting mission, otherwise how could you make it spreads so much?So probably to make an high end armor you won't spend 800 hours anymore, and tho have a decent amount of honey you don't need to stay awake nights harvesting it.It's easyer, the early game is good, but i think that in the high end you kinda be a bit more OP respect to the monsters, but i still didn't reach that level so i'm still hoping the opposite.It has a super nice graphic, the maps are breathtaking, it's updated often introducing new missions and monsters, and it's the firs MH for PC (if we don't consider the Frontier) so i suggest it to all the old HD MH player but also the the new hunters.

author: Xoroxous
review: Monster hunter randomly hard crashed on me while i was doing a quest with my friends. Was in the middle of combat and the game hard crashed to desktop. I reload back into the game and the game has me go back through the whole tutorial (which you are unable to skip.). author: y2s
review: I've just reached 1000 hours on this game and all I've got to say is dang I never expected to stick around this long playing the game and honestly I've become a huge fan. Moreover, I've enjoyed every moment playing this game despite it being my very first Monster Hunter game ever.I'll be honest, it was  and different in the beginning but that feeling goes for most games that feel foreign to you, so be a little patient. Heck, it was even in the process of being refunded after I really wasn't feeling the game's combat, It felt really slow and clunky to me. That feeling died soon after, when a friend of mine convinced me to stick around for a bit since the Monster Hunter genre . Ever since then, I learned the  and here I am with over 1000 hours in the game. I would like to highlight that I  to be able to enjoy and learn how to play the game. I did however go around hopping one weapon to the other at the start, ranging from the Switchaxe, the Insect Glaive, Dual Blades and so on. I finally settled on the , which is a  and probably the  in the game IMO, which can still be used in the game's end game content. With that being said, learning how to play all the  a challenge since each of those weapons have their own and a couple of combos to learn. With enough practice you can learn all of the weapons. However, I strongly advise players to as you don't want to become a Jack of all trades in the very start of the game. Ideally, you would want to  using the weapon of your choosing. Mastering a weapon though is a hard feat, which will take hours upon hours of practice to be able to use a weapon to its full potential. In contrast, the story wasn't too appealing IMO, so if you're a player that's playing this game for the story sorry to break it to you but there's none. Monster hunter serves  for the monsters and endemic life if you're into that.Moving on, I had already put in around 400 ish hours into base game before I progressed into Iceborne, in which I would . Once you've gotten a feel for the game, you'll probably enjoy hunting the more faster paced monsters in Iceborne; Of course you can do whatever you want, that's my personal opinion on how to enjoy the Monster Hunter experience as a beginner player. Moving on to when I first started Iceborne, the game had become a  but VERY enjoyable with a variety of new monsters that hit like a truck (Even with the best armor from base game which if I recall correctly, was the Drachen armor set from the Final Fantasy crossover monster Behemoth; the new monsters made base game armor feel like tinfoil). Every new monster that had been included in the DLC was a . Being able to fight monsters that I had missed out on in the previous Monster Hunter titles too was a great experience. Not to mention, the new  that came with the DLC and the  for the 14 weapons in the game changed the  of the hunts for me in a good way.In conclusion, my experience with Monster Hunter: World has been  so far and would probably still provide pleasant experiences until maybe a World 2 comes out. With this in mind, I would . When starting the game though, I'd recommend you at least invest a  and I promise you, you'll get your money's worth. Of course, it's okay if you don't like this game as it really isn't for everyone. (In short, I'm calling you a b*tch). Happy hunting!! :)

author: scypism
review: I'm really a fan of this game ever since it started on PSP more than 10 years ago.Now that it's on PC, a lot has improved and I can say that the lesser monsters are easy but the arch tempered elder dragons are not.Since my friends do not play this game, I usually play multiplayer via Respond to SOS.The mechanics are nice since you are able to play (co-op) with random people.What I don't like about it is that the host (player who fired the SOS) can disconnect you anytime.What I hate about it is that for harder quests (AT elder dragons), some hosts abuse this "power" by disconnecting other players when the monster is about to die. AT Elder dragons for multiplayer are still very hard to kill alone even when they are about to die because HP is still set for multiplayer and your lone damage becomes insufficient.I hope something can be done about this "power" like limiting it to half the time of the quest or the state of the monster.It's really annoying, frustrating and disappointing when you participated well in one quest for a long duration and the host just kicks you out for no valid reason. Please really do something about this. Thanks!

author: Typh
review: I'm playing this game on an i3-6100 and a 1080 with a Switch Pro Controller. I get no frame drops except during very specific hunts in certain areas, and that's with max settings besides the fog setting (volumetric something) being turned off/as low as possible. The pro controller works splendidly after turning on the pro controller setting in big picture.Excellent game. If you've wanted to try a Monster Hunter game, this is the one to try. It's very satisfying to learn each monster's patterns and succeed, as well as learning each of the 14 weapons while crafting your way up to some badass (or cute!) designs of weapons, armor, and Palico armor.For those that don't know, a Palico is a slightly anthropomorphized cat (walks on hind legs primarily, but other than that still very catlike) that acts as your companion, and is customizable much like your character. It can use some special gadgets to help you, like with heals or buffs or even one that gets more crafting materials for you.My biggest complaint is the lack of variety in weapon design in some of the weapon classes. Hunting Horn, Hammer, and a few others have very little variety in their crafting trees until you start unlocking the very end of the trees, where they are usually more varied. If you're a Fashion Hunter at heart in other games, then you might be disappointed with the weapons. Otherwise, great game that I highly recommend. This was the first $60 game that I haven't regretted buying in years, and I plan on picking up MHGU on the Switch as soon as I can.

Now let's talk about the positives, the environment and character designs are just brilliant! A sight for sore eyes indeed. Smart gameplay mechanics embedded into the 14 wepon types and the method of upgrading them is very smartly done, the grind isn't a strenuous repetative process like the older Monster hunters or other such games (warframe, I'm looking at you).The game dose a great deal in letting the players understand the how's and why's all you need to do is pay attention to the text and tutorial instructions from time to time ( or you could skip and head over to a wiki after wasting hours trying to figure out how things work) ALL IN ALL A WELL DONE GAME ! Capcom never ceases to impress.

author: Rokurai
review: I see alot of reviews bashing this game for its online component(which is currently unstable, I grant you, but so was console in the first couple of weeks, and now it's sorted). However this does not properly reflect the game itself, and would be a bad way of reviewing any game or product, much like saying "I don't like this car because the bluetooth functionality won't currently pair with my moble device." With that in mind, I'll attempt to review my experience of the GAME part of this product so far. Full disclosure: I've played the Monster Huinter franchise since MH3 Ultimate came to the West. I have over 1600 hours logged across multiple save files in MH3U, MH4U, MHGen, MHXX, and MHW Console Ver(PS4). I obviously like this series. The gameplay is great:The controls are smooth and responsive, and I've had no problems getting the game to sync up instantly to PS4 and XBOne controllers I plug in. The only issue I've really seen so far is when utilizing more than five simoultaneous inputs from a keyboard, the game sometimes (or maybe my system?) prioritizes the older key press first, resulting in what feels like a stuck keypress. Capcom said they were working on mouse and keyboard fixes, so that should hopefully be resolved soon. The environments behave like they feel they should when interacted with, and the monsters feel appropriately ferocious and/or comical. The Capcom Desire Sensor(TM) makes a strong comeback, making sure you'll grind long and hard for that gear you really want that looks so sweet, but it's part of what makes it so satisfying to get that armor or weapon. And the ticket exchange system somewhat softens the blow by allowing you to get rare monster parts if you do a number of monster bounties every week. Overall a good balance between grind/reward and RNG avoidance.The graphics are great: I won't pretend that it'll run on a potato, but I will say that even on the lowest graphics, at 60fps this game still looks better than some full graphics-locked releases out there. At highest graphics, the environments are breathtaking, and the ambience the game sound and music create works very well with the visual effects. There are some minor visual clipping issues with large monsters that have died, but in all honesty it's surprising there aren't more, given the size and complexity of the maps. The story is great: While I realise most people are here to gather mushrooms and hit monsters in the face until they die, the plot of this game is actually quite engaging if you take your time to explore the world and interact with the NPCs(derpy and endearing as they are). They really tried to make the maps feel inter-connected, and explain why so many different environments are in such proximity to one another. They tried to make the ecosystem feel alive, and, in my opinion, they succeeded.The netcode needs to catch up:People are complaining about Capcom not responding to their complaints, but Capcom has already stated they know about the connection issues and are working on them. A few days into the game's full release, Capcom additionally acknowledged issues with they keyboard and mouse controlls posted on forums and Steam boards. This does not mean they stopped working on the netcode issue, it means that they monitor community feedback and are responsive. It took two weeks on PS4 before online play was stable, but it would have been nice to have the issues resolved on release this time around. I realise netcode for console and PC are different, so I'm willing to be patient, considering how outstanding this game is in every other aspect. Actual online mechanics concerns(not netcode related):My only gripe with the actual mechanics of how online works on the PC version vs. the console version is the decision to do away with Squads. Squads, for those who are unaware, were essentially like little guilds or groups of 50 players. You could be part of multiple squads at a time and you could always go to a private squad session for a squad you were in regardless of whether or not there were other people in the squad hall. The reason I miss this is that if your friends are otherwise preoccupied hitting a monster in the face, they cant really go into a menu to copy/paste a session ID so you can hop into their hunt to help them out without the necessity of an SOS flare opening the hunt to everyone online. If joining a private session from your steam friend's list didn't require a session ID(an easy fix) Even this minor gripe would be resolved. Future development:For the console, the developers add free new content to this game on a regular basis(and have stated that ONLY cosmetic changes will cost anything, if you should choose to indulge in them), with balance issues being addressed, known bugs being fixed, and new hunts and events being introduced. I see no reason to suspect anything different will be the case for the PC version, especially as it is several months behind the console release, and thus it would be simple to head off problems before they have a chance to develop into game-breaking bugs. All in all, I guess what I'm most concerned about is that the general negativity towards this one issue with the game could spiral out of control and scare people away from playing this game before the game has a chance to get off the ground properly. I mean, Just look at the review score currently, and get a sample size to see how many of those negative reviews boil down to "online is broken, therefore game sucks." Also, I won't go into reviewing any modding until Capcom makes their stance on graphics overhaul mods and the like clear.

author: Gilwage
review: If you enjoy Souls-y combat, Elder Scrolls-y resource collection, gorgeous graphics, great character customisation, interesting and diverse playstyles, co-op, and just a bit (maybe a lot bit) of grinding, this is a title for you!Cons?A lot of complaints in the reviews are about the delayed release, the initially shoddy port from console and how long it took to fix. Perhaps my review would be different if I had pre-ordered - or owned the game when connection problems were still a major issue.Do the devs deserve your money? Maybe. You be the judge.Whether they do or don't, though, you probably deserve to ignore all of that and just enjoy a sweet game.Personally, my biggest issue with the game is pretty minor - keyboard controls were difficult. No problem if you've got a controller, though.Here's what's good.Although the quests often feel a bit like your average MMO quests in that they can seem pretty arbitrary and typically involve simply killing something or handing in some items, this game makes killing things and getting loot  rewarding. The act of physically carving up a dead monster rather than walking up to its corpse and pressing Loot All is really satisfying, and I'm certainly not tired of grabbing every plant, insect, bone and shiny rock that I pass.Another thing the game gets right is making every hunt feel like a big deal. Picking the right gear, having a good meal, heading out to the quest area and tracking a monster all serve to build anticipation for the big fight in a way that a lot of games just don't do. Even if I've previously taken down several specimens of the particular monster I'm hunting, I'm still excited to bring down another.The main thing, though? Combat - the heart of the game - is . Once you figure out which weapon you prefer and how to use it effectively (you might wanna Google it - the tutorials can be a little patchy and might not tell you everything. And practice! There's a training area), you're ready to have yourself a grand old time. Seeing a big monster reel from your attacks is always delightful.Part of why I think this is a great game may come from being new to the series. Some people have said that Monster Hunter veterans might not enjoy this game because of its differences to previous titles, and I'm in no position to refute that. If, like me, you're new to Monster Hunter, you're in luck! Veterans, maybe think about it a little longer before you buy.(Highly recommend playing with a controller - haven't tried KBM since recent update which improved it though)EDIT: At 1500 hours, I stand by the above written at 500 hours. And I want to add that the extra work that's been poured into new content, including Iceborne, has been amazing. Iceborne fixed a lot of the dependence on RNG for endgame weapon customisation and expanded immensely on how the game can be played. And the QoL improvements are fantastic.

author: Salt
review: This is the first game I've played in Monster Hunter series, and lemme tell you, it's quite intimidating with the amount of weapon choices available, theres alot that the game creators didnt bother to explain (there are youtube vids to help with that, BUT, if you stick around & get gud it becomes a rewarding experience.Great game, 10/10.

author: Finzy
review: I played this to hunter rank 50 on PS4 before so my review is gonna be heavily based on that (my PC impressions are at bottom). This is the first Monster Hunter game I've played and I generally really liked it. For anyone new to the series it's definitely the best one to pick up. The gameplay is basically kind of like boss fights all over the place with differently weighted weapons and so forth. Most movements are slow and you have to commit to the attacks and stuff you do. Every weapon offers a completely different and unique playstyle. First I played through using the Switchaxe and Bow and now on my second playthrough I'm using the Charge Blade and it's a lot of fun re-learning the game (checked other weapons too but those are my mains).The actual hunting feels very rewarding and for a game with SO much grinding it does a good job at not making it tedious because you're constantly chainsawing the ♥♥♥♥ out of those poor innocent monsters, forest animals, lizards, whatever crosses your path. You carve them up for a nice new set of armor. Or capture them so you can fight them again more conveniently. And each fight feels like a proper challenge worth your time. At least if you're playing solo or duo with a smaller group. Multiplayer can be a bit all over the place there so I would recommend people learn to hunt on their own as well. Both because grouping up doesn't always work and it helps you learn and appreciate the game more. There's also dumb restrictions in multiplayer, you have to have watched the story cutscenes before you are allowed to play with other players, wish IMHO should've been removed. I played through the PS4 version mostly duo with a friend and we still managed somehow but had to do a lot of abandoning quests to co-op through it, especially at the start of the game (later on it's a bit better and they let you group up more). Although duoing the game is pretty fun because you get 4x monster HP (and we kicked ass).The game definitely takes some learning and commitment but I would say it is the easiest approachable MH game for sure. There was even too much hand holding in the start of the game in my opinion, because I kept wanting to do harder stuff right out of the bat. And that would be most of my complaints core gameplay wise, throughout Low Rank and High Rank you have plenty of story stuff to do and it easily lasts probably at least 40 hours or more to get to the end of High Rank and start on Tempered monsters, depending on how quick you are (it was about 50+ hrs for me on PS4 iirc, but I took my time). And even after you 'beat' the game you basically just unlock a new tier of monsters and even entirely new ones, so you can keep playing for a very long time without seeing everything. I just wish the game let me fight harder monsters sooner, on PS4 I had fought Tempered Elder Dragons on a friend's investigation before even getting there way later.TL;DRSo how is it on PC? The port is not completely terrible, you have decent graphics options, and it runs okay at 1440p on high-ish settings on my 1070 GTX, although I did have to drop some stuff and expected a bit better performance (average something between 45-60 FPS). The multiplayer had some connection issues before but they have improved over some patches. One thing that really bugs me about the game is that the texture quality is really AWFUL in places. Some textures legit look PS2 quality for whatever reason on Full settings and I'm confused how that got past QA as a 'bug'. Even the PS4 version had better texture quality as far as I know so it should really be fixed...(and a fix is coming eventually, apparently?).At least compared to the PS4 version the game does load a million times faster, switching between quests takes about 5 seconds at best, and the FPS is better than that version at least. :P (which ran about 30 FPS).If you have the PC to run it and the gameplay sounds interesting I'd give it a shot. Otherwise the PS4 version may be better. I felt that it wasn't fair to judge the game purely based on its technical performance so my thumbs up is from the gameplay, which is great. There's some flaws in multiplayer they could fix in future titles for sure though, but it's not all bad.

author: Ploopyloopy
review: Friend purchased the bundle for me, as I was looking for a new game to play and couldn't afford to buy this game myself. I am so grateful to have been gifted this game, as I have really been enjoying myself playing it. I have been playing battle royales for the past 2 years nonstop, and needed something different. I have a 1660 TI and everything runs well and looks amazing. I stay at a capped 60 frames, but can sometimes dip down due to my CPU not being the greatest. Overall, I highly recommend this game, including the DLC. If you have been thinking about it, I would just do it.

author: Chromehawk_xP
review: I have played the monster hunter series since PS2 days, and a lot on PSP. This is easily the best in the series and easiest for new comers. I know there are a lot of mechanics, however it is the easiest to get into and all of the harder mechanics are streamlined in a way that makes it easy to learn. I would highly recommend this game if you like hack and slash games, or a new game to escape to. The world is incredibly crafted, even if the story isn't for everyone because there really isn't one other than kill these monsters. Monster hunter was never known for its story, its addictive gameplay and core looter style makes you want to hunt just one more monster, and look at the clock at 4am saying ♥♥♥♥ i have work in an hour.

author: BobaFettish
review: I really enjoy the variety in weapons that you can master as well as the difference in the monster fights. Mastering each weapon and each monster is what has kept me going so long. (Of coarse if speed running is your thing then you need to be top notch and have the best gear)
