author: _WYzARd
review: Update after 220 hours of play hours:- this game is a must for people who love grinding game.- this game have a very high replayability so it's worth the money (i think.. the DC problem i think is decreased a lot)- just need a performance optimization and ability to turn off the motion blur- it's a very well made game.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------yes this game has connection issue (that being fix as the time goes by)..-yes this game doesn't have the option to turn off the motion blur or option for FOV slider (i get motion sick easily)..-yes this game have many bugs, but it's still playable..-does it worth the price? i don't know for everyone else, but for me it's worth it. i'm playing this game for almost 100 hours, and i never play MHW on ps4 before, the game itself pretty amazing, even though this game basically just grind for a better gear, it's never feel repetitive, i mean like MOBA's or FPS multiplayer games, it's always the same, but on contrary it's always a unique experience.- does it have a good story? for me the story is just an usual monster hunter life in the new explored area, nothing special, but not bad.-does it have a good music? yes, i even humming it everytime, i always hear the HQ theme music on my head even i'm not playing. and then everytime i heard bazel music theme, i'll always laugh (cuz the yung maestro video).- does it have a good optimization? sadly no, there's no option to turn off motion blur, the camera movement is emulating a controller movement. the texture isn't in high res. and i often forget the shortcut key for my items, for now it's best you play with a controller, altough for 80 hours of the games i played it with my KB/M (it's still playable playing it with KB/M).. - how about Multiplayer? at first launch, i always get constant DC when joining quest, or SOS, or even in the middle of quest or  even searching for a session. but as time goes by, the DC frequency is lower.. and now, i almost never DC.. but this is not true to everyone. the multiplayer itself is fun, i strongly suggest for multiplayer run since it more fun, but it's more and more fun in endgame.so is it worth the full price? it depends, for me it's worth it, great game, high production value, this game maybe not having a perfect PC optimization like GTA V or witcher 3, but it's still a great game. so for you that not too sure to buy this game, just wait for another update, or wait for sale. or try watch the gameplay on youtube, or twitch.. or just buy it, and try it for first 2 hours, not satisfied? just refund. hehe...sooo..overall, great games, great monster hunter games, a mediocre pc port.do i recommend it? Yes.for me it's 90/100want to but this game?buy it here:

author: quickflint
review: I love Monster Hunter and finally having a version on PC has been great.  This game scales back some of the more frustrating aspects of the game and really gives new players a warm welcome.  I was able to introduce multiple friends to Monster Hunter because of this game.  The currently Mixed reviews are a result of early issues with network connections.  This was fixed quite some time ago.  The game runs great, looks great, and plays fantastically.

author: Mamaya
review: While not the best entry in the series, Monster Hunter: World still holds up as an amazing experience whether you're playing solo or with friends. With a bunch of old systems revamped for the better, the result is a game that is so fluid you just wanna run around in it. Timed events are annoying however, this game will force you to play it at its own terms rather than yours, but it should only be truly annoying for the completionist types.With Iceborne released the game got a bunch of new content and it's mostly all for the better. There's a few fatal mistakes(special scope for HBG being the first that comes to mind) but overall the game has improved.Happily waiting for the next entry in the series.

author: Ryanide
review: Overall, this game is great. The game itself runs well, the areas and monsters look amazing, and the progression system is pretty large overall. It'll keep me playing for a while.However, the network issues are a huge problem, so to anyone who intends to play this game with friends who is on the fence about getting it, wait for them to hopefully fix the network issues.Otherwise, I'd highly recommend this game. The network issues are the only problems I've had with it so far. Also I'd recommend playing this game on a controller, the keyboard/mouse controls are akin to a game like Dark Souls in my opinion and its not worth trying.

author: I love Moeka Shiotsuka
review: though I like this game a lot, but the server is an absolute nightmare, and when your friends disconnected from your quest, the rewards is still decreased and some balance issues, still, I do enjoy it a lot due to how every thing works so nicely gameplay-wise. I will recommend it, but the issues are still being acknowledged at the moment.

author: Maxime
review: Game is great so far, solo'd most of the quests in the beginning but eventually played with friends.Combat is good, lock-on could be better and the part where if I'm on the same quest as a friend we can't play it together unless we both get past the cutscene part. The network errors are a pain in the ass but besides that it is great!

author: r3d_belmont456
review: I'm revising this review because after the recent update that has somewhat lessened the disconnect issue as as well with a bit of Tweaking of my own after reading some fixes, game pretty much runs as good as it's probably gonna get for a good while. Here's what I did to fix it and I hope it helps you guys too. So it seems that the bad optimizations are part the game engine, and part the bad profiles on Nvidia's part for said game. So after installing a little program called Nvidia Inspector, running the profile inspector, locating the Monster Hunter World Profile and Deleting it, the game suddenly ran perfectly even in areas that would absolutely kill my FPS on medium settings. So now I am playing the game happily on maxed settings without any hitches or ever dropping frames which is GREAT!Some video settings are still broken mind you... Water Reflections still don't work right and texture setting is still broken (unless you download the High Res Texture DLC which is free and highly recommended for 1070 8GB Vram and up Card owners...), but at least the game is stable enough now and I don't have to make the game look ugly for it. It's a good thing too because this game is honestly great, It's everything I've ever liked in Monster Hunter games and More! Definitely a must buy if you're a fan...+Very Extensive Customization/Personalization where you can really differentiate your hunter/palico's base appearance as well as your Guild Card, your Gesture quotes, among other things...+14 Different weapons to choose from, all with their strenghts and weaknesses on top of a plethora of tools at your disposal.+Many MANY quests to undertake, and monsters to Slay or Capture+Very Extensive Crafting... +Frequently updated with new quests and Monster Hunts for free+A HUGE amount of Quality of Life changes (too many to list) from Previous Monster Hunter games that make this a very VERY welcoming experience that significantly lessens those dull moments and emphasizes on the stuff that Makes Monster Hunter an amazing game to play.+Monsters can now Infight which I absolutely LOVE btw (Kaiju battle anyone?)-Despite looking like a 10 year old game, MHW is a Mediocre and Needlessly Resource Heavy PC port... You'll have to do quite a bit of tweakning to get the game running well, especially on lower end specs, or use a mod or three (somewhat fixed between Nvidia Driver updates and recent QoL updates, Getting more frames than when game launched but can still cause issues on certain setups).-Keyboard and Mouse Controls may be hit or miss, even tho they are fully rebindable. Mouse Accel that you cannot turn off (Mouse Controls fixed as of 9/20/18 thanks to Type 2 mouse aim setting, but the way the Radial Menu handles on K+M can still use some work)...-Cannot rebind Controller at all (just like Dark Souls), well... technically you CAN swap some buttons around but it is so limited it may as well not exist. Default Controller layout may turn some people off...-Combat is most definitely not for everyone (slow, clunky and incredibly weighty)-Tutorial is a bit slow paced, but this may not be a bad thing since it's a bit more hands off than previous installments...If you want to know more about the PC version of Monster Hunter World, I highly recommend watching the Digital Foundry Analysis vid, both for comparison and troubleshooting purposes as it is highly insightful...I currently give MHW on PC a 9 out of 10, Highly Recommended to buy, especially on sale!

author: Oliverserker
review: Edited my review because I have nothing to do today.THE GOOD:1. Mainstream Monster Hunter on PC. No longer do I need to learn Korean to play Frontier.2. More immersive. Wildlife seems to be more realistic (Most monsters on the lower end of the foodchain try to hide or escape upon seeing a bigger bad)3. Turf wars. Monsters have special animations when fighting each other for territory.4. Movement is more fluid.5. Hitbox is pretty accurate. If a monster tail passed above your head and missed you by an inch, it won't hit you. No more bullsh*t hipchecks.THE SO-SO1. Horrible camera controls for mouse users have been FIXED2. Difficulty in joining online sessions has been FIXED3. Constant disconnects from online sessions have been FIXED 4. Food looks good.THE BAD:1. Very ugly, Fortnite-level textures on some objects despite being on the highest setting. NOT YET FIXED.2. People getting carted (killed) in the first 5 minutes of every hunt.3. Lack of monster variety. Why does the Old World have more monsters despite being the cradle of humans and hunters.4. Map count is very limited compared to previous titles. Even the first Monster Hunter on the PS2 has more maps iirc.5. The game is still a big CPU hog.6. No way to remove the useless items like nets fishing rod, palico commands, etc. on your item hotbar.The game was released in a rough state, but it's pretty good now if you can mostly get over the ugleh textures and occasional frame drops.

author: Marcalitus
review: I get this game and I enjoyed it. My specs are not the best, but I made sure every additional option is off and I am only a generation off cpu wise and 3 generations GPU wise. The community in this game for my 9 online sessions has been wonderful. Nice people that help you out, tell you tips and more. I am sure it will be plagued by toxic people, but I have enjoyed the monster hunter since MH 3 on the 3ds and I played more Generations than most of my 3ds games. I am also a PC gamer who has played loads of games while playing on my 3ds and I have played lots of online/MMORPG games. I have over 1k hours on most of them that are not p2p and have played warframe to hell. Now I will actually talk more about this game. I love it, I love the community, but I don't like how unstable it is. It is a good game, and after 11 hours it started acting up. I can play games that are heavy in CPU and GPU use, yet still not able to go the launch screen of this game anymore because it freezes my PC. Thank you CAPCOM for making this game on PC, but if you could make another patch for people who have bought this game for a big price point. I have tried every method the internet can offer, I have done my own fair share of troubleshooting computers,  I have looked through the forums of the support and more. I am a guy who cares not about graphics at all, I have put this game in the lowest possible settings, I have followed what the community told me to do to make my computer use less resources and I don't want to give up now. I love this game and not every game in the world is perfect, but I have to thank the people responsible for publishing this game to us the PC gamers. We need a better a PC port, thank you for this and I hope this problem gets solved soon. I recommend this because I enjoyed it when it lasted, I want it to be better and I don't people to be toxic but be patient. I want to play this game endlessly because I enjoy it and what it has to offer. I hope for a patch soon and I thank the community for not being harsh on new players to this series.

author: gamer of video
review: TL;DR already - Game's good, negative review because c'mon really?Played a lot of 4U, quite a bit of XX, was hyped for MHW on PC because of solid framerate.MHW has done a lot of changes to the standard MH formula which have made the game more enjoyable to play (easier gathering, easier inventory management, less useless quests). The locations became full ecosystems which works well with the design of the game. Weapons feel smooth and are less clunky (eg greatsword allows for a roll back after a strike, making the fight more dynamic and results in fewer feelings of "f*** this game".However, the question here is if I recommend this game.No. Absolutely not, at least not in this current state. I run the game with a few years old i5 and a geforce 960 on 55-60fps. Usually 60fps but the game randomly stutters for a couple of frames. While playable, there's no reason why that should be the case. Most of the people I know can't run the game well, even with good rigs. Some run the game on 45 fps with everything on low. The optimization is just poorly done and people are accusing both denuvo as well as capcom for writing bad code and rendering things out of sight needlessly.If you're not sure, get the game and either refund or not but in this current state, the game cannot be recommended.When there's either a patch or a fanmade mod that fixes the framerate issues, I'll gladly update this review.

author: fatsadboi
review: First and foremost, this is going to be my review as a longtime veteran, having played since 3 Ultimate and with ~1000 hours combined in every game since. As such, a large portion of this review is going to be a comparison with classic monster hunter. This is also my second time going through the game, having reached and played a large portion of the endgame on PS4. At its core, Monster Hunter: World is a huge quality of life update to classic Monster Hunter. However, the game does suffer from some major flaws - especially in the multiplayer department. Now, let’s start with what the game absolutely does right. The game is gorgeous - people have been dreaming of an HD Monhun for years and now that it’s finally here it really is breathtaking. Seamless, wide-open areas make the flow of the hunt more natural and the Monster AI itself has taken a huge step forward. Gathering has now become increasingly streamlined, cutting a large portion of busy work out of the game. Animations for both hunter and monster have been revamped and look smoother than they’ve ever been before. World is almost definitely the best single player experience that the Monster Hunter series has to offer. However, take one look at the co-op multiplayer and suddenly the game starts to break at the seams. First, let’s address the elephant in the room. The PC release has had consistent server issues ever since launch, making it near impossible to play with friends. Even without friends, often times you’ll drop into an SOS and disconnect before the end of the hunt. However, these issues can be patched eventually and I personally, will not be counting this as a huge downside to the game. What SHOULD and WILL be counted against the game is the failed structure that the game implements. Going from Monster Hunter Generations to World, Capcom decided to cut the old Monster Hunter formula and combine both the single player and multiplayer campaigns into one entity. It’s from this one decision that almost all major issues with the game arise. You’ve likely all heard the biggest complaint about playing through the story co-op by now - the cutscene requirement. Having to watch all cutscenes, leave, then join a friend who also has to have watched the cutscenes is completely obtuse and ruins any sort of pacing the game has going for it. It’s jarring, frustrating, and completely removes you from the experience. What’s even worse is that this was a non-issue in previous titles. The only reason it’s a problem now is that, like previously mentioned, the story and multiplayer are now combined. Capcom is trying to preserve the experience of going through a campaign seemingly by yourself but by not setting them into 2 different sets of quests they’re simply contradicting themselves and making it a hassle for almost all players.Another major problem that arises from combining single and multiplayer is often glossed over by other players and critics. Personally, I feel that this is because a large portion of the playerbase is inexperienced and thus will not be able to relate, but if you’ve put in a good chunk of time into any monster hunter game before suddenly there’s not much reason to play multiplayer anymore. Any hunt that you do multiplayer, especially during the campaign, could be done solo faster and more easily. In previous games, multiplayer difficulty was always higher than solo. This encouraged you to find other players to play with - now, often adding more players can prove detrimental. This, combined with the sheer difficulty of finding and joining any multiplayer hunts just removes any sort of motivation to play with other people. These issues were remedied slightly in some of the endgame quests on PS4 (Kulve Taroth), but PC has yet to see even a glimpse of those and likely will not for months. This leads into, in my opinion, the game’s biggest flaw. The game just feels lonely! People praise the SOS mechanic, but the culture behind it honestly bothers me. Players tend to simply disband after any given hunt. Gone is the simple camaraderie of playing with the same people for an entire session, exchanging guild cards and adding each other. This is made even worse by the fact that you can’t see other players from your session in Astera. It may have been slightly archaic, but having everybody in the same instance for multiplayer in the past games was really quite nice. You can say that you can simply return to the gathering hub after a quest, but in all my playtime I really have yet to see this happen even once with randoms. Having 16 players to a lobby is another huge issue - any one of these players could jump in to your hunt at any time and you’d have no idea who they were. In past games, it was 4 to a lobby, so you almost certainly knew that the people who were in your room were the people who you would be hunting with. There’s just this huge disconnect with the rest of the community, and it really is a shame. It makes it feel like you’re playing a single player game with cameos from other players rather than the excellent co-op of the previous games. Now, in light of all of this negativity it would seem as if I absolutely loathe the game. But in truth, I don’t. The core single player monster hunter experience is still intact. The game as a whole is a lot easier than previous entries which, as a veteran, displeases me, but it makes the game a great entry point for the series. I’d recommend the game to almost all new players of the series. It’s just that the more and more I play World, the more and more I miss classic Monster Hunter. The game has its moments - not having to cycle urgents 4 times for an entire party is an understated blessing, but at the same time this is just another small quality of life change. Monster Hunter: World manages to fix many of the quality of life problems that previous Monster Hunter games had. However, it fails to deliver on many of the core aspects of co-op Monster Hunter that were so central to the series as a whole. I’ll honestly keep playing it for a love of the series, but I have to say, it’s really just disappointing.

author: Dongs.exe
review: The little I played of single player seemed to work, but others have stated to have lots of issues there too. I have been lucky this far.But if you want this game for multiplayer? Don't. Not until they fix many issues. Everyone probably knows of the server issues by now, but the biggest issue of multiplayer is built into the game itself. If you wanted to hunt new monsters and go through the story with friends, you pretty much can't unless you jump through so many hoops that it's ridiculous. Everyone has to have seen all the cutscenes in a story mission to be able to join it, including finding the monster for the first time cutscene. Have fun running over to a monster, waiting for all your friends to do the same and then quit and start the quest for real with all of you together! And then get disconnected from the servers. Might not sound like much, but it adds up - oh does it ever. Some quests are even so full of cutscenes that you pretty much can't play with your friends who are at the same point. Old Monster Hunter games had separate offline and online campaigns with offline being the story and cutscenes, and with online lacking those features that might cause desyncs or something. When this one tried to mix them together, I assume all of us thought they'd be online and playable with your friends so you could enjoy it together. Nope, pretty much the exact opposite and there no longer is any proper online questline or progression, just online grinding for parts - at least not at low rank, but I wouldn't know what happens after the story quest as everyone who bought this to play together quit because they don't care to hunt alone, and neither do I, honestly. This was something no one mentioned anywhere and would have affected whether or not we would have purchased the game, so take note!Fixing the server issues will not fix this issue. The story should have been offline if it's something you have to solo or SOS randoms - which you shouldn't, as every hunter adds health to the monster and if the random hunters are bad, your fights just get longer and tougher than if you did them alone. And if you do somehow find cool hunters you'd like to continue hunting with, you really can't as you're separated after the quest without going to the same hub. And speaking of the hub, there's only one part of it that is multiplayer friendly with other players actually showing up, and no one really goes there. A big part of the multiplayer experience in past games of the series has been screwing around before and after the quests together when you're not on a hunt, so there's not really much of that left in World.I remember when the tagline of this series was "in the world of Monster Hunter, you're never alone". Well, I sure am more alone now than ever, even with the janky multiplayer of the old games.

author: Duckmom
review: Each of 14 weapon types makes combat feel like an entirely different game, from the grace and familiarity of a sword and shield, to the explosive pummel of an ammo-switching Bowgun, to the downright oddity of the Hunting Horn, a massive hammer that plays stat-buffing tunes.Monsters themselves come with a wealth of strengths and weaknesses and many, many materials to harvest, all of which can be used to create tens of possible items. You also have an adorable cat companion called a Palico which can be outfitted with its own gear, all offering different bonuses for your character. And when it all seems like you’ve got it sussed, along comes High-Rank, Monster Hunter’s “post-game” content, which changes some monsters, adds new ones, and essentially doubles the amount of gear to lust after.The deeper you look, the deeper it all seems to get - and that sheer level of complexity has historically been what stops Monster Hunter from offering mainstream appeal. But let’s get something out of the way: there’s been an assumption among the waiting audience over the past few months that - despite the protestations of Capcom itself - World would simplify the series’ more obscure ideas to help court a western audience. After just the first few hours, it becomes abundantly clear those concerns are unfounded.Monster Hunter has always been opaque, its menus pebble-dashed with byzantine statistics, and its combat purposefully designed to be methodical and challenging in a way that feels strange next to modern action games’ fluidity. Practically none of that has changed. This remains a game where learning is as important as doing, from potion recipes to intricate combos.World is decidedly not a my-first-Monster-Hunter experience.“What’s changed in some ways is how they’re presented. Quality-of-life improvements have smoothed off a few rough edges, making crafting simpler, armour skills more abundant, and introducing quicker, more efficient looting. But many difficult-to-grasp aspects still remain (it’s still crazy to me that weapon tutorials are still so meagre), and few have been made with the first-time player in mind. Playing in a party alongside new hunters, I’ve been bombarded with questions ranging from the simple (“Where can I change my weapon again?”) to the slightly more specific (“Why does my glaive come with a huge insect buddy, and what does the dust it leaves behind after sucking the juices out of a lizard do?”). The bottom line is that World is decidedly not a my-first-Monster-Hunter experience - this is full-fat, waterfall-of-information Monster Hunter. In that respect, it’s the same as it ever was.Those coming in looking for an all-encompassing adventure story will find World a little lacking, too. The central plotline - of travelling to a new continent in the wake of a migrating Elder Dragon - is a neat one, and pleasantly naturalist in tone (well, as naturalist as you can be in a game about killing mythical creatures to make shoes), but it’s nothing more than a pretext for the near-endless hunts ahead.But as far as opportunities for new experiences go, World just never seems to stop providing them – and I love that feeling. 50 hours in, it’s still regularly throwing crafting possibilities, monsters, even entirely new systems at me and expecting me to put time into learning how they can benefit my character.One of the most consistently exciting, satisfying, and gratifyingly absurd games I’ve played.“But no matter how much I or any other fan tries to convince you, there’s a chance that a game that requires this much management alongside its maiming simply won’t be for you. I urge you to at least try. Find an experienced friend to guide you or sit down for a few video tutorials, because Monster Hunter: World is one of the most consistently exciting, satisfying, and gratifyingly absurd games I’ve played since, well, the last Monster Hunter game.A disclaimer: though I’ve completed the story quest, I’m absolutely nowhere near “finished.” Side quests are clogging up my menus, I haven’t touched the majority of the weapons, and even the end of the campaign opens up a second, much more difficult half. This isn’t an admission of guilt, it’s a demonstration of what kind of game we’re dealing with. Above and beyond anything else you can say about World, there is a lot of it. It’s still stupendously generous with content and, better, matches that with consistently making your time feel well-spent instead of wasting it on empty-feeling grinding.

author: AOKCube
review: One of the best games I have ever played. Manages to strike a balance between hard farming while also allowing players to get a sense of accomplishment from finally learning a bosses moveset/fight. The act of farming itself is a challenge and engaging almost always, something which a lot of loot-focused games fail to keep steady. The Iceborne DLC adds to this, upping the difficulty significantly to allow for more experienced players to get a new challenge, while also adding balance changes to the weapons. Speaking of the weapons, no two weapons feel like copies of each other, with the closest comparison being able to be made is between the two bowguns, beyond that, each weapon is extremely different and has extremely different drawbacks and benefits. This is to the point where picking a different weapon and going through the game creates an entirely new experience. That being said, the game can be extremely punishing and will take patience to complete through, so it's not perfect for everyone, but if one is looking for a cool looking game with cool monsters while being both farmy and very challenging but never truly boring, this game is absolutely perfect for them. That being said, the game is not perfect and could use some improvements, the thing is this list is very small imo. The worst offender is the online multiplayer, something with the servers or connections or whatever ends with players getting disconnected a lot, which is disheartening. The only other thing is that for some of the harder monsters, it seems like difficulty is added through extra damage on attacks, way too much, not by making the monsters actually harder. Though for this I would really say the only offenders are the Arch Tempered new monsters like Nameille and Velkhana, so its not really a gripe, but I'd be worried if more monsters are added, even though world is sunset so this wont be happening. That's all I can think of in terms of direct fixes I'd want, which shows at least in my opinion how great it is.

author: The Black Baron
review: This game is to this date the most beautiful monster hunter game, with amazing and fun iterations of the usual weapons. It is so much fun playing with friends and random people, the community surrounding this game is great, helpful and a lot of fun. I would reccomend to play the base game first without the DLC, because some of the new features from Iceborne make aspects of the base game easier. Also don't use the defender gear, it is akin to cheating yourself out of  a great experience. Learning the game and building your own armour from slain monsters is more rewarding than picking the cheat armour when creating a new character. This is one of my most played games to this day, even though i definetly hold the Monster Hunter that started it all near and dear, (MH on Ps2 and later on MH Freedom on PSP) MH World might still be the best Monster Hunter game to this day. There is so much content in this game. From beautifully crafted areas to explore, photos to take, treassures to hunt, fishing for materials you can use to craft bombs or sharpen your weapons etc. Of course a large variety of complex monsters to hunt. Not only that, but learning how each one of them operate and what to use against them. If you want to sink countless hours in a rewarding game which takes effort and time to learn, then you should definetly buy this.

author: KilledinColumbia
review: I had friends recommending this franchise to me ever since Generations was announced. I couldn't enjoy the games on 3DS, so when World came out, I figured this was my best chance to enjoy the series. I hated it. It felt clunky and slow coming from games like Dark Souls and similar titles. The game was hard and felt almost unfair playing it the first time. I was told to just play deeper in the game and I'll learn to love it. I did't I put the game up and didn't touch it till I got it on PC 3 years later. Same story. Controls felt clunky and bad. This time however, I stuck with the game to play with friends due to guilt. After around 20 hours, I fell in LOVE with this game. It has such a charm and unique playstyle. Its rewarding and just eats away time. There are so many diverse weapons and sets you can make with armors. The game is stellar. I can't recommend this title enough. From tackling my first Anja to slaying Fatalis, I had the time of my life, and I wouldn't trade it for anything else.

author: xLegionnaryx
review: In this game you play as Monster Hunter World, the son of Monster Hunter Ultimate 6. You embark on your own adventure in the New World, which was discovered by Christoph Waltz not too long ago. To guide you is your handler, who feeds, clothes, and otherwise looks after you when they're not directing your righteous fury at rogue monsties. These monsties are running rampant through what is rightfully now your land, and you're the New World's topmost monstie hunter. The DLC, in which you play as Iceborne, Monster Hunter World's colder brother, always sends chills down my spine. In it, you discover a land of your own namesake by following a flock of dragons several miles over the ocean. In doing this, you also discover that unlike his brother, Iceborne puts all his marbles on luck instead of intelligence.

author: remyremington
review: A very long time ago I got this game on Playstation 4, I completely hated it... Although, I did play sword and shield the first time around (I hope any sword and shield players take full offense to that.) I kind of forgot the game existed for a few months after that until a friend messaged me over discord asking if I have ever played Monster Hunter World, he eventually got me back into it. Something I will never take back is that I am glad he did, because this game is a f*cking masterpiece. At the time of this review I have used every weapon (except sword and shield) twice. I have made 4 characters all with over 100+ hours on them. This game offers so many paths with weapons and abilities that my 772 hours on this game is just scratching the surface of the potential you can get. This game is just fun plain and simple. If you love beating the absolute hell out of monsters then I can not recommend this more, if you like monsters fighting other monsters then this game is for you, there has been a countless amount of times where I have seen a walking pickle that breaths dragon blight inducing smoke throw a obese lizard into the side of the wall breaking everything in its body... (maybe a little gruesome) BUT IT HAPPENS! You like getting up and close? Slam a hammer into their face. You like staying back and supporting? we got you, riddle them with bullets or pelt them with arrows while you got a healing build on your armor. Maybe you are all about that ranged and close ranged action, oh yeah man we got you, go up with a gun and pump em full of shotgun rounds as your other teammates beat the living hell out of it with pointy sticks. There is never a dull moment in this game, and EVERYBODY no matter their play style will find a weapon they like in their runs. But that is just weapons! The story in this game is phenomenal (no spoilers). It is very rich and fulfilling once you finally kill your first elder dragon that seemed impossible to even scratch. No matter what you are looking for, maybe just a nice playthrough in a monster hunting game, or maybe you want to go into a huge raid party and take down a gigantic nuke spitting dragon. No matter what you do in this game, every second of it goes toward something. I can not recommend this game enough for everybody, if you want a good game then you need this in your library. Also if you like the base game then I assure you the DLC is very worth it.... Sword and Shield players suck balls

author: DolphaBear
review: With just under 600 hours under my belt, I hope to give a decent review of this game as someone who played the first 500 hours without mods and the last 100 with them. I refuse to compare this to any other of the monster hunter games... cause of I haven't played any of them. Pros:The maps are large and has fixed gathering points for certain resources. Monsters travel around giving that true "Open-world" feel. It was neat that giant monsters would fight each other because one of them didn't like the color of their face and decided a little more blood-red. Truly eases you into the game with the tutorials and the like but you'll probably skip all that like I did. Piece of advice: GO INTO THE TRAINING AREA AND JUST PRACTICE A WEAPON TILL YOU FIND THE ONE YOU LIKE.Graphics are beautiful. Large monsters truly feel alive and breathing, which makes it all the more horrifying when you turn around and realize that the local T-Rex has finished deciding which BBQ sauce it wants to dip you in. By the way, it decided that mango habanero was the best choice.The music is godly. All soundtracks in the game seems great especially with monsters having its own theme... though, there was one song that I hate... Cons:The information dump is real. It does ease you into the game, yes. BUT, there is so much information and it's a daunting read. Jewels and Skills are so much more importantly than you first think. This makes up majority of the game in the end and eventually devolves into statistical analytics to see whose numbers are bigger.Beetlejuice... No other words.You will die. It's a real trial and error process where you need to know the monster's move set if you want to beat them with lower level weapons (or you can grind and upgrade to the max possible). Get ready to get comfortable with the ground, cause you'll be hugging it more than your favorite body pillow.Overall: 9/10 Really close to being a perfect game to me. The only downside is that some great features are locked behind the DLC. Regardless, one of the greatest games I've played.

author: Cybrid
review: Fun and a great investment for a game. The graphics are lovely. The best looking monster hunter in the series. Nice gameplay and really fun with friends. It holds up on its own, if you've never played any other Monster Hunter game. It’s a great one for beginners. There's 14 weapon categories, all which have their own upgrade tree with over 50 unique upgrades for each weapon. These don't just increase attack, but element types, things like decoration slots (which give boosts to certain things like defense overall, attack when a monster is aggravated, and many more), their own skills that have the same effects as decorations, and weapons like the bowguns, gunlance or greatbow have their own ammo types and effects unique to each tree and version of the weapon. Each monster has several types of armor unique to it, with its own skills and decoration slots available, and elemental resistances to go with them.It can sound like a lot to newcomers, but the game guides you to a point where you can understand the fundamentals, but you will have to get a bit more in depth to really bring out the strengths and weaknesses of builds.

author: Hand_Soap_Inc
review: I have played Monster Hunter, Monster Hunter Freedom, Monster Hunter Freedom 2, Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate, and Monster Hunter Generations Ultimate. As a Veteran of the series I've seen a lot, but this was the first game of the series that became a serious timesink for me.This game might lack the bright colours, quirky weird humour, and varied Monsters, but it makes up for it with streamlined gameplay packed with content. After 723 hours of gameplay I completed literally every quest I don't regret a single second of my time.The combat is a dance, rushing in and spamming attacks never works, but knoweldge and experience make all the difference. Knowing a Monster's habits, moveset, and elemental weaknesses, and tailoring your playstyle to match, is the core of what it means to be a Hunter. The game emphasises the important of the World and the Hunting aspect. Not to mention that the combat is weighty and tactile; not 100 weak hits, but one satisfying big boi SLAM!If you like a Hunt, if you like big Monsters rather than a mob rush, if you like combat that's simple to learn but hard to master, if you like weighty combay that rewards good positioning and focuses on well timed and satisfying attacks and punishes brain-dead spam: I highly recommend this game!

author: Masric
review: Monster Hunter was a series that I knew nothing about for quite a while, until I met the person that would become one of my best friends. They've been playing the series for most of their life, and convinced me to get World back when it released on console. Fast forward to today, and MHW:I is one of my favorite games to play. It has its frustrations like every other game, some the game's fault and others your own, but it has always been a wildly enjoyable time whenever I've played it. It's great on your own, and even better with other players and/or friends. (Most of) The monsters are fun and challenging to fight, (most of) their weapons and armor look and play great, along with the music and visuals. It's all so, so good. As has been the continued support for the game as time has gone on. I'm excited for what the future has in store for this game, and the MH series as a whole.

author: Necrode
review: I realize people have low attention spans to read walls of text, so I'll leave a TL;DR at the bottom. :)Monster Hunter: World is an amazing game, with a lot of care and attention to detail that keeps me coming back.With the addition of the most recent expansion, Iceborne, MHW has once again captured my attention.  If you're looking for a game that has excellent visuals, interesting and sometimes difficult boss fights, a plethora of room for experimentation, and a weapon/armor system that is very intuitive, MHW is a great option.There are 14 weapons for you to choose from, each with a very unique playstyle and role when it comes to a hunt.  To be honest, I'd say probably 9 of them feel VERY unique.  Lance and Gunlance vary in playstyle, but the overall feel is similar.  Same with most of the bows.  Minus the variance between Bow -> Great bow.  There are PLENTY of weapon options just within those 14 categories, and you unlock more as you progress onward to harder and harder monsters.The monsters themselves are amazing to look at, with their own movesets and elements associated to them.  You really have to play smart if you want to kill/capture some of the more difficult monsters, so there's always potential for growth, which I find very appealing.Honestly, the game is a bit grindy, but some people are into that, myself being one of them.  It's nice to set goals for yourself and strive to get the parts/materials you need to craft what you want.All in all, I would rate MHW 9/10.  Would be a 10 for me, but there are a few minor quality of life aspects that just aren't there.  Multiplayer is more of a hassle than it should be, but other than that, not many complaints.TL;DR - Amazing graphics, monsters, variation in weapon types, excellent progression mechanics, sort of grindyHope you enjoy this game as much as I do :D.Note: Iceborne is 100% worth the cost.

author: Nazark ツ
review: This game is super fun and exciting. The game is all about hunting monsters to earn better gear but I also spent a lot of time enjoying the scenery and the environment.The story of this game for me is good but don't expect too much. The environments or locale in this game is quite unique and  I really appreciate the amount of detail and effort that was put in this game. The fights in this game are fun. The battles are challenging and it might take you some time to finish hunt especially if its the first time you encountered that monster. But after gearing up and facing it more and more, you learn the monster's moves and the fight gets easier. The moments where I can flawlessly dodge the monster's move or timely block its attack are the moments I enjoy the most.This game frequently gets updates. There is about new content every month. These update may come as a new monster or events. The events are fun especially if you play with other hunters. The game gets better and better with the frequent updates.Thank you for reading my review, I highly recommend this game to others. I hope you may get the experience to explore and uncover the mysteries of the new world.

author: Teflon
review: It's rare that a game has captivated my attention as much as MHW. I played until the end of the story on PS4, with the release on steam I came back. I found that the game is much more in depth than I initially thought and I spent hours focusing on learning builds, how the canteen works, and other aspects I didn't even know existed. Even after 300+ hours I learn something new all the time. With the release of Iceborne, MHW is expanded even more so. I highly recommend the game but if you don't have the time or will to look outside the basic tutorials it gives you might have a tough time.

author: Havroun
review: Great experience, multiplayer is a bit weird for story, but after story is done and you get the hang of it, it's a really awesome solo or with friends. Since I pay attention so sound and aesthetics generally; - Soundtrack is pure gold, from city music to different monster themes.- Sound design is a bit curious sometimes(can hear animals which the sound is inspired from etc, such as chicken, horse, panther or a monkey), but it's generally really memorable and nicely done. - Aesthetics are great, maps and monsters are beautiful, armor sets are great, and despite some PC gamer's  reviewer's experience of having 'skimpy' and impractical outfits for FEMALES, mind you it is both ways. And both also have some very, very bulky armor depending on the set, of course. I, as a female myself, don't give a damn if I can see my character's form, or have some nice maybe not ideal for combat- armor, I just want to look good, and I can if I want to. - Combat feels great once you get the hang of it- If you like big monsters and you cannot lie, you can just capture them if you don't want to kill them. ALL OF THEM, *except elder dragons, but once you get them low, I doubt you want to capture them with what they've put you through*

author: Cranel
review: This is the first time I've played a Monster Hunter franchise and it was totally one of the best games I've ever played so far. I've seen many gameplay from this series on the old platforms and it was drastically changed or upgraded and there is just so much to do. I've spent almost 400 hours in playing this game completion just felt like it is still too far away, now that the Iceborne is coming to be released. Thus, I would really suggest this to friends or to those who are still planning to buy the game, who love to play third person RPG games that is usually filled with combos and such. This game is absolutely "exhilarating".Update: With the Iceborne released, Capcom really did a great job to maintain their development over the last few months. Performance improvements also changed drastically when CPU usage was dropped down from 100% to 70%. DX12 is now stable and better on my AMD GPU unlike on the first release of Iceborne with frequent crashes. Combos added to the weaponry is another plus for me and another thing is they added challenges as a change of pace on the treasure hunting, endemic life hunting, and observer quests. There are still more goodies to come as Capcom is still adding more feature updates as well. All in all, I would really suggest this game! Been playing for about 800 hours now and it's still extremely "exhilarating".

author: Danikuma
review: Gonna list the cons first:+ Menus and UI are absolutely NOT well-designed and beginners-friendly+ Story is meh, it's what you would expect from a Monster Hunter game+ Multiplayer although works, it's doesn't seamlessly. having to wait for friends to finish the cutscenes to join mid-quest is really annoying+ God I hate the handlerNow for the good part - the gameplay. It's what we're all here for and what we get. Though this game is basically an ultimate grind, it is a FUN grind nevertheless, especially with friends. The game is only enjoyable after you finish the low rank story though since you have to whack your head, work out the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Menus and UI and go through the somewhat mediocre story. After that, the game is pretty good.Again I recommend that you have friends to play with. It makes the game a lot better.

author: Autumn Leave
review: Great game but it has it's flaws10/10 Level design10/10 Monster design10/10 Weapon and armor design10/10 Graphics10/10 Score10/10 DLC content8/10 Character customization8/10 Events (collabs are sick but normal are eh)7/10 Plot, its good enough. You kill cool monsters that's all you need to know really, but the plot is pretty bland7/10 Loot, listen there is a lot about the loot in this game to love and it is a game built for grinding, but the RNG involved makes it annoying as hell. Some loot is rare some is common etc. which is fine but sometimes it can take 12 times to get that common loot you want. If it takes me a long ass time to get rare loot that's okay especially since the loot system is based on what you attack. For example you get tail by cutting off the tail, this system is great! But the RNG throws that out the window and makes in annoying as hell.6/10 Character animation. Conversations are horrible in this game since the animation is.. unexplainable. Animations in hunts are incredible tho so that's great.9/10 Game for me really solid the flaws of the game don't drag it down to a 9 for me it's the crappy PC port that drags it down. This game is incredible but Capcom did not realize the potential of this game on PC, thus the game suffers from it. Still a fantastic game would spend my money on it 3 times over

author: TalkingCactus
review: While some systems are overly complicated and tough to pick up for new players without someone or something to guide them, MH:W is a challenging and rewarding experience with or without friends. The PC English port, while not perfect, is still perfectly playable with most of the story voice acted properly (minus proper lip syncing). Every monster encounter is a unique experience with its own dangers and strategies you need to employ.If you can get past the learning curve with the strange crafting, buff, and eating system, MHW is an excellent choice if you're looking for a game to play solo or with friends.

author: Josh Reaver™
review: After 400+ hours of playing MHW I can absolutely recommend it! This game and its community is amazing! Coming into this entry I had tried to give other titles in the franchise a shot; they seemed interesting, however, I had two huge gripes with the earlier titles. First off, the constant loading screens in each area which slowed down the hunting experience. Secondly the systems they were on, (3DS was never comfortable for me to play for extended periods.) I can say in World these issues have been addressed!My heart was stolen right away when I hit the character creator and was able to make my Palico, (for the uninitiated it's a cat companion.) After choosing my weapon, (which there are 14 of,) I took off on my first hunt and noticed how good the gameplay felt. They updated the movesets from prior games so each weapon feels familiar to returning hunters, and still giving them new mechanics to learn. Never will I try to tell people that it doesn't have a huge learning curve, but, once learned the game is immensely rewarding.Most of all I have to stress how the world around you feels very alive in the New World. The graphics and audio design really immerse you in the biomes that surround you. Many of the monsters have a new feature called turf wars; if two monster encounter each other, while you are hunting them or not, they will engage in a very well animated fight causing huge damage to them in many cases! You will notice so many details that many developers would overlook in AAA gaming in this title and I have to applaud Capcom.The largest complaint I have is that this title does require a powerful computer and can be harsh on lower end hardware. Other than that I can say that late game is very grind heavy, however, it is still fun. Lastly is that event quests are timed, so you can do them during certain periods, which are announced on Capcoms website, or during the larger quarterly celebrations. Nevertheless, most of the complaints I have are very small and not with griping over.With Iceborne coming out this year, there isn't a better time to start preparing for the upcoming Master Rank, (this titles equivalent to G-Rank.) 1st fleet or 5th fleet you will not regret this purchase. I cannot tell you how much you are missing out on an amazing experience if you do not try this game. In my point of view this is one of the best games of the last decade if not all time.

author: Woozie
review: Monster Hunter: World is an amazing game that will keep you busy for many hours. The game has a well-balanced mix of both intriguing adventure and fun gameplay, that you can share with up to 3 other players.All locations are unique and the ecosystem and design never fails to impress, and even after many hours of playtime there are still a lot of monsters and new small places to discover. The gameplay feels like a genuine RPG game with moderate grinding that does not feel like you have a second job, unlike some other games. There are 14(!) weapon categories, of which 9 are melee, 3 are ranged and 2 are a sort of hybrid (mostly melee though). Each category has countless of weapon types with different upgrade paths and element types. Each weapon category has its own special ability, and each category is overall relatively hard to master. The abundant amount of categories means that it is very hard to become bored of the gameplay, as there is always something new to try.The story is pretty good, however it is not a masterpiece, which is understandable, as the focus of the game is the gameplay. It builds very much on mystery, which keeps your interest if you are eager to discover new monsters and locations. The graphics of the game are not the best of this generation, however, it is still a beautiful game as the style fits very well. The UI is pretty and has acceptable funcionality. However, it is obvious that the game originally was designed for consoles, so it is not the most comfortable UI to use with keyboard and mouse. The same goes for keybindings, which can be awkward at times and sometimes illogical. It is possible to play with keyboard and mouse, but if you are unlike me and are comfortable with controllers it would be recommended to use. The audio and soundtrack is very good, and really enhances the experience, especially during large battles, giving an epic feeling.It is hard to find any flaws that impacts the experience in a major way, however, there are many that report gameplay breaking network issues when playing with others. I have experienced some issues, but they have not broken the game for me personally. Overall the game is incredibly fun, and the gameplay, theme, story, graphics and sound combined delivers a memorable experience that you want to keep playing, making Monster Hunter: World a game I can definitely recommend.----To add; the Iceborne expansion released in 2020 is a very nice addition to the game, and adds dozens of hours of content, for example a new base & map, new story, and many more additions that definitely are worth getting. Basically just improving an already great game. If you loved the base game, you should definitely get this expansion!

author: Sudri
review: This game sticks to the formula that has made this franchise go as far as it has. This game really is a hit or miss and it depends entirely on what you want out of this game. This game truly is Boss Fight: The Game. 30-50 minute long missions, and all you do is fight large boss monsters, kill them, carve materials off them to craft stronger gear so you can be prepared to fight even tougher monsters. The controls might be a turn off to some people, if you see game-play footage and think that it might feel something like dark souls you'll be disappointed. Attacks lock you into the animation and make you stay committed to the attack you decide to do, not all attacks can be dodged, and not all attacks can be blocked. Weapons have a surprising amount of complexity and each feel unique and interesting to play. One of the few games I ever purchased full price and was worth it for me.One thing I should note is that many people do have connection issues, mostly disconnecting from sessions mid-mission which hasn't been full resolved at the time of writing this review.(I still experience this myself)

author: Fugazi
review: Monster Hunter World brings an interesting twist to the franchise, modernising a series that have often controlled relativily stiff and introducing many new mechanics. Movement is more free and things like gathering have been simplified to a buttonpress when passing by. The maps are wide and open, cutting out a large portion of loading times that used to be a series staple. Very few quests are centered around killing small monsters, gathering or transporting items. Which overall lets you spend more time hunting large monsters.These changes are all welcome and help introduce more people to the game. That's all cool.I did notice some flaws compared to the older games though. Many of the newer monsters look kind of uninspired and there are a lot less of them overall. The armor sets don't look as crazy as they used to be and most of the weapon upgrades look pretty boring. Almost all weapons in each tree look exactly the same except for a few details, which in a way makes more sense, but it's still more boring than it used to be. There is also no longer a separated solo and online questline. Which makes for less content but let's people chose if they want help or not for each quest. Or just lets you complete everything with a friend.Overall I problably still prefer the classic mainline games. But Monster Hunter World is still a must-have.

author: UltimateFate
review: The most polished Monster Hunter game up to date.It's not the most perfect game there is but I'll get to that later.- The world of MHW is a very immersive, be it the sound design or the living ecosystem in the world.- 14 weapons to choose from, bound to have something for everyone.- Each weapon is unique in their function and moveset. - Combat is the most fluid it has been ever, ever hit you do feels impactful and heavy.- The monster feel believable when it comes to the world and live by their own rules.- There are tons of QoL changes from the previous games that make it hard to go back honestly.- MHW feels so fluid when it comes to combat, navigation, etc.- Without a single loadscreen when it comes to quest, you feel like you're in one whole big map which is what mhw is.- As much as i love MHW, there isn't enough content as of yet. The monster variety compared to previous titles.- Most weapon design are quite unaspiring.- There isn't a real incentive to grinding past the end game. (You have to set your own goals)Overall 9/10Hopefully Iceborne solves most of the issues.

author: Japancakes
review: It's interesting this game does a lot that's faithful to the Monster Hunter genre as well as innovates and streamlines certain things. I'm generally against the idea of drastic changes to formulas that work really well already. It seemed silly to change so much about the game's system when previous MH games have already been so enjoyable.Those initial feelings aside, World is a great game. As a Monster Hunter game compared to the rest of the series I'd say it isn't the best out of them all however, it's still a very good entry. At its core it stays true to the hunt big monster craft nonsense to hunt bigger monster and delivers pretty much what you would expect from a MH game. Certain changes to the core gameplay are welcome as well as questionable but, overall it delivers an experience that is both enjoyable to new players to the series as well as not simplified enough to deter veterans of MH. PC launch was truly abysmal but I think now, after some time to update and tweak things, it really has come into its own.

author: schnitzelwegen
review: I’ve put a lot of time on this game now, and it has to be one of my favourite games. The graphics are great, soundtrack is amazing and the fights are all so fun. If you bring some friends, this game might be the most fun you’ll have with them. Even when grinding the same monster over and over for a gem, the game still doesn’t get stale to me.I’d give it a solid 9/10. This game is just all around fantastic, except for the multiplayer, which is why it’s not a 10.

author: LanceTG
review: After 200 hours I can properly review this game.Monster Hunter: World is not a bad game.The story is decent, the gameplay is fantastic, and the graphics are really good.For a port it's not that bad as how other people assume tho I wish capcom gave the PC version more love.Even after I finished the story the game had me coming back to finish all the optional quests, complete all the events and obtain every weapon and armor.There are weapons 14 types of weapons for every type of person, you like to hit the monster in the head until it falls over? The hammer is for you, or you are more of a long range dude? The bow guns and bow are waiting.Personally I don't have a main weapon because all of them are fun and satisfying to use.The only bad thing I can say about it is the server connection, sometimes you can get kicked out of a quest for no reason.Can't wait to play the Iceborne expansion when it comes out on january 9th.That sums my review of Monster Hunter: World, my score for it is 9/10

author: Legendxz
review: Was really hyped about MHW coming to PC to be honest and the hype lived up to it.The port was great and the amount of hours you can put in this game is just insane! If you're into the monster hunter series you should definitely try this one.There's a main story that you can complete as well as optional quests which are pretty well made and fun to do.Getting the high-end armours can be achieved without a lot of effort ,however if you want the high-end stuff (decorations,streamstones) prepare for some work to do as there's a lot of grinding involved in order to get those! Overall i'd recommend this to anyone and even if you're not into grinding i'm pretty sure it's still worth getting.

review: Great!

author: Stiff
review: Best game of the year! Really outstanding! I'm wasn't a great fan of the series, but I was immensely in love with one entry that really caught my attention, that was Monster Hunter Freedom Unite for PSP. From that journey on I've waited for an experience like that to repeat itself.To feel free again, in a world you could actually live and feel like you can grow, learn and be awesome! Even better, a world where you could really play along with friends, using their skills and combining the gameplay, instead of just playing alone together.This game really did it! I was very worried it would be bad as most expectations always are. But it freaked me out the level of quality of this game! It's unbelievebly good!! Monster Hunter always had these minor setbacks of having unintuitive systems or controls, but now they REALLY put an effort into making a sit and play experience. Everthing just works, and you still get to enjoy the bliss that is surpassing real challenge! You begin really easy for all ages and backgrounds to get a grasp of it, and then it begins to gradually present you with difficulty, challenge and the wide-range of progress possibilities that really hooked me on the series before!It has Meaning! This game is awesome because it is meaningful! Not in the story, not in the cutscenes, but the gameplay itself. The story that no one is telling, the environment, the monster that you have to study, the plans you need to make to hunt! The strategies you can arrange with friends! The living ecosystem you experience, where everything feels alive, and monsters interact with each other, plants and resources laying around make sense, and you can intuitively discover where the herb you need would be just by looking at the environment.They tried a story/cutscene strategy on this game, that wasn't even necessary. I even consider it one of the mistakes of the game. The world is so awesome and alive and immersive that you don't need cutscenes, so they become a bit boring. Also they get in the way of playing a campaign co-op a bit. Because you must first watch the cutscene alone, then go the your friend's "adventure" to join and kill the same monster.In the end this is a masterpiece, if you have the chance and money, play it!You will not regret it!

review: This game in a nuttshelll is really good and pretty well made. The graphics are outstanding and the gameplay is to die for with extreme amounts of thought put into it.Pros:- graphics are amaizing- gameplay is non-stop fun- armor crafting is simple and easy to use- the "hub" is large but everything is easy to find/reach- can have private rooms/sessions to play with just friendsCons:- Lag can be a big issue- screen bugs out or game won't load for some users (this is being fixed current moment)- settings for graphics and such can be better (we need more options)- this game is all about grinding and killing monsters takes time and effort (I don't mind this but if you don't like this type of gameplay this isn't the game for you)- timing out of sessions- not the easiest to join friends sessionsConclusion:The game is great but still does need lots of fixes on it to make it the game we all have been dreading over for. author: MarioMetroid
review: Monster Hunter: World is my first foray into the Monster Hunter series. I remember seeing my friend playing an earlier installment in the series on his PSP years ago and wanting to get into it since. After nearly 500 hours, I think I'm qualified to say that this installment is fantastic for introducing you to the series. This is not to say, however, you need to invest 500 hours to learn how the game works! The vast majority of that time was not spent understanding all the core mechanics but just having fun running the item treadmill, farming crowns for achievments, doing Kulve Taroth sieges, and trying to become the best Long Swordsman I could be. You might want to spend your time across several of the 14 weapons if staying with one weapon is a stale experience for you.Also good news for PC users that didn't have consoles to dive into MonHun is that keyboard and mouse works just fine! If you don't have or would rather not play with a controller, there is no need to worry. Although, just a bit of a nitpick, I feel certain moves would be more accurate with an analog stick rather than WASD keys - I may have slightly whiffed on some Spirit Helm Breakers with my Long Sword due to the keyboard limitation of 45 degree increments for input. On the flip side, I'm certain ranged weapons like the Bow, Light Bowgun, and Heavy Bowgun are massively more accurate and responsive with the keyboard and mouse as opposed to a controller so you might prefer those weapons if you really dislike controllers.On the surface, Monster Hunter seems incredibly simple - it's a just a game where you hunt monsters. However, as you scratch the surface you'll find tons of little intricacies to the design of the levels, the monsters, monster movesets, your weapon's moveset, how parts of the environment work, how your items can be used in multiple ways, and even how to make full use of the Canteen for food buffs. This is a game well worth your time and money, especially as Capcom doles out more free content to the PC. Please don't be intimidated if you've never played a Monster Hunter game before - the single player campaign's (which you can play with others if you desire) difficulty builds up at a reasonable pace, doesn't expect too much from you in the beginning, and you're certain to find a weapon you're comfortable with.My personal game of the year for 2018 and has turned me into a Monster Hunter fan - I'll probably end up getting one of the portable games now so I can play more and not just spend my time reading wikis and forum discussions.

author: Broh
review: Although the release of this game came with some flaws, like the poor optimization against certain bosses, and connection issues, capcom has already fixed them, but sadly, people didnt changed the reviews they gave, so its currently on a "mixed" review that this game dosnt diserve. Now talking about the game as it is.... The Monster Hunter series have improved a lot in this game. The graphics are beautiful, the combat design has been improved a lot, and now the game is reciving the proper updates in content that we were waiting. Monster Hunter is capcom's best product, and it was about time that western audience paid attention to this game.

author: FinallyLoading
review: MHW is a great game, in specifics the music is great to listen to, the varities of weapons allows players to satiate their playstyles or combat against certain monsters, though I do warn you that using certain weapons will slow your pace to unbearable speeds, if used to more... faster paced games.Combat is simple two button type attack and combine both for special moves and more various options in the hunter notes, rolling is different from Dark Souls, thing is you're not completely invinsible while doing so, however there will be things to improve that later, you can evade by dropping to the ground by upequipping your weapon with a running start and roll button, this will dodge almost every attack while doing so but will leave you severely opened if used to openly as there is a large window of hurt waiting for you.Jump attacks allow mounts to force monsters to fall over allowing ample time to do heavy damage. Ledges and quick climb walls(walls with serration that allows footing to climb) and sliding are one of the ways to jump attack, though in sliding some weapons are much more effective form of DPS for certain weapons (Hammer heheh spin2win). Certain weapons like the Insect Glaive, Sword and Shield, and the Switch Axe can perform mounts without those terrains which can open up various playstyles.Yet I've want to say for the bad parts of the game is when going in the game your first time without any knowledge will give you a bad time, as there's a metric loads of things you can do initially, however when you do get in touch with all these new info you have to do certain optional quest that are important for unlocking more stuff in the game and I wish they separated as requests than optionals, though don't worry, there's not many and isn't really insane hard.Another rather annoying part is unskippable cutscenes, I admit it's good and it gives you things to understand the storyline of the game, but it gets really long, that's a thing you should brace for when you play this game, but it's a good cutscene so I'll let it "sorta" pass, though I have to say that they should allow skipping if using another character slot.Last is the fact that there's other things that the game doesn't tell you and the community knows is something to know so I hope you're in for watching guides of mechanics in the game.Conclusion, game's great and enjoyable though controls are questionable tbh as it's more favored to controllersUPDATE: IB EditionSuper Late on the update but I decided to add into the new things and last patches,First of all the Clutch Claw finally gets a skill to improve its annoying mechanic of tenderizing (albeit it's been at least a year since IB launch it has come from many complaints) but hey, it got a skill to improve it in October 1st 2020. SnS got a mega buff, HH got new things and GS, LS, CB can now use slinger burst mid combo which is really nice.Negatives are the fact 2 skills are nerfed(Wex & Max Might) but a new skill rose up to the table as Monsters are now enraged longer making Agitator really stronk.IB progression of completing the storyline will be a long haul as this means raising region lvs and MR to reach 99 to finally get access to most of augments and goodies you would normally get from Tempered investigations in base world. But at least the Augment system is much better as Base World's Augment system makes few choices of modification for higher rarity which in turn made Rarity 6 Gunlances better than rarity 8 for long due to extra augments. Although Higher Rarity Weapons have less slots, you can do more than slot 1 augment at least so that's a good improvement.However the more recent title release monsters are far more..... Difficult to deal with when you're fresh outta Story(which for some reason min MR req is that low). Especially Alatreon, despite its negative view of its Damage Check, I think Alatreon's moveset is quite forgiving yet painful if you do get hit. window of evasion is far easier than most monsters which makes it a really interesting hunt(only gripe for me is how it stays in the air for a longass time)Meta:Weapon choices? Not alot as Safi/Brachy/Kjarrs are prevalent HOWEVER, with new weapon reskin augments you can make it look like certain weapons making the aesthetics more appealing.Armor is the same scenario of few armors are useful, but a bit more flavor of choice unlike Base World's Master Touch/Spare Shot because everything else didn't offer much. Game can eventually get repetitive as after all it is about hunting monsters, and players tend to lean towards Siege, Kulve, and Alatreon. But so far it's a nice addition(albeit it's another 50$+ spent but I guess it's ok)

author: Ryuseal
review: I can't remember the last time I played a game as enjoyable as this. Been cycling through different MMOs and other multiplayer games and this has been the best experience. First 1.5 weeks was a little rocky for multiplayer, but everything is pretty much smooth sailing. This is my first Monster Hunter game, and it will probably not be the last. The game mechanics are fun and the punishments for being trigger happy are well deserving. Some fights can be frustrating, but the satisfaction of slaying or capturing the monster incomparable to anything recently. I'm currently waiting for a patch to support ultrawide displays.Performance wise, I have a 34" Ultrawide monitor with 75hz. I have vsync turned on with everything on the highest possible setting, but with Volumetric Rendering turned off and I get a consistent 75fps. Specs:i7-7700k /w Asus Tuf Mk2 Z270Corsair Vengeance RGB 32GB DDR4 3000mhzGigabyte Windforce OC GTX 1080EVGA Supernova G2L 750wI have a friend that are running the game on Medium settings with a consistent 50-60fps w/ an 4th gen i3, r9 280 and 16GB DDR3 1600mhz. Overall my experience has been great and will continue to support this game.

author: OASx_AshKetchup
review: For starters, I think most of you guys know that monster hunter: world is in an unstable footing at this moment due to its server connection issues. Having stated that one problem that most people have so far with the game, the game is still playable, be it for veterans or for new players to the franchise looking for a challenge in hunting the very well designed monsters solo. But if you plan to play the game with friends or if you are just looking for that multiplayer experience while running through the game, I wouldnt recommend it at the moment until Capcom, MH:W devs, and steam fixes the connection issues. The only reason why I gave this game a thumbs up is because I myself played the game solo for most of the parts and had a ton of fun. Another thing that I was kinda disappointed of the game, is some of the monsters just feels copy and pasted, from movesets with slight changes and aesthetics that shares the same base model, hopefully future dlc's would include either old or new monsters that would fit well in the new worlds environment. Now lets talk about the maps, I have nothing but praise in how the devs just made the environment look so organic and alive, given that there are only 5 maps in the game currently, lets just hope that the devs adds more in the future. So I highly recommend buying the game, even though its multiplayer features isn't fixed yet, you can just wait and buy the game when it does get fixed which will be pretty soon since the devs have already addressed the issue and are already working on it.
