author: A Singular Chicken Nugget
review: EDIT: I love this game. Its amazing.As a first time monster hunter player this game is amazing.I love the souls-playstyle of the game. Greeding to get another hit might get you killed. Dying is punishing and you've got to learn the monsters move-set. I havent seen much of the connection issues that others mentioned. During all of my hours in-game me and my brother have been disconnected maybe twice. (I had to downgrade my graphics drivers to prevent crashes though).Multiplayer is really fun if you play with a friend. Its fun to coordinate with things like sharpening, mounting and severing stuff. All the weapons Ive tried to far feels good (Switchaxe, longsword, dual blades, Heavy bowgun and insect glaive). Hits feels good and rewarding.Tracking is fun, grind is good. Every monster is challenging (Kind of at least).One of the best games Ive played in a long time.

author: Ace_
review: As an MH veteran, this is a great step for the series. It introduces a boatload of new mechanics. For instance, an expanded upon version of the fourth gen mounting system, the slinger to traverse the land faster, and maps without load zones.I'll be entirely honest, i've been lucky as far as critical errors are concern. I've only had one crash through the course of low rank to high rank. My PC is mid to high teir and hasn't had any troubles running the game itself. FPS drops if at all are very infrequent and only happen in moments of high particle intensity. It is worth noting if your playing this game for a story, you probably should just not. Its got one, but really its just a vessel to show you a few monsters and get you into the meat of the game, like the real meat, the well-done meat. None of that rare ♥♥♥♥.Is this a fantastic port? No, however, it's a damn good monster hunter game, and a spectical to play. Beautiful maps, engaging combat, and more grinding than you could ever ask for. Basically heaven.9 Great Jagras voring an Aptonoth / 10.

author: caveinkevin
review: Good game, great gameplay, works as intended despite a few minimal flaws. I can play with my friends most of the time. Went into this series since the PS2 era and I'm happy this gets ported to PC. Most recent patch made multiplayer better, I haven't DC once since then.Like Monster Hunter in general? Don't miss this out!

author: Calo Nord
review: The aim of the game is to hunt monsters and gather their parts, using these parts you can craft new armor and weapons to help you take on even bigger monsters. Using their parts you can craft stronger gear to fight deadlier monsters, and craft even better gear. Eventually you'll look back at the path of carnage you have chosen, think of the corpses you have butchered and skulls adorned, and wonder if you should try using a bowgun next time.

author: Palin Freeborn
review: EDIT: Game is good now. Connectivity issues have been corrected, new content is forthcoming, and things are coming along smoothly. I'm sad it took the better part of a month after release to correct it, a month which saw all of my friends beating the game independent of each other, but at least we can finally join up and enjoy things now.Having that said, this is a gorgeous game with a widely-varied and well-balanced cadre of amazing weapons, all of which have their own play style and functions in combat. Items are meaningful and managing your resources mid-combat is both challenging and easy to do, with a control system that is tight and easy to understand. The game doesn't explain every mechanic to you, so at least some of the game is going to require experimentation and discovery, which can be daunting when you consider how much you have to hunt to get some items. However, going by the console release, there's only more amazing things on the horizon with MHW, and I'm sure you will love it. Just bear in mind that the "tutorial" is going to last you the entire length of your refund window, if you have any reservations. Just saying.______________________________________________________I'm going to preserve my (750+ helpful rating) previous review here, for posterity, and to encourage Capcom to think twice before releasing a game in this state again:I've purchased this game twice. I bought it for PS4, and fell in love with it. There were little disconnects here and there, but I assumed that was an issue with the stability of the console and my wi-fi internet. For months, I enthusiastically sold the game to my friends on the promise of that fun, and when they agreed to purchase it for the PC, I was ecstatic, because it meant I'd get to share it with them.I bought a second copy for PC, so I could join them on their adventure. We joked around about the unskippable cutscenes and the mandatory, slow tutorial. I listened as they plowed through the first missions, so they could get to the point where the game started letting them team up together and, when we all finally got together for our first group hunt, we endeavored to launch a mission as a squad.Oh, wait, squads don't exist on PC. You have to ♥♥♥♥ around with Steam Groups. Finally got that figured out? Bam, disconnect. Restart the mission. Bam, error code 503820-MW1, gotta rejoin a public session with my friends. Wait, now your friend hosting the session isn't showing on the "friends' sessions" list. Gotta restart the session. Someone still isn't seeing it, have them host instead. Their game crashed, everyone loads back in, finally groups up, and launches the mission. Bam, another disconnect. And another. And another. And another. And another.I'm 54 hours into this game over the last two weeks and I've finished less than a half-dozen hunts with my friends. Most of the time, everyone gets kicked out of the session, and you have to finish the battle alone against a monster that has scaled up to 140% extra health vs 4 players. Lag, disconnects on a wired connection, hosting issues, and networking problems galore have plagued me since buying this title on PC. I've disconnected more times in two weeks on PC than I ever did in 8 months of PS4 gameplay. Several of my friends have beaten the game by themselves, and are waiting for the game to be fixed so we can do something, ANYTHING, together. And to think... Capcom took an additional 8 months to release on PC because they wanted to ensure the game was "optimized and delivered in it's best possible version."Monster Hunter World is a brilliant game, when it works, but it is marred by constant and persistent stability issues, time-wasting unskippable cutscenes and credit sequences, occasionally unfair monster behavior (Pink Rathian perma-charging and Kirin lightning RDM, I'm looking RIGHT at you), and an absolutely ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ amount of networking errors that have yet to be resolved after 8 months of preparation and two weeks of the game being released. Toss in Denuvo DRM (seriously, ♥♥♥♥ DRM), issues with Big Picture/Steam Overlay that almost require you to DISABLE TWO CORE COMPONENTS OF STEAM in the platform settings, and the fact that Capcom has only issued a blanket statement about "investigating the issues" with no follow-up over the last few weeks, and you have a recipe for an avalanche of continuing problems with no time frame for correction.I'll change this review later if it's fixed, *maybe*... but for now, give this game a pass. Capcom isn't taking it seriously, so why should you?

author: Chances
review: So as someone who's never played the Monster Hunter series, I went in blank slate with no idea what I was getting into. Highly recommended by friends, strongly not recommended by many in the reviews, I had to wonder if this game was worth the asking. After nearly 40 hours of play time, I'm going to say 'It's worth a buy.' Mind, a few notes and things to consider before you do.TL;DR - I would recommend this game to folks, there are technical issues this game is handling and is coming with patches, but if you can work past it or willing to wait, its worth it.Pros:+ Beautiful Graphics+ Great Soundtrack+ Solid Gameplay + Varied approaches to your hunts+ Many, Many choices on gear and setups+ Varied and complex regions to hunt inCons- Awkward keybinds for K/M, clearly normally meant for Controller (Being patched)- Connection issues (pending patch going to fix)- Finding friends to join the same session can be irksome- Some unexplained game mechanics- Jumbled inventory system- A few AI BugsFor those of you who's played Dark Souls, you'll feel right at home. Each monster is a challenge unto itself. They're large, wild, where you need to learn their behaviors, learn what weapons meet the challenge the best, and plan accordingly. But all the monsters have multiple directions to be approached, and a huge selection of moddable and craftable weapons to chose from to tackle the challenge. Mind, this is not your standard hack n' slash, you will need to learn how each weapon functions, as going in swinging with one could end with you ending up wide open for a Monster to send you flying against the cliff face for a mistimed swing. Greatswords are huge, slow swinging beasts that do large damage, but need to plan your swings, or the dual blades where you have to learn to dance around your prey to whittle it down. All viable, but all need planning. Mind, it has a steep, but fair learning curve, be prepared to take your hard knocks till you finally figure out how to tackle your challenge best.Story-wise, it is clear they made a story purely focused on convincing you to move forward with progression, but not much else. A poorly lip-synched, barely worth understanding tale of the 5th Fleet of Monster Hunters coming to the New World to solve the mystery of the Elder Dragon migration. However, in the end, it putters along barely giving you the sense of urgency as you realize you're short two monster fangs to craft up your armor ... story can wait, back to the hunt. It all is just a backseat item to the real meat of the game...Kill monster, carve monster, make their bits into gear, kill more monsters. The system is not much more difficult to understand than that, but in turn, you're given a huge selection of weapons and armor, foregoing the usual stats and levels. Weapons from the beastly greatswords, the defensive lance and shield, the tactical and nimble insect glaive, even to hard hitting ranged Bowguns. Up to 14 different weapons to choose, all with their own tech and crafting branches to make the right tool for the job. Armor as well plays a big role as each set comes with its own bonuses and upgrade options that'll let you tackle challenges while negating the risks in the field from monster and environmental hazard alike.Along for the ride is the game’s companions, the Palico, a feline anthropomorphic character you can gear up slightly. While seeming mostly cosmetic, the Palico is more that cuteness and advertisement for the game, geared with unique tools, the Palico can help in fights with some damage output, healing, and other utilities to assist in your adventure, as well as help you call in assistance from local wildlife, by taming smaller monster beasts, to even getting in touch with indigenous Feylines who you can recruit along for your hunts. While not a major part of your arsenal, the Palico is a fun and helpful companion to make up for the lack of teammates, up till you have 3 hunters on the team. Afterwards, your Palico will faithfully wait back at camp, as you can only have them out with one other hunter, and no more.The graphics of the game, while demanding, are immersive and breathtaking, from the details of the monsters themselves, down to the foliage around you creating the lush canopy of green in the Ancient Forest, to dust covered, jagged plains of the Wastes and many other environments which changes up the strategy of approach and gear when exploring these lands. But with these great environments comes an impressive soundtrack to accompany you from just generally exploring out into the wilds, to the wild drums of the hunt as you’re toe to toe with your quarry, often falling into subtle tones as the beast runs of while you make chase, only to pick up again in intensity as the fight resumes. Weapons also come with satisfying impact, as every bladeswing, strike, and shot brings a satisfying sound of contact, even missing your swing still gives way to the sound of just how heavy and powerful your weapon is as it hits the earth, letting you know you’re playing with big toys, not whiffle bats.The game does have a few issues to its performance for seamless gameplay. For one, if you prefer keyboard and mouse like me, you’ll find that the binding options are a bit awkward to handle, as one keybind could have multiple uses, and that Ranged / Melee / and Menu have separate keybinding setups, some of which change on you when in the field or in the trading hub. Another issue is finding your friends to connect to, setting up sessions is easy enough, but finding and getting into a friends session can be problematic. Steam friends list can alleviate this a bit, but the need to trade Session codes still feels a bit archaic in today’s multiplayer world. Another issue is the inventory system, which is clearly still designed for console players, but for PC, the translation is a bit jarring and jumbled, having to deal with odd commands from different keys just to swap and deploy items, though to alleviate this, it gives options for ‘restock’ which can resupply your consumables from your Item Box to your inventory as long as you have it available. Lastly, he game tutorials can come up lacking, ending up glossing over key elements that would have sometimes been considered very important for progression seem to have been forgotten to mention, or are mentioned at much later times after the element of the game really could have been useful earlier.The game does come with its share of flaws, as well. While Capcom has acknowledged these are issues they are looking into resolving, you do run into several issues regarding connections with companions, mouse input issues, and even a few performance issues. Patches are incoming, so if you prefer to avoid as much frustration as possible, give it a few weeks for those to patch out. The game is also not very friendly to lower end gaming PCs, often running with frames per seconds to agonizingly slow rates that can make the game difficult to play, so if you’re interested in MWH, consider upgrading your PC, or at least give some time or patches to optimize the system.All in all, Monster Hunter World is delivering on its promise to bring a beautiful, amazing world with fun, yet challenging mechanics and a good time hunting gargantuan monsters with an array of tools at your disposal.PC Details:nVidia 980 GTXi7 Processor16 GB DDR4 RAM

author: Wedran
review: Firstly, it's a bad port, with mouse issues, massive performance and optimization issues, lack of graphical options, a lot of connection problems, and the fact that the game corrupts your save data if it ever crashes, it's pretty laughable after taking half a year longer to "get the port right". It also uses Denuvo Anti Tamper, known for causing performance issues, and being generally anti-consumer.Secondly, the game itself is by far the worst mainline Monster Hunter game. This stems from a couple of issues. Casualization disguised as quality of life changes, lack of monsters, the open world map design, and specifically catering to the western audience.Picking up herbs, mushrooms and honey with one click while being able to move is a QoL change, the radial menu is a QoL change, auto-crafting is a QoL change. World allows you to access the Canteen and your full item and equipment boxes in a hunt. You will never have a hunt where it comes down to the wire, your potions and items expended, the monster close to death, your heart racing because it's do or die. You can simply farcaster back to a camp, fully resupply again, and go back out. If you went into a hunt unprepared or in wrong gear, you can just change it whenever. A big part of Monster Hunter was learning the monster you were hunting and preparing for the hunt ahead, but now you can just bruteforce any hunt in the game by carrying a farcaster and going back to camp. That is not a QoL change, it's a change to the core of the game, making it easier.Moving while drinking a potion is again, a change to core gameplay, not a quality of life change, and again, it completely breaks the game because if you're burning a little bit of stamina, you can move pretty quickly, allowing you to dodge attacks while healing.Some weapons have become ridiculously overpowered and easy to use purely because they were made "less clunky". Prime example of this is the fact that the greatsword got the shoulder tackle move which you use to get out of a charged slash if you're about to get hit or miss your attack. The tackle gives you super armor, reduces the damage you take, and skips one step towards your big damage attack WHILE doing KO damage to the monster if you land a hit on the head and staggering some monsters out of attacks. You don't have to worry about proper positioning or openings to put out damage, since you can just mindlessly charge, and tackle if the monster takes a swing at you, and come out better for it. The Bow now has infinite Short Range coatings, because again, preparation and management of supplies doesn't matter in this game.There are no negative armor skills in the game. There are no point thresholds you have to pass to activate a skill anymore. You either do have a skill or you don't, meaning your armor has no actual downsides, other than resistances. You can make mixed sets that absolutely break the game with how ridiculous their skills are, and have no downside for it.The game allows you to craft charms, but the much more important decorations are pure RNG drops, meaning you might as well quit now, if you're obsessive about optimizing your sets and gear.The game has a serious lack of monsters, clocking in at only 34 large monsters (on console, with all of the DLC), and the monsters in the game are too easy. Now, I'm not good at Monster Hunter, I never was, but this game is a breeze. All the way from the first time you body the Great Jagras in under 8 minutes, to the literal final boss, who is about as difficult and complex as that Great Jagras with an inflated health pool. Even the monsters that return from previous MH games feel slower and less dangerous. Simply compare the Barroth or Diablos from World to their equivalents from older games if you don't believe me.The new monsters are either generic throwaway lizards, that are slow and have one actually threatening attack, fast and interesting to fight, but don't do enough damage and don't have enough health (Tobi-Kadachi and Odogaron), or just plain annoying, like the Bazelgeuse the devs constantly shove in your damn face as soon as you hit high-rank. Even the flagship Nergigante is just an overgrown Diablos that can't burrow, but has a big boy slam attack that he telegraphs for a full second before doing it.Hell, the monsters will take themselves out with environmental traps, status toads, standing under obvious traps practically begging you to hit them or by having some other monster driveby the monster you're fighting before it runs off. (I'll get to the driveby monsters in the map design section)Yes, I know I didn't count the "Tempered" or "Arch Tempered" monsters. That's because they're not real content. They're artificial difficulty disguised as content. They're the exact same monsters as their regular version, except they just do more damage. What even is the point? They aren't fun to fight. They're just annoying because it's the exact same monster you've already fought, but you just have to heal more, or get oneshot in the case of Arch Tempered monsters.Oh hey, map design. The Ancient Forest is a realm of nightmare and pain. Doubly so when fighting a Rathalos or Rathian. The maps are just bloated, The Ancient Forest is a mess of levels, tunnels, passages, climbable vines, inbetween levels, etc.. Combine this with Rathaloses and Rathians running from the top to the bottom of the big tree, or the middle, or anywhere on the map, and you'll just get confused. The big issue is the fact that the scoutflies don't always work like they're supposed to, or the monster moves to another part of the map while you're halfway climbing the tree and the scoutflies don't update fast enough. They disappear when you enter combat, but the game's definition of "in combat" is finnicky, so you'll be stuck without Scoutflies for up to a minute sometimes, and good luck finding your way around the forest withou them.Wildspire Wastes and the Coral Highlands are generally OK maps, but they have a lot of wasted space. The Rotten Vale has an entire level dedicated to a throwaway bootleg Uragaan fight, and the effluvium map hazard gets annoying after a while.The Elder's Recess is hell on earth. The map is way too small and interconnected for the amount of monsters it spawns at once, plus it spawns monsters that just love to go roam the map. If you're doing a non-elder dragon hunt, you'll get interrupted by some other monster three to five times per hunt. Here comes the bazelgeuse, and here's Azure Rathalos, then there's Uragaan, oh and here's Bazelgeuse again, and that's Rathalos, etc., repeat to infinity. I've had a Bazelgeuse run into a room with three other monsters and just chill in the middle of it for a good five minutes.To finish it all off, the game lacks the character of the previous entries. Most of the weapons in the same category look samey and almost all of the joke weapons like the Tigrex Tank, Felyoshka or the shark lance are gone, and I doubt they're ever coming back. The damn Handler is an ugly bint, and all of the cutscenes are unskippable. As it's own game, it's not awful, it's alright even. But seeing as you can emulate and play both MH Freedom Unite and MH Portable 3rd on PC, on any toaster, with no issues at all, AND play them online with your friends over PPSPP, I don't see the point of buying or playing this game.

author: Skizzix
review: Greetings dear Steam Community!First of all, I'd like to apologize for any mistakes that will follow. English is not my mother language and therefore I haven't mastered it yet. Moreover, this is my first review. Let's just start.I have played  (PSP),  (Wii) and also  on Xbox. That gives me i.m.o. the possibility to evaluate wether this game is better or worse than other MH-Games. The gameplay starts a bit slow for my likings, but speeds up rather fast after 1-2h of playtime. Other then in older MH-Games, you miss the feeling of freedom, when choosing a quest. That is, because you can't choose. In MHW, you follow a linear questline to complete the Main Story. Side quests do exist, but there is actually no need to complete them. This does not mean, the story is boring. I saw flashing scenes and funny stuff. Exploring the world(s) of MHW has never felt that good. The whole enviroment looks lively and dynamic. In addition to that you can use the world its elements to defeat monsters. The 14 different weapon types have a decent balancing and offer huge differences in gameplay. (BTW. The hunting horn is NOT a support weapon)I've read many many review complaining about how bad this game is ported. Actually these people are a little bit whiney. I mean the game has just released and therefore it's just normal to not work perfect. I have never had any connection issues. I was neither kicked out of a lobby nor from a quest. Also the game was just released. Give them some time to react on the release-bugs and gather some more hours to judge the game. I saw people reviewing with less then 1h played. How can people think they know much about this game?Well, not much to say. The game gives information about what is needed to play this game.Just don't play on a potato.Okay. I have to say this game is not cheap. But for this game, i have waited so many years. I would pay 100€ without wasting a thought about that. I am of the opinion that they chose the right price for this masterpiece.All in all, I can say it is worth buying. You have many hours of story, even more hours of endgame and a gorgeous world to play in. 10/10. Best Monster Hunter Game.Thanks for reading!

author: Chair

author: GhostedMemory
review: I gotta say so far I am Loving this game I see alot of people are complaining about it not being optimised But I have not ran into any problems. I am running it on 1080p 60 FPS Medium settings and the game looks great. The multiplayer does need to be fixed though because I keep getting Connection Has been lost but it is rare when that happen's.I'd say if you love Monster Hunter or are new to monster hunter then I'd say go for it.

author: Staple Boy 6.1
review: The only truly bad thing about this game on PC right now is the fact that it is a port.I do not recommend playing with mouse and keyboard because of that one simple fact (I did it for about 130 hours though, so its not that bad, its just nowhere near as good as with the controller, since it was made for it).The story here is extremely basic and unimportant, as in every MH game; Big bad monster is going to destroy the area if you don't do something about it.But I came here for the gameplay, and the game's mechanics are better than in the previous titles I played (3U and Gen), the weapons feel fresh and exciting and the world feels alive. You don't stand still after every attack with the heavier weapons and you don't have to flex after drinking a potion, I know that some veterans do not like this, saying that it takes away from the challenge (and I see their point), but I just consider these things a quality of life improvement. That being said, this is probably the easiest game of the series.The game also loads extremely fast on PC so that's a plus.The multiplayer here works flawlessly for me and anytime I got a connection error it was because of my own internet. This game is almost certainly more fun with a friend, or three.I would highly recommend that you play this game, especially if you want to get into the Monster Hunter series, as this is by far the best starting point.

author: Rampskii
review: 6 Days after release, a diamond stuck in coal, crumbling when not handled with care : Being completely new to the Monster Hunter series and having this game as a first experience feels like an amazing ride through the wild lands.Going to write some positives and negatives so prepare.It doesn't take long to get sucked into the universe that is Monster Hunter World.It's easy to see that the developers of this game are totally immersed and passionate about the mixture between full fantasy and prehistoric world creation, however there are a lot of rough patches.PROS :- carefully crafted and well designed world biomes- crazy weapon posibilities, allowing for a wide variety of playstyles- tons and tons of armor sets for both players and your cat companions- progression that seems to fluctuate depending on the monster you'll fight- wild monster fights with players and NPD(inosaur)s- Funky player & cat animationsCONS :- New player learning curve going all over the place- Horrible / Vague menu structures- unpredictible animation behavior- combat system / explanation is 100% missing from the intro's- cut scenes that are unskipable and preventing multiplayer access- not to forget the multiplayer components that are haywire, unpredictable and simply not finished.The game is a recommendation, however, take a breather when stuff goes wrong, most Con's will probably be patched.i hope

author: ginnnny

author: Bill Thaxton
review: The entire point of this game is literally just to murder a multitude of multi-ethnic and multi-cultured animals in order to get new and fresh clothes for your cat. And that's why it's good.

author: Orcish_Saiyan
review: I enjoy the game and have been a pretty avid Monster Hunter player since MHF2 on the PSP. I waited until this game came out on PC to buy and play and it's been a blast. There are some issues with it, but the developers are addressing them and hopefully they fix it in an update soon. The biggest issue is with multiplayer at the  moment and from reading other reviews that seems to be the biggest reason why everyone as a negative review on it. I love playing this game with people, but I enjoy going solo as well so I am giving it a positive review based on the fact that they are going to fix the current issues. Another minor thing that isn't a game breaker, but is annoying, is that the voice acting is not in sync with the lips of the character models. This game kind of "dumbs down" some of the mechanics of the old games, but it isn't too bad. Some veteran players may not like it, but it is all in a matter of opinion. All in all it's a good monster hunter game for new people and old players.

author: Spectre of Autism
review: The game has some release issues, most of which have been figured out, and have fixes available.I had an issue getting the game to run at all, but i fixed it with a bit of googling.The game is absolutely fantastic, looks great, runs smooth as butter, gorgeous environments, excellent gameplay loop.Genuinely, this could very well be the game of the year for me, most games are ♥♥♥♥ nwoadays, this got me playing until 4 in the morning.no game managed to hook me in like that for YEARS now.I absolutely recommend this game, go ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ play this ♥♥♥♥.If you're familiar with Dark souls, this game's easier than dark souls, but has a similar amount of challenge, but is a bit more forgiving, and there's a lot more to do in general, exploring is rewarded etc.bit of a disjointed review, but ♥♥♥♥ it, go play this ♥♥♥♥,

author: Kuon
review: First time Monster Hunter and I've been won over to the series with this game! It runs well on my setup, if you aren't so lucky I still encourage giving it a go once they resolve it's teething problems. It's been a metric heap of fun!

author: Atlen
review: Ignore all the complaints about server issues. That was expected with the amount of people getting this game. Server issues are universal to PC games and these issues are almost non-existent.This game is simply amazing. I only played MH Tri, and MH4U. This game is better than both of those combined. The quality of life changes that veterans to the game will appreciate, make the game overwhelmingly better. Capcom took almost every stressful quality of prior games and just improved them either slightly or copiously. The main change is the semi-open world aspect, where the zones are no longer separated by load screens. I could go on all day about how this game is amazing. However, let's talk PC port now. Compared to consoles the PC port has exceeded all expectations with:More than triple faster loading times (And that's only between getting sent off to quests, the only noticeable loading times are after cutscenes!)A higher framerate at a higher resolutionIncreased graphicsThe freedom to use the keyboard and mouse or a controller based on user preference. (Using mouse and keyboard, contrary to what you would initially think, is very good. Just required one or two remaps and that's it.)Steam friend integrationFree multiplayer3 Different ways to connect with your friendsEasy to alt-tab over to check wiki and stuff.=The PC version is already the superior version.

review: Bonk monster

author: CrimsX

author: ♥Chara喜生子♥
review: Port had many Issues on launch and still has a few quirks but overall has improved greatly since release.Monster Hunter as a seiries is wonderful and full of fantastic moments that you can only have in the universe. As someone with around 1800 hours in Monster Hunter Frontier Z (Another PC monster hunter game) I highly recommend the seiries to anyone willing to try it out. World is the most casual and easy to get into the seiries has ever been so now is a great time to try it out.Edit 7/14/2020:Now with Iceborne out, I can't recommend this game enough. Iceborne has brought back a lot of the classic Monster Hunter feeling while also providing a more substantive and challenging addition to the base game. The game is in the best state its ever been and I literally cannot tear myself away from it.If you're noticing the massive spike of negative reviews, a new monster was released that is very difficult. Due to some confusion about the mechanics of the fight many people think that you need extremely specific builds to beat it. This is not true and the monster can be beaten with a decently large variety of builds with some relative ease once you learn the fight enough.

author: Napoleon Stokes
review: Despite all the negative flak coming from the bad PC Port, I still believe this game is worthy of your attention. I'd say if you're on the fence about getting it, give it a few weeks to let them patch all the major port issues (which I do agree most of them are inexcusable, they had time to iron these issues). I play it single player so I don't have any co-op issues and I use a mouse and keyboard and I gotta say, it's still playable M+KB even without raw mouse input but the thing that irks me is un-bindable keys. You have an item bar that you have to scroll through to get to items and they cannot be bound to specific keys. It makes it incredibly clunky and it detracts your attention from the fights.However I am still going to recommend it because It is still an incredibly rich and detailed world to explore and the monster fights are intense and exciting. I don't think any of the major port issues stop me from enjoying this title. It just needs a few hotfixes to get it up to standards.

author: yato
review: とても良いゲームだけど友達と遊ぶマルチプレイヤーだけ直してほしいな!!!！：D

author: Bubble Buddy
review: Fantastic Game. Probably the best Monster Hunter to date so far. Not sure about all these connection issues people are talking about. I have only disconnected once in my 14 hours of play (as of this review). Great weapon variety, unique monsters, and great combat. If you are on the fence about this game, pull the trigger, you wont regret it!

author: Zeroxias
review: Writing this on my break in between sessions because even if it wasn't for the 'Mixed reviews' it definitely deserves a positive review. Coming from someone fairly new to the series, 60 hours in on writing this but expecting an endless amount more. I'm not going to address any of the launch issues or bug it currently has with the new Steam UI because I expect it to be resolved sooner or later so I don't see much point in judging the game or the devs for it.The game in itself is absolutely great and a blast to play either solo or with friends. Fans of the genre will most likely enjoy it thoroughly and MH fans or veterans have probably already played it on PS4 to know what it's about. It runs well on PC, loading times are almost non-existent (though it can depend on your rig) and the general performance is just stellar. I haven't tried playing with Keyboard/Mouse but some people might prefer it as it may offer more ease for navigation or ranged weapons.Update-wise, the PC version is behind on console but will get them eventually as free updates in the same fashion as consoles did. Which is something to be commended in this day and age.There's actually so much fun stuff you can do in the game and the littlest of detail they have put in it makes the game so much more enjoyable and perfect for me. I doubt I could write it all down in one Steam review, and I won't bother trying. I've played the game for almost 60 hours so far and am nowhere close to being done with this game.I'm enjoying every little bit of it but it has to be said that to fully enjoy it, you have to appreciate the hunt, weighty combat and the grind of it all. Cause as much as I would praise this game and say that any cons are heavily outweighed by the pros, it's not for everyone. If you're looking for a rich story you might be better off elsewhere, but if you just want to hunt big bad monsters in rich and lively environments, then it's definitely worth a try. The game is more than worth it's pricetag for what it is.Autumn Sale Edit: 400+ hours in, still great.

author: Detachi
review: I once had trouble connecting to other players on PC...Step 1: Turn on the PS4.Yes, the PS4.Step 2: Run Monster Hunter World.Step 3: Connect to any sever.Step 4: Keep the PS4 running and switch to the PC.Step 5: Run Monster Hunter World.Step 6: Connect to any server. It works now.I'm well aware that not everyone owns both a PS4, a PC and both copies of the game. But then again, I never said that this was a fix for everyone.Technical atrocities aside, the game is amazing.

author: Ameribear
review: Right now the game has several issues, including:-Network connectivity problems-No ability to change common PC settings like motion blur, depth of field, etc.-No 21:9 support-Severe texture issues even on FULL/Max settingsThe game itself is great, but be warned about the several technical issues present in the gameUPDATE - 8/26/18:Network connectivity has been significantly improved. While matchmaking still needs improvement, I have not been getting disconnected constantly from online and have been able to play with friends smoothly. PC technical issues are still present.UPDATE - 12/27/1821:9 support is confirmed to be coming in Q1 of 2019. Still no option to disable motion blur and such through in game menus. Texture issue has still not been officially addressed.UPDATE - 1/3/18I did some research and found that some, but not all, of the texture issues have been fixed. With this in mind, and the 21:9 support coming, I feel the game has improved to the point that I can recommend it.

author: Safari_Jake
review: I see a lot of complaints from normies and their toasters about the poor optimization but you can hear it from me, a guy who can actually run a computer, that these reports are demonstrably false. I was even able to run this game on my laptop (which threatens to explode in an IDE terroristic nature every time I start it up) by changing a few options. I have played this game for about 18 hours only at the cost of blood vessels bursting in both of my eyes due to my visceral primal reaction to the sheer volume of cheek blasting, skull cracking, and meat clenching carnage I unleashed on these drooling monstrous skin bags leaving me physically and spiritually blind which is the only thing slowing me down from spending the rest of my forseeable future playing this.On a more serious note, disabling volumetric rendering in the options and downscaling the graphics a tad will help with performance or maybe this is the wakeup call all you kids with your chrome books need an upgrade10/10

author: T A ↄ H A ᴎ k A
review: if this game isn't for you, go play Dauntless.

author: Aeris
review: game is good

author: Eric
review: Despite the connection issues and FPS drops, it's glorious to play MHW in 1440p and 60+ fps. I have hundreds of hours logged on the PS4 version and can confidently say this game offers extreme value. If Capcom can fix the random disconnects, optimize FPS for a range of CPU/GPU configs, and keep up the steady cadence of FREE updates, I cannot recommend this game enough.If you've never played a Monster Hunter Game, don't go watching videos and don't get stuck on the analogy of "it's essentially XX game but with boss fights and grinding". Just play the game and give it a chance. The smooth combat animations, layered progression system, and balanced weapon mechanics is worth the price of entry.

author: Artichoke Me Daddy
review: The gameplay and visuals are great.The UI and Menu system is an awful mess.Partying up with friends is a nightmare to navigate, getting quests going, getting into eachother's expeditions is a 6-7 step process despite being in the exact same online session (which in itself is 4-5 step process) just flat out inviting someone to your game wont work. They have to go to a specific NPC to join your game despite the invite.I found the menu system and the online play with friends so frustrating I found myself having to take a breather after every quest. It would say one of us haven't progressed the story far enough to join, despite both of us going through all of the previous quests fine, then starting the quest solo to find out there was a 6 second cutscene, but then being stuck in that quest so having to go back to town to then join the same quest you were just on but with your friend... who is still in the same online session as you the whole time...Yeah it makes as much sense as typing that whole thing out did.Thumbs down for just pure frustration. Developers need to take some UI/UX design 101 courses, then come back and patch this mess.

author: Itchy Paulsack
review: I have played Monster Hunter since 2013, with 350 hours in MH4U and 60 hours in MHG, and MHW for me is a really big mixed bag.  There is one BIG Minus that literally almost made me not recommend this game, but if you have enough patience to get through the big minus then you should definately get this game.POSITIVES+The co op (When it works) is friggin amazing, the gameplay of MHW is the best I have ever seen, especially ranged weapons now.  Capcom learned from Dragons Dohma with the feel of the bow and mounting, and it feels amazing.+Watching monsters fight each other in the wild is the greatest thing I have ever seen, the trailer doesn't give justice to the "oh ♥♥♥♥" moment when you see a monster pick up another monster and slam him into the ground.NEGATIVES- (The BIG minus) As someone who primarily plays Monster Hunter games for the multiplayer co-op, I have to ask Capcom, why do you have to try and meld the singleplayer and multiplayer campaign together?  There would be no trouble if you were able to play story missions together from the beginning, but you have to launch and then quit after you've finished the cutscene just to relaunch the mission if you want to play with friends. <sidenote> Capcom should be able to at least know how to put multiple people in the cutscene, or instead just show the one player in the cutscene, when you're in the party together.  Capcom should know this, because they literally have monster intro cutscenes in previous games like MH4U, granted, it isn't as cinematic as MHW, but they could have at least done something like that, just so it could stop the frustration with the players. The relaunching wouldn't be a problem because you can join one of your friends in the middle of the battle if you want, but there is one big problem with the connections itself.- I don't know if it is just me, but me and my friends literally a few states away sometimes cannot even join each other's session, or even mid join the mission.  Most of the time whenever we try to midjoin the mission after the friend watched the cutscene, a pop-up shows up saying it failed to join the quest.  I know MH is usually peer-to-peer, but it has never been this bad, and I hope Capcom fixes this issue.- Expeditions, they're just gathering quests but it is so hard to go on a multiplayer expedition.I still haven't made it past HR 8, so these are my earliest impressions and my biggest problems, and I do hope that Capcom fixes the servers if there is anything to fix, otherwise I hope there's something we can do to make the connection better for most people.

author: Unholy
review: One complaint: BRING BACK THE OVER THE TOP BLOOD GUSHING FROM THE MONSTERS. Been playing Monster Hunter since the 2004 release of Monster Hunter on Playstation 2. I've followed the franchise on several devices like PSP, iOS, Nintendo Wii U/3DS, and XBOX. I've played each game and haven't missed any releases. This game is in a genre of its own.Monster Hunter World is the most ambitious game in the franchise, adding complexity and an open-world feel. The first few hours of the game is explained quite well for new players, but if you're not new then you already understand how this game unfolds. There are 34 monsters in the MH:World in the console version, the PC version may lack a few but it should have several patches to add in some of the new ones, along with future ones once the PC version catches up with it's console predecessor. Each Monster has it's own attack pattern so rememeber to take a step back when engaging with one and observe it's pattern. Don't get to greedy when fighting one and dodge always! Once killed a monster, you will sheath your weapon and start skinning them for materials, you will then take those mats and use them at Astera's smithy and will allow you to craft many sets of Armor that will help you with upcoming fights. There are 14 different weapon types most of them play differently but there will be a few that might play smiliar, there should be enough to fit anyone's playstyle. Overall this game is a glorifed progression griding game. It does it well, with its awe enviroements and badass fighting mechanics. Something I want to see added from Capcom is a DLC for a High Resolution texture pack similar to what FFXV did. Not taking away anything from the graphics because the game is beautiful, but I know Capcom can do more with some of today's best computer builds.

author: TheDeadlyPianist
review: A lot of people are complaining about such minor details, and stuff that really doesn't affect the game at all.I have had no connection issues.Yes there are some FPS drops, but it isn't game breaking. Yes it does need fixing.However, the game is absolutely fantastic. I bought it on PS4, played it for 400 hours, and will do so again on PC. If not more, because more of my friends have it on PC now.The game is beautiful, and is easily the strongest title in the Monster Hunter series due to a lot of quality of life changes.This game is easily worth £50.It does NOT deserve a 50% Steam rating. Anything less than 80% quite frankly is an insult.It has the best, and most fluid action combat system in any game, as well as being incredibly satisfying to just fight monsters.Hits feel weighted, and finishing off strong monsters brings a sense of relief and joy that other games (except maybe Dark Souls) just cannot provide.

author: TheDevil
review: Immense networking issues preventing play on multiplayer sessions. I refuse to DMZ my network to play this game with friends and the recommended port forwarding does not work for me. Launch weeks do have issues but because of that if you want to play with friends and are uncertain about buying, save the money until reviews reflect a heavily improved online experience.(UPDATE)So it turns out a lot and i mean a lot of the networking issues were because of steam and the new chat system. I found disabling the new chat worked wonders in connectivity for online games. That stated there are still some issues and errors but they went from every five min to maybe once every few hours. The game is great, it always has been, but the networking issues (unfairly blamed on the title) caused it to be unenjoyable earning my previous review of not recommended.

author: Orbee
review: I will own up and now and say I am a huge MH fan and have been through most of the games where things weren't so streamlined and where things looked uggo. I think MHW is falling flat, gameplay wise for people in two ways and for one reason. It's accessable. MH fans might feel jarred or put off by some of the more convienient and less restrictive flow of MHW. It feels less structured and rigid than previous titles, even those with a bit of story. I was certainly thinking, 'wow, that's easier. That makes it less MH' But then there were so many systems in place that at points I felt a bit overwhelmed by new ways of doing things. All done I assume to make it more accessable to people unfamiliar with the franchise.And I think this is where newer people might come unstuck. There's a lot to take in because of this and the first few hours was tutorial based things. I am not even sure I am out of it yet. It still has the MH feel of dropping you in and letting you go despite this, which is great but also bad because newer players might not really get to the meat of the game before dismissing it. It sort of feels midground.I have had a couple crashes and one issue with online but that has been it. The online is a little confusingly done but so much better than the way it used to be, once you get your head round it, it's not so bad. Room for improvement though.It also runs... Not as well as you would hope. I have a mid tier system and it runs well enough on mid settings for it still to be a pretty game. But its not a smooth 60 experience. But coming from those 3DS days, or even PSP, I don't care.But the game play... Oh it's there alright.There is so much more to do other than slash and smash your way through a roster of monsters and this game is oozing personality in lots of subtle ways. It's great. There is a lot of content in this game, if you are willing to put the time in and learn what it's about. The combat is great on KBM, I was planning on using a controller but I actually prefer KBM. MH games have a really great combat system, with lots of subtle things and it isn't for everyone admittedly but if you are a MH fan, this title stays true but innovates enough to be fresh.The quest system wasn't what I was used to either, it feels much more RPG or MMO styled, picking up quests that aren't story based from NPCs related to what they do in regards to rewards. But it's actually a really nice change and much more immersive than 'pick from this list'.My recommendation is with caution, if you love MH you can't miss this one. If you've played MH before and thought, meh, this one might be the one to get you hooked. If you don't know if you like MH, you like hack n slash or you are expecting a Dark Souls experience tm, do lots of research before buying because it isn't for everyone and with some of the less appealing points, such as optimisation, it might not be for you.

author: Benny Bologna
review: This is a great game that is sure to suck many hours of free time out of my schedule, but....-The online component is very poorly handled. Joining on quests with your friends feels like trying to navigate through Nintendo's online system. You have to join your friend's lobby session, then, you have to join up in their actual quest. This is if you two are within a certain level of story progress, because you cannot join friends' quests if they are further up ahead than you are. That makes sense.. but you also do not get singleplayer progress, if you two are at the same stage in the story. This means you have to do each of the missions twice, one with each person as a host. The game also does not have a high tolerance for internet outages, and you will be dropped instantly, if there are any problems. This has required me to go to the main menu and re-enter the game. Other games will just lag in the lobby for a brief second or two, but this one can drop you entirely, for very brief issues. The online coop in this game is very fun, if you actually get everything working together.-The game will outright not run at all, if you have certain older GPUs or CPUs that are still capable of playing the game at a satisfactory level. This is not an issue for me, but the fact that this is happening due to the DRM (Denuvo) is completely unacceptable. Paying customers should not be punished due to anti-consumer practices.-Unbearably awful keyboard and mouse controls. I play with a PS4 controller, but I have tried out with KB/M, and you should not do that. The game has negative mouse acceleration that attempts to emulate a joystick deadzone. Why???? The UI feels very consolized, when you use KB/M, but it does offer hotkeys for quick use of items.This is an awesome, gorgeous game with some potentially ruinous issues.

author: BojackFragman
review: I ended up giving this game a recommendation, even though a thumbs down would have been just as valid. There are some serious drawbacks to the game: For a game that's pretty centered on coop (though you can easily solo it) it has BY FAR the worst multiplayer-system I've ever encountered. Mindbogglingly ridiculous decisions by the devs that gets you thinking if they've experienced a single online multiplayer system in the last couple of decades. On top of that there's major issues with connectivity, which means yhou'll get kicked from the online server regularly (this will supposedly get fixed shortly). Other than that, there are some weird performance issues at times, that even seriously hampers a pretty beefy system as mine (6700K and GTX1080), so a lot of people could have issues.So, why the recommendation? Well, looking past the other issues I have to say that I'm simply hooked. It starts out a bit slow, and I found myself wondering "What's the point" in the first few hours, as it's just one big grind. Catch/kill this monster, upgrade your gear, catch/kill the next monster, rinse and repeat. But it's just such a lovely grind somehow, once you get into it (and I'm only just getting started). I can't stop thinking about it when I'm not playing, and find myself looking up different guides and constantly changing weapons, as the 14 different weapon types are massively different from each other. It'll keep you on your toes.Another reason for the recommendation is simply that the current standing (43 % upvoted when I'm writing this) is simply not representative for the quality of the game. Try it out - you can always refund if you simply can't get past the wonky online component.

A lush beautiful landscape with different biomes to hunt in.

author: snake esports
review: Love how most of the recent negative reviews are guys with like 200+ hours in the game complaining and not recommending the game purely because we aren't getting the content updates as fast as promised, even remarking about how much they enjoy the game. Like, my dude's, you have 200+ hours from a $60 game you enjoyed, you have no ground to stand on, unless the game is truly being made worse overtime.The game is great, if you enjoyed focused grinding and the feeling of true progression in terms of personal ability then this is for you. There's few games that have given me more satisfaction than gradually improving and going from 20-30 minute kills on monsters to 7-10 minute kills. Monster designs are fun and interesting, environments are varied, difficulty is nice and balanced, story is just there and doesn't really add anything. Network issues have seemingly been fixed, I still get randomly dc'd every so often from my sessions but I'm 99% positive that's a steam issue. The only issue I have is how slow the game is to pick up at the start, it's not a game you can just pick up and decide if it's for you or not after a couple hours of gameplay.All in all, I give it a solid MattMercerIsMyWaifu/10

review: Honestly, One of the best games I have ever played. Its worth the price and you'll have endless hours of fun regardless if you're solo or want to party up with 3 other friends. All the weapons and armour sets are completely bada**. Its extremely satisfying when you do mass amounts of damage and hit combos perfectly. It's a bit of a demanding game, however, its 2019 and PC parts are decently priced. You can properly make a computer that can run it and wont make you broke. Also, controls for PC could be a bit better, however, you can rebind keys and you'll get used to it over time. Besides these minor things though, I highly recommend this game. Extremely worth it.

author: XMcKXMedX
review: Truly a fun experience for those who just want to focus on playing and enjoying their experience. Fair warning, the game will try to make you play with others as often as possible, as someone with few online friends, I am not overly fond of this idea as well as the fact that if you play with others, it will get more difficult. As someone who prefers to play games alone, this is the only drawback I can find with the game. The story is rich and interesting as well as the characters being fairly fleshed out.

author: Nathan Graves
review: I played the first time for realsies (and not just trying it and leaving it for months) in early November 2019 on PS4 after buying it and refunding it twice on Steam due to terrible performance.My first 20 hours on Ps4 were kinda not the best, I did have a cousin and my brother to play with, but it was overwhelming to me and almost gave up since I was not feeling it.Thankfully, I persevered, and managed to do 1000+ hours on Ps4 in like a 4 or 5 month span, which made it my first 1000 hour game that logged the time played, and also the most time i've played since I usually did like 1000+ hours of gaming during a whole year but spanning multiple games.So the fact that I managed to give so much of my time to this game, and then getting the steam version on May 2020 and have now logged 330 hours almost which was done in a single month, really makes me want to recommend this game to anyone that is considering it and I do not think that  going into the details of the game mechanics will make my review more helpful to someone that is looking for a reason to buy the game. Just considering the idea of getting it is reason enough, but if you have friends that would get it with you or already have it, that really would be a bigger reason to buy it, since starting off with friends you can talk with via voice will really help you get into the spirit of the game more.The only thing I would like to add to keep in mind, is that it's better to just get the Iceborne expansion from the get go since besides being a proper expansion that basically doubles the amount of content, also will let you do the latest free DLC updates that will end up adding new monsters and event missions. If you want some help I am up to help anyone that requires either actual coop help or just some answers to any stuff you might still not understand how they work like in the game.

author: Punifier
review: Monster hunter is a game about you learning to hunt for monster parts, for you to craft armour and weapon with those monster part. Then you go hunt bigger monster, gather material and parts , craft armour and weapon. Then bigger monster, get parts, craft. Monster.Parts.Craft. Except plates , you probably won't get those.It is probably my favorite one of the series, and with the expansion bringing back G-rank (called master rank i think) it should bring a bit more challenge for seasoned hunter. TL ;DR You should get this game. This game is good.

author: Chicane
review: This game got me so addicted. A lot of people will say there isn't enough content or it will get boring, but I would recommend you play this game solely just for the experience of trying a new game. There isn't a lot of content and this game is very grind based so I would recommend you take your precious time playing this game, that way you won't burn yourself out. I give it a 10/10 for sheer enjoyment and thrill!I'd like to also add:There isn't a colour blind mode option for all you colour blind people which really sucks and needs to be added in the game. I have a friend I'm playing with and some monsters look identical to others ones ex. Rathian, Rathalos, Azure Rathalos, Pink Rathian, etc. If the monster hunter devs could add a colour blind mode option that would make the game more enjoyable for those people.

The games content is great, tons of monsters to hunt, and a load of content and gear to grind.Now lets go over the complaints:REEEEE M&K CONTROLS ARE BADD REEEE - I have played this game excusilvly with M&K controls, yes the mouse takes some getting used to due to the acceleration feel to it but other then that all the controls are customizable.REEEEEEEEEE MP NO WORK- Multiple workarounds including the host remaking the sessionREEEEEEEEEEEEEEE I CANT JOIN MY FRIEND UNTIL HE SEES THE CUTSCENE- Grow up its not that hard to wait 30 seconds for him to watch the cutscene and then join himREEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE BAD GRAPHICSSS!!!!111!- It was stated that the graphics will be on par to that of the PS4 with an HD pack being released later, please learn to research before you buyDRMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMMM- Yes the game has DRM and yes it is known that it is not currently working with some old processors. author: SSShinobi
review: How you doing fellow kids? Like my dead  memes?For real though, I truly believe Capcom has an understanding of action games like no other company out there. You are a cute anime girl Hunting Monsters. Having played the PS4 version, I can say they don't look that different but even then, the game looks gorgeous. Coloful and vast locations keep the game from getting stale. You'll even catch yourself staring in awe at the jaw-dropping vistas the game has to offer. This iteration of Monster Hunter tried to focus on realism a bit more than the rest. This can be seen in the weapon designs and some armors. If you are a fan of Generations like me, this could be regarded as something bad. Though that doesn't mean there aren't some kickass weapon and armor designs. (ODOGARON <3) This is where the game shines. Basically, you fight H U G E A S S  Monsters, carve their precious parts, forge armor and equipment. Rinse and Repeat. But the process of doing it is where the fun lies. Monsters have patterns, weakspots, weaknesess to certain elements and they can even get into fights with other bigger monsters if you lead them to their den. It does make you feel like a Monster Hunter since you gotta look for footprints, mucus, carvings, etc. until you find the Monster. Since there are no levels or classes, the game allows you to change your weapon and playstyle at anytime at your base camp. Having said this, there are "roles" (which are not enforced in any way, this is more of a community thing) which can help a veteran party of 4 get hunts done more quickly. For example: Swords are better at cutting, so my "job" is to cut the tail asap. While Hammers do a hell of a lot more stun damage, so their "job" is to hit the head of the monster to stun them quicker. You can still get by perfectly fine without this, but I thought it was a nice little fun thing to do. GREATSWORD BOIS REPRESENT!!!!Oh and I can say with certainty that it runs extremely fine. You should turn off Volumetric fog and Ambient Occlusion if you are having FPS drops. Currently the game is experiencing some network issues, from what I could gather, not being able to join quests and lobbies and getting disconnected is normal since the game just launched. The game it's not without its flaws though. The worst offender being having to wait for the host to watch the cutscenes before the game lets you join the quest. Sometimes you need to go into the desired quest yourself, watch the cutscene, leave and finally then join your friend's quest. I don't understand why they decided to do this in the most stupid, roundabout way ever. Is it that difficult to make it so both players watch the same cutscene at the same time? Jeez...Regardless of all this, I sincerely L O V E this game. Its Game of The Year material for sure.  The end game is one of the most thrilling experiences there are. We are also getting tons of new events and monsters in the near future so be sure to look forward to that!

author: やりまん
review: I am a 45 yo mother, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single mother to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my husband had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

author: Toaster
review: This is a very bad port, don't reccomend at all. VERY BAD.

author: thetft
review: My opinion to all this rage here:I honestly think it is a good (not perfect) port. In 70 hours I only got like 10 DCs, what is nothing compared to the time I spent in server queues on release day of other AAA titles. Also I hit like 80-100 FPS on a i7-7700k and a GTX 1080, so no complaints. Regarding the reported mouse-input issues: yeah it is true, but why do you guys don't use a gamepad in the first place? It's like playing a flight simulator that is intended to be played with a joystick with mouse and keyboard and then complaining about how bad it feels. The argument that the devs had 9 months to perfect the port is one of the most stupid things I ever heard. 9 month in software-development are nothing, so honestly regarding the time spent on the port the devs really did a good job!To the game itself:When a game manages to get you addicted to the grind and spending hours on number crunching, you really know you like a game. Also i love the details and dedication spent on non main features, like the possibility to catch or kill every living thing you can find.I really appreciate the game and can't wait for new content. Well done capcom!

author: Meatloaf
review: To everyone ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ about how the game is having a rough start, shut the hell up already. What game has anyone ever played that didnt have a rough start? You may lose connection from time to time, and hell, even a crash or two here or there. Guess what, the game autosaves so unless its a serious bug you wont lose anything from a crash, and the load times are so fast that disconnects can be fixed in seconds by simply rejoining or backing out and reforming the quest, which is incredibly easy to do. I have over 100 hours on this game already and for anyone looking for a fun RPG game that can be enjoyed solo or with friends, this is the game for you. It has a fun grind and rewarding combat. Nothing feels better than landing your big combo and sending the monster reeling back from the hit. So if you wanna ♥♥♥♥♥ and moan and ruin a good games rating on here because of some issues that have NOTHING to do with the gameplay and EVERYTHING to do with the servers, go ahead. Just dont rate negatively and ruin it for everyone else who takes random idiots opinions on the internet seriously.

author: Hamtaro
review: Pros-Gameplay is really good and fun- a lot content if you decide do everything that is offer in the game- 14 weapons to choose and all weapons play differently-most newcomers friendly monster hunter game I played based on the previous games I played (MH3U, MH4U, and MHGen).-really fun with friends -you can absolutely solo most of the content in this game but if you get really good at the game then everything can be solo-easy to learn but difficult to masterCons-Story is okay but gameplay makes up for it-sometimes randoms will troll in the quest-might encounter some hackers but on really hard monsters only(easy to tell when they one shot or you get an incredible time) this happen to me twice so far. I see more people talk about it in the MHW subreddit but it rarely appears as a post like once a blue moon.-sometimes randoms will just afk at camp to leech off you fighting the monsters(usually hard ones) but its like at that point why don't you mod things in then if you gonna leech off. This is based off from what I read from MHW subreddit but it happen to me only once during a behemoth run.-sometimes the servers are bad and you disconnect from session -RNG base drops, can be really bad you might not get that one decoration you need for a build from half hour to months.-Monster hunter games and including this one pretty much don't tell you a lot of the hidden mechanics so you either need to have friend who is a veteran from previous monster hunter titles or look things up online or someone in your session tells you a hidden mechanic you didn't know of. All these hidden mechanics or stuff are like quality of life improvements in the game for you. For example, there's a lot of people don't know that you can buy an powercharm and armorcharm from the shop after you reach Hunter Rank 6 I believe. And then you can craft them with a bazel talon to get the powertalon and armortalon once you defeat your first bazelguese in high rank.  All four items are stackable with each other in your item pouch. So this gives you a significant boost into your overall defense and attack which makes a difference in your damage output and how much damage you can take from a monster.-console gets new content first so if you don't want spoilers you need to stay away from youtube videos about mhw and websites containing mhw content

author: Krikkit
review: There's a good game in here somewhere. The gameplay is certainly great, but unskippable cutscenes and mandatory expeditions throw pacing and the potential for a fluid multiplayer experience out the window. Part of what makes these cutscenes so damning is that the story is mediocre at best. From a technical standpoint, the game looks nice but is poorly optimized and has an inconsistent online connection. It's a shame - when the game actually let's me play it, it's great.

author: Lewdie!
review: Arguably one of the first accessible monster hunter game on multiple platforms, (I think so at least because I haven't played the other mh games)Long story short, a friend of mine gifted me base game and iceborne, said that he wanted me to experience it. So, I went ahead and tried the game. First time booting it up was a mess, because I had a crappy laptop. Well, once I got a better one, I started gaming! First impressions of the game weren't really good, but the farther I got, I started to understand certain things as my experience grew. Despite the timeless grinding at times, or not having the hunt in your favor, it feels immensely rewarding when you finally beat that monster. And then you start growing in power, getting better gear, beating monsters easily that you have struggled with before. I for myself have not beaten the game yet, but in currently in the process of doing so. SO, if you're a random guy or gal who's reading this right now, please lend me your help, I've yet to beat fatalis!All in all, this is a very fun game to play with friends, just make sure at least one of them knows how to play so they can teach you!

author: Joeygotjokes
review: I've played this game for 5000+ hours on PS4.  This has been my go to game after a long day at work, and the game of choice for all my friends who stream on Twitch.  Since I start playing on PC, it was the first time I even thought of abandoning my PS4 Character(s).  I never will though.  That being said, if you have ever been on the fence about buying this game, don't be.  Just buy it.  This game is phenomenal, by every measure you can think of.  Character design, level design, replay-ability, gameplay, etc.  FYI, this is by no means, an easy game.  Think of it as a much more fluid and better version of Dark Souls, but much more rewarding.  I cannot express how much I love this game so much.  Thank you CAPCOM, for being so generous with this franchise, and polishing it to this degree.  Thank you for 15 years of dedication, and passion for developing one of the greatest games ever made.I highly recommend getting the Master Edition of the game as it comes with the Base game, and the Iceborne Expansion, with a few extras as a thank you from CAPCOM.  Go now, buy it!!!  You won't regret it.

author: MrMars
review: If you ever wanted to try to get into the Monster Hunter series, then you found the best entry point right here. This game is a perfect entry into the Monster Hunter games. Sure, it doesn't have the content of Generations Ultimate (MHGU), since the game was build on a new engine, but it will change over time and this game will hold you for atleast 100+ hours of content pre DLC/AddOn (around 600 hours on PS4 and 200 on PC as of right now for me).New events and monsters will be added for free and will give you new armor and ways to get jewels and materials to keep the game fresh.There are 14 weapon types in this game for you to try out and master.No matter if you play alone or with friends I think you will have a great time with it.I really recommend giving this game a try.

author: genuinehealing
review: Okay so this game is the epitome of grind games. If you like doing the same things over and over for the chance something will drop and then you can finally get that final upgrade, this game is absolutely perfect for you. If you dont like these types of games there is a good chance because of how well made this game is you will start to like it but you have to give the game time to suit your likings. The mixed reviews come from the unfairness towards lower end PCs which is completely understandable. A lot of people are not fortunate enough to have high end PCs to run this game but that should not mean they can not play at low settings at a playable fps. All in all Monster Hunter World is the perfect game for the right group of people. Always look up videos to see how the game plays and whether or not it appeals to you.

author: Sean Bean
review: Monster Hunter: World is one of my most played games recently, the game play is spectacular and the game mechanics are wonderful as well. After over 300 hours of playing, I am still learning different tricks from each weapon and I still have yet to master them all. Monster Hunter: World has been a great opportunity for Capcom to open up this wonderful game series to more of the public, as the other games have not been on PC. Truly a great game!

author: Portnoy
review: "Great game, bad port" seems to be the consensus here. Maybe I've been lucky with how few connection issues I've had, or maybe I'm just tollerant to problems, but the months of fun my friends and I have had cement this as one of the best games I've ever played.

review: Sweet game.Fun multiplayer, beautifully designed world, interesting and unique monsters and a really in depth weapon and armor system which makes every build and weapon class feel super unique.It's fun both solo and with friends, and knowing that there are more Free Title Updates with more Monsters and Events coming soon makes me really excited to play more.There were a few Multiplayer issues on launch, but since those have been fixed the game has been pretty flawless.

author: Vixali
review: I have played upwards of 35 hours from release and its a little bit of a hot mess. I love the monster hunter franchise and i was ecstatic for the opportunity to play the game on my PC. We had to wait a long time for a "playable" port to come to PC. The miriad of connection issues and game crashes are hard to ignore and ruin the overall experience. I have played the game on both Playstation 4 and PC the issues on PC far out weigh those on PS4. I have read we will be getting a fix soon, but the problems shouldn't have been there to begin with, or at least a day one patch. Capcom has taken too long to respond and I cannot recommend the game if you plan to play with friends as you will have issues at every turn. If you plan on playing solo and might team up with friends later down the track then I will say its a fairly decent game and it runs pretty well, however we need a texture optimization for sure to hit higher framerates.Pros -The Game Looks Beautiful and Polished.Great Keyboard and Controller Interface.Great Customisability for Keyboard Users.Bow is Drastically Better On Mouse.Cons -Denuvo DRM Not Needed In 2018 Just Hurting Legitimate Buyers.Day One Connection Issues.Little To No Communication From Devs.Game Crashes At Random Intervals.Most Controls May Require Remapping.Port Forwarding Is A Must To Even Try Online Play.I will update this review when my grievances are patched. Until then 7/10.
