author: BanditBob
review: MHW is a great game. There's a variety of weapons with fluid reactive combat and depth (minus the dual blades with 2 main ground moves). Even so, every weapon is fun and rewarding. While I personally do not like game music, MHW does have a pretty epic soundtrack and there are some gameplay elements that incorporate the BGM. The world design is vibrant and purposeful, which leads to some inconveniences. While every major NPC and structure has a functionality, it means there's no centralize hub to do everything you need to do. You'll still have to run around and manage your resources. (IMO it's kind of immensive but I can see how annoying that can get) One of the major hurdles of this game is the steep learning curve and awkward controls implemented to the mouse and keyboard. Short answers is, if you can look pass that and enjoy the combat, you'll get use to it. That's really what it comes down to, are you willing to learn something new?

author: Peppa Pigsaw
review: This is one of those games I wish I could say I recommend it but at the same time I don't.Monster Hunter as a series has always been something special in the hearts of the fans, so for a lot of us to see the series take a step forward and make a game look THIS good while at the same time being a mostly smooth experience was great.The weapons all have a really nice feel to them, a lot of new and interesting monsters make their debut here, and the game added a lot of little QOL changes to the series that was overall a nice addition. Not having to constantly keep my whetstones stocked would probably be the first thing that comes to mind.But at the same time Monster Hunter World suffers from a few issues. It is FAR from perfect. Normally that is to be expected, but the problem is that these issues are so large that after playing the game on both PC and PS4 collectively they stick out like a sore thumb.Monster Hunter as a series has always prided itself on its unique weapon and armour design. Each monster would give you unique weapons and armour that was custom tailored to fit the theme of that monster. Any fan of the older games would know this for sure, as usually every weapon was easily distinguishable and you could tell what weapon it was at a glance.Monster Hunter World does not do this. Most weapons are a very disappointing copy paste of the original Metal and Bone weapons with monster parts simply slapped on with a bit of super glue. Which means while in previous games if you hunted a monster you would get these really sick and cool looking weapons that were unique ONLY to that monster, Capcom in this game simply hands you an ugly brown stick and says "Welcome to the Bone Zone."The endgame in Monster Hunter World is also tragically...fairly nonexistant. How they managed that in a Monster Hunter game is beyond me. But I think it has to do that Monster Hunter feels very shallow compared to the previous games. The previous games had HUNDREDS of monsters ready for you to poke with a sharp stick. World doesnt have anywhere near that many.Finally, the one everyone knows, the Clutch Claw. The Clutch Claw was a neat concept and cool idea but was so horribly implemented that it just completely throws the entire pace of hunts off. Making the base game hunts too easy, while making the Iceborne hunts bearable.The game is fun, but in some areas it really lacks a lot of the charm that the previous games had. It's something you should pick up on a sale, not really at full price. On the brightside, if you are new to the series Monster Hunter World is the easiest out of the series and should help you ease into the games as a whole.

author: Ary
review: Short Pro/Cons after the Edit. Then a lil text about my experience of the game / how it feels. i'm at about 50h now, so far i can say....+ familiar MH feeling+ a lot of (minor?) improvements in HUDs and Menues and Gameplay wich smooth out all the lil hickups the older games had, making a really solid and good base+ hunting and stealth aspects make the game much more interesting, so does the manuvering in the maps / open worlds+ really beginner friendly, tutorials are really well made and easy to understand - even the paching is great by handling you things over not to fast but also not to slow.+ Learning Curve is both good for experianced and beginner players this time+ uped the grafics (like MH tri)+ new poin system mixes it all together and you have rewards for every lil thing you do, wich feels just great!+ the lore is actually exsistent this time and is presented in a good to understand and interesting way+ as is the story. and i mean a real story, it has one this time. Maybe a bit light, but its there and its good!+ optional quests not only improve items, chefs kitchen/eating, weapons etc but aou now can also build camps and make it easier to travel and play on a map if you prepare and buold stuff up! You ahve to travel there before and find places where you CAn tho, wich is cool in my book bc its immersive, but might annoy people. - just look up a guide then.+ the grind actually got better, like in, you-can-get-quests-wich-higher-drop-chance-better ;) Its not too easy but also not too hard wich i apprichiate, having build Rathian set for what feels like the 100th time xD+ DLC / Patches are free as always ! i love you MH devs !- since so much had to be changed / fixed and of so many improvements (grafics, better story and tied-in monsters, open world, animations and movement quality) it does not have as man monster as other titles. You dont relly feel it tho, its not that much less then it might look on the paper. Its like with Tri / MH3U kinda - judging but what i saw myself and heared i would say you still got about 300h of content, so dont worry !- DLC from console does not seem to be implemented yet (?), but i guess its okay Or you can just slay monsters and help out others, just jump an and have some team action on hard monsters (they get harder with more players ofc, but its also way more fun and the teamplay is, not counting rare hiccups, really great). Go in, do your thing if thats what you like. If you have trouble you can still decide to call fo help anytime tho-! Just great how fluent it works :)Like i said, might be the best Entry yet, but i still have a lot to see so i will stop here :P

From what i can see they release a patch every 2 weeks and maybe a new dlc every month or so.

review: I think I've never seen a game made with this much love before. The entire world, the characters and monsters, are created so well and detailed. There are so many things you can do that don't really "benefit" the story, for example being able to cuddle with your palico at a footbath or going into a sauna, but they help creating this awesome atmosphere and really drag you into the world.

author: kibatamashi
review: I only finished base game and still so much post game stuffs to do. Thought I would drop the review anyway.I have never played any MonHun games before but this is currently the best one out there for sure. I got into the game expecting just 'hunt monsters with friends and grind' but there were so many other aspects of the game that my mind was blown. The amount of content is massive and if you wanna learn multiple weapons and master them the playtime just keeps extending.The monsters are a joy to learn, map is so rich and fun to explore and I absolutely adore my palico. Sound effects are also very ambient. I get lost just exploring map sometimes. I am not big on games that are too grindy but no 2 hunt is the same to me here and the grind never gets boring. Plus having friends too play with just adds to the enjoyment. And when you can finally pull off a cool move with any weapon man that feels so satisfying.Game is easily in my top 10 favourite games of all time. Get the DLC as well on sale it's worth every bit.

review: Alright, I love this game, I have over 100 hours at the time of writing, and let me tell you... it's been a challenge. If you want a difficult, yet rewarding game, this is the best you'll get. the graphics are great, the devs support mods (just not the cheaty ones), and if you decide you want it, don't forget iceborne... it actually doubles the amount of content, and you get to use the clutch claw, which comes in... well... clutch... very often.

author: Eric
review: First of all, great game that worthwhile investing. Due to the pandemic last year, I found myself a ton of time staying home where I begin to play this game. I love it! I like the combat style with the astonishing graphics. The fun comes from: 1) playing with friends. 2) challenging quests. 3) fashion and treasures hunting. There are so many ways of playing the game other than slaying monsters here and there. So many tools in hunt that allow you to develop your own hunting scheme. Most importantly, the environmental creatures, taking photos, and treasure hunting are tons of fun (I think the developer really put some efforts in these, very thoughtful)! Although I feel like a review came from me on this game is going to be super biased,  I would still recommend it to others solely because I enjoyed it a lot. And of course, games come and go, but I never regret putting all those hours in and will keep coming back whenever. Please don't feel hesitate to try!!!

author: Great troll khan
review: i started my monster hunter journey with freedom unite on psp. alas i didn't get to play the other titles after 3rd portable.now after this many years finally i got the chance to relive my childhood memories. the changes which has been done to the series is unbelievable...the game is faster and enjoyable more than ever. there are so many things you can do in the game(especially with the addition of iceborn)that you can sink hundreds  of hours into it and still not have completed the game. one of the things i really like about mhw is trying out new creative builds and having tons of them as your loud outs .really i think this is a game any one can enjoy if they try and understand it ... although i don't like the simplification which they have done to the game such as:*removing  pickaxes and bugnets from the game **making crafting easier such as giving you most of the recipes at the beginning of the game**changing the recipes so they would need only one ingredient such as health potions which used to need blue mushrooms and herbs**removing the wheatstone mechanic which used to be a item and now you can use it infinitely*...i think these mechanics might have made the previous game a bit grindy but i think they  added more depth to older titles so you should have prepared yourself for each hunt. i'll admit that these changes should've been made so more audience can get in to the game...if your fan you should've played this by now and if you aren't trust me and give it a try. you wont be disappointed ;)

author: Xeladon
review: This was my first introduction to the Monster Hunter series. From the very beginning of the game I fell in love with it, it's so different from what I'm used to playing that I just couldn't stop playing.The gameplay sounds very basic at first, you hunt and battle monsters, but once you get used to how combat works you'll notice how much depth there really is, the learning curve is very steep, which is why I can really only recommend you this game if you enjoy how the combat feels, but nevertheless I hope you give it a chance and stick to the game until after you've beaten the main story, that is where the real game starts. It can get grindy and I usually don't like grinding, but for me the game was just so much fun, that I never had the feeling I'm wasting my time, hoping that the RNG would be kind to me this time like in other modern games.The graphics are very impressive, the attention to detail is amazing, and with the free High Resolution Patch you can get the game to look a little bit more crispy. It runs fine on my system, you just have to tweak the settings to your liking. The story, while nothing game changing is fine and I think you can get invested in it if you're already enjoying the gameplay, only real problem this game has are unskippable cutscenes, but don't worry we're on PC, Mods got your back ;)tl;drTry out the gameplay, see for yourself which weapon suits your playstyle and try to optimize your hunts (never forget you can use a lot of different and very helpful items). Once you get the hang of it the game is going to be a lot of fun, I had a blast and I hope you do too! Happy Hunting!

author: Vendrick Ruler of Drip
review: Finally the monster hunter franchise comes to PC. If you've played previous titles you will enjoy this game, and if you're new to the series the game is very good, if somewhat difficult to get the handle of. I enjoy the fact that the devs have added so many monsters from previous titles, and keep adding more with events and free (not counting the Iceborne expansion) dlc/updates. The one major issue I have with the game is that there are several weapons in the game that just look...lazy. Many (especially for hammers) weapons and their upgrades look like they are just copy pasted variations of bone weaponry. There are still many cool looking weapons within MHW, but it feels like weapons lack the variety they did in previous titles. Luckily on PC if you feel like it, there are several mods that can change how weapons look so the problem is alleviated, if not by the devs themselves. All in all I'd say the game is fun, difficult when taking on endgame content (as it should be) and very much worth the money. 9/10P.S. Capcom where is the ability to skip all the cutscenes and ability to play with friends through the main story without them needing to see all the cutscenes first, ree

review: As a veteran hunter for about 10 years(from MHF 1 to MHW), here's an honest review. It surely lacks of major content such as monsters and environnement. Why would they add Ice biome in a DLC instead of adding it in game directly? The previous game already had a Ice biome with quests and such in the base game. The quests in general are way too easy compared to the other games too... There is also some awckward things such as not using a Cold Drink when you are in the Desert. The multiplayer is total crap, too many network issues that gets you disconnected in the middle of a quest and they were supposed to be fixed since a long time already. I'm honestly  disappointed. But I will still give a thumbs up because the team is working hard on this game which I hope will be promising in the future.

author: DreamedReality
review: Gameplay : 7/10A solid game experience. The AI for the monsters is fairly nicely timed to give a good challenge. Fun but grindy and can get a bit repetative. Best played with friends assuming all your friends can connect. Graphics : 8/10very beautiful but also rather intensive if trying to run high graphcs while in multiplayer.Performance : 6/10So many connection errors. Some to the point some of the people I know can't even play. Not well optimized port and the few patches that have happened are slow in coming.Controls : 8/10Controls are pretty simple and easy to learn.Story : 3/10Don't play this game for story. Its very weak and doesn't have much to it. Whats there also doesn't hold up very well. NPCs are often annoying too. Multiplayer / Community : 8/10Where this game really shines is in multiplayer. Its so satisfying to go in with your friends and learn together and figure out how to take down some of the fastest and toughest monsters out in the world. Especially with a group of friends that are all about the same gear level and experience its a huge accomplishment feeling to finally get the next trouble monster killed.Overall : 7/10This game can lose steam quite a bit due to connection errors and other port bugs. Its also not nearly as updated as the console release is. But for a multiplayer game its fantastic. Its a great co-op challenge for you and your friends to go take on some nice challenging fights. The grind can be a bit intense. But it isn't impossible. This game' saving grace is its multiplayer aspects.

That asside this is by far the easiest game on newcommers to the series so if youve ever wanted to get into the monhun series this would be the one to do it.

author:  Vox Populi 
review: Monster Hunter: World mixes it's addictive game play with a tinge of modern mechanics for the new generation. Far removed from most of the jank that has persisted the series like several maps, being unable to move when drinking potions, and needing to paint ball the monsters, this game underpins what makes the loop of kill->carve->kill so satisfying. PROS:+fast load times+Literal Hundreds of Hours of Gameplay+Tons of players at any time+14 weapons that could very well be in their own game+Satisfying end-game+free Monster/Armor/Weapon DLCsCONS:-Disconnection issues(not that persistent after latest patch)-Some performance problems on 4 core PCs(use Kaldaien's Special K mod to rectify)-Not for those who dislike grinding-weapon models lack variety-less monsters than in other games(Generations specifically)-menu needs a lot of work(several hidden elements that the game won't tell you)

author: Arkight
review: disclaimer: I am a MH vet. Played thousands of hours in previous MH games and even 200+ on the PS4 version of world.If you are one who enjoys the typical well executed RPG self-feeding loop, you get gear to improve in battle, and you battle to get gear. Then this game is for you. - The gear, this is MH, the game who provides this formula that so many love, in a way like no other. You will get satisfaction on every piece you craft, and you will feel its worth. There is no "absolute best" gear in this game. You are encouraged to craft many sets and adapt your gear to the situations.- The battle system is amazing, one of the best (IMO the best) action battle systems. This is NOT an hack and slash. If that is what you are looking for, look somewhere else. This is an action tactical battle system. Where every single input matters. Your performance in battle will be highly dependent on how skilled you are at reading the monsters, adapting to the situations, taking advantage of the environment, choosing the right gear, and ultimately how skilled you are with your weapon.- There are 14 weapon styles and every single one of them is and feels unique. They all have their own tricks and dept to them. Even if you play the same weapon for 100h+ you can still find new hidden or non-obvious tricks that can change your play style with that same weapon, potentially improving your performance.- There are details that the game will purposely not explain. This is part of MH culture, its gonna be a bit unusual to some people, but you are encouraged to explore the mechanics and figure them out by experience.- The difficulty of the game starts low, and will gradually increase as you progress. You will encounter new monsters regularly, and some of them are bound to give you more trouble then others. This is also related to the gear mechanics I mentioned earlier. Some weapons are more suited to handle certain monsters then others, but then again, its highly dependent on your skill.The story however is poor and non-interesting, so if that's your thing, you prob not gonna have a good time.I have experience in many RPG's of many styles, and (unless your the story guy) I absolutely recommend this game.You will have an incredible immersive combat experience. And satisfaction for crafting gear like no other.

author: PyroReason
review: UPDATED REVIEW FOR ICEBORNE It's unfortunate that some people are experiencing performance issues, so your mileage may vary according to your hardware. I'm using a RTX 2070, i7 9700K  16 GB Ram running on a 860 EVO  on the latest drivers that Nvidia has out. My performance so far has been a steady 60 all through out with no performance dips. Multiplayer has been steady as well. I also tried the game on a GTX 1070 Max Q, i7 7700K, 32 GB RAM 256 SSD. Ran at 60 FPS at 1080p32 Hours of play time latter, the only issues I've had so far are Multiplayer disconnection issues. I will be mid hunt on someones SOS and then lose connection. The problem is becoming more frequent. Also, when ever I fire an SOS my self, it doesn't seem anyone can join me anymore.I say it's unfortunate mostly because Iceborne is very very fun and freshens up MH:W in a way that it needed to survive as a game as a service. I'm hopeful that this game will see similar expansions in this scale in the future rather than an iteration in title entries. Sustained progress is much more favorable in my opinion, instead of starting all over again in a new game. So I'm happy the team behind this game made the decision to expand upon what is already here.TL:DR Good game gets better.

author: Rinera
review: This game is... annoying. Annoying because it's extremely fun to play, BUT due to silly design choices and port related bugs it leaves a lot to be desired.Let's just get the port issues out of the way. Performance is not at acceptable levels, settings menu is incomplete, kb/m controls are horrible for UI management but ironically just fine for combat, and there's a lot of disconnection issues. There's other issues as well but you might or might not encounter them so too rare to actually be mentioned.If you only cared about those few things, there you have a quick summary. But if you want a more detailed look into the actual game, grab a metaphorical drink and read the rest! Or just go look at the scores while I grab a literal drink wondering why I even wrote this. Anywho...The overall game consists of doing basically 1 thing, hunting monsters. There's some story but not even the game cares about it. But at the same time the story is simplistically stupid enough that it fits with the actual gameplay. You are a hunter who is.. well.. a hunter. It just happens that dinosaurs are still around, even bigger and literally more magical, so hunting is a serious business organized almost like an army. And that's about as far as it goes, but that's not a bad thing at all as the game attempts to build all of its details around that.From big things like the overall story, to small things like player animations, it all fits right in. For a quick example, during the opening cutscene, your character weirdly focus a bit too much on a food platter without much context. That seems completely out of place at first, but as you get to play even further and see the way your character is animated and the way they react, that starting little detail made more sense. It was a very simple way of driving in the point that you are a fully-fledged hunter, not some kind of noble hero. You are not there to find yourself or save the world or whatever, just there to do your job.It's not just your character that acts like but the NPCs as well to a certain extent. Everyone seems to be excited to be in this place full of mystery and research opportunities. Buuuut that's a hugely missed opportunity. For all the detail that went to drive in the point, your character is at the end of the day just a silent protagonist who does what they are told, at most nodding, not even ever declining anything. The NPCs start acting all friendly towards you as the story moves on, but it never feels like you want to care about what they say, of course they would start acting friendly towards the supposedly top hunter in their little organization. A few dialogue options and small side missions would have made a whole lot difference.But why would a game like that need such a thing, right? Well the game literally teases you about it. It keeps talking about your supposed bond between you and your "partner" and how you 2 are doing a great job and whatnot! ... Well I am mentioning her existance right now because that matters so little she might as well not be your partner but could have been a different character every time she was on screen and the story would have been the same.Ou that's a lot of words about the part of a game barely anyone cares about. Anyway, combat. It's fun, the end. Barely any complaints about the combat itself, it's the best thing about this game. Your weapons feel nice and heavy, animation quality is amazing for almost everything you or the monsters do, and there's just enough fluff like the screen shaking etc to make certain aspects feel even more impactful. You can also turn that off if it annoys you so win-win. If I were to complain about anything combat related is that the special tools you get are just boring as hell. But luckily they never become the focus, just a side thing to use if you need a bit of help.But while the part of the combat you manually do is almost flawless, the armor building is ... problematic. Not the literal crafting but picking an armorset for your needs. The meshes and textures themselves look great, with little sound details like clinging metal depending on the set you are wearing. But you can't really have the set you want because of some arbitrary passive buff system. Certain gear gives certain buffs, things like higher resistance to certain things, higher defense, immunity to stuff, that kind of thing. But they are not given to gear in a logical fashion, but springled in an almost random way. For example, a belt making you withstand monster roars better than a headpiece. That makes it partically impossible to pick the look you want AND the buffs you want. On top of that silliness going on, "boss" specific armor more often than not gives you benefits fighting against... that boss and that boss only. So in order to have an easier time fighting a boss you need to first keep fighting that boss to get the gear that boss gives material for, but after you got all the gear you have no reason to fight that boss anymore. It's not impossible to make kind of a build you want without having to sacrifice too much on the looks, or you can just ignore those passive benefits all together and pick the set you want, but that would be purposely putting yourself at a disadvantage.AND FINALLY, co-op and general online play. The game was clearly made to be played co-op, but it does not allow you to go through the story in co-op, meaning that you will NOT be able to play with your friends or even other random people through matchmaking until you reach the end-game where you'd have mostly everything unlocked. It also cuts the money you get after each mission if it was done with other people, straight up punishing you for playing with them. And then there's the lobby system. IGNORING disconnections, 16 people per session is not enough to do anything, and the matchamaking prioritizes ping over your progression, so you can end up in a session with everyone being too low to join in hunts that you might want...There's hackers too, so going in a mission with randoms is a risk as they might just decide to ruin your fun.Sooooooo because the interactions with NPCs are basically "skip dialogue and go the menu", grinding for gear is frustrating due to the impossible min-maxing of looks and utility and because of all the port related issues that do not allow you to have as much fun as the game intended you to, like playing co-op when you get bored, the game is suffering right now. While the bugs might be fixed, design choices will not, meaning that the game will never be as much fun as it should have been. Still, I did put 100 hours into it and I'll put more, because what it does right is done so right that I want more of it, it just doesn't give me a good reason to keep doing it. I'd have voted "meh" but since (that doesn't exist) my overall frustration with the game was because I enjoyed it yet the issues wouldn't go away, I'd have to recommend it.

author: Voidgazer
review: The definitive monster hunting experience is finally on PC.+huge new areas with no loading screens+new and improved weapon movesets+new monster and reworked old classics+transparent key quest system+no more gathering or small monster slaying quests+quests can now be joined in progress+various QoL improvements+HD visuals at 60 frames per second+free online multiplayer=revamped armor skill system (no more negative or inactive skills)=endgame RNG charm grind swapped places with RNG decoration grind=no more blademaster/gunner armor separation-the enemy roster could be bigger and with more variety (like carapaceon and neopteron monsters)-a lot of weapon models lack personality and look too similar to each other

author: AiiR
review: Maybe not as much content or as good as former games. But it's a step in the right direction.A PC release means they're probably considering future games to be on PC too.Numerous quality of life changes make it more accessible and fun, take gathering for example, you don't need to bring pickaxes specifically for mining outcrops anymore.New features like the Wishlist or armor and weapon previewing are also great QoL additions.Overall a solid entry to the series and would very much recommend, especially for newcomers to the series as it is a lot more casual than former titles but nonetheless still very fun for veterans.

author: Captain Mack
review: Every cutscene, every monster, every weapon, every texture, every blade of grass clearly has hours of somebody's work put into it. Since the PS4 release they've added 3 monsters, numerous cross-over content, and different seasonal events all completely free. Don't believe the reviews calling them money grubbing. Don't believe the reviews saying they shoved this out as soon as they could. I'll be the first to admit that the PC controls are terrible. Yes, going through the story Co-op is a pain because they want to force the story on you. However, I don't see either of those as good reasons to not play this fantastic game. Honestly anyone expecting good PC controls has never touched this franchise. It isn't meant for a mouse and keyboard. That's coming from a guy who is primarily a PC gamer. The Co-op thing sucks, but the vast majority of this game is outside of the story and outside of that issue. You'll forget all about it once you're into the meat of the game.I love this game with all of my heart.

author: namelessnick91
review: MHW was the first Monster Hunter game I had ever played and I picked it up for the Xbox One (I have the year one edition of the XBONE). I logged 200 hours into the game and then realized that once the game came out for the PC that I would pick that up and not ever play the Xbox version again so I stopped and waited. WELL WORTH THE WAIT!!! The only issues I have had are the slight server instabilities which is nowhere near as bad as it was for the console release, at least this is playable with some communication disconnects. Yes the default key bindings for the KB&M can be a little wonky but there are enough control options and key binding menus (with seperate melee and ranged binding options) that anyone who takes the time to make them work for you will not have an issue. The game was designed and built for a controller but I started playing with the KB&M and after some tweaks will not go back now. Even without direct mouse input the game flows a lot better and easier with the speed and precision a mouse brings along with the customization that a KB allows. I am running a EVGA 1070 with an Intel I7 6400K and have only 1 time had a stutter in my FPS with a drop from 60fps to 48fps. I have purchased the game for myself and 5 of my friends ($300 total) and do not regret it for a second. This game will keep us occupied for hundreds of hours of play time. There are some slight issues but this port is very playable and definitely worth your money!

author: Narukami
review: TL; DR: The game itself is AMAZING, the game itself has some flaws but are easy to get past and the PC port itself is good but can be better. Overall FANTASTIC game and definitely worth a purchaseMonster Hunter World is a FANTASTIC game. The countless hours I've spent on this game and series, in general, is staggering and I'm still not bored yet! The gameplay flow and pacing of the game make it easy to pick up and play grind out or just in short bursts. The graphics are beautiful and all the monsters feel fun even after killing them countless times. The PC port itself is pretty barebones with no DoF or Motion Blur options but there are still many options to configure to help the game look better or run better. The default PC controls are really wonky but every single thing can be rebound to your wishes. The game also has the option to use a controller natively including the PS4 controller. With the right HDD load, times are basically non-existent in this port which is a Godsend compared to the console versionsMultiplayer after day 2 is still pretty wonky with frequent disconnects and some lobby issues but I'm sure Capcom will be able to fix it eventually. One of the biggest flaws is that quests with cutscenes specifically story quests are technically supposed to be done solo, to play them multiplayer each player has to view the cutscene, back out and then its open to multiplayer. Its something really annoying but will eventually get fixed as later quests in the game don't have these cutscenes meaning you can do multiplayer from the very beginning. Overall this game is fantastic just with a few flaws that make the game kind of a mess to play in the early stages of the game. I HIGHLY recommend this game and or series to anyone looking into getting into it, and maybe you'll fall into the addiction of Monster Hunter that I and many others have already.Happy Hunting!

author: Red Fox 🦊
review: This is probably the most fun I've had playing a game in a while. This is my first Monster Hunter game so read the rest of the review with that in mind. There's definitely a learning curve to the game and with all the different types of weapons, it can take you 10+ hours just to figure out what play style suits you the most and that part is not the most fun to do I know. But once you're past that stage this game is extremely fun be it in solo or with a group. The monster types have huge variations with their movesets that'll require you to play a bit differently with each of them, and that's something I really enjoyed. Keep in mind though that the end game is full of grinding, so if you aren't a fan of that then there's not much to do after the main story and a few other side quests, but again even that might take upto 40 hours, so you'll get your money's worth. I'd highly recommend this game.P.S. The new Iceborne expansion is coming out that only adds to the already fantastic experience.

author: Boatplugs
review: I'm a big fan of the monster hunter series and I was extremely happy and excited to hear that worlds was making a PC release. What a wonderful game! If you appreciate tight combat mechanics, extensive weapon selections, PERFECT gameplay loops, high quality graphics and cohesive styles then you'll most likely enjoy this game. Plenty of cosmetic and stat decisions to be made when picking your armor and equipment. I'd like to note that the game developers have done an amazing job keeping the PC version of this game near flawless. The initial stream of updates were slow and sparse but overtime they've added in nearly everything a PC player could want. I initially didn't suggest this game because of the general lack of PC specific features; I rescind that review due to the update allowing ultrawide support and the various other improvements that have been made since then. I HIGHLY recommend this game. There are cat puns and you fight giant monsters what's not to love?

author: TheNightwingGrayson
review: I'm splitting this into 2 sections, 1 for the game itself and 1 for the quality of the port. This is a review from a first time Monster Hunter. Long time fans should look elsewhere for a review. tl;dr Love the game, port has issues, if your PC meets requirements get it anyway, it's too funEdit 1: Locked the game at 60, used Radeon settings to override game settings and it's much more stable. (60 frames nearly all the time) Enabled some filters, not very high but you can notice less jaggedness, with no performance loss and far less stuttering.1) The Game   Monster Hunter World is incredibly fun. The monsters themselves are interesting visually and the environments are beautiful in their own right. There are a multitude of weapons to choose from and they all have a unique play style. If you prefer faster weapons there are dual swords, or sword and shield and if you prefer a big hammer or great sword they've got you covered as well. Try them all out and see which one clicks for you. This game is deliberately slow and methodical. You can't just spam the attack button over and over again until you win. You need to recognize what attack the monster is doing and either sprint or dodge roll out of the way. The game isn't "clunky" like some people might say, it just doesn't reward mindless mashing at least not later into the game. The main thing that might completely turn you off about Monster Hunter is that it is a VERY grindy game. You will be hunting monsters over and over again for parts to craft armor and weapons. That's the foundation of the game. If you don't like grinding, regardless of whether or not the fight is fun, then you won't enjoy Monster Hunter. I can enjoy a bit of a grind, especially when there's so many big monsters to fight.2) The Port   OK, so here's a touchy subject. The port is NOT great. It's absolutely not the worst and I wouldn't even say it's bad, it's just not above average. The development team clearly needed/needs more time to fine tune things. This is their first attempt at a PC version and it shows. Some features are missing, like control over motion blur and depth of field. The game's looks don't reflect how it runs. I'm only playing at 1080p, with a mix of med/high settings (mostly medium) with some things just turned off completely like filters and volume rendering (obviously) and I get drops to mid 40s (once into the 30s) in some situations. There is such a wide swing in performance. One minute I'll be running through Ancient forest framerate anywhere from 60s to 80s (smooth) and the next an Anjanath will be charging in to fight, attack my palico and the game jolts down to 45 instantly before recovering.     I get that this is Monster Hunter's first proper appearance on PC, as well as home consoles in a long time, and that it's still better than it's ever been, performance-wise, but that doesn't excuse how unpolished parts of this port are. I really hope the dev team (and Nvidia and AMD with future drivers) can continue to improve things because this game is ridiculously fun, I think I may even love Monster Hunter, but this isn't the port this game deserves. It deserves better and it's a disservice to this game to just be "fine" with how it is. The thing is, even with how wonky the port is I still recommend it. It's just too fun not to recommend. If you have a PC that can run it (I have a Ryzen 1700x and RX 480) then give it a shot if it appeals to you.

author: Emdood
review: I really love the Monster Hunter franchise.I remember tucking in with my mates in the previous installments of the game and staying up till 5am hunting for those damned monster gems and as soon as someone got one, it was followed with us all kicking the ♥♥♥♥ out of them.Monster Hunter: World has captured almost all of the same stuff for me, minus getting together IRL.That said, I've also grown up a bit and not everyone can spare the time to hang out, so being able to play with each other in the comfort of our own homes is fine aswell.The game has a low skill floor at first, but then kicks it into 12th gear and kicks your ass at high rank, with tempered monsters giving you something super difficult to hunt.My only gripe with the game, is the lack of G-Rank, which is only lame because I really wanted some sick high rank armor sets, over slightly different ones that you can color.But luckily Iceborne is coming out soon and the addition of Master Rank sounds like its exactly what I want.Brilliant Game, would get triple carted by Kulve Taroth again.Much Reccomend.

author: Praise The Sun
review: First played Monster Hunter Tri and Ultimate for the Wii and Wii U respectively.I can definitely feel a difference in how the games stories progress. Some say that the game is really grindy, but I mean in the 3 games that I've played, that is kind of necessary. It would be silly to be able to make every armor piece of weapon after killing something 2 or 3 times. The "grind" makes things feel more special and you more accomplished in a way.(Assuming this is the final monster hunter, no clue if it is) It would be amazing to see if they could somehow incorporate the monsters from every game that they are missing currently. Just wishful thinking though, they would almost need a new island to include everyone and everything.

author: ADK
review: Aside from some connectivity issues at launch, I cannot recommend this game enough. It's extremely addictive, and leaves you wanting to hunt and hunt and hunt to get that last scale or piece you needed to upgrade that fire sword that does so much damage. The game honestly feels like the Phantom Pain of Monster Hunter. Everything the series should be, at its best.  I highly recommend this game, my only complain that still stands is that it simply isn't that well optimized. You can still manage to get mostly 60 FPS but for how good the graphics are theres no reason your hardware needs to be as good as it is. I'm hoping this will be fixed in the future, but we'll see.

author: Bryan With A Why.
review: Oh man, this game ... Where do I even start ...I've always loved the Monster Hunter series ever since I was a wee lad. I played a lot of the Monster Hunter games, with the exception of 4, 4U, Frontier and Generations. So needless to say, I've had plenty of time to get bored of the game.But it never really happened.- Graphics are nice, just detailed enough to catch your eye without distracting you too much.- The gameplay is fantastic, as it has always been.- The weapons feel great. Each has a unique playstyle.- Each monster you hunt feels unique (with a few exceptions, like the variants)- Unlike the other MH games, the environment here is completely open, with no loading time in between zones. This makes the gameplay feel smoother, and also makes it more tense (since you can't just bail out of a zone to heal in combat)- A ton of quality of life changes. Namely auto-crafting, being able to move while drinking potions, no more blademaster/gunner armor sets, etc...- Layered Armor ! (Vanity armor, basically)- The game can get very repetitive, especially end-game content.- Even though the monsters are very well made, there's not a whole lot of them. As of now, there are 31 in MH:W, as opposed to 71 in MHGen.- The weapons and armor lack the great designs we've seen in the past, and feel bland and common (with a few exceptions)- Layered Armor isn't Transmogrification. Which means there are only few sets, as opposed to unlocking every armor you craft as layered armor. (but there is a mod to fix that, I believe)- The game isn't for everyone. Some people can find the gameplay clunky at first, since there is no way to cancel an attack, but you pretty much have to treat this game's fighting as Dark Souls. Observe your enemy, commit to an attack, back off, rinse and repeat. (Unless you play some of the faster weapons, in which case you completely skip the "observe" part and go all out, dodging out of reaction time and prediction.)The game is also a constant grind to get better gear. But thankfully, just like Dark Souls, the game isn't bound to "Meta", and is only limited by your own skill. You hunt anything with any weapon (as long as you do enough damage, since there's a time limit to your hunts). Your playstyle is never NOT going to work, but there are varying degrees of success, obviously. But you're never forced into anything. (unless it's Behemoth ... ♥♥♥♥ me, that thing is strong)And if the game starts being boring ? Just hunt with friends. They fixed the servers, it's fine now. Hunting in this game is much more fun with pals, trust me. I've beaten the end-game, but I still find reasons to come back. Because my friends make this game feel more fun. Anyway, I highly recommend this game, if "thriving for improvement" is your thing. If you feel like you're having a hard time, remember: This is the easiest Monster Hunter game. Have fun ! : The game's fun, even more fun with friends, combat feels good, weapons feel good, monsters are well made, (but it's quality > quantity), weapon designs got bland, lots of QoL changes. Definetly worth the price, even more so if it's on sale.

author: Random | Wholesome Degenerate
review: When the game first arrived for PC, it wasn't at its best. It was plagued by numerous issues concerning lacking visuals, bugged visuals in cutscenes, constant connection issues, and more. Now, while the odd issue pops up every now and again with content releasing for the first time on the PC version, it has gone above and beyond in regaining consumer trust in my opinion.I was always going to play it. I don't own a PS4 and Nintendo seemed to have every other MonHun title on its platforms which I haven't owned since the Wii U. Where as I had thought we'd see simultaneous Wii U and 3DS releases, we got the one in MH3U and everything else went to the 3DS. With Monster Hunter World, we have a modern adaptation of a game series I've been in love with since 2004. With beautiful locations, monsters, and a ton of quality-of-life improvements, Monster Hunter World is the best in the series I've played so far. Keep in mind, I've only managed the first on PS2, the PSP games following it, and MH3 and MH3U on the Wii and Wii U. Were I blessed with a Switch I would definitely be spending equal time in Monster Hunter Generations Ultimate.The only real downside here is the emphasis on mixed sets which without layered armor tend to look goofy, and the poorly implemented RNG method of obtaining decorations. In prior games, at least as I observed, you'd choose a baseline set with points towards skills you like and them you'd slot in decorations and use charms to empower the existing skills are add new complimentary or utility skills. All while looking great in a full set of matching gear. There were mixed sets in that era as well, but nowhere near as prevalent and meta as they are in MHW. Though the constant updates offering varied layered armor sets allow you to look good and perform well. The decoration system is unfortunately the one black mark on the game. I'm sure it will come in a future G or Ultimate expansion to the game, but Tempered and Arch Tempered monsters as a replacement for a full-fledged G Rank series of quests with new monsters and subspecies is... well, par for the course actually. MonHun has been adding expansions to base games and selling them anew since the first in 2004, so it's not too surprising, just still disappointing. Having to rely on RNG for decorations is an absolute bore, though.That said, those are the only negative aspects I can think of for an otherwise unforgettable experience. Aside from Azure Rathalos of course being a constant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ but that's what Flashpods are for. The combat is varied and skill-based, with a different tempo and method to defeating each beast based on your class of weapon. Movelists have been expanded since my time, adding over the top special moves that will knock monsters over, sever their tails, and break their horns! The core gameplay of slaying progressively stronger, larger, and more fearsome monsters while using the body parts of your slain foes to craft and improve weapons and armor is as addictive and rewarding as ever. New investigation quests allow for extra reward slots of varied rarity to close the gap in your hunt for rare parts. Each map is a near labyrinth of ups and downs, twists and turns, with hidden alcoves and tunnels only you can access. These maps are filled to the brim with collectables and pets for your room back at base. Literally stuffed full of useful items for crafting tools, weapons, and armor. Monsters clash with each other like never before in turf wars to decide who's the biggest and baddest. It's all just so damn cool to see coming from the prior era of Monster Hunter.As my play time will show, I love this game so very much. Breached HR100 and there's still so much to do. So many weapons, armors, and decorations to collect. So many sets to build and improve for my favorite weapon types. So many upcoming monsters and AT variants with layered sets, event quests, and more. The fun won't end for a long while, so I hope you'll give this game another chance if it turned you away during the initial release. You won't regret it.

author: Lewdis
review: Great intro to the series for those who've always heard of Monster Hunter but couldn't get into it because of the consoles it was stranded on or how daunting it looked to get into, however the content is very lacking compared to the mainline series from the monster count/variation (majority of them are just generic flying wyverns to the armors and weapons available but this is obviously a stepping stone on the way to something great.If you're looking for the usual "hardcore" MH experience, you'll be better off with Generations on the switch instead. That isn't to say I don't think the game is good, but tempered monsters and grinding decos isn't enough "content" to keep me sated when Generations Ultimate is the same price with 5 times the content with G-Rank on top.

author: Dutan
review: This is a great game and in my opinion everyone is bashing it for no good reason. The game runs fine on my pc even at high graphics. People are complaining about mouse acceleration but this isn't a first person shooter that requires the most precise mouse movement in the world. People are complaining about multiplayer drops but it rarely happens to me, when it does I can just reconnect. Honestly the pc version of this game is a lot better than I thought it would be, especially since it is the first monster hunter on pc. If you want the game but bad reviews are hindering you get it anyways because I haven't found anything majorly wrong with it. Just make sure you know what the combat is like before you buy it because it is not for everyone.

author: Socially Acceptable
review: Alright, for the first time in my gaming career I'm going to give a serious review.First of all, some addressing is in order: 1) All you connection issue people? Stop writing negative reviews regarding a problem that the Capcom team is working on fixing. All online games have connectivity issues at one point or another and you are supposed to be writing a review on the game itself. 2) All of you "bad port" people? You have no idea what you're talking about. Some people are having no problems with framerate or playability with this game and their specs and some people are having some problems. It all is dependent on your HARDWARE. If you bought crappy off-brand hardware of course you're gonna have problems.And now to the review: Back when the Nintendo Wii was still putting out games, my two brothers and I pooled together our savings and bought Monster Hunter 3 Tri. Thus began a love for this series with all three of us. Capcom has been a little sketchy with universal releases and once Monster Hunter: WORLD was announced, we were all stoked. We bought the game once it released on the PC (even though I was worried I wasn't going to be able to run it on my lower-end computer) and have been going through the game together.My specs: Processor - AMD FX-6300 RAM - 8 GB of RAM Video - GTX 750 ti 2GB Story - This game has a way more in-depth story than any of the previous games and it is very enjoyable to play and read the dialogue.Graphics - I can run on mid settings with a solid 30fps (good enough for me). The look of this game is beautiful even on these settings. My youngest brother can have uncapped framerates on his 1060.Connectivity - I have only had one issue with connectivity when playing with my brothers. We reloaded the game and it was fixed. Also, for those who are having this issue, Capcom is fixing it so PLEASE stop giving the game a negative review due to ONE issue with the game.Playability - Overall, a great port (if it is one). But, I kind of doubt it is a port because it took them 7 months to bring it to the PC?Overall, this is a great game and I am looking forward to future DLC. Don't listen to those negative reviews.

author: EXO Raizy雪
review: This game is by far the most enjoyable MH game I've played, however the multiplayer issue on PC release completely ruins the whole experience for me, imagine 10 minutes into a quest and someone DCs from the session, and that person struggles to complete the quest because the difficulty DOESN'T scale back down from multiplayer so the boss still have so much HP. And this happens constantly every couple of quests, it's a horrible experience.Pros:++ Graphics++ Beautiful maps++ Soundtrack+ Improved mechanics / gameplay from previous MH games+ Stable port, I've put 100 hours in and my game hasn't ran into any issues / crashed onceCons:-- MULTIPLAYER CONSTANTLY DISCONNECTS PEOPLE MID QUESTEDIT: Ever since patch I haven't gotten a single DC, nice :)-- Main story quests that have cutscenes that cannot be watched together with friends, resulting everyone have to watch the cutscene by themselves and then start a new quest to play together. (This applies to EVERY story quest)- Lack of content(Monsters & Quests, G-Rank) compared to the previous games, more are coming as DLCs but it still feels very lacking and short on release- You can change gear in camps, but cannot change decorations? If you want to use a different element weapon you'll need to go back to the main town to change decorations that supports it- The fast travel system in the main city is great, however you have to run 10 seconds to reach it everytime you enter the city, it gets tedious overtime- Some minor bugs here and there

author: Silvermann
review: Can't believe I will ever see Monster Hunter coming to PC, but here it is.Monster Hunter: World is the latest installment, and marks the beginning of a new generation, of the popular franchise. With reaching the global audience in mind, Capcom made numerous decisions that appeals to the Western market by streamlining some mechanics in the previous games, along with updated graphics. While it has no doubt drew more audience towards it, it also annoyed many long-time fans who thought the change was too much. I am not going to cover all of those, as readers can easily find those information online.In this game, you play as a hunter, and your job is to aid the research of all kinds of monsters in this world by killing it or capturing it alive. The story involves you and your fellow hunters in going to an uncharted landmass and study the mysterious phenomon happening over there. Story is pretty simple. It is just there to give you a reason to be there, and serves as a tutorial for the players. Once the story is over, you are left on your own device to continue your research in this world, or move on to a different game if you think you are finished.When it comes to combat, I hear a lot of people compare it with the Souls games, and I think this is the sad reality of Souls coming to PC earlier than Monster Hunters. Personally, I do not think they are alike, since the focus is different. Souls is about you overcoming one obstacle after another by progressing through the world that is very hostile to you. This is not the case for Monster Hunter World, since there are many collectibles and traps on the map that you can utilize to tip the battle to your favor. Also it is usually monsters that would be the one running away instead of you. The combat is very action-packed, but you are not at such a disadvantaged position like you would be in a Souls game.Graphic is good enough to me. I think it does a pretty good job in presenting different parts of the world, and I like what I see.Content wise, I think it is enough for me. I understand there are people who are used to Monster Hunter games with almost 100 monsters, do bear in mind that the first game and the third game also started with a similar roster because of them being on a new platform. I am getting hundreds of hours from this game already, and I am content. Do I want more stuff? Absolutely.Is the game worth it, then? I would say yes. This is a good entrypoint for new players of the series, and those who likes to beat on big monsters and take their loot would appreciate the charm of the game.

author: Blazing
review: This review is written by a player new to the franchise. TL;DR:++Immersive monsters ++Armor customization and selection++Weapon customization+Weapon diversity+Reguarly adding content -Grinding-Difficulty--Port --Hub--Story--Repetitive--RNG based elements--The Handler---HitboxesStoryThe story itself is fairly uninteresting. It serves mostly as a way of introducing the world and the monsters to you. Not at any moment did I sit on the edge of my seat in curiosity for what was to be come next. Therefore, the story  should not be your reason for playing this game.GameplayI do find the gameplay fairly disappointing, mostly because of its lack of accurate hitboxes. It can be a real annoyance at times – especially when the monster can one shot you. For example, it is not uncommon for you to get charged for, as far as I can tell, its full damage when you’re standing BEHIND your target.The monsters can also often roar CC you and gets quite annoying when it happens multiple times in a row.There’s also a random chance of getting stun after being hit, which can guarantee your death if you’re, well, unlucky.The targeting system is horrible with M+K. Better off aiming manually all the time.. Flash Pods are absolutely broken and make any monster that flies into the air a joke .Walking up a climbable vines/walls makes you climb automatically – even if you’re using an healing item and therefore canceling it. This can actually kill you when you’re accidentally walking into it backwards.You can get pinned down, which seems to have no other purpose than killing you by being unable to quickly move out of terrain that damages you.Your attack animation seem to not be accurate in conjunction with the actual hits. For example, hitting a monster and seeing your weapon pass the monster entirely can not hit if the monster roars or hits you right after that.Your cat’s abilities can often get ignored when called for, and calling for them requires you to put away your weapon. This can cause you to have to repeatedly sheathe your weapon to call for it again until he does it.There seems to be no way to guarantee a mount (skillfully), it just seems to be a chance that slowly goes up.  Other than that, the mounting itself takes no skill after you realise that It also seems that CC chaining monsters is the highest tier gameplay, which is fairly disappointing.Disregarded all these imperfections, the combat is fairly enjoyable and decent.DifficultyThe game does not pose a challenge skillwise, it poses a challenge in preparation and knowledge. The most important to winning the game long term is to upgrade your equipment and weapon. For short term with a specific boss and to obviously know its general moveset.The game’s difficulty is mostly just pumping up numbers: make monsters hit harder and give them more hp. You generally have Besides that, they recoloured a few bosses and called them different. For example, The monster variety seems to be too small for a game that focuses on killing monsters, and a lot of monsters are very similar. They are, supposedly, adding frequent free monster updates, though, which does ease this issue.ImmersionWhat I believe the game excels at most, is the immersion. The monsters feel very realistic and it can feel like you’re hunting a real dinosa.. monster - at least in the beginning. The immersion does wear off fairly quick once you kill the same monster a few times and start to understand its  general pattern. The terrain, although sometimes somewhat small, can feel very immersive because of how distinct the terrain is –  clearly an eye for detail.The scoutfly system does ruin the immersion a lot, though. These shouldn’t have been constantly present. There’s a mod to remove it, though.Lip sync is off, not everything is voiced and the lines were not written well.Characters are named by their role. They literally couldn’t even name your “Handler” or any of the expedition leaders.WorldIt is NOT an open world game.The hub is especially badly designed. There’s a lot of running around for the occasional micro tasks you should be doing, because the locations are not optional - you even need to go through a loading screen for one. There’s actually a fast traveling mechanic within the hub for covenience, but they’re not well placed and missing in the most essential spot .There’s a countdown after finishing a quest, which means you may have not enough time or too much.  Should simply have an option to leave whenever you want after finishing.There’s no retry option or proper stay as group option (staying as a group in an expedition is not the same, especially when everyone has to accept the next quest all over again).MultiplayerHub seems to be mostly for playing for friends and for arena, should’ve raised the capacity so you can have an active quest board. Also could’ve made your hub fill with players and not just purposeless NPCs.The SOS system is nice for getting random people into your hunts, although I believe it shouldn’t be main co-op method.A leaver in your quest cannot be replaced, which means if someone is intentionally doing nothing you either can kick him and get no replacement or let him get double value by looting or doing nothing and still getting the boss reward.The multiplayer only scales for solo or multiplayer, not depending on the amount of players. Arena is always scaled for multiplayer (unnecessarily).GrindingThe game seems to like grinding... It really, really likes grinding... If you’re not a fan of it, I suggest you better be satisfied with only completing the story line because nearly all the customization requires grinding.  The bosses get repetitive and boring quick once you kill it 10x in a row, which ruins the immersion a lot. Just so you have a 1% chance of getting that one thing you want.CustomizationThe character customization for your character and your cat are pretty extensive, although I did miss the common body height/type modifications.The different armor sets seem very unique and you can switch them around. You can also create interesting Skill combinations.The weapon customization is even more diverse. At higher rank, UIThat chat bar is bad.The order of consumable items does not seem to consistently save, meaning you often have to reorganise it if it’s your main way of using items.The game forcefully changes your camera angle when it thinks it locates something important, even when it means locating a monster that is infront of you by turning your camera around.SOS quest board search critera does not get saved.Port/OptionsYou can rebind keys for melee and ranged weapons, but not for specific weapons. The last should be a thing because the weapons are generally very distinctive and deserve their own kind of keybinds.Quick access menu in combat allows you to sharpen your weapon while it is out, but it cannot be done with the normal use item menu (???).	Overall, I'd not recommend this game at full price unless you're a MH fan. 50% off is probably what I'd consider its value.

author: Drakkhan

author: Angel Bacon
review: TL;DR: If you like killing interesting monsters over and over to get resources to make new weapons and armor and are prepared to sink tons of hours into a game with some friends, then this is the game for you.I have 100+ hours on PS4 and I have played this series for the past 10 years. So I may be a bit Biased, but this is the opinion from a Monster Hunter Veteran:This game is an amazing entry in the series and perfect for new comers of the series who have never touched a Monster Hunter game before. It has a lot of mechanics that streamline things that were challenging in previous monster hunter or took time away from hunting such as gathering or load times between areas. Honestly, the maps are very interesting and very unique.That being said, this game also may dissapoint people who've been following the game as long as I have been. The game is way easier and there are less monsters than what has been included in recent entries in the series. It really makes me Crave Monster Hunter Generations Ultimate, but I will honestly find myself coming back to this game for a long time. Because it is more accessible more of my friends are picking up this game and its honestly not really comparable to the traditional Monster Hunters. This game has so many unique mechanics such as the Environmental Hazards and the Monster Clashes, meanwhile MHGU allows you to play as a palico and has more content. I will be picking up both this month because of this.

author: Renevoire
review: So so so Satisfied with this game! First timer to the Monster Hunter Series. Long-time MMORPG player.9/10 | The Graphics are great! Compared to previous entries, which i've always followed, it looks awesome. 10/10 | The Combat. If you've seen the trailer, you know its good. You FEEL the hits and FEEL good! Especially when you pull off a combo or the perfect positioning attack. Having  14 weapons to choose from is a HUGE added value too and all vary in gameplay. So try them all out. 4/10 | The Story... is a story. Not that great, but you do feel a sort of relationship with the characters. Won't really be invested in the npcs as much as you get invested with the monsters that you slay/capture.9/10 | Great Replayability. Create your own build. Learn all the weapons. Challenge stronger monsters. Find a multitude of ways to slay/capture a monster. Hope to see more kinds/types of monsters added to the game.Looking forward to the DLCs and would definitely pay for new significant content! On a personal note regarding other reviews:While there may be problems with the multiplayer at launch, this is common with any game launch on any platform. I think people have their expectations set way too high. Monster hunter is NOT an MMORPG. It is more of a single player game, rather than a multiplayer. Though the multiplayer is an awesome addition to the game, being a key feature with the previous entries on handheld consoles. Playing with friends is a BIG PLUS, but i think the game should not be put at the same standard as MMORPGs or Online Shooters. Monster hunter can be played solo throughout the whole game, whilst an MMORPG cannot be played offline. Heck, even MMORPGS have bad/rough launches due to connection issues. It is a common occurance. So please be reasonable with your reviews, especially if you have invested a TON of time into the game. As the future of the game; like new content, could be impacted by your review.- UPDATE - Acquired tons of Layered Armours from events.New Expansion announced and I am not disapointed. Cant wait for ICEBORNE. Been keeping up with the updates. Enjoyed AT Vaal and looking forward to Behemoth.
