author: Cynquilla
review: I had been sitting on the debate of getting this game for a long time. The fact that it has mixed reviews can be misleading. The game itself is gorgeous, with very modern physics for a game in this day of age. The ambiance is amazing. The combat system is complex, with a variety of weapons to choose from, depending on your playstyle. It's better to team up with friends in hunting the bigger monsters, though, taking on a furry t-rex solo was both challening and fun.  With the hours I put into this game, I am very addicted and satisfied with the choice I made with my purchase. My only wish is being able to interact with the Palico companion more, since you do get little pets to place into your room, and be able to interact with them. A little sad that I don't get to cuddle the kitty friendo. Character customization is what I love in games. A lot of options to choose from, including facial features, expressions, the use of a color wheel and makeup. Don't  forget to pick up your free dlc for more hair choices and a free voucher to edit your character if you don't like how they look in the beginning. Overall, the crafting system is very unique, as in, being able to have pages open on crafting the necessary components to craft what you actually need. What you need solely depends on how much you research and harvest on your expeditions.You can fend off your foes with parts you've obtained from their species and have forged into your gear. Keep an eye on effects, skills and stats your gear offers. Mixing and matching can benefit you in many ways. Researching your hunts is a huge benefactor in the game. The more you track/research them, the more you understand what  they are strong and weak against, as well as their locations, territory, diet and rivals. Watching your prey fight another monster is quite a sight and you can use this to your advantage.The hunts themselves are really fun, especially having to track and chase down your prey. Again, depending on your weapon of choice, the hunt may result in a quicker downfall of the monster. I was able to take down a Pukei-Pukei without having it run off with the Jagras form of the Commission Axe. Very satisfying, considering I was taking a chance with the bow at first. Eating is key in this game, depending on what you get at the canteen effects various stats for yourself and your Palico. I also, at least, recommend watching the cutscene of the Palicos preparing your meal at least once. On your hunts/expeditions, you can also prepare your own quick meal  with raw meat. What you do with the meat is up to you; whether tainting it for your next kill, or grilling it to the beat of the music for an increase of stamina and recovery. Upgrading and forging armor and weapons is a little mundane, and depends on what is it you're after. Choose a weapon that you can understand the combos with, and understand how affinity works.  You upgrade your weapon, if you want a higher damage, but downgrade if you want to expand the branches, and increase elemental effects or obtain even more damage. Understand that the furthur you progress in the game, the more parts you can unlock to upgrade your weapons. Honestly, if you are a PC gamer, understand that this game is better with a controller. Best of luck, hunters.

author: ShaggyShoe
review: Despite the mixed reviews, I can safely say that - as of me writing this - most/all of the glaring bugs and problems have been fixed.  Haven't had a connection drop since the patch and loading times are nice and quick.  With that out of the way, I can best describe MHW as 'repetition done fun.'  You start the game with a "Story Mode," which is essentially a glorified tutorial, getting new players situated with the world, your weapons, and - of course - your rogue's gallery of monsters that you will become well-aquainted with as you beat the ever living daylights out of on your way to creating loadouts and sets for every occasion.  You begin in Low Rank, going through story quests that pit you against most of the monsters.  Eventually you graduate to High Rank, which unlocks tougher versions of the same monsters in low rank, as well as some new ones that are only available in HR.  From there you move up to the six Elder Dragons that are apart of the base game (I'm not counting Zorah...as you don't really fight him per say.)  More to come in future updates as the PC version of the game catches up to the console version.Speaking of updates, everything that contains ACTUAL content is FREE.  That's right folks, no EA shenanigans here.  New monsters, new weapons/armor sets, holiday events and festivals, and siege events are free and will be added to the game as an automatic update.  Only cosmetic items such as stickers, gestures, and a couple of armor skins actually require monetary purchase.As I mentioned, the game is repetitive, but if one ever finds the game becoming dull as a result, just change weapons.  MHW has 14 different weapon types in it, each with its own style of play.  Want that satisfying feeling of KO'ing a charging monster ten times your size?  Roll the Hammer and play Whack-a-Mole with its face.  Want to look like and/or pretend to be a cool guy?  The Longsword and Dual Blades have some of the flashiest moves in the game.  Want to keep your distance because you're definitely not a coward or anything like that?  The Heavy Bowgun is basically an M60, have fun!As for system requirements, my computer's getting a little on in years so I run the game on med-low settings to be safe, but that being said it runs smoothly and quickly even so.TL;DRGPU: NVIDIA GeForce GTX 950 2GB x2CPU: Intel I7-6700k 4.0ghz 8MB Smart Cache LGA1151MB: GA-Z170X Gaming 3 LGA 1151 w/CrossfireRAM: 16GBRepetitive, but fun.  If you find a weapon getting boring, just swap.  Every style is different enough that it mitigates fighting the same monsters over and over.  Word of warning about Modding: Capcom is currently sitting on the fence.  If you want to play it on the safe-ish side, avoid anything that circumvents actual gameplay (basically any mod that changes the stores or introduces a 'one-hit-kill' weapon, etc).  If they do decide to crack down, those will be the first they target.8/10Would save Clifford from an Angry Pickle again.

author: Black Fox
review: What Is Monster Hunter World ?Well, I should have written a review for this game already but I couldnt stop playing it, I've played it for more than 1000 hours by this point, I've done everything I could have done and I kept making goals for myself so I kept myself interested on keeping playing it and when I had no more ways to create a goal, I kept helping new players pass through the game and when I couldnt find enough new players to help, I just booted a quest and did it again, even tho I've already finished it and having nothing to gain by doing it, I just wanted to play the game and I never felt bored, I never felt that game was done to me, until now, 700 hours in that THIS FINALLY happened, I am finally finished with Monster Hunter and this isn't a bad thing at all, I need to have time for other games too and all those hundreds of hours spent here were worth it to the point it became my favorite game ever.Now talking about the game itself rather my experience on it, monster hunter is a game that while it has some grind and emphasizes on a repetitive type of content, youre just hunting monsters and sometimes gathering stuff and nothing else, the core gameplay here makes this simplistic "hunting" concept so complex and big, because its a game that has so much variety in everything it does, from the cool monsters you fight, from the hundreds of equipments you can craft from their parts and the skills that comes with it, from the many mechanics that composes this whole hunting and pre-hunting moments, the great soundtrack, the amazingly detailed maps and atmosphere, monster hunter has no traces of being an actual cash grab modern game made specifically to make money, monster hunter is a game made full of passion and love, its a game like I can imagine everyone working on it especially the leaders of the development team were doing the game of their dreams, they made a game they WANTED to make, they didnt make a want to prove a point or do something, they wanted to make a fun game THEY WANTED to do and because of how good and well-made this idea was many people fell in love with it, its genuine, its not just a great game, to me its an masterpiece, I've yet to see a game with better combat than this, everything here is masterfully crafted, while the whole experience isnt entirely perfect, it has some flaws especially with how the PC port behaves, no games are flawless or perfect, even my favorite game of all time ocarina of time.I could talk about the entirely franchise and how many games it has and how World has finally brought the franchise experience to a bigger and better vision, Ive always been a fan of monster since MH3 on Nintendo Wii and World was a game that I was very hyped about and despite all this huge expectations the game still managed to surpass them, for monster hunter fans its a must have and for new comers, I say, PLEASE, give it a chance, its once in a lifetime experience in gaming and there is nothing like this in the whole game industry, this is a unique game after all.And here I end my review, after a thousand of hours of playing this masterpiece, I am finally free to try other games but we all know that once the upcoming expansion Iceborne drops, I will go back to it as fast as I can and surpass the thousand hours mark, because Monster Hunter is not just a game to me, its much more than that.PS: ICEBORNE WAS A FREAKING MISTAKE!

author: Pickles Von Brine
review: PC Specs3770k @ 4.5GHz16GB RAMGTX 1070 OC'd1TB SSDSo, where do I start with this game? Not sure but lets just go and jump into it. *** If you play using a keyboard and mouse it is a frustrating experience. I highly recommend getting a controller.A decently controller can be had for rather cheap. The original Xbox 360 wired controllers can be found for 10-15 bucks and work great in this game. ***This is the first Monster Hunter game I have ever played. A friend of mine who has thousands of hours in other Monster Hunter titles convinced me to get this and honestly I am glad I did. When the game first came out it had its bugs and honestly for a team who has never made a PC title before it wasn't bad. However, the connection issues were a real problem. Once Capcom figured those out this game has been a blast. Overall the graphics are absolutely amazing. Just a shear joy to run around and find something new. The entire enviroment especially in the Ancient Forest feel alive. As far as combat I can say it is a lot of fun. You would think limited move sets would make things boring and I can say it doesn't. Learning the monsters you fight and knowing your weapon is half the battle. Understanding when and where you can pull off a move is what makes this game so damn fun. You get punished later on when you make mistakes like any game should but nothing unreasonable.That being said, sometimes you just get into really dumb situations. A monster stuns you then pulls off its big move and you are dead. It happens and is frustrating. Sometimes the hit boxes are a bit off but overall the game is rather polished. I love just going into a mission and playing with a few friends. When you face a super hard monster the joy of finishing it off is great. Overall there is a lot of complexity in the game especially once you start getting into armor, weapons, decorations, etc. Figuring out what works best for not only for your play style but your weapon can be rather daunting. Luckily, the community of Monster Hunter is incredible. They are super supportive of new players and go out of their way to help. So, with me rambling on here, what do I think? Absolutely get this game. It is a load of fun but a bit grindy. If you are looking for a game where you can jump in, have a couple of games and leave this is not one of them. It is a time commitment but worthwhile. Overall I would give this game a 9/10. There are still some bugs or whathaveits but those are one of very few detractors of the game.

author: John Titor
review: Monster Hunter is one of those amazing franchises that is always going to be a great time. Particularly, with Monster Hunter World, they vastly improved on many of the previously lacking aspects of games past. No longer needing to paint monsters, mounts, camps, and fast travel systems make exploration and hunts quicker, and less tedious. The tracking system is fairly fun and fits the environment really well. The graphics and immersive environment of this game in particular is absolutely fantastic. I hope all future Monster Hunter games have environments this developed and immersive and dense. The endemic life capturing and house customization is just a cherry on the top. As for the hunts themselves, AMAZING. While this game in particular lacks in sheer number of large monsters compared to some others, such as MH4U, it certainly makes up for with some extremely cool new and interesting monsters and battles. With all the DLC and events out by now, the number is fairly well rounded compared to release and there is a lot to do. I also particularly love that they added layered armor and weapon sets. Which makes the game a lot more fun to mess around with fashion and looks. I hope further installments expound upon these systems further, as it would be nice to have access to layered equipment from the start, with more customization options always available, particularly with weapons, which are very limited at current. The weapons and armor, generally, are very cool looking, unique, and fun to mix and match, though i do have some minor complaints with some weapons, such as the bow, which often feels like most of them are simply reskins with slight changes and are rather uninspired. Many others, though, such as DB, IG, and GS for example, have a plethora of amazing looking unique weapons that make it hard to part with once you get something with better stats down the line. One further complaint I have with this game in particular, is that it is very grindy, and has a lot of RNG factor with monster drops, and decorations in particular (a weapon/armor augmentation/upgrade system). Although this system allows for a great variety of customization and is extremely powerful, far too often meta or powerful builds rely on very rare or specific decorations that can take literally 100s of hours of grinding to get if you aren't lucky. For example, the bow class and it's infamous Mighty Bow decoration, which is considered a necessity on any bow build. Luckily, they have tried to lessen the harshness of this grind with the elder melder, allowing you to craft many rare decos in exchange for a LOT of other decos, and also, with events that award a lot of decorations for beating them,such as the greatest jagras event quest. Even still, too much of the end game is reliant upon farming these decorations in order to put together the builds of your dreams. Finally, overall, this game is filled with fantastic battles, decent story, and addictive gameplay, with the one real annoyance again coming down to grind and guidance. While some grind is expected and fun, on top of having to farm monster parts, augmentation materials, and decorations, which takes hours upon hours to do, a lot of the endgame, including many of the most powerful monsters, is gated behind a confusing and poorly explained system called the Guiding Lands. The Guiding Lands themselves are fairly interesting and fun... at least for the first couple of hours.  But shortly thereafter, you are left wondering how to progress, whether you've already reached the end, or whether there is still more to unlock. This is separate from the other sets of confusing to unlock monsters, which eventually leads to the true final boss. However, once you do finally figure out how to unlock them, it is well worth it, as the sieges and the final boss are some of the best fights you will get in any game.

author: deadering
review: Not optimized as well as it could be, but a lot better than I feared.Really that's the only bad thing. It looks amazing, especially with the volumetric fog and weather and day/night system.It's the first game I've played where the world truly feels alive. I was worried about open areas but it's a massive step up from previous Monster Hunter games. It feels like you've entered a real place that developed naturally, full of living, breathing creatures.The combat and gameplay are top-notch. MH has always had amazing combat but they have streamlined it over the years. I was worried it was getting too simplistic but as a veteran it's nice to see how many quality of life improvements they've made. Clearly the dev team really care about Monster Hunter and haven't lost touch like a lot of games sequels seem to.The combat feels heavier and more impactful than ever, but also more fluid. It's like the offspring of old Monster Hunter and Dark Souls.Really I'm just scratching the surface but this is the first significant upgrade we've seen to Monster Hunter since the original. Capcom has always taken it easy, using handhelds and the weakest consoles of the generations. Granted, they pushed those consoles to their limits, but it was always so much less than it could have been with more powerful hardware.I've always dreamed of what Monster Hunter could have been if they tried as hard as they could... well we finally got to find out. It's amazing.

author: Valkroz
review: Having bought a PS4 just to play this game in January, I love this game and this series. I will mention first that I am very, very early in my PC/Steam review, so don't make a final decision based ONLY on my review. I'm here to say my first impression while its fresh. I'll start with the bad before leading to the good.I have a really good PC setup; GPU is a EVGA Nvidia Geforce 1080TI SC2 (11GB VRAM), CPU is an Intel i7-7700K (4.2 GHz), and 16 GB of DDR4 RAM. Despite my specs, I've noticed that non-cinematic scenes dip in frames when I play 4K and max settings. I'm fairly confident that its not so much my specs handling the load of my settings, but rather how the game uses CPU memory. I don't know how to give specific details, I'll just offer a personal opinion on the matter: Its not game breaking at all. I kept my eye specifically out to see if it was as doomsday as some media reported.The only thing else worth pointing out, something that's much more critical, is that default mouse and keyboard controls are a bit wonky. Combat specifically isn't that bad, its actually more navigating menus and accessing your item bar thats awkward to say the least. Everything more or less has to be confirmed with a left mouse click, and to exit anything/go back, you have to RIGHT CLICK. ESC doesn't apply all the time, and the most bizarre function I accidentally prompted was accessing a load/save-your-loadout menu while trying to equip my first weapon, and once I accessed that menu accidentally, ESC turned into a "Rename your loadout" button. Right-clicking was the exit/go back function. I don't see that as practical. Also, right-clicking is your action button too. Picking up recources, accessing item/equipment boxes, that's your button. Meanwhile, E is to use your selected item, and holding Q brings up your item bar that you have to navigate with mouse buttons, HOWEVER, to switch item-shortcut menus, you have to use arrow keys. That's pretty freaking hard to do while your mouse has to both navigate your camera, your attack moves, and your action button. I should never have to take my hand off my mouse to navigate anything.Aside from these complaints, the game is as much as I remember it feeling like when I play it on PS4. The content of the game delivered me over 400 hours of playtime, without friends who play. For all my complaints, there's 10 more praises. Play the game, play with friends, watch tutorials, find guides on armor and weapon sets, and explore one of the most engaging communities in this industry!

author: Aeylr
review: Awesome game. Game looks good, runs really well for the looks too. Some odd settings, like antialiasing making stuff blurry, but if you run ReShade the game looks amazing.Monsters act like they actually would realistically; They'll run from you and try to recover, when you chase them the monster will put all of its energy in to protecting itself only to tire itself out. Really feels like the monsters have a personality. There are 14 completely unique weapons and they are all completely viable, even the support weapons can solo a monster. All weapons have a level of complexity to it, many of them can be hard to master, but you can  pick up any of them at any time and do well enough.  Even the Greatsword, which looks really simple, has complex abilities behind the scenes that let you take it to the next level.Every monster you hunt has two armor sets and atleast one weapon set (one for all 14 weapon types). It's fun hunting monsters just to see what the smithy can do with the monster parts you collected, but it also allows for a huge amount of build diversity. All of the gear you collect gives skills that reflect the monster it came from, which leads in to.. Preparing for the hunt. The one thing most games skip out on, monster hunter does it right. Before you get in a tussle with a giant monster, you need supplies. Potions for healing, damage boosting, you need traps and explosives. You can even build a set of armor to counter the specific monster you are fighting. You'll also want to eat a big meal, don't ever hunt on an empty stomach. The more preparation you do, the smoother the hunt will go. However, it does not become flower picking simulator. Once you can grow or purchase most of what you need, you will only have to go out and collect stuff if you run out mid-hunt, or for the occasional rare material. You should still plan what you bring with you in a hunt, It'll be a bit hard to fight a monster without a cure to its ailments.Story of the game is good, but monster hunter isn't a story game first. Most of it is there to teach you the game, and give you excuses to fight the next monster. The characters are memorable though, and your custom character does show up in whatever gear you are wearing during cutscenes, so it is done really well.Singleplayer and multiplayer are smoothly transitioned. You can play the whole game solo, or call for backup at almost any point. There are also gathering hubs for hunters to gather in and hang out. The only issue I could find, if you want to do a playthrough with a friend you have to start your story missions solo to watch a cutscene. You can back out afterwards and join your friend, but it is a slight annoyance.There is also house customization, you can decorate your home and even capture smaller creatures to put in your house. Iceborn adds a lot more customization and allows multiplayer within your home, but I was having fun with it even before Iceborn released.In summary, 9/10The story is good and all you need in a MH game, the combat and customizablility are amazing, monsters act like I'd believe they would if real, the game is beautiful, and their attention to detail is amazing in all areas, including time spent before and after a hunt.Took one point off for a number of small annoyances, like having to start cutscenes in solo, having to run ReShade to get the most of the graphics, some minor hitbox issues (Most hitboxes are amazingly tight, but a select few can extend out a little too much and hit you with a ghost), and the few weapon designs that had amazing potential but were butchered by gluing monster parts to the iron variant. Overall the only issues I've found have been small, none of this really hurts game enjoyment for me.- Fifth fleet hunter, PS4/PC, Bow/Greatsword/Chargeblade user

I write this review as i wait for the credits too end for my first playthrough and i must say, this was a beautiful and amazing game to play. The game is an excellent intro to newcomers to the series and a swell game for veterans of the series. I will not use any special formats like pro and cons i will simply put it as it is. This game teaches you what you need too know to play and have fun but leaves some stuff a mystery so that you have to play and understand the weapons and builds that you make. Even with 100 hours i have only use two weapons so there is still much more for me to experience as i get up to hr-100. The only things i did not enjoy were being unable to connect to friends quest or getting randomly disconnected during quest. As this past week and a half have gone by they have beocme less frequesntly i assume from server maintenance but regardless i see no major problems with this game and i recommend anyone to give it a try and play it for a bit. P.S. The "Bug" everyone thought was a bug is just a missing file that you can find online or on the MHW subreddit and even then its rare for people to get it. Regardless enjoy the game if you desire it and try op builds and random stuff you think is awesome thats all.P.S.S. Dodogama is best boy, the ABSOLUTE UNIT

author: Zorpernorper
review: Hidey Ho!Immediately delving into the game, it set me on the lowest possible graphics. Having an i5 processor and a decent graphics card I was confused, and decided to check the settings. It told me that (even at the lowest possible Graphics settings) it was overtaking my graphics card and RAM space, but when I tabbed out of the game, my computer was totally fine. I decided to experiment, and tabbed out again, my computer was still fine.This game is absolutely beautiful, the movements are realistic, and the environments are nothing short of awe-inspiring.But the voice acting is terrible. Given that it was originally a Japanese game I expect the lip sync to be bad, but the voice acting is terrible. Just turn voice off. On top of this, a lot of people complain that the in-town music is annoying and I agree. To fix that problem, find a Spotify playlist or something, mute your music when you get into town, and press play on that playlist. Boom, instant fix.Getting into the game is like a slap in the face. It hits you with more information and you can get comfused fast. Here are my tips for newcomers like myself:Watch these two videos: -  (A source that explains weapon types) -  (A decent beginner's guide to tell you what you should do first)Some pointers: - To make your Palico's equipment, you need things called research points. You can't start getting research points until you finish the second story quest where you kill the Great Jagras, - Scout Flies are super helpful! Follow them, look at footprints to upgrade them, and you won't get lost, have to spend an agonizing amount of time looking at footprints, or miss out on resources you wish you had grabbed on that last big monster hunt. - Start with the defender armor, and abandon it as soon as you've finished the first couple missions. This way, you don't have to use crappy leather or chainmail as a last resort and make something you like, but be safe in the process. - Play with a controller if at all possible. This game was originally made for console-based controllers. It's just the smart thing. - Experiment with different fighting styles. Fainting is a-okay, and so is failing the mission, so long as you can find a good comfort zone for yourself without breaking that controller I told you to play with by smashing it into your nice 4K monitor you waited so long to buy. - Grab literally everything. Thing on the wall? Grab it. Weird bug? Grab it. Monster intestines? Grab it. They may not seem important now, but the further you get into the game the more you're going to need that weird ♥♥♥♥ you grabbed along the way.I hope this helped!8/10 so far,Zeph :)

author: nacho
review: I have always wanted to get into the Monster Hunter series and didn't know where to start, and saw that a new Monster Hunter MMO game was going to launch in 2018, and finally took a stab at the series. I have never felt in love with a game quicker. The uniqueness that every monster and creature has in the game is what gives it the charm, and the freedom to customize how you play with weapons and armor is crazy with tons of different sets and weapons to craft from monster loot. Like every MMO you're gonna have to grind to get materials, but I've never gotten bored with grinding in this game. Fighting monsters with other online players is an experience I've never felt nowhere else. I've even gotten help from veterans from the series because they could tell I was a total newbie to the game. The only cons I have to give this game is the server issues, but I think everyone knows at this point that Capcom servers are something you shouldn't have high expectations of anyway. Sometimes the game lags or crashes due to server issues as well. Also if you don't use voice channels for communication, talking with your allies is almost near impossible, but the game has something you can use to communicate with shortcuts you can customize. Obviously the task of most missions is to hunt and slay a monster, so communication isn't always needed, but when you get to harder and more challenging monsters, it's needed severely.MHW is a great experience, and very friendly to new players entering the series, the community is very welcoming and open to helping newer players and assisting with missions. Definitely worth trying out, and worth coming to if you're a fan of MMOs or RPGs.

author: Namielle
review: This game is deserving of Game of the Year awards ,because the other games never served you with free contents like CAPCOM does. I have never seen a perfect game like MHW. Besides, the other games always had repeatable contents that made you get bored.Whenever the monsters spot you, they will kill you, and yet they will retreat to sleep for some reason. There's a chance for you to get an instant kill by using bombs or any explosive items.Overall, the combat, grinding, equipment, maps, and monsters are great. The monsters' movements are like an AI , they have a brain and know what to do if you trigger them. Be careful not to get spotted by the monsters.Don't forget to support our developers by buying this game and the DLCs at full price.If you're a monster slayer, this game is yours.

author: Sol Goodguy

It's one of my favourite games since 2012, when i used to play Portable 3rd with my friends.The only big problem is the lack of a G Rank, which make the end game content be a bit boring, but the regular updates with events and new monsters have made the pc release a lot more enjoyable with the faster pace than the consoles.Happy Hunting!As of now, the G Rank(Master Rank) has been added to the game, and that meanst that we'll finally have new content! author: Munshai
review: Edited on 16/01/20-------------------------I come back to this review 300h later in game and this game keeps getting better and better with time, I can only recommend it further more :DEdited on 11/03/19-------------------------I recommend this game for many reasons, mostly because I played it with friends, although, it can absolutely be enjoyed  solo.Pros :+ Gameplay is good but you better get a controller to fully enjoy it in my opinion.+ It feels great to manage to kill a really powerful monster.+ Lots of new free content added quite regularly.+ Has everything I enjoyed in the previous Monster Hunters and more.+ Also has nice looking graphics (I really like the graphical style though).Cons :- Nice looking graphics yeah, but as long as you see them from afar (fixed with the free DLC high resolution texture pack).- The game was released with a lot of network issues that were patched later on.- You can play missions with your friends but need to watch cutscenes beforehand (for the Story).

author: ShodaMashin
review: Really polished experience as far as monster hunter goes, by far the best in the series with various quality of life improvementsAs a result of the extreme increase in quality compared to a regular MH game, there's a fair decrease in quality but content is still being released for free and being brought up to date with the console versions of the game. Judging off the success Capcom is getting from this game, i doubt they'll be quick to stop supporting it in future.Keeping in mind the "Mixed" review score, it should be noted that 90% of the negative reviews for the game at the time of writing were from the initial week and a half the game was released, mostly describing connection issues the game doesn't have anymore and while it could be argued that the existence of the issue at all might point to other bad practice from the developers, i would personally recommend discounting the initial review bomb.All in all, really great experience as the game currently is, amazing fun to play with friends and i can't wait to see where the game gets taken next.10/10 would sharpen my bagpipe again

author: りひ丂ｲ
review: After playing every other monster hunter game in the series with over 1000 hours easy on monster hunter unite alonethis is the monster hunter i have been waiting for, here is why most people will not appreciate this game as much as a series fan will.To me this is the FINAL FANTASY/DARK SOULS combo ive loved for many years1.Zone loading.Imagine this, every zone that you go through there is a loading page you must sit through acident or not this is a major change to me and i love it. no more being knocked or rolling by accident into another zone dreading that the monster doesnt hit you when you load back in2. Drop in and drop out multiplayer.OMFG i cant take hearing from people how ♥♥♥♥ the servers are it honestly makes me want to throw a dung bomb in their faces because they have no idea how big of a change this is to the series. YES this is having some major issues now but to me this is dream come true even if a player does drop out you are still able to continue the quest and have them rejoin!(ps i have found the best work around for finding your friends and joining their games is to start the game in your own online session and than going to the notice board to join their session. not sure why this works but there is an issue with joing straight from the main menu right now. youre welcome.)3. User friendly. This game will point out everything to you heck... for the first time ever there is a forced tutorial.. ill be walking around an fireflys will point out every item you pass instead of having to look for a physichal crack in the wall to mine of hope that a bush will provide bugs for you (love how you actually grab bugs off the surface) tracking a monster is a little annoying sometimes but im getting used to it.4. Chanhging gear mid quest. This part is so amazing i misspelled the title part on purpose! finaly you can go into a mission and have the option to change your gear mid game to suit the needs of your situation and team mates. i will change between guns and long swords even the hunting horn u used to HATE it now something i enjoy using in this version of monster hunter.5. The enviroment.  EVERYTHING LOOKS AMAZING!!!  you can swing from trees jump off walls grapple onto bugs on trees kick a frog that will parylize the enemy DAM like.. its so fluid and you feel like you are a true hunter instead of relying on your own provisions you can use your knowledge of the enviroment to aid your quest!These are just 5 reasons to grab this adventure of a lifetime. i didnt even mention DAMAGE INDICATORS or TURF WARSCapcom i love you so much for making this series i have started streaming this on my twitch page  i bought a cable from japan so i could stream my psp screen playing monster hunter unite it took 3 weeks to arrive! i can honestly say i will be following this game till the day i die.few Glitches and tips i have found.*players cant join from menu (as i said above there is a way around this for now)*pukie pukie gets caught in vines. now  i dont know if that is intentional but when they fly away they glitch on the vines >:D                  *WHY THE ♥♥♥♥  DOES MY PALICO GO RUNNING TO THE BOOK GIRL AND NOT ME WHEN WE MEET UP?? i feel like a horrible owner is there some way you can put a pet feature in for the palico? or i can give them a treat? i want to let them know they are appreicated </3*push to talk would be nice as there is no way to adjust my mic input in game and if i turn it off i cant hear anybody talking to me which kinda sucks cuz voice chat is an amazing feature*key bindings are totally welcome i just upgraded my mouse it has buttons i just dont have a use for them in game i would like to... BUT i completely understand and everytime i go to use an item i am reminded of good times so i dont mind :)so thats all from me i love this series so much!! if there is ever any opening for testing or affiliation i would love to be apart of it!Thank you capcom for making my dream game :) Love - asideofbread aka Wholemeal

author: DeadStrife
review: Monster Hunter is a niche game. It's always been a niche game. Go look up an old review for the oldest Monster Hunters, it's not pretty. But it's always had a large fanbase. Large enough to consider porting the game to a medium (The PC) that isn't very well understood by Japanese Developers. Monster Hunter World is the most successful Japanese made game on Steam, and one of the most Successful games on Steam period, and because of that it's no surprise that so many people do not recommend this game. It's no surprise that so many people would be furious with the port as it's not as well optimized as it could be in many regards. But often it's compared to the Dark Souls port to PC (a game that's praised despite this, for good reason), and that's kind of an unfair comparison, because this game isn't as bad a port by any means. The Good (Why I recommend it.)> Hunting oversized Lizards with oversized weapons> Modding Community> Visual eye buffet with higher end machines> Many mechanical QoL improvements for the series> Monsters and the world feel more alive than previously.The Bad (Why you might want to wait to spend your money, keep in mind some of these are being fixed)> Monster Hunter is a niche game. It can sometimes be nonsensical and frustrating.> Poor optimization in some cases. Especially when there are a lot of particle effects being created, even on the best PCs.*> Network issues.*The Ugly> Salt Factory. > Hackers exist and generally they help you on hunts. Capcom has no plans to do anything about them.> Previous quality Monster Hunter titles typically have waaay more content. *These are things that Capcom is actively fixing right now, and there have been less issues since the week of release, but they are still present issues at the time of this writing. Anyways, I'm honestly just trying to bump the score up with this review. The game is too good to have such a negative Steam score, but a lot of what people are saying is fair. If you read this far you're probably looking through all the positive reviews to feel good about your purchase or something in the sea of bad reviews. Why did I write this

author: AstroAss
review: Edit (as promised): Pretty much everything's been fixed now. The mouse feels great, the game runs extremely well (but I have since upgraded to an RTX 3090 FE - now the game runs at 5K DLSS pushing 85-100fps!), the performance can be optimized by turning off volumetrics (makes the image so much sharper and contrastier while giving better fps). Iceborne made the game a lot more fleshed out as well - love it!Definitely recommended now, even though it's still very different from the classic MH games.Day1 review: I'm a HUGE fan of the MH series, but I'm giving this game a thumb down and a middle finger up for the following reasons (until fixes are issued):1) MOUSE CONTROLS ARE HORRIBLE! What they did was map the mouse to a virtual analog stick, so you deal with things like "deadzones" and a speed cap for movement, making everything very stupid on the mouse. RIP gunners... Don't force me to play with a damn controller! The chinese MH Online works wonderfully with a mouse - apparently Japan has no PC gaming industry and knows nothing about how things are done...*smh*2) Online keeps dropping. So far my friends haven't got the game, so not yet a problem, but will need to be sorted out3) Weird bloom/blur over everything... I want a sharp, contrasted image, not a mess that maybe used to work on a TV a bazillion feet away from one's eyes with contrast pumped up on the TV.4) Too many things are mapped onto the same keys. Again, going back comparing to MH Online - MH World needs more flexibility... I'm a blademaster, but I hear gunners have problems with this particularly.5) This probably also worked on TVs a bazillion miles away from your face, but the texture detail is pretty garbage up-close... Definitely needs a high res texture pack!6) Tutorials....tutorials...more tutorials... I'm sick of them!!!! I'm a veteran and there should have been an option to turn the damn things off, like in all the previous releases. You know, you load up a game and it asks "have you played before? Do you need a tutorial?"- you hit "no, F off, I'm a veteran" and go have some fun...Annoying stuff that annoys the crap out of me as a long-time MH fan who played EVERYTHING ever since MH Freedom on PSP:1) Story. Sorry, but it's not only unnecessary but also crap. I Want to hunt monsters and craft stuff, not spend an hour on cinematic and "follow this guy" nonsense. The old games had almost no story and it was perfect.2) Autocraft of potions is weird3) Why am I allowed to have the full item box in the camp? Makes no sense. The old inventory system worked wonders, even with the addition of transporter felynes - made gathered item management a good and realistic gameplay mechanic.4) The "fireflies" or whatever they are. Stupid mechanic, takes up too much screen space, too much hand-holding and glows in your face for no reason. Hate it.Notes: Don't know if it's my settings or what, but 60-80fps on a 1080Ti (no SLI support, so I can't use my second card) at 1440p is a bit...low...I'll update this as I discover new things and the game gets updated. Hoping for fixes at LEAST for the darn mouse emulation thing, raw input is a MUST.

author: Themiscrya
review: So I gave this a lot of time in hopes that I could with a resounding heart say "YES! I recommend this game." But I can not. Dont get me wrong though if this game works on your computer then by all means play it. Its wonderful and great. The graphics are so detailed and you can get lost in the game play. I never seem to get tired of taking a big monster down or goofing off with my friends.However the reason I give this a thumbs down is because there is a group of users that cant play this game without it crashing constantly with no rhythm or reason. I could get on for a second and crash or do a few missions and crash. The crash can be as simple as being kicked out the game to locking up the whole computer and forcing me to restart the whole thing. I have tried so many different options to fix this but I feel like its a combination of things one being my radeon card and maybe the internet. Its all speculation though and those of us that do have this problem its like were this small niche of people and its not worth their time to fix the issue. So for all those unheard people I hope my thumbs down helps bring some attention to the problem.And as you can see I have put some time into the game 141 hours to date. I crash about 4-5 times in an hour so that is what 564-705 crashes since I have gotten the game. I am rank 12 now. And so you all know as well if you crash in a mission or while you are out doing things you lose all progress and items. That is what is more annoying then anything. Its very frustrating.

author: darthaegis
review: [The final paragraph serves as a TLDR.]Monster Hunter: World is an action RPG where you (obviosuly) hunt monsters. You do this mostly to turn their hides, scales, fangs, tails, etc. into armors and weapons that look cool. The game has a story and... it exists. I'm not a huge fan of grinding and I enjoyed this game quite a lot, though I'm not very likely to keep playing after finishing the game because I've already crafted the weapons I liked and I'm quite satisfied. However, if you like grinding to get a "perfect" build, there's easily hundreds of hours of gameplay to have. The game has a bunch of quests which consist of killing one or more large monsters, which are set in different open areas. You can also just explore these areas with no mission attached. Each area is fairly large, and it's just full of plants, fungi and animals. Smaller monsters have their own special loot (or just raw meat you can barbeque yourself), and different plants and small animals can be picked up to craft consumables, to be thrown as projectiles, or activated to heal you or do more interesting things such as releasing paralyzing gas or poison. The environment itself can be used in hunts: slopes and cliffs enable you to jump and try to mount a monster, and some terrain makes monsters get stuck in it when you attack them. It's pretty fun to walk around these places gathering stuff and then getting to know what to use against monsters when you hunt them later, and with all the density in bugs, plants, animals... These areas have so much detail they feel quite "lived in", in a way. When you're not exploring or on a hunt, you're in Astera, a sort of home base where you can forge and upgrade gear, eat food for buffs, collect materials you can set to farm while you're out and select bounties, which are minor MMO-style quests ("mine stuff 15 times") that you'll do anyway, but they give you good rewards.Missions usually consist of hunting a certain monster, with limits on time, number of faints (if your health turns to zero, you faint and return to the nearest camp inside that area) or retrieving the monster without killing him. The game is really fun because you start to understand the environments and the monsters. With some time, you know where they're going to go and can sort of think ahead about how you can engage each monster, and what you need. Monsters have a certain tendency to start infighting and start a "turf war", and you can use this to your advantage to get some damage on your mark. If you feel the other monster is doing to much damage, you can just throw dung at him so he'll leave your target alone. If a monster goes to sleep, just plant explosive barrels on their tail to try and cut it off, and he might even just die right there with your explosive finisher! There's just a lot of fun stuff you can take advantage of to slay your monster faster.Of course, the "classical" method of damage dealing is weaponry. The game has 14 weapon archetypes, each with a huge tree of different weapons, which require parts from different monsters. After the game's intro, you get the starting version of all types, and you can try them out in a "training area". I ended up liking the switch axe (an axe that can turn into a gigantic anime sword) and the insect glaive (a glorified vaulting pole which enables you to jump around hitting monsters, combined with an insect that collects extract from different monster parts, each part giving you different bonuses). Each weapon has their own special mechanic apart from just different movesets, and each branch in their trees has different benefits (elemental damage, status effects) so there's just an insane amount of variety in weaponry. Pretty much the only grinding I did was for a switch axe, a glaive and dual daggers. Apart from weaponry, each armor set has different bonuses as well, and decorations can be applied to them with the bonus of your choosing, making for the potential of customizing your build to perfection (though that is likely to require a lot of grinding).Each monster has mostly different movesets and behaves in different ways. Some dragons like to fly around while others are just too heavy and mostly walk around. If it has a tail, it's gonna use it against you if you try to spam attacks behind it, though you can try to cut it off and reduce that nuisance. As I mentioned, you can mount monsters. After a successful mount, the gameplay boils down to button mashing and the occasional quick time event ending up in a finisher move which knocks down the monster, but it's still pretty cool to see the monster desperately trying to shake you off, to the point where it headbutts walls to try and get rid of you. Hunts have good pacing since monsters will usually run away somewhere else after a while. This not only makes it so you don't get bored of fighting in the exact same place after a while, but it also gives you some breathing room so you can heal up, sharpen your weapon (they get blunt and ineffective after a while), and plan your next move. After a while, they start limping and return to their "home" to sleep, at which point you can capture them alive or, as I mentioned, blow them up. This game is extremely fun, and I loved my time with it. However, it's also very flawed when concerning things outside of the core gameplay. For starters, the online is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ garbage. I've been disconnected seven times for no reason, and when searching quests, I never find more than five. I mean, am I doing something wrong? There are always over fifty thousand people playing, yet the game can't show more than a few quests. The PC port is also not very good. While the game "only" crashed once, it drops down to 40 FPS whenever the screen gets too many particles. I've got a GTX 1060, and at the very least there could be a graphics setting for particle quality so I can turn it down and keep a stabler framerate. The UI is also a bit of a cluster♥♥♥♥. Yes, the game is quite complex, but there's dozens of different menus and doing anything requires at least three or four clicks. One of the most annoying things is that you can set custom loadouts so you always have the exact items you need in a hunt, and you can set hotkeys for items and messages, but even though these have completely different menus and means of access, they're linked together. If you set a loadout, then set hotkeys and then select your loadout, the hotkeys reset because you didn't guess that you must first set your hotkeys and only then save your loadout (or maybe I'm dumb and missed one of the text dump tutorials which said that). Also, there's a menu with the sole function of switching from a gamepad-friendly radial menu to the keyboard-friendly hotkeys. The game can automatically switch from keyboard button prompts to gamepad, but I guess switching menus as well is too hard or something. Also regarding keyboard and mouse, why in the everloving ♥♥♥♥ is the Interact button left mouse when you're in your home base, but right mouse when you're on hunt? Right mouse isn't used in your home base, so there's no point to this weird change. Yes, this is a nitpick but it's extremely triggering. Yes, I'm probably being autistic.Monster Hunter: World is excellent. The game is just super fun to play and its complexity and variety mean that you won't get bored quickly. Even if you only do the main quest, it's easy to play a good 40 hours and enjoy most of it. However, the PC port isn't very good, the UI is a bit of a mess and I'd maybe not recommend this game if you plan on playing online, since there's frequent disconnects. If you're playing solo and can bear with those problems, then you should absolutely play this game. If you're a fan of grinding and crafting tons of cool-looking gear, you can easily get hundreds of hours out of this.

author: Odra
review: Review and recommendation long overdue.==================================================================!!! First things first !!!==================================================================Take a look at the DLC.See it?Ok now disregard everything in there except for the Iceborne expansion and the HD Texture packAll other DLC is useless.===================================================================Terrific installment in the MH series.Every weapon changes the gameplay to the point that you actually want to change weapons and experiment as the game does not rely on stats (Like the Soul series) to effectively use weapons. Armor and upgrade combinations are too many to count. Environments are vivid and offer a lot of exploration, they each offer their own quirks and hazards. The multiplayer is robust but painless as you are left to your own devices unless you seek out to participate with others.Works great with Keyboard and Mouse, so a gamepad is not essentialSome downsides, at least personally, would be the lack of gamepad rebind customization, I was on a Souls binge and the muscle memory messed me up. The locales, while large and intricate, feel too few after a while.

author: Marked One
review: I am re-writing my review after Capcom has updated their game over time. Originally I decided to not recommend this game for Co-op based players due to the sheer amount of disconnects/network issues & poor handling of scaling, migration & other issues stemming from this. Since then, aside from keeping the disconnected person's slot occupied on disconnect, all issues have been resolved. This game is an absolute delight and time sink. The gameplay loop is surprisingly deep & will have you playing for hundreds of hours to master techniques and learn the game world. At no point did the loop break and I feel like I was wasting my time even after hundreds of hours. This game is not for the weak of will, there's an epic ton of systems to learn, styles to fight with, mods to work with, monsters to fight and lots more content. You will be playing this for quite some time trying to get all the content and by the time you get to it, they'll release more. There is no game series that matches the monster hunter series, and even with the more simplified version that is Worlds, it's truly an experience for even the most novice of players. The depth of the hunts & gameplay systems really drives home how much the developers care about their games. The graphics are beautiful and are part of why I haven't been able to play Rise yet as I've been spoiled with the game engine in World. Each location is intricately designed with quite the attention to detail that will immerse you in the game. The sound design is spectacular and has an OST worth streaming (which is on Spotify fyi). The plot gets a little banal after time, but the fights certainly do not. Each one gets progressively more & more bombastic and intense, requiring you to learn new move sets, weaknesses & other tactics to adapt and over come. You have at least 300+ hours of content with just the base game not including DLC's. This game WILL take your time, but it tends to respect it. If you are the type of person who tends to only jump on for an hour or two, this game COULD work for you but you will have problems further down the road in terms of progression as some hunts can take 45 minutes + to complete. The game plays solid in co-op and is strongly recommended to be played in either public or with friends as it really shines during those co-op only moments.

author: Baggeet
review: BEFORE BUYING: Have a computer with recommended or close to recommended specs or your experience with this game will be terribe. Pros: Graphics, Story, Gameplay, Multiple Character Slots, Upgrade TreeCons: Matchmaking system, Hub Area, Random DisconnectsPROS: The Graphics and Gameplay are determined on what computer you have. The Multiple Character Slots is good if you have another person that uses your computer and wants to play Monster Hunter: World. The Upgrade Tree at the beginning is slow but after 10 or so monster fights you get an expanding tree to upgrade your weaponry.CONS: The Matchmaking System for me ruined the experience to play with other people either my friends or random people I would've liked to meet playing this game. Sadly the Main Hub for you and others to meet isn't in the Tradeyard or Canteen but in a seperate area called the Gathering Hub, so you cant meme with your friends in the spawning area of Astera. (READ) The random disconnects in hunts made this game unplayable with other people and honestly made me hate this game to the point where I say NO to anyone who wants to buy something overpriced $60 AAA game that has worse servers than MW2, A.K.A 2009 servers on a 2018 AAA game. DISCUSTINBesides that my biggest suggestion is to watch some youtube videos of how Monster Hunter World plays on PC but for me playing Monster Hunter:World wasn't the experience I was hoping for with Friends

author: Tumtums
review: Overall I like this game. If you tried dauntless and liked it, this is similar but with much more to do, multiple monsters in the same area and with expeditions, cycling monsters in and out of the area with up to three large monsters in the area at the same time. The monsters will even attack each other. Story is rather annoying with the unskippable cutscenes and the handler. Expeditions seem to be where I enjoy the game the most but every mode has it's benefits.There are several poor design choices such as limiting your time to loot the area after finishing your task to 60 seconds while making it so that the camera pans around to different angles and being unable to carve the target for the first 10 seconds. If you think the meme of REEEE is annoying, you will despise this game. The screeches can be as frequent as 30 seconds for a single monster and up to three can fight each other in the same area making it almost non stop at times.I see a lot of people complaining about multiplayer but I have primarily been playing solo. I have noted that sometimes if I alt tab I will get disconnected from the online session but it continues in offline mode.

author: meow pal
review: There are lots of negative reviews here, this is a solid monster hunter game.Lemme try to clear it up, the game has really great hunting, the maps are full of gathering spots and the tweaks on combat have made this far more accessible and less frustrating than previous versions of the game. It plays really well.The downside is the early part of the game is focused on solo play through the main assigned missions. There is little room for true multiplayer here because of the lock on other players joining missions if all of those players haven't watched the cutscenes. So it is a pain to play this with your buddies. However, the optional quests after the story are completely joinable.Other than that, if you press "matchmake" for online you will have a bad time with disconnecting. Instead you should search for the quest you want to do and join a party.Finally, the game needs push to talk options for voice chat. I don't want to turn off chat completely, I just don't want open microphone in a 16 player lobby!

author: Sellyn
review: Please check minimum and recommended specs before you buy the game. Now, assuming you did that, the port is very good. i7-6700k and GTX1070FE nabs me 80+ fps with infrequent drops. Monster Hunter World was amazing on the PS4 and being able to play it at 60+ fps is a dream come true. Highly recommend that you turn off Volume Rendering as it adds 10-20 fps. If you've never played a monster hunter game before, the gameplay involves you tracking down large prey and killing them. Every attack in the game is dodgeable and over time you will learn when an opening is safe to attack and when it isn't, what works well against different monsters, and what doesn't work at all. Improvement in the game comes in weapon and armor smithing, which requires ore and monster parts that you will accumulate as you hunt. You can play through the game perfectly fine on your own, but you can also engage in up to 4 player co-op and even call in other hunters on the fly when you need help (S.O.S flare). Do not be ashamed in failure - it happens to even veteran players, learn from your mistakes and try again.The game is a lot of fun, but it also involves a lot of RNG in farming monster parts as certain ones are rarer than others.

author: de_nuke
review: A couple of questions for the developer:- If you and the friends you are playing with are on the exact same quest, why can't you do the quest together?- Why can you not join a quest because "you haven't watched the required cutscenes yet"?- Why are people (not just me, literally everyone in my group of friends) getting constantly disconnected from a multiplayer session? Most of the time this happens DURING a mission. - Why can't you re-join a multiplayer session during a quest if aforementioned disconnects happen? Quests take a good half hour if not more, it's extremely frustrating to be either forced to complete the quest separately or abandon it altogether.Aside from the questions above I do not recommend this game, at least not at the state it is in currently. The premise is interesting and the game itself is fun IF IT WORKS, but arbitrary decisions like disallowing multiplayer because of cutscenes RUIN the entire experience! Am I not allowed to progress through the game with my friends?! If I could I would refund this game, but the introductory cutscenes, character creation and tutorial alone take two hours so I suppose that's off the table. To anyone considering to buy this game to play with friends I can only say: Don't! Once again Japanese game devs prove they are incapable of providing a functional and streamlined multiplayer experience. Honestly I don't know why I expected Monster Hunter: World to be any better.

author: Syragar
review: I hate to see so many negative reviews for this game.  I know that there has been a lot of issues with disconnects in mutliplayer.  Although I think it's bit better than it was. I've played Monster Hunter 1 & 2 on PSP, and 3 on Wii, and 4 on 3DS... so I'm a bit of a fan of the series.  I was eager to get into MHW when I first heard about it, but was sad to hear it wasn't on any platform I owned... and I am done buying gaming consoles.  But I was very excited to hear about it's release on PC!  Finally!  A Monster Hunter on PC!  I've been wanting this for a long time!This game is a blast to play! You are a puny human that hunts monsters that are larger than life! You have to track them down and brawl it out in an epic heart-pumping battle! You really feel like you have the disadvantage and you really have to fight hard and strategize to bring the monster down. It gives you a very satisfying sense of accomplishment when you are victorious over a particularly nasty monster.The areas are very diverse and the monsters feel almost real. Some monsters will have turf wars that can be so entertaining to watch, it can be easy to forget your mission objective!  Even fighting the same monster can still be a very different experience because you never know what will happen.  Will another monster come in and stir things up? Will something happen in the environment that will throw a monkey wrench in your plans? You never know. And the fun and excitement is multiplied when playing with friends.For those that have played the previous Monster Hunter games, there are some changes in this one that I see as improvements.  Some may disagree, but I'll list some so you can decide for yourself:All of that said, there are still some multiplayer issues from time to time.   There's nothing more frustrating than starting a multiplayer investigation with a voucher only to be kicked off and be stuck in a mission scaled for multiplayer. At that point you can either tough it out and try to fight monsters that are not intended for single player... or  you can give up and accept that you will lose the investigation and voucher.  But in all, I think it's worth it. It's currently my favorite PC game.

author: DankeyKang
review: If you like grinding this game is great, bosses are a challenge until you gear up past them. I think this game is great as a solo game, but it really stands out if you can find three buddies to work together to bring down these crazy creations. I've played the monster hunter series for years and this is by far the friendliest one for new players. I really love how they incorporated how the world interacts with the fight in this one. Previous versions were more like a one on one you vs the monster. In this one you can blast him off cliffs and drop rocks on him for mega damage.(its so satisfying) I would give this a try if it interests you, I think he developers did a wonderful job and should be very proud of their work.

author: pokashine
review: Finally finished the first mission, so time to leave a review!It's good.Real good.The absolute mechanical intricacy of combat in the MH series has no peers, and World continues to uphold and expand on weighty, meaty walloping of monsters. Every weapon category has it's quirks, secrets and an unbelievable amount of depth tied to their mechanics.Not one weapon is 'simple'; there is ALWAYS something a little bit extra to it (even spread 3 HBG or ZSD spam).You can doot.You can do aerial acrobatics with a hammer.You can weeb sword your way to victory or dash-dance to a KO.But whatever you do, and however you choose to do it, make sure you buy this game first.Worth every penny at full price!Now, I'm off to beat that damn Jaggy~

author: Arjean
review: The game is great, pretty hard to run and it would mostly require good CPU and more than 2Vram but even on the lowest settings and 30-60FPS the game looks beautifull.I recommended it to my friends and they absolutely love it.The game does have flaws but it's so easy to overlook them.And this game most certainly does not deserve to be mixed or negative in steam.

author: 𝓩𝓱𝓸𝓷𝔂𝓪'𝓼
review: Monster Hunter World is a popular action role-playing game released in 2018. It received positive reviews for its detailed graphics, complex hunting mechanics, and engaging co-op multiplayer. The game offers a vast open world for players to explore and hunt down mythical creatures. It has received criticism for its steep learning curve and repetitive missions. Overall, it is considered a must-play for fans of the Monster Hunter franchise and action RPGs.

author: Fox
review: Like Bossfights in other Action Games, grindy, but very satisfying once you get the hang of it, 14 different weapons to choose from, each with its own pace and features, not easy to grasp, even harder to master, but lots of fun!Iceborne DLC recommented for additional movesets, gear and monsters to fight!EDIT Dec. 2021:After 2k hours one could say the game's done, everything is slayn, everything is gathered, but it is still fun to head out and stomp Dragons! Still missing a few Archivments, and some completition grind, but it keeps me comming back... "Monster Hunter: Rise" is on the horizon for PC, yet the demo and videos ive seen about its style "going back to the classics" make me think this is niche enought to still be popular, so this is a shoutout for everyone who is interested and unsure about this game's itteration, there are still plenty of people roaming around, joining SOS and streaming on Twitch etcFinal Conclution: Sooo much content and fun out of your money is quite rare, definetly recommented!! :funnyfoxy:

author: Papart
review: Really did not wanted to do it, but Capcom really should be hit across the head.Base game was delayed half a year as it was their first PC title of the series. Fine. But Iceborne was also delayed four months and was delivered with many bugs, including critical of people losing game saves with hundred of hours of gameplay and regression in title's performance.What's worse, Capcom butchered title with some background checks and DRM that degrades performance. The most stupid workaround confirms it, as when launching and clicking RMB on title icon and selecting "Close" gives small prompt, which asks if you want to close - just ignore it and play, with stable 60 FPS on highest settings with high resoultion texture pack. It was added with Iceborn expansion, update shove to everyone even without expansion. Now they have to stabilize and tweak it for many people to work.It's not Epic Store and F2P knock-off Dauntless, but a large publishing house with AAA franchise that broke sales record - it should not stand for such an ♥♥♥♥♥♥ up release.

author: Renatus
review: I love this game. No words can even describe how.I loved learning the moveset of a fire breathing T-Rex. I loved being a superhuman capable of carrying and slicing a fat lizard with a chunk of metal almost as big as a 2 metre door. I loved swinging around a golden katana like some 11 year old in black ops 2 attempting a 720 flash swap silent shot final killcam with their golden DSR-50 to try to apply for FaZe. I loved re-enacting Attack on Titan scenes with my dual blades. I loved making builds. I loved being a team healer and a damage dealer. I loved turning my boring archaic iron crossbow into a 21st century monster shredding shotgun. I loved unwinding in my private royal room after fighting a pissed off hungry pickle monster. I loved getting my ass spanked by a spikey dragon then overcoming it and later slaying it more times than I've had hot dinners. I loved hunting monsters, co-op and solo. I loved all weapon types (especially charge blade). What you read above was only some of the World experience, so basically even if you didn't get Iceborne you're still gonna have fun, whether it be simply finishing the story or continuing your adventure till endgame. "But if World is fun, why should I bother with Iceborne?" you might ask.Basically, take everything that world did, expand and improve on it, and you've got Iceborne.Here are some Iceborne exclusive features:- You can visit your friend's luxurious room filled with fluffy creatures (that they kidnapped from some jungle probably) after fighting a super saiyan monkey with a naruto cosplayer.- After further exploration of an area you get rewarded with the ability to chase monsters by riding a big raccoon thing (that sentence has multiple meanings) called as a Wulg. (Though, you can literally do anything while riding except for checking hunter notes? c'mon Capcom)- New weapon combos. Some of these weapons' moves are such a big deal because they add completely new play styles or nice DPS gains. (Example: Charge Blade Savage Axe mode, Longsword special sheathe, LBG evasive reload, A Thousand Dragons for Bow and, my favorite one so far, Sword and Shield perfect rush)- Lots of monsters were added (including ones from older MH games), and a snowy area was added too to accompany them. Afterall, you're gonna be fighting Diego from Ice Age, that thing can't adapt in any area except for snowy regions amirite.- Moar armor and weapons. (but to be honest some Iceborne weapons look pretty bland, although you can "mask" the appearance of your weapons to compensate for this)I could go on even more about how good this game is. Even though there's a few things in this game that are obnoxious to me like the tenderizing mechanic and , you honestly shouldn't worry too much about them if you are planning to play casually.TL;DR: Try to get the expansion too. From swinging around explosive giant transforming axes and riding literal steel dragons able to manipulate wind to arm wresting with friends, this game truly has an unforgettable experience and a long lasting endgame.

author: RickyWL
review: Monster Hunter World is a fantastic game plagued with many, many technical issues that it frankly shouldn't have due to delays. When PC gamers were told to wait for an extra 6 months so the devs could polish it, many people trusted them, expecting that they would legitimately use the time to make the port as great as it could be. What we instead have is a poorly optimized game with virtual joystick controls, horrendous networking and a poorly designed co-op story mode where players have to "watch cutscenes" before they can join each other. When Monster Hunter World works however, it's *so* much fun. It's honestly difficult to not be able to recommend MHW because from a gameplay perspective it's utterly fantastic, but the irritations that come with this dreadful port job mean I can't recommend it in good conscience. I hope they've learnt their lesson for the inevitable Monster Hunter World 2; Capcom may have goodwill from people this time for finally bringing MH to PC, next time I'm not so sure.

author: MoldyShishkabob
review: Played MHW when it was out on PS4 and XBox. Compared to that version, though, everything has been the same for me but better. Only complaints I seem to see from other reviews that I really agree with are the CPU usage and the server issues, and the latter could/will likely be fixed in the near future anyway.Maybe I just have low standards, coming from 20 sec XBox loadtimes to 1 sec PC loadtimes, and from the 30 FPS and low resolution of the 3DS games.That said, Monster Hunter is an experience best made with friends, whether it's alongside a veteran of the series who can help show the ropes through the first five hours, or if it's alongside a few others who are just there to have a good time. I hope the server issues can be fixed soon to help reflect that a bit better on the newcomers on PC.That said, looking past some of the technical issues that seem to plague the reviews section... There isn't a Monster Hunter game that's generally friendlier to beginners than this game. Though the tutorial seems long, I honestly think it's a necessary evil compared to "here's the controls, now get your butt handed to you by the first (and easiest) big monster" that seems to happen in past games.Once you get past the tutorial, some of the best gameplay in the entire series opens up, in my opinion. While past games were rigid and methodical (not a bad thing, but less welcoming), Monster Hunter World feels fluid and free in just how much detail is given to the moves of weapons and the general movement one has while fighting. Of course, monster movement is also much more fluid to compensate for this fact.Overall, I've been able to play about 9 of my first 10 hours on PC with a friend and it has been a fantastic experience so far, even in spite of how generally weird the process is for doing story missions with friends. Monster Hunter World may not have the same amount of content as Monster Hunter Generation Ultimate will at the end of this month, but the gameplay is of such good quality that I didn't think was possible, coming from an already high-quality series.

author: flemdawgheal
review: The best damn monster hunter yet.Finally they got smooth and amazing graphics. The gameplay has added mechanics that make the combat smoother. The AI is alot more smoother and not so unrelenting as it used to be. You can finally bowgun without feeling gimped. It's quite balanced with melee and ranged so I love bow gunning in this MH.Only gripe is the constant online disconnects. But this game is selling very very well so it's servers are hammered.If you have not played a monster hunter game before, you will need lube to make it through the first 24 hours of gameplay before you start to get good. Its like playing dark souls for the first time. You just have to git good. But don't give up, the pay off is huge.I'm about 1/3 of the way through and I'm quite satisfied. Would recommend this game for any serious gamer. This isn't casual land where rainbow and unicorns exist. There is a ramp up to a high skill ceiling. It feels good to get there. The question is are you too casual or do you want to git good kid? Be the gamer we need. Show capcom how we reward good games that don't cater to casuals and instead reward skillful mechanical play.10/10, enjoy :)

author: zfih
review: I'm currently enjoying myself quite a bit with this game. It seems the PC port is well done, a few graphics settings that are missing would be nice to have patched in, but it is in my opinion not that bad with quite a few settings compared to other console ports. The online is more complicated than it should but the as long as you join a friend who is either at the same place in the story or behind you, it seems to function correctly. Only problem I've had with online is that I can't join a private session even with an invite, even though the game specifies that invites should still work. A little patch to fix these issues and the game is perfect. The gameplay is quite repetitive, but it is meant to be very grindy, as where the other Monster Hunter games. If you are not looking for a grindy game then this is not for you. I will definitely recommend this game for people who are interested in this kinda game, and like these types of games. If you are unsure if it is your cup of tea, I would suggest watching some gameplay videos or reviews as the intro scenario and tutorial takes more than 2 hours and therefore might remove any possibility of a refund.

"mixed reviews" almost all based on connection issues I have never once encountered, are sacrilidge considering the amount that this game, for lack of a better word, rocks.

author: Mohl
review: It's a fantastic game, but it's a pretty bad PC port. That said, if your PC is beefy enough for it to run effectively, the game will easily last you hundreds of hours, probably even thousands.Capcom's working to fix the various issues (both in terms of optimization and disconnects), but until then, it's rather hard to play multiplayer, either due to not being able to connect to other players in the first place, or getting disconnected halfway through a hunt and being forced to deal with a scaled up monster alone.Also of note is a "bug" where the final credits cutscene can corrupt your save file. This is false, and is actually just the game crashing due to your computer not having the proper codec to run the video. As it's usually installed with windows (but not Windows N versions), it doesn't affect most people, but for those that are affected, you can simply find the proper codec online and download it, and you'll be able to continue as normal.Overall, the game's a gargantuan diamond that's somehow covered in some rust. Once it gets polished, it's going to pretty much take over your free time. In a good way, not "you gotta grind for 4 weeks to make any progress at all".

author: L³
review: If you are new to Monster Hunter, do yourself a favor and pick this game up. Nothing beats the satisfaction of getting wailed on by a monster, then, only a few hunts later, beating the same monster into a pile of dust.Monster Hunter: World has a very rewarding gameplay flow where you earn your armour and weapons, crafted from the husks of the enemies you've slain. Drop rates are reasonable and the new investigations increase the chances of getting rare parts. Overall, the smoothest MH games I've played (started with MH:4U). P.S. Story mode multiplayer is annoying, but that is only a tiny portion of the game.
