author: Haliun
review: The combat is very fun and mostly fluid (more on that a bit later), the graphics are great and the areas looks very nice in my opinion. The addition of guiding lands is a good imo, while it includes a different kind of grind, at least it removed the RNG part of Augment hunting.The main shortcomings are (in my opinion):- Clutch claw and its fluidity. I really dislike how you have to drop everything just so you can extend the "clagger" animation. - Some performance issues. While I hadn't experienced it, and from what I hear its mostly fixed, I still know people had suffered its issue with their systems (and I am not talking about 10 year old laptops having issues with it) - I know a friend of mine had problems with CPU usage on Intel x9700- While there are quite a few monters, once your gear gets pretty good 80% of the monsters just become irrelevant. Regardless of its shortcomings, I still love this game and would recommend it to anyone who likes action games and isn't afraid from a bit of a grind.

author: Malek
review: Get cool weapons. Beat up monsters. Rinse repeat

author: Mad Drunk Microbial
review: My lineage with Monster Hunter goes back to the Playstation 2 and continues through MHFU, Tri, MH4 and now this game. This is the peak of the series, bar none. An absolute mastery of the Monster Hunter concept with the best blend of pre-existing and new mechanics. It might be an overwhelming learning curve for new players, I'm not sure but for old hands at the series I sincerely believe this is the best game in the lineup.

author: Hex: Thicc Booty
review: The overall graphics and story is just immersive. The sounds and effects are excellent. First, the graphics is outstandingly overwhelming, especially when the high texture mode and DLC are installed. However, I'm not going to tap into that because it needs a powerful PC and I only play on my Ryzen 3 2400G processor and it runs great. Even with the lowest graphics, it still runs good and the immersive element is not lost.Focusing on the story, it gives a heart-warming feeling with a dash of that "success" moment when you hunt/slay/capture a monster, best with friends involved as well. The music and sounds perfectly fits the scenes where you have to listen where the roars are coming from in hunts, down to the small details of water flowing from the walls in Hoarfrost Reach----the ambiance in Seliana's gathering hub and the environment change during various weathers and time of the day.Moreover, materials and the difficulty of gameplay isn't that hard when you just know what you are doing. The game made it clear about monster behaviors because you'll know when  to capture or when the monster is really weak to slay it. I am still hoping for more to come in the future and I hope Capcom would do its best to attend to its multiplayer area.I would really recommend this game to any other players wishing for an immersive hunt! In the real world, we must conquer evil by hunting it and wearing those "scars" as our armor and weapon to defeat them!

author: The Redhead
review: Where do I begin? Monster Hunter World is a fantastic game that you should go out and play right now if you're fan of:- The Monster Hunter Series (obviously).- Constant and pure boss fights.- Teamwork.- Rewarding gameplay.- A good amount of content.There's absolutely no contest. In my opinion, as a Monster Hunter 4 Ultimate player, this is the best game in the series to date. Some aspects can be fixed and/or improved but the overall package is pure Monster Hunter love all around.I would've liked to see some monsters returning to the franchise but the new monsters do scratch that itch you're looking for. However, not everything is flowers and roses, like I said. The game has a few negative aspects that I do not find pleasing at all:- Your HR(progress) is locked behind a main story.- Unskippable cutscenes, UNSKIPPABLE CUTSCENES WHY.- Can't join a hunt if the player is doing a main story hunt and they haven't watched all cutscenes (WHY DID THEY DO THIS).- No G-rank (as of now, but iceborn will add Master Rank).- Bad gathering hub this time around. It's pointless to use it mostly.- Not good optimization for PC although it's been slightly improved (I run the game perfectly with a FX 8320 and a RX 480).- NO ZAMTRIOS.Everything else are pros from my point of view. Just be aware, if you plan to buy it to play with your friends, every single one of you will have to join a main story hunt separately, then leave and join to a single one after the cutscenes play. I still have no idea why they thought this was a good idea. The cutscenes played just fine in MH4U.Those are the caveats I found and this comes from a Monster Hunter fan. Happy hunting!

author: JEVAD
review: Barring technical/matchmaking issues, a truly amazing experience. If you like extremely satisfying combat (bow ftw), immersive environments, engaging co-op, and challenging battles with well designed AI, then this game is the jackpot. The grind may be excessive at times due to dumb RNG chances for certain items, but imo the combat and the monsters more than make up for it. However, the game has a very interesting and well thought out lore.Overall, the game is a 10/10 from me :)

author: Benton Tarantella
review: Been playing Monster Hunter since the original back on Playstation 2. Always hunted with my friends irl and we had the most fun playing the PSP Monster Hunter games back in the day. Hammer main since MH Freedom baby.If you like Monster Hunter you will like this game.My only complaints are that we need more monsters to hunt, which also ties in to another complaint I have is that there are not enough weapon trees and armor sets. Bring back all the old monsters and maybe some of the old maps reimagined in Monster Hunter World style (would love to have some of the original maps from MH1, the old forest, jungle, or swamp maps.) If they bring back more old monsters they can add a lot more variety to the weapon trees in this game as well as new armor sets to collect.Put my boys Rajang, Plesioth, Yian Garuga, and Khezu in Smash and this game would be 10/10.(Edit as of Iceborne) They added my boys Rajang and Garuga. Hell just bring back everything at this point imo. Next DLC should be an island/tropical based DLC with Plesioth, Hermitaur/Cenataur, Lagiacrus, Plesioth, Ludroth, and Mizutsune. It's free real estate Capcom!

author: The Peasant
review: How Monster Hunter World killed my Graphics Card:So it has been a while since I have gotten Monster Hunter World from a friend. Upon playing it I realized how amazingly fun the game was and the beauty of the world! Everything from the combat, monsters, quests, and story, all of it gave me thrills I haven't had for years from other AAA games. Then it got to the 'end game' bosses the elder dragons. I was obsessed with farming gems and materials for my gear. While all the Elder Dragons were difficult there was one who stood above the rest. Not because of their roar and immediate thrashings, nor because of their damage that could sometimes kill me in one hit. Oh no it was much worse than that.The Monster that gave me the hardest time was one called 'Kushala Daora'. A giant steel dragon who loves to spam his attacks quite often. At the beginning of the fight it is not a problem and most of the time easy to avoid. However it was when the dragon was weakened and went back to the peak of the mountain that I truly began suffering. As you will all know, Monster Hunter World is so beautiful in the highest graphic settings and so I am sure many of you will play it this way. Yet if you fight Kushala Daora, don't. This is because after immediately waking up he will spam tornado's with swirling debris all over the area. Even with my excellent setup there was a very noticeable frame drop and everything was choppy. With the first fight, everything was alright. Yet after a few consecutive fights against Kushala Daora the unimaginable happened. My screen went black, and I got the dreaded message 'signal lost'. I figured it was just my monitor, unplugged and plugged back in, still though the same message. I tried a different monitor I had spare and yet still the same message. I was devistated, as I knew it had to be the graphics card. I took it to someone professional I knew and they told me it had been overclocked and will no longer work. I now have to get a new graphics card.So am I upset about the entity known as Kushala Daora spamming its gritty attacks all over the place like a spastic child? Yes. Am I mad that I now have to spend hundreds of dollars on a new graphics card to replace the one I had? Extremely so. Does this mean I would stop playing Monster Hunter World? Absolutely Not. It is an extremely fun game with lots of content to discover and intriguing stories coupled with badass monsters to kill. My only advice though is if you play this game on the highest settings, be prepared to lose your graphics card. Especially when fighting the blowhard Steel chick.TL;DR  Don't play this game on highest graphics settings against Kushala Daora. I suggest turning it all down. Still a fun game even if it costs me a couple hundred dollars now.

author: Cyber Twilight
review: 200 hours gone by.Maybe less than 15 of those were of genuine frustration. All the rest has been of pure joy and entretainment.All of the streamline, the quality-of-life decisions, the OUTSTANDING environments and level desgin and, of course, a revamped monster AI with SO MANY interactions... it's just crazy.I'm not an EXTREME veteran of Monster Hunter, I've maybe spent 100 hours on 3 Ultimate - a fact easily scoffed by any hunter worth their salt. But, despite not having my favourite monster (Lagiacrus ;~;), this still became one of my favourite PC games.Honestly? Some (few) monsters' awful game design, abysmal matchmaking/lobby system, unwanted or underutilized gameplay systems, the bland characters/story and a CPU-eating PC optimization aren't nearly enough to dent the absolute blast I've had playing this game. What can a perfect core gameplay loop do for a game, eh?8/10. Cat lovers shouldn't even hesitate buying this.[Seriously though, they need to invest a tad more in player retention and dishing out great events. Halloween was very underwhelming and I have a feeling Christmas will be too.]

author: Twigs81
review: I've never played a Monster Hunter game. Never even heard of it until about a month ago. But, a lot of people I game with got it, and one of them bought me a copy. The game it beautiful. I have no issues with frame rate, the combat is fun, the monsters are awesome and the combat is great. That being said, there are two huge problems I have with the game. First, and least importantly, the menu system is a complete mess. They would have done better not having a menu at all. Second, and the reason I can't recommend this game, are the sever issues. Now, I know that a chunk of the blame falls of Steam for fixing what wasn't broken, but my god its awful. I was given this game so that I could play games with my friends. And so far, I've been able to do the for only a maybe 20 hours (out of the 80 I've played) over the course of the last week because, as sure as the sun rising in the east, 1 if not all of us will be forcefully disconnected, kicked to single player offline mode, and then be forced to restart the entire game if we want to group back up again....for 20 minutes until it disconnects us again.Its a beautiful game, but unless you are a solo gamer, its a broken mess right now. I've put 80 hours into the game sure, but I'm not going to be playing it going forward until the server issues are fixed.

author: Xarth
review: It's rare that I ever really write reviews but given the, in my opinion, unjust and kneejerk review-bombing of this game, I feel like the more input there is for the people who may be considering purchasing this game, the better. Does it have its issues? Of course it does, it's rare that releases like this that are this anticpated go over completely smoothly, and I very strongly disagree with the sentiment that it is just a "half-assed" PC port. I've seen much much worse. The multiplayer issues are much less of a port quality issue, and more of a SERVER issue. Let's not forget MH:W's multiplayer was basically unplayable for over a week at its release on console. I understand the frustration with how annoying the servers can be, but when a game slingshots up to the thirdmost game in Steam's concurrent players board the day of release, I feel like it's fair to expect some server issues. Especially when there's really no way to completely prep for a full release of that scale with new servers. When it comes to multiplayer, your yield may vary, for myself personally it has its hiccups but for the most part I've been able to do numerous succesful hunts with my friends, when it DOESN'T work however it can be a massive pain in the ass. That seems to be the BIGGEST gripe most are having with this game, but it's something I expect to be fixed soon as the amount of players levels out, or as Capcom patches the game in the future. However, there are two other issues as well.From what I can hear, the optimization can be pretty hit or miss for people. My friends and I all have PCs ranging from mid-high end, and most of us have little-no issue. The graphical settings are pretty specific and can be changed, if you're having issues I'd recommend turning a few settings down and it's easy to run consistently well on medium at or above 60 fps on most mid-range rigs.The secondmost problem being mouse controls and camera controls. The camera requires getting used to, and I changed my settings a few times to find what I was most comfortable with, but it'd be better if they were to update or patch it to be more user-friendly. Mouse controls are a straight no-go for me, unless you're using a ranged weapon of some sort. Otherwise, I pretty much only use my controller for this game, and with the response to the mouse controls I'd recommend the same.Overall, much fun to be had.- Load times have the speedforce, especially on an SSD- Higher framerate options, higher resolution options- Multiple inputs supported- Steam integration is cooler than squads, fight me.All this on top of an already amazing game with a beautiful world. The tradeoff is the servers may be janky SOMETIMES, maybe a few frame drops for you, and mouse acceleration will take some getting used to.BUY IT!!

author: bruvuvur
review: NOTE: I have *a lot* of time on this game on PS4, the 22hrs I have played on PC is not representative of my actual understanding of this game.This game is the best game I have ever played. Hands down. Whether it be the grinding system, rewarding combos, amazing monsters or simply awesome level design. This game is incredible. The regions vary widely, and the design is as beautiful as it is complicated. The little details in every aspect of the game really make it shine. Capcom has done an amazing job at polishing this game to a bright shine when it comes to graphics. Another aspect of the game I love is the grinding system. Unlike other games where one must defeat masses of weak enemies, this game has one boss-like target to defeat over 15-50 minutes. It feels like a fight for your life, not an endless grind like other games. Additionally, the grinding system also promotes skill. The more mastery you have of your combos, the more effectively you will break monster's parts, and the more loot you gain. The crafting system of weapons, armour and other items (I. e Jewels) is also great. The online multiplayer in this game is what truly sets it apart. Especially on console, and somewhat on Steam, hoping into a chat with strangers and helping them or receiving help like its no issue is so good. Making friends, memorable moments and an overall atmosphere of positivity surrounding MHW are among the many things that Online has done for both the series and myself as a player. The Session system could be more polished, especially on console where the servers sometimes crash and disconnects often occur. That aside, I've seen no such issues on PC.Overall, this is an absolute legendary game that will forever hold a place in my heart. Watching the final Dev Diary and listening to the 'Stars at Our Backs' OST play for what I thought was the final time made m appreciate how lucky and the rest of the MH community are to play such an amazing game. Worth the 80 AUD on console and 40 AUD on PC. The expansion is also one of the best I have seen. Also worth paying full price for. It doesn't matter what kind of games you played before (I came from Fortnite and COD), this game is worth investing your time and money (he he handler outfits go brrrrr) into.

author: Catory

Watch a few videos to see if you're gonna enjoy it, but you dont risk much considering the quite low price of the base game.Iceborne is only required when you've finished the base game, which means 20 hours if you rush it to 100+ hours if you take your time so feel free to buy it when you want to get to the next step after beating the main story

author: LewdGeek
review: (I was not able to ask for a refund because just to create your character and do the tutorial its take more then 2 hours...)This game is like the 55th in the franchise AND AFTER 55 games they didn't manage to do a nice Combat System... When you start a combo, it’s done you can't change the way you attack, you must stop your attack and back off, reposition to attack... LAME and BORING, AND TRUST ME, you will repeat this almost 200 times in a gameplay session and in those 200 times you will get what? 20 full combos. The Combat System is so bad that there is only 5 or 6 weapon that are useful and trust me, useful, is a REALLY BIG WORD, because almost all weapon doesn’t have a decent combo. And the hitbox are TOTALLY BROKEN, you'll get hit from far and without any reason, trust me it’s going to happen a lot… the hit boxes are really broken. In the Arena mission you will see Canons and ballista and IF you finally manage to hit with the canon the Monster will just take no damage because he was mid animation to jump up while chasing your friend… WHAT A BAD GAMEPLAY. Oh, and let’s talk about this Connection Error that happen 200 times a day “Error Code: 50382-MW1” you can’t play with your friends or Online almost half the time and when you finally get to play with your friends, they get disconnected in the middle of the Monster fight. NEXT, the online is really bad, let me explain how the online works. You enter a server where a maximum of 16 people can join, BUT, there is no point about it because you are alone in town you can’t see them. You can talk to them but not the people on a mission AND THERE IS A WHOOOLLEE chat system with Emote, Emoji and Quote… BUT FOR WHAT??? If you can’t see them in town??? And there’s this area called “The Gathering Hub” where you CAN see the other players if they come there but again what the point??? To put a Social area nobody goes?Your character will clip through everything, wall, ground, objects and more. Your pieces of armor will clip through each others. Almost all the pieces of armor are ugly as f**k, in the end, you will just hate your character after building a build you like. Your character will look fat and feel fat while walking and fighting, it’s like nobody in the game have brains. If I was fighting Monster like those, I would want something solid and light, so, I can move more freely and have a lot more endurance.There is so many items that you'll get lost trying to search one item in your inventory. When you eat food you get a bonus, okay? but after you eat, you can't see if you have eaten or not in any menu, you can't see what bonus the food gave to you and your Palico after eating, it would have been nice to get a little menu or icon you can go to see a description of the actual effect you have.My opinion about this game? The Japanese doesn’t have standards in gaming and this game is bad AS F**K… SAVE YOUR MONEY and go play the Free-To-Play, Dauntless, this is the SAME game but with decent combat and connection.Overall: 4.3 / 10Story: 2/5Waifu: 0/5 (NO WAIFU AT ALL)Characters: 1/5 (All the armor are UGLY AS "F")Cinematics: 4/5 (I will give it a 5 but the fact that the gear is not there is really annoying me.)Gameplay: 2/5 Multiplayer: 2/5SFX: 4/5 (A lot of NPC are harrassing you if you don't do your mission right away.)Voice Acting: 2/5

author: Zarya
review: Takes a while to get the hang of combat, and despite all instincts telling you to hit the big dino right out of the gate.. DO NOT SPEND 30 MINUTES ATTACKING THE PINK DINO AS YOUR FIRST KILLYour life-long companion WILL make you flaccid.Weapon choice is a bit small, but it's sufficient to find something to suit everyone I'd guess. Most complex weapons are the Guns, which you will need to pick specific types of, to access specific bullets. I personally fell in love with Dual Blades and Light Bowguns.The intro might get you excited, but you will never care about the Story ever afterPeople WILL call a giant tadpole a pickle. Best to just accept it, cause you can't convert them to the truth.You will waste 300 hours completing the vanilla game's story because of distractions, trying to acquire multiple sets of equipment, and your rewards when entering the expansion, will be a snow paradise, a small palace, and an aggressively spanish botanist that peddle pseudo-lootboxes, despite not accepting cash.Your Veggie platters WILL contain meat.Chickens are not dangerous, unless they carry glowing rocks. In which case, you will regret your life.Basil the Goose will make your Тits screamYou CAN Co-Op, but you will need to watch the cutscene for discovering the monster of the quest you're on, to have your friend come join you. If both are on the same stage, you will be forced to both progress to the monster cutscene, and one of you will have to quit your instance, in order to join the other. It's a nuisance, but better than not being able to play together. Exceptions may occour, such as Expeditions. You can join one if you stay after completing a mission with a friend, whereafter said mission will become an expedition.Do not play alone, or you will be bored.You WILL look like a bombed toilet untill you reach the Iceborne DLC, and are rewarded with the ability to craft cosmetics.7/10.

review: Not bad, can't say I've been experiencing all of the errors that others have been encountering, but I guess that's just my phenomenal luck. The only things I can nitpick on are the mouse acceleration, motion blur and the constant need to restart your game after making any graphical changes in your settings. I'm playing on a 1920x1200 monitor (16:9) and I have little black bars located on the top and bottom of my screen, hope those get fixed within the upcoming updates. Lastly, I'm playing on a GTX 1050Ti and i5 4670k and get an average of 45-60 FPS. Just be sure to turn off Volumetric Rendering.Otherwise, it's a great game. Definitely recommended to anyone who has enjoyed it on console.

author: Bobsplosion
review: Now that the connection problems have been fixed, this game is absolutely recommended for any Monster Hunter fans, old and new.It ultimately fixes a lot of smaller problems from the older games and makes it much more accessible to a wider audience. One friend I've played with has had 2 while playing with me. It is not as bad as they make it seem. It is a beautifully made game and I can see myself dropping a couple hundred hours into it.

author: ColdWolf
review: I adore this game. It's the kind of game for me that comes along for me once or twice in a generation, and consumes every waking moment of my gaming, for as long as I'm physically capable of playing it.The mechanics are wonderful, the monsters are incredible in both animation and gameplay perspectives. The world and exploration are just deep enough that you'll find new things to discover even after 40hrs, keeping you guessing and introducing you to new monsters with a drip-feed of tension and excitement. It mixes simplicity and complexity almost perfectly, and keeps you constantly surprised that there's even more content you haven't seen yet.Just when you feel like you've 'got it', and you're beating monsters in 15 mins instead of 35, it'll throw you yet another, deeper challenge; fight more than one or two of them, in the same 50min limit. The requirement to completely re-work your strategies and re-analyse your playstyle when faced with a new, seemingly unsurmountable challenge is fantastic. You're always working towards beating the next, more exciting, even more dangerous battle, and need to master the mechanics to overcome the greatest of the challenges presented to you.There's a lull in the action after the first 'main chunk' of story which some might find to be quite an intolerable grind. My only advice with this is to bear with it, the increase in challenge and complexity immediately after this is worth it!

author: Vren
review: TL:DR game is great now. Nexus has mods, generally good quality. Some mods recommended, others more so for low quality setups.Concerning other reviews from earlier and other minor technical bits:When this game came out it had problems with its online play, disconnections were frequent and lead to lots of annoyed hunters, quit quests and lost time. Nowadays, the game has cleaned up its server problem and has been quite stable as of late. while there still might be disconnects, as far as i can tell its been entirely because of internet connections.The Game:Story:not going to spoil, story is fairly simple, always involves hunting something big and probably wants to eat you. progression is fairly good, although the story is focused on someone else.Characters:there are only really 3 characters in this game that you will care about, your hunter, your large assistant murder cat and the super buff cat who works the kitchen. There is also the Handler, your supposed partner who doesn't really do anything, and the story seems focused around her.Gameplay:Very solid.While there are 14 different weapon types in this game with their own individual playstyle, there's a weapon for everyone and they are relatively easy to pick up and use. now a quick summary of the weapons:Bow: fast, versatile firing, multishot bow, dodge for life, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ ROCKET POWERED ARROW(called dragon piercer(you have infinite of these))Charge Blade: fast/medium speed, low/decent damage, can change between sword and shield and large axe, dodge/block for days, very versatile weapon, smack down and explode them mostersDual Blades: fast attacks, low damage, lots of hits, dodge for life, weeb weapon #1GreatSword: slow, hard hitting, charge up to hit harder, sheath and run or block to live, can shoulder bash a T rex to the groundGunLance: medium speed, high damage, single hard hits, block all day, EXPLOSIONS!?Hammer: medium speed, high damage, lots of hard hits, dodge for days, play wack-a-mole with the monster's faceHeavy bowgun: slow speed, medium damage, lots of ammo types, roll or block all day, choice of either dakka or anti tank rifleHunting Horn: medium speed, medium damage, casts buffs on allies and self, roll for days, SCOTTLAND *FOREVER*Insect Glaive: medium/fast speed, good damage, can self heal/boost defence/change movest, roll and fly for days, you control the skies nowLance: decent attack speed, decent damage, can block basically anything and charge, block for days, DEJA VULightbowgun: decent/burst fire speed, decent damage, can deploy mines, dodge for days, watch the monsters blow themselves upLongsword: average attack speed, average damage, pretty user friendly, dodge for days, weeb weapon #2, omae wa mou shinderuSword and shield: fast, low damage, fastest weapon in all senses, can block or dodge, very versatile, can use items without needing to sheath.SwitchAxe: medium/fast attack speed, medium damage, can swap between a slow axe or faster greatsword, dodge for days(best dodge in axe mode), exploding greatsword shoved in monster face.gameplay itself:choose from any of the above weapons to hunt your target, watch the flies guide your way/break your character's neck to show you the way. when you find the monster you group up and hit it till it dies. it will try to leave many times, there are ways to stop it like flashing it, mounting it, knocking it out, stunning it, trapping it. when monsters are low health you have the choice of capturing them by placing a trap at their feet and slapping down some tranqs or killing them while they sleep.VERY IMPORTANT:when a monster is asleep, they will take double damage from the next hit, good rule of thumb, the best people to wake up monsters are people who know the ins and outs of their weapon and who have very powerful/big weapons.The mods:The game has a fairly active modding community who have come out with fairly impressive and interesting mods. there are plenty of quality of life mods and another mod which means you don't need to compromise fashion for function. for lower grade setups there are mods which will make the game run smoother and will remove some of the annoying effects they need to patch options in for still. failing that there are shaders you can download to make it run easier sometimes.for a quick guide to how you install the mods, its fairly simple:most mods will have install instructions in the description, but most can be summed up simply as "stick the file called Native PC into 'MONSTER HUNTER:WORLD' file in steamapps common." just be sure to read the finer print of the mods you download to ensure you can get the most of them, though other mods will simply be their own applications, so take care which ones you go for.

author: Loȝan
review: The multiplayer aspect, plain and simple, needs to be tightened down. That's all there is to it.Invites often don't work, people get disconnected constantly, and just getting a quest started is an utter chore of tedious menu-navigation and screwing with settings and reconnecting and so forth.There's just no reason or excuse at all for these kinds of problems - it literally feels like 15-25% of playtime is just screwing with trying to get connected to a session, then join the quest, then get in the quest, then hope it doesn't disconnect (despite having no internet issues, it just likes to lose connection!). But oh, if you DO get disconnected, sucks to be you. The spot you were in is still "occupied" by an unnamed, non-existant player, and it won't let you rejoin for some reason? And if you then add an extra slot and try to rejoin then.. you may have waited too long and wont' get quest completion credit anymore.Not to mention numerous quests require you to pick up the quest solo with your buddy doing the same, walk into the quest, listen to some dumb cutscene, walk around some, see a big monster, leave the quest, RE-accept the quest, RE-start the quest, go out with your friend now actually in tow and THEN you get to play.It's the most awkward, needlessly convoluted and stupidly frustrating system of multiplayer I've ever seen. Just share cutscenes, it's 2018, we've been showing cutscenes to more than one player at a time for decades. There's also dozens of ways to not constantly have players disconnect from one another or, at least, be able to *re*join easily.The game was delayed heavily for PC, is full-price, and there's a whole plethora of previous titles to learn from. This is a solidly "don't bother" review just because the multiplayer is so uttelry frustrating to get working, and it loves to fail constantly when you do finally get it working. Some will say "oh well after the main story it works better" - that's not a valid justification to me at all. It's multiplayer, we've been doing this stuff since LAN-playing Doom, and I sure didn't get disconnected, booted, have invisible players occupying slots, etc. etc. happen there. It's not that hard, and all these games that do it so poorly just boggle my mind.tl;dr - It's a game that is designed around multiplayer, yet multiplayer is absurdly convoluted and unreliable to get working. If anything goes wrong, you are screwed with progress/can't rejoin.edit: Okay, even after the disconnects are improved by altering settings, and ignoring the fact that there are a dozen ways the disconnects could be mitigated (none of which MHW does - if you disconnect, you're screwed)  - I'm leaving this as a not-recommend because the design is just dumb half the time. The game actively prevents you from playing and enjoying it. Why must I join a mission, see some pointless cutscene, leave a mission, and THEN get ot play with someone sitting right beside me? Have we not figured out how to share cutscenes?Better yet, why do we need the cutscene?Spoiler, here is EVERY SINGLE MISSION in the game: STart mission, aimlessly wander until you find tracks, follow tracks to spot, see pointless cutscene where your dumb handler stands in the way of danger, narrowly shove her out of the way/avoid an attack from the foe (who you may have seen/tracked a dozen times prior, doesn't matter!), and then begin fight.It's the same, mission after mission, and it's just tedious. Wasting 15 minutes running around to find a monster I already know the lair of just to see a dumb cutscene that is the same as every other cutscene so I can leave the mission and THEN restart the quest with someone I am co-oping with.. it's just needless tedium and wasted time.When you get to the fun part of the game - fighting monsters - it's fun. But getting to that part is way too tedious, there's absolutely no need for so much of the aimless fiddling and issues in design to get in the way of an otherwise good game. But given the price, and the delay of time they had to make stuff work right (did nobody test their game on the steam servers if it's solely steams problem?) I don't really consider it acceptable - it's bad design choice.

author: Obeliske
review: This is my first MH game as I'm a PC only guy. Controls react the same way they do in Darksouls, combat is also very much the same. The game literally gives you a guiding light to your target so there's no reason to "hunt" anything. Monsters seem to only have about 4-6 different attacks which due to the way combat works is why the game feels very artificially difficult. There are only about a dozen weapons each with their own upgrades and trees (usually 2-3) meaning actual content wise there isn't a lot here. There's not much story and there certainly aren't any survival aspects.On the other hand. The game is beautiful. I'm running a mid range comp (<1k$) and running on max with no issues. I've run into two bugs that are issues but are not everytime, alt tabbing can cause the game to crash (does this about 1/10 times), and their servers suck and boot you on occasion (seems like they are more likely to boot you when you are using them rather then when they are just running in the background). Ultimately it's a game that feels like running on a treadmill do to x do y to get z to go to x etc. etc. etc. I'm roughly halfway through the game doing all side content it's taken me about 20 hours so far and I'm just starting to hit the point with weapons where the skin looks the same as the last one. However armor is neat (if in many cases overly bulky and unattractive) and doesn't seem to recycle textures like weapons do and the monsters are interesting to look at and fight. Ultimately this game is a game about fighting large monsters like a t-rex with naught but a sword. If that sounds like fun this is a game for you. If not... well move along I guess? :P

author: Cynthimon™
review: Having tried Monster Hunter in the past on handheld platforms, I couldn't quite get into them due to the graphics quality and rather frustrating controls. With Monster Hunter World, the graphics are amazing and the controls feel much better (though not perfect), so this is the first Monster Hunter game that I managed to finish the story and still keep on playing more.Pros:- Amazing graphics- Improved Monster Hunter gameplay formula, almost everything feels better than previous titles- Multiplayer, very fun playing with a group of friends- Mouse and keyboard support for the first timeCons:- Networking and disconnecting Issues (recently fixed for me, but was game breaking when it happened often)- Graphics and controls could be more optimised (hard to get 60 fps, controls and UI are still very console-like for the PC version)- Minor annoyance during co-op is the main story hunts: everyone needs to individually watch the story cutscenes first before being able to join up and play together- Story wasn't very interesting, but don't think anyone plays Monster Hunter for the storyNot perfect, but imo the best Monster Hunter experience so far.

author: El Phantasmo
review: Long time monster hunter here. I started back on Tri in 2010 and have played almost every game in the series since then, excluding generations (waiting for the ultimate switch version which releases later this month). I just got to say, Monster Hunter has never looked or played this smooth. I thought that this might ruin the gameplay I have grown accustomed to over the years, but it really doesn’t. Some of the new mechanics I am still getting used to, but this seems like the logical evolution the series needed. Getting critical hits on monsters and shooting their face off with my heavy bowgun feels exhilarating to say the least. So far, it seems to be a tad on the easy side of things when it comes to monster hunter difficulty, but I am still fairly early on in the game and I am assuming that this will ramp up. I am crossing my fingers that we get some proper g rank up in here. I am honestly, a little sad with the way that multiplayer works. As compared to past games you could just post it and go. Here, you have the whole S.O.S. flares which in theory sounds great. Having a little trouble with that single player quest? Shoot off a flare and allies will come help you! I was excited because they claimed you could do the whole single player in multiplayer! In actuality, there are quests that you can’t join until they reach a certain cutscene. This seems silly and it is frustrating to go and join a quest and have the ui tell you you’ve failed to join and give no explanation as to why.  (Come on Capcom, it’s 2018, why can’t you get multiplayer correct?) As far as the pc port is concerned, I haven’t really had any issues. I have a 1060 and a Ryzen 1600 I get minimum 54 fps rarely and most times it sits stable at 60 fps. I turned off fxaa, ambient collusion, and the volumetric options. The game still looks great. A couple things I wish, would be an option to turn off motion blur, turn off motion blur, and TURN OFF MOTION BLUR! Did I mention TURN OFF MOTION BLUR? I am baffled as to why this option was not included? 99 percent of games allow you to do this from within the advanced option. Why Capcom? I wish Capcom would continue to optimize the game, as many reviews are complaining about terrible performance. I am not having issues, but I understand others are. Also, Capcom, turn off denuvo. Just please. I am not going to beat a dead horse for that aspect of the game. Overall on the pc port side of things, Capcom did an OKAY job, the gameplay however, I feel more than makes up for that. So, I am going to give this game a recommendation, just know that Capcom still has lots of room to grow when it comes to ports.*RE-REVIEW After putting more hours into the game I can really see how terrible optomized this pc port is, that along with the issues for multiplayer (dropping in and out randomly, making me lose connection to chat) I have to say, this port is far from finished. It is so frustrating it makes me not want to even play. Fix your game crapcom!

author: Aepoh
review: For the first time in forever I can understand why a game gets mixed reviews instead of just falling into either positive or negative. Let me be clear in saying that this is an amazing game, probably one of the best I've ever played, but it's not a very good port. At least not yet. You should expect the game to improve drastically over the next few months as we start getting the same patches the PS4 version recieved. If you want to buy this game on the PC, that's absolutely fine. In fact I would reccomend it even more over the PS4 version. Just be aware that there are a few things that you're going to need in order to properly enjoy it. You should treat this game as if it's Dark Souls Prepare to Die edition. It's a port full of flaws, but a redeemable port none the less. What you'll need: And thats pretty much everything you need in order to have a decent experience like I'm having. One last point I'd like to make is that if you want to try the game out then I don't reccomend purchasing it and then refunding it if you don't like it. It takes well over 2 hours to get to the meat of what the gameplay is. By the time you know enough to form an opinion on the game you won't be able to refund it. Go on youtube and watch some other people play some of the earlier areas of the game first. Not only will this give you a safe way to tell if the game is something you'd like to play, but it will also preemptively teach you how to play.

review: I can happily recommend this game which is rare for me.I've only spent about 20 hours currently, but from what I have played of this beautiful game is brilliant.Everything down to map design to boss battles you name it I love it, well except the handler but small price to pay maybe she'll get gobbled up eventually when I'm not there to save her.Anyway if you're like me before i got this and aren't sure about getting this game all I can say is if you enjoy intense boss battles and open world landscapes with beautiful scenery then get it. author: Esterlin
review: A decent game brought low by far too many bugs and glitches.Their netcode is among one of the worst I've ever seen. Good luck finishing any mission multiplayer as the game will constantly drop network connection.Certain monsters will suddenly gain MASSIVE phantom range, hitting you from literally opposite ends of the arena despite the animation not being anywhere remotely close. I attribute this to a desync issue as it typically happens when you were in a multiplayer lobby, although I have had it rarely happen during offline fights as well.Controls are about what you can expect from a Monster Hunter game, but with the presence of occasional control issues. For example, a command not going through or buttons becoming nonresponsive.These are only some of the more frustrating and prominent bugs in the game, there are plenty more. If these bugs didn't exist, I'd recommend the game.

author: Cheri
review: The game design itself is great. Decent gameplay, good graphics, good story so far, amazing monster designs, really fun to play.Whoever is responsible for the servers and the idea for "If someone DC's for half a second, we should remove them from their party, force them to solo quests, and make it impossible to reconnect to their instance without completely restarting the game," needs to have an actual pile of feces dropped on their doorstep. If you have shotty internet, such as Spectrum, and your internet lags occasionally, or every ten minutes, the MH team has made it impossible to play the game. You'll start an instance, of which most are designed to be played with multiple people, and as soon as the internet hiccups, you get disconnected. There's no reconnect option. You can no longer call for help. If you were in a party, your party members disappear. Your instance outside of the dungeon is now screwed until you quit the entire game and restart it. You can't connect to matchmaking again, you can't connect to friends' servers, you can't even make a new one. This is the WORST setup for disconnects I have ever encountered in a game. It's doubly frustrating that even if you have a monster at low health with your group, if it disconnects, there's a chance the monster will glitch back to full health and you have to solo kill it, from scratch, without your friends, from FULL HP, with the time limit still running. Yeah, no. 0/10 would not recommend unless you're a severe masochist who enjoys wanting to pull their eyes out of their sockets on every simple level.

author: Wigi
review: Monster Hunter is one of the best game series of all time and Monster Hunter: World improves on it. I have played MH: Tri, MH: Tri U, MH: 4U, MH: Gen, and now this one. I have plenty of experience and hundreds of hours of accumulated playtime with the entire series and I can confidently say that this is the best game yet. The gameplay is awesome, the graphics and animations are great, the audio is great, etc. I literally have no complaints about the game. It is a masterpiece. Get it and get hunting!

author: alexolotl
review: Newbie to the series here. Wow, I didn't really know what I was getting into but my time in MH:W has been some of the most fun I've had in ages. The story and characters are absolutely cringe inducing but once you get out to the.. monster hunting.. it's utterly unique. The game isn't particularly well optimized but turning off the volumetric quality both improved performance drastically and (subjectively) made the game look better. Recommend trying that. Also props to Capcom for adding 21:9 support in an update.

author: ̧҉ ҉Minorou ꧁💀꧂
review: Monster Hunter is a notoriously difficult series to get into, but with World, Capcom did their best to make it as accessible as possible for newcomers to the series while still maintaining that distinctive feel of a Monster Hunter game. Did they succeed? Somewhat. The recent popularity of similar games such as the Souls series did well to get people into the mindset for the genre, and the changes made to the series with World were an additional step in the right direction to get more people invested into the franchise. Now, more people than ever are playing Monster Hunter, and the series is doing well for it overall! However, the game is not perfect; it stumbles in a few areas.As Monster Hunter moved into its now "fifth generation" of the series, it's made some significant departures from some longstanding traditions. The archaic point threshold armor skill system was replaced by a more streamlined incremental skill system that makes more sense; an overall positive for the series that promotes more build variety. The change from segmented hunting areas to a seamless single area with no loading zones changes the tempo of the hunt dynamic dramatically, and greatly enhances immersion. Things are much more vertical now, and the addition of the slinger, a grappling hook/slingshot combination, is a great move. Other quality of life improvements such as the SOS system or eating food during a hunt are also a great benefit. Some might scoff at these improvements with "back in my day" comments, but honestly, things are a lot better now.The core of the game, combat, is better than ever. Each weapon is streamlined and smoothed out to feel great. While some weapons are naturally going to be more popular than others, they're all equally viable from early game to end game. If you want to main a weapon type, or be a generalist, you are always free to do so without any feelings of missing out. The verticality and environmental hazards of the areas also greatly enhance the hunt. No longer are you just fighting in "zone 3" with flat ground and dull scenery; every part of the hunting zones in World feels like a living ecosystem, with things to help or hinder you as you see fit.Overall, the game is great, and will carry a player for a hundred hours plus, easily. However, things are not all well. The early parts of the game force you to experience the story, and you can't do so in multiplayer; other players cannot join the hunt until everyone else has seen the same cutscene. If you're playing along with friends, this results in an awkward situation where everyone all starts the same mission solo, sees the cutscene, then everyone leaves their quest to join in on one player. It's an awful mess that critically messes up the multiplayer experience for the early game. In addition, you can't see other players in the same hub unless you're in a specific area of the town, but that area doesn't have access to the farm, the ship, the armory, or anything else critical to preparing for a hunt; people often just never go there, so even though you're often in a hub with up to 15 other players, you're not seeing them. Another unfortunate thing is that once you know what you're doing, the game is much easier solo; so except for a few specific situations, you're better off hunting alone anyway.Given that this is a new generation of the series, it's inevitable that the game has relatively few monsters compared to older generations. While it's satisfactory for the game itself, veterans of the series might be dissapointed with small variety of monsters given the huge amount we've had access to in previous games. New monsters will come in time, as Capcom is constantly working to give out free updates.The last major problem with Monster Hunter World is that the end game can be a bit underwhelming. Once you get over the novelty of fighting tempered elder dragons, you suddenly find out that grinding them is pretty much all there is left to do. Sure, there's a few distractions like Kulve Taroth events, but the majority of end-game is fighting the same four to five monsters over and over again for low chance RNG drops. Older games in the series handled this better.All in all, Monster Hunter World is a great game with a few minor gripes. After all, if you get 100+ hours out of it, can you really complain? I only put up the demerits above because I love the game so much and want to see it improve, and I know it will. Capcom's been releasing patches over the past few months, fixing the problems people have had with the game. It's not perfect, but it's well worth your time.

author: Fizz
review: Ok so im going to start off this review with THAT MIXED REVIEW SCORE IS THE BIGGEST LIE SINCE NO MANS SKY DEBUT.Most the reviews on here are about self entitled ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who think 1 D/C ruins the game for them when in reality they probably got kicked from my squad for being absolute brain dead dual blade users. Posting a review saying that "OMG THIS GAME IS AMAZING BUT I COULDNT CONNECT TO MY FRIEND THAT ONE TIME SO IT SUCKS".GIVING A NO RECOMMENDATION WHILE THEY STILL PLAY IT EVERYDAY WHILE SAYING TO OTHER PLAYERS NO DONT BUY THIS GAME. Like i just think i lost afew braincells with some of these reviews. I bet most these negatives reviews love the game but are only salty at the net code issues.Clearly this isnt wasnt a PC only problem and we can go onm about whos fault it is and why we waited 7 months but i digress.You might be thinking..."Who gives a ♥♥♥♥??!" and i would respond with "you're right lets just move on"This game is AMAZING not perfect but honestly a huge step in the right direction. Some people love the old format with content upon content but for me that has gotten stale at the point WORLD has been a breath of fresh air. It's colourful, vibrant and gives my pc a run for its money finally. YES, it has been streamlined as i would make the campirison that WORLDS is the bloodborne of monster hunter fast paced and straight into the action. Which turned me off at first but honestly where the clunky difficult lacks in, it makes up for decently tough hunts. As a player who played MH before i found it a relativily easy breeze through. However non MH players who pick up WORLDS will probably find a decent challenge until you vs the HR 50 monster (GOOD LUCK ON THAT).YES, ive heard people on here say its pretty lacking in content compared to other games and 80% of armour sets look ugly af. BUT we must remember this is the teams first gam on this engine and having to make everything from the ground up to achieve this impressive game i worthy of  my £50 purchase. There are stil lthose little stupid things i mentioned like having to use transmog to not look like a clown and not much variety in monsters. However, we do get free DLC and hthis game would be supported for a good length of time.TL;DR Retarded steam reviewsGREAT GAME RECOMMEND BUYING AT FULL PRICE IF U ARE EAGERSOLID 100 hours of action packed gameplay before you reach end gameFREE DLCThere are still that 1 off D/C after the 2 patches 10/10 will touch that pickle againThis game is far from crap and i thought mixed reviews meant a game was no mans sky level bad, not just a "waaah I d/c so this game is a insta thumbs down"Theres a reason why most my friends list plays this game

author: An7en | Ntyr Ey. *
review: Following its late January console debut, the Monster Hunter: World PC release date has finally been announced—August 9, 2018. Check out its announcement trailer above.Originally down for a Fall/Autumn PC release (which Google informs me starts on September 23), the series' desktop introduction comes earlier than planned. "This is the first time we’ve taken a mainline Monster Hunter game to PC," producer Ryozo Tsujimoto tells us in a written Q&A, "so we wanted to take the time to get it right and do the proper research and preparation."In his beginner's primer, published on the day of its console launch, our Steven explored why people love Monster Hunter so damn much. Capcom tells us Monster Hunter: World has since become the developer's biggest-selling game, having shifted eight million copies globally in less than six months.sky sky sky~Here's the official skinny: In Monster Hunter: World, follow the journey of the elder dragons as they begin their once a decade migration across the sea to a land known as the New World in an event referred to by inhabitants as the Elder Crossing. As part of the Guild’s Research Commission, players must embark on a grand journey to this massive, mysterious land and uncover the secrets behind this phenomenon. As hunters set out on their quests, the Commission’s sights are set on Zorah Magdaros, a colossal elder dragon that rises from the earth like a volcano.Capcom explains collaborations and "other additional content" that's since made its way to the console variant post-launch will "be coming to PC for free at a later date." This includes monsters Deviljho and Lunastra, says Tsujimoto.We also know that visually Monster Hunter: World "will have parity" with the console version at launch, but that could improve with free future updates. There don't seem to be any plans for mod support at launch, but we do know that the game should run on some fairly old graphics cards. Check out the Monster Hunter: World system requirements to see how your machine measures up.Monster Hunter: World is due on PC via Steam on August 9, 2018.

author: EiN
review: Pros:+Huge variety of weapons to accomodate each hunter's playstyle+Addition of mantles to further help you in your hunt+New Move sets+Complete overhaul of the game itself (Removal of Loading screens, easier item customization, etc...)+Bounty quest to help you with farming+Addtional upcoming monsters ( Free DLCs)Neutral:= Thank god they removed the frenzy virus= Thank god they didn't plan on bringing back the water system= The heckin Seregios got turned into a mad red dog!= Where's my Zinogre?!= Where's my Tigrex?!= Brachy-DIO is gone : (= Lagiacrus should've been in this game!= Get your ass out there and start farming for Kulve Taroth and Behemoth!Cons:-Port is a bit unstable ( I recommended turning off Volumetric Rendering )-Desire Sensor ( It's always been there, and has not changed much since 2nd gen )-Removal of the hunting arts ( Refer to MH: G/MH: GU )-Sound can be Desync sometimesComment:From the 2nd generation to the 5th. I've been a solid fan of the MH series ever since I discovered it in the PsP and I've owned the game in PS4 and comparing it to the pc there are quite some issues with the port. I'm running an i5-8400 and a GTX 1050 TI and Medium settings works great on me. Other than that the game's been rehauled to welcome beginners and advanced hunters alike, especially the removal of loading screens and the refined user interface compared from it's previous generation! Well good luck out there, HUNT or BE HUNTED!UPDATE: They've basically added a lot more monsters from before, and with the release of Tigrex, Narga, Brachy, and Dinovaldo, this basically confirms that all monsters shown within the 20th anniversary poster is coming to ICEBORNE, so pack your gears up it's definitely the greatest time to be the HUNTER or the HUNTED!

author: Psychoticfart™
review: I played the hell out of Monster Hunter world when it first came out on PS4, so aside from saying that the game is good, i just have to genuinely question the existence of Defender weapons and armor. It severely trivializes the early game, and makes some of the tier 1 - 3 weapons look useless in comparison to the defender weapons, and the defender/guardian armor makes fighting any monster a joke. Firstly, it's a high rank+ armor that is FULLY UPGRADED that can be used in low rank, and no monster can get through the physical armor. Not only that, but it has no elemental weakness, so there is genuinely no reason to switch off of it for, say, high metal armor which has great ice protection but is made incredibly weak to lightning, so you have to think whether it's a good idea to bring it to a tobi-kadachi hunt, who will be hitting you with lightning attacks almost exclusively. It trivializes even trying, as since it has no weakness, there's no reason to stop using it for, say, the rathalos set, a set that was the low-rank flex since it is arguably one of the best sets to farm for when you're around that level.

author: bl_5ca
review: Sad to see bad reviews due to performance issues or simply because people didn't get what they expected. I can only report my experience. I've enjoyed the game immensely. The game´s goal is simple. Killing monsters. But you have to learn how to do it. You´ll need to discover their weak points. Work with others at times to accomplish the goal. There are many MMO like features. Paths of progression. But above all, plenty of weapons that offer extremely different feels. Although the goal is to kill big beasts over and over again, they are all unique. And the game keeps on trowing new layers of things you can do such as exploring, researching, hunting and so on. This is not a game I would recommend to play alone. Hallf the fun is going out on missions with friends or calling out for help and getting some random people to assist you in killing that major beast. Above all the game successfully makes you feel like a real monster hunter. Some people will greatly enjoy it and some won´t. But that doesn't mean it´s a bad game. Just it isn't for everyone.

author: Rob
review: Pretty good game so far. Can be a bit overwhelming or confusing at first, but you will get the hang of it eventually. The only things bothering me so far:The ingame chat doesn't seem to really work. There is no popup if someone writes and you manually have to go into the menu and then scroll to the chat to open it up. The Bow as a weapon also feels underwhelming. You have like 2 attacks and a third special and thats it. The mouse is just emulating a controller stick, thats why it feels like it has some extreme smoothing.No decent anti aliasing implemented. FXAA is super blurry and so is TAA. If you happen to have performance issues: Disable Volumetric Lighting. Lower SH Diffuse to low. Put Ambient Occlusion to medium.Lower LOD to medium. These 4 settings enabled me to run the game with a somewhat solid 60fps on my system:I5 2500k 4.2Ghz8GB DDR3-1600GTX 980If your CPU is even worse than that, disable Flora Sway. I will eventually expand this review once i play some more.

author: Nikanoru
review: I couldn't possibly recommend this enough.  People who've played Rise are coming back to play this game again.  I'm still going to play the heck out of Rise, but for the sheer amount of content World & Iceborne have it is more than worth the money I spent on it and more.I've fought so many of the same monsters easily dozens (if not hundreds) of times.  Tracked and fought them in so many different variations.  Without help.  With help.  Easy missions with zero interruption.  Nail bitingly difficult missions with curveball after curveball.  Random invasions from extremely aggressive monsters.  A boss fight so hard a lot of people may never see them outside of a youtube videos (this is actually a compliment considering how far you can stretch this game and the range of difficulty).I've played it for 378 hours and would very happily play it another 378 hours.  And when I'm done with this and Rise and Monster Hunter Stories 2, I'll eagerly await the next in the series.

author: Verb_๊
review: I don't really know how to feel about this game yet, there are alot of good and bad things about this game but for now I'm going to side with a recommend.The BAD:Very grindy, you will be spending alot of time gathering materials and killing mobs. The story is the generic "newbie will save the World" plot. Nothing new to see here.Voice acting is also in the typical bad video game style that usually plagues these type of games.High learning curve with unclear tutorials.Cutscenes not skippable (as far as I know, feel free to correct me if I'm wrong).Chat system is just plain dumb and borderline unusable.Connectivity issues.IN BETWEEN:Boss fights can feel a bit linearToo many optional questsBattle fluidityThe GOOD:A huge amount of customization for buildsA nice variety of weapons with different play stylesEnvironments can be used against BossesDifferent ways of taking down BossesSolo play is very challengingFighting, fighting & fightingConclusion: This game shines where it needs to and falls flat in everything else. Hunting Bosses and customizing your character into some Godly Hunter is all that really matters in a game like this and thankfully it mostly got it right. As you see above I wrote "battle fluidity" in "IN BETWEEN" and that is because the mechanics at times, can feel a bit stiff and slow. I would prefer something like Vindictus' play style which is much more fluid BUT it is still good.Not going to mention graphical stuff since all the down voters have already mentioned all that.

author: LeeIzaZombie
review: Despite the minor problems (that people are making a huge deal about) would I recommend this over the console version?YESWith modern hardware;i7 8700k (no overclock)GTX 108016 GB ramInstalled on a standard SSDI'm having a buttery smooth experience.* Exceeds console framerate of 30 - 45 fps by having 105 - 120 fps* 2 second load screens, on console it took minutes.* Play online for free, no need for BS online subscription like consoles.* Easier to socialize and find friends on PC.* The game itself is amazing, I loved the series since forever.* Day one bugs (hence the bad reviews) which will likely be fixed.    - Multiplayer often kicks you out (probably due to the mass amount of players)    - Some people get graphic errors (not me at least)* No ultrawide support, this is a big downer for me but it won't stop me from recommending!* Oh noes... You can't get 144 fps ultra 4k... Awell... Should've known the hardware these days can't manage 4k on most games unless low settings beforehand.Overall I'm hoping for some bug fixes and a community patch for ultrawide, maybe some mods too. However this is a much better experience than on console due to instant loading and smooth fps. Screw those people crying about not having more than 69 fps should've saved money and kept your eyes used to 60hz

author: The Burger King
review: Back in 2007, I wanted to go visit my friend Fale who lived in Hawaii. I had already done The Big Heat which was what my friend group referred to as our cross-country road trip from New Hampshire all the way down to California, where we finally stopped off at San Francisco. Most people drove back home but I stayed with the intention of renting a sailboat to travel across the Pacific ocean to the famed island state. After a few days out at sea, I woke up to find a peculiar little green character rummaging through my ♥♥♥♥. Instinctively, I spat rancid hot stomach bile by the liter at him - missing by just an inch. I dove for him but as he was quite the intuitive little fellow, I missed and flew right into my prized "Nostalgia Critic grimace" collection, shattering both the collection and my pants, once again. The green fellow was now on the helm, steering us away from the Sandwich Islands - unaware of my presence. I grabbed him by the legs and gave him a stern telling off before slapping him with the might of God himself and launching him back to shore. I eventually did make it to Hawaii, had a great holiday. Flew back with Delta, got home and saw a huge, pulsating green mass outside my house, chanting my name. "Colin. Colin. COLIN" it started to move towards me, as I pulled the AVGN grimace and Doug Walker scream. I dove for the ♥♥♥♥ just like his son... He popped like a couple of balloons in any training level from a quirky FPS in the 2000s. I sat on my doorstep and began to listen to Death Grips, balling my eyes out that I would never be able to demonstrate the stomach bile attack ever again. I also pissed myself.

author: Skysong
review: Where else can you have a poisonous parrot, pink vulture t-rex, and electric flying squirrel fighting each other and suddenly ganging up on you just because they don’t like your ugly mug? I have a love/hate relationship with this game now. On the one hand, the world is beautifully crafted and it’s really fun to wander around the world, finding new locations, things, or paths in the area you’ve been playing in for days now. Hunting down monsters is really fun. You follow the tracks, and suddenly you see them just around the corner, in all their majesty and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ massive size. Battles are hard, but after you’ve worn the monsters down, you track them, injured and limping as they are, as they drag themselves to their hideout for a rest, or to eat something to heal. There’s a lot of different weapons and play styles to choose from. Bored of your standard sword and shield? Try two swords! Too low on damage? Try a big-ass sword and axe. You’re dying because you’re always to close to the monsters? Try a ranged weapon! I’ve already switched weapons a couple of times to find a style that more suits what I like to do. On the other hand, I hate this game because I’m not good at it, and I end up dying more often than I would like to admit. Still, perseverance pays off in the end, when you kill/capture the baddie that’s been slamming you down on your ass for the last couple of hours. Alternatively, open up your quest for multiplayer and hope for the best. I don’t like the semi-instanced nature of the quests, but there’s an option for free play if you would like to just roam around or stock up on supplies. Definitely a 10/10 from me. Please excuse me as I go back to face the same foe I’ve been fighting the last couple of days. I have a really good feeling about this try!

author: jUSTapLAYER ( ͡° ᴥ ͡°)͜
review: I love this game reminds me alot of the first Monster Hunter Game I played on PS2.What I love most is how easy it is to pick up and go out on adventures with friends,no need to facilitate a party with long travel distances like generic mmorpgs, and thecombat system is pretty fun. I don't usually write reveiws about games but this is the perfect game for someone who plays casually. Its the type of game that respects youmight have a life outside of playing it! It also doesn't bloat its playtime by adding superficialcontent just to give people a sense of "progressing".All in all if you are just tired of the boring grind and progress mechanics generic mmorpgspossess and want to have fun without wasting ALL your time, I'd definitely would give MHW a try.

author: Highwayman
review: Hi, my name is Dandy...And I am an addict.I went from unsure to addict in 2 hours.First things first, the button mappings are awful, no widescreen support.The awful button mappings and the 'odd' combat had me sitting there wondering if i'd wasted £40. So I decided to sleep on it and try again the next day.Remapped aim to right click, and put the other attack buttons on my gaming mouse, and rearranged some of the keyboard keys.. and now I AM HOOKED.They should rename this entomology world.. Because i'm catching every insect in sight, fishing, throwing nets over bats and squirrely things.. Sniffing every damp footprint I can find, and feverishly trying to upgrade my Palico's armour because that little fluffball is adorable AF.Last night the bow was awful and the hammer was unusable.. Tonight I am a bowmaster and I've been smashing skulls with a massive bone hammer.The 'odd' combat was because I'd been treating it like every other game, dodging mid swing, trying to instantly block attacks etc. No, this game needs to be played with a touch of realism.. You can't dodge when you're midway through swining a hammer.. Because PHYSICS. So once you learn to time your attacks, move with the flow of the battle and stop button-bashing, it comes alive.This game takes time guys.. Give it time, and you might just fall in love too.

author: Gadzooks
review: Denuvo will make your CPU max out and heat upThe poorly optimized port will make your GPU max out.You will be lucky to keep a steady 60 fps. There WILL be dropsKeyboard/mouse controls are complete trash.... for example. Hold Q to open Radial menu, then use the freaking arrow keys to only be able to select 4 of the possible 8 options (since there are no diagonal arrow keys).Its a good game as far as graphics and gameplay go, but the port from console to PC, and the addition of anti-pirate software is like smearing a 3 week old dirty diaper onto a 100 dollar prime cut of steak.Ill give it a thumbs up IF and when they remove denovu, and improve some of the shoddy port aspects.

author: Taki
review: I have been playing monster hunter since the very beginning. I also previously got this on console when it came out. While it is sometimes frustrating to not be able to play with friends consistantly the game is still very well put together and very enjoyable to play again. While I do hope that they get the multiplayer fixed soon it still is easy enough to play solo.Pros:- fluid controls- short loading screens- in depth customization- beautiful level design- very rewarding gameplay- most important of all Palico'sCons- multiplayer connectivity spotty- optimization could be better- possibility of breaking a computer because of some fights.-squads were removed from this version.Now would I recommend this? The answer is yes, however, if you are wanting to play this game with friends constantly I'd say to wait till multiplayer is fixed first.Update: The capcom team is working to fix the connection issues. This is still following the same trend as far as how long it took to iron out the connection on console so it is not a big deal. They are listening to feedback and doing something about it.Update 11/21/2018The games multiplayer conectivity has been resolved and is still a great game to play.

author: Xirog
review: Endless, quality content. When you finally think "ok, this is fun, i get a grip of this game now" you realize you're already 20 hours in and it feels like the game just started - and it's true! 60 hours in, you think you beat the game aaaaaand... you're just halfway through.And then when you actually beat the game, an enormous amount of content opens its doors for you and you get to witness the sometimes frustrating yet always super rewarding endgame content! -with fun and interesting collaborations with other games.I almost refunded this because i thought it was just way too clunky and repetitive, but the variety of monsters and the 14 different weapons, all with unique and interesting movesets, managed to make me stick to it, and here i am now, wishing i had gotten into this series waaay earlier. Mind you, there will be some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and frustrating moments, some of which will be due to connection issues, but overall, amazing game! 9/10

author: ICanBeTheHeroDood?
review: If you intend to play this game primarily multiplayer (as in, you want to play the storyline missions with a partner), don't bother. Trying to join either person's game results in an error that they haven't completed the mission yet (so helpful). Actually doing it requires a goofy workaround that honestly seems more like a bug than an intentional method to enable multiplayer.Apparently once you're done all the storyline missions, multiplayer is fine. But I bought two copies of this to play with my wife, and we assumed the fact that multiplayer wasn't working for us in story missions was because we weren't done w/ the tutorial section yet, not that it was designed that way on purpose. By the time we realized multiplayer didn't actually work right we'd already gone an hour past the refund period. Don't make our mistake.
