author: Apothecaryᴿˣ
review: Seeing as this game was nominated for Game of the Year and won Best RPG, and after 300 hours of playtime, I figured it was time to give it a long overdue review.For the tl;dr people: yeah, the game is good, but it's not for everyone. Just like anything else.Is the game fun?Yeah. Sometimes. The first, maybe, 30 hours is the real experience; immersive, beautiful, fun, and it's evoked a feeling in me about games I haven't felt since MGSV. With each new area and each new monster, you really feel like you're exploring and learning about the new world. It wasn't until hour 100, where I felt like the game was a chore. To sum up endgame, it's deco grinding, build optimizing, pet hunting, and fashion hunter. Although, through long sessions of grinding I get bored at times, I've yet to be burnt out on the game, so take away that this game may click with some people and won't for others. However, I will say that each new content update keeps me coming back and I play regularly (with friends and solo) so that should speak to its replayability. Combat feels fleshed out, mechanics are balanced (so long as you care to learn them), and there's great music to pair with every setting. Won't go into detail about gameplay since you'll get more mileage for that out of watching actual gameplay than me sitting here, explaining it to you.Anything bad?Main talking points for this question are lack of content, bugs, and Denuvo. Now, personally, I never minded the initial lack of content in comparison to the console port (even though PC took 9 months longer), as I really sympathize with the developers (even though it's Capcom). However, Capcom has really pulled through these last few months and has given us many pleasant surprises with this December packing some of the most anticipated content updates (*cough cough* Behemoth *cough cough*), and seemingly by March of next year, we'll be fully caught up to the console port (with hints to newer content on the way; game awards, they said they had something big planned ^.^). So, in its current build, this game is absolutely worth it to pick up in terms of content, especially since Christmas is around the corner. Nothing bad to note here, and I can only say that for all the people who screamed at Capcom to push out more content like it was their first born child, I hope you're happy.Now, the game has had its faults with poor optimization, graphical errors, save file deletions, and the notorious connection drops, all of which, I've been a victim of except save data loss (I backup my saves). Sure, in the first 3 seconds that I experience these bugs I get pretty upset, but the game's just too damn great to stop playing over these inconveniences and as of late, they've mostly hashed out all the problems (at least in my case; there's still some connection drop issues from time to time, but I can attribute that to bad internet most of the time). They optimized the control scheme, such as the ranged weapon controls for keyboard and mouse, which I'm very grateful for. Hell, they even plan on adding Ultra Wide support for the game for the people who asked for it, so they're actually listening to their playerbase and addressing issues one step at a time.And lastly, Denuvo. Not much I can argue for in favor of MHW here. Denuvo is straight trash, and even to this day, it comes up as reason to give this game a bad review (I can see why, but at the same time I don't). Capcom has removed Denuvo from games before, but not anything recent to my knowledge, so even though MHW has recently been cracked, I don't see it going away anytime soon. However, this still doesn't deter me from playing it. Yeah, it would play better without Denuvo, but the benefits and my enjoyment far outweigh the cost of Denuvo so I couldn't care less.Returning MonHun fan?Personally, I haven't played much of the previous iterations of MonHun except a very short stint with Generations, so take this with a grain of salt. The game is different. Some things are good like no more loading times when traveling from section to section in maps during a hunt, but then there are other things that people will argue as either hand-holding or good game design. These things are like the fact that you can fast travel back to camp instead of running all the way back, or the fact that you can sometimes spawn away from camp in high rank instead of always. In some ways, yes the game does hold your hand a lot, but at the same time, it also makes the game more fluid in terms of its gameplay so take that for what you will. Other changes could be in features and meta; there's no more charm tables and instead it's deco farming, GS meta is TCS now and it works differently, new LS mechanics, etc. But, all I can say is, don't be a meta slave and don't be a baby. The game is balanced enough to where pretty much anything is viable (I main capture net). But, if you can't get over these changes because you're too attached to the old MonHun, then I'm very sorry for you, but this probably isn't your game so do the research before buying.Happy hunting!

author: Big Bird
review: POSITIVES:> Good Atmosphere (the environment, the ambient sounds, the BGM, the flora and fauna, it feels alive and authentic)> Variety (you can play this game for hours, days, or even months, and not run out of things to do, and every hunt is unique from the rest)NEGATIVES:>It has a high learning curve for new players, albeit not like Dark Souls, and the combay might feel clunky for some.>Graphics (For a PC port, it does look good when seen in a huge picture, but close up, you can see the textures are very  washed up. And with the fact that the performance isn't stellar even in high end systems can say a lot about the game.)>Multiplayer (it's like a gamble everytime you play Multiplayer, for there's a chance that you get disconnected from the host player, or the host player gets disconnected and everybody is instantly disconnected from each other, leaving you with a monster with a difficulty the same as if it were fought by four people. Not really much of an issue but it is rather a nuisance.)Overall it's still a great game, even if you don't touch the Multiplayer side of things - you could get lost in the variety of weapons and armor that you can forge and use and study what situations they are best used in, or you could get lost in the beauty and life of the environment around you, and see each monster's interaction with the world, or you could get lost in the huge number of monsters you could hunt and all the ways you could hunt them in this game.Despite the multiplayer issues, it's still worth the buy.TL;DR Rating:Graphics: 2.5/5Gameplay: 5/5Sounds: 4/5Replayability: 5/5Controls: 3.5/5

author: demonicpandemic
review: Legend sez, the first monster hunter is the core inspirations for the soul series.Alrite im done with the clickbait. But srsly, above phrase does held meaning in MHW. Yes, the game is not filled with gore, dark & gloomy atmoshphere. Yes, there is no hardcore levelling mechanic such souls series. BUT! you are gravely mistaken if you think this is a no-brainer hack n slash game. Going gung ho guns blazing will get you carted (ded) in no time.Every monster have unique traits & moveset. Every weapon is unique. changing weapon means a new mechanic and new experience (vary learning curve). Always plan before battle. Prepare your weapon, EQ, consumable items. Better yet, be familliar with the map. Every ledge and and wedge beetle can be usefull in battle. And the most importantly , in this game you can always Jolly Co-op on every quest ( praise it \[T]/ )You've finished the story? well gud. you just finished the tutorials. The real game starts on HR50. Time to up the git gud!  Sincerely ,Swagaxe hunter blast division9999/9999 ONE OF THE BEST GAME ON PC EVARRR

author: Derakel
review: Alright, so here's my personal opinion on the game.===Pros===+ Nice Character Creation+ Unique setting+ Good Story+ Interesting Combat Mechanics+ Decent Music+ Alot of different fighting styles+ Decent Graphics+ Nice Animations+ HUD isn't annoying and actually pretty good+ Plenty Immersive+ Enemy Types are interesting===Cons===- The Game babies you with Tutorials (sucks if you're already a "Gamer")- Not enough voice dialogue (atleast in English)- Fighting can be clunky at times- Constant Chase (you can fight in more than 3 areas)- Too many Plants on the way to areas. Just make them Clusters or something.- Multiplayer was not explained properly.===Things to avoid when starting===' Button Mashing' Reloading while being looked at by the Hunted' TOADS, STAY AWAY FROM THEM' Hitting friends with long Weapons (XD)===Problems I've seen so far===* Most Players seem to complain about increased CPU Usage which can make it unplayable. I have seen it spike from 40% to 90% a couple of times in my playthrough.* Reloading Bug, you just sit there and reload your Gun over and over again until something hits you.* CTD. Now I haven't gotten this yet but some people I know have. It doesn't seem to be frequent.* Multiplayer random disconnects.===Final Verdict===The Game is fun, it brings an interesting amount of mechanics to play around with during fights. Although it has problems, the gameplay outways those problems and I'm sure they will come out with Patches to fix many of these problems and add more features.I haven't played enough for it to get repetitive yet, so that's a good sign so far. I would also recommend that you actually take a look at your hud before freaking out and trying to figure out your Keys to heal, switch ammo, etc. Pretty much everything is infront of you.Lastly, I would highly recommend that you buy this game on Sale (from trusted sources) in it's current State, hope you enjoyed my review!

author: bearsboi
review: I was reluctant to play monster hunter world when it first came out because I was so attached to traditional monster hunter games, but I really regret that now because this game is SO FUN. yes it's grindy, but I like to divide that term into two groups: fun grindy, and tedious grindy. this is fun grindy. there are so many cool maps with next level verticality, leaving you with all kinds of exploration opportunities and ways to use the environment against the monster you're hunting. but, it can also be used against you. not only do you need to build an understanding of the huge variety of monsters, but the maps as well. the weapons are all very fun too, with some being more fun than others. the bowgun for example is kind of cheesy because it consists of shooting, rolling out of the way, shooting, etc. but the melee weapons have so many incredible combos that you can pull off, and they all have their own unique gimmicks. on the surface monster hunter world is actually pretty simple and they've made it so that it's easy for monster hunter beginners to get a hold of, but under that surface there's a ton of depth that will take time and skill to master

author: hold my beer
review: I am a very big fan of the Monster Hunter franchise and  to begin with. I was very happy when they announced a PC version for Monster Hunter World and i have not been disappointed at all. I think to everyone who is used to the old MH graphics this game is a real eye-catcher. There is so much detail in everything, the monsters are so well designed and it just looks in harmony. The soundtrack is speaking for itself- i get goosebumps every time i hear the main theme and most of the monster themes are very fitting for the monster.I can‘t really describe the gameplay so make sure to check out some gameplay videos to get a taste of what you are actually doing in this game and what it looks like!The fact that i am already well-experienced with the games of course helped a lot when fighting most monsters but i guess the game is very friendly to players that are new to the game as well. In MHFU you didn´t get healed by your cat all the time or had special cloaks or boosters that make the game so much easier overall. Hitboxes back then were way worse. And in MHW i have been wondering a lot already how something that would´ve knocked the crap out of me didn´t hit me at all. The controls with M+K are a bit strange at first but i got used to it very fast. If you prefer to play with controller you can do that as well. And trust me- the controls in MH: World are way less clunky than in the previous parts.I don´t know why people are complaining about the graphics and the performance. It says in the recommended specs that you will only get 30 fps on high settings if you have the listed hardware. If your PC cant handle the game don´t blame the game for it.  because as soon as the lobby leader leaves the lobby will be disbanded. This will at least lower the chances of being kicked out of the online system that is probably overloaded right now. to anyone who played , liked and loved the older games. To anyone who is new to the franchise be warned: it can be a tough and tilting experience at first and it will be likely that you don´t succeed with every quest from the beginning on. Although you get spammed with help you  but it is definetly worth a try for everyone who likes challenges and needs something different than the usual games he plays.

author: Tyson Bits
review: Been playing MH since MH2 on PsP.  It took me a solid day of gametime to get used to gathering while running and stuff auto combining. At first i didnt like the practice of being able to access all your stuff when your on quests (swapping gear, refill items) but being able to do that is pretty damn useful, especially when your bag is full from gathering and you can easily empty it without leaving a quest for expiedition. Also, fireflies are pretty cool, but i never minded having to keep a monster paintballed. (fast traveling between camps is EXTREMELY useful.) Theres a ♥♥♥♥ ton of quality of life changes, like being able to walk/jog while healing, or being able to roll and stop the healing animation, and a few named in the post above. (gunner specific pouch for gunner ammo so it doesnt take up 2/3 of your bag space for ammo and crafting mats.) I love how monsters dont feel as easily predictable as in previous games, as well as all the little interactive things in the zones. (heal plants, smackable flashbombs poison plants ect.) im loving basically everything about this game. Other than one thing that is EXTREMELY annoying.. having to do the story questline multiple times because you cant join a friends quest if you havent already finished it, in previous MH's i believe you could go on quests, and you were just forced to watch the cut scenes with the quest poster. this is my only thinkable annoyance to the game, (its pretty annoying..some people might not find it that bad but to me its damn annoying.)If youve played MH before and enjoyed it, this game is a must.

Do not expect much from a story here, the whole game is about hitting punching bags, the only thing that changes is their appearence. Also game likes to restrict the controls (monster roars and stuns) even though you haven't messed up, so generally speaking, monster could oneshot you without failing from your side, which is annoying. But summing up the whole expirience it is pretty fun, especially if you have someone to play with

author: [LoG] Fr3zZ0r ♥
review: Man, I was so hyped for this game, the first Monster Hunter on PC i'd be able to play with friends. But of the 100+ hours on my account I probably enjoyed only a third, maybe less. I was let down by the difficulties to even get in a lobby with only friends and joining them on the main quests. Network Issues and Framedrops just got unbearable, especially after Patch 1.1, where I had at least one 10 second freeze every other hunt. The bad hitboxes and iframes get even worse when there is any kind of visual effect on screen and the fps drop down to about 5-10. Theres problems with textures not loading properly. The monster AI seems bugged, instead of fighting each other, they stand and look for you even before spotting you in the first place, 3 minutes straight. Some features were probably meant good, but are either buggy or straight up annoying after 50+ hours of it, EVERY HUNT (I'm looking at a certain bombing bagel). Weekly Quests reset (not the weekly reset) for no good reason, some items dont seem to work as intended, quests disappear Theres so much more little things I dislike about World, but they could be overlooked by just how fun the concept of Monster Hunter can be. But I caught myself not having fun way too often, wondering why I even play this game. Most of it boils down to massive performance and network issues that could be easily fixed, as they were no problem on console. But until then I think I'm through.

author: stubs4limbs
review: Monster Hunter: World is a game that rewards precision.- Taking the time to gather tracks and research monsters grants knowledge of their strengths, weaknesses, and vulnerabilities, making your hunter that much more deadly, and the monsters' health pool that much more insignificant. - Taking the time to master a weapon's intricacies grants outstanding combos and impressive finishers, making each swing of your weapon a dazzling display of finesse and relentless damage output.- Taking the time to learn a monster's moveset enables a nonstop offensive via utilization of precise i-frames embedded in your dodge-rolls. Monster attacks? You time your dodge and leave that monster empty handed.Master these core gameplay mechanics and you'll be turning even the biggest and baddest of turbo lizards into a hat so posh you won't even care what kind of garbage armor skills it has.In all seriousness, I've already put 500 hours into the console version of this game, here's to another 500 on PC. This game is as fun as it gets; highly recommended to anyone looking for something they can play casual with friends, or someone looking for a long but tasteful and rewarding grind.See you in the New World, Hunters!

author: TheUndeadCapt
review: Definitely a worthwhile purchase. this was my first game in the series and I had a blast playing it and still am. Whether you play solo, with friends or with randoms you'll have a fun experience. There's the meta ways to build your class for being absolutely optimal but there is also plenty of off-meta ways to build that work as well.      If you get bored of hunting monsters you can instead hunt rare endemic life to collect and show off to others in your room which other players can now visit. There's also treasure hunting if that is your fancy; though, the way to obtain the tips about the treasure is a little lack luster.

Probably because many people who ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ love this game are playing and not wasting their time on forum. A lot of people play this game at the same time (almost 300k) and many people encounter some problems. I personally have ecountered like 3; the game doesn't run on 1920x1080 (little black strapes on left and right), sometimes strange errors pop up when I alt-tab my game and the last thing - some textures are pretty low resolution (probably gonna get fixed sooner or later.Stable framerate, plays really good on mouse and keyboard, many translantions, free DLCs, heaven-like soundtrack, BEAUTIFUL graphics and the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ godlike amazing gameplay. I'm not a die-hard Monster Hunter fan, but it really feels great to play it on PC instead of your little 3DS. Some people say it's too hard, yeah it's Monster Hunter, not a game directed for casuals but still it's the easiest Monster Hunter ever so many new people in the series shouldn't get lost (but gonna struggle a lot though). Easily one of the best game (if not the best one) of the recent years.

author: Wowowood
review: To put it simply, if you want quick and easy satisfaction this game is not for you, each mission can take a really long time and each target monster has a ton of help, the time limits for objectives is usually around 50 minutes for a reason. However, the feeling of finally taking down a monster and gaining all of the useful materials it has is easily one of the most gratifying things I've ever done in a game

author: Tokfan
review: Finally a proper game!If you do not pay attention you will get smacked around like a rag.The combat is really good and if you take your time and actually watch the monsters attack patterns things become much much easier, and if you got problems with a specific one it's probably time to check your gear and/or consumables.If everything else fails; make them fight each other and pick them off afterwards.So it's only really difficult if you;a) don't pay attentionb) go in and spam attacksc) use the wrong tool for the job -speaking about elemental damage here, not your weapon of choice (ofc some weapons will struggle with some bosses while they just murder other).So is it easy then? heck no. That's why its finally a good game on Steam.This only holds your hand for the first hour or so, and by holding your hand I mean pointing you in the right directions. It doesn't put you in a wheel chair and sprint past the challenges while you can drool and recieve achievements.When it comes to the online bit, well some things you might want to get help on i.e. Nergigante, Pink Rathian, Diablos to name a few.... BUT the monster scales up so if you get someone clueless well, that's it. Shared lives so while you might be prepared nothing is guaranteeing the ones joining are. Or it might be someone who can kill it within a second, real roulette here.The multiplayer stability is just fine as long as you do not alt+tab out of the game for too long or using wi-fi connection. So if you got a friend who'd like this game aswell I'd say go for it.There's two downsides though;The price, while I'd say it's worth the price it might be a bit too steep so maybe wait for a sale. Also when you think you've beaten the game, well that's just halfway through the game and then there's plenty of times where you go "wait there's ANOTHER end boss for me to get horrible murdered on a dozen of times?!?!"And then things start to scale with you -never giving you an upper hand.

author: Watsu
review: I have around 500h (and the platinum trophy) in the PS4 version and the regular reviews talking how good this game is and how it's an amazing entry point for newcomers, so I'll focus on the PS4-to-PC experience:+ Most console ports are a bit lazy when they introduce mouse+keyboard inputs and MHW is NOT in that category. Menus can be navigated with your mouse and you can click everything, it's fantastic. There's also a new mmo-like item toolbar that helps mkb players even more.+ Even though my PC is under the minimum system requirements, I still decided to give it a shot. It actually runs pretty well, 30fps with a few stutters when there's too many particle effects on the screen, so I can't complain about the performance. + The new load times are fantastic. I spent hours watching the game load on the PS4 and now I can barely read the tips on the screen, I can get into quests in less than five seconds.+/- The online system is the same as the PS4, so if you don't know the workarounds to play story quests (enter quest, watch cutscenes then tell your friends to join), you'll suffer a bit. Occasional disconnects happen when Steam hiccups, though. Not great, but so far it has happened to me only once. The upside is that it's easier than ever to join your friend's sessions and guilds are now Steam Groups, so joining other people is easier than ever. On PS4 I had to message my friends and make sure everyone is in the same page before playing, on PC I can just hop on a lobby and do some quests with people on my friend's list.I still strongly recommend the game. Despite the online interface and some menus being still a bit below the industry standard for online play, this is still a fantastic game with hundreds of hours of content. Happy hunting!

author: addtolibrary
review: So, with a little persistence I was finally able to start learning all the obscure systems of the Monster Hunter universe.  I had tried 3 on the Wii U, and 4U on the 3ds, but they just didn't click.  Monster Hunter World completely drew me in, however, and has me hopelessly addicted.  Now all I can think about is chasing down giant beasties to loot them, to make better armor for bigger beasties.  I enjoy this game so much that I got Monster Hunter Generations Ultimate for the Switch, so I can Monster Hunt while I'm not Monster Hunting.  It's really a great game, and works really, really well with the Steam controller.  A must have for fans of ARPG's, or Souls-like games.Edit:  Or fans of WoW raids.  I think it perfectly scratches that itch.  Gathering mats for upgrades and pots, and great big co-op boss fights.Edit Edit:  I can't stop

author: Sammy the Wizard
review: Monster Hunter World i the first Monster Hunter game I have played. it is very fun. there are lots of cool monsters to fight. once you fight them you build new weapons and armours out of thier bodies. The fights can take time, but are not boring. there is lots to do in adition to fighting such as capturing pets to decorate your room, exploring and fishing. author: Santa
review: This game is one of the best games I've played.  Ever.Beautiful world, beautiful monsters (dinosaurs? and dragons!).  Very immersive.   Incredibly challenging and incredibly rewarding.  Addicting and amazing.  I'm running out of adjectives.Takes a bit to get a hang of the controls.  I'd suggest to dedicate yourself to one weapon style starting out and branch out from there.  Takes decent hand-eye coordination and hones your reaction time. You make armor and weapons, and you upgrade armor and weapons.  You get your arse kicked a lot, which can be fun because you learn from your mistakes and try again, or you say "Screw this monster, I never want to fight it again for the rest of my life"... and then you try again.  Online community is very large so you'll never be without someone to play with.Get this game.  Play it.  Lose yourself in it like I did.  Can't say much more because the game speaks for itself.

author: Mikelangelo
review: Initial impression: I'm hooked.  It has enough grind to make it fun.----After many hours: This was my 2020 game of the year.  I still load it up from time to time, and there's still 2 monsters I haven't beat (I might need better teammates than randoms).  It has enough grind to keep me playing, but not too much.   Every match is a boss fight, the feeling of satisfaction of taking down a monster after a long hunt (up to 50 minutes) is really great.  The weapons are all precise and have a learning curve.  I just picked up lance (my all time favorite) after 2h blades, after hammer, after greatsword.  I could pick up a new one of the 16 and keep the game fresh.  I got a buddy to get it, but he thought it was too rpg-y. It has less rpg-y-ness than even Borderlands really I told him, also the loot is carves from the monsters you craft to make new gear.  The community is pretty good.  Most people are quiet, and the social media people seem helpful.  I am comparing this to say Evolve, another monster like game where I found the online community toxic.  I have had maybe 1 or 2 bad experiences with other players the whole time, the last being someone who got mad the lance charges flinced him (you can get items to stop flinches) and complained I didn't do enough damage the round (my doorbell rang, and the loser had to download a mod to see everyone's damage percentage it's not native).  Overall, I really got my money's worth.

author: Lesrid
review: This is a pretty great port that got even better with a recent patch that made mouse/keyboard controls much more bearable. A couple graphics settings have been broken since launch but there are some workarounds and a recent patch fixed texture size options.

author: Lord Chicken
review: This is the Monster Hunter I've been waiting for since Freedom Unite. This game is everything I've always wanted and more. It's got a bad rap for being "poorly optimized" and there being problems on release, but people are just being overdramatic. At this time as of writing the review, there are plenty of options to solve what issues people do have. Such as driver rollbacks and port forwarding. And these are proven to work now. Capcom wanted to deliver the best PC experience they could with limited experience in PC, I think they did very admirably. And it's only going to improve.|So buckled up kids, quit complaining about it and play a wonderful game.For those looking to know what this game is about!This is a game about being a puny human fighting large monsters that could crush your bones to dust with nary an effort. It rewards patience, punishes rushed strategies, and tells a fairly interesting story. It's not for the faint of heart, but don't let that dissuade you.

author: Konnichi-wassup
review: Where Monster Hunter: World improved on the old and traditional monster hunting formula by simplifying aspects of gameplay, exploration and crafting it also created many more flawed game design conflicts.When an MH game start to hold your hands through the beginning levels and making tutorials that are unnecessarily long, you know that the newest instalment in a long-running franchise is catered to casuals. However, I actually like it as it serves as a good entry point to the franchise and is quite accessible to many players. Adding fuel to the fire, the story is also really stupid,boring pointless and extremely forgettable with unskippable cutscenes it is absolutely ridiculous.Further frustration, however, comes from the game itself with the server disconnecting every 10 minutes, confusing and non-sensical co-op / multiplayer with a questionable PC optimization.The game is designed to be played in co-op as upon selecting your save file, you are immediately given the options to join multiplayer, create a session or join a friend's session. Joining the session does not put you in a shared hub meaning you cannot see other players in the same session thus have any interactions, unlike previous MH games. To participate in a quest, one has to post a mission and others has to run to the nearest quest board to accept it rather than just having it appear on the screen as you are already in the same session. Even when all 4 players joined the quest but did not select ready, the quest starter will depart on the job by themselves and others has to then depart individually to the same session.Participation on main story missions requires everyone to first start the mission solo and play up to the point of encountering the boss and trigger the cutscenes associated with it. The players then need to quite the mission in order to join the story mission together. Otherwise, the game will tell you either that you have not progressed enough into the story to participate (When you clearly has) or the host has not finished the cutscenes and you cannot join. On top of this, the constant disconnects (or should I say random?) from the server will automatically kick you out of the multiplayer session and you either have to join again or play solo leaving an essential aspect of MH working smoothly only half of the time which ultimately ruins the fun of the game.Did I also mention that under full screen the game forces big picture mode which replaced the traditional steam overlay meaning you have to alt+tap out in order to talk with friends. Ridiculous.As far as co-op goes, the game is not fit for purpose and currently half broken. However, IGN and many other outlets seem to say otherwise.But hey, at least I can run the game smoothly...(Buy it with caution and Capcom fix your ♥♥♥♥♥!!!)

author: Keeks
review: Almost a year after its release MHW is still plagued by the negative reviews that came with its launch. If this is the main thing stopping you from getting the game, then don't hesitate to get it now as most of these issues have been fixed. The graphics are amazing, gameplay stays true to the Monster Hunter formula, and most importantly, the online multiplayer has been stable for the most part. The game isn't perfect, but the constant work that has been put in after its release makes it better than the "mixed" review it has suggests.

author: nonsense
review: [UPDATE]Hello fellas,I found a solution, that works for me and for some other gamers, in the steam forums (link:  )Long story short: I turned off the overclocking, (ram, cpu and graphic card). I just used the on board overclocking settings.I hope this will help some of you guys and gals. But mind, this may not work for everyone.The negative review remains anyway. The game should have worked from its release. And it just works (for me) because the community figured out some possible solutions. The credit goes to the awesome community (Thank you guys and gals) and NOT to Capcom.Keep cool and have a nice day.[Old review]I enjoy playing this game and would like to play this game more, but it crashes way too much.The game freezes but you still hear the in-game-music or it just crahes to the desktop.System requirements are fullfilled, Windows 10N.If the console version works stable, buy the console version of MHW.Keep cool and have a nice day.

author: Chris!!
review: I really wish Steam would allow me to give this a "mixed" rating, but since that's not possible I'll have to give it a thumbs-up instead.Don't get me wrong, the game is fantastic, it takes some time to get the hang of the mechanics with all the controls thrown at you, the difficulty of the fights at times, and all the various resources you can collect and what exactly they're used for. Once you're past that phase, the game really opens up to you with all of it's splendor. It's got great combat with a wealth of weapons for you to use, beautiful scenary to immerse yourself into, and a pretty sweet and reasonable grind that allows you to take your time with the main story or rush it as you see fit. The game is easily playable both in solo and multiplayer mode, so however you prefer to play the game you don't have to worry about feeling like the game leaves you behind.Now all of these positives are all nice and dandy, so you might be wondering why I'd give this a "mixed" rating instead of a positive one instead? The reason is that, unfortunately, is that the game includes a spitroast cooking minigame, where in said minigame, a "well-done steak" is considered an overall better item than a "rare steak" when cooking raw meat over an open flame. This is absolute blasphemy, and it completely ruins the experience for me that I am forced to ruin good meat if I don't want to end up with, according to the game, a "worse" item. So basically, the game is worth picking up and will bring many great hours, but be wary what you're getting yourself into so you don't end up paying for the game and then get slapped across the face by a terrible design choice.

author: clonevacuum
review: It has improved with time and currently stands as a pretty darn full game!

author: Arteis
review: Grindwall with content in here somewhere. Overall fun MP experience with a lot of depth. Musch of the endgame is repetitive  but that is normal enough.

author: Throbbing Dad
review: Monster Hunter World is a game with 14 categories of weapons, and each plays vastly differently from the others (even weapons that look similar like Lance and Gunlance). Each weapon type has a well thought out moveset, having moves that excel in certain situations, and this is where a rift might be created between people who enjoy the game and people who dont. Souls-like games require you to learn the enemy and counter with technical prowess, but what sets them apart is that Monster Hunter relies a bit less on being able to react perfectly to enemies, and more on positioning yourself advantageously, preparing before battle with favourable weapons that suit the behaviour of the monster you're encountering and, due to the depth of the weapon movesets, learn how to use them proficiently (e.g: greatswords dont have the best mobility or dodges, but your shoulder tackle has hyper armor and minimal chip damage and can be used to counter monster attack when used properly). Because of all this, you need to ignore a lot of what you have learnt in souls like games and put effort into relearning the combat, because tactics youd use on a souls like wont work on Monster Hunter and vice-versa.TL;DR:The game will take time and effort to learn and master, but once you do, youll get some of the most satisfying combat moments you can have in a game

author: Rothschwerth
review: According to an old Chinese adage, a man should only kneel before the heavens and before his wife. As it turns out, many also bend their "chi-knees" before the Chinese Communist Party in order to show their indignation towards a 10 second dad joke. -----With numerous QoL improvements and a greatly reduced need for grinding (except for endgame content), this is the most accessible Monster Hunter to date. I personally much prefer MH's combat gameplay to other action game combat systems. The soundtrack includes some tracks good enough to be listened to even outside of the game, which is good considering you won't have the leisure to savour them during a fight. The graphics are not outstanding, but still far exceed most other ports of Japanese console games. Speaking of ports, after some initial issues concerning performance, save file corruption and graphical glitches, the game seems to be running quite well; I have played it on both AMD and Nvidia hardware without major problems.If the concept of Monster Hunter appeals to you even in the slightest, then you will have a good time with this game.

author: IvoryFalcon
review: The good: -the skill ceiling for every weapon is extremely high and extremely rewarding to learn. -The monster AI is mostly phenomenal, with the occasional flying for 5 minutes bs. -The gameplay loop is rewarding enough to sink thousands of hours in, and fun enough to just play through the campaign and fight every monster. If you can't beat a monster, practice and you'll get there. -the armor design is top notch for both male characters and female charactersThe bad: -though the skill ceiling is incredibly high, you can't learn the weapons purely by yourself: you pretty much NEED to watch youtube videos explaining how they work (i suggest Arekkz), otherwise you'll find yourself banging your head against the wall because your movement will feel clunky. -The fights don't change: the first time you fight a monster will be similar to the 20th time you fight a monster, so if you don't like that, this game may not be for you. -The endgame decoration grind. One of the mechanics in the game are decorations, which drop from high rank and master rank monsters. The RNG involved in this system is a huge turn off, but this is primarily an endgame thing so if you're new, don't stress over thisFinal thoughts: I obviously adore this game. The graphics are tight, the performance is good and the mechanics tie the fights in so tightly that once you get the rush of taking down the hard monsters, you'll never stop. It is grindy, but in my opinion the grind is, for the most part, fair: the journey is as rewarding as the destination.

author: wa
review: As someone who's never played any of the other Monster Hunter games, I was recommended this one as something friendlier to newcomers.Game itself is fine, and the new Iceborne expansion does bring new content (the Clutch Claw and the new regions being one), but much of it is recycled from the base game and does not add as much as expected for a $40 DLC. Find it to be the same old grind as the base game and it's the same formula just reused with a fresh coat of snow covering it all.Unlike many other users, I personally do not find performance to be an issue, and the game is overall noticeably prettier (Ryzen 3600 and a GTX 1080 so nothing overkill). If I could give this a "meh" rating, I would do just that.

author: Ravage
review: I am not usually a fan of grindy games. Once the storyline is done, so am I....usually. This game has held my attention though as you can see by the amount of hours I have played it (350+). Pros: Beautifully rendered. Interesting storyline. Dynamic combat. A plethora of weapons and customizable armor options for all your monster hunting needs. Also, Palicos!Cons: Mildly annoyed that a huge company like CAPCOM couldn't match the voices to the characters lip movements. I am sure it is keyed to it's native Japanese, and to be honest its just nitpicking on my part. It's very grindy after the initial story is complete. That's ok though, because the game is fun and they release regular content and event updates to keep you interested.

author: Jesus
review: This installment of the Monster Hunter series greatly improves on its graphical and mechanical hindrances from previous games and creates a product which is satisfying and enjoyable. Monster Hunter World is a great initiation for new players to the series, and ever since I experienced this game, I have been hooked on Monster Hunter's previous games and monsters. MHW's ability to reach a wider audience has garnered much success for Capcom, and I hope they continue to update their game to the degree they have already. I am excited for Iceborne and all that is to come following the expansion, which I hope can fill the same shoes this game has already. (or even possibly exceed it) World will take you into a genre which you may or may not have experienced before and will leave you wanting more and more. MHW is, quite simply, a stellar game. I highly recommend you make the purchase, and if you enjoy the base game, look into the Iceborne expansion as well for an extra challenge. Happy hunting!

(Not that I can even fight them yet) Im just barely into high rank and ive already sunk over 30 hours into this game, i think thats longer than the usual but I had to collect the full sets for all my favorite monsters! Anyway yeah the game is good and mostly fixed now, still getting some frame drops with a i7-700k and a GTX 1080 at 1080p which is kinda really bad, but ya know!

author: nasi cumi hitam madura pak kris
review: i owned the game on my main account. finished base game and also the expansion. here's my review:pros:game is really fun, even without the expansion you could experience a great monster hunting game. the game offers you to build your characters however you like, use weapons that you want you can freely change and alter your play style. hunt varies of monsters. cons:the game doesn't have autosave that many game does. there is a save option on the settings menu and you get the option to save your game once you want to close the game.

author: Kyou4Ryou
review: This review is written mainly based on my experience on console, I have a massive love for Monster Hunter and feel like World has tried to do new things, it has gotten some of the aspects right and others wrong.Graphics - The graphics within Monster Hunter World (referred to as MHW) are beautiful, unlike the previous titles MHW has really stepped the level of graphics up to show the true beauty the game holds, there is no bad side to this as the graphics in all previous titles were a little 'blocky', but that is due to system limitations.Controls - The controls are a lot more fluid when compared to any of the older games and makes it much easier for newcomers to get to grips with the game, there is obviously more experienced techniques for those that are already seasoned hunters, some of the commands though feel a little too easy which can break a bit of the immersion.Gameplay - This one is subject to debate, the gameplay within MHW has been highly simplified to reach a larger target audience, but at the same time that also leaves the seasoned hunters with a feeling of the game being too easy, take for example the whetstones and resource gathering, they no longer has uses but are an unlimited tool for you to use as much as you wish, also monster materials no longer take a space within your inventory but have their own seperate spot. The monster AI while at times it can seem a little dopy it does well to try and interact with the world around it bringing more life to the world.There's probably much more I could expand upon or add to this review but I'm not the best at writing them so I'll leave it at that. Overall I'd recommend this game for both new and returning hunters, but for those returning I'd advise not to expect the same kind of difficulty that the previous titles have offered.

author: Gargoyle Girl
review: This game is very fun, but it has a few issues that make it annoying. Overall though, I recommend it. It is grind heavy, but if you enjoy chasing around interesting environments and bashing or shooting monsters, this is for you.The game involves a lot of learning the patterns of the monsters you're fighting, using the environment to your advantage and generally becoming familiar with everything you encounter, from the zones themselves to the various enemies within it. There's a kind of pattern you need to get used to, even in town, in order to play this game effectively. It is very fun though, and I enjoy the world itself, it's lore and the of course the monsters.The annoying parts, to me, are the grouping options, which I feel could be streamlined a little. The learning curve, while not steep, has a lot of 'secret knowledge' things involved; concept and tactics you need to learn from other veteran players in order to really get better that the game itself doesn't really communicate well to you... or at all sometimes. And the story itself is forced; you can't go through it with friends in a simple fashion, as you need to watch cutscenes before you can get any help on story missions, and if a friend hasn't seen it either, they still can't help. It's a little *too* endgame focused, especially not that the Iceborne expansion is a thing.All in all it's a fun, interesting game to play, and I recommend giving it a try though.

author: Smiley Mann
review: Dunno who needs to hear this in 2022 but yeah, MHW is dope.  Just about the only thing I can complain about is that using a wireless controller and having it disconnect (idle/ dead battery/ etc) is pretty annoying because it's often mid-hunt and now I have to relaunch.I knew the MKB controls once upon a time but it didn't add all that much to the game for me and MH games have always been controller oriented for obvious reasons.  Other games seem to handle controller reconnection just fine but MHW seems to lack object permanence in this regard which is pretty forgivable since a game and not a sentient being.  However, it does seem  a little weird when you see this exact feature working in so many other games and MHW could almost be expected to be able to do this as well considering it first launched on console and came to PC months afterward.However, when you compare this shortcoming to something like a Bethesda game and interesting question arises from it... "What the ♥♥♥♥ does Bethesda even do?  Why do I still have to install modpack on modpack to fix bugs that have been in this series since mfing Morrowind??"In conclusion; Monster Hunter World is a great game and if you still need to hear someone tell you that it's worth it to buy it on PC in 2022, then let me be the first to welcome you to owning a PC.  I know, it's probably your first and I'm very excited for you and all of the mods you're going to try to install in Skyrim and Fallout 4, because lets be honest that's the real reason you got a PC.  Don't even deny it, you're just lying to yourself, and there's nothing to be ashamed about.  Now go watch some MXR and download all the best mods and play the "I'm going to mod the absolute ♥♥♥♥ out of this game just to play it for 2 hours and get bored" game and then come back to this review, mark it helpful, and then buy and play MHW.  Don't forget to use your SOS flare when you can, even if you fail a few times because of randoms you can learn a lot by paying attention to what seasoned players do, a lot of us have been around since the first game.

author: Lolo
review: As someone who's originally played Monster Hunter in the psp (Freedom 2, Unite and Portable 3rd), Monster Hunter World was a breath of fresh air. With the maps loaded for the whole hunt, to the smoothness of the hunter and monsters, and finally the new mechanics introduced like the scoutflies, slinger pods and clutch claw. I enjoyed a lot of these new features, but am also glad that they were able to bring back and mix the old mechanics with the new. I also enjoyed the new monsters introduced with the new turf war system, as well as the return of fan favorites (Rip carapaceon tho). I originally played MonHon with my cousins due to the limited connectivity of the psp, but World gave ways to reach people from all over the world, increasing the people you can play with. Always thankful to Capcom for making such a wonderful game and hoping for another installment in the PC realm in the coming years.

author: Eggotistic
review: Monster Hunter World is a good game. With a lively environment, beatiful graphics and intense fights. But enough of the "pros" let me hit you with what most potential buyers are looking for in reviews, the flaws of a masterpiece.To put it plainly:-Lots of grind (if its not ur cup of tea then you probably won't enjoy farming the recquired materials for high level gear)-Story is boring (nothing surprising,heartwarming, or tearjerking, just a girl screaming at you to try and dodge monster attacks when you've already soaked in 50 hrs into fighting living breathing killing machines)-You can get tired of the end game (although there is going to be more stuff to be added, once you've reached around HR 100 or even less, you can get tired since most likely, you've seen it all.)-Bazelguese (find out about it yourself)With all that being said, do still buy the game but keep these points in the back of your head while doing so.

review: The game story is good by its own, also the diffculty of the monsters increase by a reasonable amount but the only con I would say about diffculty is that it counts 2 players as 4 players diffculty which is unfair and i hope it gets fixed

author: CowBaby
review: Wonderful game with a wide variety of playstyles to choose from. The game requires some time to get used to in terms of difficulty, but playing multiplayer helps with that. There is grinding but it's reasonable (Example: you may need to fight a monster more than once for the items it drops for a specific piece of armor/weapon). I highly recommend playing with other people, but it's easy enough to find randoms if you don't have friends who play. The only downside to this game in terms of gameplay would probably be the lack of tutorials. I was lucky to have friends who played previous versions of monster hunter (even the concole version of this one) to guide me through the more intricate mechanics. Even though there are some splashscreens that give you the basics now and then, the information they give you is slim and I can see why some people might have a hard time getting into the game. My best recomendation would be to look up a few beginner guides on youtube or check out the Monster Hunter Wiki.When I bought this on release, there were a variety of issues in terms of performance and connectivity. These issues have been mostly addressed and fixed (I would say 90% of the issues I had at launch are no longer present).

review: The game is awesome.Problem is: it crashes randomly, all the time. And not just for me.And no, my PC is not a potato or whatever. Gtx 1080, 32 gb ram, i7 cpu, you name it... The most delicious pie in the world is useless if you can't eat it - that about sums it up how I feel about this game. If Capcom fixes the NUMEROUS technical issues people are having with the game (lots of ppl have fps issues apparently, the crash issues, connectity stuff etc...) and once I'm able to play like, you know, more than 3 hours without crashing.... then sure, I'll update my review.But right now, with me crashing every 15 to 30 minutes........ my review of this game will remain negative.Revised Review:No technical problems anymore. Not sure whether it was patching or because I upgraded my CPU to one with more threads. Either way, since it's been working MH World was a blast to play that I enjoyed for hundreds of hours and is always worth a revisit. :D

author: Corsica96
review: This is my first Monster Hunter game in the franchise. It's a truly immersive masterpiece, and makes me realize how and why the franchise is such a successful and addictive series. Do yourself a favor and buy this game.

author: Lorenzaru
review: I already owned the game on ps4 and I bought it here to play with a few buds and it's still worth it. If the game ever gets stale, just change your weapon and it's a whole new game. The only complaint I have that I've seen a lot is that the monsters here feel SUPER agile for no reason. Rajang for instance was never so fast in the old world, but it's kind of made up up for with the added mobility that hunters have. Slower weapons sometimes can feel impossible to hunt with, but if you can get past that in iceborne, you'll be fine. Set making is made super accessible and clear to understand in this game too, so you can always have fun theory crafting and experimenting.  I've played through the game twice, and both times my runs were completely different even with the same gameplay loop. If you like games with rewarding combat and mechanics, this is for you! :)

author: Mynx
review: From a singleplayer point of view, this game is a lot of fun, lots of content and really you'll never get bored of it. There's a whole lot to do, whether it's farming, fighting new monsters, playing with friends, getting drunk at the canteen, fashion hunting, fishing,.. you name it. Plenty to do, you can very easily get over a thousand hours out of this game and still not get bored of it.However the online portion of the game...Capcom screwed co-op up. You HAVE to watch the monster cutscene BEFORE being able to send an SOS flare. And before your friends can join they also need to WATCH the cutscenes, which results in someone having to abandon the quest just to play with their friends... huge hassle, not enjoyable.Here are the pros and cons I found in a list.---Pros:- Lots of replay value- Extremely fun with friends- Extremely fun alone- Main story lasts quite a while (took me ~ 43h to finish it, as a veteran of the series)- Great character customization- New monsters will be added via free DLC and game updates, adding to the replay value.- Game is a lot more casual compared to other MH games, making it easier to get into. Also a con for older players, read Cons for explanation.- AMAZING soundtrack.Cons:- Playing with friends is not enjoyable until you reach high rank. Unskippable cutscenes, and impossible to watch together. You must depart alone and then you can SOS flare for your friend(s) to join. This becomes much less of an issue in high rank where there's nearly no cutscenes anymore.- Forced motion blur, DoF, mouse acceleration.- Very CPU intensive. - As of the time of writing, online mode is really unstable - check the EDIT for a temporary fix.- Game is a lot more casual compared to other MH games, making it a bit too easy for people that have been following the series for a while. Gone are the moments where you can't sign up for a quest because you ran out of zenny, where you forget whetstones, potions, took the wrong weapon, etc.. Now all of those issues can quickly be solved, either within an expedition/quest itself or it's simply been removed (entry fee for quests). Also a pro, though overall it doesn't make the game less enjoyable to me, just more care-free.--Now, would I recommend it?Despite its flaws, yes, absolutely. It's a game worth the premium 60€ price tag, and I recommend it vividly, the game is a huge sucess and there's a good reason behind it. No brainer of a purchase.Thank you for reading.

author: »melonbuns«
review: I haven't written many reviews before, but I'll do my best with this one. I've been playing Monster Hunter since MH3 on Wii and man, has it been a journey up to this game. My friend gifted me a copy of this game and I appreciate it very much. I'd been waiting eagerly for the PC port and I am so glad I waited. Personally, I really love this game and honestly, I'm so spoiled by World that I'll find it hard to get back to the older games. I'm quite looking forward to MHGU on Switch at the end of this month, we'll see how well the adjustment goes for me.*I recommend a controller to play this game. I have heard the kb+m controls aren't so fantastic.PROS:+Unlimited pickaxes/bug nets/whetstones? Yes please. Running out of pickaxes or bug nets during a quest always sucked hardcore. I love picking up materials on each quest I go, it makes it so much nicer to have both of these unlimited without taking up an item space. Oh, and whetstones too, though you could argue it wasn't very easy to run out of those anyways.+Fast gathering? Hell yeah. It always felt incredibly slow when you would have to do a gathering quest in the older games (looking at you, MH3). I absolutely love how you can run by something and gather it with just one button press and I adore that when you DO have to do the sometimes tedious (some more than others) gathering quests, it gets delivered without having to go back to the camp. Except, y'know, good old egg quests.+No more paintballs! Once you've studied enough tracks from a monster, your scoutflies will level up and start leading you to where the monster is and they will show up on the map. I absolutely love this improvement, especially for those times I forgot to paintball a monster and completely lost track of where it was. It also saves some time (if your scoutflies are a high enough level, anyways) since you won't have to look for the monster in each area. It's also nice to see where each gathering material is on the map and how long it'll take to replenish itself.+The enviroments are amazing. I love how MHW utilizes most of the things that are in the area surrounding you, such as sporepuffs or poison cups. It's also fun to see big monsters trap themselves in vine traps from trees they knock down or just hiding in a bush and watching a couple of them duke it out with each other. I love the interaction that each monster has with each other. Instead of just auto aggroing the player (most times anyways), they start a turf war until one runs off  in shame.+MHW is very beginner friendly compared to the old titles. I feel as if this game is much easier for a new player to get into seeing as how different it is from the older formula. My first time playing a MH title was not a kind one, but I learned to love it as I kept playing. Now, I'm enjoying a game that I love with a new style with my friends who haven't played the titles before this one.+PETS. You can collect pets to decorate your room. Who in their right mind doesn't love collecting cute, cool, or interesting animals to spice up a place?+POOGIE PETS IN HD. Praise be to Poogie.+Weapon changes. I feel like the weapons have changed at least a little bit from what I've seen of them in the old games. I main switch axe and have for quite a while now, and I love love LOVE the combos! I also really like the design of some of the weapons (some better than others, of course..)+Layered armor. Whaaaat? I think its a really neat addition to the game and it may possibly bring fashion hunting to a new light. I hope to see a few more layered armor sets, I like the samurai one from the deluxe edition, but I like having variety, too.+Palicos are great in this game! In the previous titles, there was an enthusiasm system for your palicos. The lower their enthusiasm, the less likely they will be to fight. There also used to be different classes/specializations of palicos and they would have certain monsters or duties they would do (i.e. fighting, large monsters only, support bias, etc). At the beginning of the game when you first get your palico, it has a gadget called Vigorwasp spray that heals you reliably so (at least, in my experience). There are times where they pull a Donald Duck move from Kingdom Hearts and heal you after you've already used a potion. There are different palico gadgets that you get through the game, mainly from optional quests, so ultimately you decide exactly what you want your palico to do. Also, most the armor for them is just so freakin' cute. Capcom is really after my heart with this game.+NO LOADING TIMES BETWEEN AREAS. FINALLY, it really broke immersion in the previous titles how there was always a short loading screen between each area, but it was useful for when you wanted to get away from monsters to heal or.. do whatever you need to do, really. Though just because there aren't loading screens between areas in this game, you can still either hide in bushes (your screen will indicate when you're hiding with a kind of black border? I'm not too sure how to describe it so well, but you'll know when you see it). Either that or you could use the Ghillie Mantle (which you get pretty early on) to basically become 'invisible' to monsters until you attack or the mantle runs out of time. Ghillie Mantle is VERY convenient for the egg quests.+Free content. There are a couple of event quests that come out at specified times (schedule here:  and from what I've read from previous posts from Capcom, some of these events come with special materials to make rare layered armor sets. Of course, the upcoming events aren't as cool as the ones out for consoles, but that's mostly because the PC port just came out and I am positive the cooler quests will come later down the line.CONS-Some of the settings interfere with the FPS from the get-go. For better performance, I recommend turning off volume rendering and playing in borderless windowed mode. I'm not actually sure if there are any other settings that should be turned off, so if you know any I don't, please let me know!-The main story is kind of bland in my opinion. Traveling to a new land when suddenly OH NO an ELDER DRAGON APPEARS TO BE GOING TO THE NEW WORLD!? We have to FIND IT and CAPTURE IT and then RESEARCH IT! It's personally not my favorite, but I haven't finished the story all the way through, so I'll update after I've done so.-At the moment, multiplayer doesn't seem to work too well. You also have to disband your group after each quest in order to go back to the hub.-Remember the monster turf wars? Yeah, sometimes those get a little bit annoying. Though its really fun to watch another monster get beat down, it can drag on for a little bit too long when I'm just trying to farm or end the quest.-Sometimes fights make your FPS crash hard, but I suppose that's what happens with most games when too much is going on all at once.-If grinding for materials isn't something you enjoy, I wouldn't recommend this game. Personally I like the grind, but I understand that not everyone enjoys the time (and sometimes frustration) that goes into it.-If you're looking for a hack and slash game, this definitely is not it. The combat is rather slow but incredibly rewarding once you've learned a monster's patterns, when to dodge, and when to use your combos. Though, combat speed varies with whatever weapon you use (i.e. dual blades are faster than hammer).-No Sophia AKA Guildmarm from MH4U. I miss being called doodle.-Event quests are no longer permanently in your quest list. In older games when you downloaded a special/event quest, you could do it whenever you want. For MHW, the event quests are only around for a specified amount of time but I believe they do come back around.Overall, I've had a blast playing this new entry in the Monster Hunter series and I look forward to the future. I'd really like to see everything Capcom has in store for the next games.

author: L-laine
review: An amazing monster bashing time with a so so story. The base games story is OK but nothing to write home about. From start to finish you'll more than likely not pay too much attention to it anyway like I did. Where this games shines is the atmosphere and combat which are all A+ material.Too bad that the console and pc disconnect between content release is such a pain in the butt. Seriously CAPCOM how are you gonna release an expansion for the game on console then make pc players wait OVER HALF A YEAR TO GET THE SAME CONTENT??!!! (AKA ICEBORNE)I recommend the game for gameplay and visuals alone but don't be surprised when you don't get newer content for over half a year or even longer despite console players already having it.8/10 You should try it.

author: Kottery
review: Iceborne edit:Still fun. I saw a lot of mention about bad performance since the Iceborne expansion, but as far as I can tell it has been fixed as the game has been running perfectly fine for me. The clutch claw addition is really badass and fun to use and the new attacks for the various weapons are great. I'm particularly fond of the [Any attack] > slinger fire > True Charged Slash for greatsword combined with the increased damage from the second hit of that attack if you connect with the initial hit. It's so good that I "main" greatsword now when I had barely touched it during my time playing the base game.Something about the game overall that's come to bother me is the weapon appearances, however. Looooootta recolors/"bone weapon with [Monster] bits slapped on". Having been playing MHGU on Switch recently this became even more apparent. It's obviously not a deal-breaker cause the game is still incredible and, IMO, the best entry point into the Monster Hunter series, but it's definitely a glaring issue with the game.______________________________________________________Base game review from around the PC version's release:Combined with my time on PS4 earlier this year I've got ~100 hours in, which still isn't much by Monster Hunter standards, but E H.MHW is damn fun and honestly makes it really hard to go back to MH3U and Generations with the amount of QoL improvements that were made in this installment. I remember seeing people complain about connectivity issues with the PC port around release, but I've only gotten a single connection problem and that was when I was just AFK in the base so I unno musta been fixed. Aside from that single thing that didn't really affect me at all it's been a flawless port...if you just use a controller. K&B controls just don't feel right even when you customize keybindings. Luckily it feels really good with a controller and that's coming from someone that has spent 90% of their time in MHW using the heavy bowgun and bow so, ya know, relatively accurate aiming is needed.Good gameGood portJust use a controller

author: I COOKA DA PIZZA
review: Amazing game,but prepare for connection issues. This is by far my favorite monster hunter game in the series, and is a great starting point for anyone on the fence about trying it for the first time, however be aware that the game is EXTERMELY CPU heavy and there are numerous connection issues bogging down an otherwise amazing experience. Thumbs up for amazing gameplay and monster design, but just be aware that you may have problems.EDIT: In light of recent review scores,I thought it important to note that while the game in it's current state is not at all what a AAA high profile release should be by any means, I also do not believe it to be indicitive of the overall quality of the game. It needs work, yes, but it is by no means as bad as the score makes it look. Bad, yes, but not THAT bad.

author: Nctosa
review: If you are a fan of the franchise you already know what this game is about. I wasn't, till this one so I will write my review as a person who have played a Monster Hunter game for the first time.TL;DR If you are an MMORPG lover, who also enjoy raids with friends or grinding and leveling up your character and kill endless bosses and mobs alone, this game is for you (I highly recommend playing multiplayer though) The game basically is boss fight after boss fight in every quest, enemy variations are great and combat mechanics are not simple to learn yet not impossible and you'll definitely have fun while doing so. Though I'd say don't expect a mind blowing story cause you won't find it in this game, the game is not about the story anyways. It's about hunting monsters and it does what it supposed to do very well.Graphics are good but I should warn you though, you definitely need a good PC, otherwise you won't get a good framerate, or you'll end up playing the game with potato graphics cause even though the graphics are great and smooth in most occasions it's not really that succesfully optimized for older systems so even medium graphic settings looks very bad.Audio is nice and fitting, soundtrack does work very well with the game, which is all I need from a game soundtrack anyways. (Though when a game has a soundtrack that can be considered a masterpiece I never complain obviously)I played it with both controller and keyboard and since this game heavily depends on weapon (of your choice - there is a good weapon selection in game which is a plus) combos, I'd say it's way better and comfortable with a controller. But that doesn't necessarily mean that it was badly optimized for keyboard users, it's doable. It's up to your preferences I guess.And last of all, grinding is a real thing in this game, you'll end up grinding for supplies, killing endless amount of monsters and if you find grinding in games intolerable you'd end up hating this, be aware of this before you buy it.TL;DR ended :) Over all I really enjoy this game, it's challenging, it's fun and it's well worth it's price.

review: The game is awesome. Nothing much to add there. As a Monster hunter fan it is everything I ever hoped for. If you think the trailer is awesome, go buy it and enjoy it.It bums me out that most of the negative reviews regard the lack of options or similar stuff, which doesn't make the whole game bad imo. In a system where only "thumbs up" and "thumbs down" exist, this game definitely deserves an upvote, even if you're mad about the lack of an FOV slider or something.

author: Syke_low
review: I love this game. It runs very smoothly with 3+ giant dinosaurs on one screen and 3 other players. I think I may be going insane though because people seem to be having a terrible experience. So my specs:AMD Ryzen 7 1700xMsi GTX 1070ti16gb RamI'm a little peeved I cant run 2k resolution with my 21:9 monitor but the 1080p frame stretch looks good enough. I've played 10 hours of this game in 2 days and I can't wait to dive back in. Its like Shadow of the Colossus and Dark Souls melded to form gameplay candy, ripe for the picking.

author: RelativelyFine
review: I never knew how stingy steam could get. All the negative reviews, Every One of Them, are complaining about the amount of bugs the game has. Isn't that expected from such a large MMORPG port in the first few weeks? Besides, games these days are only getting larger and more complex, ports are getting harder to do and with a game of this size and complexity, both major and minor bugs are bound to appear. People don't seem to understand that.None of these negatives are commenting on gameplay. Without a doubt, if you are willing to wait for the bugs to be ironed out, the game is an amazing experience, which should be apparent from the initial console release.

author: ClouD
review: if you're having problems running/even playing MH:W, go and download Dauntless in the mean time, it's pretty much the same game but simpler and free.PS; AMD FX X100 CPU's apparently can't run the game, at all. There's no ultrawide support, and if you can run the game but getting bad FPS, turn "Volume Rendering Quality" down or off, it's a heavy hitter to your FPS.That said, my PC (specs are on my profile under my bio thing, way over recommended) is running the game perfectly fine in all areas of the game at highest settings, everything turned on, 1080p, same with 1440p, haven't tried 4k yet.Game is okay and from what i've met of the community they're pretty nice normally, it's definitely a better game to play with people than on your own though.

review: It's a gear based grinding game, but if you are into those, this is one of the best. Gorgeous environments and creature designs, fun combat, loads of character customization.Expansion is massive and adds a ton of fun content. 9/10

author: Concerned Black Father
review: Probably played over 2000 hours of this in my adolescence and I must say this game definitely does not feel like a let down in the gameplay department. The story it forces down your throat with custscence that you cannot skip is incredibly annoying but once you get past it your left with a fun monster murd- researching simulation that will provide you endless hours of entertainment. The jewel system, the augmentations, the armors, the colors schemes, and inherent armor skills all come together to create a very deep level of customization that will allow to create your own unique builds or just copy the most meta ones you find on the internet like everyone else. Overall I would say this is pretty fun game with a fairly steep but rewarding learning curve.

author: PaintLegz
review: Monster Hunter is a very unique gameplay experience due to the fact that you are basically just doing boss fight after boss fight. There is a bit of a steep learning curve, but it is very satisfying as you become more skilled. The core gameplay loop once you finish the main story is similar to warframe; pick cool gear and farm for it, which you can sink a lot of time in to if that is the kind of end game you enjoy. This game is much better if you have a group of friends to play with.

author: Kung Fu Kenny
review: This game as any Monster Hunter game will do; is a time sink which you will enjoy. The grind doesn't feel reptitvie and boring unlike *COUGH* Destiny *COUGH. The game isn't perfect as there are issues like the complete absence of any sort of lip sync of characters with their audio respectively and the game can be quite overwhemly with the tutorials and potential stuff you can do, so this might put off some new comers such as me, however if you look past this you can easily see yourself playing over 100+ hours in this game which is well worth the money.Now about the multiplayer, it isn't as easy to play the inital story mode with your mates as  you both have to watch the cutscences seperately which is kind of annoying and you cant see other hunters in the hub area apart in the gathering which is a small section of the hub.The PC port is really poor and consume alot of pc resources to not even match the XBOX ONE X visually. Hopefully Capcom can patch this mess.Pushing past these small faults I can wholeheartedly recommend this without any doubt.

author: Arvenide
review: + Beautiful and unique places+ Challenging combat that requires tactics on different monsters+ 14 weapons type to choose from and each monster gives their own specialities+ A lot of equipments to choose, which can make a lot of unique builds + Longsword + NO MICROTRANSACTION= Story is not great, but not bad either- Git gud- RNGsus can be a pain in the ass

author: Pocheesi
review: This game is absolutely amazing in so many ways. The graphics are gorgeous and everything looks so seamless. The combat is fun and challenging at times. Though there aren't many monsters included in this game (A whole lot less than other MH titles) the variety is still there and it never feels like you're fighting the same monster all the time. The many quality of life changes added to this game have made it very enjoyable to hunt big nasty creatures for new and old hunters alike!

author: NotReallyMyName
review: Game is not for everyone, there is quite a lot of grind, frustrations, ragequits and hunting, yes, just like the title implies, monsters, or animals, or whatever you might want to label the creatures in game. There are network errorrs (there is an unofficial solution though), there were occasional crashes, maybe still are. These are cons, and I understand why people might dislike/hate this game because of this, maybe also the 14 weapon types that are hard to get along with initially, and mastering them might be even harder, as there are a few combos that you can only get through trial and error (or by watching/reading guides). That's why if you're too lazy to spend 5-30 minutes of searching for monsters, another half an hour to learn the way of a [insert weapon type here], getting killed (or carted), and just want to get it all, then forget about this and go play some shooters on easiest difficulty to chill after a hard day.Now with bad stuff mostly over, ask yourself, do you enjoy games with open world? Do you like hunting, skinning, slaughtering away innocent monsters, stealing eggs, mining ores, rummaging through bonepiles, gathering herbs and mushrooms, running through fields in hope to capture another rare animal and let it loose in your cramped quarters, eating, drinking, fishing, and giving sausages to your pet? (If last part makes you smile, congrats, you're pervert.) If so, congrats, you just have to come aboard a ship, get yourself a chicken, mead and a weapon of choice before you get into troubles. Also customize your character, your bipedal cat sidekick, and go on hunting. There will be challenges, there will be some frustrations, you'll hate any weapon you get your hands on for first couple of hunts, you'll hate big guys for being too strong for you, you'll hate the waklings for grabbing a bite out of you, you'll hate when big guys limp away, and you'll love to finally skin the bastards after an hour of hunt. Also grab a joystick if you're going melee, keyboard and mouse are fine for ranged.You might hate the multiplayer in this game though.
