review: Good game

author: Nishmo
review: A pulse-pounding action game based around fighting large monsters and gathering their materials so that you can craft stronger weapons and better gear so that you are able to take on even tougher monsters! The amount of adrenaline that rushes through your veins when trying to topple a monster that may be out of your league creates an artificial "fight or flight response" that I just haven't felt so purely in a video game before.Gathering resources can be a pain, but when you're all ready and go up against that next monster, you feel absolutely pumped and even when you get your butt kicked, you're right back into the fray. That's the best part about Monster Hunter: You can lose over and over again but the moment you get into the groove of the fight, you feel like a complete monster of your own: learning the monster's movements, getting that gut feeling of when the monster is close to death, and having an unexpected second monster coming in to completely change all of that as you try to juggle two monsters at once.With fourteen different weapons to try out, you can really experiment with what weapon type works the best for you whether it be the hammer to bonk the monster into submission, the hunting horn to play sweet music in the ear of your foe, the longsword to weeaboo your path to victory in style, or the bowguns to pew pew the monster to death. Added on top of this is your Palico, your feline companion that you customize alongside your main character who you can eventually equip with different support gear depending on what feral feline group you've managed to make allies of that can absolutely save you: the earliest and arguably the most useful early on of which is the Vigorwasp, which allows you to heal yourself instantly without using a potion!Monster Hunter: World is a game of boss battle after boss battle. You're constantly going up against monsters that could easily become the bane of your existence and you will likely feel the need to go back and teach them who's boss once you've upped your gear far above what they can handle. But once you reach the end and you've faced the monster to end all monsters and you've managed to come out on top, there is no game in the world that can top that level of satisfaction and euphoria quite like Monster Hunter: World can.

author: Sirm
review: I've been playing Monster Hunter since the first western release on PS2 with the wonders of the attack stick controls. After watching this series grow over the years, i'm honestly impressed that they have made it to this point with the game. A few years ago i never would have thought they would have been able to produce a MH game with such detailed maps and fluid controls(compared to other MH Titles). when they announced the game i was ecstatic. If this is the new direction for the Monster Hunter series, I fully support their decision. So many quality of life changes that it almost brings a tear to my eye, such as:     being able to move while drinking potions and consumables     actually being able to dodge while carrying wyvern/herbivour eggs     changing gear while out in the field     being able to eat a meal out in the field for passive buffs(no longer have to worry about forgetting before a big hunt)     no Blademaster and Gunner armor sets and the list goes onone of my favorite things about the amount of detail that they put into each area is the endemic life and how you can capture them to display in your home. it truly brings out the Pokemon complex in me, i always keep my net equiped just in case i run into a new little creature to add to my collectionnow i know most other hunters out there that have played previous MH games have been showing their disdain for the lack of G rank, though i know, as with previous monster hunter games, they will release G rank for monster hunter world, and since it is on pc, xbone, and ps4 they will most likely do it as expansion that you can purchase instead of what they previously had to do which was rereleasing the as an Ultimate or G version.my review for MHW may be a little biased but that is because i had the pleasure to watch this series grow into the wonderful world it has become over the year, but if you truly wish to appreciate and enjoy this game, i strongly reccomend finding your way to the  program which was officially recognized by Capcom before the initial release on consolesthe game may have some optimization issues but overall they did a decent job for their first main series Monster Hunter release on PCtldr;     Great Game, can't wait to see what comes next in the main series

author: DefaultNPC
review: [Quick summary as I feel pretty passionate about this and dont want to waste the time of people that wouldn't care.  Amazing game,  first quality port in years,  incredibly well optimized for how pretty it looks, occasional stutter when 1 specific dragon spams the screen. Online connectivity issues that cause a DC once every 7 hunts or so. A valve issue that's being worked on. Best title this year. Easily.]Let me start this off with the following statement:I don't get surprised by many things in life.Yet somehow almost every aspect of this game from development to launch has surprised the hell out of me.When capcom said that they'd be releasing this title for PC, I expected it far down the line. Monster hunters don't get released soon enough. August release wasn't even considered for me. While being released, there were dozens of people making such bold statements as: "This uses Denuvo? I'm not buying" which surprised the hell out of me again. Some passionate people even posted negative reviews for the use of denuvo. That's got to be band wagon,  right? As an adult willing to support the franchise it surprisingly doesn't matter to me if the game is DRM or not. I imagine the category of people complaining would like to see a game non DRM? With literally tens of thousands that just downloaded the game free? I'll never understand why this was ever anyone's concern or problem of you're enjoying the game as designed.Upon release, the game was incredible.  It ran perfectly smooth on high settings with my 1060, and has consistently shocked me over how incredible the game looks without tanking my medium end machine. There are reviews of people well below reasonable setups complaining of how demanding the game is.  Sorry? I feel for you. But this game? Amazing port.  I doubt making a review about performance on a shoddy machine is a legitimate review.The online, if it were a but more consistent,  would be game changing.  The entire story can be completed with friends. They can drop in at any time and help the progress of any active quest using either SOS flares, or manual joining via quest board. I haven't played a game where playing with others was that easy. Speaking of playing with others leads me to my next point. Online is unreliable.  The GAME, which I imagine anyone bothering to right a review would base their opinion on, is stellar.  The connectivity issue that VALVE(not sure why you're writing negatively about Capcom and not them.) causes is annoying,  sure. Bur enough to say that it's a bad game? Ridiculous.  Especially considering that "Lukeda14yroldSasukemain"s negative review of the game blaming connectivity issues has invested well over 100 hours into a "bad" game.*Pizza is incredible.  Sometimes I can't share it with my friends because the uber eats guy dropped their portions while delivering.  Because of this the pizza suddenly tastes horrible.  I'll write a negative yelp review and never site the driver. Now excuse me while I order the same pizza for 150 hours. Why? Because it's delicious.  Bad pizza though.*That sounds brain dead to me. Yet it's literally 90% of the negative reviews. Then there's the kid with way too much money that's upset that running the game on three 4k screens at once on ultra settings while bit coin mining in the back ground only nets 46 fps instead of 60. I can kind of understand this negative review. You paid a lot of money for your set up. But the game looks and runs smoother than its console counterpart so I'm not sure what you want. I also imagine that adults having this issue are just fine with not running the game ultra on three monitors. Only entitled brats could bother stating: "My computer can't run this game in "Real71f3p". As a gamer looking for a positive gaming experience,  I don't consider that an actual issue.Dude who wrote the review about investing 60 hours to have his save deleted? He's legit. I'll leave him be. That's a pretty honest reason to be upset.All in all this game is insane. Fantastic port, fantastic content, attention to detail is overwhelming at times,  and it all runs so damn well. I saw a trail of ants carrying a monster part. I saw the little iguana raptors flee once enough of them are picked off. I see them get brave when their primary predator has been incapacitated.  There's pet collection, Quest collection, a complex skill structure that makes hyper interesting builds,  and a shocking amount of free upcoming content. Each weapon is like playing a new game. Each habituated is lush, interesting, unique, and an absolute joy to traverse. At no point do I feel confined to a small premade space, or cursed to wander endlessly through an open world environment. The quality of life choices in this game are enough to exceed any expectations I could've had for It.,And the pet system? You can catch ants. You can put your pets(The ants) in your home.  You can literally come home to a floor full of ants.  That's crazy.  If something gets game of the year over this, I'm going to be very upset.Monster hunter has always been niche.  I'm glad it now has it's time in the public eye. Just wish so many confused people understood the point if reviewing a GAME.

author: Shadowth117
review: Look, at its core, this is a fantastic game and the combat feels great and polished. BUT and I mean a massive BUT, there are so many dumb little problems with the online that it's ridiculous. Major issues-Alt tabbing sometimes kicks you offline-You can randomly be sent offline-Guilds were removed and replaced with Steam Groups. Would be fine, however the option to host a server with ONLY your Group members able to join was REMOVED from the Steam version mind-bogglingly enough. -You are unable to set basic join restrictions such as "Friends Only". Yes, believe it or not, this is a problem in 2018 for this game.-For people with seemingly less than 12 logical cores (typical i7 processor), there is microlag due to the developers trying to use more processing threads than they should. This is mostly fixed by a steam community mod called "Special K" atm, but still a developer fault. Minor issues-You cannot join friends who are in a quest where they have new cutscenes to still see.-Parties are locked into P2P servers called "sessions" meaning joining your friends consists of joining their "session", THEN joining their party.-Even in the same session, you can't see each other in the main lobbies. You have to be in a specific lobby area to see other players at all.All in all, this is definitely a must buy for Monster Hunter fans and a great game, but it's hampered by a lot of dumb issues that we thought the long wait for a pc release would fix. I like this game a lot, but please....CAPCOM, fix your game! It's a horrible online experience right now.

author: bigthrilla
review: I'll never understand why someone would give a negative review to a game they mostly enjoyed, but has a couple of graphical or occasional connection flaws. If you're considering buying this game and are hesitant because of all the negative reviews:1) Note that virtually all of the connection issues and many graphical issues have been fixed.2) Look at the hours played by people giving very salty reviews about a few FPS drops, the lack of editing of a certain graphics option, or complaining that the mouse control is too sticky (use a controller people!). It seems a lot of people refused to wait a few weeks for these problems to be fixed, and haven't changed their reviews to positive. The game itself is a really rewarding and addictive action RPG that is based on hunting monsters in different environments, by mastersing one (or several) of 14 different weapon types, beating up the monster alone or with a few fellow hunters, taking it's parts, crafting new weapons and armor, so that you can hunt stronger monsters. If you care about story, or exploring a vast open world with cool characters you won't find it here. Monster Hunter certainly has beautiful environments that are fun to explore, but it's based on fun and complicated combat with many weapons, and essentially doing many differnt kinds of thrilling boss fights with monsters to craft gear. Note that these fights will usually be 20 minutes long. This may seem like too much, but remember these fights are the whole point of this game. One complaint that I have, and this may be partially my fault since the game has only been out for 1.5 months on PC, is that once you finish the main story and do 30 hours or so of post game content, while still fun, it gets fairly repetitive. This is due to the fact that there are "only" about 30 something monsters, and the new ones roll will out slowly (monthly or less frequently). 100 hours or so of gameplay may seem like a lot, but for a non-story focused multiplayer game that the devs promise to support with content for years you expect more. Since this is the first AAA MH game for PC they have to remake all the skeletons, skins and attack patterns for the monsters in this environment, so I guess that can take a long time. I think the game will truly be fleshed out with content updates, but for now, expect about ~100 hours of gameplay that's not too repetitive, is addicitng and challenging.

author: Scaleeth
review: I've always enjoyed Monster Hunter games, and I think this one is my favorite so far! Because it's on PC, I was able to introduce the Monster Hunter series to friends who had never played the previous games (and probably never would have, since they don't really play on consoles). It runs great on my computer, the combat is a lot of fun, and the skill curve is ; You'll get noticably better at the game over time, and it feels great to down a monster you had been having trouble with previously.The $60 price tag may not be for everyone, especially if they're on the fence about whether or not they'd like the game. I think it's definitely worth picking up while it's on sale, though.

author: trashchan
review: game has done a 180 since release and has gotten better many times. i come back to this game many times and hunt monsters with the boys. very good game------everything below this line is a review of when the game initially released on pc------i love this game 10/10network connection 1/10what i did to fix it: - port forwarded- turned off firewall (even though i whitelisted my whole (E:). all games installed on e drive)- setting my steam friends & chat as offline- joining and hosting sessions using session id only and not joining on friends- windowed borderless (because fullscreen alt tabbing crashes the game and d/c everyone from the session)if everyone did this, it would fix the issue. the problem is that this is an issue in the first placewould i recommend the game to a friend? only if they're willing to do everything i did above yeah, otherwise no

author: MaskedMouse
review: Fun and addicting game. Recommended to play together with friends and do the story solo!Pros:- Feels like an adventure!- Fun to farm, doesn't feel like a chore- Moderate / good difficulty scaling, sometimes difficulty spikes- Feels like an achievement hunting the more difficult monsters successfully- Good intro / tutorial information- Fun to play with friends, advisable to play the storyline solo- Overall a good port, had no crashes whatsoever. No memory leaks.- Can be played casually and hardcore!Cons:- Settings require a little tweaking so that the FPS doesn't drop. Audio to surround sound and headset.Personal opinion Cons:- Somewhat limited character creation customization, a lot of options feel the same. Couldn't really find a face for the character that I liked.- Max 4 player co-op, sometimes we have 5 players meaning someone has to sit one out. Would've liked to see bigger maps for 5 or 6 players. But I can understand for performance and balance that 4 is a maximum.- Server issues at release, but they're working on a fix! It made me fail a hunt somewhere at the beginning of the game. Also occured just about starting an arena quest with friends, we got seperated from eachother at the start due to this issue. Had quite a difficult fight alone.- Rewards for investigation quests feel a bit off. 10k for an easy vespoid quest that takes 3 min, compared to a hunt quest that gives the same amount but takes a lot longer to complete, like 15~30 minutes. When the quest is done with multiple ppl it splits the money reward making the quest reward even less attractive. Some quests have low time and low reward whereas others have high time and high reward. Just feels off.- Constantly spams Steam Friends that they play the game, a bug that requires to be fixed soon.What I like about monster hunter world is that the farm required doesn't feel like a chore to do. It's actually fun to farm.It has moderate / good difficulty scaling, things feel like an achievement and not being all that easy to complete at times. Which is nice.It is sad to see ppl complaining about either Denuvo, FPS or Server issues.Denuvo doesn't kill performance of MHW, I don't even notice it is in there.FPS is fine as long as you tweak your settings, there are so many hardware configurations for PC that creating a setting that works for everyone is just difficult. I've set Volume Rendering Quality to variable, the overall suggestion is turning this off to increase performance. Yes the game is CPU intensive, got an i7 6700k @ 4.5 GHz overclocked to support it. Do I have FPS drops? pretty much none.Server issues are just starting issues, probably a too high load for the servers. They're working on a fix though, sure it sucks when it happens but it does not make the game not recommendable like a lot of people do. They're going to fix it.
